11: 
12:     Upon the midlands now the industrious muse doth fall,
13:     The shires which we the heart of England well may call.
14: 
15:         *       *       *       *       *
16: 
17:     My native country thou, which so brave spirits hast bred,
18:     If there be virtues yet remaining in the earth,
19:     Or any good of thine thou bred'st into my birth,
20:     Accept it as thine own, whilst now I sing of thee,
21:     Of all thy later brood the unworthiest though I be.
22: 
23:                                            --DRAYTON; _Polyolbion_.

36: FELIX HOLT, THE RADICAL.
37: 
38: 
39: 
40: 
41: INTRODUCTION.
42: 
43: 
44: Five-and-thirty years ago the glory had not yet departed from the old
45: coach roads: the great roadside inns were still brilliant with
46: well-polished tankards, the smiling glances of pretty barmaids, and the
47: repartees of jocose hostlers; the mail still announced itself by the
48: merry notes of the horn; the hedge-cutter or the rick-thatcher might
49: still know the exact hour by the unfailing yet otherwise meteoric
50: apparition of the pea-green Tally-ho or the yellow Independent; and
51: elderly gentlemen in pony-chaises, quartering nervously to make way for
52: the rolling, swinging swiftness, had not ceased to remark that times
53: were finely changed since they used to see the pack-horses and hear the
54: tinkling of their bells on this very highway.
55: 
56: In those days there were pocket boroughs, a Birmingham unrepresented in
57: Parliament and compelled to make strong representations out of it,
58: unrepealed corn-laws, three-and-sixpenny letters, a brawny and
59: many-breeding pauperism, and other departed evils; but there were some
60: pleasant things, too, which have also departed. _Non omnia grandior ætas
61: quæ fugiamus habet_, says the wise goddess: you have not the best of it
62: in all things, O youngsters! the elderly man has his enviable memories,
63: and not the least of them is the memory of a long journey in mid-spring
64: or autumn on the outside of a stage coach. Posterity may be shot, like a
65: bullet through a tube, by atmospheric pressure, from Winchester to
66: Newcastle: that is a fine result to have among our hopes; but the slow,
67: old fashioned way of getting from one end of our country to the other is
68: the better thing to have in the memory. The tube-journey can never lend
69: much to picture and narrative; it is as barren as an exclamatory O!
70: Whereas, the happy outside passenger, seated on the box from the dawn to
71: the gloaming, gathered enough stories of English life, enough of English
72: labors in town and country, enough aspects of earth and sky, to make
73: episodes for a modern Odyssey. Suppose only that his journey took him
74: through that central plain, watered at one extremity by the Avon, at the
75: other by the Trent. As the morning silvered the meadows with their long
76: lines of bushy willows marking the water-courses, or burnished the
77: golden corn-ricks clustered near the long roofs of some midland
78: homestead, he saw the full-uddered cows driven from their pasture to the
79: early milking. Perhaps it was the shepherd, head-servant of the farm,
80: who drove them, his sheep-dog following with a heedless, unofficial air,
81: as of a beadle in undress. The shepherd, with a slow and slouching walk,
82: timed by the walk of grazing beasts, moved aside, as if unwillingly,
83: throwing out a monosyllabic hint to his cattle; his glance, accustomed
84: to rest on things very near the earth, seemed to lift itself with
85: difficulty to the coachman. Mail or stage coach for him belonged to the
86: mysterious distant system of things called "Gover'ment," which, whatever
87: it might be, was no business of his, any more than the most outlying
88: nebula or the coal-sacks of the southern hemisphere: his solar system
89: was the parish; the master's temper and the casualties of lambing-time
90: were his region of storms. He cut his bread and bacon with his
91: pocket-knife, and felt no bitterness except in the matter of pauper
92: laborers and the bad-luck that sent contrarious seasons and the
93: sheep-rot. He and his cows were soon left behind, and the homestead,
94: too, with its pond overhung by elder-trees, its untidy kitchen-garden
95: and cone-shaped yew-tree arbor. But everywhere the bushy hedgerows
96: wasted the land with their straggling beauty, shrouded the grassy
97: borders of the pastures with catkined hazels, and tossed their long
98: blackberry branches on the corn-fields. Perhaps they were white with
99: May, or starred with pale pink dog-roses; perhaps the urchins were
100: already nutting among them, or gathering the plenteous crabs. It was
101: worth the journey only to see those hedgerows, the liberal homes of
102: unmarketable beauty--of the purple blossomed, ruby-berried nightshade,
103: of the wild convolvulus climbing and spreading in tendriled strength
104: till it made a great curtain of pale-green hearts and white trumpets, of
105: the many-tubed honey-suckle which, in its most delicate fragrance, hid a
106: charm more subtle and penetrating than beauty. Even if it were winter,
107: the hedgerows showed their coral, the scarlet haws, the deep-crimson
108: hips, with lingering brown leaves to make a resting-place for the jewels
109: of the hoar-frost. Such hedgerows were often as tall as the laborers'
110: cottages dotted along the lanes, or clustered into a small hamlet, their
111: little dingy windows telling, like thick-filmed eyes, of nothing but the
112: darkness within. The passenger on the coach-box, bowled along above
113: such a hamlet, saw chiefly the roofs of it: probably it turned its back
114: on the road, and seemed to lie away from everything but its own patch of
115: earth and sky, away from the parish church by long fields and green
116: lanes, away from all intercourse except that of tramps. If its face
117: could be seen, it was most likely dirty; but the dirt was Protestant
118: dirt, and the big, bold, gin-breathing tramps were Protestant tramps.
119: There was no sign of superstition near, no crucifix or image to indicate
120: a misguided reverence: the inhabitants were probably so free from
121: superstition that they were in much less awe of the parson than of the
122: overseer. Yet they were saved from the excess of Protestantism by not
123: knowing how to read, and by the absence of handlooms and mines to be the
124: pioneers of Dissent: they were kept safely in the _via media_ of
125: indifference, and could have registered themselves in the census by a
126: big black mark as members of the Church of England.
127: 
128: But there were trim cheerful villages too, with a neat or handsome
129: parsonage and gray church set in the midst; there was the pleasant
130: tinkle of the blacksmith's anvil, the patient cart horses waiting at his
131: door; the basket-maker peeling his willow wands in the sunshine; the
132: wheelwright putting his last touch to a blue cart with red wheels; here
133: and there a cottage with bright transparent windows showing pots full of
134: blooming balsams or geraniums, and little gardens in front all double
135: daisies or dark wallflowers; at the well, clean and comely women
136: carrying yoked buckets, and toward the free school small Britons
137: dawdling on, and handling their marbles in the pockets of unpatched
138: corduroys adorned with brass buttons. The land around was rich and
139: marly, great corn-stacks stood in the rick-yards--for the rick-burners
140: had not found their way hither; the homesteads were those of rich
141: farmers who paid no rent, or had the rare advantage of a lease, and
142: could afford to keep the corn till prices had risen. The coach would be
143: sure to overtake some of them on their way to their outlying fields or
144: to the market-town, sitting heavily on their well-groomed horses, or
145: weighing down one side of an olive-green gig. They probably thought of
146: the coach with some contempt, as an accommodation for people who had not
147: their own gigs, or who, wanting to travel to London and such distant
148: places, belonged to the trading and less solid part of the nation. The
149: passenger on the box could see that this was the district of protuberant
150: optimists, sure that old England was the best of all possible countries,
151: and that if there were any facts which had not fallen under their own
152: observation, they were facts not worth observing: the district of clean
153: little market-towns without manufactures, of fat livings, an
154: aristocratic clergy, and low poor-rates. But as the day wore on the
155: scene would change: the land would begin to be blackened with coal-pits,
156: the rattle of handlooms to be heard in hamlets and villages. Here were
157: powerful men walking queerly with knees bent outward from squatting in
158: the mine, going home to throw themselves down in their blackened flannel
159: and sleep through the daylight, then rise and spend much of their high
160: wages at the ale-house with their fellows of the Benefit Club; here the
161: pale eager faces of the handloom-weavers, men and women, haggard from
162: sitting up late at night to finish the week's work, hardly begun till
163: the Wednesday. Everywhere the cottages and the small children were
164: dirty, for the languid mothers gave their strength to the loom; pious
165: Dissenting women, perhaps, who took life patiently, and thought that
166: salvation depended chiefly on predestination, and not at all on
167: cleanliness. The gables of Dissenting chapels now made a visible sign of
168: religion, and of a meeting-place to counterbalance the ale-house, even
169: in the hamlets; but if a couple of old termagants were seen tearing each
170: other's caps, it was a safe conclusion that, if they had not received
171: the sacraments of the Church, they had not at least given in to
172: schismatic rites, and were free from the errors of Voluntaryism. The
173: breath of the manufacturing town, which made a cloudy day and a red
174: gloom by night on the horizon, diffused itself over all the surrounding
175: country, filling the air with eager unrest. Here was a population not
176: convinced that old England was as good as possible; here were
177: multitudinous men and women aware that their religion was not exactly
178: the religion of their rulers, who might therefore be better than they
179: were, and who, if better, might alter many things which now made the
180: world perhaps more painful than it need be, and certainly more sinful.
181: Yet there were the gray steeples too, and the churchyards, with their
182: grassy mounds and venerable headstones, sleeping in the sunlight; there
183: were broad fields and homesteads, and fine old woods covering a rising
184: ground, or stretching far by the roadside, allowing only peeps at the
185: park and mansion which they shut in from the working-day world. In these
186: midland districts the traveller passed rapidly from one phase of English
187: life to another: after looking down on a village dingy with coal-dust,
188: noisy with the shaking of looms, he might skirt a parish all of fields,
189: high hedges, and deep rutted lanes; after the coach had rattled over the
190: pavement of a manufacturing town, the scenes of riots and trades-union
191: meetings, it would take him in another ten minutes into a rural region,
192: where the neighborhood of the town was only felt in the advantages of a
193: near market for corn, cheese, and hay, and where men with a considerable
194: banking account were accustomed to say that "they never meddled with
195: politics themselves." The busy scenes of the shuttle and the wheel, of
196: the roaring furnace, of the shaft and the pulley, seemed to make but
197: crowded nests in the midst of the large-spaced, slow-moving life of
198: homesteads and far-away cottages and oak-sheltered parks. Looking at the
199: dwellings scattered amongst the woody flats and the plowed uplands,
200: under the low gray sky which overhung them with an unchanging stillness
201: as if Time itself were pausing, it was easy for the traveller to
202: conceive that town and country had no pulse in common, except where the
203: handlooms made a far-reaching straggling fringe about the great centres
204: of manufacture; that till the agitation about the Catholics in '29,
205: rural Englishmen had hardly known more of Catholics than of the fossil
206: mammals; and that their notion of Reform was a confused combination of
207: rick-burners, trades-unions, Nottingham riots, and in general whatever
208: required the calling out of the yeomanry. It was still easier to see
209: that, for the most part, they resisted the rotation of crops and stood
210: by their fallows: and the coachman would perhaps tell how in one parish
211: an innovating farmer, who talked of Sir Humphrey Davy, had been fairly
212: driven out by popular dislike, as if he had been a confounded Radical;
213: and how, the parson having one Sunday preached from the words, "Break up
214: your fallow-ground," the people thought he had made the text out of his
215: own head, otherwise it would never have come "so pat" on a matter of
216: business; but when they found it in the Bible at home, some said it was
217: an argument for fallows (else why should the Bible mention fallows?),
218: but a few of the weaker sort were shaken, and thought it was an argument
219: that fallows should be done away with, else the Bible would have said,
220: "Let your fallows lie"; and the next morning the parson had a stroke of
221: apoplexy, which, as coincident with a dispute about fallows, so set the
222: parish against the innovating farmer and the rotation of crops, that he
223: could stand his ground no longer, and transferred his lease.
224: 
225: The coachman was an excellent travelling companion and commentator on
226: the landscape: he could tell the names of sites and persons, and explain
227: the meaning of groups, as well as the shade of Virgil in a more
228: memorable journey; he had as many stories about parishes, and the men
229: and women in them, as the Wanderer in the "Excursion," only his style
230: was different. His view of life had originally been genial, such as
231: became a man who was well warmed within and without, and held a position
232: of easy, undisputed authority; but the recent initiation of railways had
233: embittered him: he now, as in a perpetual vision, saw the ruined country
234: strewn with shattered limbs, and regarded Mr. Huskisson's death as a
235: proof of God's anger against Stephenson. "Why, every inn on the road
236: would be shut up!" and at that word the coachman looked before him with
237: the blank gaze of one who had driven his coach to the outermost edge of
238: the universe, and saw his leaders plunging into the abyss. Still he
239: would soon relapse from the high prophetic strain to the familiar one of
240: narrative. He knew whose the land was wherever he drove; what noblemen
241: had half-ruined themselves by gambling; who made handsome returns of
242: rent; and who was at daggers-drawn with his eldest son. He perhaps
243: remembered the fathers of actual baronets, and knew stories of their
244: extravagant or stingy housekeeping; whom they had married, whom they had
245: horsewhipped, whether they were particular about preserving their game,
246: and whether they had had much to do with canal companies. About any
247: actual landed proprietor he could also tell whether he was a Reformer or
248: an Anti-Reformer. That was a distinction which had "turned up" in latter
249: times, and along with it the paradox, very puzzling to the coachman's
250: mind, that there were men of old family and large estate who voted for
251: the Bill. He did not grapple with the paradox; he let it pass, with all
252: the discreetness of an experienced theologian or learned scholiast,
253: preferring to point his whip at some object which could raise no
254: questions.
255: 
256: No such paradox troubled our coachman when, leaving the town of Treby
257: Magna behind him, he drove between the hedges for a mile or so, crossed
258: the queer long bridge over the river Lapp, and then put his horses to a
259: swift gallop up the hill by the low-nestled village of Little Treby,
260: till they were on the fine level road, skirted on one side by grand
261: larches, oaks, and wych elms, which sometimes opened so far as to let
262: the traveller see that there was a park behind them.
263: 
264: How many times in the year, as the coach rolled past the
265: neglected-looking lodges which interrupted the screen of trees, and
266: showed the river winding through a finely-timbered park, had the
267: coachman answered the same questions, or told the same things without
268: being questioned! That?--oh, that was Transome Court, a place there had
269: been a fine sight of lawsuits about. Generations back, the heir of the
270: Transome name had somehow bargained away the estate, and it fell to the
271: Durfeys, very distant connections, who only called themselves Transomes
272: because they had got the estate. But the Durfeys' claim had been
273: disputed over and over again; and the coachman, if he had been asked,
274: would have said, though he might have to fall down dead the next minute,
275: that property didn't always get into the right hands. However, the
276: lawyers had found their luck in it; and people who inherited estates
277: that were lawed about often lived in them as poorly as a mouse in a
278: hollow cheese; and, by what he could make out, that had been the way
279: with these present Durfeys, or Transomes, as they called themselves. As
280: for Mr. Transome, he was as poor, half-witted a fellow as you'd wish to
281: see; but _she_ was master, had come of a high family, and had a
282: spirit--you might see it in her eye and the way she sat her horse. Forty
283: years ago, when she came into this country, they said she was a pictur';
284: but her family was poor, and so she took up with a hatchet-faced fellow
285: like this Transome. And the eldest son had been just such another as his
286: father, only worse--a wild sort of half-natural, who got into bad
287: company. They said his mother hated him and wished him dead; for she'd
288: got another son, quite of a different cut, who had gone to foreign parts
289: when he was a youngster, and she wanted her favorite to be heir. But
290: heir or no heir, Lawyer Jermyn had had _his_ picking out of the estate.
291: Not a door in his big house but what was the finest polished oak, all
292: got off the Transome estate. If anybody liked to believe he paid for it,
293: they were welcome. However, Lawyer Jermyn had sat on that box-seat many
294: and many a time. He had made the wills of most people thereabout. The
295: coachman would not say that Lawyer Jermyn was not the man he would
296: choose to make his own will some day. It was not so well for a lawyer to
297: be over-honest, else he might not be up to other people's tricks. And as
298: for the Transome business, there had been ins and outs in time gone by,
299: so that you couldn't look into it straight backward. At this Mr. Sampson
300: (everybody in North Loamshire knew Sampson's coach) would screw his
301: features into a grimace expressive of entire neutrality, and appear to
302: aim his whip at a particular spot on the horse's flank. If the passenger
303: was curious for further knowledge concerning the Transome affairs,
304: Sampson would shake his head and say there had been fine stories in his
305: time; but he never condescended to state what the stories were. Some
306: attributed this reticence to a wise incredulity, others to a want of
307: memory, others to simple ignorance. But at least Sampson was right in
308: saying that there had been fine stories--meaning, ironically, stories
309: not altogether creditable to the parties concerned.
310: 
311: And such stories often come to be fine in a sense that is not ironical.
312: For there is seldom any wrong-doing which does not carry along with it
313: some downfall of blindly-climbing hopes, some hard entail of suffering,
314: some quickly-satiated desire that survives, with the life in death of
315: old paralytic vice, to see itself cursed by its woeful progeny--some
316: tragic mark of kinship in the one brief life to the far-stretching life
317: that went before, and to the life that is to come after, such as has
318: raised the pity and terror of men ever since they began to discern
319: between will and destiny. But these things are often unknown to the
320: world; for there is much pain that is quite noiseless; and vibrations
321: that make human agonies are often a mere whisper in the roar of hurrying
322: existence. There are glances of hatred that stab and raise no cry of
323: murder; robberies that leave man or woman forever beggared of peace and
324: joy, yet kept secret by the sufferer--committed to no sound except that
325: of low moans in the night, seen in no writing except that made on the
326: face by the slow months of suppressed anguish and early morning tears.
327: Many an inherited sorrow that has marred a life has been breathed into
328: no human ear.
329: 
330: The poets have told us of a dolorous enchanted forest in the under
331: world. The thorn-bushes there, and the thick-barked stems, have human
332: histories hidden in them; the power of unuttered cries dwells in the
333: passionless-seeming branches, and the red warm blood is darkly feeding
334: the quivering nerves of a sleepless memory that watches through all
335: dreams. These things are a parable.
336: 
337: 
338: 
339: 
340: CHAPTER I.
341: 
342:     He left me when the down upon his lip
343:     Lay like the shadow of a hovering kiss.
344:     "Beautiful mother, do not grieve," he said;
345:     "I will be great, and build our fortunes high.
346:     And you shall wear the longest train at court,
347:     And look so queenly, all the lords shall say,
348:     'She is a royal changeling: there is some crown
349:     Lacks the right head, since hers wears naught but braids.'"
350:     O, he is coming now--but I am gray:
351:     And he----
352: 
353: 
354: On the first of September, in the memorable year 1832, some one was
355: expected at Transome Court. As early as two o'clock in the afternoon the
356: aged lodge-keeper had opened the heavy gate, green as the tree trunks
357: were green with nature's powdery paint, deposited year after year.
358: Already in the village of Little Treby, which lay on the side of a steep
359: hill not far off the lodge-gates, the elder matrons sat in their best
360: gowns at the few cottage doors bordering the road, that they might be
361: ready to get up and make their courtesy when a travelling carriage
362: should come in sight; and beyond the village several small boys were
363: stationed on the look-out, intending to run a race to the barn-like old
364: church, where the sexton waited in the belfry ready to set the one bell
365: in joyful agitation just at the right moment.
366: 
367: The old lodge-keeper had opened the gate and left it in the charge of
368: his lame wife, because he was wanted at the Court to sweep away the
369: leaves, and perhaps to help in the stables. For though Transome Court
370: was a large mansion, built in the fashion of Queen Anne's time, with a
371: park and grounds as fine as any to be seen in Loamshire, there were very
372: few servants about it. Especially, it seemed, there must be a lack of
373: gardeners; for, except on the terrace surrounded with a stone parapet in
374: front of the house, where there was a parterre, kept with some neatness,
375: grass had spread itself over the gravel walks, and over all the low
376: mounds once carefully cut as black beds for the shrubs and larger
377: plants. Many of the windows had the shutters closed, and under the grand
378: Scotch fir that stooped toward one corner, the brown fir-needles of many
379: years lay in a small stone balcony in front of two such darkened
380: windows. All round, both near and far, there were grand trees,
381: motionless in the still sunshine, and, like all large motionless things,
382: seemed to add to the stillness. Here and there a leaf fluttered down;
383: petals fell in a silent shower; a heavy moth fluttered by, and, when it
384: settled, seemed to fall wearily; the tiny birds alighted on the walks,
385: and hopped about in perfect tranquillity; even a stray rabbit sat
386: nibbling a leaf that was to its liking, in the middle of a grassy space,
387: with an air that seemed quite impudent in so timid a creature. No sound
388: was to be heard louder than a sleepy hum, and the soft monotony of
389: running water hurrying on to the river that divided the park. Standing
390: on the south or east side of the house, you would never have guessed
391: that an arrival was expected.
392: 
393: But on the west side, where the carriage entrance was, the gates under
394: the stone archway were thrown open; and so was the double door of the
395: entrance-hall, letting in the warm light on the scagliola pillars, the
396: marble statues, and the broad stone staircase, with its matting worn
397: into large holes. And, stronger sign of expectation than all, from one
398: of the doors that surrounded the entrance-hall, there came forth from
399: time to time a lady, who walked lightly over the polished stone floor,
400: and stood on the door-steps and watched and listened. She walked
401: lightly, for her figure was slim and finely formed, though she was
402: between fifty and sixty. She was a tall, proud-looking woman, with
403: abundant gray hair, dark eyes and eyebrows, and a somewhat eagle-like
404: yet not unfeminine face. Her tight-fitting black dress was much worn;
405: the fine lace of her cuffs and collar, and of the small veil that fell
406: backward over her high comb, was visibly mended; but rare jewels flashed
407: on her hands, which lay on her folded black-clad arms like finely-cut
408: onyx cameos.
409: 
410: Meantime Mrs. Transome went to the door-steps, watching and listening in
411: vain. Each time she returned to the same room; it was a moderate-sized
412: comfortable room, with low ebony bookshelves round it, and it formed an
413: ante-room to a large library, of which a glimpse could be seen through
414: an open doorway, partly obstructed by a heavy tapestry curtain drawn on
415: one side. There was a great deal of tarnished gilding and dinginess on
416: the walls and furniture of this smaller room, but the pictures above the
417: bookcases were all of a cheerful kind: portraits in pastel of
418: pearly-skinned ladies with hair-powder, blue ribbons, and low bodices; a
419: splendid portrait in oils of a Transome in the gorgeous dress of the
420: Restoration; another of a Transome in his boyhood, with his hand on the
421: neck of a small pony; and a large Flemish battle-piece, where war seemed
422: only a picturesque blue-and-red accident in a vast sunny expanse of
423: plain and sky. Probably such cheerful pictures had been chosen because
424: this was Mrs. Transome's usual sitting-room: it was certainly for this
425: reason that, near the chair in which she seated herself each time she
426: re-entered, there hung a picture of a youthful face which bore a strong
427: resemblance to her own: a beardless but masculine face, with rich brown
428: hair hanging low on the forehead, and undulating beside each cheek down
429: to the loose white cravat. Near this same chair were her writing table,
430: with vellum-covered account-books on it, the cabinet in which she kept
431: her neatly-arranged drugs, her basket for her embroidery, a folio volume
432: of architectural engravings from which she took her embroidery-patterns,
433: a number of the "North Loamshire Herald," and the cushion for her fat
434: Blenheim, which was too old and sleepy to notice its mistress's
435: restlessness. For, just now, Mrs. Transome could not abridge the sunny
436: tedium of the day by the feeble interest of her usual indoor
437: occupations. Her consciousness was absorbed by memories and prospects,
438: and except that she walked to the entrance-door to look out, she sat
439: motionless with folded arms, involuntarily from time to time turning
440: toward the portrait close by her, and as often, when its young brown
441: eyes met hers, turning away again with self-checking resolution.
442: 
443: At last, prompted by some sudden thought or by some sound, she rose and
444: went hastily beyond the tapestry curtain into the library. She paused
445: near the door without speaking: apparently she only wished to see that
446: no harm was being done. A man nearer seventy than sixty was in the act
447: of ranging on a large library-table a series of shallow drawers, some of
448: them containing dried insects, others mineralogical specimens. His pale
449: mild eyes, receding lower jaw, and slight frame, could never have
450: expressed much vigor, either bodily or mental; but he had now the
451: unevenness of gait and feebleness of gesture which tell of a past
452: paralytic seizure. His threadbare clothes were thoroughly brushed: his
453: soft white hair was carefully parted and arranged: he was not a
454: neglected-looking old man; and at his side a fine black retriever, also
455: old, sat on its haunches, and watched him as he went to and fro. But
456: when Mrs. Transome appeared within the doorway, her husband paused in
457: his work and shrank like a timid animal looked at in a cage where flight
458: was impossible. He was conscious of a troublesome intention, for which
459: he had been rebuked before--that of disturbing all his specimens with a
460: view to a new arrangement.
461: 
462: After an interval, in which his wife stood perfectly still, observing
463: him, he began to put back the drawers in their places in the row of
464: cabinets which extended under the bookshelves at one end of the
465: library. When they were all put back and closed, Mrs. Transome turned
466: away, and the frightened old man seated himself with Nimrod the
467: retriever on an ottoman. Peeping at him again, a few minutes after, she
468: saw that he had his arm round Nimrod's neck, and was uttering his
469: thoughts to the dog in a loud whisper, as little children do to any
470: object near them when they believe themselves unwatched.
471: 
472: At last the sound of the church-bell reached Mrs. Transome's ear, and
473: she knew that before long the sound of wheels must be within hearing;
474: but she did not at once start up and walk to the entrance-door. She sat
475: still, quivering and listening; her lips became pale, her hands were
476: cold and trembling. Was her son really coming? She was far beyond fifty;
477: and since her early gladness in this best-loved boy, the harvest of her
478: life had been scanty. Could it be that now--when her hair was gray, when
479: sight had become one of the day's fatigues, when her young
480: accomplishments seemed almost ludicrous, like the tone of her first
481: harpsichord and the words of the song long browned with age--she was
482: going to reap an assured joy? to feel that the doubtful deeds of her
483: life were justified by the result, since a kind Providence had
484: sanctioned them?--to be no longer tacitly pitied by her neighbors for
485: her lack of money, her imbecile husband, her graceless eldest-born, and
486: the loneliness of her life; but to have at her side a rich, clever,
487: possibly a tender, son? Yes; but there were the fifteen years of
488: separation, and all that had happened in that long time to throw her
489: into the background of her son's memory and affection. And yet--did not
490: men sometimes become more filial in their feeling when experience had
491: mellowed them, and they had themselves become fathers? Still, if Mrs.
492: Transome had expected only her son, she would have trembled less; she
493: expected a little grandson also: and there were reasons why she had not
494: been enraptured when her son had written to her only when he was on the
495: eve of returning that he already had an heir born to him.
496: 
497: But the facts must be accepted as they stood, and, after all, the chief
498: thing was to have her son back again. Such pride, such affection, such
499: hopes as she cherished in this fifty-sixth year of her life, must find
500: their gratification in him--or nowhere. Once more she glanced at the
501: portrait. The young brown eyes seemed to dwell on her pleasantly; but,
502: turning from it with a sort of impatience, and saying aloud, "Of course
503: he will be altered!" she rose almost with difficulty, and walked more
504: slowly than before across the hall to the entrance-door.
505: 
506: Already the sound of wheels was loud upon the gravel. The momentary
507: surprise of seeing that it was only a post-chaise, without a servant or
508: much luggage, that was passing under the stone archway and then wheeling
509: round against the flight of stone steps, was at once merged in the sense
510: that there was a dark face under a red travelling-cap looking at her
511: from the window. She saw nothing else; she was not even conscious that
512: the small group of her own servants had mustered, or that old Hickes the
513: butler had come forward to open the chaise door. She heard herself
514: called "Mother!" and felt a light kiss on each cheek; but stronger than
515: all that sensation was the consciousness which no previous thought could
516: prepare her for, that this son who had come back to her was a stranger.
517: Three minutes before, she had fancied that, in spite of all changes
518: wrought by fifteen years of separation, she should clasp her son again
519: as she had done at their parting; but in the moment when their eyes met,
520: the sense of strangeness came upon her like a terror. It was not hard to
521: understand that she was agitated, and the son led her across the hall to
522: the sitting-room, closing the door behind them. Then he turned toward
523: her and said, smiling--
524: 
525: "You would not have known me, eh, mother?"
526: 
527: It was perhaps the truth. If she had seen him in a crowd, she might have
528: looked at him without recognition--not, however, without startled
529: wonder; for though the likeness to herself was no longer striking, the
530: years had overlaid it with another likeness which would have arrested
531: her. Before she answered him, his eyes, with a keen restlessness, as
532: unlike as possible to the lingering gaze of the portrait, had travelled
533: quickly over the room, alighting on her as she said--
534: 
535: "Everything is changed, Harold. I am an old woman, you see."
536: 
537: "But straighter and more upright than some of the young ones!" said
538: Harold; inwardly, however, feeling that age had made his mother's face
539: very anxious and eager. "The old women at Smyrna are like sacks. You've
540: not got clumsy and shapeless. How is it I have the trick of getting
541: fat?" (Here Harold lifted his arm and spread out his plump hand.) "I
542: remember my father was as thin as a herring. How is my father? Where is
543: he?"
544: 
545: Mrs. Transome just pointed to the curtained doorway, and let her son
546: pass through it alone. She was not given to tears: but now, under the
547: pressure of emotion that could find no other vent, they burst forth. She
548: took care that they should be silent tears, and before Harold came out
549: of the library again they were dried. Mrs. Transome had not the feminine
550: tendency to seek influence through pathos; she had been used to rule in
551: virtue of acknowledged superiority. The consciousness that she had to
552: make her son's acquaintance, and that her knowledge of the youth of
553: nineteen might help her little in interpreting the man of thirty-four,
554: had fallen like lead on her soul; but in this new acquaintance of theirs
555: she cared especially that her son, who had seen a strange world, should
556: feel that he was come home to a mother who was to be consulted on all
557: things, and who could supply his lack of the local experience necessary
558: to an English landholder. Her part in life had been that of the clever
559: sinner, and she was equipped with the views, the reasons, and the habits
560: which belonged to that character; life would have little meaning for her
561: if she were to be gently thrust aside as a harmless elderly woman. And
562: besides, there were secrets which her son must never know. So, by the
563: time Harold came from the library again, the traces of tears were not
564: discernible, except to a very careful observer. And he did not observe
565: his mother carefully; his eyes only glanced at her on their way to the
566: _North Loamshire Herald_, lying on the table near her, which he took up
567: with his left hand, as he said--
568: 
569: "Gad! what a wreck poor father is! Paralysis, eh? Terribly shrunk and
570: shaken--crawls about among his books and beetles as usual, though. Well,
571: it's a slow and easy death. But he's not much over sixty-five, is he?"
572: 
573: "Sixty-seven, counting by birthdays; but your father was born old, I
574: think," said Mrs. Transome, a little flushed with the determination not
575: to show any unasked for feeling. Her son did not notice her. All the
576: time he had been speaking his eyes had been running down the columns of
577: the newspaper.
578: 
579: "But your little boy, Harold--where is he? How is it he has not come
580: with you?"
581: 
582: "Oh, I left him behind, in town," said Harold, still looking at the
583: paper. "My man Dominic will bring him, with the rest of the luggage. Ah,
584: I see it is young Debarry, and not my old friend Sir Maximus, who is
585: offering himself as candidate for North Loamshire."
586: 
587: "Yes. You did not answer me when I wrote to you to London about your
588: standing. There is no other Tory candidate spoken of, and you would
589: have all the Debarry interest."
590: 
591: "I hardly think that," said Harold, significantly.
592: 
593: "Why? Jermyn says a Tory candidate can never be got in without it."
594: 
595: "But I shall not be a Tory candidate."
596: 
597: Mrs. Transome felt something like an electric shock.
598: 
599: "What then?" she said, almost sharply. "You will not call yourself a
600: Whig?"
601: 
602: "God forbid! I'm a Radical."
603: 
604: Mrs. Transome's limbs tottered; she sank into a chair. Here was a
605: distinct confirmation of the vague but strong feeling that her son was a
606: stranger to her. Here was a revelation to which it seemed almost as
607: impossible to adjust her hopes and notions of a dignified life as if her
608: son had said that he had been converted to Mahometanism at Smyrna, and
609: had four wives, instead of one son, shortly to arrive under the care of
610: Dominic. For the moment she had a sickening feeling that it was of no
611: use that the long-delayed good fortune had come at last--all of no use
612: though the unloved Durfey was dead and buried, and though Harold had
613: come home with plenty of money. There were rich Radicals, she was aware,
614: as there were rich Jews and Dissenters, but she had never thought of
615: them as county people. Sir Francis Burdett had been generally regarded
616: as a madman. It was better to ask no questions, but silently to prepare
617: herself for anything else there might be to come.
618: 
619: "Will you go to your rooms, Harold, and see if there is anything you
620: would like to have altered?"
621: 
622: "Yes, let us go," said Harold, throwing down the newspaper, in which he
623: had been rapidly reading almost every advertisement while his mother had
624: been going through her sharp inward struggle. "Uncle Lingon is on the
625: bench still, I see," he went on, as he followed her across the hall; "is
626: he at home--will he be here this evening?"
627: 
628: "He says you must go to the rectory when you want to see him. You must
629: remember you have come back to a family with old-fashioned notions. Your
630: uncle thought I ought to have you to myself in the first hour or two. He
631: remembered that I had not seen my son for fifteen years."
632: 
633: "Ah, by Jove! fifteen years--so it is!" said Harold, taking his mother's
634: hand and drawing it under his arm; for he had perceived that her words
635: were charged with an intention. "And you are as straight as an arrow
636: still; you will carry the shawls I have brought you as well as ever."
637: 
638: They walked up the broad stone steps together in silence. Under the
639: shock of discovering her son's Radicalism, Mrs. Transome had no impulse
640: to say one thing rather than another; as in a man who had just been
641: branded on the forehead all wonted motives would be uprooted. Harold, on
642: his side, had no wish opposed to filial kindness, but his busy thoughts
643: were determined by habits which had no reference to any woman's
644: feelings; and even if he could have conceived what his mother's feeling
645: was, his mind, after that momentary arrest, would have darted forward on
646: its usual course.
647: 
648: "I have given you the south rooms, Harold," said Mrs. Transome, as they
649: passed along a corridor lit from above and lined with old family
650: pictures. "I thought they would suit you best, as they all open into
651: each other, and this middle one will make a pleasant sitting-room for
652: you."
653: 
654: "Gad! the furniture is in a bad state," said Harold, glancing around at
655: the middle room which they had just entered; "the moths seem to have got
656: into the carpets and hangings."
657: 
658: "I had no choice except moths or tenants who would pay rent," said Mrs.
659: Transome. "We have been too poor to keep servants for uninhabited
660: rooms."
661: 
662: "What! you've been rather pinched, eh?"
663: 
664: "You find us living as we have been living these twelve years."
665: 
666: "Ah, you've had Durfey's debts as well as the lawsuits--confound them!
667: It will make a hole in sixty thousand pounds to pay off the mortgages.
668: However, he's gone now, poor fellow; and I suppose I should have spent
669: more in buying an English estate some time or other. I always meant to
670: be an Englishman, and thrash a lord or two who thrashed me at Eton."
671: 
672: "I hardly thought you could have meant that, Harold, when I found you
673: had married a foreign wife."
674: 
675: "Would you have had me wait for a consumptive lackadaisical
676: Englishwoman, who would have hung all her relations around my neck? I
677: hate English wives; they want to give their opinion about everything.
678: They interfere with a man's life. I shall not marry again."
679: 
680: Mrs. Transome bit her lip, and turned away to draw up a blind. She would
681: not reply to words which showed how completely any conception of herself
682: and her feelings was excluded from her son's inward world.
683: 
684: As she turned round again she said, "I suppose you have been used to
685: great luxury; these rooms look miserable to you, but you can soon make
686: any alterations you like."
687: 
688: "Oh, I must have a private sitting-room fitted up for myself
689: down-stairs. And the rest are bedrooms, I suppose," he went on, opening
690: a side-door. "Ah, I can sleep here a night or two. But there's a bedroom
691: down-stairs, with an ante-room, I remember, that would do for my man
692: Dominic and the little boy. I should like to have that."
693: 
694: "Your father has slept there for years. He will be like a distracted
695: insect, and never know where to go, if you alter the track he has to
696: walk in."
697: 
698: "That's a pity. I hate going up-stairs."
699: 
700: "There is the steward's room: it is not used, and might be turned into a
701: bedroom. I can't offer you my room, for I sleep up-stairs." (Mrs.
702: Transome's tongue could be a whip upon occasion, but the lash had not
703: fallen on a sensitive spot.)
704: 
705: "No; I'm determined not to sleep up-stairs. We'll see about the
706: steward's room to-morrow, and I dare say I shall find a closet of some
707: sort for Dominic. It's a nuisance he had to stay behind, for I shall
708: have nobody to cook for me. Ah, there's the old river I used to fish in.
709: I often thought, when I was at Smyrna, that I would buy a park with a
710: river through it as much like the Lapp as possible. Gad, what fine oaks
711: those are opposite! Some of them must come down, though."
712: 
713: "I've held every tree sacred on the demesne, as I told you, Harold. I
714: trusted to your getting the estate some time, and releasing it; and I
715: determined to keep it worth releasing. A park without fine timber is no
716: better than a beauty without teeth and hair."
717: 
718: "Bravo, mother!" said Harold, putting his hand on her shoulder. "Ah,
719: you've had to worry yourself about things that don't properly belong to
720: a woman--my father being weakly. We'll set all that right. You shall
721: have nothing to do now but to be grandmamma on satin cushions."
722: 
723: "You must excuse me from the satin cushions. That is a part of the old
724: woman's duty I am not prepared for. I am used to be chief bailiff, and
725: to sit in the saddle two or three hours every day. There are two farms
726: on our hands besides the Home Farm."
727: 
728: "Phew-ew! Jermyn manages the estate badly, then. That will not last
729: under _my_ reign," said Harold, turning on his heel and feeling in his
730: pockets for the keys of his portmanteaus, which had been brought up.
731: 
732: "Perhaps when you've been in England a little longer," said Mrs.
733: Transome, coloring as if she had been a girl, "you will understand
734: better the difficulty there is in letting farms these times."
735: 
736: "I understand the difficulty perfectly, mother. To let farms, a man must
737: have the sense to see what will make them inviting to farmers, and to
738: get sense supplied on demand is just the most difficult transaction I
739: know of. I suppose if I ring there's some fellow who can act as valet
740: and learn to attend to my hookah?"
741: 
742: "There is Hickes the butler, and there is Jabez the footman; those are
743: all the men in the house. They were here when you left."
744: 
745: "Oh, I remember Jabez--he was a dolt. I'll have old Hickes. He was a
746: neat little machine of a butler; his words used to come like the clicks
747: of an engine. He must be an old machine now, though."
748: 
749: "You seem to remember some things about home wonderfully well, Harold."
750: 
751: "Never forget places and people--how they look and what can be done with
752: them. All the country round here lies like a map in my brain. A deuced
753: pretty country too; but the people were a stupid set of old Whigs and
754: Tories. I suppose they are much as they were."
755: 
756: "I am, at least, Harold. You are the first of your family that ever
757: talked of being a Radical. I did not think I was taking care of our old
758: oaks for that. I always thought Radicals' houses stood staring above
759: poor sticks of young trees and iron hurdles."
760: 
761: "Yes, but the Radical sticks are growing, mother, and half the Tory oaks
762: are rotting," said Harold, with gay carelessness. "You've arranged for
763: Jermyn to be early to-morrow?"
764: 
765: "He will be here to breakfast at nine. But I leave you to Hickes now; we
766: dine in an hour."
767: 
768: Mrs. Transome went away and shut herself in her own dressing-room. It
769: had come to pass now--this meeting with the son who had been the object
770: of so much longing; whom she had longed for before he was born, for whom
771: she had sinned, from whom she had wrenched herself with pain at their
772: parting, and whose coming again had been the one great hope of her
773: years. The moment was gone by; there had been no ecstasy, no gladness
774: even; hardly half an hour had passed, and few words had been spoken,
775: yet with that quickness in weaving new futures which belongs to women
776: whose actions have kept them in habitual fear of consequences, Mrs.
777: Transome thought she saw with all the clearness of demonstration that
778: her son's return had not been a good for her in the sense of making her
779: any happier.
780: 
781: She stood before a tall mirror, going close to it and looking at her
782: face with hard scrutiny, as if it were unrelated to herself. No elderly
783: face can be handsome, looked at in that way; every little detail is
784: startlingly prominent, and the effect of the whole is lost. She saw the
785: dried-up complexion, and the deep lines of bitter discontent about the
786: mouth.
787: 
788: "I am a hag!" she said to herself (she was accustomed to give her
789: thoughts a very sharp outline), "an ugly old woman who happens to be his
790: mother. That is what he sees in me, as I see a stranger in him. I shall
791: count for nothing. I was foolish to expect anything else."
792: 
793: She turned away from the mirror and walked up and down her room.
794: 
795: "What a likeness!" she said, in a loud whisper; "yet, perhaps, no one
796: will see it besides me."
797: 
798: She threw herself into a chair, and sat with a fixed look, seeing
799: nothing that was actually present, but inwardly seeing with painful
800: vividness what had been present with her a little more than thirty years
801: ago--the little round-limbed creature that had been leaning against her
802: knees, and stamping tiny feet, and looking up at her with gurgling
803: laughter. She had thought that the possession of this child would give
804: unity to her life, and make some gladness through the changing years
805: that would grow as fruit out of these early maternal caresses. But
806: nothing had come just as she had wished. The mother's early raptures had
807: lasted but a short time, and even while they lasted there had grown up
808: in the midst of them a hungry desire, like a black poisonous plant
809: feeding in the sunlight,--the desire that her first, rickety, ugly,
810: imbecile child should die, and leave room for her darling, of whom she
811: could be proud. Such desires make life a hideous lottery, where every day
812: may turn up a blank; where men and women who have the softest beds and
813: the most delicate eating, who have a very large share of that sky and
814: earth which some are born to have no more of than the fraction to be got
815: in a crowded entry, yet grow haggard, fevered, and restless, like those
816: who watch in other lotteries. Day after day, year after year, had
817: yielded blanks; new cares had come, bringing other desires for results
818: quite beyond her grasp, which must also be watched for in the lottery;
819: and all the while the round-limbed pet had been growing into a strong
820: youth, who liked many things better than his mother's caresses, and who
821: had a much keener consciousness of his independent existence than of his
822: relation to her: the lizard's egg, that white rounded passive
823: prettiness, had become a brown, darting, determined lizard. The mother's
824: love is at first an absorbing delight, blunting all other sensibilities;
825: it is an expansion of the animal existence; it enlarges the imagined
826: range for self to move in: but in after years it can only continue to be
827: joy on the same terms as other long-lived love--that is, by much
828: suppression of self, and power of living in the experience of another.
829: Mrs. Transome had darkly felt the pressure of that unchangeable fact.
830: Yet she had clung to the belief that somehow the possession of this son
831: was the best thing she lived for; to believe otherwise would have made
832: her memory too ghastly a companion. Some time or other, by some means,
833: the estate she was struggling to save from the grasp of the law would be
834: Harold's. Somehow the hated Durfey, the imbecile eldest, who seemed to
835: have become tenacious of a despicable squandering life, would be got rid
836: of; vice might kill him. Meanwhile the estate was burdened: there was no
837: good prospect for any heir. Harold must go and make a career for himself
838: and this was what he was bent on, with a precocious clearness of
839: perception as to the conditions on which he could hope for any
840: advantages in life. Like most energetic natures, he had a strong faith
841: in his luck; he had been gay at their parting, and had promised to make
842: his fortune; and in spite of past disappointments, Harold's possible
843: fortune still made some ground for his mother to plant her hopes in. His
844: luck had not failed him; yet nothing had turned out according to her
845: expectations. Her life had been like a spoiled shabby pleasure-day, in
846: which the music and the processions are all missed, and nothing is left
847: at evening but the weariness of striving after what has been failed of.
848: Harold had gone with the Embassy to Constantinople, under the patronage
849: of a high relative, his mother's cousin; he was to be diplomatist, and
850: work his way upward in public life. But his luck had taken another
851: shape: he had saved the life of an Armenian banker, who in gratitude had
852: offered him a prospect which his practical mind had preferred to the
853: problematic promises of diplomacy and high-born cousinship. Harold had
854: become a merchant and banker at Smyrna; and let the years pass without
855: caring to find the possibility of visiting his early home, and had shown
856: no eagerness to make his life at all familiar to his mother, asking for
857: letters about England, but writing scantily about himself. Mrs. Transome
858: had kept up the habit of writing to her son, but gradually the
859: unfruitful years had dulled her hopes and yearnings; increasing
860: anxieties about money had worried her, and she was more sure of being
861: fretted by bad news about her dissolute eldest son than of hearing
862: anything to cheer her from Harold. She had begun to live merely in small
863: immediate cares and occupations, and like all eager-minded women who
864: advance in life without any activity of tenderness or any large
865: sympathy, she had contracted small rigid habits of thinking and acting,
866: she had her "ways" which must not be crossed, and had learned to fill up
867: the great void of life with giving small orders to tenants, insisting on
868: medicines for infirm cottagers, winning small triumphs in bargains and
869: personal economies, and parrying ill-natured remarks of Lady Debarry's
870: by lancet-edged epigrams. So her life had gone on till more than a year
871: ago, when that desire which had been so hungry when she was a blooming
872: young mother, was at last fulfilled--at last, when her hair was gray,
873: and her face looked bitter, restless, and unenjoying, like her life. The
874: news came from Jersey that Durfey, the imbecile son, was dead. _Now_
875: Harold was heir to the estate; now the wealth he had gained could
876: release the land from its burdens; now he would think it worth while to
877: return home. A change had come over her life, and the sunlight breaking
878: the clouds at evening was pleasant, though the sun must sink before
879: long. Hopes, affections, the sweeter part of her memories, started from
880: their wintry sleep, and it once more seemed a great good to have had a
881: second son who in some ways had cost her dearly. But again there were
882: conditions she had not reckoned on. When the good tidings had been sent
883: to Harold, and he had announced that he would return so soon as he could
884: wind up his affairs, he had for the first time informed his mother that
885: he had been married, that his Greek wife was no longer living, but that
886: he should bring home a little boy, the finest and most desirable of
887: heirs and grandsons. Harold seated in his distant Smyrna home considered
888: that he was taking a rational view of what things must have become by
889: this time at the old place in England, when he figured his mother as a
890: good elderly lady, who would necessarily be delighted with the
891: possession on any terms of a healthy grandchild, and would not mind
892: much about the particulars of a long-concealed marriage.
893: 
894: Mrs. Transome had torn up that letter in a rage. But in the months which
895: had elapsed before Harold could actually arrive, she had prepared
896: herself as well as she could to suppress all reproaches or queries which
897: her son might resent, and to acquiesce in his evident wishes. The return
898: was still looked for with longing; affection and satisfied pride would
899: again warm her later years. She was ignorant what sort of man Harold had
900: become now, and of course he must be changed in many ways; but though
901: she told herself this, still the image that she knew, the image fondness
902: clung to, necessarily prevailed over the negatives insisted on by her
903: reason.
904: 
905: And so it was, that when she had moved to the door to meet him, she had
906: been sure that she should clasp her son again, and feel that he was the
907: same who had been her boy, her little one, the loved child of her
908: passionate youth. An hour seemed to have changed everything for her. A
909: woman's hopes are woven of sunbeams; a shadow annihilates them. The
910: shadow which had fallen over Mrs. Transome in this first interview with
911: her son was the presentiment of her powerlessness. If things went wrong,
912: if Harold got unpleasantly disposed in a certain direction where her
913: chief dread had always lain, she seemed to foresee that her words would
914: be of no avail. The keenness of her anxiety in this matter had served as
915: insight; and Harold's rapidity, decision, and indifference to any
916: impressions in others, which did not further or impede his own purposes,
917: had made themselves felt by her as much as she would have felt the
918: unmanageable strength of a great bird which had alighted near her, and
919: allowed her to stroke its wing for a moment because food lay near her.
920: 
921: Under the cold weight of these thoughts Mrs. Transome shivered. That
922: physical reaction roused her from her reverie, and she could now hear
923: the gentle knocking at the door to which she had been deaf before.
924: Notwithstanding her activity and the fewness of her servants, she had
925: never dressed herself without aid; nor would that small, neat,
926: exquisitely clean old woman who now presented herself have wished that
927: her labor should be saved at the expense of such a sacrifice on her
928: lady's part. The small old woman was Mrs. Hickes, the butler's wife, who
929: acted as housekeeper, lady's-maid, and superintendent of the
930: kitchen--the large stony scene of inconsiderable cooking. Forty years
931: ago she had entered Mrs. Transome's service, when that lady was
932: beautiful Miss Lingon, and her mistress still called her Denner, as she
933: had done in the old days.
934: 
935: "The bell has rung, then, Denner, without my hearing it?" said Mrs.
936: Transome, rising.
937: 
938: "Yes, madam," said Denner, reaching from a wardrobe an old black velvet
939: dress trimmed with much-mended point, in which Mrs. Transome was wont to
940: look queenly of an evening.
941: 
942: Denner had still strong eyes of that short-sighted kind which sees
943: through the narrowest chink between the eyelashes. The physical contrast
944: between the tall, eagle-faced, dark-eyed lady, and the little peering
945: waiting woman, who had been round-featured and of pale mealy complexion
946: from her youth up, had doubtless had a strong influence in determining
947: Denner's feeling toward her mistress, which was of that worshipful sort
948: paid to a goddess in ages when it was not thought necessary or likely
949: that a goddess should be very moral. There were different orders of
950: beings--so ran Denner's creed--and she belonged to another order than
951: that to which her mistress belonged. She had a mind as sharp as a
952: needle, and would have seen through and through the ridiculous
953: pretensions of a born servant who did not submissively accept the rigid
954: fate which had given her born superiors. She would have called such
955: pretensions the wrigglings of a worm that tried to walk on its tail.
956: There was a tacit understanding that Denner knew all her mistress's
957: secrets, and her speech was plain and unflattering; yet with wonderful
958: subtlety of instinct she never said anything which Mrs. Transome could
959: feel humiliated by, as by familiarity from a servant who knew too much.
960: Denner identified her own dignity with that of her mistress. She was a
961: hard-headed godless little woman, but with a character to be reckoned on
962: as you reckon on the qualities of iron.
963: 
964: Peering into Mrs. Transome's face she saw clearly that the meeting with
965: the son had been a disappointment in some way. She spoke with a refined
966: accent, in a low quick, monotonous tone--
967: 
968: "Mr. Harold is dressed; he shook me by the hand in the corridor, and was
969: very pleasant."
970: 
971: "What an alteration, Denner! No likeness to me now."
972: 
973: "Handsome, though, spite of his being so browned and stout. There's a
974: fine presence about Mr. Harold. I remember you used to say, madam, there
975: were some people you would always know were in the room though they
976: stood round a corner, and others you might never see till you ran
977: against them. That's as true as truth. And as for likenesses,
978: thirty-five and sixty are not much alike, only to people's memories."
979: 
980: Mrs. Transome knew perfectly that Denner had divined her thoughts.
981: 
982: "I don't know how things will go on now, but it seems something too good
983: to happen that they will go on well. I am afraid of ever expecting
984: anything good again."
985: 
986: "That's weakness, madam. Things don't happen because they're bad or
987: good, else all eggs would be addled or none at all, and at the most it
988: is but six to the dozen. There's good chances and bad chances, and
989: nobody's luck is pulled only by one string."
990: 
991: "What a woman you are, Denner! You talk like a French infidel. It seems
992: to me you are afraid of nothing. I have been full of fears all my
993: life--always seeing something or other hanging over me that I couldn't
994: bear to happen."
995: 
996: "Well, madam, put a good face on it, and don't seem to be on the look-out
997: for crows, else you'll set other people watching. Here you have a rich
998: son come home, and the debts will all be paid, and you have your health
999: and can ride about, and you've such a face and figure, and will have if
1000: you live to be eighty, that everybody is cap in hand to you before they
1001: know you who are; let me fasten up your veil a little higher: there's a
1002: good deal of pleasure in life for you yet."
1003: 
1004: "Nonsense! there's no pleasure for old women, unless they get it out of
1005: tormenting other people. What are your pleasures, Denner--besides being
1006: a slave to me?"
1007: 
1008: "Oh, there's pleasure in knowing one's not a fool, like half the people
1009: one sees about. And managing one's husband is some pleasure; and doing
1010: all one's business well. Why, if I've only got some orange flowers to
1011: candy, I shouldn't like to die till I see them all right. Then there's
1012: the sunshine now and then; I like that as the cats do. I look upon it,
1013: life is like our game at whist, when Banks and his wife come to the
1014: still-room of an evening. I don't enjoy the game much, but I like to
1015: play my cards well, and see what will be the end of it; and I want to
1016: see you make the best of your hand, madam, for your luck has been mine
1017: these forty years now. But I must go and see how Kitty dishes up the
1018: dinner, unless you have any more commands."
1019: 
1020: "No, Denner; I am going down immediately."
1021: 
1022: As Mrs. Transome descended the stone staircase in her old black velvet
1023: and point, her appearance justified Denner's personal compliment. She
1024: had that high-born, imperious air which would have marked her as an
1025: object of hatred and reviling by a revolutionary mob. Her person was too
1026: typical of social distinctions to be passed by with indifference by any
1027: one: it would have fitted an empress in her own right, who had had to
1028: rule in spite of faction, to dare the violation of treaties and dread
1029: retributive invasions, to grasp after new territories, to be defiant in
1030: desperate circumstances, and to feel a woman's hunger of the heart
1031: forever unsatisfied. Yet Mrs. Transome's cares and occupations had not
1032: been at all of an imperial sort. For thirty years she had led the
1033: monotonous, narrowing life which used to be the lot of our poorer
1034: gentry; who never went to town, and were probably not on speaking terms
1035: with two out of the five families whose parks lay within the distance of
1036: a drive. When she was young she had been thought wonderfully clever and
1037: accomplished, and had been rather ambitious of intellectual
1038: superiority--had secretly picked out for private reading the higher
1039: parts of dangerous French authors--and in company had been able to talk
1040: of Mr. Burke's style, or of Chateaubriand's eloquence--had laughed at
1041: the Lyrical Ballads, and admired Mr. Southey's Thalaba. She always
1042: thought that the dangerous French writers were wicked and that her
1043: reading of them was a sin; but many sinful things were highly agreeable
1044: to her, and many things which she did not doubt to be good and true were
1045: dull and meaningless. She found ridicule of Biblical characters very
1046: amusing, and she was interested in stories of illicit passion; but she
1047: believed all the while that truth and safety lay in due attendance on
1048: prayers and sermons, in the admirable doctrines and ritual of the Church
1049: of England, equally remote from Puritanism and Popery; in fact, in such
1050: a view of this world and the next as would preserve the existing
1051: arrangements of English society quite unshaken, keeping down the
1052: obtrusiveness of the vulgar and the discontent of the poor. The history
1053: of the Jews, she knew, ought to be preferred to any profane history; the
1054: Pagans, of course, were vicious, and their religions quite nonsensical,
1055: considered as religions--but classical learning came from the Pagans;
1056: the Greeks were famous for sculpture; the Italians for painting; the
1057: middle ages were dark and Papistical; but now Christianity went hand in
1058: hand with civilization, and the providential government of the world,
1059: though a little confused and entangled in foreign countries, in our
1060: favored land was clearly seen to be carried forward on Tory and Church
1061: of England principles, sustained by the succession of the House of
1062: Brunswick, and by sound English divines. For Miss Lingon had had a
1063: superior governess, who held that a woman should be able to write a good
1064: letter, and to express herself with propriety on general subjects. And
1065: it is astonishing how effective this education appeared in a handsome
1066: girl, who sat supremely well on horseback, sang and played a little,
1067: painted small figures in water-colors, had a naughty sparkle in her eyes
1068: when she made a daring quotation, and an air of serious dignity when she
1069: recited something from her store of correct opinions. But however such a
1070: stock of ideas may be made to tell in elegant society, and during a few
1071: seasons in town, no amount of bloom and beauty can make them a perennial
1072: source of interest in things not personal; and the notion that what is
1073: true and, in general, good for mankind, is stupid and drug-like, is not
1074: a safe theoretic basis in circumstances of temptation and difficulty.
1075: Mrs. Transome had been in her bloom before this century began, and in
1076: the long painful years since then, what she had once regarded as her
1077: knowledge and accomplishments had become as valueless as old-fashioned
1078: stucco ornaments, of which the substance was never worth anything, while
1079: the form is no longer to the taste of any living mortal. Crosses,
1080: mortifications, money-cares, conscious blame-worthiness, had changed the
1081: aspect of the world for her; there was anxiety in the morning sunlight;
1082: there was unkind triumph or disapproving pity in the glances of greeting
1083: neighbors; there was advancing age, and a contracting prospect in the
1084: changing seasons as they came and went. And what could then sweeten the
1085: days to a hungry, much-exacting self like Mrs. Transome's? Under
1086: protracted ill every living creature will find something that makes a
1087: comparative ease, and even when life seems woven of pain, will convert
1088: the fainter pang into a desire. Mrs. Transome, whose imperious will had
1089: availed little to ward off the great evils of her life, found the opiate
1090: for her discontent in the exertion of her will about smaller things. She
1091: was not cruel, and could not enjoy thoroughly what she called the old
1092: woman's pleasure of tormenting; but she liked every little sign of power
1093: her lot had left her. She liked that a tenant should stand bareheaded
1094: below her as she sat on horseback. She liked to insist that work done
1095: without her orders should be undone from beginning to end. She liked to
1096: be courtesied and bowed to by all the congregation as she walked up the
1097: little barn of a church. She liked to change a laborer's medicine
1098: fetched from the doctor, and substitute a prescription of her own. If
1099: she had only been more haggard and less majestic, those who had glimpses
1100: of her outward life might have said she was a tyrannical, griping
1101: harridan, with a tongue like a razor. No one said exactly that; but they
1102: never said anything like the full truth about her, or divined what was
1103: hidden under that outward life--a woman's keen sensibility and dread,
1104: which lay screened behind all her petty habits and narrow notions, as
1105: some quivering thing with eyes and throbbing heart may lie crouching
1106: behind withered rubbish. The sensibility and dread had palpitated all
1107: the faster in the prospect of her son's return; and now that she had
1108: seen him, she said to herself, in her bitter way, "It is a lucky eel
1109: that escapes skinning. The best happiness I shall ever know, will be to
1110: escape the worst misery."
1111: 
1112: 
1113: 
1114: 
1115: CHAPTER II.
1116: 
1117:     A jolly parson of the good old stock,
1118:     By birth a gentleman, yet homely too,
1119:     Suiting his phrase to Hodge and Margery
1120:     Whom he once christened, and has married since,
1121:     A little lax in doctrine and in life.
1122:     Not thinking God was captious in such things
1123:     As what a man might drink on holidays,
1124:     But holding true religion was to do
1125:     As you'd be done by--which could never mean
1126:     That he should preach three sermons in a week.
1127: 
1128: 
1129: Harold Transome did not choose to spend the whole evening with his
1130: mother. It was his habit to compress a great deal of effective
1131: conversation into a short space of time, asking rapidly all the
1132: questions he wanted to get answered, and diluting no subject with
1133: irrelevancies, paraphrase, or repetitions. He volunteered no information
1134: about himself and his past life at Smyrna, but answered pleasantly
1135: enough, though briefly, whenever his mother asked for any detail. He was
1136: evidently ill-satisfied as to his palate, trying red pepper to
1137: everything, then asking if there were any relishing sauces in the house,
1138: and when Hickes brought various home-filled bottles, trying several,
1139: finding them failures, and finally falling back from his plate in
1140: despair. Yet he remained good-humored, saying something to his father
1141: now and then for the sake of being kind, and looking on with a pitying
1142: shrug as he saw him watch Hickes cutting his food. Mrs. Transome thought
1143: with some bitterness that Harold showed more feeling for her feeble
1144: husband who had never cared in the least about him, than for her, who
1145: had given him more than the usual share of mother's love. An hour after
1146: dinner, Harold, who had already been turning over the leaves of his
1147: mother's account-books, said--
1148: 
1149: "I shall just cross the park to the parsonage to see my uncle Lingon."
1150: 
1151: "Very well. He can answer more questions for you."
1152: 
1153: "Yes," said Harold, quite deaf to the innuendo, and accepting the words
1154: as a simple statement of the fact. "I want to hear all about the game
1155: and the North Loamshire hunt. I'm fond of sport; we had a great deal of
1156: it at Smyrna, and it keeps down my fat."
1157: 
1158: The Reverend John Lingon became very talkative over his second bottle of
1159: port, which was opened on his nephew's arrival. He was not curious about
1160: the manners of Smyrna, or about Harold's experience, but he unbosomed
1161: himself very freely as to what he himself liked and disliked, which of
1162: the farmers he suspected of killing the foxes, what game he had bagged
1163: that very morning, what spot he would recommend as a new cover, and the
1164: comparative flatness of all existing sport compared with cock-fighting,
1165: under which Old England had been prosperous and glorious, while, so far
1166: as he could see, it had gained little by the abolition of a practice
1167: which sharpened the faculties of men, gratified the instincts of the
1168: fowl, and carried out the designs of heaven in its admirable device of
1169: spurs. From these main topics, which made his points of departure and
1170: return, he rambled easily enough at any new suggestion or query; so that
1171: when Harold got home at a late hour, he was conscious of having gathered
1172: from amidst the pompous full-toned triviality of his uncle's chat some
1173: impressions, which were of practical importance. Among the rector's
1174: dislikes, it appeared, was Mr. Matthew Jermyn.
1175: 
1176: "A fat-handed, glib-tongued fellow, with a scented cambric handkerchief;
1177: one of your educated low-bred fellows; a foundling who got his Latin for
1178: nothing at Christ's Hospital; one of your middle-class upstarts who want
1179: to rank with gentlemen, and think they'll do it with kid gloves and new
1180: furniture."
1181: 
1182: But since Harold meant to stand for the county, Mr. Lingon was equally
1183: emphatic as to the necessity of his not quarrelling with Jermyn till the
1184: election was over. Jermyn must be his agent; Harold must wink hard till
1185: he found himself safely returned; and even then it might be well to let
1186: Jermyn drop gently and raise no scandal. He himself had no quarrel with
1187: the fellow: a clergyman should have no quarrels, and he made it a point
1188: to be able to take wine with any man he met at table. And as to the
1189: estate, and his sister's going too much by Jermyn's advice, he never
1190: meddled with business: it was not his duty as a clergyman. That, he
1191: considered, was the meaning of Melchisedec and the tithe, a subject,
1192: into which he had gone to some depth thirty years ago, when he preached
1193: the Visitation sermon.
1194: 
1195: The discovery that Harold meant to stand on the Liberal side--nay, that
1196: he boldly declared himself a Radical--was rather startling; but to his
1197: uncle's good-humor, beatified by the sipping of port-wine, nothing could
1198: seem highly objectionable, provided it did not disturb that operation.
1199: In the course of half an hour he had brought himself to see that
1200: anything really worthy to be called British Toryism had been entirely
1201: extinct since the Duke of Wellington and Sir Robert Peel had passed the
1202: Catholic Emancipation Bill; that Whiggery, with its rights of man
1203: stopping short at ten-pound householders, and its policy of pacifying a
1204: wild beast with a bite, was a ridiculous monstrosity; that therefore,
1205: since an honest man could not call himself a Tory, which it was, in
1206: fact, as impossible to be now as to fight for the old Pretender, and
1207: could still less become that execrable monstrosity a Whig, there
1208: remained but one course open to him. "Why, lad, if the world was turned
1209: into a swamp, I suppose we should leave off shoes and stockings, and
1210: walk about like cranes"--whence it followed plainly enough that, in
1211: these hopeless times, nothing was left to men of sense and good family
1212: but to retard the national ruin by declaring themselves Radicals, and
1213: take the inevitable process of changing everything out of the hands of
1214: beggarly demagogues and purse-proud tradesmen. It is true the rector was
1215: helped to this chain of reasoning by Harold's remarks; but he soon
1216: became quite ardent in asserting the conclusion.
1217: 
1218: "If the mob can't be turned back, a man of family must try and head the
1219: mob, and save a few homes and hearths, and keep the country up on its
1220: last legs as long as he can. And you're a man of family, my lad--dash
1221: it! You're a Lingon, whatever else you may be, and I'll stand by you.
1222: I've no great interest; I'm a poor parson. I've been forced to give up
1223: hunting; my pointers and a glass of good wine are the only decencies
1224: becoming my station that I can allow myself. But I'll give you my
1225: countenance--I'll stick to you as my nephew. There's no need for me to
1226: change sides exactly. I was born a Tory, and I shall never be a bishop.
1227: But if anybody says you're in the wrong, I shall say, 'My nephew is in
1228: the right; he has turned Radical to save his country. If William Pitt
1229: had been living now he'd have done the same; for what did he say when he
1230: was dying? Not 'Oh, save my party!' but 'Oh, save my country, heaven!'
1231: That was what they dinned in our ears about Peel and the Duke; and now
1232: I'll turn it round upon them. They shall be hoist with their own petard.
1233: Yes, yes, I'll stand by you."
1234: 
1235: Harold did not feel sure that his uncle would thoroughly retain this
1236: satisfactory thread of argument in the uninspired hours of the morning;
1237: but the old gentleman was sure to take the facts easily in the end, and
1238: there was no fear of family coolness or quarrelling on this side. Harold
1239: was glad of it. He was not to be turned aside from any course he had
1240: chosen; but he disliked all quarrelling as an unpleasant expenditure of
1241: energy that could have no good practical result. He was at once active
1242: and luxurious; fond of mastery, and good-natured enough to wish that
1243: every one about him should like his mastery; not caring greatly to know
1244: other people's thoughts, and ready to despise them as blockheads if
1245: their thoughts differed from his, and yet solicitous that they should
1246: have no colorable reason for slight thoughts about _him_. The blockheads
1247: must be forced to respect him. Hence, in proportion as he foresaw his
