1248: equals in the neighborhood would be indignant with him for his political
1249: choice, he cared keenly about making a good figure before them in every
1250: other way. His conduct as a landholder was to be judicious, his
1251: establishment was to be kept up generously, his imbecile father treated
1252: with careful regard, his family relations entirely without scandal. He
1253: knew that affairs had been unpleasant in his youth--that there had been
1254: ugly lawsuits--and that his scapegrace brother Durfey had helped to
1255: lower still farther the depressed condition of the family. All this must
1256: be retrieved, now that events had made Harold the head of the Transome
1257: name.
1258: 
1259: Jermyn must be used for the election, and after that if he must be got
1260: rid of, it would be well to shake him loose quietly; his uncle was
1261: probably right on both these points. But Harold's expectation that he
1262: should want to get rid of Jermyn was founded on other reasons than his
1263: scented handkerchief and his charity-school Latin.
1264: 
1265: If the lawyer had been presuming on Mrs. Transome's ignorance as a
1266: woman, and on the stupid rakishness of the original heir, the new heir
1267: would prove to him that he had calculated rashly. Otherwise, Harold had
1268: no prejudice against him. In his boyhood and youth he had seen Jermyn
1269: frequenting Transome Court, but had regarded him with that total
1270: indifference with which youngsters are apt to view those who neither
1271: deny them pleasure nor give them any. Jermyn used to smile at him, and
1272: speak to him affably; but Harold, half proud, half shy, got away from
1273: such patronage as soon as possible; he knew Jermyn was a man of
1274: business; his father, his uncle, and Sir Maximus Debarry did not regard
1275: him as a gentleman and their equal. He had known no evil of the man; but
1276: he saw now that if he were really a covetous upstart, there had been a
1277: temptation for him in the management of the Transome affairs; and it was
1278: clear that the estate was in a bad condition.
1279: 
1280: When Mr. Jermyn was ushered into the breakfast-room the next morning,
1281: Harold found him surprisingly little altered by the fifteen years. He
1282: was gray, but still remarkably handsome; fat, but tall enough to bear
1283: that trial to man's dignity. There was as strong a suggestion of
1284: toilette about him as if he had been five-and-twenty instead of nearly
1285: sixty. He chose always to dress in black, and was especially addicted to
1286: black satin waistcoats, which carried out the general sleekness of his
1287: appearance; and this, together with his white, fat, but
1288: beautifully-shaped hands, which he was in the habit of rubbing gently on
1289: his entrance into a room, gave him very much the air of a lady's
1290: physician. Harold remembered with some amusement his uncle's dislike of
1291: those conspicuous hands; but as his own were soft and dimpled, and as he
1292: too was given to the innocent practice of rubbing those members, his
1293: suspicions were not yet deepened.
1294: 
1295: "I congratulate you, Mrs. Transome," said Jermyn, with a soft and
1296: deferential smile, "all the more," he added, turning toward Harold, "now
1297: I have the pleasure of actually seeing your son. I am glad to perceive
1298: that an Eastern climate has not been unfavorable to him."
1299: 
1300: "No," said Harold, shaking Jermyn's hand carelessly, and speaking with
1301: more than his usual brusqueness, "the question is, whether the English
1302: climate will agree with me. It's deuced shifting and damp; and as for
1303: the food, it would be the finest thing in the world for this country if
1304: the southern cooks would change their religion, get persecuted, and fly
1305: to England, as the old silk-weavers did."
1306: 
1307: "There are plenty of foreign cooks for those who are rich enough to pay
1308: for them, I suppose," said Mrs. Transome, "but they are unpleasant
1309: people to have about one's house."
1310: 
1311: "Gad! I don't think so," said Harold.
1312: 
1313: "The old servants are sure to quarrel with them."
1314: 
1315: "That's no concern of mine. The old servants will have to put up with my
1316: man Dominic, who will show them how to cook and do everything else in a
1317: way that will rather astonish them."
1318: 
1319: "Old people are not so easily taught to change all their ways, Harold."
1320: 
1321: "Well, they can give up and watch the young ones," said Harold, thinking
1322: only at that moment of old Mrs. Hickes and Dominic. But his mother was
1323: not thinking of them only.
1324: 
1325: "You have a valuable servant, it seems," said Jermyn, who understood
1326: Mrs. Transome better than her son did, and wished to smoothen the
1327: current of their dialogue.
1328: 
1329: "Oh, one of those wonderful southern fellows that make one's life easy.
1330: He's of no country in particular. I don't know whether he's most of a
1331: Jew, a Greek, an Italian, or a Spaniard. He speaks five or six
1332: languages, one as well as another. He's cook, valet, major-domo, and
1333: secretary all in one; and what's more, he's an affectionate fellow--I
1334: can trust to his attachment. That's a sort of human specimen that
1335: doesn't grow here in England, I fancy. I should have been badly off if I
1336: could not have brought Dominic."
1337: 
1338: They sat down to breakfast with such slight talk as this going on. Each
1339: of the party was preoccupied and uneasy. Harold's mind was busy
1340: constructing probabilities about what he should discover of Jermyn's
1341: mismanagement or dubious application of funds, and the sort of
1342: self-command he must in the worst case exercise in order to use the man
1343: as long as he wanted him. Jermyn was closely observing Harold with an
1344: unpleasant sense that there was an expression of acuteness and
1345: determination about him which would make him formidable. He would
1346: certainly have preferred at that moment that there had been no second
1347: heir of the Transome name to come back upon him from the East. Mrs.
1348: Transome was not observing the two men; rather, her hands were cold, and
1349: her whole person shaken by their presence; she seemed to hear and see
1350: what they said and did with preternatural acuteness, and yet she was
1351: also seeing and hearing what had been said and done many years before,
1352: and feeling a dim terror about the future. There were piteous
1353: sensibilities in this faded woman, who thirty-four years ago, in the
1354: splendor of her bloom, had been imperious to one of these men, and had
1355: rapturously pressed the other as an infant to her bosom, and now knew
1356: that she was of little consequence to either of them.
1357: 
1358: "Well, what are the prospects about election?" said Harold, as the
1359: breakfast was advancing. "There are two Whigs and one Conservative
1360: likely to be in the field, I know. What is your opinion of the chances?"
1361: 
1362: Mr. Jermyn had a copious supply of words which often led him into
1363: periphrase, but he cultivated a hesitating stammer, which, with a
1364: handsome impassiveness of face, except when he was smiling at a woman,
1365: or when the latent savageness of his nature was thoroughly roused, he
1366: had found useful in many relations, especially in business. No one could
1367: have found out that he was not at his ease. "My opinion," he replied,
1368: "is in a state of balance at present. This division of the county, you
1369: are aware, contains one manufacturing town of the first magnitude, and
1370: several smaller ones. The manufacturing interest is widely dispersed. So
1371: far--a--there is a presumption--a--in favor of the two Liberal
1372: candidates. Still, with a careful canvass of the agricultural districts,
1373: such as those we have round us at Treby Magna, I think--a--the
1374: auguries--a--would not be unfavorable to the return of a Conservative. A
1375: fourth candidate of good position, who should coalesce with Mr.
1376: Debarry--a----"
1377: 
1378: Here Mr. Jermyn hesitated for the third time, and Harold broke in.
1379: 
1380: "That will not be my line of action, so we need not discuss it. If I put
1381: up it will be as a Radical; and I fancy, in any county that would return
1382: Whigs there would be plenty of voters to be combed off by a Radical who
1383: offered himself with good pretensions."
1384: 
1385: There was the slightest possible quiver discernible across Jermyn's
1386: face. Otherwise he sat as he had done before, with his eyes fixed
1387: abstractedly on the frill of a ham before him, and his hand trifling
1388: with his fork. He did not answer immediately, but, when he did, he
1389: looked round steadily at Harold.
1390: 
1391: "I'm delighted to perceive that you have kept yourself so thoroughly
1392: acquainted with English politics."
1393: 
1394: "Oh, of course," said Harold, impatiently. "I'm aware how things have
1395: been going on in England. I always meant to come back ultimately. I
1396: suppose I know the state of Europe as well as if I'd been stationary at
1397: Little Treby for the last fifteen years. If a man goes to the East,
1398: people seem to think he gets turned into something like the one-eyed
1399: calender in the 'Arabian Nights!'"
1400: 
1401: "Yet I should think there are some things which people who have been
1402: stationary at Little Treby could tell you, Harold," said Mrs. Transome.
1403: "It did not signify about your holding Radical opinions at Smyrna; but
1404: you seem not to imagine how your putting up as a Radical will affect
1405: your position here, and the position of your family. No one will visit
1406: you. And then--the sort of people who will support you! You really have
1407: no idea what an impression it conveys when you say you are a Radical.
1408: There are none of our equals who will not feel that you have disgraced
1409: yourself."
1410: 
1411: "Pooh!" said Harold, rising and walking along the room.
1412: 
1413: But Mrs. Transome went on with growing anger in her voice--"It seems to
1414: me that a man owes something to his birth and station, and has no right
1415: to take up this notion or other, just as it suits his fancy; still less
1416: to work at the overthrow of his class. That was what every one said of
1417: Lord Grey, and my family at least is as good as Lord Grey's. You have
1418: wealth now, and might distinguish yourself in the county; and if you had
1419: been true to your colors as a gentleman, you would have had all the
1420: greater opportunity, because the times are so bad. The Debarrys and Lord
1421: Wyvern would have set all the more store by you. For my part, I can't
1422: conceive what good you propose to yourself. I only entreat you to think
1423: again before you take any decided step."
1424: 
1425: "Mother," said Harold, not angrily or with any raising of his voice, but
1426: in a quick, impatient manner, as if the scene must be got through as
1427: quickly as possible; "it is natural that you should think in this way.
1428: Women, very properly, don't change their views, but keep to the notions
1429: in which they have been brought up. It doesn't signify what they
1430: think--they are not called upon to judge or to act. You must leave me to
1431: take my own course in these matters, which properly belong to men.
1432: Beyond that, I will gratify any wish you may choose to mention. You
1433: shall have a new carriage and a pair of bays all to yourself; you shall
1434: have the house done up in first-rate style, and I am not thinking of
1435: marrying. But let us understand that there shall be no further collision
1436: between us on subjects on which I must be master of my own actions."
1437: 
1438: "And you will put the crown to the mortifications of my life, Harold. I
1439: don't know who would be a mother if she could foresee what a slight
1440: thing she will be to her son when she is old."
1441: 
1442: Mrs. Transome here walked out of the room by the nearest way--the glass
1443: door open toward the terrace. Mr. Jermyn had risen too, and his hands
1444: were on the back of his chair. He looked quite impassive: it was not the
1445: first time he had seen Mrs. Transome angry; but now, for the first time,
1446: he thought the outburst of her temper would be useful to him. She, poor
1447: woman, knew quite well that she had been unwise, and that she had been
1448: making herself disagreeable to Harold to no purpose. But half the
1449: sorrows of women would be averted if they could repress the speech they
1450: know to be useless--nay, the speech they have resolved not to utter.
1451: Harold continued his walking a moment longer, and then said to Jermyn--
1452: 
1453: "You smoke?"
1454: 
1455: "No, I always defer to the ladies. Mrs. Jermyn is peculiarly sensitive
1456: in such matters, and doesn't like tobacco."
1457: 
1458: Harold, who, underneath all the tendencies which had made him a Liberal,
1459: had intense personal pride, thought, "Confound the fellow--with his Mrs.
1460: Jermyn! Does he think we are on a footing for me to know anything about
1461: his wife?"
1462: 
1463: "Well, I took my hookah before breakfast," he said aloud, "so, if you
1464: like, we'll go into the library. My father never gets up till midday, I
1465: find."
1466: 
1467: "Sit down, sit down," said Harold, as they entered the handsome,
1468: spacious library. But he himself continued to stand before a map of the
1469: county which he had opened from a series of rollers occupying a
1470: compartment among the bookshelves. "The first question, Mr. Jermyn, now
1471: you know my intentions, is, whether you will undertake to be my agent in
1472: this election, and help me through? There's no time to be lost, and I
1473: don't want to lose my chance, as I may not have another for seven years.
1474: I understand," he went on, flashing a look straight at Jermyn, "that you
1475: have not taken any conspicuous course in politics, and I know that
1476: Labron is agent for the Debarrys."
1477: 
1478: "Oh--a--my dear sir--a man necessarily has his political convictions,
1479: but of what use is it for a professional man--a--of some education, to
1480: talk of them in a little country town? There really is no comprehension
1481: of public questions in such places. Party feeling, indeed, was quite
1482: asleep here before the agitation about the Catholic Relief Bill. It is
1483: true that I concurred with our incumbent in getting up a petition
1484: against the Reform Bill, but I did not state my reasons. The weak points
1485: in that Bill are--a--too palpable, and I fancy you and I should not
1486: differ much on that head. The fact is, when I knew that you were to come
1487: back to us, I kept myself in reserve, though I was much pressed by the
1488: friends of Sir James Clement, the Ministerial candidate, who is----"
1489: 
1490: "However, you will act for me--that's settled?" said Harold.
1491: 
1492: "Certainly," said Jermyn, inwardly irritated by Harold's rapid manner of
1493: cutting him short.
1494: 
1495: "Which of the Liberal candidates, as they call themselves, has the
1496: better chance, eh?"
1497: 
1498: "I was going to observe that Sir James Clement has not so good a
1499: chance as Mr. Garstin, supposing that a third Liberal candidate
1500: presents himself. There are two senses in which a politician can be
1501: liberal"--here Mr. Jermyn smiled--"Sir James Clement is a poor baronet,
1502: hoping for an appointment, and can't be expected to be liberal in that
1503: wider sense which commands majorities."
1504: 
1505: "I wish this man were not so much of a talker," thought Harold, "he'll
1506: bore me. We shall see," he said aloud, "what can be done in the way of
1507: combination. I'll come down to your office after one o'clock if it will
1508: suit you?"
1509: 
1510: "Perfectly."
1511: 
1512: "Ah, and you'll have all the lists and papers and necessary information
1513: ready for me there. I must get up a dinner for the tenants, and we can
1514: invite whom we like besides the tenants. Just now, I'm going over one of
1515: the farms on hand with the bailiff. By the way, that's a desperately bad
1516: business, having three farms unlet--how comes that about, eh?"
1517: 
1518: "That is precisely what I wanted to say a few words about to you. You
1519: have observed already how strongly Mrs. Transome takes certain things to
1520: heart. You can imagine that she has been severely tried in many ways.
1521: Mr. Transome's want of health; Mr. Durfey's habits--a----"
1522: 
1523: "Yes, yes."
1524: 
1525: "She is a woman for whom I naturally entertain the highest respect, and
1526: she has had hardly any gratification for many years, except the sense of
1527: having affairs to a certain extent in her own hands. She objects to
1528: changes; she will not have a new style of tenants; she likes the old
1529: stock of farmers who milk their own cows, and send their younger
1530: daughters out to service: all this makes it difficult to do the best
1531: with the estate. I am aware things are not as they ought to be, for, in
1532: point of fact, improved agricultural management is a matter in which I
1533: take considerable interest, and the farm which I myself hold on the
1534: estate you will see, I think, to be in a superior condition. But Mrs.
1535: Transome is a woman of strong feeling, and I would urge you, my dear
1536: sir, to make the changes which you have, but which I had not the right
1537: to insist on, as little painful to her as possible."
1538: 
1539: "I shall know what to do, sir, never fear," said Harold, much offended.
1540: 
1541: "You will pardon, I hope, a perhaps undue freedom of suggestion from a
1542: man of my age, who has been so long in a close connection with the
1543: family affairs--a--I have never considered that connection simply in a
1544: light of business--a----"
1545: 
1546: "Damn him, I'll soon let him know that _I_ do," thought Harold. But in
1547: proportion as he found Jermyn's manners annoying, he felt the necessity
1548: of controlling himself. He despised all persons who defeated their own
1549: projects by the indulgence of momentary impulses.
1550: 
1551: "I understand, I understand," he said aloud. "You've had more awkward
1552: business on your hands than usually falls to the share of a family
1553: lawyer. We shall set everything right by degrees. But now as to the
1554: canvassing. I've made arrangements with a first-rate man in London, who
1555: understands these matters thoroughly--a solicitor, of course--he has
1556: carried no end of men into Parliament. I'll engage him to meet us at
1557: Duffield--say when?"
1558: 
1559: The conversation after this was driven carefully clear of all angles,
1560: and ended with determined amicableness. When Harold, in his ride an hour
1561: or two afterward, encountered his uncle shouldering a gun, and followed
1562: by one black and one liver-spotted pointer, his muscular person with its
1563: red eagle face set off by a velveteen jacket and leather leggings, Mr.
1564: Lingon's first question was--
1565: 
1566: "Well, lad, how have you got on with Jermyn?"
1567: 
1568: "Oh, I don't think I shall like the fellow. He's a sort of amateur
1569: gentleman. But I must make use of him. I expect whatever I get out of
1570: him will only be something short of fair pay for what he has got out of
1571: us. But I shall see."
1572: 
1573: "Ay, ay, use his gun to bring down your game, and after that, beat the
1574: thief with the butt end. That's wisdom and justice and pleasure all in
1575: one--talking between ourselves as uncle and nephew. But I say, Harold, I
1576: was going to tell you, now I come to think of it, this is rather a
1577: nasty business, your calling yourself a Radical. I've been turning it
1578: over in after-dinner speeches, but it looks awkward--it's not what
1579: people are used to--it wants a good deal of Latin to make it go down. I
1580: shall be worried about it at the sessions, and I can think of nothing
1581: neat enough to carry about in my pocket by way of answer."
1582: 
1583: "Nonsense, uncle! I remember what a good speechifier you always were;
1584: you'll never be at a loss. You only want a few more evenings to think of
1585: it."
1586: 
1587: "But you'll not be attacking the Church and the institutions of the
1588: country--you'll not be going those lengths; you'll keep up the bulwarks,
1589: and so on, eh?"
1590: 
1591: "No, I shan't attack the Church, only the incomes of the bishops,
1592: perhaps, to make them eke out the incomes of the poor clergy."
1593: 
1594: "Well, well, I have no objection to that. Nobody likes our bishop: he's
1595: all Greek and greediness; too proud to dine with his own father. You may
1596: pepper the bishops a little. But you'll respect the constitution handed
1597: down, etc.--and you'll rally round the throne--and the King, God bless
1598: him, and the usual toasts, eh?"
1599: 
1600: "Of course, of course. I am a Radical only in rooting out abuses."
1601: 
1602: "That's the word I wanted, my lad!" said the vicar, slapping Harold's
1603: knee. "That's a spool to wind a speech on. Abuses is the very word; and
1604: if anybody shows himself offended, he'll put the cap on for himself."
1605: 
1606: "I remove the rotten timbers," said Harold, inwardly amused, "and
1607: substitute fresh oak, that's all."
1608: 
1609: "Well done, my boy! By George, you'll be a speaker! But I say, Harold, I
1610: hope you've got a little Latin left. This young Debarry is a tremendous
1611: fellow at the classics, and walks on stilts to any length. He's one of
1612: the new Conservatives. Old Sir Maximus doesn't understand him at all."
1613: 
1614: "That won't do at the hustings," said Harold. "He'll get knocked off his
1615: stilts pretty quickly there."
1616: 
1617: "Bless me! it's astonishing how well you're up in the affairs of the
1618: country, my boy. But rub up a few quotations--'_Quod turpe bonis decebat
1619: Crispinum_'--and that sort of thing--just to show Debarry what you could
1620: do if you liked. But you want to ride on?"
1621: 
1622: "Yes; I have an appointment at Treby. Good-bye."
1623: 
1624: "He's a cleverish chap," muttered the vicar, as Harold rode away. "When
1625: he's had plenty of English exercise, and brought out his knuckle a bit,
1626: he'll be a Lingon again as he used to be. I must go and see how Arabella
1627: takes his being a Radical. It's a little awkward; but a clergyman must
1628: keep peace in a family. Confound it! I'm not bound to love Toryism
1629: better than my own flesh and blood, and the manor I shoot over. That's a
1630: heathenish, Brutus-like sort of thing, as if Providence couldn't take
1631: care of the country without my quarrelling with my own sister's son!"
1632: 
1633: 
1634: 
1635: 
1636: CHAPTER III.
1637: 
1638:     'Twas town, yet country too: you felt the warmth
1639:     Of clustering houses in the wintry time:
1640:     Supped with a friend, and went by lantern home.
1641:     Yet from your chamber window you could hear
1642:     The tiny bleat of new-yeaned lambs, or see
1643:     The children bend beside the hedgerow banks
1644:     To pluck the primroses.
1645: 
1646: 
1647: Treby Magna, on which the Reform Bill had thrust the new honor of being
1648: a polling-place, had been, at the beginning of the century, quite a
1649: typical old market-town, lying in pleasant sleepiness among green
1650: pastures, with a rush-fringed river meandering through them. Its
1651: principal street had various handsome and tall-windowed brick houses
1652: with walled gardens behind them; and at the end, where it widened into
1653: the market-place, there was the cheerful rough-stuccoed front of that
1654: excellent inn, the Marquis of Granby, where the farmers put up their
1655: gigs, not only on fair and market days, but on exceptional Sundays when
1656: they came to church. And the church was one of those fine old English
1657: structures worth travelling to see, standing in a broad churchyard with
1658: a line of solemn yew-trees beside it, and lifting a majestic tower and
1659: spire far above the red-and-purple roofs of the town. It was not large
1660: enough to hold all the parishioners of a parish which stretched over
1661: distant villages and hamlets; but then they were never so unreasonable
1662: as to wish to be all in at once, and had never complained that the space
1663: of a large side-chapel was taken up by the tombs of the Debarrys, and
1664: shut in by a handsome iron screen. For when the black Benedictines
1665: ceased to pray and chant in this church, when the Blessed Virgin and St.
1666: Gregory were expelled, the Debarrys, as lords of the manor, naturally
1667: came next to Providence and took the place of the saints. Long before
1668: that time, indeed, there had been a Sir Maximus Debarry who had been at
1669: the fortifying of the old castle, which now stood in ruins in the midst
1670: of the green pastures, and with its sheltering wall toward the north
1671: made an excellent strawyard for the pigs of Wace & Co., brewers of the
1672: celebrated Treby beer. Wace & Co. did not stand alone in the town as
1673: prosperous traders on a large scale, to say nothing of those who had
1674: retired from business; and in no country town of the same small size as
1675: Treby was there a larger proportion of families who had handsome sets of
1676: china without handles, hereditary punch-bowls, and large silver ladles
1677: with a Queen Anne's guinea in the centre. Such people naturally took tea
1678: and supped together frequently; and as there was no professional man or
1679: tradesman in Treby who was not connected by business, if not by blood,
1680: with the farmers of the district, the richer sort of these were much
1681: invited, and gave invitations in their turn. They played at whist, ate
1682: and drank generously, praised Mr. Pitt and the war as keeping up prices
1683: and religion, and were very humorous about each other's property, having
1684: much the same coy pleasure in allusions to their secret ability to
1685: purchase, as blushing lasses sometimes have in jokes about their secret
1686: preferences. The rector was always of the Debarry family, associated
1687: only with county people, and was much respected for his affability; a
1688: clergyman who would have taken tea with the townspeople would have given
1689: a dangerous shock to the mind of a Treby churchman.
1690: 
1691: Such was the old-fashioned, grazing, brewing, wool-packing,
1692: cheese-loading life of Treby Magna, until there befell new conditions,
1693: complicating its relation with the rest of the world, and gradually
1694: awakening in it that higher consciousness which is known to bring higher
1695: pains. First came the canal; next, the working of the coal-mines at
1696: Sproxton, two miles off the town; and thirdly, the discovery of a saline
1697: spring, which suggested to a too constructive brain the possibility of
1698: turning Treby Magna into a fashionable watering-place. So daring an idea
1699: was not originated by a native Trebian, but by a young lawyer who came
1700: from a distance, knew the dictionary by heart, and was probably an
1701: illegitimate son of somebody or other. The idea, although it promised an
1702: increase of wealth to the town, was not well received at first; ladies
1703: objected to seeing "objects" drawn about in hand-carriages, the doctor
1704: foresaw the advent of unsound practitioners, and most retail tradesmen
1705: concurred with him that new doings were usually for the advantage of new
1706: people. The more unanswerable reasoners urged that Treby had prospered
1707: without baths, and it was yet to be seen how it would prosper with them;
1708: while a report that the proposed name for them was Bethesda Spa,
1709: threatened to give the whole affair a blasphemous aspect. Even Sir
1710: Maximus Debarry, who was to have an unprecedented return for the
1711: thousands he would lay out on a pump-room and hotel, regarded the thing
1712: as a little too new, and held back for some time. But the persuasive
1713: powers of the young lawyer, Mr. Matthew Jermyn, together with the
1714: opportune opening of a stone-quarry, triumphed at last; the handsome
1715: buildings were erected, an excellent guide-book and descriptive cards,
1716: surmounted by vignettes, were printed, and Treby Magna became conscious
1717: of certain facts in its own history of which it had previously been in
1718: contented ignorance.
1719: 
1720: But it was all in vain. The Spa, for some mysterious reason, did not
1721: succeed. Some attributed the failure to the coal-mines and the canal;
1722: others to the peace, which had had ruinous effects on the country; and
1723: others, who disliked Jermyn, to the original folly of the plan. Among
1724: these last was Sir Maximus himself, who never forgave the too persuasive
1725: attorney: it was Jermyn's fault not only that a useless hotel had been
1726: built, but that he, Sir Maximus, being straitened for money, had at last
1727: let the building, with the adjacent land lying on the river, on a long
1728: lease, on the supposition that it was to be turned into a tape
1729: manufactory--a bitter thing to any gentleman, and especially to the
1730: representative of one of the oldest families in England.
1731: 
1732: In this way it happened that Treby Magna gradually passed from being
1733: simply a respectable market town--the heart of a great rural district,
1734: where the trade was only such as had close relations with the local
1735: landed interest--and took on the more complex life brought by mines and
1736: manufactures, which belong more directly to the great circulating system
1737: of the nation than to the local system to which they had been
1738: superadded; and in this way it was that Trebian Dissent gradually
1739: altered its character. Formerly it had been of a quiescent, well-to-do
1740: kind, represented architecturally by a small, venerable, dark-pewed
1741: chapel, built by Presbyterians, but long occupied by a sparse
1742: congregation of Independents, who were as little moved by doctrinal zeal
1743: as their church-going neighbors, and did not feel themselves deficient
1744: in religious liberty, inasmuch as they were not hindered from
1745: occasionally slumbering in their pews, and were not obliged to go
1746: regularly to the weekly prayer-meeting. But when stone-pits and
1747: coal-pits made new hamlets that threatened to spread up to the very
1748: town, when the tape-weavers came with their news-reading inspectors and
1749: book-keepers, the Independent chapel began to be filled with eager men
1750: and women, to whom the exceptional possession of religious truth was the
1751: condition which reconciled them to a meagre existence, and made them
1752: feel in secure alliance with the unseen but supreme rule of a world in
1753: which their own visible part was small. There were Dissenters in Treby
1754: now who could not be regarded by the Church people in the light of old
1755: neighbors to whom the habit of going to chapel was an innocent,
1756: unenviable inheritance along with a particular house and garden, a
1757: tan-yard, or a grocery business--Dissenters who, in their turn, without
1758: meaning to be in the least abusive, spoke of the high-bred rector as a
1759: blind leader of the blind. And Dissent was not the only thing that the
1760: times had altered; prices had fallen, poor-rates had risen, rent and
1761: tithe were not elastic enough, and the farmer's fat sorrow had become
1762: lean; he began to speculate on causes, and to trace things back to that
1763: causeless mystery, the cessation of one-pound notes. Thus, when
1764: political agitation swept in a current through the country, Treby Magna
1765: was prepared to vibrate. The Catholic Emancipation Bill opened the eyes
1766: of neighbors and made them aware how very injurious they were to each
1767: other and to the welfare of mankind generally. Mr. Tiliot, the Church
1768: spirit-merchant, knew now that Mr. Nuttwood, the obliging grocer, was
1769: one of those Dissenters, Deists, Socinians, Papists, and Radicals, who
1770: were in league to destroy the Constitution. A retired old London
1771: tradesman, who was believed to understand politics, said that thinking
1772: people must wish George III were alive again in all his early vigor of
1773: mind: and even the farmers became less materialistic in their view of
1774: causes, and referred much to the agency of the devil and the Irish
1775: Romans. The rector, the Reverend Augustus Debarry, really a fine
1776: specimen of the old-fashioned aristocratic clergyman, preaching short
1777: sermons, understanding business, and acting liberally about his tithe,
1778: had never before found himself in collision with Dissenters; but now he
1779: began to feel that these people were a nuisance in the parish, that his
1780: brother Sir Maximus must take care lest they should get land to build
1781: more chapels, and that it might not have been a bad thing if the law had
1782: furnished him as a magistrate with a power of putting a stop to the
1783: political sermons of the Independent preacher, which, in their way,
1784: were as pernicious sources of intoxication as the beerhouses. The
1785: Dissenters, on their side, were not disposed to sacrifice the cause of
1786: truth and freedom to a temporizing mildness of language; but they
1787: defended themselves from the charge of religious indifference, and
1788: solemnly disclaimed any lax expectations that Catholics were likely to
1789: be saved--urging, on the contrary, that they were not too hopeful about
1790: Protestants who adhered to a bloated and worldly Prelacy. Thus Treby
1791: Magna, which had lived quietly through the great earthquakes of the
1792: French Revolution and the Napoleonic wars, which had remained unmoved by
1793: the "Rights of Man," and saw little in Mr. Cobbett's "Weekly Register"
1794: except that he held eccentric views about potatoes, began at last to
1795: know the higher pains of a dim political consciousness; and the
1796: development had been greatly helped by the recent agitation about the
1797: Reform Bill. Tory, Whig, and Radical did not perhaps become clearer in
1798: their definition of each other; but the names seemed to acquire so
1799: strong a stamp of honor or infamy, that definitions would only have
1800: weakened the impression. As to the short and easy method of judging
1801: opinions by the personal character of those who held them, it was liable
1802: to be much frustrated in Treby. It so happened in that particular town
1803: that the Reformers were not all of them large-hearted patriots or ardent
1804: lovers of justice; indeed, one of them, in the very midst of the
1805: agitation, was detected in using unequal scales--a fact to which many
1806: Tories pointed with disgust as showing plainly enough, without further
1807: argument, that the cry for a change in the representative system was
1808: hollow trickery. Again, the Tories were far from being all oppressors,
1809: disposed to grind down the working classes into serfdom; and it was
1810: undeniable that the inspector at the tape manufactory, who spoke with
1811: much eloquence on the extension of the suffrage, was a more tyrannical
1812: personage than open-handed Mr. Wace, whose chief political tenet was
1813: that it was all nonsense to give men votes when they had no stake in the
1814: country. On the other hand there were some Tories who gave themselves a
1815: great deal of leisure to abuse hypocrites, Radicals, Dissenters, and
1816: atheism generally, but whose inflamed faces, theistic swearing, and
1817: frankness in expressing a wish to borrow, certainly did not mark them
1818: out strongly as holding opinions likely to save society.
1819: 
1820: The Reformers had triumphed: it was clear that the wheels were going
1821: whither they were pulling, and they were in fine spirits for exertion.
1822: But if they were pulling toward the country's ruin, there was the more
1823: need for others to hang on behind and get the wheels to stick if
1824: possible. In Treby, as elsewhere, people were told they must "rally" at
1825: the coming election; but there was now a large number of waverers--men
1826: of flexible, practical minds, who were not such bigots as to cling to
1827: any views when a good tangible reason could be urged against them; while
1828: some regarded it as the most neighborly thing to hold a little with both
1829: sides, and were not sure that they should rally or vote at all. It
1830: seemed an invidious thing to vote for one gentleman rather than another.
1831: 
1832: These social changes in Treby parish are comparatively public matters,
1833: and this history is chiefly concerned with the private lot of a few men
1834: and women; but there is no private life which has not been determined by
1835: a wider public life, from the time when the primeval milkmaid had to
1836: wander with the wanderings of her clan, because the cow she milked was
1837: one of a herd which had made the pastures bare. Even in that
1838: conservatory existence where the fair Camellia is sighed for by the
1839: noble young Pine-apple, neither of them needing to care about the frost,
1840: or rain outside, there is a nether apparatus of hot water pipes liable
1841: to cool down on a strike of the gardeners or a scarcity of coal. And the
1842: lives we are about to look back upon do not belong to those conservatory
1843: species; they are rooted in the common earth, having to endure all the
1844: ordinary chances of past and present weather. As to the weather of 1832,
1845: the Zadkiel of that time had predicted that the electrical condition of
1846: the clouds in the political hemisphere would produce unusual
1847: perturbations in organic existence, and he would perhaps have seen a
1848: fulfillment of his remarkable prophecy in that mutual influence of
1849: dissimilar destinies which we shall see gradually unfolding itself. For
1850: if the mixed political conditions of Treby Magna had not been acted on
1851: by the passing of the Reform Bill, Mr. Harold Transome would not have
1852: presented himself as a candidate for North Loamshire, Treby would not
1853: have been a polling-place, Mr. Matthew Jermyn would not have been on
1854: affable terms with a Dissenting preacher and his flock, and the
1855: venerable town would not have been placarded with handbills, more or
1856: less complimentary and retrospective--conditions in this case essential
1857: to the "where," and the "what," without which, as the learned know,
1858: there can be no event whatever.
1859: 
1860: For example, it was through these conditions that a young man named
1861: Felix Holt made a considerable difference in the life of Harold
1862: Transome, though nature and fortune seemed to have done what they could
1863: to keep the lots of the two men quite aloof from each other. Felix was
1864: heir to nothing better than a quack medicine; his mother lived up a back
1865: street in Treby Magna, and her sitting-room was ornamented with her best
1866: tea-tray and several framed testimonials to the virtues of Holt's
1867: Cathartic Lozenges and Holt's Restorative Elixir. There could hardly
1868: have been a lot less like Harold Transome's than this of the quack
1869: doctor's son, except in the superficial facts that he called himself a
1870: Radical, that he was the only son of his mother, and that he had lately
1871: returned to his home with ideas and resolves not a little disturbing to
1872: that mother's mind.
1873: 
1874: But Mrs. Holt, unlike Mrs. Transome, was much disposed to reveal her
1875: troubles, and was not without a counsellor into whose ear she could pour
1876: them. On this second of September, when Mr. Harold Transome had had his
1877: first interview with Jermyn, and when the attorney went back to his
1878: office with new views of canvassing in his mind, Mrs. Holt had put on
1879: her bonnet as early as nine o'clock in the morning, and had gone to see
1880: the Reverend Rufus Lyon, minister of the Independent Chapel usually
1881: spoken of as "Malthouse Yard."
1882: 
1883: 
1884: 
1885: 
1886: CHAPTER IV.
1887: 
1888:     "A pious and painful preacher."--FULLER.
1889: 
1890: 
1891: Mr. Lyon lived in a small house, not quite so good as the parish
1892: clerk's, adjoining the entry which led to the Chapel Yard. The new
1893: prosperity of Dissent at Treby had led to an enlargement of the chapel,
1894: which absorbed all extra funds and left none for the enlargement of the
1895: minister's income. He sat this morning, as usual, in a low up-stairs
1896: room, called his study, which, by means of a closet capable of holding
1897: his bed, served also as a sleeping-room. The bookshelves did not suffice
1898: for his store of old books, which lay about him in piles so arranged as
1899: to leave narrow lanes between them; for the minister was much given to
1900: walking about during his hours of meditation, and very narrow passages
1901: would serve for his small legs, unencumbered by any other drapery than
1902: his black silk stockings and the flexible, though prominent, bows of
1903: black ribbon that tied his knee-breeches. He was walking about now, with
1904: his hands clasped behind him, an attitude in which his body seemed to
1905: bear about the same proportion to his head as the lower part of a stone
1906: Hermes bears to the carven image that crowns it. His face looked old and
1907: worn, yet the curtain of hair that fell from his bald crown and hung
1908: about his neck retained much of its original auburn tint, and his large,
1909: brown, short-sighted eyes were still clear and bright. At the first
1910: glance, every one thought him a very odd-looking rusty old man; the
1911: free-school boys often hooted after him, and called him "Revelations";
1912: and to many respectable Church people, old Lyon's little legs and large
1913: head seemed to make Dissent additionally preposterous. But he was too
1914: short-sighted to notice those who tittered at him--too absent from the
1915: world of small facts and petty impulses in which titterers live. With
1916: Satan to argue against on matters of vital experience as well as of
1917: church government, with great texts to meditate on, which seemed to get
1918: deeper as he tried to fathom them, it had never occurred to him to
1919: reflect what sort of image his small person made on the retina of a
1920: light-minded beholder. The good Rufus had his ire and his egoism; but
1921: they existed only as the red heat which gave force to his belief and his
1922: teaching. He was susceptible concerning the true office of deacons in
1923: the primitive Church, and his small nervous body was jarred from head to
1924: foot by the concussion of an argument to which he saw no answer. In
1925: fact, the only moments when he could be said to be really conscious of
1926: his body, were when he trembled under the pressure of some agitating
1927: thought.
1928: 
1929: He was meditating on the text for his Sunday morning sermon, "And all
1930: the people said, Amen"--a mere mustard-seed of a text, which had split
1931: at first only into two divisions, "What was said," and "Who said it";
1932: but these were growing into a many-branched discourse, and the
1933: preacher's eyes dilated, and a smile played about his mouth till, as his
1934: manner was, when he felt happily inspired, he had begun to utter his
1935: thoughts aloud in the varied measure and cadence habitual to him,
1936: changing from a rapid but distinct undertone to a loud emphatic
1937: _rallentando_.
1938: 
1939: "My brethren, do you think that great shout was raised in Israel by each
1940: man's waiting to say 'amen' till his neighbors had said amen? Do you
1941: think there will be a great shout for the right--the shout of a nation
1942: as of one man, rounded and whole, like the voice of the archangel that
1943: bound together all the listeners of earth and heaven--if every Christian
1944: of you peeps round to see what his neighbors in good coats are doing, or
1945: else puts his hat before his face that he may shout and never be heard?
1946: But this is what you do: when the servant of God stands up to deliver
1947: his message, do you lay your souls beneath the Word as you set out your
1948: plants beneath the falling rain? No; one of you sends his eyes to all
1949: corners, he smothers his soul with small questions, 'What does brother
1950: Y. think?' 'Is this doctrine high enough for brother Z.?' 'Will the
1951: church members be pleased?' And another----"
1952: 
1953: Here the door was opened, and old Lyddy, the minister's servant, put in
1954: her head to say, in a tone of despondency, finishing with a groan, "Here
1955: is Mrs. Holt wanting to speak to you; she says she comes out of season,
1956: but she's in trouble."
1957: 
1958: "Lyddy," said Mr. Lyon, falling at once into a quiet conversational
1959: tone, "if you are wrestling with the enemy, let me refer you to Ezekiel
1960: the thirteenth and twenty-second, and beg of you not to groan. It is a
1961: stumbling-block and offence to my daughter; she would take no broth
1962: yesterday, because she said you had cried into it. Thus you cause the
1963: truth to be lightly spoken of, and make the enemy rejoice. If your
1964: faceache gives him an advantage, take a little warm ale with your
1965: meat--I do not grudge the money."
1966: 
1967: "If I thought my drinking warm ale would hinder poor dear Miss Esther
1968: from speaking light--but she hates the smell of it."
1969: 
1970: "Answer not again, Lyddy, but send up Mistress Holt to me."
1971: 
1972: Lyddy closed the door immediately.
1973: 
1974: "I lack grace to deal with these weak sisters," said the minister, again
1975: thinking aloud, and walking. "Their needs lie too much out of the track
1976: of my meditations, and take me often unawares. Mistress Holt is another
1977: who darkens counsel by words without knowledge, and angers the reason of
1978: the natural man. Lord, give me patience. My sins were heavier to bear
1979: than this woman's folly. Come in, Mrs. Holt--come in."
1980: 
1981: He hastened to disencumber a chair of Matthew Henry's Commentary, and
1982: begged his visitor to be seated. She was a tall elderly woman, dressed
1983: in black, with a light-brown front and a black band over her forehead.
1984: She moved the chair a little and seated herself in it with some
1985: emphasis, looking fixedly at the opposite wall with a hurt and
1986: argumentative expression. Mr. Lyon had placed himself in the chair
1987: against his desk, and waited with the resolute resignation of a patient
1988: who is about to undergo an operation. But his visitor did not speak.
1989: 
1990: "You have something on your mind, Mrs. Holt?" he said, at last.
1991: 
1992: "Indeed I have, sir, else I shouldn't be here."
1993: 
1994: "Speak freely."
1995: 
1996: "It's well known to you, Mr. Lyon, that my husband, Mr. Holt, came from
1997: the north, and was a member in Malthouse Yard long before _you_ began
1998: to be pastor of it, which was seven year ago last Michaelmas. It's the
1999: truth, Mr. Lyon, and I'm not that woman to sit here and say it if it
2000: wasn't true."
2001: 
2002: "Certainly, it is true."
2003: 
2004: "And if my husband had been alive when you'd come to preach upon trial,
2005: he'd have been as good a judge of your gifts as Mr. Nuttwood or Mr.
2006: Muscat, though whether he'd have agreed with some that your doctrine
2007: wasn't high enough, I can't say. For myself, I've my opinion about high
2008: doctrine."
2009: 
2010: "Was it my preaching you came to speak about?" said the minister,
2011: hurrying in the question.
2012: 
2013: "No, Mr. Lyon, I'm not that woman. But this I _will_ say, for my husband
2014: died before your time, that he had a wonderful gift in prayer, as the
2015: old members well know, if anybody likes to ask 'em, not believing my
2016: words, and he believed himself that the receipt for the Cancer Cure,
2017: which I've sent out in bottles till this very last April before
2018: September as now is, and have bottles standing by me--he believed it was
2019: sent to him in answer to prayer; and nobody can deny it, for he prayed
2020: most regular, and read out of the green baize Bible."
2021: 
2022: Mrs. Holt paused, appearing to think that Mr. Lyon had been successfully
2023: confuted, and should show himself convinced.
2024: 
2025: "Has any one been aspersing your husband's character?" said Mr. Lyon,
2026: with a slight initiative toward that relief of groaning for which he had
2027: reproved Lyddy.
2028: 
2029: "Sir, they daredn't. For though he was a man of prayer, he didn't want
2030: skill and knowledge to find things out for himself; and that's what I
2031: used to say to _my_ friends when they wondered at my marrying a man from
2032: Lancashire, with no trade nor fortune, but what he'd got in his head.
2033: But my husband's tongue 'ud have been a fortune to anybody, and there
2034: was many a one said it was as good as a dose of physic to hear him talk;
2035: not but what that got him into trouble in Lancashire, but he always
2036: said, if the worst came to the worst, he could go and preach to the
2037: blacks. But he did better than that, Mr. Lyon, for he married me; and
2038: this I will say, that for age, and conduct, and managing----"
2039: 
2040: "Mistress Holt," interrupted the minister, "these are not the things
2041: whereby we may edify one another. Let me beg of you to be as brief as
2042: you can. My time is not my own."
2043: 
2044: "Well, Mr. Lyon, I've a right to my own character; and I'm one of your
2045: congregation, though I'm not a church member, for I was born in the
2046: General Baptist connection: and as for being saved without works,
2047: there's a many, I dare say, can't do without that doctrine; but I thank
2048: the Lord I never needed to put _my_self on a level with the thief on the
2049: cross. I've done _my_ duty, and more, if anybody comes to that; for I've
2050: gone without my bit of meat to make broth for a sick neighbor: and if
2051: there's any of the church members say they've done the same, I'd ask
2052: them if they had the sinking at the stomach as I have; for I've ever
2053: strove to do the right thing, and more, for good-natured I always was;
2054: and I little thought, after being respected by everybody, I should come
2055: to be reproached by my own son. And my husband said, when he was
2056: a-dying--'Mary,' he said, 'the Elixir, and the Pills, and the Cure will
2057: support you, for they've a great name in all the country round, and
2058: you'll pray for a blessing on them.' And so I've done, Mr. Lyon; and to
2059: say they're not good medicines, when they've been taken for fifty miles
2060: round by high and low, rich and poor, and nobody speaking against 'em
2061: but Dr. Lukin, it seems to me it's a flying in the face of Heaven; for
2062: if it was wrong to take the medicines, couldn't the blessed Lord have
2063: stopped it?"
2064: 
2065: Mrs. Holt was not given to tears; she was much sustained by conscious
2066: unimpeachableness, and by an argumentative tendency which usually checks
2067: the too great activity of the lachrymal gland; nevertheless her eyes had
2068: become moist, her fingers played on her knee in an agitated manner, and
2069: she finally plucked a bit of her gown and held it with great nicety
2070: between her thumb and finger. Mr. Lyon, however, by listening
2071: attentively, had begun partly to divine the source of her trouble.
2072: 
2073: "Am I wrong in gathering from what you say, Mistress Holt, that your son
2074: has objected in some way to your sale of your late husband's medicines?"
2075: 
2076: "Mr. Lyon, he's masterful beyond everything, and he talks more than his
2077: father did. I've got my reason, Mr. Lyon, and if anybody talks sense I
2078: can follow him; but Felix talks so wild, and contradicts his mother. And
2079: what do you think he says, after giving up his 'prenticeship, and going
2080: off to study at Glasgow, and getting through all the bit of money his
2081: father saved for his bringing-up--what has all his learning come to? He
2082: says I'd better never open my Bible, for it's as bad poison to me as the
2083: pills are to half the people as swallow 'em. You'll not speak of this
2084: again, Mr. Lyon--I don't think ill enough of you to believe _that_. For
2085: I suppose a Christian can understand the word o' God without going to
2086: Glasgow, and there's texts upon texts about ointment and medicine, and
2087: there's one as might have been for a receipt of my husband's--it's just
2088: as if it was a riddle, and Holt's Elixir was the answer."
2089: 
2090: "Your son uses rash words, Mistress Holt," said the minister, "but it is
2091: quite true that we may err in giving a too private interpretation to the
2092: Scripture. The word of God has to satisfy the larger needs of His
2093: people, like the rain and the sunshine--which no man must think to be
2094: meant for his own patch of seed-ground solely. Will it not be well that
2095: I should see your son, and talk with him on these matters? He was at
2096: chapel, I observe, and I suppose I am to be his pastor."
2097: 
2098: "That was what I wanted to ask you, Mr. Lyon. For perhaps he'll listen
2099: to you, and not talk you down as he does his poor mother. For after we'd
2100: been to chapel, he spoke better of you than he does of most: he said you
2101: was a fine old fellow, and an old-fashioned Puritan--he uses dreadful
2102: language, Mr. Lyon; but I saw he didn't mean you ill, for all that. He
2103: calls most folks's religion rottenness; and yet another time he'll tell
2104: me I ought to feel myself a sinner, and do God's will and not my own.
2105: But it's my belief he says first one thing and then another only to
2106: abuse his mother. Or else he's going off his head, and must be sent to a
2107: 'sylum. But if he writes to the _North Loamshire Herald_ first, to tell
2108: everybody the medicines are good for nothing, how can I ever keep him
2109: and myself?"
2110: 
2111: "Tell him I shall feel favored if he will come and see me this evening,"
2112: said Mr. Lyon, not without a little prejudice in favor of the young man,
2113: whose language about the preacher in Malthouse Yard did not seem to him
2114: to be altogether dreadful. "Meanwhile, my friend, I counsel you to send
2115: up a supplication, which I shall not fail to offer also, that you may
2116: receive a spirit of humility and submission, so that you may not be
2117: hindered from seeing and following the Divine guidance in this matter by
2118: any false lights of pride and obstinacy. Of this more when I have spoken
2119: with your son."
2120: 
2121: "I'm not proud or obstinate, Mr. Lyon. I never did say I was everything
2122: that was bad, and I never will. And why this trouble should be sent on
2123: me above everybody else--for I haven't told you all. He's made himself a
2124: journeyman to Mr. Prowd the watchmaker--after all this learning--and he
2125: says he'll go with patches on his knees, and he shall like himself the
2126: better. And as for him having little boys to teach, they'll come in all
2127: weathers with dirty shoes. If it's madness, Mr. Lyon, it's no use your
2128: talking to him."
2129: 
2130: "We shall see. Perhaps it may even be the disguised working of grace
2131: within him. We must not judge rashly. Many eminent servants of God have
2132: been led by ways as strange."
2133: 
2134: "Then I'm sorry for their mothers, that's all, Mr. Lyon; and all the
2135: more if they'd been well-spoken-on women. For not my biggest enemy,
2136: whether it's he or she, if they'll speak the truth, can turn round and
2137: say I've deserved this trouble. And when everybody gets their due, and
2138: people's doings are spoke of on the house-tops, as the Bible says they
2139: will be, it'll be known what I've gone through with those medicines--the
2140: pounding and the pouring, and the letting stand, and the weighing--up
2141: early and down late--there's nobody knows yet but One that's worthy to
2142: know; and the pasting o' the printed labels right side upwards. There's
2143: few women would have gone through with it; and it's reasonable to think
2144: it'll be made up to me; for if there's promised and purchased blessings,
2145: I should think this trouble is purchasing 'em. For if my son Felix
2146: doesn't have a strait-waistcoat put on him, he'll have his way. But I
2147: say no more. I wish you good-morning, Mr. Lyon, and thank you, though I
2148: well know it's your duty to act as you're doing. And I never troubled
2149: you about my own soul, as some do who look down on me for not being a
2150: church member."
2151: 
2152: "Farewell, Mistress Holt, farewell. I pray that a more powerful teacher
2153: than I am may instruct you."
2154: 
2155: The door was closed, and the much-tried Rufus walked about again, saying
2156: aloud, groaningly--
2157: 
2158: "This woman has sat under the Gospel all her life, and she is as blind
2159: as a heathen, and as proud and stiff-necked as a Pharisee; yet she is
2160: one of the souls I watch for. 'Tis true that even Sara, the chosen
2161: mother of God's people, showed a spirit of unbelief, and perhaps of
2162: selfish anger; and it is a passage that bears the unmistakable signet,
2163: 'doing honor to the wife or woman, as unto the weaker vessel.' For
2164: therein is the greatest check put on the ready scorn of the natural
2165: man."
2166: 
2167: 
2168: 
2169: 
2170: CHAPTER V.
2171: 
2172:     1ST CITIZEN. Sir, there's a hurry in the veins of youth
2173:                  That makes a vice of virtue by excess.
2174: 
2175:     2D CITIZEN.  What if the coolness of our tardier veins
2176:                  Be loss of virtue?
2177: 
2178:     1ST CITIZEN.                      All things cool with time--
2179:                  The sun itself, they say, till heat shall find
2180:                  A general level, nowhere in excess.
2181: 
2182:     2D CITIZEN.  'Tis a poor climax, to my weaker thought,
2183:                  That future middlingness.
2184: 
2185: 
2186: In the evening, when Mr. Lyon was expecting the knock at the door that
2187: would announce Felix Holt, he occupied his cushionless arm-chair in the
2188: sitting-room, and was skimming rapidly, in his short-sighted way, by the
2189: light of one candle, the pages of a missionary report, emitting
2190: occasionally a slight "Hm-m" that appeared to be expressive of criticism
2191: rather than of approbation. The room was dismally furnished, the only
2192: objects indicating an intention of ornament being a bookcase, a map of
2193: the Holy Land, an engraved portrait of Dr. Doddridge, and a black bust
2194: with a colored face, which for some reason or other was covered with
2195: green gauze. Yet any one whose attention was quite awake must have been
2196: aware, even on entering, of certain things that were incongruous with
2197: the general air of sombreness and privation. There was a delicate scent
2198: of dried rose-leaves; the light by which the minister was reading was a
2199: wax-candle in a white earthenware candle-stick, and the table on the
2200: opposite side of the fireplace held a dainty work-basket frilled with
2201: blue satin.
2202: 
2203: Felix Holt, when he entered, was not in an observant mood; and when,
2204: after seating himself, at the minister's invitation, near the little
2205: table which held the work-basket, he stared at the wax-candle opposite
2206: to him, he did so without any wonder or consciousness that the candle
2207: was not of tallow. But the minister's sensitiveness gave another
2208: interpretation to the gaze which he divined rather than saw; and in
2209: alarm lest this inconsistent extravagance should obstruct his
2210: usefulness, he hastened to say--
2211: 
2212: "You are doubtless amazed to see me with a wax-light, my young friend;
2213: but this undue luxury is paid for with the earnings of my daughter, who
2214: is so delicately framed that the smell of tallow is loathsome to her."
2215: 
2216: "I heeded not the candle, sir. I thank Heaven I am not a mouse to have a
2217: nose that takes note of wax or tallow."
2218: 
2219: The loud abrupt tones made the old man vibrate a little. He had been
2220: stroking his chin gently before, with a sense that he must be very
2221: quiet and deliberate in his treatment of the eccentric young man; but
2222: now, quite unreflectingly, he drew forth a pair of spectacles, which he
2223: was in the habit of using when he wanted to observe his interlocutor
2224: more closely than usual.
2225: 
2226: "And I myself, in fact, am equally indifferent," he said, as he opened
2227: and adjusted his glasses, "so that I have a sufficient light on my
2228: book." Here his large eyes looked discerningly through the spectacles.
2229: 
2230: "'Tis the quality of the page you care about, not of the candle," said
2231: Felix, smiling pleasantly enough at his inspector. "You're thinking that
2232: you have a roughly-written page before you now."
2233: 
2234: That was true. The minister, accustomed to the respectable air of
2235: provincial townsmen, and especially to the sleek well-clipped gravity of
2236: his own male congregation, felt a slight shock as his glasses made
2237: perfectly clear to him the shaggy-headed, large-eyed, strong-limbed
2238: person of this questionable young man, without waistcoat or cravat. But
2239: the possibility, supported by some of Mrs. Holt's words, that a
2240: disguised work of grace might be going on in the son of whom she
2241: complained so bitterly, checked any hasty interpretations.
2242: 
2243: "I abstain from judging by the outward appearance only," he answered,
2244: with his usual simplicity. "I myself have experienced that when the
2245: spirit is much exercised it is difficult to remember neck-bands and
2246: strings and such small accidents of our vesture, which are nevertheless
2247: decent and needful so long as we sojourn in the flesh. And you, too, my
2248: young friend, as I gather from your mother's troubled and confused
2249: report, are undergoing some travail of mind. You will not, I trust,
2250: object to open yourself fully to me, as to an aged pastor who has
2251: himself had much inward wrestling, and has especially known much
2252: temptation from doubt."
2253: 
2254: "As to doubt," said Felix, loudly and brusquely as before, "if it is
2255: those absurd medicines and gulling advertisements that my mother has
2256: been talking of to you--and I suppose it is--I've no more doubt about
2257: _them_ than I have about pocket-picking. I know there's a stage of
2258: speculation in which a man may doubt whether a pickpocket is
2259: blameworthy--but I'm not one of your subtle fellows who keep looking at
2260: the world through their own legs. If I allowed the sale of those
2261: medicines to go on, and my mother to live out of the proceeds when I can
2262: keep her by the honest labor of my hands, I've not the least doubt that
2263: I should be a rascal."
2264: 
2265: "I would fain enquire more particularly into your objection to these
2266: medicines," said Mr. Lyon, gravely. Notwithstanding his
2267: conscientiousness and a certain originality in his own mental
2268: disposition, he was too little used to high principle quite dissociated
2269: from sectarian phraseology to be as immediately in sympathy with it as
2270: he would otherwise have been. "I know they have been well reported of,
2271: and many wise persons have tried remedies providentially discovered by
2272: those who are not regular physicians, and have found a blessing in the
2273: use of them. I may mention the eminent Mr. Wesley, who, though I hold
2274: not altogether with his Arminian doctrine, nor with the usages of his
2275: institutions, was nevertheless a man of God; and the journals of various
2276: Christians whose names have left a sweet savor, might be cited in the
2277: same sense. Moreover, your father, who originally concocted these
2278: medicines and left them as a provision for your mother, was, as I
2279: understand, a man whose walk was not unfaithful."
2280: 
2281: "My father was ignorant," said Felix, bluntly. "He knew neither the
2282: complication of the human system, nor the way in which drugs counteract
2283: each other. Ignorance is not so damnable as humbug, but when it
2284: prescribes pills it may happen to do more harm. I know something about
2285: these things. I was 'prentice for five miserable years to a stupid brute
2286: of a country apothecary--my poor father left money for that--he thought
2287: nothing could be finer for me. No matter: I know that the Cathartic
2288: Pills are a drastic compound which may be as bad as poison to half the
2289: people who swallow them; that the Elixir is an absurd farrago of a dozen
2290: incompatible things; and that the Cancer Cure might as well be bottled
2291: ditch-water."
2292: 
2293: Mr. Lyon rose and walked up and down the room. His simplicity was
2294: strongly mixed with sagacity as well as sectarian prejudice, and he did
2295: not rely at once on a loud-spoken integrity--Satan might have flavored
2296: it with ostentation. Presently he asked, in a rapid, low tone, "How long
2297: have you known this, young man?"
2298: 
2299: "Well put, sir," said Felix. "I've known it a good deal longer than I
2300: have acted upon it, like plenty of other things. But you believe in
2301: conversion?"
2302: 
2303: "Yea, verily."
2304: 
2305: "So do I. I was converted by six weeks' debauchery."
2306: 
2307: The minister started. "Young man," he said, solemnly, going up close to
2308: Felix and laying a hand on his shoulder, "speak not lightly of the
2309: Divine operations, and restrain unseemly words."
2310: 
2311: "I'm not speaking lightly," said Felix. "If I had not seen that I was
2312: making a hog of myself very fast, and that pig-wash, even if I could
2313: have got plenty of it, was a poor sort of thing, I should never have
2314: looked life fairly in the face to see what was to be done with it. I
2315: laughed out loud at last to think that a poor devil like me, in a Scotch
2316: garret, with my stockings out at heel and a shilling or two to be
2317: dissipated upon, with a smell of raw haggis mounting from below, and old
2318: women breathing gin as they passed me on the stairs--wanting to turn my
2319: life into easy pleasure. Then I began to see what else it could be
2320: turned into. Not much, perhaps. This world is not a very fine place for
2321: a good many of the people in it. But I've made up my mind it shan't be
2322: the worse for me, if I can help it. They may tell me I can't alter the
2323: world--that there must be a certain number of sneaks and robbers in it,
2324: and if I don't lie and filch somebody else will. Well then, somebody
2325: else shall, for I won't. That's the upshot of my conversion, Mr. Lyon,
2326: if you want to know it."
2327: 
2328: Mr. Lyon removed his hand from Felix's shoulder and walked about again.
2329: "Did you sit under any preacher at Glasgow, young man?"
2330: 
2331: "No: I heard most of the preachers once, but I never wanted to hear them
2332: twice."
2333: 
2334: The good Rufus was not without a slight rising of resentment at this
2335: young man's want of reverence. It was not yet plain whether he wanted to
2336: hear twice the preacher in Malthouse Yard. But the resentful feeling was
2337: carefully repressed: a soul in so peculiar a condition must be dealt
2338: with delicately.
2339: 
2340: "And now, may I ask," he said, "what course you mean to take, after
2341: hindering your mother from making and selling these drugs? I speak no
2342: more in their favor after what you have said. God forbid that I should
2343: strive to hinder you from seeking whatsoever things are honest and
2344: honorable. But your mother is advanced in years; she needs comfortable
2345: sustenance; you have doubtless considered how you may make her amends?
2346: 'He that provideth not for his own----' I trust you respect the
2347: authority that so speaks. And I will not suppose that, after being
2348: tender of conscience toward strangers, you will be careless toward your
2349: mother. There be indeed some who, taking a mighty charge on their
2350: shoulder, must perforce leave their households to Providence, and to the
2351: care of humbler brethren, but in such a case the call must be clear."
2352: 
2353: "I shall keep my mother as well--nay, better--than she has kept herself.
2354: She has always been frugal. With my watch and clock cleaning, and
2355: teaching one or two little chaps that I've got to come to me, I can earn
2356: enough. As for me, I can live on bran porridge. I have the stomach of a
2357: rhinoceros."
2358: 
2359: "But for a young man so well furnished as you, who can questionless
2360: write a good hand and keep books, were it not well to seek some higher
2361: situation as clerk or assistant? I could speak to Brother Muscat, who is
2362: well acquainted with all such openings. Any place in Pendrell's Bank, I
2363: fear, is now closed against such as are not Churchmen. It used not to be
2364: so, but a year ago he discharged Brother Bodkin, although he was a
2365: valuable servant. Still, something might be found. There are ranks and
2366: degrees--and those who can serve in the higher must not unadvisedly
2367: change what seems to be a providential appointment. Your poor mother is
2368: not altogether----"
2369: 
2370: "Excuse me, Mr. Lyon; I've had all that out with my mother, and I may as
2371: well save you any trouble by telling you that my mind has been made up
2372: about that a long while ago. I'll take no employment that obliges me to
2373: prop up my chin with a high cravat, and wear straps, and pass the
2374: livelong day with a set of fellows who spend their spare money on shirt
2375: pins. That sort of work is really lower than many handicrafts; it only
2376: happens to be paid out of proportion. That's why I set myself to learn
2377: the watchmaking trade. My father was a weaver first of all. It would
2378: have been better for him if he had remained a weaver. I came home
2379: through Lancashire and saw an uncle of mine who is a weaver still. I
2380: mean to stick to the class I belong to--people who don't follow the
2381: fashions."
2382: 
2383: Mr. Lyon was silent a few moments. This dialogue was far from plain
2384: sailing; he was not certain of his latitude and longitude. If the
2385: despiser of Glasgow preachers had been arguing in favor of gin and
2386: Sabbath-breaking, Mr. Lyon's course would have been clearer. "Well,
2387: well," he said, deliberately, "it is true that St. Paul exercised the
2388: trade of tent-making, though he was learned in all the wisdom of the
2389: Rabbis."
2390: 
2391: "St. Paul was a wise man," said Felix. "Why should I want to get into
2392: the middle class because I have some learning? The most of the middle
2393: class are as ignorant as the working people about everything that
2394: doesn't belong to their own Brummagem life. That's how the workingmen
2395: are left to foolish devices and keep worsening themselves: the best
2396: heads among them forsake their boon comrades, and go in for a house with
2397: a high door-step and a brass knocker."
2398: 
2399: Mr. Lyon stroked his mouth and chin, perhaps because he felt some
2400: disposition to smile; and it would not be well to smile too readily at
2401: what seemed but a weedy resemblance of Christian unworldliness. On the
2402: contrary, there might be a dangerous snare in an unsanctified
2403: outstepping of average Christian practice.
2404: 
2405: "Nevertheless," he observed, gravely, "it is by such self-advancement
2406: that many have been enabled to do good service to the cause of liberty
2407: and to the public well-being. The ring and the robe of Joseph were no
2408: objects for a good man's ambition, but they were the signs of that
2409: credit which he won by his divinely-inspired skill, and which enabled
2410: him to act as a saviour to his brethren."
2411: 
2412: "Oh, yes, your ringed and scented men of the people!--I won't be one of
2413: them. Let a man once throttle himself with a satin stock, and he'll get
2414: new wants and new motives. Metamorphosis will have begun at his
2415: neck-joint, and it will go on till it has changed his likings first and
2416: then his reasoning, which will follow his likings as the feet of a
2417: hungry dog follow his nose. I'll have none of your clerkly gentility. I
2418: might end by collecting greasy pence from poor men to buy myself a fine
2419: coat and a glutton's dinner, on pretence of serving the poor men. I'd
2420: sooner be Paley's fat pigeon than a demagogue all tongue and stomach,
2421: though"--here Felix changed his voice a little--"I should like well
2422: enough to be another sort of demagogue, if I could."
2423: 
2424: "Then you have a strong interest in the great political movements of
2425: these times?" said Mr. Lyon, with a perceptible flashing of the eyes.
2426: 
2427: "I should think so. I despise every man who has not--or, having it,
2428: doesn't try to rouse it in other men."
2429: 
2430: "Right, my young friend, right," said the minister, in a deep cordial
2431: tone. Inevitably his mind was drawn aside from the immediate
2432: consideration of Felix Holt's spiritual interest by the prospect of
2433: political sympathy. In those days so many instruments of God's cause in
2434: the fight for religious and political liberty held creeds that were
2435: painfully wrong, and, indeed, irreconcilable with salvation! "That is
2436: my own view, which I maintain in the face of some opposition from
2437: brethren who contend that a share in public movements is a hindrance to
2438: the closer walk, and that the pulpit is no place for teaching men their
2439: duties as members of the commonwealth. I have had much puerile blame
2440: cast upon me because I have uttered such names as Brougham and
2441: Wellington in the pulpit. Why not Wellington as well as Rabshakeh? and
2442: why not Brougham as well as Balaam? Does God know less of men than He
2443: did in the days of Hezekiah and Moses?--is His arm shortened, and is the
2444: world become too wide for His providence? But, they say, there are no
2445: politics in the New Testament----"
2446: 
2447: "Well, they're right enough there," said Felix, with his usual
2448: unceremoniousness.
2449: 
2450: "What! you are of those who hold that a Christian minister should not
2451: meddle with public matters in the pulpit?" said Mr. Lyon, coloring. "I
2452: am ready to join issue on that point."
2453: 
2454: "Not I, sir," said Felix; "I should say, teach any truth you can,
2455: whether it's in the Testament or out of it. It's little enough anybody
2456: can get hold of, and still less what he can drive into the skulls of a
2457: pence-counting, parcel-tying generation, such as mostly fill your
2458: chapels."
2459: 
2460: "Young man," said Mr. Lyon, pausing in front of Felix. He spoke rapidly,
2461: as he always did, except when his words were specially weighted with
2462: emotion: he overflowed with matter, and in his mind matter was always
2463: completely organized into words. "I speak not on my own behalf, for not
2464: only have I no desire that any man should think of me above that which
2465: he seeth me to be, but I am aware of much that should make me patient
2466: under a disesteem resting even on too hasty a construction. I speak not
2467: as claiming reverence for my own age and office--not to shame you, but
2468: to warn you. It is good that you should use plainness of speech, and I
2469: am not of those who would enforce a submissive silence on the young,
2470: that they themselves, being elders, may be heard at large; but Elihu was
2471: the youngest of Job's friends, yet was there a wise rebuke in his words;
2472: and the aged Eli was taught by a revelation to the boy Samuel. I have to
2473: keep a special watch over myself in this matter, inasmuch as I have need
2474: of utterance which makes the thought within me seem as a pent-up fire,
2475: until I have shot it forth, as it were, in arrowy words, each one
2476: hitting its mark. Therefore I pray for a listening spirit, which is a
2477: great mark of grace. Nevertheless, my young friend, I am bound, as I
2478: said, to warn you. The temptations that most beset those who have great
2479: natural gifts, and are wise after the flesh, are pride and scorn, more
2480: particularly toward those weak things of the world which have been
2481: chosen to confound the things which are mighty. The scornful nostril and
2482: the high head gather not the odors that lie on the track of truth. The
2483: mind that is too ready at contempt and reprobation is----"
2484: 
2485: Here the door opened, and Mr. Lyon paused to look around, but seeing
2486: only Lyddy with the tea-tray, he went on--
2487: 
2488: "Is, I may say, as a clenched fist that can give blows, but is shut up
2489: from receiving and holding aught that is precious--though it were
2490: heaven-sent manna."
2491: 
2492: "I understand you, sir," said Felix, good-humoredly, putting out his
2493: hand to the little man, who had come close to him as he delivered the
2494: last sentence with sudden emphasis and slowness. "But I'm not inclined
2495: to clench my fist at you."
2496: 
2497: "Well, well," said Mr. Lyon, shaking the proffered hand, "we shall see
2498: more of each other, and I trust shall have much profitable communing.
2499: You will stay and have a dish of tea with us: we take the meal late on
2500: Thursdays, because my daughter is detained by giving a lesson in the
2501: French tongue. But she is doubtless returned now, and will presently
2502: come and pour out tea for us."
2503: 
2504: "Thank you, I'll stay," said Felix, not from any curiosity to see the
2505: minister's daughter, but from a liking for the society of the minister
2506: himself--for his quaint looks and ways, and the transparency of his
2507: talk, which gave a charm even to his weakness. The daughter was probably
2508: some prim Miss, neat, sensible, pious, but all in a small feminine way,
2509: in which Felix was no more interested than in Dorcas meetings,
2510: biographies of devout women, and that amount of ornamental knitting
2511: which was not inconsistent with Non-conforming seriousness.
2512: 
2513: "I'm perhaps a little too fond of banging and smashing," he went on: "a
2514: phrenologist at Glasgow told me I had large veneration; another man
2515: there, who knew me, laughed out and said I was the most blasphemous
2516: iconoclast living. 'That,' says my phrenologist, 'is because of his
2517: large ideality, which prevents him from finding anything perfect enough
2518: to be venerated.' Of course I put my ears down and wagged my tail at
2519: that stroking."
2520: 
2521: "Yes, yes; I have had my own head explored with somewhat similar
2522: results. It is, I fear, but a vain show of fulfilling the heathen
2523: precept, 'Know thyself,' and too often leads to a self-estimate which
2524: will subsist in the absence of that fruit by which alone the quality of
2525: the tree is made evident. Nevertheless----Esther, my dear, this is Mr.
