2526: Holt, whose acquaintance I have now been making with more than ordinary
2527: interest. He will take tea with us."
2528: 
2529: Esther bowed slightly as she walked across the room to fetch the candle
2530: and place it near her tray. Felix rose and bowed, also with an air of
2531: indifference, which was perhaps exaggerated by the fact that he was
2532: inwardly surprised. The minister's daughter was not the sort of person
2533: he expected. She was quite incongruous with his notion of ministers'
2534: daughters in general; and though he had expected something nowise
2535: delightful, the incongruity repelled him. A very delicate scent, the
2536: faint suggestion of a garden, was wafted as she went. He would not
2537: observe her, but he had a sense of an elastic walk, the tread of small
2538: feet, a long neck and a high crown of shining brown plaits and curls
2539: that floated backward--things, in short, that suggested a fine lady to
2540: him, and determined him to notice her as little as possible. A fine lady
2541: was always a sort of spun-glass affair--not natural, and with no beauty
2542: for him as art; but a fine lady as the daughter of this rusty old
2543: Puritan was especially offensive.
2544: 
2545: "Nevertheless," continued Mr. Lyon, who rarely let drop any thread of
2546: discourse, "that phrenological science is not irreconcilable with the
2547: revealed dispensations. And it is undeniable that we have our varying
2548: native dispositions which even grace will not obliterate. I myself, from
2549: my youth up, have been given to question too curiously concerning the
2550: truth--to examine and sift the medicine of the soul rather than to apply
2551: it."
2552: 
2553: "If your truth happens to be such medicine as Holt's Pills and Elixir,
2554: the less you swallow of it the better," said Felix. "But truth-vendors
2555: and medicine-vendors usually recommend swallowing. When a man sees his
2556: livelihood in a pill or a proposition, he likes to have orders for the
2557: dose, and not curious enquiries."
2558: 
2559: This speech verged on rudeness, but it was delivered with a brusque
2560: openness that implied the absence of any personal intention. The
2561: minister's daughter was now for the first time startled into looking at
2562: Felix. But her survey of this unusual speaker was soon made, and she
2563: relieved her father from the need to reply by saying--
2564: 
2565: "The tea is poured out, father."
2566: 
2567: That was the signal for Mr. Lyon to advance toward the table, raise his
2568: right hand, and ask a blessing at sufficient length for Esther to glance
2569: at the visitor again. There seemed to be no danger of his looking at
2570: her: he was observing her father. She had time to remark that he was a
2571: peculiar looking person, but not insignificant, which was the quality
2572: that most hopelessly consigned a man to perdition. He was massively
2573: built. The striking points in his face were large clear gray eyes and
2574: full lips.
2575: 
2576: "Will you draw up to the table, Mr. Holt?" said the minister.
2577: 
2578: In the act of rising, Felix pushed back his chair too suddenly against
2579: the rickety table close by him, and down went the blue-frilled
2580: work-basket, flying open, and dispersing on the floor reels, thimble,
2581: muslin-work, a small sealed bottle of attar of rose, and something
2582: heavier than these--a duodecimo volume which fell near him between the
2583: table and the fender.
2584: 
2585: "Oh, my stars!" said Felix, "I beg your pardon." Esther had already
2586: started up, and with wonderful quickness had picked up half the small
2587: rolling things while Felix was lifting the basket and the book. This
2588: last had opened, and had its leaves crushed in falling; and, with the
2589: instinct of a bookish man, he saw nothing more pressing to be done than
2590: to flatten the corners of the leaves.
2591: 
2592: "Byron's Poems!" he said, in a tone of disgust, while Esther was
2593: recovering all the other articles. "'The Dream'--he'd better have been
2594: asleep and snoring. What! do you stuff your memory with Byron, Miss
2595: Lyon?"
2596: 
2597: Felix on his side, was led at last to look straight at Esther, but it
2598: was with a strong denunciatory and pedagogic intention. Of course he saw
2599: more clearly than ever that she was a fine lady.
2600: 
2601: She reddened, drew up her long neck, and said, as she retreated to her
2602: chair again--
2603: 
2604: "I have a great admiration for Byron."
2605: 
2606: Mr. Lyon had paused in the act of drawing his chair to the tea table,
2607: and was looking on at this scene, wrinkling the corners of his eyes with
2608: a perplexed smile. Esther would not have wished him to know anything
2609: about the volume of Byron, but she was too proud to show any concern.
2610: 
2611: "He is a worldly and vain writer, I fear," said Mr. Lyon. He knew
2612: scarcely anything of the poet, whose books embodied the faith and ritual
2613: of many young ladies and gentlemen.
2614: 
2615: "A misanthropic debauchee," said Felix, lifting a chair with one hand,
2616: and holding the book open in the other, "whose notion of a hero was
2617: that he should disorder his stomach and despise mankind. His corsairs
2618: and renegades, his Alps and Manfreds, are the most paltry puppets that
2619: were ever pulled by the strings of lust and pride."
2620: 
2621: "Hand the book to me," said Mr. Lyon.
2622: 
2623: "Let me beg of you to put it aside till after tea, father," said Esther.
2624: "However objectionable Mr. Holt may find its pages, they would certainly
2625: be made worse by being greased with bread-and-butter."
2626: 
2627: "That is true, my dear," said Mr. Lyon, laying down the book on the
2628: small table behind him. He saw that his daughter was angry.
2629: 
2630: "Ho, ho!" thought Felix, "her father is frightened at her. How came he
2631: to have such a nice-stepping, long-necked peacock for his daughter? but
2632: she shall see that I am not frightened." Then he said aloud, "I should
2633: like to know how you will justify your admiration for such a writer,
2634: Miss Lyon."
2635: 
2636: "I should not attempt it with you, Mr. Holt," said Esther. "You have
2637: such strong words at command that they make the smallest argument seem
2638: formidable. If I had ever met the giant Cormoran, I should have made a
2639: point of agreeing with him in his literary opinions."
2640: 
2641: Esther had that excellent thing in woman, a soft voice with clear fluent
2642: utterance. Her sauciness was always charming because it was without
2643: emphasis, and was accompanied with graceful little turns of the head.
2644: 
2645: Felix laughed at her thrust with young heartiness.
2646: 
2647: "My daughter is a critic of words, Mr. Holt," said the minister, smiling
2648: complacently, "and often corrects mine on the ground of niceties, which
2649: I profess are as dark to me as if they were the reports of a sixth sense
2650: which I possess not. I am an eager seeker for precision, and would fain
2651: find language subtle enough to follow the utmost intricacies of the
2652: soul's pathways, but I see not why a round word that means some object,
2653: made and blessed by the Creator, should be branded and banished as a
2654: malefactor."
2655: 
2656: "Oh, your niceties--I know what they are," said Felix, in his usual
2657: _fortissimo_. "They'll go on your system of make-believe. 'Rottenness'
2658: may suggest what is unpleasant, so you'd better say 'sugar-plums,' or
2659: something else such a long way off the fact that nobody is obliged to
2660: think of it. Those are your roundabout euphuisms that dress up swindling
2661: till it looks as well as honesty, and shoot with boiled peas instead of
2662: bullets. I hate your gentlemanly speakers."
2663: 
2664: "Then you would not like Mr. Jermyn, I think," said Esther. "That
2665: reminds me, father, that to-day, when I was giving Miss Louisa Jermyn
2666: her lesson, Mr. Jermyn came in and spoke to me with grand politeness,
2667: and asked me at what times you were likely to be disengaged, because he
2668: wished to make your better acquaintance, and consult you on matters of
2669: importance. He never took the least notice of me before. Can you guess
2670: the reason of his sudden ceremoniousness?"
2671: 
2672: "Nay, child," said the minister, ponderingly.
2673: 
2674: "Politics, of course," said Felix. "He's on some committee. An election
2675: is coming. Universal peace is declared, and the foxes have a sincere
2676: interest in prolonging the lives of the poultry. Eh, Mr. Lyon? Isn't
2677: that it?"
2678: 
2679: "Nay, not so. He is the close ally of the Transome family, who are blind
2680: hereditary Tories like the Debarrys, and will drive their tenants to the
2681: poll as if they were sheep, and it has even been hinted that the heir
2682: who is coming from the East may be another Tory candidate, and coalesce
2683: with the younger Debarry. It is said that he has enormous wealth, and
2684: could purchase every vote in the county that has a price."
2685: 
2686: "He is come," said Esther. "I heard Miss Jermyn tell her sister that she
2687: had seen him going out of her father's room."
2688: 
2689: "'Tis strange," said Mr. Lyon.
2690: 
2691: "Something extraordinary must have happened," said Esther, "for Mr.
2692: Jermyn to intend courting us. Miss Jermyn said to me only the other day
2693: that she could not think how I came to be so well educated and ladylike.
2694: She always thought Dissenters were ignorant, vulgar people. I said, so
2695: they were, usually, and Church people also in small towns. She considers
2696: herself a judge of what is ladylike, and she is vulgarity
2697: personified--with large feet, and the most odious scent on her
2698: handkerchief, and a bonnet that looks like 'The Fashion' printed in
2699: capital letters."
2700: 
2701: "One sort of fine-ladyism is as good as another," said Felix.
2702: 
2703: "No, indeed. Pardon me," said Esther. "A real fine-lady does not wear
2704: clothes that flare in people's eyes, or use importunate scents, or make
2705: a noise as she moves: she is something refined and graceful, and
2706: charming, and never obtrusive."
2707: 
2708: "Oh, yes," said Felix, contemptuously. "And she reads Byron also, and
2709: admires Childe Harold--gentlemen of unspeakable woes, who employ a
2710: hairdresser, and look seriously at themselves in the glass."
2711: 
2712: Esther reddened, and gave a little toss. Felix went on triumphantly. "A
2713: fine-lady is a squirrel-headed thing, with small airs, and small
2714: notions, about as applicable to the business of life as a pair of
2715: tweezers to the clearing of a forest. Ask your father what those old
2716: persecuted emigrant Puritans would have done with fine-lady wives and
2717: daughters."
2718: 
2719: "Oh, there is no danger of such _mésalliances_," said Esther. "Men who
2720: are unpleasant companions and make frights of themselves, are sure to
2721: get wives tasteless enough to suit them."
2722: 
2723: "Esther, my dear," said Mr. Lyon, "let not your playfulness betray you
2724: into disrespect toward those venerable pilgrims. They struggled and
2725: endured in order to cherish and plant anew the seeds of a scriptural
2726: doctrine and of a pure discipline."
2727: 
2728: "Yes, I know," said Esther, hastily, dreading a discourse on the pilgrim
2729: fathers.
2730: 
2731: "Oh, they were an ugly lot!" Felix burst in, making Mr. Lyon start.
2732: "Miss Medora wouldn't have minded if they had all been put into the
2733: pillory and lost their ears. She would have said, 'Their ears did stick
2734: out so.' I shouldn't wonder if that's a bust of one of them." Here
2735: Felix, with sudden keenness of observation, nodded at the black bust
2736: with the gauze over its colored face.
2737: 
2738: "No," said Mr. Lyon, "that is the eminent George Whitfield, who, you
2739: well know, had a gift of oratory as of one on whom the tongue of flame
2740: had rested visibly. But Providence--doubtless for wise ends in relation
2741: to the inner man, for I would not enquire too closely into minutiæ which
2742: carry too many plausible interpretations for any one of them to be
2743: stable--Providence, I say, ordained that the good man should squint; and
2744: my daughter has not yet learned to bear with his infirmity."
2745: 
2746: "She has put a veil over it. Suppose you had squinted yourself?" said
2747: Felix, looking at Esther.
2748: 
2749: "Then, doubtless, you could have been more polite to me, Mr. Holt," said
2750: Esther, rising and placing herself at her work-table. "You seem to
2751: prefer what is unusual and ugly."
2752: 
2753: "A peacock!" thought Felix. "I should like to come and scold her every
2754: day, and make her cry and cut her fine hair off."
2755: 
2756: Felix rose to go, and said, "I will not take up any more of your
2757: valuable time, Mr. Lyon. I know that you have not many spare evenings."
2758: 
2759: "That is true, my young friend; for I now go to Sproxton one evening in
2760: the week. I do not despair that we may some day need a chapel there,
2761: though the hearers do not multiply save among the women, and there is no
2762: work as yet begun among the miners themselves. I shall be glad of your
2763: company in my walk thither to-morrow at five o'clock, if you would like
2764: to see how that population has grown of late years."
2765: 
2766: "Oh, I've been to Sproxton already several times. I had a congregation
2767: of my own there last Sunday evening."
2768: 
2769: "What! do you preach?" said Mr. Lyon, with brightened glance.
2770: 
2771: "Not exactly. I went to the ale-house."
2772: 
2773: Mr. Lyon started. "I trust you are putting a riddle to me, young man,
2774: even as Samson did to his companions. From what you said but lately, it
2775: cannot be that you are given to tippling and to taverns."
2776: 
2777: "Oh, I don't drink much. I order a pint of beer, and I get into talk
2778: with the fellows over their pots and pipes. Somebody must take a little
2779: knowledge and common-sense to them in this way, else how are they to get
2780: it? I go for educating the non-electors, so I put myself in the way of
2781: my pupils--my academy is the beer-house. I'll walk with you to-morrow
2782: with pleasure."
2783: 
2784: "Do so, do so," said Mr. Lyon, shaking hands with his odd acquaintance.
2785: "We shall understand each other better by-and-by, I doubt not."
2786: 
2787: "I wish you good-evening, Miss Lyon."
2788: 
2789: Esther bowed very slightly, without speaking.
2790: 
2791: "That is a singular young man, Esther," said the minister, walking about
2792: after Felix was gone. "I discern in him a love for whatsoever things are
2793: honest and true, which I would fain believe to be an earnest of further
2794: endowment with the wisdom that is from on high. It is true that, as the
2795: traveller in the desert is often lured, by a false vision of water and
2796: freshness, to turn aside from the track which leads to the tried and
2797: established fountains, so the Evil One will take advantage of a natural
2798: yearning toward the better, to delude the soul with a self-flattering
2799: belief in a visionary virtue, higher than the ordinary fruits of the
2800: Spirit. But I trust it is not so here. I feel a great enlargement in
2801: this young man's presence, notwithstanding a certain license in his
2802: language, which I shall use my efforts to correct."
2803: 
2804: "I think he is very coarse and rude," said Esther, with a touch of
2805: temper in her voice. "But he speaks better English than most of our
2806: visitors. What is his occupation?"
2807: 
2808: "Watch and clock making, by which, together with a little teaching, as I
2809: understand, he hopes to maintain his mother, not thinking it right that
2810: he should live by the sale of medicines whose virtues he distrusts. It
2811: is no common scruple."
2812: 
2813: "Dear me," said Esther, "I thought he was something higher than that."
2814: She was disappointed.
2815: 
2816: Felix, on his side, as he strolled out in the evening air, said to
2817: himself: "Now by what fine meshes of circumstance did that queer devout
2818: old man, with his awful creed, which makes this world a vestibule with
2819: double doors to hell, and a narrow stair on one side whereby the thinner
2820: sort may mount to heaven--by what subtle play of flesh and spirit did he
2821: come to have a daughter so little in his own likeness? Married
2822: foolishly, I suppose. I'll never marry, though I should have to live on
2823: raw turnips to subdue my flesh. I'll never look back and say, 'I had a
2824: fine purpose once--I meant to keep my hands clean and my soul upright,
2825: and to look truth in the face; but pray excuse me, I have a wife and
2826: children--I must lie and simper a little, else they'll starve'; or 'My
2827: wife is nice, she must have her bread well buttered, and her feelings
2828: will be hurt if she is not thought genteel.' That is the lot Miss Esther
2829: is preparing for some man or other. I could grind my teeth at such
2830: self-satisfied minxes, who think they can tell everybody what is the
2831: correct thing, and the utmost stretch of their ideas will not place them
2832: on a level with the intelligent fleas. I should like to see if she could
2833: be made ashamed of herself."
2834: 
2835: 
2836: 
2837: 
2838: CHAPTER VI.
2839: 
2840:     Though she be dead, yet let me think she lives,
2841:     And feed my mind, that dies for want of her.
2842: 
2843:                                  --MARLOWE: _Tamburlaine the Great_.
2844: 
2845: 
2846: Hardly any one in Treby who thought at all of Mr. Lyon and his daughter
2847: had not felt the same sort of wonder about Esther as Felix felt. She was
2848: not much liked by her father's church and congregation. The less serious
2849: observed that she had too many airs and graces and held her head much
2850: too high; the stricter sort feared greatly that Mr. Lyon had not been
2851: sufficiently careful in placing his daughter among God-fearing people,
2852: and that, being led astray by the melancholy vanity of giving her
2853: exceptional accomplishments, he had sent her to a French school, and
2854: allowed her to take situations where she had contracted notions not
2855: only above her own rank, but of too worldly a kind to be safe in any
2856: rank. But no one knew what sort of woman her mother had been, for Mr.
2857: Lyon never spoke of his past domesticities. When he was chosen as pastor
2858: at Treby in 1825, it was understood that he had been a widower many
2859: years, and he had no companion but the tearful and much-exercised Lyddy,
2860: his daughter being still at school. It was only two years ago that
2861: Esther had come home to live permanently with her father, and take
2862: pupils in the town. Within that time she had excited a passion in two
2863: young Dissenting breasts that were clad in the best style of Treby
2864: waistcoat--a garment which at that period displayed much design both in
2865: the stuff and the wearer; and she had secured an astonished admiration
2866: of her cleverness from the girls of various ages who were her pupils;
2867: indeed, her knowledge of French was generally held to give a distinction
2868: to Treby itself as compared with other market-towns. But she had won
2869: little regard of any other kind. Wise Dissenting matrons were divided
2870: between fear lest their sons should want to marry her and resentment
2871: that she should treat those "undeniable" young men with a distant scorn
2872: which was hardly to be tolerated in a minister's daughter; not only
2873: because that parentage appeared to entail an obligation to show an
2874: exceptional degree of Christian humility, but because, looked at from a
2875: secular point of view, a poor minister must be below the substantial
2876: householders who keep him. For at that time the preacher who was paid
2877: under the Voluntary system was regarded by his flock with feelings not
2878: less mixed than the spiritual person who still took his tithe-pig or his
2879: _modus_. His gifts were admired, and tears were shed under best bonnets
2880: at his sermons; but the weaker tea was thought good enough for him; and
2881: even when he went to preach a charity sermon in a strange town, he was
2882: treated with home-made wine and the smaller bedroom. As the good
2883: Churchman's reverence was often mixed with growling, and was apt to be
2884: given chiefly to an abstract parson who was what a parson ought to be,
2885: so the good Dissenter sometimes mixed his approval of ministerial gifts
2886: with considerable criticism and cheapening of the human vessel which
2887: contained those treasures. Mrs. Muscat and Mrs. Nuttwood applied the
2888: principle of Christian equality by remarking that Mr. Lyon had his
2889: oddities, and that he ought not to allow his daughter to indulge in such
2890: unbecoming expenditure on her gloves, shoes, and hosiery, even if she
2891: did pay for them out of her earnings. As for the Church people who
2892: engaged Miss Lyon to give lessons in their families, their imaginations
2893: were altogether prostrated by the incongruity between accomplishments
2894: and Dissent, between weekly prayer-meetings and a conversance with so
2895: lively and altogether worldly a language as the French. Esther's own
2896: mind was not free from a sense of irreconcilableness between the objects
2897: of her taste and the conditions of her lot. She knew that Dissenters
2898: were looked down upon by those whom she regarded as the most refined
2899: classes; her favorite companions, both in France and at an English
2900: school where she had been a junior teacher, had thought it quite
2901: ridiculous to have a father who was a Dissenting preacher; and when an
2902: ardently admiring school-fellow induced her parents to take Esther as a
2903: governess to the younger children, all her native tendencies toward
2904: luxury, fastidiousness, and scorn of mock gentility, were strengthened
2905: by witnessing the habits of a well-born and wealthy family. Yet the
2906: position of servitude was irksome to her, and she was glad at last to
2907: live at home with her father, for though, throughout her girlhood, she
2908: had wished to avoid this lot, a little experience had taught her to
2909: prefer its comparative independence. But she was not contented with her
2910: life; she seemed to herself to be surrounded with ignoble, uninteresting
2911: conditions, from which there was no issue; for even if she had been
2912: unamiable enough to give her father pain deliberately, it would have
2913: been no satisfaction to her to go to Treby church, and visibly turn her
2914: back on Dissent. It was not religious differences, but social
2915: differences, that Esther was concerned about, and her ambitious taste
2916: would have been no more gratified in the society of the Waces than in
2917: that of the Muscats. The Waces spoke imperfect English and played whist;
2918: the Muscats spoke the same dialect and took in the "Evangelical
2919: Magazine." Esther liked neither of these amusements. She had one of
2920: those exceptional organizations which are quick and sensitive without
2921: being in the least morbid; she was alive to the finest shades of manner,
2922: to the nicest distinctions of tone and accent; she had a little code of
2923: her own about scents and colors, textures and behavior, by which she
2924: secretly condemned or sanctioned all things and persons. And she was
2925: well satisfied with herself for her fastidious taste, never doubting
2926: that hers was the highest standard. She was proud that the best-born
2927: and handsomest girls at school had always said that she might be taken
2928: for a born lady. Her own pretty instep, clad in a silk stocking, her
2929: little heel, just rising from a kid slipper, her irreproachable nails
2930: and delicate wrist, were the objects of delighted consciousness to her;
2931: and she felt that it was her superiority which made her unable to use
2932: without disgust any but the finest cambric handkerchiefs and freshest
2933: gloves. Her money all went in the gratification of these nice tastes,
2934: and she saved nothing from her earnings. I can not say that she had
2935: pangs of conscience on this score; for she felt sure that she was
2936: generous: she hated all meanness, would empty her purse impulsively on
2937: some sudden appeal to her pity, and if she found out that her father had
2938: a want, she would supply it with some pretty device of a surprise. But
2939: then the good man so seldom had a want--except the perpetual desire,
2940: which she could never gratify, of seeing her under convictions, and fit
2941: to become a member of the church.
2942: 
2943: As for little Mr. Lyon, he loved and admired this unregenerate child
2944: more, he feared, than was consistent with the due preponderance of
2945: impersonal and ministerial regards: he prayed and pleaded for her with
2946: tears, humbling himself for her spiritual deficiencies in the privacy of
2947: his study; and then came down stairs to find himself in timorous
2948: subjection to her wishes, lest, as he inwardly said, he should give his
2949: teaching an ill savor, by mingling it with outward crossing. There will
2950: be queens in spite of Salic or other laws of later date than Adam and
2951: Eve; and here in this small dingy house of the minister in Malthouse
2952: Yard, there was a light-footed, sweet-voiced Queen Esther.
2953: 
2954: The stronger will always rule, say some, with an air of confidence which
2955: is like a lawyer's flourish, forbidding exceptions or additions. But
2956: what is strength? Is it blind wilfulness that sees no terrors, no
2957: many-linked consequences, no bruises and wounds of those whose cords it
2958: tightens? Is it the narrowness of a brain that conceives no needs
2959: differing from its own, and looks to no results beyond the bargains of
2960: to-day; that tugs with emphasis for every small purpose, and thinks it
2961: weakness to exercise the sublime power of resolved renunciation? There
2962: is a sort of subjection which is the peculiar heritage of largeness and
2963: of love; and strength is often only another name for willing bondage to
2964: irremediable weakness.
2965: 
2966: Esther had affection for her father: she recognized the purity of his
2967: character, and a quickness of intellect in him which responded to her
2968: own liveliness, in spite of what seemed a dreary piety, which selected
2969: everything that was least interesting and romantic in life and history.
2970: But his old clothes had a smoky odor, and she did not like to walk with
2971: him, because, when people spoke to him in the street, it was his wont,
2972: instead of remarking on the weather and passing on, to pour forth in an
2973: absent manner some reflections that were occupying his mind about the
2974: traces of the Divine government, or about a peculiar incident narrated
2975: in the life of the eminent Mr. Richard Baxter. Esther had a horror of
2976: appearing ridiculous even in the eyes of vulgar Trebians. She fancied
2977: that she should have loved her mother better than she was able to love
2978: her father; and she wished she could have remembered that mother more
2979: thoroughly.
2980: 
2981: But she had no more than a broken vision of the time before she was five
2982: years old--the time when the word oftenest on her lips was "Mamma"; when
2983: a low voice spoke caressing French words to her, and she in her turn
2984: repeated the words to her rag doll; when a very small white hand,
2985: different from any that came after, used to pat her, and stroke her, and
2986: tie on her frock and pinafore, and when at last there was nothing but
2987: sitting with a doll on a bed where mamma was lying, till her father once
2988: carried her away. Where distinct memory began, there was no longer the
2989: low caressing voice and the small white hand. She knew that her mother
2990: was a Frenchwoman, that she had been in want and distress, and that her
2991: maiden name was Annette Ledru. Her father had told her no more than
2992: this; and once, he had said, "My Esther, until you are a woman, we will
2993: only think of your mother: when you are about to be married and leave
2994: me, we will speak of her, and I will deliver to you her ring and all
2995: that was hers; but, without a great command laid upon me, I cannot
2996: pierce my heart by speaking of that which was and is not." Esther had
2997: never forgotten these words, and the older she became, the more
2998: impossible she felt it that she should urge her father with questions
2999: about the past.
3000: 
3001: His inability to speak of that past to her depended on manifold causes.
3002: Partly it came from an initial concealment. He had not the courage to
3003: tell Esther that he was not really her father: he had not the courage to
3004: renounce that hold on her tenderness which the belief in his natural
3005: fatherhood must help to give him, or to incur any resentment that her
3006: quick spirit might feel at having been brought up under a false
3007: supposition. But there were other things yet more difficult for him to
3008: be quite open about--deep sorrows of his life as a Christian minister
3009: that were hardly to be told to a girl.
3010: 
3011: Twenty-two years ago, when Rufus Lyon was no more than thirty-six years
3012: old, he was the admired pastor of a large Independent congregation in
3013: one of our southern seaport towns. He was unmarried, and had met all
3014: exhortations of friends who represented to him that a bishop, _i.e._,
3015: the overseer of an Independent church and congregation--should be the
3016: husband of one wife, by saying that St. Paul meant this particular as a
3017: limitation, and not as an injunction; that a minister was permitted to
3018: have one wife, but that he, Rufus Lyon, did not wish to avail himself of
3019: that permission, finding his studies and other labors of his vocation
3020: all-absorbing, and seeing that mothers in Israel were sufficiently
3021: provided by those who had not been set apart for a more special work.
3022: His church and congregation were proud of him: he was put forward on
3023: platforms, was made a "deputation," and was requested to preach
3024: anniversary sermons in far-off towns. Wherever noteworthy preachers were
3025: discussed, Rufus Lyon was almost sure to be mentioned as one who did
3026: honor to the Independent body; his sermons were said to be full of fire;
3027: and while he had more of human knowledge than many of his brethren, he
3028: showed in an eminent degree the marks of a true ministerial vocation.
3029: But on a sudden this burning and shining light seemed to be quenched:
3030: Mr. Lyon voluntarily resigned his charge and withdrew from the town.
3031: 
3032: A terrible crisis had come upon him; a moment in which religious doubt
3033: and newly-awakened passion had rushed together in a common flood, and
3034: had paralyzed his ministerial gifts. His thirty-six years had been a
3035: story of purely religious and studious fervor; his passion had been for
3036: doctrines, for argumentative conquest on the side of right; the sins he
3037: had chiefly to pray against had been those of personal ambition (under
3038: such forms as ambition takes in the mind of a man who has chosen the
3039: career of an Independent preacher), and those of a too restless
3040: intellect, ceaselessly urging questions concerning the mystery of that
3041: which was assuredly revealed, and thus hindering the due nourishment of
3042: the soul on the substance of the truth delivered. Even at that time of
3043: comparative youth, his unworldliness and simplicity in small matters
3044: (for he was keenly awake to the larger affairs of this world) gave a
3045: certain oddity to his manners and appearance; and though his sensitive
3046: face had much beauty, his person altogether seemed so irrelevant to a
3047: fashionable view of things, that well-dressed ladies and gentlemen
3048: usually laughed at him, as they probably did at Mr. John Milton after
3049: the Restoration and ribbons had come in, and still more at that apostle,
3050: of weak bodily presence, who preached in the back streets of Ephesus and
3051: elsewhere, a new view of a religion that hardly anybody believed in.
3052: Rufus Lyon was the singular-looking apostle of the Meeting in Skipper's
3053: Lane. Was it likely that any romance should befall such a man? Perhaps
3054: not; but romance did befall him.
3055: 
3056: One winter's evening in 1812, Mr. Lyon was returning from a village
3057: preaching. He walked at his usual rapid rate, with busy thoughts
3058: undisturbed by any sight more distinct than the bushes and the hedgerow
3059: trees, black beneath a faint moonlight, until something suggested to him
3060: that he had perhaps omitted to bring away with him a thin account-book
3061: in which he recorded certain subscriptions. He paused, unfastened his
3062: outer coat, and felt in all his pockets, then he took off his hat and
3063: looked inside it. The book was not to be found, and he was about to walk
3064: on, when he was startled by hearing a low, sweet voice, say, with a
3065: strong foreign accent--
3066: 
3067: "Have pity on me, sir."
3068: 
3069: Searching with his short-sighted eyes, he perceived some one on a
3070: side-bank; and approaching, he found a young woman with a baby on her
3071: lap. She spoke again more faintly than before.
3072: 
3073: "Sir, I die with hunger; in the name of God take the little one."
3074: 
3075: There was no distrusting the pale face and the sweet low voice. Without
3076: pause, Mr. Lyon took the baby in his arms and said, "Can you walk by my
3077: side, young woman?"
3078: 
3079: She rose, but seemed tottering. "Lean on me," said Mr. Lyon, and so they
3080: walked slowly on, the minister for the first time in his life carrying a
3081: baby.
3082: 
3083: Nothing better occurred to him than to take his charge to his own house;
3084: it was the simplest way of relieving the woman's wants, and finding out
3085: how she could be helped further; and he thought of no other
3086: possibilities. She was too feeble for more words to be spoken between
3087: them till she was seated by his fireside. His elderly servant was not
3088: easily amazed at anything her master did in the way of charity, and at
3089: once took the baby, while Mr. Lyon unfastened the mother's damp bonnet
3090: and shawl, and gave her something warm to drink. Then, waiting by her
3091: till it was time to offer her more, he had nothing to do but to notice
3092: the loveliness of her face, which seemed to him as that of an angel,
3093: with a benignity in its repose that carried a more assured sweetness
3094: than any smile. Gradually she revived, lifted up her delicate hands
3095: between her face and the firelight, and looked at the baby which lay
3096: opposite to her on the old servant's lap, taking in spoonfuls with much
3097: content, and stretching out naked feet toward the warmth. Then, as her
3098: consciousness of relief grew into contrasting memory, she lifted up her
3099: eyes to Mr. Lyon, who stood close by her, and said, in her pretty broken
3100: way:
3101: 
3102: "I knew you had a good heart when you took your hat off. You seemed to
3103: me as the image of the _bien-amié Saint Jean_."
3104: 
3105: The grateful glance of those blue-gray eyes, with their long
3106: shadow-making eyelashes, was a new kind of good to Rufus Lyon; it seemed
3107: to him as if a woman had never really looked at him before. Yet this
3108: poor thing was apparently a blind French Catholic--of delicate nurture,
3109: surely, judging from her hands. He was in a tremor; he felt that it
3110: would be rude to question her, and he only urged her now to take a
3111: little food. She accepted it with evident enjoyment, looking at the
3112: child continually, and then, with a fresh burst of gratitude, leaning
3113: forward to press the servant's hand and say, "Oh, you are good!" Then
3114: she looked up at Mr. Lyon again and said, "Is there in the world a
3115: prettier _marmot?_"
3116: 
3117: The evening passed; a bed was made up for the strange woman, and Mr.
3118: Lyon had not asked her so much as her name. He never went to bed himself
3119: that night. He spent it in misery, enduring a horrible assault of Satan.
3120: He thought a frenzy had seized him. Wild visions of an impossible future
3121: thrust themselves upon him. He dreaded lest the woman had a husband; he
3122: wished that he might call her his own, that he might worship her beauty,
3123: that she might love and caress him. And what to the mass of men would
3124: have been only one of many allowable follies--a transient fascination,
3125: to be dispelled by daylight and contact with those common facts of which
3126: common-sense is the reflex--was to him a spiritual convulsion. He was as
3127: one who raved, and knew that he raved. These mad wishes were
3128: irreconcilable with what he was, and must be, as a Christian minister,
3129: nay, penetrating his soul as tropic heat penetrates the frame, and
3130: changes for it all aspects and all flavors, they were irreconcilable
3131: with that conception of the world which made his faith. All the busy
3132: doubt which had before been mere impish shadows flitting around a belief
3133: that was strong with the strength of an unswerving moral bias, had now
3134: gathered blood and substance. The questioning spirit had become suddenly
3135: bold and blasphemous; it no longer insinuated scepticism--it prompted
3136: defiance; it no longer expressed cool, inquisitive thought, but was the
3137: voice of a passionate mood. Yet he never ceased to regard it as the
3138: voice of the tempter: the conviction which had been the law of his
3139: better life remained within him as a conscience.
3140: 
3141: The struggle of that night was an abridgment of all the struggles that
3142: came after. Quick souls have their intensest life in the first
3143: anticipatory sketch of what may or will be, and the pursuit of their
3144: wish is the pursuit of that paradisiacal vision which only impelled
3145: them, and is left farther and farther behind, vanishing forever even out
3146: of hope in the moment which is called success.
3147: 
3148: The next morning Mr. Lyon heard his guest's history. She was the
3149: daughter of a French officer of considerable rank, who had fallen in the
3150: Russian campaign. She had escaped from France to England with much
3151: difficulty in order to rejoin her husband, a young Englishman, to whom
3152: she had become attached during his detention as a prisoner of war on
3153: parole at Vesoul, where she was living under the charge of some
3154: relatives, and to whom she had been married without the consent of her
3155: family. Her husband had served in the Hanoverian army, had obtained his
3156: discharge in order to visit England on some business, with the nature of
3157: which she was not acquainted, and had been taken prisoner as a suspected
3158: spy. A short time after their marriage he and his fellow-prisoners had
3159: been moved to a town nearer the coast, and she had remained in wretched
3160: uncertainty about him, until at last a letter had come from him telling
3161: her that an exchange of prisoners had occurred, that he was in England,
3162: that she must use her utmost effort to follow him, and that on arriving
3163: on English ground she must send him word under a cover which he
3164: enclosed, bearing an address in London. Fearing the opposition of her
3165: friends, she started unknown to them, with a very small supply of money;
3166: and after enduring much discomfort and many fears in waiting for a
3167: passage which she at last got in a small trading smack, she arrived at
3168: Southampton--ill. Before she was able to write, her baby was born; and
3169: before her husband's answer came, she had been obliged to pawn some
3170: clothes and trinkets. He desired her to travel to London where he would
3171: meet her at the Belle Sauvage, adding that he was himself in distress,
3172: and unable to come to her: when once she was in London they would take
3173: ship and quit the country. Arrived at the Belle Sauvage, the poor thing
3174: waited three days in vain for her husband: on the fourth a letter came
3175: in a strange hand, saying that in his last moments he had desired this
3176: letter to be written to inform her of his death, and recommend her to
3177: return to her friends. She could choose no other course, but she had
3178: soon been reduced to walking, that she might save her pence to buy bread
3179: with: and on the evening when she made her appeal to Mr. Lyon, she had
3180: pawned the last thing, over and above needful clothing, that she could
3181: persuade herself to part with. The things she had not borne to part with
3182: were her marriage-ring, and a locket containing her husband's hair, and
3183: bearing his baptismal name. This locket, she said, exactly resembled one
3184: worn by her husband on his watch-chain, only that his bore the name
3185: Annette, and contained a lock of her hair. The precious trifle now hung
3186: round her neck by a cord, for she had sold the small gold chain which
3187: formerly held it.
3188: 
3189: The only guarantee of this story, besides the exquisite candor of her
3190: face, was a small packet of papers which she carried in her pocket,
3191: consisting of her husband's few letters, the letter which announced his
3192: death, and her marriage certificate. It was not so probable a story as
3193: that of many an inventive vagrant; but Mr. Lyon did not doubt it for a
3194: moment. It was impossible to him to suspect this angelic-faced woman,
3195: but he had strong suspicions concerning her husband. He could not help
3196: being glad that she had not retained the address he had desired her to
3197: send to in London, as that removed any obvious means of learning
3198: particulars about him. But enquiries might have been made at Vesoul by
3199: letter, and her friends there might have been appealed to. A
3200: consciousness, not to be quite silenced, told Mr. Lyon that this was the
3201: course he ought to take, but it would have required an energetic
3202: self-conquest, and he was excused from it by Annette's own
3203: disinclination to return to her relatives, if any other acceptable
3204: possibility could be found.
3205: 
3206: He dreaded, with a violence of feeling which surmounted all struggles,
3207: lest anything should take her away, and place such barriers between them
3208: as would make it unlikely or impossible that she should ever love him
3209: well enough to become his wife. Yet he saw with perfect clearness that
3210: unless he tore up his mad passion by the roots, his ministerial
3211: usefulness would be frustrated, and the repose of his soul would be
3212: destroyed. This woman was an unregenerate Catholic; ten minutes'
3213: listening to her artless talk made that plain to him: even if her
3214: position had been less equivocal, to unite himself to such a woman was
3215: nothing less than a spiritual fall. It was already a fall that he had
3216: wished there was no high purpose to which he owed an allegiance--that he
3217: had longed to fly to some backwoods where there was no church to
3218: reproach him, and where he might have this sweet woman to wife, and to
3219: know the joys of tenderness. Those sensibilities which in most lives are
3220: diffused equally through the youthful years, were aroused suddenly in
3221: Mr. Lyon, as some men have their special genius revealed to them by a
3222: tardy concurrence of conditions. His love was the first love of a fresh
3223: young heart full of wonder and worship. But what to one man is the
3224: virtue which he has sunk below the possibility of aspiring to, is to
3225: another the backsliding by which he forfeits his spiritual crown.
3226: 
3227: The end was, that Annette remained in his house. He had striven against
3228: himself so far as to represent her position to some chief matrons in his
3229: congregation, praying and yet dreading that they would so take her by
3230: the hand as to impose on him that denial of his own longing not to let
3231: her go out of his sight, which he found it too hard to impose on
3232: himself. But they regarded the case coldly; the woman was, after all, a
3233: vagrant. Mr. Lyon was observed to be surprisingly weak on the
3234: subject--his eagerness seemed disproportionate and unbecoming; and this
3235: young Frenchwoman, unable to express herself very clearly, was no more
3236: interesting to those matrons and their husbands than other pretty young
3237: women suspiciously circumstanced. They were willing to subscribe
3238: something to carry her on her way, or if she took some lodgings they
3239: would give her a little sewing, and endeavor to convert her from
3240: Papistry. If, however, she was a respectable person, as she said, the
3241: only proper thing for her was to go back to her own country and friends.
3242: In spite of himself, Mr. Lyon exulted. There seemed a reason now that he
3243: should keep Annette under his own eyes. He told himself that no real
3244: object would be served by his providing food and lodging for her
3245: elsewhere--an expense which he could ill afford. And she was apparently
3246: so helpless, except as to the one task of attending to her baby, that it
3247: would have been folly to think of her exerting herself for her own
3248: support.
3249: 
3250: But this course of his was severely disapproved by his church. There
3251: were various signs that the minister was under some evil influence: his
3252: preaching wanted its old fervor, he seemed to shun the intercourse of
3253: his brethren, and very mournful suspicions were entertained. A formal
3254: remonstrance was presented to him, but he met it as if he had already
3255: determined to act in anticipation of it. He admitted that external
3256: circumstances, conjoined with a peculiar state of mind, were likely to
3257: hinder the fruitful exercise of his ministry, and he resigned it. There
3258: was much sorrowing, much expostulation, but he declared that for the
3259: present he was unable to unfold himself more fully; he only wished to
3260: state solemnly that Annette Ledru, though blind in spiritual things, was
3261: in a worldly sense a pure and virtuous woman. No more was to be said,
3262: and he departed to a distant town. Here he maintained himself, Annette
3263: and the child, with the remainder of his stipend, and with the wages he
3264: earned as a printer's reader. Annette was one of those angelic-faced
3265: helpless women who take all things as manna from heaven: the good image
3266: of the well-beloved Saint John wished her to stay with him, and there
3267: was nothing else that she wished for except the unattainable. Yet for a
3268: whole year Mr. Lyon never dared to tell Annette that he loved her: he
3269: trembled before this woman; he saw that the idea of his being her lover
3270: was too remote from her mind for her to have any idea that she ought not
3271: to live with him. She had never known, never asked the reason why he
3272: gave up his ministry. She seemed to entertain as little concern about
3273: the strange world in which she lived as a bird in its nest: an avalanche
3274: had fallen over the past, but she sat warm and uncrushed--there was food
3275: for many morrows, and her baby flourished. She did not seem even to care
3276: about a priest, or about having her child baptized; and on the subject
3277: of religion Mr. Lyon was as timid, and shrank as much from speaking to
3278: her, as on the subject of his love. He dreaded anything that might cause
3279: her to feel a sudden repulsion toward him. He dreaded disturbing her
3280: simple gratitude and content. In these days his religious faith was not
3281: slumbering; it was awake and achingly conscious of having fallen in a
3282: struggle. He had had a great treasure committed to him, and had flung it
3283: away: he held himself a backslider. His unbelieving thoughts never
3284: gained the full ear and consent of his soul. His prayers had been
3285: stifled by the sense that there was something he preferred to complete
3286: obedience; they had ceased to be anything but intermittent cries and
3287: confessions, and a submissive presentiment, rising at times even to an
3288: entreaty, that some great discipline might come, that the dull spiritual
3289: sense might be roused to full vision and hearing as of old, and the
3290: supreme facts become again supreme in his soul. Mr. Lyon will perhaps
3291: seem a very simple personage, with pitiably narrow theories; but none of
3292: our theories are quite large enough for all the disclosures of time, and
3293: to the end of men's struggles a penalty will remain for those who sink
3294: from the ranks of the heroes into the crowd for whom the heroes fight
3295: and die.
3296: 
3297: One day, however, Annette learned Mr. Lyon's secret. The baby had a
3298: tooth coming, and being large and strong now, was noisily fretful. Mr.
3299: Lyon, though he had been working extra hours and was much in need of
3300: repose, took the child from its mother immediately on entering the house
3301: and walked about with it, patting and talking soothingly to it. The
3302: stronger grasp, the new sensations, were a successful anodyne, and baby
3303: went to sleep on his shoulder. But fearful lest any movement should
3304: disturb it, he sat down, and endured the bondage of holding it still
3305: against his shoulder.
3306: 
3307: "You do nurse baby well," said Annette, approvingly. "Yet you never
3308: nursed before I came?"
3309: 
3310: "No," said Mr. Lyon. "I had no brothers and sisters."
3311: 
3312: "Why were you not married?" Annette had never thought of asking that
3313: question before.
3314: 
3315: "Because I never loved any woman--till now. I thought I should never
3316: marry. Now I wish to marry."
3317: 
3318: Annette started. She did not see at once that she was the woman he
3319: wanted to marry; what had flashed on her mind was, that there might be a
3320: great change in Mr. Lyon's life. It was as if the lightning had entered
3321: into her dream and half awaked her.
3322: 
3323: "Do you think it foolish, Annette, that I should wish to marry?"
3324: 
3325: "I did not expect it," she said, doubtfully. "I did not know you thought
3326: about it."
3327: 
3328: "You know the woman I should like to marry?"
3329: 
3330: "I know her?" she said, interrogatively, blushing deeply.
3331: 
3332: "It is you, Annette--you whom I have loved better than my duty. I
3333: forsook everything for you."
3334: 
3335: Mr. Lyon paused: he was about to do what he felt would be ignoble--to
3336: urge what seemed like a claim.
3337: 
3338: "Can you love me, Annette? Will you be my wife?" Annette trembled and
3339: looked miserable.
3340: 
3341: "Do not speak--forget it," said Mr. Lyon, rising suddenly and speaking
3342: with loud energy. "No, no--I do not want it--I do not wish it."
3343: 
3344: The baby awoke as he started up; he gave the child into Annette's arms,
3345: and left her.
3346: 
3347: His work took him away early the next morning and the next again. They
3348: did not need to speak much to each other. The third day Mr. Lyon was too
3349: ill to go to work. His frame had been overwrought; he had been too poor
3350: to have sufficiently nourishing food, and under the shattering of his
3351: long deferred hope his health had given away. They had no regular
3352: servant--only occasional help from an old woman, who lit the fires and
3353: put on the kettles. Annette was forced to be the sick-nurse, and this
3354: sudden demand on her shook away some of her torpor. The illness was a
3355: serious one, and the medical man one day hearing Mr. Lyon in his
3356: delirium raving with an astonishing fluency in Biblical language,
3357: suddenly looked round with increased curiosity at Annette, and asked if
3358: she were the sick man's wife, or some other relative.
3359: 
3360: "No--no relation," said Annette, shaking her head. "He has been good to
3361: me."
3362: 
3363: "How long have you lived with him?"
3364: 
3365: "More than a year."
3366: 
3367: "Was he a preacher once?"
3368: 
3369: "Yes."
3370: 
3371: "When did he leave off being a preacher?"
3372: 
3373: "Soon after he took care of me."
3374: 
3375: "Is that his child?"
3376: 
3377: "Sir," said Annette, coloring indignantly, "I am a widow."
3378: 
3379: The doctor, she thought, looked at her oddly, but he asked no more
3380: questions.
3381: 
3382: When the sick man was getting better, and able to enjoy invalid's food,
3383: he observed one day, while he was taking some broth, that Annette was
3384: looking at him; he paused to look at her in return, and was struck with
3385: a new expression in her face, quite distinct from the merely passive
3386: sweetness which usually characterized it. She laid her little hand on
3387: his, which was now transparently thin, and said, "I am getting very
3388: wise; I have sold some of the books to make money--the doctor told me
3389: where; and I have looked into the shops where they sell caps and bonnets
3390: and pretty things, and I can do all that, and get more money to keep
3391: us. And when you are well enough to get up, we will go out and be
3392: married--shall we not? See! and _la petite_" (the baby had never
3393: been named anything else) "shall call you Papa--and then we shall never
3394: part."
3395: 
3396: Mr. Lyon trembled. This illness--something else, perhaps--had made a
3397: great change in Annette. A fortnight after that they were married. The
3398: day before he had ventured to ask her if she felt any difficulty about
3399: her religion, and if she would consent to have _la petite_ baptized and
3400: brought up as a Protestant. She shook her head and said very simply--
3401: 
3402: "No: in France, in other days, I would have minded; but all is changed.
3403: I never was fond of religion, but I knew it was right. _J'aimais les
3404: fleurs, les bals, la musique, et mon mari qui était beau_. But all that
3405: is gone away. There is nothing of my religion in this country. But the
3406: good God must be here, for you are good; I leave all to you."
3407: 
3408: It was clear that Annette regarded her present life as a sort of death
3409: to the world--an existence on a remote island where she had been saved
3410: from wreck. She was too indolent mentally, too little interested, to
3411: acquaint herself with any secrets of the isle. The transient energy, the
3412: more vivid consciousness and sympathy which had been stirred in her
3413: during Mr. Lyon's illness, had soon subsided into the old apathy to
3414: everything except her child. She withered like a plant in strange air,
3415: and the three years of life that remained were but a slow and gentle
3416: death. Those three years were to Mr. Lyon a period of such
3417: self-suppression and life in another as few men know. Strange! that the
3418: passion for this woman, which he felt to have drawn him aside from the
3419: right as much as if he had broken the most solemn vows--for that only
3420: was right to him which he held the best and highest--the passion for a
3421: being who had no glimpse of his thoughts induced a more thorough
3422: renunciation than he had ever known in the time of his complete devotion
3423: to his ministerial career. He had no flattery now, either from himself
3424: or the world; he knew that he had fallen, and _his_ world had forgotten
3425: him, or shook their heads at his memory. The only satisfaction he had
3426: was the satisfaction of his tenderness--which meant untiring work,
3427: untiring patience, untiring wakefulness even to the dumb signs of
3428: feeling in a creature whom he alone cared for.
3429: 
3430: The day of parting came, and he was left with little Esther as the one
3431: visible sign of that four years' break in his life. A year afterward he
3432: entered the ministry again, and lived with the utmost sparingness that
3433: Esther might be so educated as to be able to get her own bread in case
3434: of his death. Her probable facility in acquiring French naturally
3435: suggested his sending her to a French school, which would give her a
3436: special advantage as a teacher. It was a Protestant school, and French
3437: Protestantism had the high recommendation of being non-Prelatical. It
3438: was understood that Esther would contract no Papistical superstitions;
3439: and this was perfectly true; but she contracted, as we see, a good deal
3440: of non-Papistical vanity.
3441: 
3442: Mr. Lyon's reputation as a preacher and devoted pastor had revived; but
3443: some dissatisfaction beginning to be felt by his congregation at a
3444: certain laxity detected by them in his views as to the limits of
3445: salvation, which he had in one sermon even hinted might extend to
3446: unconscious recipients of mercy, he had found it desirable seven years
3447: ago to quit this ten years' pastorate and accept a call from the less
3448: important church in Malthouse Yard, Treby Magna.
3449: 
3450: This was Rufus Lyon's history, at that time unknown in its fullness to
3451: any human being besides himself. We can perhaps guess what memories they
3452: were that relaxed the stringency of his doctrine on the point of
3453: salvation. In the deepest of all senses his heart said--
3454: 
3455:     "Though she be dead, yet let me think she lives,
3456:     And feed my mind, that dies for want of her."
3457: 
3458: 
3459: 
3460: 
3461: CHAPTER VII.
3462: 
3463:     _M._  It was but yesterday you spoke him well--
3464:           You've changed your mind so soon?
3465: 
3466:     _N._                    Not I--'tis he
3467:           That, changing to my thought, has changed my mind.
3468:           No man puts rotten apples in his pouch
3469:           Because their upper side looked fair to him.
3470:           Constancy in mistake is constant folly.
3471: 
3472: 
3473: The news that the rich heir of the Transomes was actually come back, and
3474: had been seen at Treby, was carried to some one else who had more
3475: reasons for being interested in it than the Reverend Rufus Lyon was yet
3476: conscious of having. It was owing to this that at three o'clock, two
3477: days afterward, a carriage and pair, with coachman and footman in
3478: crimson and drab, passed through the lodge gates at Transome Court.
3479: Inside there was a hale, good-natured-looking man of sixty, whose hands
3480: rested on a knotted stick held between his knees; and a blue-eyed,
3481: well-featured lady, fat and middle-aged--a mountain of satin, lace, and
3482: exquisite muslin embroidery. They were not persons of a highly
3483: remarkable appearance, but to most Trebians they seemed absolutely
3484: unique, and likely to be known anywhere. If you had looked down upon
3485: them from the box of Sampson's coach, he would have said, after lifting
3486: his hat, "Sir Maximus and his lady--did you see?" thinking it needless
3487: to add the surname.
3488: 
3489: "We shall find her greatly elated, doubtless," Lady Debarry was saying.
3490: "She has been in the shade so long."
3491: 
3492: "Ah, poor thing!" said Sir Maximus. "A fine woman she was in her bloom.
3493: I remember the first county ball she attended we were all ready to fight
3494: for the sake of dancing with her. I always liked her from that time--I
3495: never swallowed the scandal about her myself."
3496: 
3497: "If we are to be intimate with her," said Lady Debarry, "I wish you
3498: would avoid making such allusions, Sir Maximus. I should not like Selina
3499: and Harriet to hear them."
3500: 
3501: "My dear, I should have forgotten all about the scandal, only you remind
3502: me of it sometimes," retorted the baronet, smiling and taking out his
3503: snuff-box.
3504: 
3505: "These sudden turns of fortune are often dangerous to an excitable
3506: constitution," said Lady Debarry, not choosing to notice her husband's
3507: epigram. "Poor Lady Alicia Methurst got heart-disease from a sudden
3508: piece of luck--the death of her uncle, you know. If Mrs. Transome was
3509: wise she would go to town--she can afford it now, and consult Dr.
3510: Truncheon. I should say myself he would order her digitalis: I have
3511: often guessed exactly what a prescription would be. But it certainly was
3512: one of her weak points to think she understood medicine better than
3513: other people."
3514: 
3515: "She's a healthy woman enough, surely: see how upright she is, and she
3516: rides about like a girl of twenty."
3517: 
3518: "She is so thin that she makes me shudder."
3519: 
3520: "Pooh! she's slim and active; women are not bid for by the pound."
3521: 
3522: "Pray don't be so coarse."
3523: 
3524: Sir Maximus laughed and showed his good teeth, which made his laughter
3525: very becoming. The carriage stopped, and they were soon ushered to Mrs.
3526: Transome's sitting-room, where she was working at her worsted
3527: embroidery. A little daily embroidery had been a constant element in
3528: Mrs. Transome's life; but that soothing occupation of taking stitches to
3529: produce what neither she nor any one else wanted, was then the resource
3530: of many a well-born and unhappy woman.
3531: 
3532: She received much warm congratulation and pressure of her hand with
3533: perfect composure of manner; but she became paler than usual, and her
3534: hands turned quite cold. The Debarrys did not yet know what Harold's
3535: politics were.
3536: 
3537: "Well, our lucky youngster is come in the nick of time," said Sir
3538: Maximus: "if he'll stand, he and Philip can run in harness together and
3539: keep out both the Whigs."
3540: 
3541: "It is really quite a providential thing--his returning just now," said
3542: Lady Debarry. "I couldn't help thinking that something would occur to
3543: prevent Philip from having such a man as Peter Garstin for his
3544: colleague."
3545: 
3546: "I call my friend Harold a youngster," said Sir Maximus, "for, you know,
3547: I remember him only as he was when that portrait was taken."
3548: 
3549: "That is a long while ago," said Mrs. Transome. "My son is much altered,
3550: as you may imagine."
3551: 
3552: There was a confused sound of voices in the library while this talk was
3553: going on. Mrs. Transome chose to ignore that noise, but her face, from
3554: being pale, began to flush a little.
3555: 
3556: "Yes, yes, on the outside, I dare say. But he was a fine fellow--I
3557: always liked him. And if anybody should ask me what I should choose for
3558: the good of the country, I couldn't have thought of anything better than
3559: having a young Transome for a neighbor who will take an active part. The
3560: Transomes and the Debarrys were always on the right side together in old
3561: days. Of course he'll stand--he has made up his mind to it?"
3562: 
3563: The need for an answer to this embarrassing question was deferred by the
3564: increase of inarticulate sounds accompanied by a bark from the library,
3565: and the sudden appearance at the tapestry-hung doorway of old Mr.
3566: Transome with a cord around his waist, playing a very poor-paced horse
3567: for a black-maned little boy about three years old, who was urging him
3568: on with loud encouraging noises and occasional thumps from a stick which
3569: he wielded with difficulty. The old man paused with a vague smile at the
3570: doorway while the baronet got up to speak to him. Nimrod snuffed at his
3571: master's legs to ascertain that he was not hurt, and the little boy,
3572: finding something new to be looked at, let go the cord and came round in
3573: front of the company, dragging his stick, and standing at a safe
3574: war-dancing distance as he fixed his great black eyes on Lady Debarry.
3575: 
3576: "Dear me, what a splendid little boy, Mrs. Transome! why--it cannot
3577: be--can it be--that you have the happiness to be a grandmamma?"
3578: 
3579: "Yes; that is my son's little boy."
3580: 
3581: "Indeed!" said Lady Debarry, really amazed. "I never heard you speak of
3582: his marriage. He has brought you home a daughter-in-law, then?"
3583: 
3584: "No," said Mrs. Transome, coldly; "she is dead."
3585: 
3586: "O--o--oh!" said Lady Debarry, in a tone ludicrously undecided between
3587: condolence, satisfaction, and general mistiness. "How very singular--I
3588: mean that we should not have heard of Mr. Harold's marriage. But he's a
3589: charming little fellow: come to me, you round-cheeked cherub."
3590: 
3591: The black eyes continued fixed as if by a sort of fascination on Lady
3592: Debarry's face, and her affable invitation was unheeded. At last,
3593: putting his head forward and pouting his lips, the cherub gave forth
3594: with marked intention the sounds, "Nau-o-oom," many times repeated:
3595: apparently they summed up his opinion of Lady Debarry, and may perhaps
3596: have meant "naughty old woman," but his speech was a broken lisping
3597: polyglot of hazardous interpretation. Then he turned to pull at the
3598: Blenheim spaniel, which, being old and peevish, gave a little snap.
3599: 
3600: "Go, go, Harry; let poor Puff alone--he'll bite you," said Mrs.
3601: Transome, stooping to release her aged pet.
3602: 
3603: Her words were too suggestive, for Harry immediately laid hold of her
3604: arm with his teeth, and bit with all his might. Happily the stuffs upon
3605: it were some protection, but the pain forced Mrs. Transome to give a low
3606: cry; and Sir Maximus, who had now turned to reseat himself, shook the
3607: little rascal off, whereupon he burst away and trotted into the library
3608: again.
3609: 
3610: "I fear you are hurt," said Lady Debarry, with sincere concern. "What a
3611: little savage! Do have your arm attended to, my dear--I recommend
3612: fomentation--don't think of me."
3613: 
3614: "Oh, thank you, it is nothing," said Mrs. Transome, biting her lip and
3615: smiling alternately; "it will soon go off. The pleasures of being a
3616: grandmamma, you perceive. The child has taken a dislike to me; but he
3617: makes quite a new life for Mr. Transome; they were playfellows at once."
3618: 
3619: "Bless my heart!" said Sir Maximus, "it is odd to think of Harold having
3620: been a family man so long. I made up my mind he was a young bachelor.
3621: What an old stager I am, to be sure! And whom has he married? I hope we
3622: shall soon have the pleasure of seeing Mrs. Harold Transome." Sir
3623: Maximus, occupied with old Mr. Transome, had not overheard the previous
3624: conversation on that subject.
3625: 
3626: "She is no longer living," Lady Debarry hastily interposed; "but now, my
3627: dear Sir Maximus, we must not hinder Mrs. Transome from attending to her
3628: arm. I am sure she is in pain. Don't say another word, my dear--we shall
3629: see you again--you and Mr. Harold will come and dine with us on
3630: Thursday--say yes, only yes. Sir Maximus is longing to see him: and
3631: Philip will be down."
3632: 
3633: "Yes, yes!" said Sir Maximus; "he must lose no time in making Philip's
3634: acquaintance. Tell him Philip is a fine fellow--carried everything
3635: before him at Oxford. And your son must be returned along with him for
3636: North Loamshire. You said he meant to stand?"
3637: 
3638: "I will write and let you know if Harold has any engagement for
3639: Thursday; he would of course be happy otherwise," said Mrs. Transome,
3640: evading the question.
3641: 
3642: "If not Thursday, the next day--the very first day he can."
3643: 
3644: The visitors left, and Mrs. Transome was almost glad of the painful bite
3645: which had saved her from being questioned further about Harold's
3646: politics. "This is the last visit I shall receive from them," she said
3647: to herself as the door closed behind them, and she rang for Denner.
3648: 
3649: "That poor creature is not happy, Sir Maximus," said Lady Debarry as
3650: they drove along. "Something annoys her about her son. I hope there is
3651: nothing unpleasant in his character. Either he kept his marriage a
3652: secret from her, or she was ashamed of it. He is thirty-four at least by
3653: this time. After living in the East so long he may have become a sort of
3654: person one would not care to be intimate with, and that savage boy--he
3655: doesn't look like a lady's child."
3656: 
3657: "Pooh, my dear," said Sir Maximus, "women think so much of those
3658: minutiæ. In the present state of the country it is our duty to look at a
3659: man's position and politics. Philip and my brother are both of that
3660: opinion, and I think they know what's right, if any man does. We are
3661: bound to regard every man of our party as a public instrument, and to
3662: pull all together. The Transomes have always been a good Tory family,
3663: but it has been a cipher of late years. This young fellow coming back
3664: with a fortune to give the family a head and a position is a clear gain
3665: to the county; and with Philip he'll get into the right hands--of course
3666: he wants guiding, having been out of the country so long. All we have to
3667: ask is, whether a man's a Tory, and will make a stand for the good of
3668: the country?--that's the plain English of the matter. And I do beg of
3669: you, my dear, to set aside all these gossiping niceties, and exert
3670: yourself, like a woman of sense and spirit as you are, to bring the
3671: right people together."
3672: 
3673: Here Sir Maximus gave a deep cough, took out his snuff-box, and tapped
3674: it: he had made a serious marital speech, an exertion to which he was
3675: rarely urged by anything smaller than a matter of conscience. And this
3676: outline of the whole duty of a Tory was a matter of conscience with him;
3677: though the _Duffield Watchman_ had pointed expressly to Sir Maximus
3678: Debarry amongst others, in branding the co-operation of the Tories as a
3679: conscious selfishness and reckless immorality, which, however, would be
3680: defeated by the co-operation of all the friends of truth and liberty,
3681: who, the _Watchman_ trusted, would subordinate all non-political
3682: differences in order to return representatives pledged to support the
3683: present government.
3684: 
3685: "I am sure, Sir Maximus," Lady Debarry answered, "you could not have
3686: observed that anything was wanting in my manners to Mrs. Transome."
3687: 
3688: "No, no, my dear; but I say this by way of caution. Never mind what was
3689: done at Smyrna, or whether Transome likes to sit with his heels tucked
3690: up. We may surely wink at a few things for the sake of the public
3691: interest, if God Almighty does; and if He didn't, I don't know what
3692: would have become of the country--Government could never have been
3693: carried on, and many a good battle would have been lost. That's the
3694: philosophy of the matter, and common-sense too."
3695: 
3696: Good Sir Maximus gave a deep cough and tapped his box again, inwardly
3697: remarking, that if he had not been such a lazy fellow he might have made
3698: as good a figure as his son Philip.
3699: 
3700: But at this point the carriage, which was rolling by a turn toward Treby
3701: Magna, passed a well-dressed man, who raised his hat to Sir Maximus, and
3702: called to the coachman to stop.
3703: 
3704: "Excuse me, Sir Maximus," said this personage, standing uncovered at the
3705: carriage-door, "but I have just learned something of importance at
3706: Treby, which I thought you would like to know as soon as possible."
3707: 
3708: "Ah! what's that? Something about Garstin or Clement?" said Sir Maximus,
3709: seeing the other draw a poster from his pocket.
3710: 
3711: "No; rather worse, I fear you will think. A new Radical candidate. I got
3712: this by a stratagem from the printer's boy. They're not posted yet."
3713: 
3714: "A Radical!" said Sir Maximus, in a tone of incredulous disgust, as he
3715: took the folded bill. "What fool is he?--he'll have no chance."
3716: 
3717: "They say he's richer than Garstin."
3718: 
3719: "Harold Transome!" shouted Sir Maximus, as he read the name in
3720: three-inch letters. "I don't believe it--it's a trick--it's a squib:
3721: why--why--we've just been to his place--eh? do you know any more? Speak,
3722: sir--speak; don't deal out your story like a damned mountebank, who
3723: wants to keep people gaping."
3724: 
3725: "Sir Maximus, pray don't give way so," said Lady Debarry.
3726: 
3727: "I'm afraid there's no doubt about it, sir," said Christian. "After
3728: getting the bill, I met Mr. Labron's clerk, and he said he had just had
3729: the whole story from Jermyn's clerk. The Ram Inn is engaged already, and
3730: a committee is being made up. He says Jermyn goes like a steam engine,
3731: when he has a mind, although he makes such long-winded speeches."
3732: 
3733: "Jermyn be hanged for a two-faced rascal! Tell Mitchell to drive on.
3734: It's of no use to stay chattering here. Jump up on the box and go home
3735: with us. I may want you."
3736: 
3737: "You see I was right, Sir Maximus," said the baronet's wife. "I had an
3738: instinct that we should find him an unpleasant person."
3739: 
3740: "Fudge! if you had such a fine instinct, why did you let us go to
3741: Transome Court and make fools of ourselves?"
3742: 
3743: "Would you have listened to me? But of course you will not have him to
3744: dine with you?"
3745: 
3746: "Dine with me? I should think not. I'd sooner he should dine off me. I
3747: see how it is clearly enough. He has become a regular beast among those
3748: Mahometans--he's got neither religion nor morals left. He can't know any
3749: thing about English politics. He'll go and cut his own nose off as a
3750: landholder, and never know. However, he won't get in--he'll spend his
3751: money for nothing."
3752: 
3753: "I fear he is a very licentious man," said Lady Debarry. "We know now
3754: why his mother seemed so uneasy. I should think she reflects a little,
3755: poor creature."
3756: 
3757: "It's a confounded nuisance we didn't meet Christian on our way, instead
3758: of coming back; but better now than later. He's an uncommonly adroit,
3759: useful fellow, that factotum of Philip's. I wish Phil would take my man
3760: and give me Christian. I'd make him house-steward: he might reduce the
3761: accounts a little."
3762: 
3763: Perhaps Sir Maximus would not have been so sanguine as to Mr.
3764: Christian's economical virtues if he had seen that gentleman relaxing
3765: himself the same evening among the other distinguished dependents of the
3766: family and frequenters of the steward's room. But a man of Sir Maximus's
3767: rank is like those antediluvian animals whom the system of things
3768: condemned to carry such a huge bulk that they really could not inspect
3769: their bodily appurtenance, and had no conception of their own tails:
3770: their parasites doubtless had a merry time of it, and often did
3771: extremely well when the high-bred saurian himself was ill at ease. Treby
3772: Manor, measured from the front saloon to the remotest shed, was as large
3773: as a moderate-sized village, and there were certainly more lights
3774: burning in it every evening, more wine, spirits, and ale drunk, more
3775: waste and more folly, than could be found in some large villages. There
3776: was fast revelry in the steward's room, and slow revelry in the Scotch
3777: bailiff's room; short whist, costume, and flirtation in the
3778: housekeeper's room, and the same at a lower price in the servants' hall;
3779: a select Olympian feast in the private apartment of the cook, who was a
3780: much grander person than her ladyship, and wore gold and jewelry to a
3781: vast amount of suet; a gambling group in the stables, and the coachman,
3782: perhaps the most innocent member of the establishment, tippling in
3783: majestic solitude by a fire in the harness-room. For Sir Maximus, as
3784: every one said, was a gentleman of the right sort, condescended to no
3785: mean enquiries, greeted his head-servants with a "good-evening,
3786: gentlemen," when he met them in the park, and only snarled in a subdued
3787: way when he looked over the accounts, willing to endure some personal
3788: inconvenience in order to keep up the institutions of the country, to
3789: maintain his hereditary establishment, and do his duty in that station
3790: of life--the station of the long-tailed saurian--to which it had pleased
3791: Providence to call him.
3792: 
3793: The focus of brilliancy at Treby Manor that evening was in no way the
3794: dining-room, where Sir Maximus sipped his port under some mental
3795: depression, as he discussed with his brother, the Reverend Augustus, the
3796: sad fact that one of the oldest names in the county was to be on the
3797: wrong side--not in the drawing-room, where Miss Debarry and Miss Selina,
3798: quietly elegant in their dress and manners, were feeling rather dull
3799: than otherwise, having finished Mr. Bulwer's "Eugene Aram," and being
3800: thrown back on the last great prose work of Mr. Southey, while their
3801: mamma slumbered a little on the sofa. No; the centre of eager talk and
3802: enjoyment was the steward's room, where Mr. Scales, house-steward and
3803: head-butler, a man most solicitous about his boots, wristbands, the roll
3804: of his whiskers, and other attributes of a gentleman, distributed
3805: cigars, cognac, and whiskey, to various colleagues and guests who were
3806: discussing, with that freedom of conjecture which is one of our
3807: inalienable privileges as Britons, the probable amount of Harold
3808: Transome's fortune, concerning which fame had already been busy long
3809: enough to have acquired vast magnifying power.
3810: 
3811: The chief part in this scene was undoubtedly Mr. Christian's, although
3812: he had hitherto been comparatively silent; but he occupied two chairs
3813: with so much grace, throwing his right leg over the seat of the second,
3814: and resting his right hand on the back; he held his cigar and displayed
3815: a splendid seal-ring with such becoming nonchalance, and had his gray
3816: hair arranged with so much taste, that experienced eyes would at once
3817: have seen even the great Scales himself to be but a secondary character.
3818: 
3819: "Why," said Mr. Crowder, an old respectable tenant, though much in
3820: arrear as to his rent, who condescended frequently to drink in the
3821: steward's room for the sake of the conversation; "why, I suppose they
3822: get money so fast in the East--it's wonderful. Why," he went on, with a
3823: hesitating look toward Mr. Scales, "this Transome p'r'aps got a matter
3824: of a hundred thousand."
3825: 
3826: "A hundred thousand, my dear sir! fiddle-stick's end of a hundred
3827: thousand," said Mr. Scales, with a contempt very painful to be borne by
3828: a modest man.
3829: 
3830: "Well," said Mr. Crowder, giving way under torture, as the all-knowing
3831: butler puffed and stared at him, "perhaps not so much as that."
3832: 
3833: "Not so much, sir! I tell you that a hundred thousand pounds is a
3834: bagatelle."
3835: 
3836: "Well, I know it's a big sum," said Mr. Crowder, deprecatingly.
3837:
