3838: Here there was a general laugh. All the other intellects present were
3839: more cultivated than Mr. Crowder's.
3840: 
3841: "Bagatelle is the French for trifle, my friend," said Mr. Christian.
3842: "Don't talk over people's heads so, Scales. I shall have hard work to
3843: understand you myself soon."
3844: 
3845: "Come, that's a good one," said the head-gardener, who was a ready
3846: admirer; "I should like to hear the thing you don't understand,
3847: Christian."
3848: 
3849: "He's a first-rate hand at sneering," said Mr. Scales, rather nettled.
3850: 
3851: "Don't be waspie, man. I'll ring the bell for lemons, and make some
3852: punch. That's the thing for putting people up to the unknown tongues,"
3853: said Mr. Christian, starting up and slapping Scales's shoulder as he
3854: passed him.
3855: 
3856: "What I mean, Mr. Crowder, is this." Here Mr. Scales paused to puff,
3857: and pull down his waistcoat in a gentlemanly manner, and drink. He was
3858: wont in this way to give his hearers time for meditation.
3859: 
3860: "Come, then, speak English; I'm not against being taught," said the
3861: reasonable Crowder.
3862: 
3863: "What I mean is, that in a large way of trade a man turns his capital
3864: over almost as soon as he can turn himself. Bless your soul! I know
3865: something about these matters, eh, Brent?"
3866: 
3867: "To be sure you do--few men more," said the gardener, who was the person
3868: appealed to.
3869: 
3870: "Not that I've had anything to do with commercial families myself. I've
3871: those feelings that I look to other things besides lucre. But I can't
3872: say that I've not been intimate with parties who have been less nice
3873: than I am myself; and knowing what I know, I shouldn't wonder if
3874: Transome had as much as five hundred thousand. Bless your soul, sir!
3875: people who get their money out of land are as long scraping five pounds
3876: together as your trading men are in turning five pounds into a hundred."
3877: 
3878: "That's a wicked thing, though," said Mr. Crowder, meditatively.
3879: "However," he went on, retreating from this difficult ground, "trade or
3880: no trade, the Transomes have been poor enough this many a long year.
3881: I've a brother a tenant on their estate--I ought to know a little bit
3882: about that."
3883: 
3884: "They've kept up no establishment at all," said Mr. Scales, with
3885: disgust. "They've even let their kitchen gardens. I suppose it was the
3886: son's gambling. I've seen something of that. A man who has always lived
3887: in first-rate families is likely to know a thing or two on that
3888: subject."
3889: 
3890: "Ah, but it wasn't gambling did the first mischief," said Mr. Crowder,
3891: with a slight smile, feeling that it was his turn to have some
3892: superiority. "New-comers don't know what happened in this country twenty
3893: and thirty years ago. I'm turned fifty myself, and my father lived under
3894: Sir Maximus's father. But if anybody from London can tell me more than I
3895: know about this country-side, I'm willing to listen."
3896: 
3897: "What was it, then, if it wasn't gambling?" said Mr. Scales, with some
3898: impatience. "_I_ don't pretend to know."
3899: 
3900: "It was law--law--that's what it was. Not but what the Transomes always
3901: won."
3902: 
3903: "And always lost," said the too-ready Scales. "Yes, yes; I think we all
3904: know the nature of law."
3905: 
3906: "There was the last suit of all made the most noise, as I understood,"
3907: continued Mr. Crowder; "but it wasn't tried hereabout. They said there
3908: was a deal o' false swearing. Some young man pretended to be the true
3909: heir--let me see--I can't justly remember the names--he'd got two. _He_
3910: swore he was one man, and _they_ swore he was another. However Lawyer
3911: Jermyn won it--they say he'd win a game against the Old One himself--and
3912: the young fellow turned out to be a scamp. Stop a bit--his name was
3913: Scaddon--Henry Scaddon."
3914: 
3915: Mr. Christian here let a lemon slip from his hand into the punch-bowl
3916: with a splash which sent some of the nectar into the company's faces.
3917: 
3918: "Hallo! What a bungler I am!" he said, looking as if he were quite
3919: jarred by this unusual awkwardness of his. "Go on with your tale, Mr.
3920: Crowder--a scamp named Henry Scaddon."
3921: 
3922: "Well, that's the tale," said Mr. Crowder. "He was never seen nothing of
3923: anymore. It was a deal talked of at the time--and I've sat by; and my
3924: father used to shake his head; and always when this Mrs. Transome was
3925: talked of, he used to shake his head, and say she carried things with a
3926: high hand once. But, Lord! it was before the battle of Waterloo, and I'm
3927: a poor hand at tales; I don't see much good in 'em myself--but if
3928: anybody'll tell me a cure for the sheep-rot, I'll thank him."
3929: 
3930: Here Mr. Crowder relapsed into smoking and silence, a little discomfited
3931: that the knowledge of which he had been delivered had turned out rather
3932: a shapeless and insignificant birth.
3933: 
3934: "Well, well, bygones should be bygones; there are secrets in most good
3935: families," said Mr. Scales, winking, "and this young Transome, coming
3936: back with a fortune to keep up the establishment, and have things done
3937: in a decent and gentlemanly way--it would all have been right if he'd
3938: not been this sort of Radical madman. But now he's done for himself. I
3939: heard Sir Maximus say at dinner that he would be excommunicated; and
3940: that's a pretty strong word, I take it."
3941: 
3942: "What does it mean, Scales?" said Mr. Christian, who loved tormenting.
3943: 
3944: "Ay, what's the meaning?" insisted Mr. Crowder, encouraged by finding
3945: that even Christian was in the dark.
3946: 
3947: "Well, it's a law term--speaking in a figurative sort of way--meaning
3948: that a Radical was no gentleman."
3949: 
3950: "Perhaps it's partly accounted for by his getting his money so fast, and
3951: in foreign countries," said Mr. Crowder, tentatively. "It's reasonable
3952: to think he'd be against the land and this country--eh, Sircome?"
3953: 
3954: Sircome was an eminent miller who had considerable business transactions
3955: at the Manor, and appreciated Mr. Scales's merits at a handsome
3956: percentage on the yearly account. He was a highly honorable tradesman,
3957: but in this and in other matters submitted to the institutions of his
3958: country; for great houses, as he observed, must have great butlers. He
3959: replied to his friend Crowder sententiously.
3960: 
3961: "I say nothing. Before I bring words to market, I should like to see 'em
3962: a bit scarcer. There's the land and there's trade--I hold with both. I
3963: swim with the stream."
3964: 
3965: "Hey-day, Mr. Sircome! that's a Radical maxim," said Mr. Christian, who
3966: knew that Mr. Sircome's last sentence was his favorite formula. "I
3967: advise you to give it up, else it will injure the quality of your
3968: flour."
3969: 
3970: "A Radical maxim!" said Mr. Sircome, in a tone of angry astonishment. "I
3971: should like to hear you prove that. It's as old as my grandfather,
3972: anyhow."
3973: 
3974: "I'll prove it in one minute," said the glib Christian. "Reform has set
3975: in by the will of the majority--that's the rabble, you know; and the
3976: respectability and good sense of the country, which are in the minority,
3977: are afraid of Reform running on too fast. So the stream must be running
3978: toward Reform and Radicalism; and if you swim with it, Mr. Sircome,
3979: you're a Reformer and a Radical, and your flour is objectionable, and
3980: not full weight--and being tried by Scales, will be found wanting."
3981: 
3982: There was a roar of laughter. This pun upon Scales was highly
3983: appreciated by every one except the miller and butler. The latter pulled
3984: down his waistcoat, and puffed and stared in rather an excited manner.
3985: Mr. Christian's wit, in general, seemed to him a poor kind of quibbling.
3986: 
3987: "What a fellow you are for fence, Christian," said the gardener. "Hang
3988: me, if I don't think you're up to everything."
3989: 
3990: "That's a compliment you might pay Old Nick, if you come to that," said
3991: Mr. Sircome, who was in the painful position of a man deprived of his
3992: formula.
3993: 
3994: "Yes, yes," said Mr. Scales; "I'm no fool myself, and could parry a
3995: thrust if I liked, but I shouldn't like it to be said of me that I was
3996: up to everything. I'll keep a little principle if you please."
3997: 
3998: "To be sure," said Christian, ladling out the punch. "What would justice
3999: be without Scales?"
4000: 
4001: The laughter was not quite so full-throated as before. Such excessive
4002: cleverness _was_ a little Satanic.
4003: 
4004: "A joke's a joke among gentlemen," said the butler, getting exasperated;
4005: "I think there has been quite liberties enough taken with my name. But
4006: if you must talk about names, I've heard of a party before now calling
4007: himself a Christian, and being anything _but_ it."
4008: 
4009: "Come, that's beyond a joke," said the surgeon's assistant, a fast man,
4010: whose chief scene of dissipation was the manor. "Let it drop, Scales."
4011: 
4012: "Yes, I dare say it's beyond a joke. I'm not a harlequin to talk nothing
4013: but jokes. I leave that to other Christians, who are up to everything,
4014: and have been everywhere--to the hulks, for what I know; and more than
4015: that, they come from nobody knows where, and try to worm themselves into
4016: gentlemen's confidence, to the prejudice of their betters."
4017: 
4018: There was a stricter sequence in Mr. Scales's angry eloquence than was
4019: apparent--some chief links being confined to his own breast, as is often
4020: the case in energetic discourse. The company were in a state of
4021: expectation. There was something behind worth knowing, and something
4022: before them worth seeing. In the general decay of other fine British
4023: pugnacious sports, a quarrel between gentlemen was all the more
4024: exciting, and though no one would himself have liked to turn on Scales,
4025: no one was sorry for the chance of seeing him put down. But the amazing
4026: Christian was unmoved. He had taken out his handkerchief and was rubbing
4027: his lips carefully. After a slight pause, he spoke with perfect
4028: coolness.
4029: 
4030: "I don't intend to quarrel with you, Scales. Such talk as this is not
4031: profitable to either of us. It makes you purple in the face--you _are_
4032: apoplectic, you know--and it spoils good company. Better tell a few fibs
4033: about me behind my back--it will heat you less, and do me more harm.
4034: I'll leave you to it; I shall go and have a game of whist with the
4035: ladies."
4036: 
4037: As the door closed behind the questionable Christian, Mr. Scales was in
4038: a state of frustration that prevented speech. Every one was rather
4039: embarrassed.
4040: 
4041: "That's an uncommon sort o' fellow," said Mr. Crowder, in an undertone,
4042: to his next neighbor, the gardener. "Why, Mr. Philip picked him up in
4043: foreign parts, didn't he?"
4044: 
4045: "He was a courier," said the gardener. "He's had a deal of experience.
4046: And I believe, by what I can make out--for he's been pretty free with me
4047: sometimes--there was a time when he was in that rank of life that he
4048: fought a duel."
4049: 
4050: "Ah! that makes him such a cool chap," said Mr. Crowder.
4051: 
4052: "He's what I call an overbearing fellow," said Mr. Sircome, also _sotto
4053: voce_, to his next neighbor, Mr. Filmore, the surgeon's assistant. "He
4054: runs you down with a sort of talk that's neither here nor there. He's
4055: got a deal too many samples in his pocket for me."
4056: 
4057: "All I know is, he's a wonderful hand at cards," said Mr. Filmore, whose
4058: whiskers and shirt-pin were quite above the average. "I wish I could
4059: play _écarté_ as he does; it's beautiful to see him; he can make a man
4060: look pretty blue; he'll empty his pocket for him in no time."
4061: 
4062: "That's none to his credit," said Mr. Sircome.
4063: 
4064: The conversation had in this way broken up into _tête-à-tête_, and the
4065: hilarity of the evening might be considered a failure. Still the punch
4066: was drunk, the accounts were duly swelled, and, notwithstanding the
4067: innovating spirit of the time, Sir Maximus Debarry's establishment was
4068: kept up in sound hereditary British manner.
4069: 
4070: 
4071: 
4072: 
4073: CHAPTER VIII.
4074: 
4075:     "Rumor doth double like the voice and echo."--_Shakespeare._
4076: 
4077:     The mind of a man is as a country which was once open to squatters,
4078:     who have bred and multiplied and become masters of the land. But
4079:     then happeneth a time when new and hungry comers dispute the land;
4080:     and there is trial of strength, and the stronger wins. Nevertheless
4081:     the first squatters be they who have prepared the ground, and the
4082:     crops to the end will be sequent (though chiefly on the nature of
4083:     the soil, as of light sand, mixed loam, or heavy clay, yet)
4084:     somewhat on the primal labor and sowing.
4085: 
4086: 
4087: That talkative maiden, Rumor, though in the interest of art she is
4088: figured as a youthful, winged beauty with flowing garments, soaring
4089: above the heads of men, and breathing world-thrilling news through a
4090: gracefully-curved trumpet, is in fact a very old maid, who puckers her
4091: silly face by the fireside, and really does no more than chirp a wrong
4092: guess or a lame story into the ear of a fellow gossip; all the rest of
4093: the work attributed to her is done by the ordinary working of those
4094: passions against which men pray in the Litany, with the help of a
4095: plentiful stupidity against which we have never yet had any authorized
4096: form of prayer.
4097: 
4098: When Mr. Scales's strong need to make an impressive figure in
4099: conversation, together with his very slight need of any other premise
4100: than his own sense of his wide general knowledge and probable
4101: infallibility, led him to specify five hundred thousand as the lowest
4102: admissible amount of Harold Transome's commercially-acquired fortune, it
4103: was not fair to put this down to poor old Miss Rumor, who had only told
4104: Scales that the fortune was considerable. And again, when the curt Mr.
4105: Sircome found occasion at Treby to mention the five hundred thousand as
4106: a fact that folks seemed pretty sure about, this expansion of the butler
4107: into "folks" was entirely due to Mr. Sircome's habitual preference for
4108: words which could not be laid hold of or give people a handle over him.
4109: It was in this simple way that the report of Harold Transome's fortune
4110: spread and was magnified, adding much lustre to his opinion in the eyes
4111: of Liberals, and compelling even men of the opposite party to admit that
4112: it increased his eligibility as a member for North Loamshire. It was
4113: observed by a sound thinker in these parts that property was ballast;
4114: and when once the aptness of that metaphor had been perceived, it
4115: followed that a man was not fit to navigate the sea of politics without
4116: a great deal of such ballast; and that, rightly understood, whatever
4117: increased the expense of election, inasmuch as it virtually raised the
4118: property qualification, was an unspeakable boon to the country.
4119: 
4120: Meanwhile the fortune that was getting larger in the imagination of
4121: constituents was shrinking a little in the imagination of its owner. It
4122: was hardly more than a hundred and fifty thousand; and there were not
4123: only the heavy mortgages to be paid off, but also a large amount of
4124: capital was needed in order to repair the farm-buildings all over the
4125: estate, to carry out extensive drainage, and make allowances to
4126: in-coming tenants, which might remove the difficulties of newly letting
4127: the farms in a time of agricultural depression. The farms actually
4128: tenanted were held by men who had begged hard to succeed their fathers
4129: in getting a little poorer every year, on land which was also getting
4130: poorer, where the highest rate of increase was in the arrears of rent,
4131: and where the master, in crushed hat and corduroys, looked pitiably lean
4132: and care-worn by the side of pauper laborers, who showed that superior
4133: assimilating power often observed to attend nourishment by the public
4134: money. Mr. Goffe, of Rabbit's End, had never had it explained to him
4135: that, according to the true theory of rent, land must inevitably be
4136: given up when it would not yield a profit equal to the ordinary rate of
4137: interest; so that from want of knowing what was inevitable, and not from
4138: a Titanic spirit of opposition, he kept on his land. He often said to
4139: himself, with a melancholy wipe of his sleeve across his brow, that he
4140: "didn't know which-a-way to turn"; and he would have been still more at
4141: a loss on the subject if he had quitted Rabbit's End with a wagonful of
4142: furniture and utensils, a file of receipts, a wife with five children,
4143: and a shepherd dog in low spirits.
4144: 
4145: It took no long time for Harold Transome to discover this state of
4146: things, and to see, moreover, that, except on the demesne immediately
4147: around the house, the timber had been mismanaged. The woods had been
4148: recklessly thinned, and there had been insufficient planting. He had not
4149: yet thoroughly investigated the various accounts kept by his mother, by
4150: Jermyn, and by Banks the bailiff; but what had been done with the large
4151: sums which had been received for timber was a suspicious mystery to him.
4152: He observed that the farm held by Jermyn was in first-rate order, that a
4153: good deal had been spent on the buildings, and that the rent had stood
4154: unpaid. Mrs. Transome had taken an opportunity of saying that Jermyn had
4155: had some of the mortgage deeds transferred to him, and that his rent was
4156: set against so much interest. Harold had only said, in his careless yet
4157: decisive way, "Oh, Jermyn be hanged! It seems to me if Durfey hadn't
4158: died and made room for me, Jermyn would have ended by coming to live
4159: here, and you would have had to keep the lodge and open the gate for his
4160: carriage. But I shall pay him off--mortgages and all--by-and-by. I'll
4161: owe him nothing--not even a curse!" Mrs. Transome said no more. Harold
4162: did not care to enter fully into the subject with his mother. The fact
4163: that she had been active in the management of the estate--had ridden
4164: about it continually, had busied herself with accounts, had been
4165: head-bailiff of the vacant farms, and had yet allowed things to go
4166: wrong--was set down by him simply to the general futility of women's
4167: attempts to transact men's business. He did not want to say anything to
4168: annoy her: he was only determined to let her understand, as quietly as
4169: possible, that she had better cease all interference.
4170: 
4171: Mrs. Transome did understand this; and it was very little that she dared
4172: to say on business, though there was a fierce struggle of her anger and
4173: pride with a dread which was nevertheless supreme. As to the old
4174: tenants, she only observed, on hearing Harold burst forth about their
4175: wretched condition, "that with the estate so burdened, the yearly loss
4176: by arrears could better be borne than the outlay and sacrifice necessary
4177: in order to let the farms anew."
4178: 
4179: "I was really capable of calculating, Harold," she ended, with a touch
4180: of bitterness. "It seems easy to deal with farmers and their affairs
4181: when you only see them in print, I dare say; but it's not quite so easy
4182: when you live among them. You have only to look at Sir Maximus's estate:
4183: you will see plenty of the same thing. The times have been dreadful and
4184: old families like to keep their old tenants. But I dare say that is
4185: Toryism."
4186: 
4187: "It's a hash of odds and ends, if that is Toryism, my dear mother.
4188: However, I wish you had kept three more old tenants; for then I should
4189: have had three more fifty-pound voters. And, in a hard run, one may be
4190: beaten by a head. But," Harold added, smiling and handing her a ball of
4191: worsted which had fallen, "a woman ought to be a Tory, and graceful, and
4192: handsome, like you. I should hate a woman who took up my opinions and
4193: talked for me. I'm an Oriental, you know. I say, mother, shall we have
4194: this room furnished with rose-color? I notice that it suits your bright
4195: gray hair."
4196: 
4197: Harold thought it was only natural that his mother should have been in a
4198: sort of subjection to Jermyn throughout the awkward circumstances of the
4199: family. It was the way of women, and all weak minds, to think that what
4200: they had been used to was unalterable, and any quarrel with a man who
4201: managed private affairs was necessarily a formidable thing. He himself
4202: was proceeding very cautiously, and preferred not even to know too much
4203: just at present, lest a certain personal antipathy he was conscious of
4204: toward Jermyn, and an occasional liability to exasperation, should get
4205: the better of a calm and clear-sighted resolve not to quarrel with the
4206: man while he could be of use. Harold would have been disgusted with
4207: himself if he had helped to frustrate his own purpose. And his strongest
4208: purpose now was to get returned for Parliament, to make a figure there
4209: as a Liberal member, and to become on all grounds a personage of weight
4210: in North Loamshire.
4211: 
4212: How Howard Transome came to be a Liberal in opposition to all the
4213: traditions of his family, was a more subtle enquiry than he had ever
4214: cared to follow out. The newspapers undertook to explain it. The _North
4215: Loamshire Herald_ witnessed with a grief and disgust certain to be
4216: shared by all persons who were actuated by wholesome British feeling, an
4217: example of defection in the inheritor of a family name which in times
4218: past had been associated with attachment to right principle, and with
4219: the maintenance of our constitution in Church and State; and pointed to
4220: it as an additional proof that men who had passed any large portion of
4221: their lives beyond the limits of our favored country, usually contracted
4222: not only a laxity of feeling toward Protestantism, nay, toward religion
4223: itself--a latitudinarian spirit hardly distinguishable from atheism--but
4224: also a levity of disposition, inducing them to tamper with those
4225: institutions by which alone Great Britain had risen to her pre-eminence
4226: among the nations. Such men, infected with outlandish habits,
4227: intoxicated with vanity, grasping at momentary power by flattery of the
4228: multitude, fearless because godless, Liberal because un-English, were
4229: ready to pull one stone from under another in the national edifice, till
4230: the great structure tottered to its fall. On the other hand, the
4231: _Duffield Watchman_ saw in this signal instance of self-liberation from
4232: the trammels of prejudice, a decisive guarantee of intellectual
4233: pre-eminence, united with a generous sensibility to the claims of man as
4234: man, which had burst asunder, and cast off, by a spontaneous exertion of
4235: energy, the cramping out-worn shell of hereditary bias and class
4236: interest.
4237: 
4238: But these large-minded guides of public opinion argued from wider data
4239: than could be furnished by any knowledge of the particular case
4240: concerned. Harold Transome was neither the dissolute cosmopolitan so
4241: vigorously sketched by the Tory _Herald_, nor the intellectual giant and
4242: moral lobster suggested by the Liberal imagination of the _Watchman_.
4243: Twenty years ago he had been a bright, active, good-tempered lad, with
4244: sharp eyes and a good aim; he delighted in success and in predominance;
4245: but he did not long for an impossible predominance, and become sour and
4246: sulky because it was impossible. He played at the games he was clever
4247: in, and usually won; all other games he let alone, and thought them of
4248: little worth. At home and at Eton he had been side by side with his
4249: stupid elder brother Durfey, whom he despised; and he very early began
4250: to reflect that since this Caliban in miniature was older than himself,
4251: he must carve out his own fortune. That was a nuisance; and on the whole
4252: the world seemed rather ill-arranged, at Eton especially, where there
4253: were many reasons why Harold made no great figure. He was not sorry the
4254: money was wanting to send him to Oxford; he did not see the good of
4255: Oxford; he had been surrounded by many things during his short life, of
4256: which he had distinctly said to himself that he did not see the good,
4257: and he was not disposed to venerate on the strength of any good that
4258: others saw. He turned his back on home very cheerfully, though he was
4259: rather fond of his mother, and very fond of Transome Court, and the
4260: river where he had been used to fish; but he said to himself as he
4261: passed the lodge-gates, "I'll get rich somehow, and have an estate of my
4262: own, and do what I like with it." This determined aiming at something
4263: not easy but clearly possible, marked the direction in which Harold's
4264: nature was strong; he had the energetic will and muscle, the
4265: self-confidence, the quick perception, and the narrow imagination which
4266: make what is admiringly called the practical mind.
4267: 
4268: Since then his character had been ripened by a various experience, and
4269: also by much knowledge which he had set himself deliberately to gain.
4270: But the man was no more than the boy writ large, with an extensive
4271: commentary. The years had nourished an inclination to as much opposition
4272: as would enable him to assert his own independence and power without
4273: throwing himself into that tabooed condition which robs power of its
4274: triumph. And this inclination had helped his shrewdness in forming
4275: judgments which were at once innovating and moderate. He was addicted at
4276: once to rebellion and to conformity, and only an intimate personal
4277: knowledge could enable any one to predict where his conformity would
4278: begin. The limit was not defined by theory, but was drawn in an
4279: irregular zigzag by early disposition and association; and his
4280: resolution, of which he had never lost hold, to be a thorough Englishman
4281: again some day, had kept up the habit of considering all his conclusions
4282: with reference to English politics and English social conditions. He
4283: meant to stand up for every change that the economical condition of the
4284: country required, and he had an angry contempt for men with coronets on
4285: their coaches, but too small a share of brains to see when they had
4286: better make a virtue of necessity. His respect was rather for men who
4287: had no coronets, but who achieved a just influence by furthering all
4288: measures which the common-sense of the country, and the increasing
4289: self-assertion of the majority, peremptorily demanded. He could be such
4290: a man himself.
4291: 
4292: In fact Harold Transome was a clever, frank, good-natured egoist; not
4293: stringently consistent, but without any disposition to falsity; but with
4294: a pride that was moulded in an individual rather than an hereditary
4295: form; unspeculative, unsentimental, unsympathetic; fond of sensual
4296: pleasures, but disinclined to all vice, and attached as a healthy,
4297: clear-sighted person, to all conventional morality, construed with a
4298: certain freedom, like doctrinal articles to which the public order may
4299: require subscription. A character is apt to look but indifferently,
4300: written out in this way. Reduced to a map, our premises seem
4301: insignificant, but they make, nevertheless, a very pretty freehold to
4302: live in and walk over; and so, if Harold Transome had been among your
4303: acquaintances, and you had observed his qualities through the medium of
4304: his agreeable person, bright smile, and a certain easy charm which
4305: accompanies sensuousness when unsullied by coarseness--through the
4306: medium also of the many opportunities in which he would have made
4307: himself useful or pleasant to you--you would have thought him a good
4308: fellow, highly acceptable as a guest, a colleague, or a brother-in-law.
4309: Whether all mothers would have liked him as a son is another question.
4310: 
4311: It is a fact perhaps kept a little too much in the background, that
4312: mothers have a self larger than their maternity, and that when their
4313: sons have become taller than themselves, and are gone from them to
4314: college or into the world, there are wide spaces of their time which are
4315: not filled with praying for their boys, reading old letters, and envying
4316: yet blessing those who are attending to their shirt-buttons. Mrs.
4317: Transome was certainly not one of those bland, adoring, and gently
4318: tearful women. After sharing the common dream that when a beautiful
4319: man-child was born to her, her cup of happiness would be full, she had
4320: travelled through long years apart from that child to find herself at
4321: last in the presence of a son of whom she was afraid, who was utterly
4322: unmanageable by her, and to whose sentiments in any given case she
4323: possessed no key. Yet Harold was a kind son: he kissed his mother's
4324: brow, offered her his arm, let her choose what she liked for the house
4325: and garden, asked her whether she would have bays or grays for her new
4326: carriage, and was bent on seeing her make as good a figure in the
4327: neighborhood as any other woman of her rank. She trembled under this
4328: kindness: it was not enough to satisfy her; still, if it should ever
4329: cease and give place to something else--she was too uncertain about
4330: Harold's feelings to imagine clearly what that something would be. The
4331: finest threads, such as no eye sees, if bound cunningly about the
4332: sensitive flesh, so that the movement to break them would bring torture,
4333: may make a worse bondage than any fetters. Mrs. Transome felt the fatal
4334: thread about her, and the bitterness of this helpless bondage mingled
4335: itself with the new elegancies of the dining and drawing-rooms, and all
4336: the household changes which Harold had ordered to be brought about with
4337: magical quickness. Nothing was as she had once expected it would be. If
4338: Harold had shown the least care to have her stay in the room with
4339: him--if he had really cared for her opinion--if he had been what she had
4340: dreamed he would be in the eyes of those people who had made her
4341: world--if all the past could be dissolved, and leave no solid trace of
4342: itself--mighty _ifs_ that were all impossible--she would have tasted
4343: some joy; but now she began to look back with regret to the days when
4344: she sat in loneliness among the old drapery, and still longed for
4345: something that might happen. Yet, save in a bitter little speech, or in
4346: a deep sigh, heard by no one besides Denner, she kept all these things
4347: hidden in her heart, and went out in the autumn sunshine to overlook the
4348: alterations in the pleasure-grounds very much as a happy woman might
4349: have done. One day, however, when she was occupied in this way, an
4350: occasion came on which she chose to express indirectly a part of her
4351: inward care.
4352: 
4353: She was standing on the broad gravel in the afternoon; the long shadows
4354: lay on the grass; the light seemed the more glorious because of the
4355: reddened and golden trees. The gardeners were busy at their pleasant
4356: work; the newly-turned soil gave out an agreeable fragrance; and little
4357: Harry was playing with Nimrod round old Mr. Transome, who sat placidly
4358: on a low garden-chair. The scene would have made a charming picture of
4359: English domestic life, and the handsome, majestic, gray-haired woman
4360: (obviously grandmamma) would have been especially admired. But the
4361: artist would have felt it requisite to turn her face toward her husband
4362: and little grandson, and to have given her an elderly amiability of
4363: expression which would have divided remark with his exquisite rendering
4364: of her Indian shawl. Mrs. Transome's face was turned the other way, and
4365: for this reason she only heard an approaching step, and did not see
4366: whose it was; yet it startled her: it was not quick enough to be her
4367: son's step, and besides, Harold was away at Duffield. It was Mr.
4368: Jermyn's.
4369: 
4370: 
4371: 
4372: 
4373: CHAPTER IX.
4374: 
4375:     "A woman naturally born to fears."--_King John._
4376: 
4377:                                      "Methinks,
4378:     Some unborn sorrow, ripe in fortune's womb,
4379:     Is coming toward me; and my inward soul
4380:     With nothing trembles."--_King Richard II._
4381: 
4382: 
4383: Matthew Jermyn approached Mrs. Transome taking off his hat and smiling.
4384: She did not smile, but said--
4385: 
4386: "You knew Harold was not at home?"
4387: 
4388: "Yes; I came to see you, to know if you had any wishes that I could
4389: further, since I have not had an opportunity of consulting you since he
4390: came home."
4391: 
4392: "Let us walk toward the Rookery, then."
4393: 
4394: They turned together, Mr. Jermyn still keeping his hat off and holding
4395: it behind him; the air was so soft and agreeable that Mrs. Transome had
4396: nothing but a large veil over her head.
4397: 
4398: They walked for a little while in silence till they were out of sight,
4399: under tall trees, and treading noiselessly on falling leaves. What
4400: Jermyn was really most anxious about, was to learn from Mrs. Transome
4401: whether anything had transpired that was significant of Harold's
4402: disposition toward him, which he suspected to be very far from friendly.
4403: Jermyn was not naturally flinty-hearted: at five-and-twenty he had
4404: written verses, and had got himself wet through in order not to
4405: disappoint a dark-eyed woman whom he was proud to believe in love with
4406: him; but a family man with grown up sons and daughters, a man with a
4407: professional position and complicated affairs that make it hard to
4408: ascertain the exact relation between property and liabilities,
4409: necessarily thinks of himself and what may be impending.
4410: 
4411: "Harold is remarkably acute and clever," he began at last, since Mrs.
4412: Transome did not speak. "If he gets into Parliament, I have no doubt he
4413: will distinguish himself. He has a quick eye for business of all kinds."
4414: 
4415: "That is no comfort to me," said Mrs. Transome. To-day she was more
4416: conscious than usual of that bitterness which was always in her mind in
4417: Jermyn's presence, but which was carefully suppressed:--suppressed
4418: because she could not endure that the degradation she inwardly felt
4419: should ever become visible or audible in acts or words of her
4420: own--should ever be reflected in any word or look of his. For years
4421: there had been a deep silence about the past between them; on her side
4422: because she remembered; on his, because he more and more forgot.
4423: 
4424: "I trust he is not unkind to you in any way. I know his opinions pain
4425: you; but I trust you find him in everything else disposed to be a good
4426: son."
4427: 
4428: "Oh, to be sure--good as men are disposed to be to women, giving them
4429: cushions and carriages, and recommending them to enjoy themselves, and
4430: then expecting them to be contented under contempt and neglect. I have
4431: no power over him--remember that--none."
4432: 
4433: Jermyn turned to look in Mrs. Transome's face: it was long since he had
4434: heard her speak to him as if she were losing her self-command.
4435: 
4436: "Has he shown any unpleasant feeling about your management of affairs?"
4437: 
4438: "_My_ management!" Mrs. Transome said, with concentrated rage, flashing
4439: a fierce look at Jermyn. She checked herself: she felt as if she were
4440: lighting a torch to flare on her own past folly and misery. It was a
4441: resolve which had become a habit, that she would never quarrel with this
4442: man--never tell him what she saw him to be. She had kept her woman's
4443: pride and sensibility intact: through all her life there had vibrated
4444: the maiden need to have her hand kissed and be the object of chivalry.
4445: And so she sank into silence again, trembling.
4446: 
4447: Jermyn felt annoyed--nothing more. There was nothing in his mind
4448: corresponding to the intricate meshes of sensitiveness in Mrs.
4449: Transome's. He was anything but stupid; yet he always blundered when he
4450: wanted to be delicate or magnanimous; he constantly sought to soothe
4451: others by praising himself. Moral vulgarity cleaved to him like an
4452: hereditary odor. He blundered now.
4453: 
4454: "My dear Mrs. Transome," he said, in a tone of bland kindness, "you are
4455: agitated--you appear angry with me. Yet I think, if you consider, you
4456: will see that you have nothing to complain of in me, unless you will
4457: complain of the inevitable course of man's life. I have always met your
4458: wishes both in happy circumstances and in unhappy ones. I should be
4459: ready to do so now, if it were possible."
4460: 
4461: Every sentence was as pleasant to her as if it had been cut in her bared
4462: arm. Some men's kindness and love-making are more exasperating, more
4463: humiliating than others' derision; but the pitiable woman who has once
4464: made herself secretly dependent on a man who is beneath her in feeling,
4465: must bear that humiliation for fear of worse. Coarse kindness is at
4466: least better than coarse anger; and in all private quarrels the duller
4467: nature is triumphant by reason of its dullness. Mrs. Transome knew in
4468: her inmost soul that those relations which had sealed her lips on
4469: Jermyn's conduct in business matters, had been with him a ground for
4470: presuming that he should have impunity in any lax dealing into which
4471: circumstances had led him. She knew that she herself had endured all the
4472: more privation because of his dishonest selfishness. And now, Harold's
4473: long-deferred heirship, and his return with startlingly unexpected
4474: penetration, activity, and assertion of mastery, had placed them both in
4475: the full presence of a difficulty which had been prepared by the years
4476: of vague uncertainty as to issues. In this position, with a great dread
4477: hanging over her, which Jermyn knew, and ought to have felt that he had
4478: caused her, she was inclined to lash him with indignation, to scorch him
4479: with the words that were just the fit names for his doings--inclined all
4480: the more when he spoke with an insolent blandness, ignoring all that was
4481: truly in her heart. But no sooner did the words "You have brought it on
4482: me" rise within her than she heard within also the retort, "You brought
4483: it on yourself." Not for all the world beside could she bear to hear
4484: that retort uttered from without. What did she do? With strange sequence
4485: to all that rapid tumult, after a few moments' silence she said--
4486: 
4487: "Let me take your arm."
4488: 
4489: He gave it immediately, putting on his hat and wondering. For more than
4490: twenty years Mrs. Transome had never chosen to take his arm.
4491: 
4492: "I have but one thing to ask. Make me a promise."
4493: 
4494: "What is it?"
4495: 
4496: "That you will never quarrel with Harold."
4497: 
4498: "You must know that it is my wish not to quarrel with him."
4499: 
4500: "But make a vow--fix it in your mind as a thing not to be done. Bear
4501: anything from him rather than quarrel with him."
4502: 
4503: "A man can't make a vow not to quarrel," said Jermyn, who was already a
4504: little irritated by the implication that Harold might be disposed to use
4505: him roughly. "A man's temper may get the better of him at any moment. I
4506: am not prepared to bear _anything_."
4507: 
4508: "Good God!" said Mrs. Transome, taking her hand from his arm, "is it
4509: possible you don't feel how horrible it would be?"
4510: 
4511: As she took away her hand, Jermyn let his arm fall, put both his hands
4512: in his pockets, and shrugging his shoulders said, "I shall use him as he
4513: uses me."
4514: 
4515: Jermyn had turned round his savage side, and the blandness was out of
4516: sight. It was this that had always frightened Mrs. Transome: there was a
4517: possibility of fierce insolence in this man who was to pass with those
4518: nearest to her as her indebted servant, but whose brand she secretly
4519: bore. She was as powerless with him as she was with her own son.
4520: 
4521: This woman, who loved rule, dared not speak another word of attempted
4522: persuasion. They were both silent, taking the nearest way into the
4523: sunshine again. There was a half-formed wish in both their minds--even
4524: in the mother's--that Harold Transome had never been born.
4525: 
4526: "We are working hard for the election," said Jermyn, recovering
4527: himself, as they turned into the sunshine again. "I think we shall get
4528: him returned, and in that case he will be in high good-humor. Everything
4529: will be more propitious than you are apt to think. You must persuade
4530: yourself," he added, smiling at her, "that it is better for a man of his
4531: position to be in Parliament on the wrong side than not to be in at
4532: all."
4533: 
4534: "Never," said Mrs. Transome. "I am too old to learn to call bitter sweet
4535: and sweet bitter. But what I may think or feel is of no consequence now.
4536: I am as unnecessary as a chimney ornament."
4537: 
4538: And in this way they parted on the gravel, in that pretty scene where
4539: they had met. Mrs. Transome shivered as she stood alone: all around her,
4540: where there had once been brightness and warmth, there were white ashes,
4541: and the sunshine looked dreary as it fell on them.
4542: 
4543: Mr. Jermyn's heaviest reflections in riding homeward turned on the
4544: possibility of incidents between himself and Harold Transome which would
4545: have disagreeable results, requiring him to raise money, and perhaps
4546: causing scandal, which in its way might also help to create a monetary
4547: deficit. A man of sixty, with a wife whose Duffield connections were of
4548: the highest respectability, with a family of tall daughters, an
4549: expensive establishment, and a large professional business, owed a great
4550: deal more to himself as the mainstay of all those solidities, than to
4551: feelings and ideas which were quite unsubstantial. There were many
4552: unfortunate coincidences which placed Mr. Jermyn in an uncomfortable
4553: position just now; he had not been much to blame, he considered; if it
4554: had not been for a sudden turn of affairs no one would have complained.
4555: He defied any man to say that he had intended to wrong people; he was
4556: able to refund, to make reprisals, if they could be fairly demanded.
4557: Only he would certainly have preferred that they should not be demanded.
4558: 
4559: A German poet was entrusted with a particularly fine sausage, which he
4560: was to convey to the donor's friend at Paris. In the course of a long
4561: journey he smelled the sausage; he got hungry, and desired to taste it;
4562: he pared a morsel off, then another, and another, in successive moments
4563: of temptation, till at last the sausage was, humanly speaking, at an
4564: end. The offence had not been premeditated. The poet had never loved
4565: meanness, but he loved sausage; and the result was undeniably awkward.
4566: 
4567: So it was with Matthew Jermyn. He was far from liking that ugly
4568: abstraction rascality, but he had liked other things which had suggested
4569: nibbling. He had to do many things in law and in daily life which, in
4570: the abstract, he would have condemned; and indeed he had never been
4571: tempted by them in the abstract. Here, in fact, was the inconvenience:
4572: he had sinned for the sake of particular concrete things, and particular
4573: concrete consequences were likely to follow.
4574: 
4575: But he was a man of resolution, who, having made out what was the best
4576: course to take under a difficulty, went straight to his work. The
4577: election must be won: that would put Harold in good-humor, give him
4578: something to do, and leave himself more time to prepare for any crisis.
4579: 
4580: He was in anything but low spirits that evening. It was his eldest
4581: daughter's birthday, and the young people had a dance. Papa was
4582: delightful--stood up for a quadrille and a country-dance, told stories
4583: at supper, and made humorous quotations from his early readings: if
4584: these were Latin, he apologized, and translated to the ladies; so that a
4585: deaf lady-visitor from Duffield kept her trumpet up continually, lest
4586: she should lose any of Mr. Jermyn's conversation, and wished that her
4587: niece Maria had been present, who was young and had a good memory.
4588: 
4589: Still the party was smaller than usual, for some families in Treby
4590: refused to visit Jermyn, now that he was concerned for a Radical
4591: candidate.
4592: 
4593: 
4594: 
4595: 
4596: CHAPTER X.
4597: 
4598:     "He made love neither with roses, nor with apples, nor with locks
4599:     of hair."--THEOCRITUS.
4600: 
4601: 
4602: One Sunday afternoon Felix Holt rapped at the door of Mr. Lyon's house,
4603: although he could hear the voice of the minister preaching in the
4604: chapel. He stood with a book under his arm, apparently confident that
4605: there was someone in the house to open the door for him. In fact, Esther
4606: never went to chapel in the afternoon: that "exercise" made her head
4607: ache.
4608: 
4609: In these September weeks Felix had got rather intimate with Mr. Lyon.
4610: They shared the same political sympathies; and though, to Liberals who
4611: had neither freehold nor copyhold nor leasehold, the share in a county
4612: election consisted chiefly of that prescriptive amusement of the
4613: majority known as "looking on," there was still something to be said on
4614: the occasion, if not to be done. Perhaps the most delightful friendships
4615: are those in which there is much agreement, much disputation, and yet
4616: more personal liking; and the advent of the public-spirited,
4617: contradictory, yet affectionate Felix, into Treby life, had made a
4618: welcome epoch to the minister. To talk with this young man, who, though
4619: hopeful, had a singularity which some might at once have pronounced
4620: heresy, but which Mr. Lyon persisted in regarding as orthodoxy "in the
4621: making," was like a good bite to strong teeth after a too plentiful
4622: allowance of spoon meat. To cultivate his society with a view to
4623: checking his erratic tendencies was a laudable purpose; but perhaps if
4624: Felix had been rapidly subdued and reduced to conformity, little Mr.
4625: Lyon would have found the conversation much flatter.
4626: 
4627: Esther had not seen so much of their new acquaintance as her father had.
4628: But she had begun to find him amusing, and also rather irritating to her
4629: woman's love of conquest. He always opposed and criticised her; and
4630: besides that, he looked at her as if he never saw a single detail about
4631: her person--quite as if she were a middle-aged woman in a cap. She did
4632: not believe that he had ever admired her hands, or her long neck, or her
4633: graceful movements, which had made all the girls at school call her
4634: Calypso (doubtless from their familiarity with "Telémaque"). Felix ought
4635: properly to have been a little in love with her--never mentioning it, of
4636: course, because that would have been disagreeable, and his being a
4637: regular lover was out of the question. But it was quite clear that,
4638: instead of feeling any disadvantage on his own side, he held himself to
4639: be immeasurably her superior: and, what was worse, Esther had a secret
4640: consciousness that he was her superior. She was all the more vexed at
4641: the suspicion that he thought slightly of her; and wished in her
4642: vexation that she could have found more fault with him--that she had not
4643: been obliged to admire more and more the varying expressions of his open
4644: face and his deliciously good-humored laugh, always loud at a joke
4645: against himself. Besides, she could not help having her curiosity roused
4646: by the unusual combinations both in his mind and in his outward
4647: position, and she had surprised herself as well as her father one day by
4648: suddenly starting up and proposing to walk with him when he was going to
4649: pay an afternoon visit to Mrs. Holt, to try and soothe her concerning
4650: Felix. "What a mother he has!" she said to herself when they came away
4651: again; "but, rude and queer as he is, I cannot say there is anything
4652: vulgar about him. Yet--I don't know--if I saw him by the side of a
4653: finished gentleman." Esther wished that finished gentleman were among
4654: her acquaintances: he would certainly admire her, and make her aware of
4655: Felix's inferiority.
4656: 
4657: On this particular Sunday afternoon, when she heard the knock at the
4658: door, she was seated in the kitchen corner between the fire and the
4659: window reading "Réné." Certainly in her well-fitting light-blue
4660: dress--she almost always wore some shade of blue--with her delicate
4661: sandaled slipper stretched toward the fire, her little gold watch, which
4662: had cost her nearly a quarter's earnings, visible at her side, her
4663: slender fingers playing with a shower of brown curls, and a coronet of
4664: shining plaits, at the summit of her head, she was a remarkable
4665: Cinderella. When the rap came, she colored, and was going to shut her
4666: book and put it out of the way on the window ledge behind her; but she
4667: desisted with a little toss, laid it open on the table beside her, and
4668: walked to the outer door, which opened into the kitchen. There was
4669: rather a mischievous gleam in her face: the rap was not a small one; it
4670: came probably from a large personage with a vigorous arm.
4671: 
4672: "Good afternoon, Miss Lyon," said Felix, taking off his cloth cap: he
4673: resolutely declined the expensive ugliness of a hat, and in a poked cap
4674: and without a cravat, made a figure at which his mother cried every
4675: Sunday, and thought of with a slow shake of the head at several passages
4676: in the minister's prayer.
4677: 
4678: "Dear me, it is you, Mr. Holt! I fear you will have to wait some time
4679: before you can see my father. The sermon is not ended yet, and there
4680: will be the hymn and the prayer, and perhaps other things to detain
4681: him."
4682: 
4683: "Well, will you let me sit down in the kitchen? I don't want to be a
4684: bore."
4685: 
4686: "Oh, no," said Esther, with her pretty light laugh, "I always give you
4687: credit for not meaning it. Pray come in, if you don't mind waiting. I
4688: was sitting in the kitchen: the kettle is singing quite prettily. It is
4689: much nicer than the parlor--not half so ugly."
4690: 
4691: "There I agree with you."
4692: 
4693: "How very extraordinary! But if you prefer the kitchen, and don't want
4694: to sit with me, I can go into the parlor."
4695: 
4696: "I came on purpose to sit with you," said Felix, in his blunt way, "but
4697: I thought it likely you might be vexed at seeing me. I wanted to talk to
4698: you, but I've got nothing pleasant to say. As your father would have it,
4699: I'm not given to prophesy smooth things--to prophesy deceit."
4700: 
4701: "I understand," said Esther, sitting down. "Pray be seated. You thought
4702: I had no afternoon sermon, so you came to give me one."
4703: 
4704: "Yes," said Felix, seating himself sideways in a chair not far off her,
4705: and leaning over the back to look at her with his large, clear, gray
4706: eyes, "and my text is something you said the other day. You said you
4707: didn't mind about people having right opinions so that they had good
4708: taste. Now I want you to see what shallow stuff that is."
4709: 
4710: "Oh, I don't doubt it if you say so. I know you are a person of right
4711: opinions."
4712: 
4713: "But by opinions you mean men's thoughts about great subjects, and by
4714: taste you mean their thoughts about small ones: dress, behavior,
4715: amusements, ornaments."
4716: 
4717: "Well--yes--or rather, their sensibilities about those things."
4718: 
4719: "It comes to the same thing; thoughts, opinions, knowledge, are only a
4720: sensibility to facts and ideas. If I understand a geometrical problem,
4721: it is because I have a sensibility to the way in which lines and figures
4722: are related to each other; and I want you to see that the creature who
4723: has the sensibilities that you call taste, and not the sensibilities
4724: that you call opinions, is simply a lower, pettier sort of thing--an
4725: insect that notices the shaking of the table, but never notices the
4726: thunder."
4727: 
4728: "Very well, I am an insect; yet I notice that you are thundering at me."
4729: 
4730: "No, you are not an insect. That is what exasperates me at your making a
4731: boast of littleness. You have enough understanding to make it wicked
4732: that you should add one more to the women who hinder men's lives from
4733: having any nobleness in them."
4734: 
4735: Esther colored deeply: she resented this speech, yet she disliked it
4736: less than many Felix had addressed to her.
4737: 
4738: "What is my horrible guilt?" she said, rising and standing, as she was
4739: wont, with one foot on the fender, and looking at the fire. If it had
4740: been any one but Felix who was near her, it might have occurred to her
4741: that this attitude showed her to advantage; but she had only a mortified
4742: sense that he was quite indifferent to what others praised her for.
4743: 
4744: "Why do you read this mawkish stuff on a Sunday, for example?" he said,
4745: snatching up "Réné," and running his eye over the pages.
4746: 
4747: "Why don't you always go to chapel, Mr. Holt, and read Howe's 'Living
4748: Temple,' and join the church?"
4749: 
4750: "There's just the difference between us--I know why I don't do those
4751: things. I distinctly see that I can do something better. I have other
4752: principles, and should sink myself by doing what I don't recognize as
4753: the best."
4754: 
4755: "I understand," said Esther, as lightly as she could, to conceal her
4756: bitterness. "I am a lower kind of being, and could not so easily sink
4757: myself."
4758: 
4759: "Not by entering into your father's ideas. If a woman really believes
4760: herself to be a lower kind of being, she should place herself in
4761: subjection: she should be ruled by the thoughts of her father or
4762: husband. If not, let her show her power of choosing something better.
4763: You must know that your father's principles are greater and worthier
4764: than what guides your life. You have no reason but idle fancy and
4765: selfish inclination for shirking his teaching and giving your soul up to
4766: trifles."
4767: 
4768: "You are kind enough to say so. But I am not aware that I have ever
4769: confided my reasons to you."
4770: 
4771: "Why, what worth calling a reason could make any mortal hang over this
4772: trash?--idiotic immorality dressed up to look fine, with a little bit of
4773: doctrine tacked to it, like a hare's foot on a dish, to make believe the
4774: mess is not cat's flesh. Look here! 'Est-ce ma faute, si je trouve
4775: partout les bornes, si ce qui est fini n'a pour moi aucune valeur?' Yes,
4776: sir, distinctly your fault, because you're an ass. Your dunce who can't
4777: do his sums always has a taste for the infinite. Sir, do you know what a
4778: rhomboid is? Oh, no, I don't value these things with limits. 'Cependant,
4779: j'aime la monotonie des sentimens de la vie, et si j'avais encore la
4780: folie de croire au bonheur----'"
4781: 
4782: "Oh, pray, Mr. Holt, don't go on reading with that dreadful accent; it
4783: sets one's teeth on edge." Esther, smarting helplessly under the
4784: previous lashes, was relieved by this diversion of criticism.
4785: 
4786: "There it is!" said Felix, throwing the book on the table, and getting
4787: up to walk about. "You are only happy when you can spy a tag or a tassel
4788: loose to turn the talk, and get rid of any judgment that must carry
4789: grave action after it."
4790: 
4791: "I think I have borne a great deal of talk without turning it."
4792: 
4793: "Not enough, Miss Lyon--not all that I came to say. I want you to
4794: change. Of course I am a brute to say so. I ought to say you are
4795: perfect. Another man would, perhaps. But I say I want you to change."
4796: 
4797: "How am I to oblige you? By joining the Church?"
4798: 
4799: "No; but by asking yourself whether life is not as solemn a thing as
4800: your father takes it to be--in which you may be either a blessing or a
4801: curse to many. You know you have never done that. You don't care to be
4802: better than a bird trimming its feathers, and pecking about after what
4803: pleases it. You are discontented with the world because you can't get
4804: just the small things that suit your pleasure, not because it's a world
4805: where myriads of men and women are ground by wrong and misery, and
4806: tainted with pollution."
4807: 
4808: Esther felt her heart swelling with mingled indignation at this liberty,
4809: wounded pride at this depreciation, and acute consciousness that she
4810: could not contradict what Felix said. He was outrageously ill-bred; but
4811: she felt that she should be lowering herself by telling him so, and
4812: manifesting her anger; in that way she would be confirming his
4813: accusation of a littleness that shrank from severe truth; and, besides,
4814: through all her mortification there pierced a sense that this
4815: exasperation of Felix against her was more complimentary than anything
4816: in his previous behavior. She had self-command enough to speak with her
4817: usual silvery voice.
4818: 
4819: "Pray go on, Mr. Holt. Relieve yourself of these burning truths. I am
4820: sure they must be troublesome to carry unuttered."
4821: 
4822: "Yes, they are," said Felix, pausing, and standing not far off her. "I
4823: can't bear to see you going the way of the foolish women who spoil men's
4824: lives. Men can't help loving them, and so they make themselves slaves to
4825: the petty desires of petty creatures. That's the way those who might do
4826: better spend their lives for nought--get checked in every great
4827: effort--toil with brain and limb for things that have no more to do with
4828: a manly life than tarts and confectionery. That's what makes women a
4829: curse; and life is stunted to suit their littleness. That's why I'll
4830: never love, if I can help it; and if I love, I'll bear it, and never
4831: marry."
4832: 
4833: The tumult of feeling in Esther's mind--mortification, anger, the sense
4834: of a terrible power over her that Felix seemed to have as his angry
4835: words vibrated through her--was getting almost too much for her
4836: self-control. She felt her lips quivering; but her pride, which feared
4837: nothing so much as the betrayal of her emotion, helped her to a
4838: desperate effort. She pinched her own hand hard to overcome her tremor,
4839: and said, in a tone of scorn--
4840: 
4841: "I ought to be very much obliged to you for giving me your confidence so
4842: freely."
4843: 
4844: "Ah! now you are offended with me, and disgusted with me. I expected it
4845: would be so. A woman doesn't like a man who tells her the truth."
4846: 
4847: "I think you boast a little too much of your truth-telling, Mr. Holt,"
4848: said Esther, flashing out at last. "That virtue is apt to be easy to
4849: people when they only wound others and not themselves. Telling the truth
4850: often means no more than taking a liberty."
4851: 
4852: "Yes, I suppose I should have been taking a liberty if I had tried to
4853: drag you back by the skirt when I saw you running into a pit."
4854: 
4855: "You should really found a sect. Preaching is your vocation. It is a
4856: pity you should ever have an audience of only one."
4857: 
4858: "I see I have made a fool of myself. I thought you had a more generous
4859: mind--that you might be kindled to a better ambition. But I've set your
4860: vanity aflame--nothing else. I'm going. Good-bye."
4861: 
4862: "Good-bye," said Esther, not looking at him. He did not open the door
4863: immediately. He seemed to be adjusting his cap and pulling it down.
4864: Esther longed to be able to throw a lasso round him and compel him to
4865: stay, that she might say what she chose to him; her very anger made this
4866: departure irritating, especially as he had the last word, and that a
4867: very bitter one. But soon the latch was lifted and the door closed
4868: behind him. She ran up to her bedroom and burst into tears. Poor maiden!
4869: There was a strange contradiction of impulses in her mind in those first
4870: moments. She could not bear that Felix should not respect her, yet she
4871: could not bear that he should see her bend before his denunciation. She
4872: revolted against his assumption of superiority, yet she felt herself in
4873: a new kind of subjection to him. He was ill-bred, he was rude, he had
4874: taken an unwarrantable liberty; yet his indignant words were a tribute
4875: to her: he thought she was worth more pains than the women of whom he
4876: took no notice. It was excessively impertinent in him to tell her of his
4877: resolving not to love--not to marry--as if she cared about that; as if
4878: he thought himself likely to inspire an affection that would incline any
4879: woman to marry him after such eccentric steps as he had taken. Had he
4880: ever for a moment imagined that she had thought of him in the light of a
4881: man who would make love to her?----But did he love her one little bit,
4882: and was that the reason why he wanted her to change? Esther felt less
4883: angry at that form of freedom; though she was quite sure that she did
4884: not love him, and that she could never love any one who was so much of a
4885: pedagogue and master, to say nothing of his oddities. But he wanted her
4886: to change. For the first time in her life Esther felt herself seriously
4887: shaken in her self-contentment. She knew there was a mind to which she
4888: appeared trivial, narrow, selfish. Every word Felix had said to her
4889: seemed to have burned itself into her memory. She felt as if she should
4890: forevermore be haunted by self-criticism, and never do anything to
4891: satisfy those fancies on which she had simply piqued herself before
4892: without being dogged by inward questions. Her father's desire for her
4893: conversion had never moved her; she saw that he adored her all the
4894: while, and he never checked her unregenerate acts as if they degraded
4895: her on earth, but only mourned over them as unfitting her for heaven.
4896: Unfitness for heaven (spoken of as "Jerusalem" and "glory"), the prayers
4897: of a good little father, whose thoughts and motives seemed to her like
4898: the "Life of Dr. Doddridge," which she was content to leave unread, did
4899: not attack her self-respect and self-satisfaction. But now she had been
4900: stung--stung even into a new consciousness concerning her father. Was it
4901: true that his life was so much worthier than her own? She could not
4902: change for anything Felix said, but she told herself he was mistaken if
4903: he supposed her incapable of generous thoughts.
4904: 
4905: She heard her father coming into the house. She dried her tears, tried
4906: to recover herself hurriedly, and went down to him.
4907: 
4908: "You want your tea, father; how your forehead burns!" she said gently,
4909: kissing his brow, and then putting her cool hand on it.
4910: 
4911: Mr. Lyon felt a little surprise; such spontaneous tenderness was not
4912: quite common with her; it reminded him of her mother.
4913: 
4914: "My sweet child," he said gratefully, thinking with wonder of the
4915: treasures still left in our fallen nature.
4916: 
4917: 
4918: 
4919: 
4920: CHAPTER XI.
4921: 
4922:     Truth is the precious harvest of the earth.
4923:     But once, when harvest waved upon a land,
4924:     The noisome cankerworm and caterpillar,
4925:     Locusts, and all the swarming foul-born broods,
4926:     Fastened upon it with swift, greedy jaws,
4927:     And turned the harvest into pestilence,
4928:     Until men said, What profits it to sow?
4929: 
4930: 
4931: Felix was going to Sproxton that Sunday afternoon. He always enjoyed his
4932: walk to that outlying hamlet; it took him (by a short cut) through a
4933: corner of Sir Maximus Debarry's park; then across a piece of common,
4934: broken here and there into red ridges below dark masses of furze; and
4935: for the rest of the way alongside of the canal, where the Sunday
4936: peacefulness that seemed to rest on the bordering meadows and pastures
4937: was hardly broken if a horse pulled into sight along the towing-path,
4938: and a boat, with a little curl of blue smoke issuing from its tin
4939: chimney, came slowly gliding behind. Felix retained something of his
4940: boyish impression that the days in a canal-boat were all like Sundays;
4941: but the horse, if it had been put to him, would probably have preferred
4942: a more Judaic or Scotch rigor with regard to canal-boats, or at least
4943: that the Sunday towing should be done by asses, as a lower order.
4944: 
4945: This canal was only a branch of the grand trunk, and ended among the
4946: coal-pits, where Felix, crossing a network of black tram-roads, soon
4947: came to his destination--that public institute of Sproxton, known to its
4948: frequenters chiefly as Chubb's, but less familiarly as the Sugar Loaf,
4949: or the New Pits; this last being the name for the more modern and lively
4950: nucleus of the Sproxton hamlet. The other nucleus, known as the Old
4951: Pits, also supported its "public," but it had something of the forlorn
4952: air of an abandoned capital; and the company at the Blue Cow was of an
4953: inferior kind--equal, of course, in the fundamental attributes of
4954: humanity, such as desire for beer, but not equal in ability to pay for
4955: it.
4956: 
4957: When Felix arrived, the great Chubb was standing at the door. Mr. Chubb
4958: was a remarkable publican; none of your stock Bonifaces, red, bloated,
4959: jolly, and joking. He was thin and sallow, and was never, as his
4960: constant guests observed, seen to be the worse (or the better) for
4961: liquor; indeed, as among soldiers an eminent general was held to have a
4962: charmed life, Chubb was held by the members of the Benefit Club to have
4963: a charmed sobriety, a vigilance over his own interest that resisted all
4964: narcotics. His very dreams, as stated by himself, had a method in them
4965: beyond the waking thoughts of other men. Pharaoh's dream, he observed,
4966: was nothing to them; and, as lying so much out of ordinary experience,
4967: they were held particularly suitable for narration on Sunday evenings,
4968: when the listening colliers, well washed and in their best coats, shook
4969: their heads with a sense of peculiar edification which belongs to the
4970: inexplicable. Mr. Chubb's reasons for becoming landlord of the Sugar
4971: Loaf, were founded on the severest calculation. Having an active mind,
4972: and being averse to bodily labor, he had thoroughly considered what
4973: calling would yield him the best livelihood with the least possible
4974: exertion, and in that sort of line he had seen that a "public" amongst
4975: miners who earned high wages was a fine opening. He had prospered
4976: according to the merits of such judicious calculation, was already a
4977: forty-shilling freeholder, and was conscious of a vote for the county.
4978: He was not one of those mean-spirited men who found the franchise
4979: embarrassing, and would rather have been without it: he regarded his
4980: vote as part of his investment, and meant to make the best of it. He
4981: called himself a straight-forward man, and at suitable moments expressed
4982: his views freely; in fact, he was known to have one fundamental division
4983: for all opinion--"my idee" and "humbug."
4984: 
4985: When Felix approached, Mr. Chubb was standing, as usual, with his hands
4986: nervously busy in his pockets, his eyes glancing around with a detective
4987: expression at the black landscape, and his lipless mouth compressed, yet
4988: in constant movement. On a superficial view it might be supposed that so
4989: eager-seeming a personality was unsuited to the publican's business; but
4990: in fact, it was a great provocative to drinking. Like the shrill biting
4991: talk of a vixenish wife, it would have compelled you to "take a little
4992: something" by way of dulling your sensibility.
4993: 
4994: Hitherto, notwithstanding Felix drank so little ale, the publican
4995: treated him with high civility. The coming election was a great
4996: opportunity for applying his political "idee," which was, that society
4997: existed for the sake of the individual, and that the name of that
4998: individual was Chubb. Now, for a conjunction of absurd circumstances
4999: inconsistent with that idea, it happened that Sproxton hereto had been
5000: somewhat neglected in the canvass. The head member of the company that
5001: worked the mines was Mr. Peter Garstin, and the same company received
5002: the rent from the Sugar Loaf. Hence, as the person who had the most
5003: power of annoying Mr. Chubb, and being of detriment to him, Mr. Garstin
5004: was naturally the candidate for whom he had reserved his vote. But where
5005: there is this intention of ultimately gratifying a gentleman by voting
5006: for him in an open British manner on the day of the poll, a man, whether
5007: Publican or Pharisee (Mr. Chubb used this generic classification of
5008: mankind as one that was sanctioned by Scripture), is all the freer in
5009: his relation with those deluded persons who take him for what he is not,
5010: and imagine him to be a waverer. But for some time opportunity had
5011: seemed barren. There were but three dubious votes besides Mr. Chubb's
5012: in the small district of which the Sugar Loaf could be regarded as the
5013: centre of intelligence and inspiration: the colliers, of course, had no
5014: votes, and did not need political conversion; consequently, the
5015: interests of Sproxton had only been tacitly cherished in the breasts of
5016: candidates. But ever since it had been known that a Radical candidate
5017: was in the field, that in consequence of this Mr. Debarry had coalesced
5018: with Mr. Garstin, and that Sir James Clement, the poor baronet, had
5019: retired, Mr. Chubb had been occupied with the most ingenious mental
5020: combinations in order to ascertain what possibilities of profit to the
5021: Sugar Loaf might lie in this altered state of the canvass.
5022: 
5023: He had a cousin in another county, also a publican, but in a larger way,
5024: and resident in a borough, and from him Mr. Chubb had gathered more
5025: detailed political information than he could find in the Loamshire
5026: newspapers. He was now enlightened enough to know that there was a way
5027: of using voteless miners and navvies at nominations and elections. He
5028: approved of that; it entered into his political "idee"; and indeed he
5029: would have been for extending the franchise to this class--at least in
5030: Sproxton. If any one had observed that you must draw a line somewhere,
5031: Mr. Chubb would have concurred at once, and would have given permission
5032: to draw it at a radius of two miles from his own tap.
5033: 
5034: From the first Sunday evening when Felix had appeared at the Sugar Loaf,
5035: Mr. Chubb had made up his mind that this 'cute man who kept himself
5036: sober was an electioneering agent. That he was hired for some purpose or
5037: other there was not a doubt; a man didn't come and drink nothing without
5038: a good reason. In proportion as Felix's purpose was not obvious to
5039: Chubb's mind, it must be deep; and this growing conviction had even led
5040: the publican on the last Sunday evening privately to urge his mysterious
5041: visitor to let a little ale be chalked up for him--it was of no
5042: consequence. Felix knew his man, and had taken care not to betray too
5043: soon that his real object was so to win the ear of the best fellows
5044: about him as to induce them to meet him on a Saturday evening in the
5045: room where Mr. Lyon, or one of his deacons, habitually held his
5046: Wednesday preachings. Only women and children, three old men, a
5047: journeyman tailor, and a consumptive youth, attended those preachings;
5048: not a collier had been won from the strong ale of the Sugar Loaf, not
5049: even a navvy from the muddier drink of the Blue Cow. Felix was sanguine;
5050: he saw some pleasant faces among the miners when they were washed on
5051: Sundays; they might be taught to spend their wages better. At all
5052: events, he was going to try: he had great confidence in his powers of
5053: appeal, and it was quite true that he never spoke without arresting
5054: attention. There was nothing better than a dame school in the hamlet; he
5055: thought that if he could move the fathers, whose blackened week-day
5056: persons and flannel caps, ornamented with tallow candles by way of
5057: plume, were a badge of hard labor, for which he had a more sympathetic
5058: fibre than for any ribbon in the buttonhole--if he could move these men
5059: to save something from their drink and pay a school-master for their
5060: boys, a greater service would be done them than if Mr. Garstin and his
5061: company were persuaded to establish a school.
5062: 
5063: "I'll lay hold of them by their fatherhood," said Felix; "I'll take one
5064: of their little fellows and set him in the midst. Till they can show
5065: there's something they love better than swilling themselves with ale,
5066: extension of the suffrage can never mean anything for them but extension
5067: of boozing. One must begin somewhere: I'll begin at what is under my
5068: nose. I'll begin at Sproxton. That's what a man would do if he had a
5069: red-hot superstition. Can't one work for sober truth as hard as for
5070: megrims?"
5071: 
5072: Felix Holt had his illusions, like other young men, though they were not
5073: of a fashionable sort; referring neither to the impression his costume
5074: and horsemanship might make on beholders, nor to the ease with which he
5075: would pay the Jews when he gave a loose to his talents and applied
5076: himself to work. He had fixed his choice on a certain Mike Brindle (not
5077: that Brindle was his real name--each collier had his _sobriquet_) as the
5078: man whom he would induce to walk part of the way home with him this very
5079: evening, and get to invite some of his comrades for the next Saturday.
5080: Brindle was one of the head miners: he had a bright good-natured face,
5081: and had given especial attention to certain performances with a magnet
5082: which Felix carried in his pocket.
5083: 
5084: Mr. Chubb, who had also his illusions, smiled graciously as the
5085: enigmatic customer came up to the door-step.
5086: 
5087: "Well, sir, Sunday seems to be your day: I begin to look for you on a
5088: Sunday now."
5089: 
5090: "Yes, I'm a workingman; Sunday is my holiday," said Felix, pausing at
5091: the door since the host seemed to expect this.
5092: 
5093: "Ah, sir, there's many ways of working. I look at it you're one of those
5094: as work with your brains. That's what I do myself."
5095: 
5096: "One may do a good deal of that and work with one's hands too."
5097: 
5098: "Ah, sir," said Mr. Chubb, with a certain bitterness in his smile, "I've
5099: that sort of head that I've often wished I was stupider. I use things
5100: up, sir; I see into things a deal too quick. I eat my dinner, as you may
5101: say, at breakfast-time. That's why I hardly ever smoke a pipe. No sooner
5102: do I stick a pipe in my mouth than I puff and puff till it's gone before
5103: other folks' are well lit; and then, where am I? I might as well have
5104: let it alone. In this world it's better not to be too quick. But you
5105: know what it is, sir."
5106: 
5107: "Not I," said Felix, rubbing the back of his head, with a grimace. "I
5108: generally feel myself rather a blockhead. The world's a largish place,
5109: and I haven't turned everything inside out yet."
5110: 
5111: "Ah, that's your deepness. I think we understand one another. And about
5112: this here election, I lay two to one we should agree if we was to come
5113: to talk about it."
5114: 
5115: "Ah!" said Felix, with an air of caution.
5116: 
5117: "You're none of a Tory, eh, sir? You won't go to vote for Debarry? That
5118: was what I said at the very first go-off. Says I, he's no Tory. I think
5119: I was right, sir--eh?"
5120: 
5121: "Certainly; I'm no Tory."
5122: 
5123: "No, no, you don't catch me wrong in a hurry. Well, between you and me,
5124: I care no more for the Debarrys than I care for Johnny Groats. I live on
5125: none o' their land, and not a pot's-worth did they ever send to the
5126: Sugar Loaf. I'm not frightened at the Debarrys: there's no man more
5127: independent than me. I'll plump or I'll split for them as treat me the
5128: handsomest and are the most of what I call gentlemen; that's my idee.
5129: And in the way of hatching for any man, them are fools that don't employ
5130: me."
5131: 
5132: We mortals sometimes cut a pitiable figure in our attempts at display.
5133: We may be sure of our own merits, yet fatally ignorant of the point of
5134: view from which we are regarded by our neighbor. Our fine patterns in
5135: tattooing may be far from throwing him into a swoon of admiration,
5136: though we turn ourselves all round to show them. Thus it was with Mr.
5137: Chubb.
5138: 
5139: "Yes," said Felix, dryly; "I should think there are some sorts of work
5140: for which you are just fitted."
5141: 
5142: "Ah, you see that? Well, we understand one another. You're no Tory; no
5143: more am I. And if I'd got four hands to show at a nomination, the
5144: Debarrys shouldn't have one of 'em. My idee is, there's a deal too much
5145: of their scutchins and their moniments in Treby Church. What's their
5146: scutchins mean? They're a sign with little liquor behind 'em; that's how
5147: I take it. There's nobody can give account of 'em as I ever heard."
5148: 
5149: Mr. Chubb was hindered from further explaining his views as to the
