5150: historical element in society by the arrival of new guests, who
5151: approached in two groups. The foremost group consisted of well-known
5152: colliers, in their good Sunday beavers and colored handkerchiefs serving
5153: as cravats, with the long ends floating. The second group was a more
5154: unusual one, and caused Mr. Chubb to compress his mouth and agitate the
5155: muscles about it in rather an excited manner.
5156: 
5157: First came a smartly-dressed personage on horseback, with a conspicuous
5158: expansive shirt-front and figured satin stock. He was a stout man, and
5159: gave a strong sense of broadcloth. A wild idea shot through Mr. Chubb's
5160: brain; could this grand visitor be Harold Transome? Excuse him: he had
5161: been given to understand by his cousin from the distant borough that a
5162: Radical candidate in the condescension of canvassing had even gone the
5163: length of eating bread-and-treacle with the children of an honest
5164: freeman, and declaring his preference for that simple fare. Mr. Chubb's
5165: notion of a Radical was that he was a new and agreeable kind of
5166: lick-spittle who fawned on the poor instead of on the rich, and so was
5167: likely to send customers to a "public"; so that he argued well enough
5168: from the premises at his command.
5169: 
5170: The mounted man of broadcloth had followers: several shabby-looking men,
5171: and Sproxton boys of all sizes, whose curiosity had been stimulated by
5172: unexpected largesse. A stranger on horseback scattering half-pence on a
5173: Sunday was so unprecedented that there was no knowing what he might do
5174: next; and the smallest hindmost fellows in sealskin caps were not
5175: without hope that an entirely new order of things had set in.
5176: 
5177: Everyone waited outside for the stranger to dismount, and Mr. Chubb
5178: advanced to take the bridle.
5179: 
5180: "Well, Mr. Chubb," were the first words when the great man was safely
5181: out of the saddle, "I've often heard of your fine tap, and I'm come to
5182: taste it."
5183: 
5184: "Walk in, sir--pray walk in," said Mr. Chubb, giving the horse to the
5185: stable-boy. "I shall be proud to draw for you. If anybody's been
5186: praising me, I think my ale will back him."
5187: 
5188: All entered in the rear of the stranger except the boys, who peeped in
5189: at the window.
5190: 
5191: "Won't you please to walk into the parlor, sir," said Mr. Chubb,
5192: obsequiously.
5193: 
5194: "No, no, I'll sit down here. This is what I like to see," said the
5195: stranger, looking round at the colliers, who eyed him rather shyly--"a
5196: bright hearth where workingmen can enjoy themselves. However, I'll step
5197: into the other room for three minutes, just to speak half a dozen words
5198: with you."
5199: 
5200: Mr. Chubb threw open the parlor door, and then stepping back, took the
5201: opportunity of saying, in a low tone, to Felix, "Do you know this
5202: gentleman?"
5203: 
5204: "Not I; no."
5205: 
5206: Mr. Chubb's opinion of Felix Holt sank from that moment. The parlor door
5207: was closed, but no one sat down or ordered beer.
5208: 
5209: "I say, master," said Mike Brindle, going up to Felix, "don't you think
5210: that's one o' the 'lection men?"
5211: 
5212: "Very likely."
5213: 
5214: "I heared a chap say they're up and down everywhere," said Brindle; "and
5215: now's the time, they say, when a man can get beer for nothing."
5216: 
5217: "Ay, that's sin' the Reform," said a big, red-whiskered man, called
5218: Dredge. "That's brought the 'lections and the drink into these parts;
5219: for afore that, it was all kep' up the Lord knows wheer."
5220: 
5221: "Well, but the Reform's niver come anigh Sprox'on," said a gray-haired
5222: but stalwart man called Old Sleck. "I don't believe nothing about'n, I
5223: don't."
5224: 
5225: "Don't you?" said Brindle, with some contempt. "Well, I do. There's
5226: folks won't believe beyond the end o' their own pickaxes. You can't
5227: drive nothing into 'em, not if you split their skulls. I know for
5228: certain sure, from a chap in the cartin' way, as he's got money and
5229: drink too, only for hollering. Eh, master, what do _you_ say?" Brindle
5230: ended, turning with some deference to Felix.
5231: 
5232: "Should you like to know all about the Reform?" said Felix, using his
5233: opportunity. "If you would, I can tell you."
5234: 
5235: "Ay, ay--tell's; you know I'll be bound," said several voices at once.
5236: 
5237: "Ah, but it will take some little time. And we must be quiet. The
5238: cleverest of you--those who are looked up to in the Club--must come and
5239: meet me at Peggy Button's cottage next Saturday, at seven o'clock, after
5240: dark. And, Brindle, you must bring that little yellow-haired lad of
5241: yours. And anybody that's got a little boy--a very little fellow, who
5242: won't understand what is said--may bring him. But you must keep it
5243: close, you know. We don't want fools there. But everybody who hears me
5244: may come. I shall be at Peggy Button's."
5245: 
5246: "Why, that's where the Wednesday preachin' is," said Dredge. "I've been
5247: aforced to give my wife a black eye to hinder her from going to the
5248: preachin'. Lors-a-massy, she thinks she knows better nor me, and I can't
5249: make head nor tail of her talk."
5250: 
5251: "Why can't you let the woman alone?" said Brindle, with some disgust.
5252: "I'd be ashamed to beat a poor crawling thing 'cause she likes
5253: preaching."
5254: 
5255: "No more I did beat her afore, not if she scrat' me," said Dredge, in
5256: vindication; "but if she jabbers at me, I can't abide it. Howsomever,
5257: I'll bring my Jack to Peggy's o' Saturday. His mother shall wash him. He
5258: is but four year old, and he'll swear and square at me a good un, if I
5259: set him on."
5260: 
5261: "There you go blatherin'," said Brindle, intending a mild rebuke.
5262: 
5263: This dialogue, which was in danger of becoming too personal, was
5264: interrupted by the reopening of the parlor door, and the reappearance of
5265: the impressive stranger with Mr. Chubb, whose countenance seemed
5266: unusually radiant.
5267: 
5268: "Sit you down here, Mr. Johnson," said Chubb, moving an arm-chair. "This
5269: gentleman is kind enough to treat the company," he added, looking round,
5270: "and what's more, he'll take a cup with 'em; and I think there's no man
5271: but what'll say that's a honor."
5272: 
5273: The company had nothing equivalent to a "hear, hear," at command, but
5274: they perhaps felt the more, as they seated themselves with an
5275: expectation unvented by utterance. There was a general satisfactory
5276: sense that the hitherto shadowy Reform had at length come to Sproxton in
5277: a good round shape, with broadcloth and pockets. Felix did not intend to
5278: accept the treating, but he chose to stay and hear, taking his pint as
5279: usual.
5280: 
5281: "Capital ale, capital ale," said Mr. Johnson, as he set down his glass,
5282: speaking in a quick, smooth treble. "Now," he went on, with a certain
5283: pathos in his voice, looking at Mr. Chubb, who sat opposite, "there's
5284: some satisfaction to me in finding an establishment like this at the
5285: Pits. For what would higher wages do for the workingman if he couldn't
5286: get a good article for his money? Why, gentlemen"--here he looked
5287: round--"I've been into ale-houses where I've seen a fine fellow of a
5288: miner or a stone-cutter come in and have to lay down money for beer that
5289: I should be sorry to give to my pigs!" Here Mr. Johnson leaned forward
5290: with squared elbows, hands placed on his knees, and a defiant shake of
5291: the head.
5292: 
5293: "Aw, like at the Blue Cow," fell in the irrepressible Dredge, in a deep
5294: bass; but he was rebuked by a severe nudge from Brindle.
5295: 
5296: "Yes, yes, you know what it is, my friend," said Mr. Johnson, looking at
5297: Dredge, and restoring his self-satisfaction. "But it won't last much
5298: longer, that's one good thing. Bad liquor will be swept away with other
5299: bad articles. Trade will prosper--and what's trade now without steam?
5300: and what is steam without coal? And mark you this, gentlemen--there's no
5301: man and no government can make coal."
5302: 
5303: A loud "Haw, haw," showed that this fact was appreciated.
5304: 
5305: "Nor freeston', nayther," said a wide-mouthed wiry man called Gills, who
5306: wished for an exhaustive treatment of the subject, being a stone-cutter.
5307: 
5308: "Nor freestone, as you say; else, I think, if coal could be made
5309: above-ground, honest fellows who are the pith of our population would
5310: not have to bend their backs and sweat in a pit six days out of the
5311: seven. No, no; I say, as this country prospers it has more and more need
5312: of you, sirs. It can do without a pack of lazy lords and ladies, but it
5313: can never do without brave colliers. And the country _will_ prosper. I
5314: pledge you my word, sirs, this country will rise to the tiptop of
5315: everything, and there isn't a man in it but what shall have his joint in
5316: the pot, and his spare money jingling in his pocket, if we only exert
5317: ourselves to send the right men to Parliament--men who will speak up for
5318: the collier, and the stone-cutter, and the navvy" (Mr. Johnson waved his
5319: hand liberally), "and will stand no nonsense. This is a crisis, and we
5320: must exert ourselves. We've got Reform, gentlemen, but now the thing is
5321: to make Reform work. It's a crisis--I pledge you my word it's a crisis."
5322: 
5323: Mr. Johnson threw himself back as if from the concussion of that great
5324: noun. He did not suppose that one of his audience knew what a crisis
5325: meant; but he had large experience in the effect of uncomprehended
5326: words; and in this case the colliers were thrown into a state of
5327: conviction concerning they did not know what, which was a fine
5328: preparation for "hitting out," or any other act carrying a due sequence
5329: to such a conviction.
5330: 
5331: Felix felt himself in danger of getting into a rage. There is hardly any
5332: mental misery worse than that of having our own serious phrases, our own
5333: rooted beliefs, caricatured by a charlatan or a hireling. He began to
5334: feel the sharp lower edge of his tin pint-measure, and to think it a
5335: tempting missile.
5336: 
5337: Mr. Johnson certainly had some qualifications as an orator. After this
5338: impressive pause he leaned forward again, and said, in a lowered tone,
5339: looking round--
5340: 
5341: "I think you all know the good news."
5342: 
5343: There was a movement of shoe-soles on the quarried floor, and a scrape
5344: of some chair legs, but no other answer.
5345: 
5346: "The good news I mean is, that a first-rate man, Mr. Transome, of
5347: Transome Court, has offered himself to represent you in Parliament,
5348: sirs. I say you in particular, for what he has at heart is the welfare
5349: of the workingman--of the brave fellows that wield the pickaxe, and the
5350: saw, and the hammer. He's rich--has more money than Garstin--but he
5351: doesn't want to keep it to himself. What he wants is, to make a good use
5352: of it, gentlemen. He's come back from foreign parts with his pockets
5353: full of gold. He could buy up the Debarrys, if they were worth buying,
5354: but he's got something better to do with his money. He means to use it
5355: for the good of the workingmen in these parts. I know there are some men
5356: who put up for Parliament and talk a little too big. They may say they
5357: want to befriend the colliers, for example. But I should like to put a
5358: question to them. I should like to ask them, 'What colliers?' There are
5359: colliers up at Newcastle, and there are colliers down in Wales. Will it
5360: do any good to honest Tom, who is hungry in Sproxton, to hear that Jack
5361: at Newcastle has his belly full of beef and pudding?"
5362: 
5363: "It ought to do him good," Felix burst in, with his loud, abrupt voice,
5364: in odd contrast with glib Mr. Johnson's. "If he knows it's a bad thing
5365: to be hungry and not have enough to eat, he ought to be glad that
5366: another fellow, who is not idle, is not suffering in the same way."
5367: 
5368: Every one was startled. The audience was much impressed with the
5369: grandeur, the knowledge, and the power of Mr. Johnson. His brilliant
5370: promises confirmed the impression that Reform had at length reached the
5371: New Pits; and Reform, if it were good for anything, must at last resolve
5372: itself into spare money--meaning "sport" and drink, and keeping away
5373: from work for several days in the week. These "brave" men of Sproxton
5374: liked Felix as one of themselves, only much more knowing--as a
5375: workingman who had seen many distant parts, but who must be very poor,
5376: since he never drank more than a pint or so. They were quite inclined to
5377: hear what he had got to say on another occasion, but they were rather
5378: irritated by his interruption at the present moment. Mr. Johnson was
5379: annoyed, but he spoke with the same glib quietness as before, though
5380: with an expression of contempt.
5381: 
5382: "I call it a poor-spirited thing to take up a man's straight-forward
5383: words and twist them. What I meant to say was plain enough--that no man
5384: can be saved from starving by looking on while others eat. I think
5385: that's common-sense, eh, sirs?"
5386: 
5387: There was again an approving "Haw, haw." To hear anything said, and
5388: understand it, was a stimulus that had the effect of wit. Mr. Chubb cast
5389: a suspicious and viperous glance at Felix, who felt that he had been a
5390: simpleton for his pains.
5391: 
5392: "Well, then," continued Mr. Johnson, "I suppose I may go on. But if
5393: there is any one here better able to inform the company than I am, I
5394: give way--I give way."
5395: 
5396: "Sir," said Mr. Chubb, magisterially, "no man shall take the words out
5397: of _your_ mouth in this house. And," he added, looking pointedly at
5398: Felix, "company that's got no more orders to give, and wants to turn up
5399: rusty to them that has, had better be making room than filling it. Love
5400: an' 'armony's the word on our Club's flag, an' love an' 'armony's the
5401: meaning of 'The Sugar Loaf, William Chubb.' Folks of a different mind
5402: had better seek another house of call."
5403: 
5404: "Very good," said Felix, laying down his money and taking his cap. "I'm
5405: going." He saw clearly enough that if he said more, there would be a
5406: disturbance which could have no desirable end.
5407: 
5408: When the door had closed behind him, Mr. Johnson said, "What is that
5409: person's name?"
5410: 
5411: "Does anybody know it?" said Mr. Chubb.
5412: 
5413: A few noes were heard.
5414: 
5415: "I've heard him speak like a downright Reformer, else I should have
5416: looked a little sharper after him. But you may see he's nothing
5417: partic'lar."
5418: 
5419: "It looks rather bad that no one knows his name," said Mr. Johnson.
5420: "He's most likely a Tory in disguise--a Tory spy. You must be careful,
5421: sirs, of men who come to you and say they're Radicals, and yet do
5422: nothing for you. They'll stuff you with words--no lack of words--but
5423: words are wind. Now, a man like Transome comes forward and says to the
5424: workingmen of this country: 'Here I am, ready to serve you and speak for
5425: you in Parliament, and to get the laws made all right for you; and in
5426: the meanwhile, if there's any of you who are my neighbors who want a
5427: day's holiday, or a cup to drink with friends, or a copy of the King's
5428: likeness--why, I'm your man. I'm not a paper handbill--all words and no
5429: substance--nor a man with land and nothing else; I've got bags of gold
5430: as well as land.' I think you know what I mean by the King's likeness."
5431: 
5432: Here Mr. Johnson took a half-crown out of his pocket and held the head
5433: toward the company.
5434: 
5435: "Well, sirs, there are some men who like to keep this pretty picture a
5436: great deal too much to themselves. I don't know whether I'm right, but I
5437: think I've heard of such a one not a hundred miles from here. I think
5438: his name was Spratt, and he managed some company's coal-pits."
5439: 
5440: "Haw, haw! Spratt--Spratt's his name," was rolled forth to an
5441: accompaniment of scraping shoe-soles.
5442: 
5443: "A screwing fellow, by what I understand--a domineering fellow--who
5444: would expect men to do as he liked without paying them for it. I think
5445: there's not an honest man wouldn't like to disappoint such an upstart."
5446: 
5447: There was a murmur which was interpreted by Mr. Chubb. "I'll answer for
5448: 'em, sir."
5449: 
5450: "Now, listen to me. Here's Garstin: he's one of the company you work
5451: under. What's Garstin to you? who sees him? and when they do see him
5452: they see a thin miserly fellow who keeps his pockets buttoned. He calls
5453: himself a Whig, yet he'll split votes with a Tory--he'll drive with the
5454: Debarrys. Now, gentlemen, if I said I'd got a vote, and anybody asked me
5455: what I should do with it, I should say, 'I'll plump for Transome.'
5456: You've got no votes, and that's a shame. But you _will_ have some day,
5457: if such men as Transome are returned; and then you'll be on a level with
5458: the first gentleman in the land, and if he wants to sit in Parliament,
5459: he must take off his hat and ask your leave. But though you haven't got
5460: a vote you can give a cheer for the right man, and Transome's not a man
5461: like Garstin; if you lost a day's wages by giving a cheer for Transome,
5462: he'll make you amends. That's the way a man who has no vote can serve
5463: himself and his country; he can lift up his hand and shout 'Transome
5464: forever!'--'hurray for Transome!' Let the workingmen--let the colliers
5465: and navvies and stone-cutters, who between you and me have a good deal
5466: too much the worst of it, as things are now--let them join together and
5467: give their hands and voices for the right man, and they'll make the
5468: great people shake in their shoes a little; and when you shout for
5469: Transome, remember you shout for more wages, and more of your rights,
5470: and you shout to get rid of rats and _sprats_ and such small animals,
5471: who are the tools the rich make use of to squeeze the blood out of the
5472: poor man."
5473: 
5474: "I wish there'd be a row--I'd pommel him," said Dredge, who was
5475: generally felt to be speaking to the question.
5476: 
5477: "No, no, my friend--there you're a little wrong. No pommelling--no
5478: striking first. There you have the law and the constable against you. A
5479: little rolling in the dust and knocking hats off, a little pelting with
5480: soft things that'll stick and not bruise--all that doesn't spoil the
5481: fun. If a man is to speak when you don't like to hear him, it is but
5482: fair you should give him something he doesn't like in return. And the
5483: same if he's got a vote and doesn't use it for the good of the country;
5484: I see no harm in splitting his coat in a quiet way. A man must be taught
5485: what's right if he doesn't know it. But no kicks, no knocking down, no
5486: pommelling."
5487: 
5488: "It 'ud be good fun, though, if so-_be_," said Old Sleck, allowing
5489: himself an imaginative pleasure.
5490: 
5491: "Well, well, if a Spratt wants you to say Garstin, it's some pleasure to
5492: think you can say Transome. Now, my notion is this. You are men who can
5493: put two and two together--I don't know a more solid lot of fellows than
5494: you are; and what I say is, let the honest men in this country who've
5495: got no vote show themselves in a body when they have got the chance.
5496: Why, sirs, for every Tory sneak that's got a vote, there's fifty-five
5497: fellows who must stand by and be expected to hold their tongues. But I
5498: say let 'em hiss the sneaks, let 'em groan at the sneaks, and the sneaks
5499: will be ashamed of themselves. The men who've got votes don't know how
5500: to use them. There's many a fool with a vote, who is not sure in his
5501: mind whether he shall poll, say for Debarry, or Garstin, or
5502: Transome--whether he'll plump or whether he'll split; a straw will turn
5503: him. Let him know your mind if he doesn't know his own. What's the
5504: reason Debarry gets returned? Because people are frightened at the
5505: Debarrys. What's that to you? You don't care for the Debarrys. If people
5506: are frightened at the Tories, we'll turn round and frighten _them_. You
5507: know what a Tory is--one who wants to drive the workingman as he'd drive
5508: cattle. That's what a Tory is; and a Whig is no better, if he's like
5509: Garstin. A Whig wants to knock the Tory down and get the whip, that's
5510: all. But Transome's neither Whig nor Tory; he's the workingman's friend,
5511: the collier's friend, the friend of the honest navvy. And if he gets
5512: into Parliament, let me tell you it will be better for you. I don't say
5513: it will be the better for overlookers and screws, and rats and _sprats_;
5514: but it will be the better for every good fellow who takes his pot at the
5515: Sugar Loaf."
5516: 
5517: Mr. Johnson's exertions for the political education of the Sproxton men
5518: did not stop here, which was the more disinterested in him as he did not
5519: expect to see them again, and could only set on foot an organization by
5520: which their instruction could be continued without him. In this he was
5521: quite successful. A man known among the "butties" as Pack, who had
5522: already been mentioned by Mr. Chubb, presently joined the party, and had
5523: a private audience of Mr. Johnson, that he might be instituted as the
5524: "shepherd" of this new flock.
5525: 
5526: "That's a right down genelman," said Pack, as he took the seat vacated
5527: by the orator, who had ridden away.
5528: 
5529: "What's his trade, think you?" said Gills, the wiry stone-cutter.
5530: 
5531: "Trade?" said Mr. Chubb. "He one of the top sawyers of the country. He
5532: works with his head, you may see that."
5533: 
5534: "Let's have our pipes, then," said Old Sleck; "I'm pretty well tired o'
5535: jaw."
5536: 
5537: "So am I," said Dredge. "It's wriggling work--like follering a stoat. It
5538: makes a man dry. I'd as lief hear preaching, on'y there's naught to be
5539: got by't. I shouldn't know which end I stood on if it wasn't for the
5540: tickets and the treatin'."
5541: 
5542: 
5543: 
5544: 
5545: CHAPTER XII.
5546: 
5547:     "Oh, sir, 'twas that mixture of spite and over-fed merriment
5548:     which passes for humor with the vulgar. In their fun, they have
5549:     much resemblance to a turkey-cock. It has a cruel beak, and
5550:     a silly iteration of ugly sounds; it spreads its tail in
5551:     self-glorification, but shows you the wrong side of the
5552:     ornament--liking admiration, but knowing not what is admirable."
5553: 
5554: 
5555: This Sunday evening, which promised to be so memorable in the experience
5556: of the Sproxton miners, had its drama also for those unsatisfactory
5557: objects to Mr. Johnson's moral sense, the Debarrys. Certain incidents
5558: occurring at Treby Manor caused an excitement there which spread from
5559: the dining-room to the stables; but no one underwent such agitating
5560: transitions of feeling as Mr. Scales. At six o'clock that superior
5561: butler was chuckling in triumph at having played a fine and original
5562: practical joke on his rival, Mr. Christian. Some two hours after that
5563: time he was frightened, sorry, and even meek; he was on the brink of a
5564: humiliating confession; his cheeks were almost livid; his hair was
5565: flattened for want of due attention from his fingers; and the fine roll
5566: of his whiskers, which was too firm to give way, seemed only a sad
5567: reminiscence of past splendor and felicity. His sorrow came about in
5568: this wise.
5569: 
5570: After service on that Sunday morning, Mr. Philip Debarry had left the
5571: rest of the family to go home in the carriage, and had remained at the
5572: rectory to lunch with his uncle Augustus, that he might consult him
5573: touching some letters of importance. He had returned the letters to his
5574: pocket-book but had not returned the book to his pocket, and he finally
5575: walked away leaving the enclosure of private papers and bank-notes on
5576: his uncle's escritoire. After his arrival at home he was reminded of his
5577: omission, and immediately dispatched Christian with a note begging his
5578: uncle to seal up the pocket-book and send it by the bearer. This
5579: commission, which was given between three and four o'clock, happened to
5580: be very unwelcome to the courier. The fact was that Mr. Christian, who
5581: had been remarkable through life for that power of adapting himself to
5582: circumstances which enables a man to fall safely on all-fours in the
5583: most hurried expulsions and escapes, was not exempt from bodily
5584: suffering--a circumstance to which there is no known way of adapting
5585: one's self so as to be perfectly comfortable under it, or to push it off
5586: on to other people's shoulders. He did what he could: he took doses of
5587: opium when he had an access of nervous pains, and he consoled himself as
5588: to future possibilities by thinking that if the pains ever became
5589: intolerably frequent, a considerable increase in the dose might put an
5590: end to them altogether. He was neither Cato nor Hamlet, and though he
5591: had learned their soliloquies at his first boarding-school, he would
5592: probably have increased his dose without reciting those master-pieces.
5593: Next to the pain itself he disliked that any one should know of it:
5594: defective health diminished a man's market value; he did not like to be
5595: the object of the sort of pity he himself gave to a poor devil who was
5596: forced to make a wry face or "give in" altogether.
5597: 
5598: He had felt it expedient to take a slight dose this afternoon, and still
5599: he was not altogether relieved at the time he set off for the rectory.
5600: On returning with the valuable case safely deposited in his hind
5601: pocket, he felt increasing bodily uneasiness, and took another dose.
5602: Thinking it likely that he looked rather pitiable, he chose not to
5603: proceed to the house by the carriage-road. The servants often walked in
5604: the park on a Sunday, and he wished to avoid any meeting. He would make
5605: a circuit, get into the house privately, and after delivering his packet
5606: to Mr. Debarry, shut himself up till the ringing of the half-hour bell.
5607: But when he reached an elbowed seat under some sycamores, he felt so ill
5608: at ease that he yielded to the temptation of throwing himself on it to
5609: rest a little. He looked at his watch: it was but five; he had done his
5610: errand quickly hitherto, and Mr. Debarry had not urged haste. But in
5611: less than ten minutes he was in a sound sleep. Certain conditions of his
5612: system had determined a stronger effect than usual from the opium.
5613: 
5614: As he had expected, there were servants strolling in the park, but they
5615: did not all choose the most frequented part. Mr. Scales, in pursuit of a
5616: light flirtation with the younger lady's maid, had preferred a more
5617: sequestered walk in the company of that agreeable nymph. And it happened
5618: to be this pair, of all others, who alighted on the sleeping
5619: Christian--a sight which at the very first moment caused Mr. Scales a
5620: vague pleasure as at an incident that must lead to something clever on
5621: his part. To play a trick, and make some one or other look foolish, was
5622: held the most pointed form of wit throughout the back regions of the
5623: Manor, and served as a constant substitute for theatrical entertainment:
5624: what the farce wanted in costume or "make up" it gained in the reality
5625: of the mortification which excited the general laughter. And lo! here
5626: was the offensive, the exasperatingly cool and superior Christian,
5627: caught comparatively helpless, with his head hanging on his shoulder,
5628: and one coat-tail hanging out heavily below the elbow of the rustic
5629: seat. It was this coat-tail which served as a suggestion to Mr. Scales's
5630: genius. Putting his finger up in warning to Mrs. Cherry, and saying,
5631: "Hush--be quiet--I see a fine bit of fun"--he took a knife from his
5632: pocket, stepped behind the unconscious Christian, and quickly cut off
5633: the pendent coat-tail. Scales knew nothing of the errand to the rectory;
5634: and as he noticed that there was something in the pocket, thought it was
5635: probably a large cigar-case. So much the better--he had no time to
5636: pause. He threw the coat-tail as far as he could, and noticed that it
5637: fell among the elms under which they had been walking. Then, beckoning
5638: to Mrs Cherry, he hurried away with her toward the more open part of
5639: the park, not daring to explode in laughter until it was safe from the
5640: chance of waking the sleeper. And then the vision of the graceful,
5641: well-appointed Mr. Christian, who sneered at Scales about his "get up,"
5642: having to walk back to the house with only one tail to his coat, was a
5643: source of so much enjoyment to the butler, that the fair Cherry began to
5644: be quite jealous of the joke. Still she admitted that it really was
5645: funny, tittered intermittently, and pledged herself to secrecy. Mr.
5646: Scales explained to her that Christian would try to creep in unobserved,
5647: but that this must be made impossible; and he requested her to imagine
5648: the figure this interloping fellow would cut when everybody was asking
5649: what had happened. "Hallo, Christian! where's your coat tail?" would
5650: become a proverb at the Manor, where jokes kept remarkably well without
5651: the aid of salt; and Mr. Christian's comb would be cut so effectually
5652: that it would take a long time to grow again. Exit Scales, laughing, and
5653: presenting a fine example of dramatic irony to any one in the secret of
5654: Fate.
5655: 
5656: When Christian awoke, he was shocked to find himself in the twilight. He
5657: started up, shook himself, missed something, and soon became aware what
5658: it was he missed. He did not doubt that he had been robbed, and he at
5659: once foresaw that the consequences would be highly unpleasant. In no way
5660: could the cause of the accident be so represented to Mr. Philip Debarry
5661: as to prevent him from viewing his hitherto unimpeachable factotum in a
5662: new and unfavorable light. And though Mr. Christian did not regard his
5663: present position as brilliant, he did not see his way to anything
5664: better. A man nearly fifty who is not always quite well is seldom
5665: ardently hopeful: he is aware that this is a world in which merit is
5666: often overlooked. With the idea of robbery in full possession of his
5667: mind, to peer about and search in the dimness, even if it had occurred
5668: to him, would have seemed a preposterous waste of time and energy. He
5669: knew it was likely that Mr. Debarry's pocket-book had important and
5670: valuable contents, and that he should deepen his offence by deferring
5671: his announcement of the unfortunate fact. He hastened back to the house,
5672: relieved by the obscurity from that mortification of his vanity on which
5673: the butler had counted. Indeed, to Scales himself the affair had already
5674: begun to appear less thoroughly jocose than he had anticipated. For he
5675: observed that Christian's non-appearance before dinner had caused Mr.
5676: Debarry some consternation; and he had gathered that the courier had
5677: been sent on a commission to the rectory. "My uncle must have detained
5678: him for some reason or other," he heard Mr. Philip say; "but it is odd.
5679: If he were less trusty about commissions, or had ever seemed to drink
5680: too much, I should be uneasy." Altogether the affair was not taking the
5681: turn Mr. Scales had intended. At last, when dinner had been removed, and
5682: the butler's chief duties were at an end, it was understood that
5683: Christian had entered without his coat tail, looking serious and even
5684: agitated; that he had asked leave at once to speak to Mr. Debarry, and
5685: that he was even then in parley with the gentleman in the dining-room.
5686: Scales was in alarm; it must have been some property of Mr. Debarry's
5687: that had weighted the pocket. He took a lantern, got a groom to
5688: accompany him with another lantern, and with the utmost practical speed
5689: reached the fatal spot in the park. He searched under the elms--he was
5690: certain that the pocket had fallen there--and he found the pocket; but
5691: he found it empty, and, in spite of further search, did not find the
5692: contents, though he had first consoled himself with thinking that they
5693: had fallen out, and would be lying not far off. He returned with the
5694: lanterns and the coat tail and a most uncomfortable consciousness in
5695: that great seat of a butler's emotion, the stomach. He had no sooner
5696: re-entered than he was met by Mrs. Cherry, pale and anxious, who drew
5697: him aside to say that if he didn't tell everything she would; that the
5698: constables were to be sent for; that there had been no end of bank-notes
5699: and letters and things in Mr. Debarry's pocket-book, which Christian was
5700: carrying in that very pocket Scales had cut off; that the rector was
5701: sent for, the constable was coming, and they should all be hanged. Mr.
5702: Scales's own intellect was anything but clear as to the possible issues.
5703: Crest-fallen, and with the coat-tail in his hands as an attestation that
5704: he was innocent of anything more than a joke, he went and made his
5705: confession. His story relieved Christian a little, but did not relieve
5706: Mr. Debarry, who was more annoyed at the loss of the letters, and the
5707: chance of their getting into hands that might make use of them, than at
5708: the loss of the bank-notes. Nothing could be done for the present, but
5709: that the rector, who was a magistrate, should instruct the constables,
5710: and that the spot in the park indicated by Scales should again be
5711: carefully searched. This was done, but in vain; and many of the family
5712: at the Manor had disturbed sleep that night.
5713: 
5714: 
5715: 
5716: 
5717: CHAPTER XIII.
5718: 
5719:     "Give sorrow leave awhile, to tutor me
5720:     To this submission."--_Richard II._
5721: 
5722: 
5723: Meanwhile Felix Holt had been making his way back from Sproxton to Treby
5724: in some irritation and bitterness of spirit. For a little while he
5725: walked slowly along the direct road, hoping that Mr. Johnson would
5726: overtake him, in which case he would have the pleasure of quarrelling
5727: with him, and telling him what he thought of his intentions in coming to
5728: cant at the Sugar Loaf. But he presently checked himself in this folly
5729: and turned off again toward the canal, that he might avoid the
5730: temptation of getting into a passion to no purpose.
5731: 
5732: "Where's the good," he thought, "of pulling at such a tangled skein as
5733: this electioneering trickery? As long as three-fourths of the men in
5734: this country see nothing in an election but self-interest, and nothing
5735: in self-interest but some form of greed, one might as well try to purify
5736: the proceedings of the fishes, and say to a hungry cod-fish--'My good
5737: friend, abstain; don't goggle your eyes so, or show such a stupid
5738: gluttonous mouth, or think the little fishes are worth nothing except in
5739: relation to your own inside.' He'd be open to no argument short of
5740: crimping him. I should get into a rage with this fellow, and perhaps end
5741: by thrashing him. There's some reason in me as long as I keep my temper,
5742: but my rash humor is drunkenness without wine. I shouldn't wonder if he
5743: upsets all my plans with these colliers. Of course he's going to treat
5744: them for the sake of getting up a posse at the nomination and
5745: speechifyings. They'll drink double, and never come near me on a
5746: Saturday evening. I don't know what sort of man Transome really is. It's
5747: no use my speaking to anybody else, but if I could get at him, he might
5748: put a veto on this thing. Though, when once the men have been promised
5749: and set a-going, the mischief is likely to be past mending. Hang the
5750: Liberal cod-fish! I shouldn't have minded so much if he'd been a Tory!"
5751: 
5752: Felix went along in the twilight struggling in this way with the
5753: intricacies of life, which would certainly be greatly simplified if
5754: corrupt practices were the invariable mark of wrong opinions. When he
5755: had crossed the common and had entered the park, the overshadowing trees
5756: deepened the gray gloom of the evening; it was useless to try and keep
5757: the blind path, and he could only be careful that his steps should be
5758: bent in the direction of the park gate. He was striding along rapidly
5759: now, whistling "Bannockburn" in a subdued way as an accompaniment to
5760: his inward discussion, when something smooth and soft on which his foot
5761: alighted arrested him with an unpleasant startling sensation, and made
5762: him stoop to examine the object he was treading on. He found it to be a
5763: large leather pocket-book swelled by its contents, and fastened with a
5764: sealed ribbon as well as a clasp. In stooping he saw about a yard off
5765: something whitish and square lying on the dark grass. This was an
5766: ornamental note-book of pale leather stamped with gold. Apparently it
5767: had burst open in falling, and out of the pocket formed by the cover,
5768: there protruded a small gold chain about four inches long, with various
5769: seals and other trifles attached to it by a ring at the end. Felix
5770: thrust the chain back, and finding that the clasp of the note-book was
5771: broken, he closed it and thrust it into his side-pocket, walking along
5772: under some annoyance that fortune had made him the finder of articles
5773: belonging most probably to one of the family at Treby Manor. He was much
5774: too proud a man to like any contact with the aristocracy, and he could
5775: still less endure coming within speech of their servants. Some plan must
5776: be devised by which he could avoid carrying these things up to the Manor
5777: himself: he thought at first of leaving them at the lodge, but he had a
5778: scruple against placing property, of which the ownership was after all
5779: uncertain, in the hands of persons unknown to him. It was possible that
5780: the large pocket-book contained papers of high importance, and that it
5781: did not belong to any of the Debarry family. He resolved at last to
5782: carry his findings to Mr. Lyon, who would perhaps be good-natured enough
5783: to save him from the necessary transactions with the people at the Manor
5784: by undertaking those transactions himself. With this determination he
5785: walked straight to Malthouse Yard, and waited outside the chapel until
5786: the congregation was dispersing, when he passed along the aisle to the
5787: vestry in order to speak to the minister in private.
5788: 
5789: But Mr. Lyon was not alone when Felix entered. Mr. Nuttwood, the grocer,
5790: who was one of the deacons, was complaining to him about the obstinate
5791: demeanor of the singers, who had declined to change the tunes in
5792: accordance with a change in the selection of hymns, and had stretched
5793: short metre into long out of pure wilfulness and defiance, irreverently
5794: adapting the most sacred monosyllables to a multitude of quavers,
5795: arranged, it was to be feared, by some musician who was inspired by
5796: conceit rather than by the true spirit of psalmody.
5797: 
5798: "Come in, my friend," said Mr. Lyon, smiling at Felix, and then
5799: continuing in a faint voice, while he wiped the perspiration from his
5800: brow and bald crown, "Brother Nuttwood, we must be content to carry a
5801: thorn in our sides while the necessities of our imperfect state demand
5802: that there should be a body set apart and called a choir, whose special
5803: office it is to lead the singing, not because they are more disposed to
5804: the devout uplifting of praise, but because they are endowed with better
5805: vocal organs, and have attained more of the musician's art. For all
5806: office, unless it be accompanied by peculiar grace, becomes, as it were,
5807: a diseased organ, seeking to make itself too much of a centre. Singers,
5808: specially so called, are, it must be confessed, an anomaly among us who
5809: seek to reduce the Church to its primitive simplicity, and to cast away
5810: all that may obstruct the direct communion of spirit with spirit."
5811: 
5812: "They are so headstrong," said Mr. Nuttwood, in a tone of sad
5813: perplexity, "that if we dealt not warily with them they might end in
5814: dividing the church, even now that we have had the chapel enlarged.
5815: Brother Kemp would side with them, and draw the half part of the members
5816: after him. I cannot but think it a snare when a professing Christian has
5817: a bass voice like Brother Kemp's. It makes him desire to be heard of
5818: men; but the weaker song of the humble may have more power in the ear of
5819: God."
5820: 
5821: "Do you think it any better vanity to flatter yourself that God likes to
5822: hear you, though men don't?" said Felix, with unwarrantable bluntness.
5823: 
5824: The civil grocer was prepared to be scandalized by anything that came
5825: from Felix. In common with many hearers in Malthouse Yard, he already
5826: felt an objection to a young man who was notorious for having interfered
5827: in a question of wholesale and retail, which should have been left to
5828: Providence. Old Mr. Holt, being a church member, had probably had
5829: "leadings" which were more to be relied on than his son's boasted
5830: knowledge. In any case, a little visceral disturbance and inward
5831: chastisement to the consumers of questionable medicines would tend less
5832: to obscure the divine glory than a show of punctilious morality in one
5833: who was not a "professor." Besides, how was it to be known that the
5834: medicines would not be blessed, if taken with due trust in a higher
5835: influence? A Christian must consider not the medicines alone in their
5836: relation to our frail bodies (which are dust), but the medicines with
5837: Omnipotence behind them. Hence a pious vendor will look for "leadings,"
5838: and he is likely to find them in the cessation of demand and the
5839: disproportion of expenses and returns. The grocer was thus on his guard
5840: against the presumptuous disputant.
5841: 
5842: "Mr. Lyon may understand you, sir," he replied. "He seems to be fond of
5843: your conversation. But you have too much of the pride of human learning
5844: for me. I follow no new lights."
5845: 
5846: "Then follow an old one," said Felix, mischievously disposed toward a
5847: sleek tradesman. "Follow the light of the old-fashioned Presbyterians
5848: that I've heard sing at Glasgow. The preacher gives out the psalm, and
5849: then everybody sings a different tune, as it happens to turn up in their
5850: throats. It's a domineering thing to set a tune and expect everybody
5851: else to follow it. It's a denial of private judgment."
5852: 
5853: "Hush, hush, my young friend," said Mr. Lyon, hurt by this levity, which
5854: glanced at himself as well as at the deacon. "Play not with paradoxes.
5855: That caustic which you handle in order to scorch others, may happen to
5856: sear your own fingers and make them dead to the quality of things. 'Tis
5857: difficult enough to see our way and keep our torch steady in this dim
5858: labyrinth: to whirl the torch and dazzle the eyes of our fellow-seekers
5859: is a poor daring, and may end in total darkness. You yourself are a
5860: lover of freedom, and a bold rebel against usurping authority. But the
5861: right to rebellion is the right to seek a higher rule, and not to wander
5862: in mere lawlessness. Wherefore, I beseech you, seem not to say that
5863: liberty is license. And I apprehend--though I am not endowed with an ear
5864: to seize those earthly harmonies, which to some devout souls have
5865: seemed, as it were, the broken echoes of the heavenly choir--I apprehend
5866: that there is a law in music, disobedience whereunto would bring us in
5867: our singing to the level of shrieking maniacs or howling beasts: so that
5868: herein we are well instructed how true liberty can be nought but the
5869: transfer of obedience from the will of one or of a few men to that will
5870: which is the norm or rule for all men. And though the transfer may
5871: sometimes be but an erroneous direction of search, yet is the search
5872: good and necessary to the ultimate finding. And even as in music, where
5873: all obey and concur to one end, so that each has the joy of contributing
5874: to a whole whereby he is ravished and lifted up into the courts of
5875: heaven, so will it be in that crowning time of the millennial reign,
5876: when our daily prayer will be fulfilled, and one law shall be written on
5877: all hearts, and be the very structure of all thought, and be the
5878: principle of all action."
5879: 
5880: Tired, even exhausted, as the minister had been when Felix Holt entered,
5881: the gathering excitement of speech gave more and more energy to his
5882: voice and manner; he walked away from the vestry table, he paused, and
5883: came back to it; he walked away again, then came back, and ended with
5884: his deepest toned largo, keeping his hands clasped behind him, while his
5885: brown eyes were bright with the lasting youthfulness of enthusiastic
5886: thought and love. But to any one who had no share in the energies that
5887: were thrilling his little body, he would have looked queer enough. No
5888: sooner had he finished his eager speech, than he held out his hand to
5889: the deacon, and said, in his former faint tone of fatigue--
5890: 
5891: "God be with you, brother. We shall meet to-morrow, and we will see what
5892: can be done to subdue these refractory spirits."
5893: 
5894: When the deacon was gone, Felix said, "Forgive me, Mr. Lyon; I was
5895: wrong, and you are right."
5896: 
5897: "Yes, yes, my friend, you have that mark of grace within you, that you
5898: are ready to acknowledge the justice of a rebuke. Sit down; you have
5899: something to say--some packet there."
5900: 
5901: They sat down at a corner of the small table, and Felix drew the
5902: note-book from his pocket to lay it down with the pocket-book, saying--
5903: 
5904: "I've had the ill-luck to be the finder of these things in the Debarrys'
5905: park. Most likely they belong to one of the family at the Manor, or to
5906: some grandee who is staying there. I hate having anything to do with
5907: such people. They'll think me a poor rascal, and offer me money. You are
5908: a known man, and I thought you would be kind enough to relieve me by
5909: taking charge of these things, and writing to Debarry, not mentioning
5910: me, and asking him to send some one for them. I found them on the grass
5911: in the park this evening about half-past seven, in the corner we cross
5912: going to Sproxton."
5913: 
5914: "Stay," said Mr. Lyon, "this little book is open; we may venture to look
5915: in it for some sign of ownership. There be others who possess property,
5916: and might be crossing that end of the park, besides the Debarrys."
5917: 
5918: As he lifted the note-book close to his eyes, the chain again slipped
5919: out. He arrested it and held it in his hand, while he examined some
5920: writing, which appeared to be a name on the inner leather. He looked
5921: long, as if he were trying to decipher something that was partly rubbed
5922: out; and his hands began to tremble noticeably. He made a movement in an
5923: agitated manner, as if he were going to examine the chain and seals,
5924: which he held in his hand. But he checked himself, closed his hand
5925: again, and rested it on the table, while with the other hand he pressed
5926: the sides of the note-book together.
5927: 
5928: Felix observed his agitation, and was much surprised; but with a
5929: delicacy of which he was capable under all his abruptness, he said, "You
5930: are overcome with fatigue, sir. I was thoughtless to tease you with
5931: these matters at the end of Sunday, when you have been preaching three
5932: sermons."
5933: 
5934: Mr. Lyon did not speak for a few moments, but at last he said--
5935: 
5936: "It is true. I am overcome. It was a name I saw--a name that called up a
5937: past sorrow. Fear not; I will do what is needful with these things. You
5938: may trust them to me."
5939: 
5940: With trembling fingers he replaced the chain, and tied both the large
5941: pocket-book and the note-book in his handkerchief. He was evidently
5942: making a great effort over himself. But when he had gathered the knot of
5943: the handkerchief in his hand he said--
5944: 
5945: "Give me your arm to the door, my friend. I feel ill. Doubtless I am
5946: over-wearied."
5947: 
5948: The door was already open, and Lyddy was watching for her master's
5949: return. Felix therefore said good-night and passed on, sure that this
5950: was what Mr. Lyon would prefer. The minister's supper of warm porridge
5951: was ready by the kitchen-fire, where he always took it on a Sunday
5952: evening, and afterward smoked his weekly pipe up the broad chimney--the
5953: one great relaxation he allowed himself. Smoking, he considered, was a
5954: recreation of the travailled spirit, which, if indulged in, might endear
5955: this world to us by the ignoble bonds of mere sensuous ease. Daily
5956: smoking might be lawful, but it was not expedient. And in this Esther
5957: concurred with a doctrinal eagerness that was unusual in her. It was her
5958: habit to go to her own room, professedly to bed, very early on
5959: Sundays--immediately on her return from chapel--that she might avoid her
5960: father's pipe. But this evening she had remained at home, under a true
5961: plea of not feeling well; and when she heard him enter, she ran out of
5962: the parlor to meet him.
5963: 
5964: "Father, you are ill," she said, as he tottered to the wicker-bottomed
5965: arm-chair, while Lyddy stood by, shaking her head.
5966: 
5967: "No, my dear," he answered feebly, as she took off his hat and looked in
5968: his face enquiringly; "I am weary."
5969: 
5970: "Let me lay these things down for you," said Esther, touching the bundle
5971: in the handkerchief.
5972: 
5973: "No; they are matters which I have to examine," he said, laying them on
5974: the table, and putting his arm across them. "Go you to bed, Lyddy."
5975: 
5976: "Not me, sir. If ever a man looked as if he was struck with death, it's
5977: you, this very night as here is."
5978: 
5979: "Nonsense, Lyddy," said Esther, angrily. "Go to bed when my father
5980: desires it. I will stay with him."
5981: 
5982: Lyddy was electrified by surprise at this new behavior of Miss Esther's.
5983: She took her candle silently and went.
5984: 
5985: "Go you too, my dear," said Mr. Lyon, tenderly, giving his hand to
5986: Esther, when Lyddy was gone. "It is your wont to go early. Why are you
5987: up?"
5988: 
5989: "Let me lift your porridge from before the fire, and stay with you,
5990: father. You think I'm so naughty that I don't like doing anything for
5991: you," said Esther, smiling rather sadly at him.
5992: 
5993: "Child, what has happened? You have become the image of your mother
5994: to-night," said the minister, in a loud whisper. The tears came and
5995: relieved him while Esther, who had stooped to lift the porridge from the
5996: fender, paused on one knee and looked up at him.
5997: 
5998: "She was very good to you?" asked Esther, softly.
5999: 
6000: "Yes, dear. She did not reject my affection. She thought not scorn of my
6001: love. She would have forgiven me, if I had erred against her, from very
6002: tenderness. Could you forgive me, child?"
6003: 
6004: "Father, I have not been good to you; but I will be, I will be," said
6005: Esther, laying her head on his knee.
6006: 
6007: He kissed her head. "Go to bed, dear; I would be alone."
6008: 
6009: When Esther was lying down that night, she felt as if the little
6010: incidents between herself and her father on this Sunday had made it an
6011: epoch. Very slight words and deeds may have a sacramental efficacy, if
6012: we can cast our self-love behind us, in order to say or do them. And it
6013: has been well believed through many ages that the beginning of
6014: compunction is the beginning of a new life; that the mind which sees
6015: itself blameless may be called dead in trespasses--in trespasses on the
6016: love of others, in trespasses on their weakness, in trespasses on all
6017: those great claims which are the image of our own need.
6018: 
6019: But Esther persisted in assuring herself that she was not bending to any
6020: criticism from Felix. She was full of resentment against his rudeness,
6021: and yet more against his too harsh conception of her character. She was
6022: determined to keep as much at a distance from him as possible.

6029:     This man's metallic; at a sudden blow
6030:     His soul rings hard. I cannot lay my palm,
6031:     Trembling with life, upon that jointed brass.
6032:     I shudder at the cold unanswering touch;
6033:     But if it press me in response, I'm bruised.

6036: The next morning, when the Debarrys, including the rector, who had
6037: ridden over to the Manor early, were still seated at breakfast,

6041: 
6042: The letter was addressed to Sir Maximus.
6043:

6050: 
6051: Philip cast his eyes over it, and then read aloud in a tone of

6053: 
6054:     SIR,--I send this letter to apprise you that I have now in my
6055:     possession certain articles, which, last evening, at about
6056:     half-past seven o'clock, were found lying on the grass at the
6057:     western extremity of your park. The articles are =1=, a well-filled
6058:     pocket-book, of brown leather, fastened with a black ribbon and
6059:     with a seal of red wax; =2=, a small note-book, covered with gilded
6060:     vellum, whereof the clasp was burst, and from out whereof had
6061:     partly escaped a small chain, with seals and a locket attached, the
6062:     locket bearing on the back a device, and round the face a female
6063:     name.
6064:

6066:     articles in the right hands, by ascertaining whether any person
6067:     within your walls claims them as his property, and by sending that
6068:     person to me (if such be found); for I will on no account let them
6069:     pass from my care save into that of one who, declaring himself to
6070:     be the owner, can state to me what is the impression on the seal,
6071:     and what the device and name upon the locket.
6072:

6074: 
6075:     Malthouse Yard. Oct. 3, 1832.                    RUFUS LYON.
6076: 
6077: "Well done, old Lyon," said the rector; "I didn't think that any
6078: composition of his would ever give me so much pleasure."
6079:

6082:

6096: 
6097: "No, it was this head of Achilles. Here, I can take it off the ring, and
6098: you can carry it, Christian. But don't lose that, for I've had it ever

6100: the rector went on, looking at his brother, "and beg that since he has
6101: so much wise caution at command, he would exercise a little in more
6102: public matters, instead of making himself a firebrand in my parish, and
6103: teaching hucksters and tape-weavers that it's their business to dictate
6104: to statesmen."
6105: 
6106: "How did Dissenters, and Methodists, and Quakers, and people of that
6107: sort first come up, uncle?" said Miss Selina, a radiant girl of
6108: twenty, who had given much time to the harp.
6109: 
6110: "Dear me, Selina," said her elder sister, Harriet, whose forte was
6111: general knowledge, "don't you remember 'Woodstock'? They were in
6112: Cromwell's time."
6113: 
6114: "Oh! Holdenough, and those people? Yes; but they preached in the
6115: churches; they had no chapels. Tell me, uncle Gus; I like to be wise,"
6116: said Selina, looking up at the face which was smiling down on her with a
6117: sort of severe benignity. "Phil says I'm an ignorant puss."
6118: 
6119: "The seeds of Nonconformity were sown at the Reformation, my dear, when
6120: some obstinate man made scruples about surplices and the place of the
6121: communion-table, and other trifles of that sort. But the Quakers came up
6122: about Cromwell's time, and the Methodists only in the last century. The
6123: first Methodists were regular clergymen, the more's the pity."
6124: 
6125: "But all those wrong things, why didn't government put them down?"
6126: 
6127: "Ah, to be sure," fell in Sir Maximus, in a cordial tone of
6128: corroboration.
6129: 
6130: "Because error is often strong, and government is often weak, my dear.
6131: Well, Phil, have you finished your letter?"
6132: 
6133: "Yes, I will read it to you," said Philip, turning and leaning over the
6134: back of his chair with the letter in his hand.
6135: 
6136: There is a portrait of Mr. Philip Debarry still to be seen at Treby
6137: Manor, and a very fine bust of him at Rome, where he died fifteen years
6138: later, a convert to Catholicism. His face would have been plain but for
6139: the exquisite setting of his hazel eyes, which fascinated even the dogs
6140: of the household. The other features, though slight and irregular, were
6141: redeemed from triviality by the stamp of gravity and intellectual
6142: preoccupation in his face and bearing. As he read aloud, his voice was
6143: what his uncle's might have been if it had been modulated by delicate
6144: health and a visitation of self-doubt.
6145: 
6146:     SIR,--In reply to the letter with which you have favored me this
6147:     morning, I beg to state that the articles you describe were lost
6148:     from the pocket of my servant, who is the bearer of this letter to
6149:     you, and is the claimant of the vellum note-book and the gold
6150:     chain. The large leathern pocket-book is my own property and the
6151:     impression on the wax, a helmeted head of Achilles, was made by my
6152:     uncle, the Reverend Augustus Debarry, who allows me to forward this
6153:     seal to you in proof that I am not making a mistaken claim.
6154: 
6155:     I feel myself under deep obligation to you, sir, for the care and
6156:     trouble you have taken in order to restore to its right owner a
6157:     piece of property which happens to be of particular importance to
6158:     me. And I shall consider myself doubly fortunate if at any time you
6159:     can point out to me some method by which I may procure you as
6160:     lively a satisfaction as I am now feeling, in that full and speedy
6161:     relief from anxiety which I owe to your considerate conduct.
6162: 
6163:    I remain, sir, your obliged and faithful servant,
6164:                                                  PHILIP DEBARRY.
6165: 
6166: "You know best, Phil, of course," said Sir Maximus, pushing his plate
6167: from him, by way of interjection. "But it seems to me you exaggerate
6168: preposterously every little service a man happens to do for you. Why
6169: should you make a general offer of that sort? How do you know what he
6170: will be asking you to do? Stuff and nonsense! Tell Willis to send him a
6171: few head of game. You should think twice before you give a blank check
6172: of that sort to one of these quibbling, meddlesome Radicals."
6173: 
6174: "You are afraid of my committing myself to 'the bottomless perjury of an
6175: et cetera,'" said Philip, smiling, as he turned to fold his letter. "But
6176: I think I am not doing any mischief; at all events I could not be
6177: content to say less. And I have a notion that he would regard a present
6178: of game just now as an insult. I should, in his place."
6179: 
6180: "Yes, yes, you; but you don't make yourself a measure of Dissenting
6181: preachers, I hope," said Sir Maximus, rather wrathfully. "What do you
6182: say, Gus?"
6183: 
6184: "Phil is right," said the rector, in an absolute tone. "I would not deal
6185: with a Dissenter, or put profits into the pocket of a Radical which I
6186: might put into the pocket of a good Churchman and a quiet subject. But
6187: if the greatest scoundrel in the world made way for me, or picked my hat
6188: up, I would thank him. So would you, Max."
6189: 
6190: "Pooh! I didn't mean that one shouldn't behave like a gentleman," said
6191: Sir Maximus, in some vexation. He had great pride in his son's
6192: superiority even to himself; but he did not quite trust the dim vision
6193: opened by Phil's new words and new notions. He could only submit in
6194: silence while the letter was delivered to Christian, with the order to
6195: start for Malthouse Yard immediately.
6196: 
6197: Meanwhile, in that somewhat dim locality the possible claimant of the
6198: note-book and the chain was thought of and expected with palpitating
6199: agitation. Mr. Lyon was seated in his study, looking haggard and already
6200: aged from a sleepless night. He was so afraid lest his emotion should
6201: deprive him of the presence of mind necessary to the due attention to
6202: particulars in the coming interview, that he continued to occupy his
6203: sight and touch with the objects which had stirred the depths, not only
6204: of memory, but of dread. Once again he unlocked a small box which stood
6205: beside his desk, and took from it a little oval locket, and compared
6206: this with one which hung with the seals on the stray gold chain. There
6207: was the same device in enamel on the back of both: clasped hands
6208: surrounded with blue flowers. Both had round the face a name in gold
6209: italics on a blue ground: the name on the locket taken from the drawer
6210: was _Maurice_; the name on the locket which hung with the seals was
6211: _Annette_, and within the circle of this name there was a lover's knot
6212: of light brown hair, which matched a curl that lay in the box. The hair
6213: in the locket which bore the name of Maurice was of a very dark brown,
6214: and before returning it to the drawer Mr. Lyon noted the color and
6215: quality of this hair more carefully than ever. Then he recurred to the
6216: note-book: undoubtedly there had been something, probably a third name,
6217: beyond the names _Maurice Christian_, which had themselves been rubbed
6218: and slightly smeared as if by accident; and from the very first
6219: examination in the vestry, Mr. Lyon could not prevent himself from
6220: transferring the mental image of the third name in faint lines to the
6221: rubbed leather. The leaves of the note-book seemed to have been recently
6222: inserted; they were of fresh white paper, and only bore some
6223: abbreviations in pencil with a notation of small sums. Nothing could be
6224: gathered from the comparison of the writing in the book with that of the
6225: yellow letters which lay in the box; the smeared name had been carefully
6226: printed, and so bore no resemblance to the signature of those letters;
6227: and the pencil abbreviations and figures had been made too hurriedly to
6228: bear any decisive witness. "I will ask him to write--to write a
6229: description of the locket," had been one of Mr. Lyon's thoughts; but he
6230: faltered in that intention. His power of fulfilling it must depend on
6231: what he saw in this visitor, of whose coming he had a horrible dread, at
6232: the very time he was writing to demand it. In that demand he was obeying
6233: the voice of his rigid conscience, which had never left him perfectly at
6234: rest under his one act of deception--the concealment from Esther that he
6235: was not her natural father, the assertion of a false claim upon her.
6236: "Let my path be henceforth simple," he had said to himself in the
6237: anguish of that night; "let me seek to know what is, and if possible to
6238: declare it." If he was really going to find himself face to face with
6239: the man who had been Annette's husband, and who was Esther's father--if
6240: that wandering of his from the light had brought the punishment of a
6241: blind sacrilege as the issue of a conscious transgression,--he prayed
6242: that he might be able to accept all consequences of pain to himself. But
6243: he saw other possibilities concerning the claimant of the book and
6244: chain. His ignorance and suspicions as to the history and character of
6245: Annette's husband made it credible that he had laid a plan for
6246: convincing her of his death as a means of freeing himself from a
6247: burdensome tie; but it seemed equally probable that he was really dead,
6248: and that these articles of property had been a bequest, or a payment, or
6249: even a sale, to their present owner. Indeed, in all these years there was
6250: no knowing into how many hands such pretty trifles might have passed.
6251: And the claimant might, after all, have no connection with the Debarrys;
6252: he might not come on this day or the next. There might be more time left
6253: for reflection and prayer.
6254: 
6255: All these possibilities, which would remove the pressing need for
6256: difficult action, Mr. Lyon represented to himself, but he had no
6257: effective belief in them; his belief went with his strongest feeling,
6258: and in these moments his strongest feeling was dead. He trembled under
6259: the weight that seemed already added to his own sin; he felt himself
6260: already confronted by Annette's husband and Esther's father. Perhaps the
6261: father was a gentleman on a visit to the Debarrys. There was no
6262: hindering the pang with which the old man said to himself--
6263: 
6264: "The child will not be sorry to leave this poor home, and I shall be
6265: guilty in her sight."
6266: 
6267: He was walking about among the rows of books when there came a loud rap
6268: at the outer door. The rap shook him so that he sank into his chair,
6269: feeling almost powerless. Lyddy presented herself.
6270: 
6271: "Here's ever such a fine man from the Manor wants to see you, sir. Dear
6272: heart, dear heart! shall I tell him you're too bad to see him?"
6273: 
6274: "Show him up," said Mr. Lyon, making an effort to rally. When Christian
6275: appeared, the minister half rose, leaning on an arm of his chair, and
6276: said, "Be seated, sir," seeing nothing but that a tall man was entering.
6277: 
6278: "I've brought you a letter from Mr. Debarry," said Christian, in an
6279: off-hand manner. The rusty little man, in his dismal chamber, seemed to
6280: the Ulysses of the steward's room a pitiable sort of human curiosity, to
6281: whom a man of the world would speak rather loudly, in accommodation to
6282: an eccentricity which was likely to be accompanied with deafness. One
6283: cannot be eminent in everything; and if Mr. Christian had dispersed his
6284: faculties in study that would have enabled him to share unconventional
6285: points of view, he might have worn a mistaken kind of boot, and been
6286: less competent to win at _écarté_, or at betting, or in any other
6287: contest suitable to a person of figure.
6288: 
6289: As he seated himself, Mr. Lyon opened the letter, and held it close to
6290: his eyes, so that his face was hidden. But at the word "servant" he
6291: could not avoid starting, and looking off the letter toward the bearer.
6292: Christian, knowing what was in the letter, conjectured that the old man
6293: was amazed to learn that so distinguished-looking a personage was a
6294: servant; he leaned forward with his elbows on his knees, balanced his
6295: cane on his fingers, and began a whispering whistle. The minister
6296: checked himself, finished the reading of the letter, and then slowly and
6297: nervously put on his spectacles to survey this man, between whose fate
6298: and his own there might be a terrible collision. The word "servant" had
6299: been a fresh caution to him. He must do nothing rashly. Esther's lot was
6300: deeply concerned.
6301: 
6302: "Here is the seal mentioned in the letter," said Christian.
6303: 
6304: Mr. Lyon drew the pocket-book from his desk, and after comparing the
6305: seal with the impression, said, "It is right, sir: I deliver the
6306: pocket-book to you."
6307: 
6308: He held it out with the seal, and Christian rose to take them, saying
6309: carelessly, "The other things--the chain and the little book--are mine."
6310: 
6311: "Your name then is----"
6312: 
6313: "Maurice Christian."
6314: 
6315: A spasm shot through Mr. Lyon. It had seemed possible that he might hear
6316: another name, and be freed from the worse half of his anxiety. His next
6317: words were not wisely chosen, but escaped him impulsively.
6318: 
6319: "And you have no other name?"
6320: 
6321: "What do you mean?" said Christian, sharply.
6322: 
6323: "Be so good as to reseat yourself."
6324: 
6325: Christian did not comply. "I'm rather in a hurry, sir," he said,
6326: recovering his coolness. "If it suits you to restore to me those small
6327: articles of mine, I shall be glad; but I would rather leave them behind
6328: than be detained." He had reflected that the minister was simply a
6329: punctilious old bore. The question meant nothing else. But Mr. Lyon had
6330: wrought himself up to the task of finding out, then and there, if
6331: possible, whether or not this were Annette's husband. How could he lay
6332: himself and his sin before God if he wilfully declined to learn the
6333: truth? "Nay, sir, I will not detain you unreasonably," he said, in a
6334: firmer tone than before. "How long have these articles been your
6335: property?"
6336: 
6337: "Oh, for more than twenty years," said Christian, carelessly.
6338: 
6339: He was not altogether easy under the minister's persistence, but for
6340: that very reason he showed no more impatience.
6341: 
6342: "You have been in France and in Germany?"
6343: 
6344: "I have been in most countries on the continent."
6345: 
6346: "Be so good as to write me your name," said Mr. Lyon, dipping a pen in
6347: ink, and holding it out with a piece of paper.
6348: 
6349: Christian was much surprised, but not now greatly alarmed. In his rapid
6350: conjectures as to the explanation of the minister's curiosity, he had
6351: alighted on one which might carry advantage rather than inconvenience.
6352: But he was not going to commit himself.
6353: 
6354: "Before I oblige you there, sir," he said, laying down the pen, and
6355: looking straight at Mr. Lyon, "I must know exactly the reasons you have
6356: for putting these questions to me. You are a stranger to me--an
6357: excellent person, I dare say--but I have no concern about you farther
6358: than to get from you those small articles. Do you still doubt that they
6359: are mine? You wished, I think, that I should tell you what the locket is
6360: like. It has a pair of hands and blue flowers on one side and the name
6361: Annette round the hair on the other side. That is all I have to say. If
6362: you wish for anything more from me, you will be good enough to tell me
6363: why you wish it. Now then, sir, what is your concern with me?"
6364: 
6365: The cool stare, the hard challenging voice, with which these words were
6366: uttered, made them fall like the beating cutting chill of heavy hail on
6367: Mr. Lyon. He sank back in his chair in utter irresolution and
6368: helplessness. How was it possible to lay bare the sad and sacred past in
6369: answer to such a call as this? The dread with which he had thought of
6370: this man's coming, the strongly-confirmed suspicion that he was really
6371: Annette's husband, intensified the antipathy created by his gestures and
6372: glances. The sensitive little minister knew instinctively that words
6373: which would cost him efforts as painful as the obedient footsteps of a
6374: wounded bleeding hound that wills a foreseen throe, would fall on this
6375: man as the pressure of tender fingers falls on a brazen glove. And
6376: Esther--if this man was her father, every additional word might help to
6377: bring down irrevocable, perhaps cruel consequences on her. A thick mist
6378: seemed to have fallen where Mr. Lyon was looking for the track of duty:
6379: the difficult question, how far he was to care for consequences in
6380: seeking and avowing the truth, seemed anew obscured. All these things,
6381: like the vision of a coming calamity, were compressed into a moment of
6382: consciousness. Nothing could be done to-day; everything must be
6383: deferred. He answered Christian in a low apologetic tone.
6384: 
6385: "It is true, sir; you have told me all I can demand. I have no
6386: sufficient reason for detaining your property further."
6387: 
6388: He handed the note-book and chain to Christian, who had been observing
6389: him narrowly, and now said, in a tone of indifference, as he pocketed
6390: the articles--
6391: 
6392: "Very good, sir. I wish you a good-morning."
6393: 
6394: "Good-morning," said Mr. Lyon, feeling, while the door closed behind his
6395: guest, that mixture of uneasiness and relief which all procrastination
6396: of difficulty produces in minds capable of strong forecast. The work
6397: was still to be done. He had still before him the task of learning
6398: everything that could be learned about this man's relation to himself
6399: and Esther.
6400: 
6401: Christian, as he made his way back along Malthouse Lane, was thinking,
6402: "This old fellow has got some secret in his head. It's not likely he can
6403: know anything about me: it must be about Bycliffe. But Bycliffe was a
6404: gentleman: how should he ever have had anything to do with such a seedy
6405: old ranter as that?"
6406: 
6407: 
6408: 
6409: 
6410: CHAPTER XV.
6411: 
6412:     And doubt shall be as lead upon the feet
6413:     Of thy most anxious will.
6414: 
6415: 
6416: Mr. Lyon was careful to look in at Felix as soon as possible after
6417: Christian's departure, to tell him that his trust was discharged. During
6418: the rest of the day he was somewhat relieved from agitating reflections
6419: by the necessity of attending to his ministerial duties, the rebuke of
6420: rebellious singers being one of them; and on his return from the Monday
6421: evening prayer-meeting he was so overcome with weariness that he went to
6422: bed without taking note of any objects in his study. But when he rose
6423: the next morning, his mind, once more eagerly active, was arrested by
6424: Philip Debarry's letter, which still lay open on his desk, and was
6425: arrested by precisely that portion which had been unheeded the day
6426: before:--"_I shall consider myself doubly fortunate if at any time you
6427: can point out to me some method by which I may procure you as lively a
6428: satisfaction as I am now feeling, in that full and speedy relief from
6429: anxiety which I owe to your considerate conduct_."
6430: 
6431: To understand how these words could carry the suggestion they actually
6432: had for the minister in a crisis of peculiar personal anxiety and
6433: struggle, we must bear in mind that for many years he had walked through
6434: life with the sense of having for a space been unfaithful to what he
6435: esteemed the highest trust ever committed to man--the ministerial
6436: vocation. In a mind of any nobleness, a lapse into transgression against
6437: an object still regarded as supreme, issues in a new and purer
6438: devotedness, chastised by humility and watched over by a passionate
6439: regret. So it was with that ardent spirit which animated the little body
6440: of Rufus Lyon. Once in his life he had been blinded, defeated, hurried
6441: along by rebellious impulse; he had gone astray after his own desires,
6442: and had let the fire die out on the altar; and as the true penitent,
6443: hating his self-besotted error, asks from all coming life duty instead
6444: of joy, and service instead of ease, so Rufus was perpetually on the
6445: watch lest he should ever again postpone to some private affection a
6446: great public opportunity which to him was equivalent to a command.
6447: 
6448: Now here was an opportunity brought by a combination of that unexpected
6449: incalculable kind which might be regarded as the Divine emphasis
6450: invoking especial attention to trivial events--an opportunity of
6451: securing what Rufus Lyon had often wished for as a means of honoring
6452: truth, and exhibiting error in the character of a stammering, halting,
6453: short-breathed usurper of office and dignity. What was more exasperating
6454: to a zealous preacher, with whom copious speech was not a difficulty but
6455: a relief--who never lacked argument, but only combatants and
6456: listeners--than to reflect that there were thousands on thousands of
6457: pulpits in this kingdom, supplied with handsome sounding-boards, and
6458: occupying an advantageous position in buildings far larger than the
6459: chapel in Malthouse Yard--buildings sure to be places of resort, even as
6460: the markets were, if only from habit and interest; and that these
6461: pulpits were filled, or rather made vacuous, by men whose privileged
6462: education in the ancient centres of instruction issued in twenty
6463: minutes' formal reading of tepid exhortation or probably infirm
6464: deductions from premises based on rotten scaffolding? And it is in the
6465: nature of exasperation gradually to concentrate itself. The sincere
6466: antipathy of a dog toward cats in general, necessarily takes the form of
6467: indignant barking at the neighbor's black cat which makes daily
6468: trespass; the bark at imagined cats, though a frequent exercise of the
6469: canine mind, is yet comparatively feeble. Mr. Lyon's sarcasm was not
6470: without an edge when he dilated in general on an elaborate education for
6471: teachers which issued in the minimum of teaching, but it found a
6472: whetstone in the particular example of that bad system known as the
6473: rector of Treby Magna. There was nothing positive to be said against the
6474: Rev. Augustus Debarry; his life could not be pronounced blameworthy
6475: except for its negatives. And the good Rufus was too pure-minded not to
6476: be glad of that. He had no delight in vice as discrediting wicked
6477: opponents; he shrank from dwelling on the images of cruelty or
6478: grossness, and his indignation was habitually inspired only by those
6479: moral and intellectual mistakes which darken the soul but do not injure
6480: or degrade the temple of the body. If the rector had been a less
6481: respectable man, Rufus would have more reluctantly made him an object
6482: of antagonism; but as an incarnation of soul-destroying error,
6483: dissociated from those baser sins which have no good repute even with
6484: the worldly, it would be an argumentative luxury to get into close
6485: quarters with him, and fight with a dialectic short-sword in the eyes of
6486: the Treby world (sending also a written account thereof to the chief
