6487: organs of Dissenting opinion). Vice was essentially stupid--a deaf and
6488: eyeless monster, insusceptible to demonstration: the Spirit might work
6489: on it by unseen ways, and the unstudied sallies of sermons were often as
6490: the arrows which pierced and awakened the brutified conscience; but
6491: illuminated thought, finely divided speech, were the choicer weapons of
6492: the Divine armory, which whoso could wield must be careful not to leave
6493: idle.
6494: 
6495: Here, then, was the longed-for opportunity. Here was an engagement--an
6496: expression of a strong wish--on the part of Philip Debarry, if it were
6497: in his power, to procure a satisfaction to Rufus Lyon. How had that man
6498: of God and exemplary Independent minister, Mr. Ainsworth, of persecuted
6499: sanctity, conducted himself when a similar occasion had befallen him at
6500: Amsterdam? He had thought of nothing but the glory of the highest cause,
6501: and had converted the offer of recompense into a public debate with a
6502: Jew on the chief mysteries of the faith. Here was a model: the case was
6503: nothing short of a heavenly indication, and he, Rufus Lyon, would seize
6504: the occasion to demand a public debate with the rector on the
6505: constitution of the true Church.
6506: 
6507: What if he were inwardly torn by doubt and anxiety concerning his own
6508: private relations and the facts of his past life? That danger of
6509: absorption within the narrow bounds of self only urged him the more
6510: toward action which had a wider bearing, and might tell on the welfare
6511: of England at large. It was decided. Before the minister went down to
6512: breakfast that morning he had written the following letter to Mr. Philip
6513: Debarry:--
6514: 
6515:     SIR,--Referring to your letter of yesterday, I find the following
6516:     words: "I shall consider myself doubly fortunate if at any time you
6517:     can point out to me some method by which I may procure you as
6518:     lively a satisfaction as I am now feeling, in that full and speedy
6519:     relief from anxiety which I owe to your considerate conduct."
6520: 
6521:     I am not unaware, sir, that, in the usage of the world, there are
6522:     words of courtesy (so called) which are understood, by those
6523:     amongst whom they are current, to have no precise meaning, and to
6524:     constitute no bond of obligation. I will not now insist that this
6525:     is an abuse of language, wherein our fallible nature requires the
6526:     strictest safeguards against laxity and misapplication, for I do
6527:     not apprehend that in writing the words I have above quoted, you
6528:     were open to the reproach of using phrases which, while seeming to
6529:     carry a specific meaning, were really no more than what is called a
6530:     polite form. I believe, sir, that you used these words advisedly,
6531:     sincerely, and with an honorable intention of acting on them as a
6532:     pledge, should such action be demanded. No other supposition on my
6533:     part would correspond to the character you bear as a young man who
6534:     aspires (albeit mistakenly) to engraft the finest fruits of public
6535:     virtue on a creed and institutions, whereof the sap is composed
6536:     rather of human self-seeking than of everlasting truth.
6537: 
6538:     Wherefore I act on this my belief in the integrity of your written
6539:     word; I beg you to procure for me (as it is doubtless in your
6540:     power) that I may be allowed a public discussion with your near
6541:     relative, the rector of this parish, the Reverend Augustus Debarry,
6542:     to be held in the large room of the Free School, or in the Assembly
6543:     Room of the Marquis of Granby, these being the largest covered
6544:     spaces at our command. For I presume he would neither allow me to
6545:     speak within his church, nor would consent himself to speak within
6546:     my chapel; and the probable inclemency of the approaching season
6547:     forbids an assured expectation that we could discourse in the open
6548:     air. The subjects I desire to discuss are--first, the Constitution
6549:     of the true Church; and secondly, the bearing thereupon of the
6550:     English Reformation. Confidently expecting that you will comply
6551:     with this request, which is the sequence of your expressed desire,
6552:     I remain, sir, yours, with the respect offered to a sincere
6553:     withstander,
6554:                                                      RUFUS LYON,
6555:     Malthouse Yard.
6556: 
6557: After writing this letter, the good Rufus felt that serenity and
6558: elevation of mind which is infallibly brought by a preoccupation with
6559: the wider relations of things. Already he was beginning to sketch the
6560: course his argument might most judiciously take in the coming debate;
6561: his thoughts were running into sentences, and marking off careful
6562: exceptions in parentheses; and he had come down and seated himself at
6563: the breakfast-table quite automatically, without expectation of toast or
6564: coffee, when Esther's voice and touch recalled to him an inward debate
6565: of another kind, in which he felt himself much weaker. Again there arose
6566: before him the image of that cool, hard-eyed, worldly man, who might be
6567: this dear child's father, and one against whose rights he had himself
6568: grievously offended. Always as the image recurred to him Mr. Lyon's
6569: heart sent forth a prayer for guidance, but no definite guidance had yet
6570: made itself visible for him. It could not be guidance--it was a
6571: temptation--that said, "Let the matter rest: seek to know no more; know
6572: only what is thrust upon you." The remembrance that in his time of
6573: wandering he had wilfully remained in ignorance of facts which he might
6574: have enquired after, deepened the impression that it was now an
6575: imperative duty to seek the fullest attainable knowledge. And the
6576: enquiry might possibly issue in a blessed repose, by putting a negative
6577: on all his suspicions. But the more vividly all the circumstances became
6578: present to him, the more unfit he felt himself to set about any
6579: investigation concerning this man who called himself Maurice Christian.
6580: He could seek no confidant or helper among "the brethren"; he was
6581: obliged to admit to himself that the members of his church, with whom he
6582: hoped to go to heaven, were not easy to converse with on earth touching
6583: the deeper secrets of his experience, and were still less able to advise
6584: him as to the wisest procedure in a case of high delicacy, with a
6585: worldling who had a carefully-trimmed whisker and a fashionable costume.
6586: For the first time in his life it occurred to the minister that he
6587: should be glad of an adviser who had more worldly than spiritual
6588: experience, and that it might not be inconsistent with his principles to
6589: seek some light from one who had studied human law. But it was a thought
6590: to be paused upon, and not followed out rashly; some other guidance
6591: might intervene.
6592: 
6593: Esther noticed that her father was in a fit of abstraction, that he
6594: seemed to swallow his coffee and toast quite unconsciously, and that he
6595: vented from time to time a low guttural interjection, which was habitual
6596: with him when he was absorbed by an inward discussion. She did not
6597: disturb him by remarks, and only wondered whether anything unusual had
6598: occurred on Sunday evening. But at last she thought it needful to say,
6599: "You recollect what I told you yesterday, father?"
6600: 
6601: "Nay, child; what?" said Mr. Lyon, rousing himself.
6602: 
6603: "That Mr. Jermyn asked me if you would probably be at home this morning
6604: before one o'clock."
6605: 
6606: Esther was surprised to see her father start and change color as if he
6607: had been shaken by some sudden collision before he answered--
6608: 
6609: "Assuredly; I do not intend to move from my study after I have once been
6610: out to hand this letter to Zachary."
6611: 
6612: "Shall I tell Lyddy to take him up at once to your study if he comes? If
6613: not, I shall have to stay in my own room, because I shall be at home all
6614: this morning, and it is rather cold now to sit without a fire."
6615: 
6616: "Yes, my dear, let him come up to me; unless, indeed, he should bring a
6617: second person, which might happen, seeing that in all likelihood he is
6618: coming, as hitherto, on electioneering business. And I could not well
6619: accommodate two visitors up-stairs."
6620: 
6621: When Mr. Lyon went out to Zachary, the pew-opener, to give him a second
6622: time the commission of carrying a letter to Treby Manor, Esther gave her
6623: injunction to Lyddy that if one gentleman came he was to be shown
6624: up-stairs--if two, they were to be shown into the parlor. But she had to
6625: resolve several questions before Lyddy clearly saw what was before
6626: her--as that, "if it was the gentleman as came on Thursday in the
6627: pepper-and-salt coat, was he to be shown up-stairs? And the gentleman
6628: from the Manor yesterday as went out whistling--had Miss Esther heard
6629: about him? There seemed no end of these great folks coming to Malthouse
6630: Yard since there was talk of the election; but they might be poor lost
6631: creatures the most of 'em." Whereupon Lyddy shook her head and groaned,
6632: under an edifying despair as to the future lot of gentlemen callers.
6633: 
6634: Esther always avoided asking questions of Lyddy, who found an answer as
6635: she found a key, by pouring out a pocketful of miscellanies. But she had
6636: remarked so many indications that something had happened to cause her
6637: father unusual excitement and mental preoccupation, that she could not
6638: help connecting with them the fact of this visit from the Manor, which
6639: he had not mentioned to her.
6640: 
6641: She sat down in the dull parlor and took up her netting; for since
6642: Sunday she had felt unable to read when she was alone, being obliged, in
6643: spite of herself, to think of Felix Holt--to imagine what he would like
6644: her to be, and what sort of views he took of life so as to make it seem
6645: valuable in the absence of all elegance, luxury, gayety, or romance. Had
6646: he yet reflected that he had behaved very rudely to her on Sunday?
6647: Perhaps not. Perhaps he had dismissed her from his mind with contempt.
6648: And at that thought Esther's eyes smarted unpleasantly. She was fond of
6649: netting, because it showed to advantage both her hand and her foot; and
6650: across this image of Felix Holt's indifference and contempt there passed
6651: the vaguer image of a possible somebody who would admire her hands and
6652: feet, and delight in looking at their beauty, and long, yet not dare, to
6653: kiss them. Life would be much easier in the presence of such a love. But
6654: it was precisely this longing after her own satisfaction that Felix had
6655: reproached her with. Did he want her to be heroic? That seemed
6656: impossible without some great occasion. Her life was a heap of
6657: fragments, and so were her thoughts: some great energy was needed to
6658: bind them together. Esther was beginning to lose her complacency at her
6659: own wit and criticism; to lose the sense of superiority in an awakening
6660: need of reliance on one whose vision was wider, whose nature was purer
6661: and stronger than her own. But then, she said to herself, that "one"
6662: must be tender to her, not rude and predominating in his manners. A man
6663: with any chivalry in him could never adopt a scolding tone toward a
6664: woman--that is, toward a charming woman. But Felix had no chivalry in
6665: him. He loved lecturing and opinion too well ever to love any woman.
6666: 
6667: In this way Esther strove to see that Felix was thoroughly in the
6668: wrong--at least, if he did not come again expressly to show that he was
6669: sorry.
6670: 
6671: 
6672: 
6673: 
6674: CHAPTER XVI.
6675: 
6676:     _Trueblue._ These men have no votes. Why should I court them?
6677: 
6678:     _Grayfox._ No votes, but power.
6679: 
6680:     _Trueblue._ What! over charities?
6681: 
6682:     _Grayfox._ No, over brains: which disturbs the canvass. In a
6683:     natural state of things the average price of a vote at Paddlebrook
6684:     is nine-and-sixpence, throwing the fifty pound tenants, who cost
6685:     nothing, into the divisor. But these talking men cause an
6686:     artificial rise of prices.
6687: 
6688: 
6689: The expected important knock at the door came about twelve o'clock, and
6690: Esther could hear that there were two visitors. Immediately the parlor
6691: door was opened and the shaggy-haired, cravatless image of Felix Holt,
6692: which was just then full in the mirror of Esther's mind, was displaced
6693: by the highly-contrasted appearance of a personage whose name she
6694: guessed before Mr. Jermyn had announced it. The perfect morning costume
6695: of that day differed much from our present ideal: it was essential that
6696: a gentleman's chin should be well propped, that his collar should have a
6697: voluminous roll, that his waistcoat should imply much discrimination,
6698: and that his buttons should be arranged in a manner which would now
6699: expose him to general contempt. And it must not be forgotten that at the
6700: distant period when Treby Magna first knew the excitements of an
6701: election, there existed many other anomalies now obsolete, besides
6702: short-waisted coats and broad stiffeners.
6703: 
6704: But we have some notions of beauty and fitness which withstand the
6705: centuries; and quite irrespective of dates, it would be pronounced that
6706: at the age of thirty-four Harold Transome was a striking and handsome
6707: man. He was one of those people, as Denner remarked, to whose presence
6708: in the room you could not be indifferent; if you do not hate or dread
6709: them, you must find the touch of their hands, nay, their very shadows,
6710: agreeable.
6711: 
6712: Esther felt a pleasure quite new to her as she saw his finely-embrowned
6713: face and full bright eyes turned toward her with an air of deference by
6714: which gallantry must commend itself to a refined woman who is not
6715: absolutely free from vanity. Harold Transome regarded women as slight
6716: things, but he was fond of slight things in the intervals of business;
6717: and he held it among the chief arts of life to keep these pleasant
6718: diversions within such bounds that they should never interfere with the
6719: course of his serious ambition. Esther was perfectly aware, as he took a
6720: chair near her, that he was under some admiring surprise at her
6721: appearance and manner. How could it be otherwise? She believed that in
6722: the eyes of a well-bred man no young lady in Treby could equal her: she
6723: felt a glow of delight at the sense that she was being looked at.
6724: 
6725: "My father expected you," she said to Mr. Jermyn. "I delivered your
6726: letter to him yesterday. He will be down immediately."
6727: 
6728: She disentangled her foot from her netting and wound it up.
6729: 
6730: "I hope you are not going to let us disturb you," said Harold, noticing
6731: her action. "We come to discuss election affairs, and we particularly
6732: desire to interest the ladies."
6733: 
6734: "I have no interest with any one who is not already on the right side,"
6735: said Esther smiling.
6736: 
6737: "I am happy to see at least that you wear the Liberal colors."
6738: 
6739: "I fear I must confess that it is more from love of blue than from love
6740: of Liberalism. Yellow opinions could only have brunettes on their side."
6741: Esther spoke with her usual pretty fluency, but she had no sooner
6742: uttered the words than she thought how angry they would have made Felix.
6743: 
6744: "If my cause is to be recommended by the becomingness of my colors, then
6745: I am sure you are acting in my interest by wearing them."
6746: 
6747: Esther rose to leave the room.
6748: 
6749: "Must you really go?" said Harold, preparing to open the door for her.
6750: 
6751: "Yes, I have an engagement--a lesson at half past twelve," said Esther,
6752: bowing and floating out like a blue-robed Naïad, but not without a
6753: suffused blush as she passed through the doorway.
6754: 
6755: It was a pity the room was so small, Harold Transome thought: this girl
6756: ought to walk in a house where there were halls and corridors. But he
6757: had soon dismissed this chance preoccupation with Esther; for before the
6758: door was closed again Mr. Lyon had entered, and Harold was entirely bent
6759: on what had been the object of his visit. The minister, though no
6760: elector himself, had considerable influence over Liberal electors, and
6761: it was the part of wisdom in a candidate to cement all political
6762: adhesion by a little personal regard, if possible. Garstin was a harsh
6763: and wiry fellow; he seemed to suggest that sour whey, which some say was
6764: the original meaning of Whig in the Scottish, and it might suggest the
6765: theoretic advantages of Radicalism if it could be associated with a more
6766: generous presence. What would conciliate the personal regard of old Mr.
6767: Lyon became a curious problem to Harold, now the little man made his
6768: appearance. But canvassing makes a gentleman acquainted with many
6769: strange animals; together with the ways of catching and taming them; and
6770: thus the knowledge of natural history advances amongst the aristocracy
6771: and wealthy commoners of our land.
6772: 
6773: "I am very glad to have secured this opportunity of making your personal
6774: acquaintance, Mr. Lyon," said Harold, putting out his hand to the
6775: minister when Jermyn had mentioned his name. "I am to address the
6776: electors here, in the Market-Place, to-morrow; and I should have been
6777: sorry to do so without first paying my respects privately to my chief
6778: friends, as there may be points on which they particularly wish me to
6779: explain myself."
6780: 
6781: "You speak civilly, sir, and reasonably," said Mr. Lyon, with a vague
6782: short-sighted gaze, in which a candidate's appearance evidently went for
6783: nothing. "Pray be seated, gentlemen. It is my habit to stand."
6784: 
6785: He placed himself at a right angle with his visitors, his worn look of
6786: intellectual eagerness, slight frame, and rusty attire, making an odd
6787: contrast with their flourishing persons, unblemished costume, and
6788: comfortable freedom from excitement. The group was fairly typical of the
6789: difference between the men who are animated by ideas and the men who are
6790: expected to apply them. Then he drew forth his spectacles, and began to
6791: rub them with the thin end of his coat tail. He was inwardly exercising
6792: great self-mastery--suppressing the thought of his personal needs, which
6793: Jermyn's presence tended to suggest, in order that he might be equal to
6794: the larger duties of this occasion.
6795: 
6796: "I am aware--Mr. Jermyn has told me," said Harold, "what good service
6797: you have done me already, Mr. Lyon. The fact is, a man of intellect like
6798: you was especially needed in my case. The race I am running is really
6799: against Garstin only, who calls himself a Liberal, though he cares for
6800: nothing, and understands nothing, except the interests of the wealthy
6801: traders. And you have been able to explain the difference between
6802: Liberal and Liberal, which, as you and I know, is something like the
6803: difference between fish and fish."
6804: 
6805: "Your comparison is not unapt, sir," said Mr. Lyon, still holding his
6806: spectacles in his hand, "at this epoch, when the mind of the nation has
6807: been strained on the passing of one measure. Where a great weight has to
6808: be moved, we require not so much selected instruments as abundant
6809: horse-power. But it is an unavoidable evil of these massive achievements
6810: that they encourage a coarse undiscriminatingness obstructive of more
6811: nicely-wrought results, and an exaggerated expectation inconsistent with
6812: the intricacies of our fallen and struggling condition. I say not that
6813: compromise is unnecessary, but it is an evil attendant on our
6814: imperfection; and I would pray every one to mark that, where compromise
6815: broadens, intellect and conscience are thrust into narrower room.
6816: Wherefore it has been my object to show our people that there are many
6817: who have helped to draw the car of Reform, whose ends are but partial,
6818: and who forsake not the ungodly principle of selfish alliances, but
6819: would only substitute Syria for Egypt--thinking chiefly of their own
6820: share in peacocks, gold and ivory."
6821: 
6822: "Just so," said Harold, who was quick at new languages, and still
6823: quicker at translating other men's generalities into his own special and
6824: immediate purposes, "men who will be satisfied if they can only bring in
6825: a plutocracy, buy up the land, and stick the old crests on their new
6826: gateways. Now the practical point to secure against these false Liberals
6827: at present is, that our electors should not divide their votes. As it
6828: appears that many who vote for Debarry are likely to split their votes
6829: in favor of Garstin, it is of the first consequence that my voters
6830: should give me plumpers. If they divide their votes they can't keep out
6831: Debarry, and they may help to keep out me. I feel some confidence in
6832: asking you to use your influence in this direction, Mr. Lyon. We
6833: candidates have to praise ourselves more than is graceful; but you are
6834: aware that, while I belong by my birth to the classes that have their
6835: roots in tradition and all the old loyalties, my experience has lain
6836: chiefly among those who make their own career, and depend on the new
6837: rather than the old. I have had the advantage of considering the
6838: national welfare under varied lights: I have wider views than those of a
6839: mere cotton lord. On questions connected with religious liberty I would
6840: stop short at no measure that was not thorough."
6841: 
6842: "I hope not, sir--I hope not," said Mr. Lyon, gravely; finally putting
6843: on his spectacles and examining the face of the candidate, whom he was
6844: preparing to turn into a catechumen. For the good Rufus, conscious of
6845: his political importance as an organ of persuasion, felt it his duty to
6846: catechise a little, and also to do his part toward impressing a probable
6847: legislator with a sense of his responsibility. But the latter branch of
6848: duty somewhat obstructed the catechising, for his mind was so urged by
6849: considerations which he held in danger of being overlooked, that the
6850: questions and answers bore a very slender proportion to his exposition.
6851: It was impossible to leave the question of church-rates without noting
6852: the grounds of their injustice, and without a brief enumeration of
6853: reasons why Mr. Lyon, for his own part, would not present that passive
6854: resistance to a legal imposition which had been adopted by the Friends
6855: (whose heroism in this regard was nevertheless worthy of all honor).
6856: 
6857: Comprehensive talkers are apt to be tiresome when we are not athirst for
6858: information, but, to be quite fair, we must admit that superior
6859: reticence is a good deal due to the lack of matter. Speech is often
6860: barren; but silence also does not necessarily brood over a full nest.
6861: Your still fowl, blinking at you without remark, may all the while be
6862: sitting on one addled nest-egg; and when it takes to cackling, will have
6863: nothing to announce but that addled delusion.
6864: 
6865: Harold Transome was not at all a patient man, but in matters of business
6866: he was quite awake to his cue, and in this case it was perhaps easier to
6867: listen than to answer questions. But Jermyn, who had plenty of work on
6868: his hands, took an opportunity of rising, and saying, as he looked at
6869: his watch--
6870: 
6871: "I must really be at the office in five minutes. You will find me there,
6872: Mr. Transome; you have probably still many things to say to Mr. Lyon."
6873: 
6874: "I beseech you, sir," said the minister, changing color, and by a quick
6875: movement laying his hand on Jermyn's arm--"I beseech you to favor me
6876: with an interview on some private business--this evening, if it were
6877: possible."
6878: 
6879: Mr. Lyon, like others who are habitually occupied with impersonal
6880: subjects, was liable to this impulsive sort of action. He snatched at
6881: the details of life as if they were darting past him--as if they were
6882: like the ribbons at his knees, which would never be tied all day if they
6883: were not tied on the instant. Through these spasmodic leaps out of his
6884: abstractions into real life, it constantly happened that he suddenly
6885: took a course which had been the subject of too much doubt with him ever
6886: to have been determined on by continuous thought. And if Jermyn had not
6887: startled him by threatening to vanish just when he was plunged in
6888: politics, he might never have made up his mind to confide in a worldly
6889: attorney.
6890: 
6891: ("An odd man," as Mrs. Muscat observed, "to have such a gift in the
6892: pulpit. But there's One knows better than we do----" which, in a lady
6893: who rarely felt her judgment at a loss, was a concession that showed
6894: much piety.)
6895: 
6896: Jermyn was surprised at the little man's eagerness. "By all means," he
6897: answered, quite cordially. "Could you come to my office at eight
6898: o'clock?"
6899: 
6900: "For several reasons, I must beg you to come to me."
6901: 
6902: "Oh, very good. I'll walk out and see you this evening, if possible. I
6903: shall have much pleasure in being of any use to you." Jermyn felt that
6904: in the eyes of Harold he was appearing all the more valuable when his
6905: services were thus in request. He went out, and Mr. Lyon easily relapsed
6906: into politics, for he had been on the brink of a favorite subject on
6907: which he was at issue with his fellow-Liberals.
6908: 
6909: At that time, when faith in the efficacy of political change was at
6910: fever-heat in ardent Reformers, many measures which men are still
6911: discussing with little confidence on either side, were then talked about
6912: and disposed of like property in near reversion. Crying abuses--"bloated
6913: paupers," "bloated pluralists," and other corruptions hindering men from
6914: being wise and happy--had to be fought against and slain. Such a time is
6915: a time of hope. Afterward when the corpses of those monsters have been
6916: held up to the public wonder and abhorrence, and yet wisdom and
6917: happiness do not follow, but rather a more abundant breeding of the
6918: foolish and unhappy, comes a time of doubt and despondency. But in the
6919: great Reform-year Hope was mighty: the prospect of Reform had even
6920: served the voters instead of drink; and in one place, at least, there
6921: had been "a dry election." And now the speakers at Reform banquets were
6922: exuberant in congratulation and promise: Liberal clergymen of the
6923: Establishment toasted Liberal Catholic clergymen without any allusion to
6924: scarlet, and Catholic clergymen replied with a like tender reserve.
6925: Some dwelt on the abolition of all abuses, and on millennial blessedness
6926: generally; others, whose imaginations were less suffused with
6927: exhalations of the dawn insisted chiefly on the ballot-box.
6928: 
6929: Now on this question of the ballot the minister strongly took the
6930: negative side. Our pet opinions are usually those which place us in a
6931: minority of a minority amongst our own party:--very happily, else those
6932: poor opinions, born with no silver spoon in their mouths--how would they
6933: get nourished and fed? So it was with Mr. Lyon and his objection to the
6934: ballot. But he had thrown out a remark on the subject which was not
6935: quite clear to his hearer, who interpreted it according to his best
6936: calculation of probabilities.
6937: 
6938: "I have no objection to the ballot," said Harold, "but I think that is
6939: not the sort of thing we have to work at just now. We shouldn't get it.
6940: And other questions are imminent."
6941: 
6942: "Then, sir, you would vote for the ballot?" said Mr. Lyon, stroking his
6943: chin.
6944: 
6945: "Certainly, if the point came up. I have too much respect for the
6946: freedom of the voter to oppose anything which offers a chance of making
6947: that freedom more complete."
6948: 
6949: Mr. Lyon looked at the speaker with a pitying smile and a subdued
6950: "h'm--m--m," which Harold took for a sign of satisfaction. He was soon
6951: undeceived.
6952: 
6953: "You grieve me, sir; you grieve me much. And I pray you to reconsider
6954: this question, for it will take you to the root, as I think, of
6955: political morality. I engage to show to any impartial mind, duly
6956: furnished with the principles of public and private rectitude, that the
6957: ballot would be pernicious, and that if it were not pernicious, it would
6958: still be futile. I will show, first, that it would be futile as a
6959: preservative from bribery and illegitimate influence; and, secondly,
6960: that it would be in the worst kind pernicious, as shutting the door
6961: against those influences whereby the soul of a man and the character of
6962: a citizen are duly educated for their great functions. Be not alarmed if
6963: I detain you, sir. It is well worth the while."
6964: 
6965: "Confound this old man," thought Harold. "I'll never make a canvassing
6966: call on a preacher again, unless he has lost his voice from a cold." He
6967: was going to excuse himself as prudently as he could, by deferring the
6968: subject till the morrow, and inviting Mr. Lyon to come to him in the
6969: committee-room before the time appointed for his public speech; but he
6970: was relieved by the opening of the door. Lyddy put in her head to say--
6971: 
6972: "If you please, sir, here's Mr. Holt wants to know if he may come in and
6973: speak to the gentleman. He begs your pardon, but you're to say 'no' if
6974: you don't like him to come."
6975: 
6976: "Nay, show him in at once, Lyddy. A young man," Mr. Lyon went on,
6977: speaking to Harold, "whom a representative ought to know--no voter, but
6978: a man of ideas and study."
6979: 
6980: "He is thoroughly welcome," said Harold, truthfully enough, though he
6981: felt little interest in the voteless man of ideas except as a diversion
6982: from the subject of the ballot. He had been standing for the last minute
6983: or two, feeling less of a victim in that attitude, and more able to
6984: calculate on means of escape.
6985: 
6986: "Mr. Holt, sir," said the minister, as Felix entered, "is a young friend
6987: of mine, whose opinions on some points I hope to see altered, but who
6988: has a zeal for public justice which I trust he will never lose."
6989: 
6990: "I am glad to see Mr. Holt," said Harold, bowing. He perceived from the
6991: way in which Felix bowed to him and turned to the most distant spot in
6992: the room, that the candidate's shake of the hand would not be welcome
6993: here. "A formidable fellow," he thought, "capable of mounting a cart in
6994: the market-place to-morrow and cross-examining me, if I say anything
6995: that doesn't please him."
6996: 
6997: "Mr. Lyon," said Felix, "I have taken a liberty with you in asking to
6998: see Mr. Transome when he is engaged with you. But I have to speak to him
6999: on a matter which I shouldn't care to make public at present, and it is
7000: one on which I am sure you will back me. I heard that Mr. Transome was
7001: here, so I ventured to come. I hope you will both excuse me, as my
7002: business refers to some electioneering measures which are being taken by
7003: Mr. Transome's agents."
7004: 
7005: "Pray go on," said Harold, expecting something unpleasant.
7006: 
7007: "I'm not going to speak against treating voters," said Felix; "I suppose
7008: buttered ale, and grease of that sort to make the wheels go, belong to
7009: the necessary humbug of representation. But I wish to ask you, Mr.
7010: Transome, whether it is with your knowledge that agents of yours are
7011: bribing rough fellows who are no voters--the colliers and navvies at
7012: Sproxton--with the chance of extra drunkenness, that they may make a
7013: posse on your side at the nomination and polling?"
7014: 
7015: "Certainly not," said Harold. "You are aware, my dear sir, that a
7016: candidate is very much at the mercy of his agents as to the means by
7017: which he is returned, especially when many years' absence has made him a
7018: stranger to the men actually conducting business. But are you sure of
7019: your facts?"
7020: 
7021: "As sure as my senses can make me," said Felix, who then briefly
7022: described what had happened on Sunday. "I believed that you were
7023: ignorant of all this, Mr. Transome," he ended, "and that was why I
7024: thought some good might be done by speaking to you. If not, I should be
7025: tempted to expose the whole affair as a disgrace to the Radical party.
7026: I'm a Radical myself, and mean to work all my life long against
7027: privilege, monopoly, and oppression. But I would rather be a
7028: livery-servant proud of my master's title, than I would seem to make
7029: common cause with scoundrels who turn the best hopes of men into
7030: by-words for cant and dishonesty."
7031: 
7032: "Your energetic protest is needless here, sir," said Harold, offended at
7033: what sounded like a threat, and was certainly premature enough to be in
7034: bad taste. In fact, this error of behavior in Felix proceeded from a
7035: repulsion which was mutual. It was a constant source of irritation to
7036: him that the public men on his side were, on the whole, not
7037: conspicuously better than the public men on the other side; that the
7038: spirit of innovation, which with him was a part of religion, was in many
7039: of its mouthpieces no more of a religion than the faith in rotten
7040: boroughs; and he was thus predisposed to distrust Harold Transome.
7041: Harold, in his turn, disliked impracticable notions of loftiness and
7042: purity--disliked all enthusiasm; and he thought he saw a very
7043: troublesome, vigorous incorporation of that nonsense in Felix. But it
7044: would be foolish to exasperate him in any way.
7045: 
7046: "If you choose to accompany me to Jermyn's office," he went on, "the
7047: matter shall be enquired into in your presence. I think you will agree
7048: with me, Mr. Lyon, that this will be the most satisfactory course."
7049: 
7050: "Doubtless," said the minister, who liked the candidate very well, and
7051: believed that he would be amenable to argument; "and I would caution my
7052: young friend against a too great hastiness of words and action. David's
7053: cause against Saul was a righteous one; nevertheless not all who clave
7054: unto David were righteous men."
7055: 
7056: "The more was the pity, sir," said Felix. "Especially if he winked at
7057: their malpractices."
7058: 
7059: Mr. Lyon smiled, shook his head, and stroked his favorite's arm
7060: deprecatingly.
7061: 
7062: "It is rather too much for any man to keep the consciences of all his
7063: party," said Harold. "If you had lived in the East, as I have, you would
7064: be more tolerant, for example, of an active industrious selfishness,
7065: such as we have here, though it may not always be quite scrupulous: you
7066: would see how much better it is than an idle selfishness. I have heard
7067: it said, a bridge is a good thing--worth helping to make, though half
7068: the men who worked at it were rogues."
7069: 
7070: "Oh, yes!" said Felix, scornfully, "give me a handful of generalities
7071: and analogies, and I'll undertake to justify Burke and Hare, and prove
7072: them benefactors of their species. I'll tolerate no nuisances but such
7073: as I can't help; and the question now is, not whether we can do away
7074: with all the nuisances in the world, but with a particular nuisance
7075: under our noses."
7076: 
7077: "Then we had better cut the matter short, as I propose, by going at once
7078: to Jermyn's," said Harold. "In that case, I must bid you good-morning,
7079: Mr. Lyon."
7080: 
7081: "I would fain," said the minister, looking uneasy--"I would fain have
7082: had a further opportunity of considering that question of the ballot
7083: with you. The reasons against it need not be urged lengthily; they only
7084: require complete enumeration to prevent any seeming hiatus, where an
7085: opposing fallacy might thrust itself in."
7086: 
7087: "Never fear, sir," said Harold, shaking Mr. Lyon's hand cordially,
7088: "there will be opportunities. Shall I not see you in the committee-room
7089: to-morrow?"
7090: 
7091: "I think not," said Mr. Lyon, rubbing his brow, with a sad remembrance
7092: of his personal anxieties. "But I will send you, if you will permit me,
7093: a brief writing, on which you can meditate at your leisure."
7094: 
7095: "I shall be delighted. Good-bye."
7096: 
7097: Harold and Felix went out together; and the minister, going up to his
7098: dull study, asked himself whether, under the pressure of conflicting
7099: experience, he had faithfully discharged the duties of the past
7100: interview?
7101: 
7102: If a cynical sprite were present, riding on one of the motes in that
7103: dusty room, he may have made himself merry at the illusions of the
7104: little minister who brought so much conscience to bear on the production
7105: of so slight an effect. I confess to smiling myself, being sceptical as
7106: to the effect of ardent appeals and nice distinctions on gentlemen who
7107: are got up, both inside and out, as candidates in the style of the
7108: period; but I never smiled at Mr. Lyon's trustful energy without falling
7109: to penitence and veneration immediately after. For what we call
7110: illusions are often, in truth, a wider vision of past and recent
7111: realities--a willing movement of a man's soul with the larger sweep of
7112: the world's forces--a movement toward a more assured end than the
7113: chances of a single life. We see human heroism broken into units and
7114: say, this unit did little--might as well not have been. But in this way
7115: we might break up a great army into units; in this way we might break
7116: the sunlight into fragments, and think that this and the other might be
7117: cheaply parted with. Let us rather raise a monument to the soldiers
7118: whose brave hearts only kept the ranks unbroken and met death--a
7119: monument to the faithful who were not famous, and who are precious as
7120: the continuity of the sunbeams is precious, though some of them fall
7121: unseen and on barrenness.
7122: 
7123: At present, looking back on that day at Treby, it seem to me that the
7124: sadder illusion lay with Harold Transome, who was trusting in his own
7125: skill to shape the success of his own morrows, ignorant of what many
7126: yesterdays had determined for him beforehand.
7127: 
7128: 
7129: 
7130: 
7131: CHAPTER XVII.
7132: 
7133:     It is a good and soothfast saw;
7134:     Half-roasted never will be raw;
7135:     No dough is dried once more to meal,
7136:     No crock new-shapen by the wheel;
7137:     You can't turn curds to milk again,
7138:     Nor Now, by wishing, back to Then;
7139:     And having tasted stolen honey,
7140:     You can't buy innocence for money.
7141: 
7142: 
7143: Jermyn was not particularly pleased that some chance had apparently
7144: hindered Harold Transome from making other canvassing visits immediately
7145: after leaving Mr. Lyon, and so had sent him back to the office earlier
7146: than he had been expected to come. The inconvenient chance he guessed at
7147: once to be represented by Felix Holt, whom he knew very well by Trebian
7148: report to be a young man with so little of the ordinary Christian
7149: motives as to making an appearance and getting on in the world, that he
7150: presented no handle to any judicious and respectable person who might be
7151: willing to make use of him.
7152: 
7153: Harold Transome, on his side, was a great deal annoyed at being worried
7154: by Felix in an enquiry about electioneering details. The real dignity
7155: and honesty there was in him made him shrink from this necessity of
7156: satisfying a man with a troublesome tongue; it was as if he were to show
7157: indignation at the discovery of one barrel with a false bottom, when he
7158: had invested his money in a manufactory where a larger or smaller
7159: number of such barrels had always been made. A practical man must seek a
7160: good end by the only possible means; that is to say, if he is to get
7161: into Parliament he must not be too particular. It was not disgraceful to
7162: be neither a Quixote nor a theorist, aiming to correct the moral rules
7163: of the world: but whatever actually was, or might prove to be,
7164: disgraceful, Harold held in detestation. In this mood he pushed on
7165: unceremoniously to the inner office without waiting to ask questions;
7166: and when he perceived that Jermyn was not alone he said, with haughty
7167: quickness--
7168: 
7169: "A question about the electioneering at Sproxton. Can you give your
7170: attention to it at once? Here is Mr. Holt, who has come to me about the
7171: business."
7172: 
7173: "A--yes--a--certainly," said Jermyn, who, as usual, was the more cool
7174: and deliberate because he was vexed. He was standing, and, as he turned
7175: round, his broad figure concealed the person who was seated writing at
7176: the bureau. "Mr. Holt--a--will doubtless--a--make a point of saving a
7177: busy man's time. You can speak at once. This gentleman"--here Jermyn
7178: made a slight backward movement of the head--"is one of ourselves; he is
7179: a true-blue."
7180: 
7181: "I have simply to complain," said Felix, "that one of your agents has
7182: been sent on a bribing expedition to Sproxton--with what purpose you,
7183: sir, may know better than I do. Mr. Transome, it appears, was ignorant
7184: of the affair, and does not approve it."
7185: 
7186: Jermyn, looking gravely and steadily at Felix while he was speaking, at
7187: the same time drew forth a small sheaf of papers from his side pocket,
7188: and then, as he turned his eyes slowly on Harold, felt in his
7189: waistcoat-pocket for his pencil-case.
7190: 
7191: "I don't approve of it at all," said Harold, who hated Jermyn's
7192: calculated slowness and conceit in his own impenetrability. "Be good
7193: enough to put a stop to it, will you?"
7194: 
7195: "Mr. Holt, I know, is an excellent Liberal," said Jermyn, just inclining
7196: his head to Harold, and then alternately looking at Felix and docketing
7197: his bills; "but he is perhaps too inexperienced to be aware that no
7198: canvass--a--can be conducted without the action of able men, who
7199: must--a--be trusted, and not interfered with. And as to any possibility
7200: of promising to put a stop--a--to any procedure--a--that depends. If he
7201: had ever held the coachman's ribbons in his hands, as I have in my
7202: younger days--a--he would know that stopping is not always easy."
7203: 
7204: "I know very little about holding ribbons," said Felix; "but I saw
7205: clearly enough at once that more mischief had been done than could be
7206: well mended. Though I believe, if it were heartily tried, the treatment
7207: might be reduced and something might be done to hinder the men from
7208: turning out in a body to make a noise, which might end in worse."
7209: 
7210: "They might be hindered from making a noise on our side," said Jermyn,
7211: smiling. "That is perfectly true. But if they made a noise on the
7212: other--would your purpose be answered better, sir?"
7213: 
7214: Harold was moving about in an irritated manner while Felix and Jermyn
7215: were speaking. He preferred leaving the talk to the attorney, of whose
7216: talk he himself liked to keep as clear as possible.
7217: 
7218: "I can only say," answered Felix, "that if you make use of those heavy
7219: fellows when the drink is in them, I shouldn't like your responsibility.
7220: You might as well drive bulls to roar on our side as bribe a set of
7221: colliers and navvies to shout and groan."
7222: 
7223: "A lawyer may well envy your command of language, Mr. Holt," said
7224: Jermyn, pocketing his bills again, and shutting up his pencil; "but he
7225: would not be satisfied with the accuracy--a--of your terms. You must
7226: permit me to check your use of the word 'bribery.' The essence of
7227: bribery is, that it should be legally proved; there is not such a
7228: thing--a--_in rerum natura_--a--as unproved bribery. There has been no
7229: such thing as bribery at Sproxton, I'll answer for it. The presence of a
7230: body of stalwart fellows on--a--the Liberal side will tend to preserve
7231: order; for we know that the benefit clubs from the Pitchley district
7232: will show for Debarry. Indeed, the gentleman who has conducted the
7233: canvass at Sproxton is experienced in Parliamentary affairs, and would
7234: not exceed--a--the necessary measures that a rational judgment would
7235: dictate."
7236: 
7237: "What! you mean the man who calls himself Johnson?" said Felix, in a
7238: tone of disgust.
7239: 
7240: Before Jermyn chose to answer, Harold broke in, saying, quickly and
7241: peremptorily, "The long and short of it is this, Mr. Holt: I shall
7242: desire and insist that whatever can be done by way of remedy shall be
7243: done. Will that satisfy you? You see now some of the candidate's
7244: difficulties?" said Harold, breaking into his most agreeable smile. "I
7245: hope you will have some pity for me."
7246: 
7247: "I suppose I must be content," said Felix, not thoroughly propitiated.
7248: "I bid you good-morning, gentlemen."
7249: 
7250: When he was gone out, and had closed the door behind him, Harold,
7251: turning round and flashing, in spite of himself, an angry look at
7252: Jermyn, said--
7253: 
7254: "And who is Johnson? an _alias_, I suppose. It seems you are fond of the
7255: name."
7256: 
7257: Jermyn turned perceptibly paler, but disagreeables of this sort between
7258: himself and Harold had been too much in his anticipations of late for
7259: him to be taken by surprise. He turned quietly round and just touched
7260: the shoulder of the person seated at the bureau, who now rose.
7261: 
7262: "On the contrary," Jermyn answered, "the Johnson in question is this
7263: gentleman, whom I have the pleasure of introducing to you as one of my
7264: most active helpmates in electioneering business--Mr. Johnson, of
7265: Bedford Row, London. I am comparatively a novice--a--in these matters.
7266: But he was engaged with James Putty in two hardly-contested elections,
7267: and there could scarcely be a better initiation. Putty is one of the
7268: first men of the country as an agent--a--on the Liberal side--a--eh,
7269: Johnson? I think Makepiece is--a--not altogether a match for him, not
7270: quite of the same calibre--a--_haud consimili ingenio_--a--in
7271: tactics--a--and in experience?"
7272: 
7273: "Makepiece is a wonderful man, and so is Putty," said the glib Johnson,
7274: too vain not to be pleased with an opportunity of speaking, even when
7275: the situation was rather awkward. "Makepiece for scheming, but Putty for
7276: management. Putty knows men, sir," he went on, turning to Harold: "it's
7277: a thousand pities that you have not had his talents employed in your
7278: service. He's beyond any man for saving a candidate's money--does half
7279: the work with his tongue. He'll talk of anything, from the Areopagus,
7280: and that sort of thing, down to the joke about 'Where are you going,
7281: Paddy?'--you know what I mean, sir! 'Back again, says Paddy'--an
7282: excellent electioneering joke. Putty understands these things. He has
7283: said to me, 'Johnson, bear in mind there are two ways of speaking an
7284: audience will always like: one is to tell them what they don't
7285: understand; and the other is, to tell them what they're used to.' I
7286: shall never be the man to deny that I owe a great deal to Putty. I
7287: always say it was a most providential thing in the Mugham election last
7288: year that Putty was not on the Tory side. He managed the women; and, if
7289: you'll believe me, sir, one-fourth of the men would never have voted if
7290: their wives hadn't driven them to it for the good of their families. And
7291: as for speaking--it's currently reported in our London circles that
7292: Putty writes regularly for the _Times_. He has that kind of language;
7293: and I needn't tell you, Mr. Transome, that it's the apex, which, I take
7294: it, means the tiptop--and nobody can get higher than that, I think. I've
7295: belonged to a political debating society myself; I've heard a little
7296: language in my time; but when Mr. Jermyn first spoke to me about having
7297: the honor to assist in your canvass of North Loamshire"--here Johnson
7298: played with his watch-seals and balanced himself a moment on his
7299: toes--"the very first thing I said was, 'And there's Garstin has got
7300: Putty! No Whig could stand against a Whig,' I said, 'who had Putty on
7301: his side: I hope Mr. Transome goes in for something of a deeper color.'
7302: I don't say that, as a general rule, opinions go for much in a return,
7303: Mr. Transome; it depends on who are in the field before you, and on the
7304: skill of your agents. But as a Radical, and a moneyed Radical, you are
7305: in a fine position, sir; and with care and judgment--with care and
7306: judgment----"
7307: 
7308: It had been impossible to interrupt Johnson before, without the most
7309: impolitic rudeness. Jermyn was not sorry that he should talk, even if he
7310: made a fool of himself; for in that solid shape, exhibiting the average
7311: amount of human foibles, he seemed less of the _alias_ which Harold had
7312: insinuated him to be, and had all the additional plausibility of a lie
7313: with a circumstance.
7314: 
7315: Harold had thrown himself with contemptuous resignation into a chair,
7316: had drawn off one of his buff gloves, and was looking at his hand. But
7317: when Johnson gave his iteration with a slightly slackened pace, Harold
7318: looked up at him and broke in--
7319: 
7320: "Well then, Mr. Johnson, I shall be glad if you will use your care and
7321: judgment in putting an end, as well as you can, to this Sproxton affair;
7322: else it may turn out an ugly business."
7323: 
7324: "Excuse me, sir; I must beg you to look at the matter a little more
7325: closely. You will see that it is impossible to take a single step
7326: backward at Sproxton. It was a matter of necessity to get the Sproxton
7327: men; else I know to a certainty the other side would have laid hold of
7328: them first, and now I've undermined Garstin's people. They'll use their
7329: authority, and give a little shabby treating, but I've taken all the
7330: wind out of their sails. But if, by your orders, I or Mr. Jermyn here
7331: were to break promise with the honest fellows, and offend Chubb the
7332: publican, what would come of it? Chubb would leave no stone unturned
7333: against you, sir; he would egg on his customers against you; the
7334: colliers and navvies would be at the nomination and the election all the
7335: same, or rather not all the same, for they would be there against us;
7336: and instead of hustling people good-humoredly by way of a joke, and
7337: counterbalancing Debarry's cheers, they'd help to kick the cheering and
7338: voting out of our men, and instead of being, let us say, half-a-dozen
7339: ahead of Garstin, you'd be half-a-dozen behind him, that's all. I speak
7340: plain English to you, Mr. Transome, though I've the highest respect for
7341: you as a gentleman of first-rate talents and position. But, sir, to
7342: judge of these things a man must know the English voter and the English
7343: publican; and it would be a poor tale indeed"--here Mr. Johnson's mouth
7344: took an expression at once bitter and pathetic--"that a gentleman like
7345: you, to say nothing of the good of the country, should have gone to the
7346: expense and trouble of a canvass for nothing but to find himself out of
7347: Parliament at the end of it. I've seen it again and again; it looks bad
7348: in the cleverest man to have to sing small."
7349: 
7350: Mr. Johnson's argument was not the less stringent because his idioms
7351: were vulgar. It requires a conviction and resolution amounting to
7352: heroism not to wince at phrases that class our foreshadowed endurance
7353: among those common and ignominious troubles which the world is more
7354: likely to sneer at than to pity. Harold remained a few minutes in angry
7355: silence looking at the floor, with one hand on his knee and the other on
7356: his hat, as if he were preparing to start up.
7357: 
7358: "As to undoing anything that's been done down there," said Johnson,
7359: throwing in this observation as something into the bargain, "I must wash
7360: my hands of it, sir. I couldn't work knowingly against your interest.
7361: And that young man who is just gone out,--you don't believe that he need
7362: be listened to, I hope? Chubb, the publican, hates him. Chubb would
7363: guess he was at the bottom of your having the treating stopped, and he'd
7364: set half-a-dozen of the colliers to duck him in the canal, or break his
7365: head by mistake. I'm an experienced man, sir. I hope I've put it clear
7366: enough."
7367: 
7368: "Certainly, the exposition befits the subject," said Harold, scornfully,
7369: his dislike of the man Johnson's personality being stimulated by causes
7370: which Jermyn more than conjectured. "It's a damned, unpleasant, ravelled
7371: business that you and Mr. Jermyn have knit up between you. I've no more
7372: to say."
7373: 
7374: "Then, sir, if you've no more commands, I don't wish to intrude. I shall
7375: wish you good-morning, sir," said Johnson, passing out quickly.
7376: 
7377: Harold knew that he was indulging his temper, and he would probably have
7378: restrained it as a foolish move if he had thought there was great danger
7379: in it. But he was beginning to drop much of his caution and self-mastery
7380: where Jermyn was concerned, under the growing conviction that the
7381: attorney had very strong reasons for being afraid of him; reasons which
7382: would only be reinforced by any action hostile to the Transome interest.
7383: As for a sneak like this Johnson, a gentleman had to pay him, not to
7384: please him. Harold had smiles at command in the right place, but he was
7385: not going to smile when it was neither necessary nor agreeable. He was
7386: one of those good-humored, yet energetic men, who have the gift of
7387: anger, hatred, and scorn upon occasion, though they are too healthy and
7388: self-contented for such feelings to get generated in them without
7389: external occasion. And in relation to Jermyn the gift was coming into
7390: fine exercise.
7391: 
7392: "A--pardon me, Mr. Harold," said Jermyn, speaking as soon as Johnson
7393: went out, "but I am sorry--a--you should behave disobligingly to a man
7394: who has it in his power to do much service--who, in fact, holds many
7395: threads in his hands. I admit that--a--_nemo mortalium omnibus horis
7396: sapit_, as we say--a----"
7397: 
7398: "Speak for yourself," said Harold. "I don't talk in tags of Latin, which
7399: might be learned by a school-master's foot-boy. I find the King's
7400: English expresses my meaning better."
7401: 
7402: "In the King's English, then," said Jermyn, who could be idiomatic
7403: enough when he was stung, "a candidate should keep his kicks till he's a
7404: member."
7405: 
7406: "Oh, I suppose Johnson will bear a kick if you bid him. You're his
7407: principal, I believe."
7408: 
7409: "Certainly, thus far--a--he is my London agent. But he is a man of
7410: substance, and----"
7411: 
7412: "I shall know what he is if it's necessary, I dare say. But I must jump
7413: into the carriage again. I've no time to lose; I must go to Hawkins at
7414: the factory. Will you go?"
7415: 
7416: When Harold was gone, Jermyn's handsome face gathered blackness. He
7417: hardly ever wore his worst expression in the presence of others, and but
7418: seldom when he was alone, for he was not given to believe that any game
7419: would ultimately go against him. His luck had been good. New conditions
7420: might always turn up to give him new chances; and if affairs threatened
7421: to come to an extremity between Harold and himself, he trusted to
7422: finding some sure resource.
7423: 
7424: "He means to see to the bottom of everything if he can, that's quite
7425: plain," said Jermyn to himself. "I believe he has been getting another
7426: opinion; he has some new light about those annuities on the estate that
7427: are held in Johnson's name. He has inherited a deuced faculty for
7428: business--there's no denying that. But I shall beg leave to tell him
7429: that I've propped up the family. I don't know where they would have been
7430: without me; and if it comes to balancing, I know into which scale the
7431: gratitude ought to go. Not that he's likely to feel any--but he can feel
7432: something else; and if he makes signs of setting the dogs on me, I shall
7433: make him feel it. The people named Transome owe me a good deal more than
7434: I owe them."
7435: 
7436: In this way Mr. Jermyn inwardly appealed against an unjust construction
7437: which he foresaw that his old acquaintance the law might put on certain
7438: items in his history.
7439: 
7440: I have known persons who have been suspected of under-valuing gratitude,
7441: and excluding it from the list of virtues; but on closer observation it
7442: has been seen that, if they have never felt grateful, it has been for
7443: want of an opportunity; and that, far from despising gratitude, they
7444: regard it as the virtue most of all incumbent--on others toward them.
7445: 
7446: 
7447: 
7448: 
7449: CHAPTER XVIII.
7450: 
7451:     The little, nameless, unremembered acts
7452:     Of kindness and of love.
7453: 
7454:                                   --WORDSWORTH: _Tintern Abbey_.
7455: 
7456: 
7457: Jermyn did not forget to pay his visit to the minister in Malthouse Yard
7458: that evening. The mingled irritation, dread and defiance which he was
7459: feeling toward Harold Transome in the middle of the day depended on too
7460: many and far-stretching causes to be dissipated by eight o'clock; but
7461: when he left Mr. Lyon's house he was in a state of comparative triumph
7462: in the belief that he, and he alone, was now in possession of facts
7463: which, once grouped together, made a secret that gave him new power over
7464: Harold.
7465: 
7466: Mr. Lyon, in his need for help from one who had that wisdom of the
7467: serpent which, he argued, is not forbidden, but is only of hard
7468: acquirement to dovelike innocence, had been gradually led to pour out to
7469: the attorney all the reasons which made him desire to know the truth
7470: about the man who called himself Maurice Christian: he had shown all the
7471: precious relics, the locket, the letters, and the marriage certificate.
7472: And Jermyn had comforted him by confidently promising to ascertain,
7473: without scandal or premature betrayals, whether this man were really
7474: Annette's husband, or Maurice Christian Bycliffe.
7475: 
7476: Jermyn was not rash in making this promise, since he had excellent
7477: reasons for believing that he had already come to a true conclusion on
7478: the subject. But he wished both to know a little more of this man
7479: himself, and to keep Mr. Lyon in ignorance--not a difficult
7480: precaution--in an affair which it cost the minister so much pain to
7481: speak of. An easy opportunity of getting an interview with Christian was
7482: sure to offer itself before long--might even offer itself to-morrow.
7483: Jermyn had seen him more than once, though hitherto without any reason
7484: for observing him with interest; he had heard that Philip Debarry's
7485: courier was often busy in the town, and it seemed specially likely that
7486: he would be seen there when the market was to be agitated by politics,
7487: and the new candidate was to show his paces.
7488: 
7489: The world of which Treby Magna was the centre was, naturally, curious to
7490: see the young Transome, who had come from the East, was as rich as a
7491: Jew, and called himself a Radical--characteristics all equally vague in
7492: the minds of various excellent ratepayers, who drove to market in their
7493: taxed carts or in their hereditary gigs. Places at convenient windows
7494: had been secured beforehand for a few best bonnets; but, in general, a
7495: Radical candidate excited no ardent feminine partisanship, even among
7496: the Dissenters in Treby, if they were of the prosperous and
7497: long-resident class. Some chapel-going ladies were fond of remembering
7498: that "their family had been Church"; others objected to politics
7499: altogether as having spoiled old neighborliness, and sundered friends
7500: who had kindred views as to cowslip wine and Michaelmas cleaning;
7501: others, of the melancholy sort, said it would be well if people would
7502: think less of reforming Parliament and more of pleasing God.
7503: Irreproachable Dissenting matrons, like Mrs. Muscat, whose youth had
7504: been passed in a short-waisted bodice and tight skirt, had never been
7505: animated by the struggle for liberty, and had a timid suspicion that
7506: religion was desecrated by being applied to the things of this world.
7507: Since Mr. Lyon had been in Malthouse Yard there had been far too much
7508: mixing up of politics with religion; but, at any rate, these ladies had
7509: never yet been to hear speechifying in the market-place, and they were
7510: not going to begin that practice.
7511: 
7512: Esther, however, had heard some of her feminine acquaintances say that
7513: they intended to sit at the druggist's upper window, and she was
7514: inclined to ask her father if he could think of a suitable place where
7515: she also might see and hear. Two inconsistent motives urged her. She
7516: knew that Felix cared earnestly for public questions, and she supposed
7517: that he held it one of her deficiencies not to care about them: well,
7518: she would try to learn the secret of this ardor, which was so strong in
7519: him that it animated what she thought the dullest form of life. She was
7520: not too stupid to find it out. But this self-correcting motive was
7521: presently displaced by a motive of a different sort. It had been a
7522: pleasant variety in her monotonous days to see a man like Harold
7523: Transome, with a distinguished appearance and polished manners, and she
7524: would like to see him again: he suggested to her that brighter and more
7525: luxurious life on which her imagination dwelt without the painful effort
7526: it required to conceive the mental condition which would place her in
7527: complete sympathy with Felix Holt. It was this less unaccustomed
7528: prompting of which she was chiefly conscious when she awaited her
7529: father's coming down to breakfast. Why, indeed, should she trouble
7530: herself so much about Felix?
7531: 
7532: Mr. Lyon, more serene now that he had unbosomed his anxieties and
7533: obtained a promise of help, was already swimming so happily in the deep
7534: water of polemics in expectation of Philip Debarry's answer to his
7535: challenge, that, in the occupation of making a few notes lest certain
7536: felicitous inspirations should be wasted, he had forgotten to come down
7537: to breakfast. Esther, suspecting his abstraction, went up to his study,
7538: and found him at his desk looking up with wonder at her interruption.
7539: 
7540: "Come, father, you have forgotten your breakfast."
7541: 
7542: "It is true, child, I will come," he said, lingering to make some final
7543: strokes.
7544: 
7545: "Oh, you naughty father!" said Esther, as he got up from his chair,
7546: "your coat-collar is twisted, your waistcoat is buttoned all wrong, and
7547: you have not brushed your hair. Sit down and let me brush it again as I
7548: did yesterday."
7549: 
7550: He sat down obediently, while Esther took a towel, which she threw over
7551: his shoulders, and then brushed the thick, long fringe of soft auburn
7552: hair. This very trifling act, which she had brought herself to for the
7553: first time yesterday, meant a great deal in Esther's little history. It
7554: had been her habit to leave the mending of her father's clothes to
7555: Lyddy; she had not liked even to touch his cloth garments; still less
7556: had it seemed a thing she would willingly undertake to correct his
7557: toilette, and use a brush for him. But having once done this, under her
7558: new sense of faulty omission, the affectionateness that was in her
7559: flowed so pleasantly, as she saw how much her father was moved by what
7560: he thought a great act of tenderness, that she quite longed to repeat
7561: it. This morning, as he sat under her hands, his face had such a calm
7562: delight in it that she could not help kissing the top of his bald head;
7563: and afterward, when they were seated at breakfast, she said, merrily--
7564: 
7565: "Father, I shall make a _petit maître_ of you by-and-by; your hair looks
7566: so pretty and silken when it is well brushed."
7567: 
7568: "Nay, child, I trust that while I would willingly depart from my evil
7569: habit of a somewhat slovenly forgetfulness in my attire, I shall never
7570: arrive at the opposite extreme. For though there is that in apparel
7571: which pleases the eye, and I deny not that your neat gown and the color
7572: thereof--which is that of certain little flowers that spread themselves
7573: in the hedgerows, and make a blueness there as of the sky when it is
7574: deepened in the water--I deny not, I say, that these minor strivings
7575: after a perfection which is, as it were, an irrecoverable yet haunting
7576: memory, are a good in their proportion. Nevertheless, the brevity of our
7577: life, and the hurry and crush of the great battle with error and sin,
7578: often oblige us to an advised neglect of what is less momentous. This, I
7579: conceive, is the principle on which my friend Felix Holt acts; and I
7580: cannot but think the light comes from the true fount, though it shines
7581: through obstructions."
7582: 
7583: "You have not seen Mr. Holt since Sunday, have you, father?"
7584: 
7585: "Yes, he was here yesterday. He sought Mr. Transome, having a matter of
7586: some importance to speak upon with him. And I saw him afterward in the
7587: street, when he agreed that I should call for him this morning before I
7588: go into the market-place. He will have it," Mr. Lyon went on, smiling,
7589: "that I must not walk about in the crowd without him to act as my
7590: special constable."
7591: 
7592: Esther felt vexed with herself that her heart was suddenly beating with
7593: unusual quickness, and that her last resolution not to trouble herself
7594: about what Felix thought had transformed itself with magic swiftness
7595: into mortification that he evidently avoided coming to the house when
7596: she was there, though he used to come on the slightest occasion. He knew
7597: that she was always at home until the afternoon on market-days: that was
7598: the reason why he would not call for her father. Of course it was
7599: because he attributed such littleness to her that he supposed she would
7600: retain nothing else than a feeling of offence toward him for what he had
7601: said to her. Such distrust of any good in others, such arrogance of
7602: immeasurable superiority, was extremely ungenerous. But presently she
7603: said--
7604: 
7605: "I should have liked to hear Mr. Transome speak, but I suppose it is too
7606: late to get a place now."
7607: 
7608: "I am not sure, I would fain have you go if you desire it, my dear,"
7609: said Mr. Lyon, who could not bear to deny Esther any lawful wish. "Walk
7610: with me to Mrs. Holt's, and we will learn from Felix, who will doubtless
7611: already have been out, whether or not he could lead you in safety to
7612: Friend Lambert's."
7613: 
7614: Esther was glad of the proposal, because, if it answered no other
7615: purpose, it would be an easy way of obliging Felix to see her, and of
7616: showing him that it was not she who cherished offence. But when, later
7617: in the morning, she was walking toward Mrs. Holt's with her father, they
7618: met Mr. Jermyn, who stopped them to ask, in his most affable manner,
7619: whether Miss Lyon intended to hear the candidate, and whether she had
7620: secured a suitable place. And he ended by insisting that his daughters,
7621: who were presently coming in an open carriage, should call for her if
7622: she would permit them. It was impossible to refuse this civility, and
7623: Esther turned back to await the carriage, pleased with the certainty of
7624: hearing and seeing, yet sorry to miss Felix. There was another day for
7625: her to think of him with unsatisfied resentment, mixed with some
7626: longings for a better understanding: and in our spring-time every day
7627: has its hidden growths in the mind, as it has in the earth when the
7628: little folded blades are getting ready to pierce the ground.
7629: 
7630: 
7631: 
7632: 
7633: CHAPTER XIX.
7634: 
7635:     Consistency?--I never changed my mind,
7636:     Which is, and always was, to live at ease.
7637: 
7638: 
7639: It was only in the time of summer fairs that the market-place had ever
7640: looked more animated than it did under that autumn midday sun. There
7641: were plenty of blue cockades and streamers, faces at all the windows,
7642: and a crushing buzzing crowd, urging each other backward and forward
7643: round the small hustings in front of the Ram Inn, which showed its more
7644: plebeian sign at right angles with the venerable Marquis of Granby.
7645: Sometimes there were scornful shouts, sometimes a rolling cascade of
7646: cheers, sometimes the shriek of a penny whistle; but above all these
7647: fitful and feeble sounds, the fine old church-tower, which looked down
7648: from above the trees on the other side of the narrow stream, sent
7649: vibrating, at every quarter, the sonorous tones of its great bell, the
7650: Good Queen Bess.
7651: 
7652: Two carriages, with blue ribbons on the harness, were conspicuous near
7653: the hustings. One was Jermyn's, filled with the brilliantly-attired
7654: daughters, accompanied by Esther, whose quieter dress helped to mark her
7655: out for attention as the most striking of the group. The other was
7656: Harold Transome's; but in this there was no lady--only the olive-skinned
7657: Dominic, whose acute yet mild face was brightened by the occupation of
7658: amusing little Harry and rescuing from his tyrannies a King Charles
7659: puppy, with big eyes, much after the pattern of the boy's.
7660: 
7661: This Trebian crowd did not count for much in the political force of the
7662: nation, but it was not the less determined as to lending or not lending
7663: its ears. No man was permitted to speak from the platform except Harold
7664: and his uncle Lingon, though, in the interval of expectation, several
7665: Liberals had come forward. Among these ill-advised persons the one whose
7666: attempt met the most emphatic resistance was Rufus Lyon. This might have
7667: been taken for resentment at the unreasonableness of the cloth, that,
7668: not content with pulpits, from whence to tyrannize over the ears of men,
7669: wishes to have the larger share of the platforms; but it was not so, for
7670: Mr. Lingon was heard with much cheering, and would have been welcomed
7671: again.
7672: 
7673: The rector of Little Treby had been a favorite in the neighborhood since
7674: the beginning of the century. A clergyman thoroughly unclerical in his
7675: habits had a piquancy about him which made him a sort of practical joke.
7676: He had always been called Jack Lingon, or Parson Jack--sometimes, in
7677: older and less serious days, even "Cock-fighting Jack." He swore a
7678: little when the point of a joke seemed to demand it, and was fond of
7679: wearing a colored bandana tied loosely over his cravat, together with
7680: large brown leather leggings; he spoke in a pithy familiar way that
7681: people could understand, and had none of that frigid mincingness called
7682: dignity, which some have thought a peculiar clerical disease. In fact,
7683: he was "a charicter--" something cheerful to think of, not entirely out
7684: of connection with Sunday and sermons. And it seemed in keeping that he
7685: should have turned sharp round in politics, his opinions being only
7686: part of the excellent joke called Parson Jack. When his red eagle face
7687: and white hair were seen on the platform, the Dissenters hardly cheered
7688: this questionable Radical; but to make amends, all the Tory farmers gave
7689: him a friendly "hurray." "Let's hear what old Jack will say for
7690: himself," was the predominant feeling among them; "he'll have something
7691: funny to say, I'll bet a penny."
7692: 
7693: It was only Lawyer Labron's young clerks and their hangers-on who were
7694: sufficiently dead to Trebian traditions to assail the parson with
7695: various sharp-edged interjections, such as broken shells, and cries of
7696: "Cock-a-doodle-doo."
7697: 
7698: "Come now, my lads," he began, in his full, pompous, yet jovial tones,
7699: thrusting his hands into the stuffed-out pockets of his greatcoat, "I'll
7700: tell you what; I'm a parson you know; I ought to return good for evil.
7701: So here are some good nuts for you to crack in return for your shells."
7702: 
7703: There was a roar of laughter and cheering as he threw handfuls of nuts
7704: and filberts among the crowd.
7705: 
7706: "Come now, you'll say I used to be a Tory; and some of you, whose faces
7707: I know as well as I know the head of my own crab-stick, will say that's
7708: why I'm a good fellow. But now I'll tell you something else. It's for
7709: that very reason--that I used to be a Tory, and am a good fellow--that I
7710: go along with my nephew here, who is a thorough-going Liberal. For will
7711: anybody here come forward and say, 'A good fellow has no need to tack
7712: about and change his road?' No, there's not one of you such a Tom-noddy.
7713: What's good for one time is bad for another. If anybody contradicts
7714: that, ask him to eat pickled pork when he's thirsty, and to bathe in the
7715: Lapp there when the spikes of ice are shooting. And that's the reason
7716: why the men who are the best Liberals now are the very men who used to
7717: be the best Tories. There isn't a nastier horse than your horse that'll
7718: jib and back and turn round when there is but one road for him to go,
7719: and that's the road before him.
7720: 
7721: "And my nephew here--he comes of a Tory breed, you know--I'll answer for
7722: the Lingons. In the old Tory times there was never a pup belonged to a
7723: Lingon but would howl if a Whig came near him. The Lingon blood is good,
7724: rich old Tory blood--like good rich milk--and that's why, when the right
7725: time comes, it throws up a liberal cream. The best sort of Tory turns to
7726: the best sort of Radical. There's plenty of Radical scum--I say, beware
7727: of the scum, and look but for the cream. And here's my nephew--some of
7728: the cream, if there is any: none of your Whigs, none of your painted
7729: water that looks as if it ran, and it's standing still all the while;
7730: none of your spinning-jenny fellows. A gentleman; but up to all sorts of
7731: business. I'm no fool myself; I'm forced to wink a good deal, for fear
7732: of seeing too much, for a neighborly man must let himself be cheated a
7733: little. But though I've never been out of my own country, I know less
7734: about it than my nephew does. You may tell what he is, and only look at
7735: him. There's one sort of fellow sees nothing but the end of his own
7736: nose, and another sort that sees nothing but the hinder side of the
7737: moon; but my nephew Harold is of another sort; he sees everything that's
7738: at hitting distance, and he's not one to miss his mark. A good-looking
7739: man in his prime! Not a greenhorn; not a shrivelled old fellow, who'll
7740: come to speak to you and find he's left his teeth at home by mistake.
7741: Harold Transome will do you credit; if anybody says the Radicals are a
7742: set of sneaks, Brummagem half-pennies, scamps who want to play
7743: pitch-and-toss with the property of the country, you can say, 'Look at
7744: the member for North Loamshire!' And mind what you'll hear him say;
7745: he'll go in for making everything right--Poor-laws and Charities and
7746: Church--he wants to reform 'em all. Perhaps you'll say, 'There's that
7747: Parson Lingon talking about Church Reform--why, he belongs to the Church
7748: himself--he wants reforming too.' Well, well, wait a bit, and you'll
7749: hear by-and-by that old Parson Lingon is reformed--shoots no more,
7750: cracks his joke no more, has drunk his last bottle: the dogs, the old
7751: pointers, will be sorry; but you'll hear that the Parson at Little Treby
7752: is a new man. That's what Church Reform is sure to come to before long.
7753: So now here are some more nuts for you, lads, and I leave you to listen
7754: to your candidate. Here he is--give him a good hurray; wave your hats,
7755: and I'll begin. Hurray!"
7756: 
7757: Harold had not been quite confident beforehand as to the good effect of
7758: his uncle's introduction; but he was soon reassured. There was no acrid
7759: partisanship among the old-fashioned Tories who mustered strong about
7760: the Marquis of Granby, and Parson Jack had put them in a good humor.
7761: Harold's only interruption came from his own party. The oratorical clerk
7762: at the Factory, acting as the tribune of the Dissenting interest, and
7763: feeling bound to put questions, might have been troublesome; but his
7764: voice being unpleasantly sharp, while Harold's was full and
7765: penetrating, the questioning was cried down. Harold's speech "did": it
7766: was not of the glib-nonsensical sort, not ponderous, not
7767: hesitating--which is as much as to say, that it was remarkable among
7768: British speeches. Read in print the next day, perhaps it would be
7769: neither pregnant nor conclusive, which is saying no more than that its
7770: excellence was not of an abnormal kind, but such as is usually found in
7771: the best efforts of eloquent candidates. Accordingly, the applause
7772: drowned the opposition, and content predominated.
7773: 
7774: But, perhaps, the moment of most diffusive pleasure from public speaking
7775: is that in which the speech ceases and the audience can turn to
7776: commenting on it. The one speech, sometimes uttered under great
