7777: responsibility as to missiles and other consequences, has given a text
7778: to twenty speakers who are under no responsibility. Even in the days of
7779: duelling a man was not challenged for being a bore, nor does this
7780: quality apparently hinder him from being much invited to dinner, which
7781: is the great index of social responsibility in a less barbarous age.
7782: 
7783: Certainly the crowd in the market-place seemed to experience this
7784: culminating enjoyment when the speaking on the platform in front of the
7785: Ram had ceased, and there were no less than three orators holding forth
7786: from the elevation of chance vehicles, not at all to the prejudice of
7787: the talking among those who were on a level with their neighbors. There
7788: was little ill-humor among the listeners, for Queen Bess was striking
7789: the last quarter before two, and a savory smell from the inn kitchens
7790: inspired them with an agreeable consciousness that the speakers were
7791: helping to trifle away the brief time before dinner.
7792: 
7793: Two or three of Harold's committee had lingered talking to each other on
7794: the platform, instead of re-entering; and Jermyn, after coming out to
7795: speak to one of them, had turned to the corner near which the carriages
7796: were standing, that he might tell the Transome's coachman to drive round
7797: to the side door and signal to his own coachman to follow. But a
7798: dialogue which was going on below induced him to pause, and instead of
7799: giving the order, to assume the air of a careless gazer. Christian, whom
7800: the attorney had already observed looking out of a window at the Marquis
7801: of Granby, was talking to Dominic. The meeting appeared to be one of new
7802: recognition, for Christian was saying:
7803: 
7804: "You've not got gray, as I have, Mr. Lenoni; you're not a day older for
7805: the sixteen years. But no wonder you didn't know me; I'm bleached like a
7806: dried bone."
7807: 
7808: "Not so. It is true I was confused a meenute--I could put your face
7809: nowhere; but, after that, Naples came behind it, and I said, Mr.
7810: Creesstian. And so you reside at the Manor, and I am at Transome Court."
7811: 
7812: "Ah! it's a thousand pities you're not on our side, else we might have
7813: dined together at the Marquis," said Christian. "Eh, could you manage
7814: it?" he added, languidly, knowing there was no chance of a yes.
7815: 
7816: "No--much obliged--couldn't leave the leetle boy. Ahi! Arry, Arry, pinch
7817: not poor Moro."
7818: 
7819: While Dominic was answering, Christian had stared about him, as his
7820: manner was when he was being spoken to, and had had his eyes arrested by
7821: Esther, who was leaning forward to look at Mr. Harold Transome's
7822: extraordinary little gypsy of a son. But, happening to meet Christian's
7823: stare, she felt annoyed, drew back, and turned away her head, coloring.
7824: 
7825: "Who are those ladies?" said Christian, in a low tone, to Dominic, as if
7826: he had been startled into a sudden wish for this information.
7827: 
7828: "They are Meester Jermyn's daughters," said Dominic, who knew nothing
7829: either of the lawyer's family or of Esther.
7830: 
7831: Christian looked puzzled a moment or two, and was silent.
7832: 
7833: "Oh, well--_au revoir_," he said, kissing the tips of his fingers as the
7834: coachman, having had Jermyn's order, began to urge on the horses.
7835: 
7836: "Does he see some likeness in the girl?" thought Jermyn, as he turned
7837: away. "I wish I hadn't invited her to come in the carriage, as it
7838: happens."
7839: 
7840: 
7841: 
7842: 
7843: CHAPTER XX.
7844: 
7845:     "Good earthenware pitchers, sir!--of an excellent quaint pattern
7846:     and sober color."
7847: 
7848: 
7849: The market dinner at "the Marquis" was in high repute in Treby and its
7850: neighborhood. The frequenters of this three-and-sixpenny ordinary liked
7851: to allude to it, as men allude to anything which implies that they move
7852: in good society, and habitually converse with those who are in the
7853: secret of the highest affairs. The guests were not only such rural
7854: residents as had driven to market, but some of the most substantial
7855: townsmen, who had always assured their wives that business required this
7856: weekly sacrifice of domestic pleasure. The poorer farmers, who put up at
7857: the Ram or the Seven Stars, where there was no fish, felt their
7858: disadvantage, bearing it modestly or bitterly, as the case might be;
7859: and although the Marquis was a Tory house, devoted to Debarry, it was
7860: too much to expect that such tenants of the Transomes as had always been
7861: used to dine there, should consent to eat a worse dinner, and sit with
7862: worse company, because they suddenly found themselves under a Radical
7863: landlord, opposed to the political party known as Sir Maxim's. Hence the
7864: recent political divisions had not reduced the handsome length of the
7865: table at the Marquis; and the many gradations of dignity--from Mr. Wace,
7866: the brewer, to the rich butcher from Leek Malton, who always modestly
7867: took the lowest seat, though without the reward of being asked to come
7868: up higher--had not been abbreviated by any secessions.
7869: 
7870: To-day there was an extra table spread for expected supernumeraries, and
7871: it was at this that Christian took his place with some of the younger
7872: farmers, who had almost a sense of dissipation in talking to a man of
7873: his questionable station and unknown experience. The provision was
7874: especially liberal, and on the whole the presence of a minority destined
7875: to vote for Transome was a ground for joking, which added to the good
7876: humor of the chief talkers. A respectable old acquaintance turned
7877: Radical rather against his will, was rallied with even greater gusto
7878: than if his wife had had twins twice over. The best Trebian Tories were
7879: far too sweet-blooded to turn against such old friends, and to make no
7880: distinction between them and the Radical, Dissenting, Papistical,
7881: Deistical set with whom they never dined, and probably never saw except
7882: in their imagination. But the talk was necessarily in abeyance until the
7883: more serious business of dinner was ended, and the wine, spirits, and
7884: tobacco raised mere satisfaction into beatitude.
7885: 
7886: Among the frequent though not regular guests, whom every one was glad to
7887: see, was Mr. Nolan, the retired London hosier, a wiry old gentleman past
7888: seventy, whose square, tight forehead, with its rigid hedge of gray
7889: hair, whose bushy eyebrows, sharp dark eyes, and remarkable hooked nose,
7890: gave a handsome distinction to his face in the midst of rural
7891: physiognomies. He had married a Miss Pendrell early in life, when he was
7892: a poor young Londoner, and the match had been thought as bad as ruin by
7893: her family; but fifteen years ago he had had the satisfaction of
7894: bringing his wife to settle amongst her own friends, and of being
7895: received with pride as a brother-in-law, retired from business,
7896: possessed of unknown thousands, and of a most agreeable talent for
7897: anecdote and conversation generally. No question had ever been raised
7898: as to Mr. Nolan's extraction on the strength of his hooked nose, or of
7899: his name being Baruch. Hebrew names "ran" in the best Saxon families;
7900: the Bible accounted for them; and no one among the uplands and hedgerows
7901: of that district was suspected of having an oriental origin unless he
7902: carried a peddler's jewel-box. Certainly, whatever genealogical research
7903: might have discovered, the worthy Baruch Nolan was so free from any
7904: distinctive marks of religious persuasion--he went to church with so
7905: ordinary an irregularity, and so often grumbled at the sermon--that
7906: there was no ground for classing him otherwise than with good Trebian
7907: Churchmen. He was generally regarded as a good-looking old gentleman,
7908: and a certain thin eagerness in his aspect was attributed to the life of
7909: the metropolis, where narrow space had the same sort of effect on men as
7910: on thickly-planted trees. Mr. Nolan always ordered his pint of port,
7911: which, after he had sipped it a little, was wont to animate his
7912: recollections of the Royal Family, and the various ministries which had
7913: been contemporary with the successive stages of his prosperity. He was
7914: always listened to with interest: a man who had been born in the year
7915: when good old King George came to the throne--who had been acquainted
7916: with the nude leg of the Prince Regent, and hinted at private reasons
7917: for believing that the Princess Charlotte ought not to have died--had
7918: conversational matter as special to his auditors as Marco Polo could
7919: have had on his return from his Asiatic travel.
7920: 
7921: "My good sir," he said to Mr. Wace, as he crossed his knees and spread
7922: his silk handkerchief over them, "Transome may be returned, or he may
7923: not be returned--that's a question for North Loamshire; but it makes
7924: little difference to the kingdom. I don't want to say things which may
7925: put younger men out of spirits, but I believe this country has seen it's
7926: best days--I do, indeed."
7927: 
7928: "I am sorry to hear it from one of your experience, Mr. Nolan," said the
7929: brewer, a large, happy-looking man. "I'd make a good fight myself before
7930: I'd leave a worse world for my boys than I've found for myself. There
7931: isn't a greater pleasure than doing a bit of planting and improving
7932: one's buildings, and investing one's money in some pretty acres of land,
7933: and when it turns up here and there--land you've known from a boy. It's
7934: a nasty thought that these Radicals are to turn things round so as one
7935: can calculate on nothing. One doesn't like it for one's self, and one
7936: doesn't like it for one's neighbors. But somehow, I believe it won't
7937: do: if we can't trust the Government just now, there's Providence and
7938: the good sense of the country; and there's a right in things--that's
7939: what I've always said--there's a right in things. The heavy end will get
7940: downmost. And if Church and King, and every man being sure of his own,
7941: are things good for this country, there's a God above will take care of
7942: 'em."
7943: 
7944: "It won't do, my dear sir," said Mr. Nolan--"It won't do. When Peel and
7945: the Duke turned round about the Catholics in '29, I saw it was all over
7946: with us. We could never trust ministers any more. It was to keep off a
7947: rebellion, they said; but I say it was to keep their places. They're
7948: monstrously fond of place, both of them--that I know." Here Mr. Nolan
7949: changed the crossing of his legs, and gave a deep cough, conscious of
7950: having made a point. Then he went on--"What we want is a king with a
7951: good will of his own. If we'd had that, we shouldn't have heard what
7952: we've heard to-day; Reform would never have come to this pass. When our
7953: good old King George III. heard his ministers talking about Catholic
7954: Emancipation, he boxed their ears all round. Ah, poor soul! he did
7955: indeed, gentlemen," ended Mr. Nolan, shaken by a deep laugh of
7956: admiration.
7957: 
7958: "Well, now, that's something like a king," said Mr. Crowder, who was an
7959: eager listener.
7960: 
7961: "It was uncivil, though. How did they take it?" said Mr. Timothy Rose, a
7962: "gentleman farmer" from Leek Malton, against whose independent position
7963: nature had provided the safeguard of a spontaneous servility. His large
7964: porcine cheeks, round twinkling eyes, and thumbs habitually twirling,
7965: expressed a concentrated effort not to get into trouble, and to speak
7966: everybody fair except when they were safely out of hearing.
7967: 
7968: "Take it! they'd be obliged to take it," said the impetuous young Joyce,
7969: a farmer of superior information. "Have you ever heard of the king's
7970: prerogative?"
7971: 
7972: "I don't say but what I have," said Rose, retreating. "I've nothing
7973: against it--nothing at all."
7974: 
7975: "No, but the Radicals have," said young Joyce, winking. "The prerogative
7976: is what they want to clip close. They want us to be governed by
7977: delegates from the trades-unions, who are to dictate to everybody, and
7978: make everything square to their mastery."
7979: 
7980: "They're a pretty set, now, these delegates," said Mr. Wace, with
7981: disgust. "I once heard two of 'em spouting away. They're a sort of
7982: fellow I'd never employ in my brewery, or anywhere else. I've seen it
7983: again and again. If a man takes to tongue-work it's all over with him.
7984: 'Everything's wrong,' says he. That's a big text. But does he want to
7985: make everything right? Not he. He'd lose his text. 'We want every man's
7986: good,' say they. Why, they never knew yet what a man's good is. How
7987: should they? It's working for his victual--not getting a slice of other
7988: people's."
7989: 
7990: "Ay, ay," said young Joyce, cordially. "I should just have liked all the
7991: delegates in the country mustered for our yeomanry to go into--that's
7992: all. They'd see where the strength of Old England lay then. You may tell
7993: what it is for a country to trust to trade when it breeds such spindling
7994: fellows as those."
7995: 
7996: "That isn't the fault of trade, my good sir," said Mr. Nolan, who was
7997: often a little pained by the defects of provincial culture. "Trade,
7998: properly conducted, is good for a man's constitution. I could have shown
7999: you, in my time, weavers past seventy, with all their faculties as sharp
8000: as a pen-knife, doing without spectacles. It's the new system of trade
8001: that's to blame: a country can't have too much trade if it's properly
8002: managed. Plenty of sound Tories have made their fortune by trade. You've
8003: heard of Calibut & Co.--everybody has heard of Calibut. Well, sir, I
8004: knew old Mr. Calibut as well as I know you. He was once a crony of mine
8005: in a city warehouse; and now, I'll answer for it, he has a larger rent
8006: roll than Lord Wyvern. Bless your soul! his subscriptions to charities
8007: would make a fine income for a nobleman. And he's as good a Tory as I
8008: am. And as for his town establishment--why, how much butter do you think
8009: is consumed there annually?"
8010: 
8011: Mr. Nolan paused, and then his face glowed with triumph as he answered
8012: his own question. "Why, gentlemen, not less than two thousand pounds of
8013: butter during the few months the family is in town! Trade makes
8014: property, my good sir, and property is conservative, as they say now.
8015: Calibut's son-in-law is Lord Fortinbras. He paid me a large debt on his
8016: marriage. It's all one web, sir. The prosperity of the country is one
8017: web."
8018: 
8019: "To be sure," said Christian, who, smoking his cigar with his chair
8020: turned away from the table, was willing to make himself agreeable in the
8021: conversation. "We can't do without nobility. Look at France. When they
8022: got rid of the old nobles they were obliged to make new."
8023: 
8024: "True, very true," said Mr. Nolan, who thought Christian a little too
8025: wise for his position, but could not resist the rare gift of an instance
8026: in point. "It's the French Revolution that has done us harm here. It was
8027: the same at the end of the last century, but the war kept it off--Mr.
8028: Pitt saved us. I knew Mr. Pitt. I had a particular interview with him
8029: once. He joked me about getting the length of his foot. 'Mr. Nolan,'
8030: said he, 'there are those on the other side of the water whose name
8031: begins with N. who would be glad to know what you know.' I was
8032: recommended to send an account of that to the newspapers after his
8033: death, poor man! but I'm not fond of that kind of show myself." Mr.
8034: Nolan swung his upper leg a little, and pinched his lip between his
8035: thumb and finger, naturally pleased with his own moderation.
8036: 
8037: "No, no--very right," said Mr. Wace, cordially. "But you never said a
8038: truer word than that about property. If a man's got a bit of property, a
8039: stake in the country, he'll want to keep things square. Where Jack isn't
8040: safe, Tom's in danger. But that's what makes it such an uncommonly nasty
8041: thing that a man like Transome should take up with these Radicals. It's
8042: my belief he does it only to get into Parliament; he'll turn round when
8043: he gets there. Come, Dibbs, there's something to put you in spirits,"
8044: added Mr. Wace, raising his voice a little and looking at a guest lower
8045: down. "You've got to vote for a Radical with one side of your mouth, and
8046: make a wry face with the other; but he'll turn round by-and-by. As
8047: Parson Jack says, he's got the right sort of blood in him."
8048: 
8049: "I don't care two straws who I vote for," said Dibbs, sturdily. "I'm not
8050: going to make a wry face. It stands to reason a man should vote for his
8051: landlord. My farm's in good condition, and I've got the best pasture on
8052: the estate. The rot's never come nigh me. Let them grumble as are on the
8053: wrong side of the hedge."
8054: 
8055: "I wonder if Jermyn'll bring him in, though," said Mr. Sircome, the
8056: great miller. "He's an uncommon fellow for carrying things through. I
8057: know he brought me through that suit about my weir; it cost a pretty
8058: penny, but he brought me through."
8059: 
8060: "It's a bit of a pill for him, too, having to turn Radical," said Mr.
8061: Wace. "They say he counted on making friends with Sir Maximus, by this
8062: young one coming home and joining with Mr. Philip."
8063: 
8064: "But I'll bet a penny he brings Transome in," said Mr. Sircome. "Folks
8065: say he hasn't got many votes hereabout; but toward Duffield, and all
8066: there, where the Radicals are, everybody's for him. Eh, Mr. Christian?
8067: Come--you're at the fountain-head--what do they say about it now at the
8068: Manor?"
8069: 
8070: When general attention was called to Christian young Joyce looked down
8071: at his own legs and touched the curves of his own hair, as if measuring
8072: his own approximation to that correct copy of a gentleman. Mr. Wace
8073: turned his head to listen for Christian's answer with that tolerance of
8074: inferiority which becomes men in places of public resort.
8075: 
8076: "They think it will be a hard run between Transome and Garstin," said
8077: Christian. "It depends on Transome's getting plumpers."
8078: 
8079: "Well, I know I shall not split for Garstin," said Mr. Wace. "It's
8080: nonsense for Debarry's voters to split for a Whig. A man's either a Tory
8081: or not a Tory."
8082: 
8083: "It seems reasonable there should be one of each side," said Mr. Timothy
8084: Rose. "I don't like showing favor either way. If one side can't lower
8085: the poor's rates and take off the tithe, let the other try."
8086: 
8087: "But there's this in it, Wace," said Mr. Sircome. "I'm not altogether
8088: against the Whigs. For they don't want to go so far as the Radicals do,
8089: and when they find they've slipped a bit too far they'll hold on all the
8090: tighter. And the Whigs have got the upper hand now, and it's no use
8091: fighting with the current. I run with the----"
8092: 
8093: Mr. Sircome checked himself, looked furtively at Christian, and, to
8094: divert criticisms, ended with--"eh, Mr. Nolan?"
8095: 
8096: "There have been eminent Whigs, sir. Mr. Fox was a Whig," said Mr.
8097: Nolan. "Mr. Fox was a great orator. He was very intimate with the Prince
8098: of Wales. I've seen him, and the Duke of York too, go home by daylight
8099: with their hats crushed. Mr. Fox was a great leader of Opposition:
8100: Government requires an Opposition. The Whigs should always be in
8101: opposition, and the Tories on the ministerial side. That's what the
8102: country used to like. 'The Whigs for salt and mustard, the Tories for
8103: meat,' Mr. Gottlib, the banker, used to say to me. Mr. Gottlib was a
8104: worthy man. When there was a great run on Mr. Gottlib's bank in '16, I
8105: saw a gentleman come in with bags of gold, and say, 'Tell Mr. Gottlib
8106: there's plenty more where that came from.' It stopped the run,
8107: gentlemen--it did indeed."
8108: 
8109: This anecodote was received with great admiration, but Mr. Sircome
8110: returned to the previous question.
8111: 
8112: "There now, you see, Wace--it's right there should be Whigs as well as
8113: Tories--Pitt and Fox--I've always heard them go together."
8114: 
8115: "Well, I don't like Garstin," said the brewer. "I didn't like his
8116: conduct about the Canal Company. Of the two, I like Transome best. If a
8117: nag is to throw me, I say, let him have some blood."
8118: 
8119: "As for blood, Wace," said Mr. Salt, the wool-factor, a bilious man, who
8120: only spoke when there was a good opportunity of contradicting, "ask my
8121: brother-in-law, Labron, a little about that. These Transomes are not the
8122: old blood."
8123: 
8124: "Well, they're the oldest that's forthcoming, I suppose," said Mr. Wace,
8125: laughing. "Unless you believe in mad old Tommy Trounsem. I wonder where
8126: that old poaching fellow is now."
8127: 
8128: "I saw him half-drunk the other day," said young Joyce. "He'd got a
8129: flag-basket with handbills in it over his shoulder."
8130: 
8131: "I thought the old fellow was dead," said Mr. Wace. "Hey! why, Jermyn,"
8132: he went on merrily, as he turned round and saw the attorney entering;
8133: "you Radical! how dare you show yourself in this Tory house? Come, this
8134: is going a bit too far. We don't mind Old Harry managing our law for
8135: us--that's his proper business from time immemorial; but----"
8136: 
8137: "But--a--" said Jermyn, smiling, always ready to carry on a joke, to
8138: which his slow manner gave the piquancy of surprise, "if he meddles with
8139: politics he must be a Tory."
8140: 
8141: Jermyn was not afraid to show himself anywhere in Treby. He knew many
8142: people were not exactly fond of him, but a man can do without that, if
8143: he is prosperous. A provincial lawyer in those old-fashioned days was as
8144: independent of personal esteem as if he had been a Lord Chancellor.
8145: 
8146: There was a good-humored laugh at this upper end of the room as Jermyn
8147: seated himself at about an equal angle between Mr. Wace and Christian.
8148: 
8149: "We were talking about old Tommy Trounsem; you remember him? They say
8150: he's turned up again," said Mr. Wace.
8151: 
8152: "Ah?" said Jermyn, indifferently. "But--a--Wace--I'm very busy
8153: to-day--but I wanted to see you about that bit of land of yours at the
8154: corner of Pod's End. I've had a handsome offer for you--I'm not at
8155: liberty to say from whom--but an offer that ought to tempt you."
8156: 
8157: "It won't tempt me," said Mr. Wace, peremptorily, "if I've got a bit of
8158: land, I'll keep it. It's hard enough to get hereabouts."
8159: 
8160: "Then I'm to understand that you refuse all negotiation?" said Jermyn,
8161: who had ordered a glass of sherry, and was looking around slowly as he
8162: sipped it, till his eyes seemed to rest for the first time on Christian,
8163: though he had seen him at once on entering the room.
8164: 
8165: "Unless one of the confounded railways should come. But then I'll stand
8166: out and make 'em bleed for it."
8167: 
8168: There was a murmur of approbation; the railways were a public wrong much
8169: denunciated in Treby.
8170: 
8171: "A--Mr. Philip Debarry at the Manor now?" said Jermyn, suddenly
8172: questioning Christian, in a haughty tone of superiority which he often
8173: chose to use.
8174: 
8175: "No," said Christian, "he is expected to-morrow morning."
8176: 
8177: "Ah!----" Jermyn paused a moment or two, and then said, "You are
8178: sufficiently in his confidence, I think, to carry a message to him with
8179: a small document?"
8180: 
8181: "Mr. Debarry has often trusted me so far," said Christian, with much
8182: coolness; "but if the business is yours, you can probably find some one
8183: you know better."
8184: 
8185: There was a little winking and grimacing among those of the company who
8186: heard this answer.
8187: 
8188: "A--true--a," said Jermyn, not showing any offence; "if you decline. But
8189: I think, if you will do me the favor to step round to my residence on
8190: your way back, and learn the business, you will prefer carrying it
8191: yourself. At my residence, if you please--not my office."
8192: 
8193: "Oh, very well," said Christian. "I shall be very happy." Christian
8194: never allowed himself to be treated as a servant by anyone but his
8195: master, and his master treated a servant more deferentially than an
8196: equal.
8197: 
8198: "Will it be five o'clock? what hour shall we say?" said Jermyn.
8199: 
8200: Christian looked at his watch and said, "About five I can be there."
8201: 
8202: "Very good," said Jermyn, finishing his sherry.
8203: 
8204: "Well--a--Wace--a--so you will hear nothing about Pod's End?"
8205: 
8206: "Not I."
8207: 
8208: "A mere pocket-handkerchief, not enough to swear by-a--" here Jermyn's
8209: face broke into a smile--"without a magnifying-glass."
8210: 
8211: "Never mind. It's mine into the bowels of the earth and up to the sky. I
8212: can build the Tower of Babel on it if I like--eh, Mr. Nolan?"
8213: 
8214: "A bad investment, my good sir," said Mr. Nolan, who enjoyed a certain
8215: flavor of infidelity in this smart reply, and laughed much at it in his
8216: inward way.
8217: 
8218: "See now, how blind you Tories are," said Jermyn, rising; "if I had been
8219: your lawyer, I'd have had you make another forty-shilling freeholder
8220: with that land, and all in time for this election. But--a--the _verbum
8221: sapientibus_ comes a little too late now."
8222: 
8223: Jermyn was moving away as he finished speaking, but Mr. Wace called out
8224: after him, "We're not so badly off for votes as you are--good sound
8225: votes, that'll stand the Revising Barrister. Debarry at the top of the
8226: poll!"
8227: 
8228: The lawyer was already out of the doorway.
8229: 
8230: 
8231: 
8232: 
8233: CHAPTER XXI.
8234: 
8235:     'Tis grievous that with all amplification of travel both by sea and
8236:     land, a man can never separate himself from his past history.
8237: 
8238: 
8239: Mr. Jermyn's handsome house stood a little way out of the town,
8240: surrounded by garden and lawn and plantations of hopeful trees. As
8241: Christian approached it he was in a perfectly easy state of mind: the
8242: business he was going on was none of his, otherwise than as he was well
8243: satisfied with any opportunity of making himself valuable to Mr. Philip
8244: Debarry. As he looked at Jermyn's length of wall and iron railing, he
8245: said to himself, "These lawyers are the fellows for getting on in the
8246: world with the least expense of civility. With this cursed conjuring
8247: secret of theirs called Law, they think everybody is frightened at them.
8248: My Lord Jermyn seems to have his insolence as ready as his soft sawder.
8249: He's as sleek as a rat, and has as vicious a tooth. I know the sort of
8250: vermin well enough. I've helped to fatten one or two."
8251: 
8252: In this mood of conscious, contemptuous penetration, Christian was shown
8253: by the footman into Jermyn's private room, where the attorney sat
8254: surrounded with massive oaken bookcases, and other furniture to
8255: correspond, from the thickest-legged library-table to the calendar frame
8256: and card-rack. It was the sort of a room a man prepares for himself when
8257: he feels sure of a long and respectable future. He was leaning back in
8258: his leather chair, against the broad window opening on the lawn, and had
8259: just taken off his spectacles and let the newspaper fall on his knees,
8260: in despair of reading by the fading light.
8261: 
8262: When the footman opened the door and said, "Mr. Christian," Jermyn said,
8263: "Good evening, Mr. Christian. Be seated," pointing to a chair opposite
8264: himself and the window. "Light the candles on the shelf, John, but leave
8265: the blinds alone."
8266: 
8267: He did not speak again till the man was gone out, but appeared to be
8268: referring to a document which lay on the bureau before him. When the
8269: door was closed he drew himself up again, began to rub his hands, and
8270: turned toward his visitor, who seemed perfectly indifferent to the fact
8271: that the attorney was in shadow, and that the light fell on himself.
8272: 
8273: "A--your name--a--is Henry Scaddon."
8274: 
8275: There was a start through Christian's frame which he was quick enough,
8276: almost simultaneously, to try and disguise as a change of position. He
8277: uncrossed his legs and unbuttoned his coat. But before he had time to
8278: say anything, Jermyn went on with slow emphasis.
8279: 
8280: "You were born on the sixteenth of December, 1782, at Blackheath. Your
8281: father was a cloth-merchant in London: he died when you were barely of
8282: age, leaving an extensive business: before you were five-and-twenty you
8283: had run through the greater part of the property, and had compromised
8284: your safety by an attempt to defraud your creditors. Subsequently you
8285: forged a check on your father's elder brother, who had intended to make
8286: you his heir."
8287: 
8288: Here Jermyn paused a moment and referred to the document. Christian was
8289: silent.
8290: 
8291: "In 1808 you found it expedient to leave this country in a military
8292: disguise, and were taken prisoner by the French. On the occasion of an
8293: exchange of prisoners you had the opportunity of returning to your own
8294: country, and to the bosom of your own family. You were generous enough
8295: to sacrifice that prospect in favor of a fellow-prisoner, of about your
8296: own age and figure, who had more pressing reasons than yourself for
8297: wishing to be on this side of the water. You exchanged dress, luggage,
8298: and names with him, and he passed to England instead of you as Henry
8299: Scaddon. Almost immediately afterward you escaped from your
8300: imprisonment, after feigning an illness which prevented your exchange of
8301: names from being discovered; and it was reported that you--that is, you
8302: under the name of your fellow-prisoner--were drowned in an open boat,
8303: trying to reach a Neapolitan vessel bound for Malta. Nevertheless I
8304: have to congratulate you on the falsehood of that report, and on the
8305: certainty that you are now, after the lapse of more than twenty years,
8306: seated here in perfect safety."
8307: 
8308: Jermyn paused so long that he was evidently awaiting some answer. At
8309: last Christian replied in a dogged tone--
8310: 
8311: "Well, sir, I've heard much longer stories than that told quite as
8312: solemnly, when there was not a word of truth in them. Suppose I deny the
8313: very peg you hang your statement on. Suppose I say I am not Henry
8314: Scaddon."
8315: 
8316: "A--in that case--a," said Jermyn, with wooden indifference, "you would
8317: lose the advantage which--a--may attach to your possession of Henry
8318: Scaddon's knowledge. And at the same time, if it were in the
8319: least--a--inconvenient to you that you should be recognized as Henry
8320: Scaddon, your denial would not prevent me from holding the knowledge and
8321: evidence which I possess on that point; it would only prevent us from
8322: pursuing the present conversation."
8323: 
8324: "Well, sir, suppose we admit, for the sake of the conversation, that
8325: your account of the matter is the true one: what advantage have you to
8326: offer the man named Henry Scaddon?"
8327: 
8328: "The advantage--a--is problematical; but it may be considerable. It
8329: might, in fact, release you from the necessity of acting as courier,
8330: or--a--valet, or whatever other office you may occupy which prevents you
8331: from being your own master. On the other hand, my acquaintance with your
8332: secret is not necessarily a disadvantage to you. To put the matter in a
8333: nutshell, I am not inclined--a--gratuitously--to do you any harm, and I
8334: may be able to do you a considerable service."
8335: 
8336: "Which you want me to earn somehow?" said Christian. "You offer me a
8337: turn in a lottery?"
8338: 
8339: "Precisely. The matter in question is of no earthly interest to you,
8340: except--a--as it may yield you a prize. We lawyers have to do with
8341: complicated questions, and--a--legal subtleties, which are
8342: never--a--fully known even to the parties immediately interested, still
8343: less to the witnesses. Shall we agree, then, that you continue to retain
8344: two-thirds of the name which you gained by exchange, and that you oblige
8345: me by answering certain questions as to the experience of Henry
8346: Scaddon?"
8347: 
8348: "Very good. Go on."
8349: 
8350: "What articles of property once belonging to your fellow-prisoner,
8351: Maurice Christian Bycliffe, do you still retain?"
8352: 
8353: "This ring," said Christian, twirling round the fine seal-ring on his
8354: finger, "his watch, and the little matters that hung with it, and a case
8355: of papers. I got rid of a gold snuff-box once when I was hard up. The
8356: clothes are all gone, of course. We exchanged everything; it was all
8357: done in a hurry. Bycliffe thought we should meet again in England before
8358: long, and he was mad to get there. But that was impossible--I mean that
8359: we should meet soon after. I don't know what's become of him, else I
8360: would give him up his papers and the watch, and so on--though, you know,
8361: it was I who did _him_ the service, and he felt that."
8362: 
8363: "You were at Vesoul together before being moved to Verdun?"
8364: 
8365: "Yes."
8366: 
8367: "What else do you know about Bycliffe?"
8368: 
8369: "Oh, nothing very particular," said Christian pausing, and rapping his
8370: boot with his cane. "He'd been in the Hanoverian army--a high-spirited
8371: fellow, took nothing easily; not over-strong in health. He made a fool
8372: of himself with marrying at Vesoul; and there was the devil to pay with
8373: the girl's relations; and then, when the prisoners were ordered off,
8374: they had to part. Whether they ever got together again I don't know."
8375: 
8376: "Was the marriage all right then?"
8377: 
8378: "Oh, all on the square--civil marriage, church--everything. Bycliffe was
8379: a fool--a good-natured, proud, headstrong fellow."
8380: 
8381: "How long did the marriage take place before you left Vesoul?"
8382: 
8383: "About three months. I was witness to the marriage."
8384: 
8385: "And you know no more about the wife?"
8386: 
8387: "Not afterward. I knew her very well before--pretty Annette--Annette
8388: Ledru was her name. She was of a good family, and they had made up a
8389: fine match for her. But she was one of your meek little diablesses, who
8390: have a will of their own once in their lives--the will to choose their
8391: own master."
8392: 
8393: "Bycliffe was not open to you about his other affairs?"
8394: 
8395: "Oh, no--a fellow you wouldn't dare to ask a question of. People told
8396: him everything, but he told nothing in return. If Madame Annette ever
8397: found him again, she found her lord and master with a vengeance; but she
8398: was a regular lapdog. However, her family shut her up--made a prisoner
8399: of her--to prevent her running away."
8400: 
8401: "Ah--good. Much of what you have been so obliging as to say is
8402: irrelevant to any possible purpose of mine, which, in fact, has only to
8403: do with a mouldy law-case that might be aired some day. You will
8404: doubtless, on your own account, maintain perfect silence on what has
8405: passed between us, and with that condition duly preserved--a--it is
8406: possible that--a--the lottery you have put into--as you observe--may
8407: turn up a prize."
8408: 
8409: "This, then, is all the business you have with me?" said Christian,
8410: rising.
8411: 
8412: "All. You will, of course, preserve carefully all the papers and other
8413: articles which have so many--a--recollections--a--attached to them?"
8414: 
8415: "Oh, yes. If there's any chance of Bycliffe turning up again, I shall be
8416: sorry to have parted with the snuff-box; but I was hard-up at Naples. In
8417: fact, as you see, I was obliged at last to turn courier."
8418: 
8419: "An exceedingly agreeable life for a man of some--a--accomplishments
8420: and--a--no income," said Jermyn, rising, and reaching a candle, which he
8421: placed against his desk.
8422: 
8423: Christian knew this was a sign that he was expected to go, but he
8424: lingered standing, with one hand on the back of his chair. At last, he
8425: said rather sulkily--
8426: 
8427: "I think you're too clever, Mr. Jermyn, not to perceive that I'm not a
8428: man to be made a fool of."
8429: 
8430: "Well--a--it may perhaps be a still better guarantee for you," said Jermyn,
8431: smiling, "that I see no use in attempting that--a--metamorphosis."
8432: 
8433: "The old gentleman, who ought never to have felt himself injured, is
8434: dead now, and I'm not afraid of creditors after more than twenty years."
8435: 
8436: "Certainly not;--a--there may indeed be claims which can't assert
8437: themselves--a--legally, which yet are molesting to a man of some
8438: reputation. But you may perhaps be happily free from such fears."
8439: 
8440: Jermyn drew round his chair toward the bureau, and Christian, too acute
8441: to persevere uselessly, said, "Good-day," and left the room.
8442: 
8443: After leaning back in his chair to reflect a few minutes, Jermyn wrote
8444: the following letter:--
8445: 
8446:     DEAR JOHNSON,--I learn from your letter, received this morning,
8447:     that you intend returning to town on Saturday.
8448: 
8449:     While you are there, be so good as to see Medwin, who used to be
8450:     with Batt & Cowley, and ascertain from him indirectly, and in the
8451:     course of conversation on other topics, whether in that old
8452:     business in 1810-11, Scaddon _alias_ Bycliffe, or Bycliffe _alias_
8453:     Scaddon, before his imprisonment, gave Batt & Cowley any reason to
8454:     believe that he was married and expected to have a child. The
8455:     question, as you know, is of no practical importance; but I wish to
8456:     draw up an abstract of the Bycliffe case, and the exact position in
8457:     which it stood before the suit was closed by the death of the
8458:     plaintiff, in order that, if Mr. Harold Transome desires it, he may
8459:     see how the failure of the last claim has secured the
8460:     Durfey-Transome title, and whether there is a hair's breadth of
8461:     chance that another claim should be set up.
8462: 
8463:     Of course there is not a shadow of such a chance. For even if Batt
8464:     & Cowley were to suppose that they had alighted on a surviving
8465:     representative of the Bycliffes, it would not enter their heads to
8466:     set up a new claim, since they brought evidence that the last life
8467:     which suspended the Bycliffe remainder was extinct before the case
8468:     was closed, a good twenty years ago.
8469: 
8470:     Still I want to show the present heir of the Durfey-Transomes the
8471:     exact condition of the family title to the estates. So get me an
8472:     answer from Medwin on the above mentioned point.
8473: 
8474:     I shall meet you at Duffield next week. We must get Transome
8475:     returned. Never mind his having been a little rough the other day,
8476:     but go on doing what you know is necessary for his interest. His
8477:     interest is mine, which I need not say is John Johnson's.
8478: 
8479:                 Yours faithfully,                MATTHEW JERMYN.
8480: 
8481: When the attorney had sealed this letter and leaned back in his chair
8482: again, he was inwardly saying--
8483: 
8484: "Now, Mr. Harold, I shall shut up this affair in a private drawer till
8485: you choose to take any extreme measures which will force me to bring it
8486: out. I have the matter entirely in my own power. No one but old Lyon
8487: knows about the girl's birth. No one but Scaddon can clench the evidence
8488: about Bycliffe, and I've got Scaddon under my thumb. No soul except
8489: myself and Johnson, who is a limb of myself, knows that there is one
8490: half-dead life which may presently leave the girl a new claim to the
8491: Bycliffe heirship. I shall learn through Methurst whether Batt & Cowley
8492: knew, through Bycliffe, of this woman having come to England. I shall
8493: hold all the threads between my thumb and finger. I can use the evidence
8494: or I can nullify it.
8495: 
8496: "And so, if Mr. Harold pushes me to extremity, and threatens me with
8497: chancery and ruin, I have an opposing threat, which will either save me
8498: or turn into a punishment for him."
8499: 
8500: He rose, put out his candles, and stood with his back to the fire,
8501: looking out on the dim lawn, with its black twilight fringe of shrubs,
8502: still meditating. Quick thought was gleaming over five-and-thirty years
8503: filled with devices more or less clever, more or less desirable to be
8504: avowed. Those which might be avowed with impunity were not always to be
8505: distinguished as innocent by comparison with those which it was
8506: advisable to conceal. In a profession where much that is noxious may be
8507: done without disgrace, is a conscience likely to be without balm when
8508: circumstances have urged a man to overstep the line where his good
8509: technical information makes him aware that (with discovery) disgrace is
8510: likely to begin?
8511: 
8512: With regard to the Transome affairs, the family had been in pressing
8513: need of money, and it had lain with him to get it for them: was it to be
8514: expected that he would not consider his own advantage where he had
8515: rendered services such as are never fully paid? If it came to a question
8516: of right and wrong instead of law, the least justifiable things he had
8517: ever done had been done on behalf of the Transomes. It had been a
8518: deucedly unpleasant thing for him to get Bycliffe arrested and thrown
8519: into prison as Henry Scaddon--perhaps hastening the man's death in that
8520: way. But if it had not been done by dint of his (Jermyn's) exertions and
8521: tact, he would like to know where the Durfey-Transomes might have been
8522: by this time. As for right or wrong, if the truth were known, the very
8523: possession of the estate by the Durfey-Transomes was owing to law-tricks
8524: that took place nearly a century ago, when the original old Durfey got
8525: his base fee.
8526: 
8527: But inward argument of this sort now, as always, was merged in anger, in
8528: exasperation, that Harold, precisely Harold Transome, should have turned
8529: out to be the probable instrument of a visitation which would be bad
8530: luck, not justice; for is there any justice where ninety-nine out of
8531: every hundred escape? He felt himself beginning to hate Harold as he had
8532: never--
8533: 
8534: Just then Jermyn's third daughter, a tall slim girl, wrapped in a white
8535: woollen shawl, which she had hung over her blanket-wise, skipped across
8536: the lawn toward the greenhouse to get a flower. Jermyn was startled, and
8537: did not identify the figure, or rather he identified it falsely with
8538: another tall white-wrapped figure which had sometimes set his heart
8539: beating quickly more than thirty years before. For a moment he was fully
8540: back in those distant years when he and another bright-eyed person had
8541: seen no reason why they should not indulge their passion and their
8542: vanity, and determine for themselves how their lives should be made
8543: delightful in spite of unalterable external conditions. The reasons had
8544: been unfolding themselves gradually ever since through all the years
8545: which had converted the handsome, soft-eyed, slim young Jermyn (with a
8546: touch of sentiment) into a portly lawyer of sixty, for whom life had
8547: resolved itself into the means of keeping up his head among his
8548: professional brethren and maintaining an establishment--into a
8549: gray-haired husband and father, whose third affectionate and expensive
8550: daughter now rapped at the window and called to him, "Papa, papa, get
8551: ready for dinner; don't you remember that the Lukyns are coming?"
8552: 
8553: 
8554: 
8555: 
8556: CHAPTER XXII.
8557: 
8558:     Her gentle looks shot arrows, piercing him
8559:     As gods are pierced, with poison of sweet pity.
8560: 
8561: 
8562: The evening of the market-day had passed, and Felix had not looked in at
8563: Malthouse Yard to talk over the public events with Mr. Lyon. When Esther
8564: was dressing the next morning, she had reached a point of irritated
8565: anxiety to see Felix, at which she found herself devising little schemes
8566: for attaining that end in some way that would be so elaborate as to seem
8567: perfectly natural. Her watch had a long-standing ailment of losing;
8568: possibly it wanted cleaning; Felix would tell her if it merely wanted
8569: regulating, whereas Mr. Prowd might detain it unnecessarily, and cause
8570: her useless inconvenience. Or could she not get a valuable hint from
8571: Mrs. Holt about the home-made bread, which was something as "sad" as
8572: Lyddy herself? Or, if she came home that way at twelve o'clock, Felix
8573: might be going out, she might meet him, and not be obliged to call.
8574: Or--but it would be very much beneath her to take any steps of this
8575: sort. Her watch had been losing for the last two months--why should it
8576: not go on losing a little longer? She could think of no devices that
8577: were not so transparent as to be undignified. All the more undignified
8578: because Felix chose to live in a way that would prevent any one from
8579: classing him according to his education and mental refinement--"which
8580: certainly are very high," said Esther, inwardly, coloring, as if in
8581: answer to some contrary allegation, "else I should not think his opinion
8582: of any consequence." But she came to the conclusion that she could not
8583: possibly call at Mrs. Holt's.
8584: 
8585: It followed that, up to a few minutes past twelve, when she reached the
8586: turning toward Mrs. Holt's, she believed that she should go home the
8587: other way; but at the last moment there is always a reason not existing
8588: before--namely, the impossibility of further vacillation. Esther turned
8589: the corner without any visible pause, and in another minute was knocking
8590: at Mrs. Holt's door, not without an inward flutter, which she was bent
8591: on disguising.
8592: 
8593: "It's never you, Miss Lyon! who'd have thought of seeing you at this
8594: time? Is the minister ill? I thought he looked creechy. If you want
8595: help, I'll put my bonnet on."
8596: 
8597: "Don't keep Miss Lyon at the door, mother; ask her to come in," said the
8598: ringing voice of Felix, surmounting various small shufflings and
8599: babbling voices within.
8600: 
8601: "It's my wish for her to come in, I'm sure," said Mrs. Holt, making way;
8602: "but what is there for her to come in to? a floor worse than any public.
8603: But step in, pray, if you're so inclined. When I've been forced to take
8604: my bit of carpet up, and have benches, I don't see why I need mind
8605: nothing no more."
8606: 
8607: "I only came to ask Mr. Holt if he would look at my watch for me," said
8608: Esther, entering, and blushing a general rose-color.
8609: 
8610: "He'll do that fast enough," said Mrs. Holt, with emphasis; "that's one
8611: of the things he _will_ do."
8612: 
8613: "Excuse my rising, Miss Lyon," said Felix; "I'm binding up Job's
8614: finger."
8615: 
8616: Job was a small fellow about five, with a germinal nose, large round
8617: blue eyes, and red hair that curled close to his head like the wool on
8618: the back of an infantine lamb. He had evidently been crying, and the
8619: corners of his mouth were still dolorous. Felix held him on his knee as
8620: he bound and tied up very cleverly a tiny forefinger. There was a table
8621: in front of Felix and against the window, covered with his watchmaking
8622: implements and some open books. Two benches stood at right angles on the
8623: sanded floor, and six or seven boys of various ages up to twelve were
8624: getting their caps and preparing to go home. They huddled themselves
8625: together and stood still when Esther entered. Felix could not look up
8626: till he had finished his surgery, but he went on speaking.
8627: 
8628: "This is a hero, Miss Lyon. This is Job Tudge, a bold Briton whose
8629: finger hurts him, but who doesn't mean to cry. Good-morning, boys. Don't
8630: lose your time. Get out into the air."
8631: 
8632: Esther seated herself on the end of the bench near Felix, much relieved
8633: that Job was the immediate object of attention; and the other boys
8634: rushed out behind her with a brief chant of "Good-morning!"
8635: 
8636: "Did you ever see," said Mrs. Holt, standing to look on, "how wonderful
8637: Felix is at that small work with his large fingers? And that's because
8638: he learned doctoring. It isn't for want of cleverness he looks like a
8639: poor man, Miss Lyon. I've left off speaking, else I should say it's a
8640: sin and a shame."
8641: 
8642: [Illustration: FELIX HOLT AND JOB TUDGE.]
8643: 
8644: "Mother," said Felix, who often amused himself and kept good-humored by
8645: giving his mother answers that were unintelligible to her, "you have an
8646: astonishing readiness in the Ciceronian antiphrasis, considering you
8647: have never studied oratory. There, Job--thou patient man--sit still if
8648: thou wilt; and now we can look at Miss Lyon."
8649: 
8650: Esther had taken off her watch and was holding it in her hand. But he
8651: looked at her face, or rather at her eyes, as he said, "You want me to
8652: doctor your watch?"
8653: 
8654: Esther's expression was appealing and timid, as it had never been before
8655: in Felix's presence; but when she saw the perfect calmness, which to her
8656: seemed coldness, of his clear gray eyes, as if he saw no reason for
8657: attaching any emphasis to this first meeting, a pang swift as an
8658: electric shock darted through her. She had been very foolish to think so
8659: much of it. It seemed to her as if her inferiority to Felix made a gulf
8660: between them. She could not at once rally her pride and self-command,
8661: but let her glance fall on her watch, and said, rather tremulously, "It
8662: loses. It is very troublesome. It has been losing a long while."
8663: 
8664: Felix took the watch from her hand; then, looking round and seeing that
8665: his mother was gone out of the room, he said, very gently--
8666: 
8667: "You look distressed, Miss Lyon. I hope there is no trouble at home"
8668: (Felix was thinking of the minister's agitation on the previous Sunday).
8669: "But I ought perhaps to beg your pardon for saying so much."
8670: 
8671: Poor Esther was quite helpless. The mortification which had come like a
8672: bruise to all the sensibilities that had been in keen activity, insisted
8673: on some relief. Her eyes filled instantly, and a great tear rolled down
8674: while she said in a loud sort of whisper, as involuntary as her tears--
8675: 
8676: "I wanted to tell you that I was not offended--that I am not
8677: ungenerous--I thought you might think--but you have not thought of it."
8678: 
8679: Was there ever more awkward speaking?--or any behavior less like that of
8680: the graceful, self-possessed Miss Lyon, whose phrases were usually so
8681: well turned, and whose repartees were so ready?
8682: 
8683: For a moment there was silence. Esther had her two little
8684: delicately-gloved hands clasped on the table. The next moment she felt
8685: one hand of Felix covering them both and pressing them firmly; but he
8686: did not speak. The tears were both on her cheeks now, and she could look
8687: up at him. His eyes had an expression of sadness in them, quite new to
8688: her. Suddenly little Job, who had his mental exercises on the occasion,
8689: called out, impatiently--
8690: 
8691: "She's tut her finger!"
8692: 
8693: Felix and Esther laughed, and drew their hands away; and as Esther took
8694: her handkerchief to wipe the tears from her cheeks she said--
8695: 
8696: "You see, Job, I am a naughty coward. I can't help crying when I've hurt
8697: myself."
8698: 
8699: "Zoo soodn't kuy," said Job energetically, being much impressed with a
8700: moral doctrine which had come to him after a sufficient transgression of
8701: it.
8702: 
8703: "Job is like me," said Felix, "fonder of preaching than of practice. But
8704: let us look at this same watch," he went on, opening and examining it.
8705: "These little Geneva toys are cleverly constructed to go always a little
8706: wrong. But if you wind them up and set them regularly every night, you
8707: may know at least that it's not noon when the hand points there."
8708: 
8709: Felix chatted, that Esther might recover herself; but now Mrs. Holt came
8710: back and apologized.
8711: 
8712: "You'll excuse my going away, I know, Miss Lyon. But there were the
8713: dumplings to see to, and what little I've got left on my hands now I
8714: like to do well. Not but what I've more cleaning to do than ever I had
8715: in my life before, as you may tell soon enough if you look at this
8716: floor. But when you've been used to doing things, and they've been taken
8717: away from you, it's as if your hands had been cut off, and you felt the
8718: fingers as are of no use to you."
8719: 
8720: "That's a great image, mother," said Felix, as he snapped the watch
8721: together and handed it to Esther; "I never heard you use such an image
8722: before."
8723: 
8724: "Yes, I know you've always some fault to find with what your mother
8725: says. But if ever there was a woman could talk with the open Bible
8726: before her, and not be afraid, it's me. I never did tell stories, and I
8727: never will--though I know it's done, Miss Lyon, and by church members
8728: too, when they have candles to sell, as I could bring you to the proof.
8729: But I never was one of 'em, let Felix say what he will about the
8730: printing on the tickets. His father believed it was gospel truth, and
8731: it's presumptuous to say it wasn't. For as for curing, how can anybody
8732: know? There's no physic'll cure without a blessing, and _with_ a
8733: blessing I know I've seen a mustard plaister work when there was no more
8734: smell nor strength in the mustard than so much flour. And reason
8735: good--for the mustard had lain in paper nobody knows how long--so I'll
8736: leave you to guess."
8737: 
8738: Mrs. Holt looked hard out of the window and gave a slight, inarticulate
8739: sound of scorn.
8740: 
8741: Felix had leaned back in his chair with a resigned smile, and was
8742: pinching Job's ears.
8743: 
8744: Esther said, "I think I had better go now," not knowing what else to
8745: say, yet not wishing to go immediately, lest she should seem to be
8746: running away from Mrs. Holt. She felt keenly how much endurance there
8747: must be for Felix. And she had often been discontented with her father,
8748: and called him tiresome!
8749: 
8750: "Where does Job Tudge live?" she said, still sitting and looking at the
8751: droll little figure, set off by a ragged jacket with a tail about two
8752: inches deep sticking out above the funniest of corduroys.
8753: 
8754: "Job has two mansions," said Felix. "He lives here chiefly; but he has
8755: another home, where his grandfather, Mr. Tudge, the stone-breaker,
8756: lives. My mother is very good to Job, Miss Lyon. She has made him a
8757: little bed in a cupboard, and she gives him sweetened porridge."
8758: 
8759: The exquisite goodness implied in these words of Felix impressed Esther
8760: the more, because in her hearing his talk had usually been pungent and
8761: denunciatory. Looking at Mrs. Holt, she saw that her eyes had lost their
8762: bleak north-easterly expression, and were shining with some mildness on
8763: little Job, who had turned round toward her, propping his head against
8764: Felix.
8765: 
8766: "Well, why shouldn't I be motherly to the child, Miss Lyon?" said Mrs.
8767: Holt, whose strong powers of argument required the file of an imagined
8768: contradiction, if there were no real one at hand. "I never was
8769: hard-hearted, and I never will be. It was Felix picked the child up and
8770: took to him, you may be sure, for there's nobody else master where he
8771: is; but I wasn't going to beat the orphan child and abuse him because of
8772: that, and him as straight as an arrow when he's stripped, and me so fond
8773: of children, and only had one of my own to live. I'd three babies, Miss
8774: Lyon, but the blessed Lord only spared Felix, and him the masterfulest
8775: and brownest of 'em all. But I did my duty by him, and I said, he'll
8776: have more schooling than his father, and he'll grow up a doctor, and
8777: marry a woman with money to furnish--as I was myself, spoons and
8778: everything--and I shall have the grandchildren to look up to me, and be
8779: drove out in the gig sometimes, like old Mrs. Lukyn. And you see what
8780: it's all come to, Miss Lyon: here's Felix made a common man of himself,
8781: and says he'll never be married--which is the most unreasonable thing,
8782: and him never easy but when he's got the child on his lap, or when----"
8783: 
8784: "Stop, stop, mother," Felix burst in; "pray don't use that limping
8785: argument again--that a man should marry because he's fond of children.
8786: That's a reason for not marrying. A bachelor's children are always
8787: young: they're immortal children--always lisping, waddling, helpless,
8788: and with a chance of turning out good."
8789: 
8790: "The Lord above may know what you mean! And haven't other folks's
8791: children a chance of turning out good?"
8792: 
8793: "Oh, they grow out of it very fast. Here's Job Tudge now," said Felix,
8794: turning the little one round on his knee, and holding his head by the
8795: back--"Job's limbs will get lanky; this little fist that looks like a
8796: puff-ball and can hide nothing bigger than a gooseberry, will get large
8797: and bony, and perhaps want to clutch more than its share; these wide
8798: blue eyes that tell me more truth than Job knows, will narrow and narrow
8799: and try to hide truth that Job would be better without knowing; this
8800: little negative nose will become long and self-asserting; and this
8801: little tongue--put out thy tongue, Job"--Job, awe-struck under this
8802: ceremony, put out a little red tongue very timidly--"this tongue, hardly
8803: bigger than a rose-leaf, will get large and thick, wag out of season, do
8804: mischief, brag and cant for gain or vanity, and cut as cruelly, for all
8805: its clumsiness, as if it were a sharp-edged blade. Big Job will perhaps
8806: be naughty--" As Felix, speaking with the loud emphatic distinctness
8807: habitual to him, brought out this terribly familiar word, Job's sense of
8808: mystification became too painful: he hung his lip and began to cry.
8809: 
8810: "See here," said Mrs. Holt, "you're frightening the innocent child with
8811: such talk--and it's enough to frighten them that think themselves the
8812: safest."
8813: 
8814: "Look here, Job, my man," said Felix, setting the boy down and turning
8815: him toward Esther; "go to Miss Lyon, ask her to smile at you, and that
8816: will dry up your tears like the sunshine."
8817: 
8818: Job put his two brown fists on Esther's lap, and she stooped to kiss
8819: him. Then holding his face between her hands she said, "Tell Mr. Holt we
8820: don't mean to be naughty, Job. He should believe in us more. But now I
8821: must really go home."
8822: 
8823: Esther rose and held out her hand to Mrs. Holt, who kept it while she
8824: said, a little to Esther's confusion--
8825: 
8826: "I'm very glad it's took your fancy to come here sometimes, Miss Lyon. I
8827: know you're thought to hold your head high, but I speak of people as I
8828: find 'em. And I'm sure anybody had need be humble that comes where
8829: there's a floor like this--for I've put by my best tea-trays, they're so
8830: out of all character--I must look Above for comfort now; but I don't say
8831: I'm not worthy to be called on for all that."
8832: 
8833: Felix had risen and moved toward the door that he might open it and
8834: shield Esther from more last words on his mother's part.
8835: 
8836: "Good-bye, Mr. Holt."
8837: 
8838: "Will Mr. Lyon like for me to sit with him an hour this evening, do you
8839: think?"
8840: 
8841: "Why not? He always likes to see you."
8842: 
8843: "Then I will come. Good-bye."
8844: 
8845: "She's a very straight figure," said Mrs. Holt. "How she carries
8846: herself! But I doubt there's some truth in what our people say. If she
8847: won't look at young Muscat, it's the better for _him_. He'd need have a
8848: big fortune that marries her."
8849: 
8850: "That's true, mother," said Felix, sitting down, snatching up little
8851: Job, and finding a vent for some unspeakable feeling in the pretence of
8852: worrying him.
8853: 
8854: Esther was rather melancholy as she went home, yet happier withal than
8855: she had been for many days before. She thought, "I need not mind having
8856: shown so much anxiety about his opinion. He is too clear-sighted to
8857: mistake our mutual position; he is quite above putting a false
8858: interpretation on what I have done. Besides, he had not thought of me at
8859: all--I saw that plainly enough. Yet he was very kind. There is something
8860: greater and better in him than I had imagined. His behavior to-day--to
8861: his mother and me too--I should call it the highest gentlemanliness,
8862: only it seems in him to be something deeper. But he has chosen an
8863: intolerable life; though I suppose, if I had a mind equal to his, and if
8864: he loved me very dearly, I should choose the same life."
8865: 
8866: Esther felt that she had prefixed an impossible "if" to that result. But
8867: now she had known Felix her conception of what a happy love must be had
8868: become like a dissolving view, in which the once-dear images were
8869: gradually melting into new forms and new colors. The favorite Byronic
8870: heroes were beginning to look like last night's decorations seen in the
8871: sober dawn. So fast does a little leaven spread within us--so
8872: incalculable is one personality on another. Behind all Esther's
8873: thoughts, like an unacknowledged yet constraining presence, there was
8874: the sense, that if Felix Holt were to love her, her life would be
8875: exalted into something quite new--into a sort of difficult blessedness,
8876: such as one may imagine in beings who are conscious of painfully growing
8877: into possession of higher powers.
8878: 
8879: It was quite true that Felix had not thought the more of Esther because
8880: of that Sunday afternoon's interview which had shaken her mind to the
8881: very roots. He had avoided intruding on Mr. Lyon without special reason,
8882: because he believed the minister to be preoccupied with some private
8883: care. He had thought a great deal of Esther with a mixture of strong
8884: disapproval and strong liking, which both together made a feeling the
8885: reverse of indifference; but he was not going to let her have any
8886: influence on his life. Even if his determination had not been fixed, he
8887: would have believed that she would utterly scorn him in any other light
8888: than that of an acquaintance, and the emotion she had shown to-day did
8889: not change that belief. But he was deeply touched by this manifestation
8890: of her better qualities, and felt that there was a new tie of friendship
8891: between them. That was the brief history Felix would have given of his
8892: relation to Esther. And he was accustomed to observe himself. But very
8893: close and diligent looking at living creatures, even through the best
8894: microscope, will leave room for new and contradictory discoveries.
8895: 
8896: Felix found Mr. Lyon particularly glad to talk to him. The minister had
8897: never yet disburdened himself about his letter to Mr. Philip Debarry
8898: concerning the public conference; and as by this time he had all the
8899: heads of his discussion thoroughly in his mind, it was agreeable to
8900: recite them, as well as to express his regret that time had been lost by
8901: Mr. Debarry's absence from the Manor, which had prevented the immediate
8902: fulfillment of his pledge.
8903: 
8904: "I don't see how he can fulfill it if the rector refuses," said Felix,
8905: thinking it well to moderate the little man's confidence.
8906: 
8907: "The rector is of a spirit that will not incur earthly impeachment, and
8908: he cannot refuse what is necessary to his nephew's honorable discharge
8909: of an obligation," said Mr. Lyon. "My young friend, it is a case wherein
8910: the prearranged conditions tend by such a beautiful fitness to the issue
8911: I have sought, that I should have forever held myself a traitor to my
8912: charge had I neglected the indication."
8913: 
8914: 
8915: 
8916: 
8917: CHAPTER XXIII.
8918: 
8919:     "I will not excuse you; you shall not be excused; excuses shall not
8920:     be admitted; there's no excuse shall serve; you shall not be
8921:     excused."--_Henry IV._
8922: 
8923: 
8924: When Philip Debarry had come home that morning and read the letters
8925: which had not been forwarded to him, he laughed so heartily at Mr.
8926: Lyon's that he congratulated himself on being in his private room.
8927: Otherwise his laughter would have awakened the curiosity of Sir Maximus,
8928: and Philip did not wish to tell any one the contents of the letter until
8929: he had shown them to his uncle. He determined to ride over to the
8930: rectory to lunch; for as Lady Mary was away, he and his uncle might be
8931: _tête-á-tête_.
8932: 
8933: The rectory was on the other side of the river, close to the church of
8934: which it was the fitting companion: a fine old brick-and-stone house,
8935: with a great bow-window opening from the library on to the deep-turfed
8936: lawn, one fat dog sleeping on the door-stone, another fat dog waddling
8937: on the gravel, the autumn leaves duly swept away, the lingering
8938: chrysanthemums cherished, tall trees stooping or soaring in the most
8939: picturesque variety, and a Virginian creeper turning a little rustic hut
8940: into a scarlet pavilion. It was one of those rectories which are among
8941: the bulwarks of our venerable institutions--which arrest disintegrating
8942: doubt, serve as a double embankment against Popery and Dissent, and
8943: rally feminine instinct and affection to reinforce the decisions of
8944: masculine thought.
8945: 
8946: "What makes you look so merry, Phil?" said the rector, as his nephew
8947: entered the pleasant library.
8948: 
8949: "Something that concerns you," said Philip, taking out the letter. "A
8950: clerical challenge. Here's an opportunity for you to emulate the divines
8951: of the sixteenth century and have a theological duel. Read this letter."
8952: 
8953: "What answer have you sent the crazy little fellow?" said the rector,
8954: keeping the letter in his hand and running over it again and again, with
8955: brow knit, but eyes gleaming without any malignity.
8956: 
8957: "Oh, I sent no answer. I awaited yours."
8958: 
8959: "Mine!" said the rector, throwing down the letter on the table. "You
8960: don't suppose I'm going to hold a public debate with a schismatic of
8961: that sort? I should have an infidel shoemaker next expecting me to
8962: answer blasphemies delivered in bad grammar."
8963: 
8964: "But you see how he puts it," said Philip. With all his gravity of
8965: nature he could not resist a slightly mischievous prompting, though he
8966: had a serious feeling that he should not like to be regarded as failing
8967: to fulfill his pledge. "I think if you refuse, I shall be obliged to
8968: offer myself."
8969: 
8970: "Nonsense! Tell him he is himself acting a dishonorable part in
8971: interpreting your words as a pledge to do any preposterous thing that
8972: suits his fancy. Suppose he had asked you to give him land to build a
8973: chapel on; doubtless that would have given him a 'lively satisfaction.'
8974: A man who puts a non-natural, strained sense on a promise is no better
8975: than a robber."
8976: 
8977: "But he has not asked for land. I dare say he thinks you won't object to
8978: his proposal. I confess there's a simplicity and quaintness about the
8979: letter that rather pleases me."
8980: 
8981: "Let me tell you, Phil, he's a crazy little firefly, that does a great
8982: deal of harm in my parish. He inflames the Dissenters' minds on
8983: politics. There's no end to the mischief done by these busy, prating
8984: men. They make the ignorant multitude the judges of the largest
8985: questions, both political and religious, till we shall soon have no
8986: institution left that is not on a level with the comprehension of a
8987: huckster or a drayman. There can be nothing more retrograde--losing all
8988: the results of civilization, all the lessons of Providence--letting the
8989: windlass run down after men have been turning at it painfully for
8990: generations. If the instructed are not to judge for the uninstructed,
8991: why, let us set Dick Stubbs to make our almanacs, and have a President
8992: of the Royal Society elected by universal suffrage."
8993: 
8994: The rector had risen, placed himself with his back to the fire, and
8995: thrust his hands in his pockets, ready to insist further on this wide
8996: argument. Philip sat nursing one leg, listening respectfully, as he
8997: always did, though often listening to the sonorous echo of his own
8998: statements, which suited his uncle's needs so exactly that he did not
8999: distinguish them from his own impressions.
9000: 
9001: "True," said Philip; "but in special cases we have to do with special
9002: conditions. You know I defend the casuists. And it may happen that, for
9003: the honor of the church in Treby, and a little also for my honor,
9004: circumstances may demand a concession even to some notions of a
9005: Dissenting preacher."
9006: 
9007: "Not at all. I should be making a figure which my brother clergy might
9008: well take as an affront to themselves. The character of the
9009: Establishment has suffered enough already through the Evangelicals, with
9010: their extempore incoherence and their pipe-smoking piety. Look at
9011: Wimple, the man who is vicar of Shuttleton--without his gown and bands
9012: anybody would take him for a grocer in mourning."
9013: 
9014: "Well, I shall cut a still worse figure, and so will you, in the
9015: Dissenting magazines and newspapers. It will go the round of the
9016: kingdom. There will be a paragraph headed, 'Tory Falsehood and Clerical
9017: Cowardice,' or else, 'The Meanness of the Aristocracy and the
9018: Incompetence of the Beneficed Clergy.'"
9019: 
9020: "There would be a worse paragraph if I were to consent to the debate. Of
9021: course it would be said that I was beaten hollow, and, that now the
9022: question had been cleared up at Treba Magna, the Church had not a sound
9023: leg to stand on. Besides," the rector went on, frowning and smiling,
9024: "it's all very well for you to talk, Phil; but this debating is not so
9025: easy when a man's close upon sixty. What one writes or says must be
9026: something good and scholarly; and, after all had been done, this little
9027: Lyon would buzz about one like a wasp, and cross-question and rejoin.
9028: Let me tell you, a plain truth may be so worried and mauled by fallacies
9029: as to get the worst of it. There's no such thing as tiring a
9030: talking-machine like Lyon."
9031: 
9032: "Then you absolutely refuse?"
9033: 
9034: "Yes, I do."
9035: 
9036: "You remember that when I wrote my letter of thanks to Lyon you approved
9037: my offer to serve him if possible."
9038: 
9039: "Certainly I remember it. But suppose he had asked you to vote for civil
9040: marriage, or to go and hear him preach every Sunday?"
9041: 
9042: "But he has not asked that."
9043: 
9044: "Something as unreasonable, though."
9045: 
9046: "Well," said Philip, taking up Mr. Lyon's letter and looking
9047: graver--looking even vexed, "it is rather an unpleasant business for me.
9048: I really felt obliged to him. I think there's a sort of worth in the man
9049: beyond his class. Whatever may be the reason of the case, I shall
9050: disappoint him instead of doing him the service I offered."
9051: 
9052: "Well, that's a misfortune; we can't help it."
9053: 
9054: "The worst of it is, I should be insulting him to say, 'I will do
9055: anything else, but not just this that you want.' He evidently feels
9056: himself in company with Luther and Zwingle and Calvin, and considers our
9057: letters part of the history of Protestantism."
9058: 
9059: "Yes, yes. I know it's rather an unpleasant thing, Phil. You are aware
9060: that I would have done anything in reason to prevent you from becoming
9061: unpopular here. I consider your character a possession to all of us."
9062: 
9063: "I think I must call on him forthwith and explain and apologize."
9064: 
9065: "No, sit still; I've thought of something," said the rector, with a
9066: sudden revival of spirits. "I've just seen Sherlock coming in. He is to
9067: lunch with me to-day. It would do no harm for him to hold the debate--a
9068: curate and a young man--he'll gain by it; and it would release you from
9069: any awkwardness, Phil. Sherlock is not going to stay here long, you
9070: know; he'll soon have his title. I'll put the thing to him. He won't
9071: object if I wish it. It's a capital idea. It will do Sherlock good. He's
9072: a clever fellow, but he wants confidence."
9073: 
9074: Philip had not time to object before Mr. Sherlock appeared--a young
9075: divine of good birth and figure, of sallow complexion and bashful
9076: address.
9077: 
9078: "Sherlock, you have come in most opportunely," said the rector. "A case
9079: has turned up in the parish in which you can be of eminent use. I know
9080: that is what you have desired ever since you have been with me. But I'm
9081: about so much myself that there really has not been sphere enough for
9082: you. You are a studious man, I know; I dare say you have all the
9083: necessary matter prepared--at your finger-ends, if not on paper."
9084: 
9085: Mr. Sherlock smiled with rather a trembling lip, willing to distinguish
9086: himself, but hoping that the rector only alluded to a dialogue on
9087: Baptism by Aspersion, or some other pamphlet suited to the purposes of
9088: the Christian Knowledge Society. But as the rector proceeded to unfold
9089: the circumstances under which his eminent service was to be rendered, he
9090: grew more and more nervous.
9091: 
9092: "You'll oblige me very much, Sherlock," the rector ended, "by going into
9093: this thing zealously. Can you guess what time you will require? because
9094: it will rest with us to fix the day."
9095: 
9096: "I should be rejoiced to oblige you, Mr. Debarry, but I really think I
9097: am not competent to----"
9098: 
9099: "That's your modesty, Sherlock. Don't let me hear any more of that. I
9100: know Filmore of Corpus said you might be a first-rate man if your
9101: diffidence didn't do you injustice. And you can refer anything to me,
9102: you know. Come, you will set about the thing at once. But, Phil, you
9103: must tell the preacher to send a scheme of the debate--all the different
9104: heads--and he must agree to keep rigidly within the scheme. There, sit
9105: down at my desk and write the letter now; Thomas shall carry it."
9106: 
9107: Philip sat down to write, and the rector, with his firm ringing voice,
9108: went on at his ease, giving "indications" to his agitated curate.
9109: 
9110: "But you can begin at once preparing a good, cogent, clear statement,
9111: and considering the probable points of assault. You can look into Jewel,
9112: Hall, Hooker, Whitgift, and the rest: you'll find them all here. My
9113: library wants nothing in English divinity. Sketch the lower ground taken
9114: by Usher and those men, but bring all your force to bear on marking out
9115: the true High-Church doctrine. Expose the wretched cavils of the
9116: Noncomformists, and the noisy futility that belongs to schismatics
9117: generally. I will give you a telling passage from Burke on the
9118: Dissenters, and some good quotations which I brought together in two
9119: sermons of my own on the Position of the English Church in Christendom.
9120: How long do you think it will take you to bring your thoughts together?
9121: You can throw them afterward into the form of an essay; we'll have the
9122: thing printed; it will do you good with the Bishop."
9123: 
9124: With all Mr. Sherlock's timidity, there was fascination for him in this
9125: distinction. He reflected that he could take coffee and sit up late, and
9126: perhaps produce something rather fine. It might be a first step toward
9127: that eminence which it was no more than his duty to aspire to. Even a
9128: polemical fame like that of a Philpotts must have had a beginning. Mr.
9129: Sherlock was not insensible to the pleasure of turning sentences
9130: successfully, and it was a pleasure not always unconnected with
9131: preferment. A diffident man likes the idea of doing something
9132: remarkable, which will create belief in him without any immediate
9133: display of brilliancy. Celebrity may blush and be silent, and win a
9134: grace the more. Thus Mr. Sherlock was constrained, trembling all the
9135: while, and much wishing that his essay were already in print.
9136: 
9137: "I think I could hardly be ready under a fortnight."
9138: 
9139: "Very good. Just write that, Phil, and tell him to fix the precise day
9140: and place. And then we'll go to lunch."
9141: 
9142: The rector was quite satisfied. He had talked himself into thinking that
9143: he should like to give Sherlock a few useful hints, look up his own
9144: earlier sermons, and benefit the curate by his criticism, when the
9145: argument had been got into shape. He was a healthy-natured man, but that
9146: was not at all a reason why he should not have those sensibilities to
9147: the odor of authorship which belong to almost everybody who is not
9148: expected to be a writer--and especially to that form of authorship
9149: which is called suggestion, and consists in telling another man that he
9150: might do a great deal with a given subject, by bringing a sufficient
9151: amount of knowledge, reasoning, and wit to bear upon it.
9152: 
9153: Philip would have had some twinges of conscience about the curate, if he
9154: had not guessed that the honor thrust upon him was not altogether
9155: disagreeable. The Church might perhaps have had a stronger supporter;
9156: but for himself, he had done what he was bound to do: he had done his
