9157: best toward fulfilling Mr. Lyon's desire.
9158: 
9159: 
9160: 
9161: 
9162: CHAPTER XXIV.
9163: 
9164:     If he come not, the play is marred.--_Midsummer Night's Dream._
9165: 
9166: 
9167: Rufus Lyon was very happy on that mild November morning appointed for
9168: the great conference in the larger room at the Free School, between
9169: himself and the Reverend Theodore Sherlock, B.A. The disappointment of
9170: not contending with the rector in person, which had at first been
9171: bitter, had been gradually lost sight of in the positive enjoyment of an
9172: opportunity for debating on any terms. Mr. Lyon had two grand elements
9173: of pleasure on such occasions: confidence in the strength of his case,
9174: and confidence in his own power of advocacy. Not--to use his own
9175: phrase--not that "he glorified himself herein;" for speech and
9176: exposition were so easy to him, that if he argued forcibly, he believed
9177: it to be simply because the truth was forcible. He was not proud of
9178: moving easily in his native medium. A panting man thinks of himself as a
9179: clever swimmer; but a fish swims much better, and takes his performance
9180: as a matter of course.
9181: 
9182: Whether Mr. Sherlock were that panting, self-gratulating man, remained a
9183: secret. Philip Debarry, much occupied with his electioneering affairs,
9184: had only once had an opportunity of asking his uncle how Sherlock got
9185: on, and the rector had said, curtly, "I think he'll do. I've supplied
9186: him well with references. I advise him to read only, and decline
9187: everything else as out of order. Lyon will speak to a point, and then
9188: Sherlock will read: it will be all the more telling. It will give
9189: variety." But on this particular morning peremptory business connected
9190: with the magistracy called the rector away.
9191: 
9192: Due notice had been given, and the feminine world of Treby Magna was
9193: much more agitated by the prospect than by that of any candidate's
9194: speech. Mrs. Pendrell at the Bank, Mrs. Tiliot, and the Church ladies
9195: generally felt bound to hear the curate, who was known, apparently by an
9196: intuition concerning the nature of curates, to be a very clever young
9197: man; and he would show them what learning had to say on the right side.
9198: One or two Dissenting ladies were not without emotion at the thought
9199: that, seated on the front benches, they should be brought near to old
9200: Church friends, and have a longer greeting than had taken place since
9201: the Catholic Emancipation. Mrs. Muscat, who had been a beauty, and was
9202: as nice in her millinery as any Trebian lady belonging to the
9203: Establishment, reflected that she should put on her best embroidered
9204: collar, and that she should ask Mrs. Tiliot where it was in Duffield
9205: that she once got her bed-hanging dyed so beautifully. When Mrs. Tiliot
9206: was Mary Salt, the two ladies had been bosom friends; but Mr. Tiliot
9207: looked higher and higher since his gin had become so famous; and in the
9208: year '29 he had, in Mr. Muscat's hearing, spoken of Dissenters as
9209: sneaks--a personality which could not be overlooked.
9210: 
9211: The debate was to begin at eleven, for the rector would not allow the
9212: evening to be chosen, when low men and boys might want to be admitted
9213: out of mere mischief. This was one reason why the female part of the
9214: audience outnumbered the males. But some chief Trebians were there, even
9215: men whose means made them as independent of theory as Mr. Pendrell and
9216: Mr. Wace; encouraged by reflecting that they were not in a place of
9217: worship, and would not be obliged to stay longer than they chose. There
9218: was a muster of all Dissenters who could spare the morning time, and on
9219: the back benches were all the aged Churchwomen who shared the remnants
9220: of the sacrament wine, and who were humbly anxious to neglect nothing
9221: ecclesiastical or connected with "going to a better place."
9222: 
9223: At eleven the arrival of listeners seemed to have ceased. Mr. Lyon was
9224: seated on the school tribune or dais at his particular round table;
9225: another round table, with a chair, awaited the curate, with whose
9226: superior position it was quite in keeping that he should not be the
9227: first on the ground. A couple of extra chairs were placed farther back,
9228: and more than one important personage had been requested to act as
9229: chairman; but no Churchman would place himself in a position so
9230: equivocal as to dignity of aspect, and so unequivocal as to the
9231: obligation of sitting out the discussion; and the rector had beforehand
9232: put a veto on any Dissenting chairman.
9233: 
9234: Mr. Lyon sat patiently absorbed in his thoughts, with his notes in
9235: minute handwriting lying before him, seeming to look at the audience,
9236: but not seeing them. Every one else was contented that there should be
9237: an interval in which there could be a little neighborly talk.
9238: 
9239: Esther was particularly happy, seated on a side-bench near her father's
9240: side of the tribune, with Felix close behind her, so that she could turn
9241: her head and talk to him. He had been very kind ever since that morning
9242: when she had called at his home, more disposed to listen indulgently to
9243: what she had to say, and less blind to her looks and movements. If he
9244: had never railed at her or ignored her, she would have been less
9245: sensitive to the attention he gave her; but as it was, the prospect of
9246: seeing him seemed to light up her life, and to disperse the old
9247: dullness. She looked unusually charming to-day, from the very fact that
9248: she was not vividly conscious of anything but of having a mind near her
9249: that asked her to be something better than she actually was. The
9250: consciousness of her own superiority amongst the people around her was
9251: superseded, and even a few brief weeks had given a softened expression
9252: to her eyes, a more feminine beseechingness and self-doubt to her
9253: manners. Perhaps, however, a little new defiance was rising in place of
9254: the old contempt--defiance of the Trebian views about Felix Holt.
9255: 
9256: "What a very nice-looking young woman your minister's daughter is?" said
9257: Mrs. Tiliot in an undertone to Mrs. Muscat, who, as she had hoped, had
9258: found a seat next her quondam friend--"quite the lady."
9259: 
9260: "Rather too much so, considering," said Mrs. Muscat. "She's thought
9261: proud, and that is not pretty in a girl, even if there was anything to
9262: back it up. But now she seems to be encouraging that young Holt, who
9263: scoffs at everything, as you may judge by his appearance. She has
9264: despised his betters before now; but I leave you to judge whether a
9265: young man who has taken to low ways of getting a living can pay for fine
9266: cambric handkerchiefs and light kid gloves."
9267: 
9268: Mrs. Muscat lowered her blonde eyelashes and swayed her neat head just
9269: perceptibly from side to side, with a sincere desire to be moderate in
9270: her expressions, notwithstanding any shock that facts might have given
9271: her.
9272: 
9273: "Dear, dear," said Mrs. Tiliot. "What! that is young Holt leaning
9274: forward now without a cravat? I've never seen him before to notice him,
9275: but I've heard Tiliot talking about him. They say he's a dangerous
9276: character, and goes stirring up the workingmen at Sproxton. And--well,
9277: to be sure, such great eyes and such a great head of hair--it is enough
9278: to frighten one. What can she see in him? Quite below her."
9279: 
9280: "Yes, and brought up a governess," said Mrs. Muscat; "you'd have thought
9281: she'd knowed better how to choose. But the minister has let her get the
9282: upper hand sadly too much. It's a pity in a man of God. I don't deny
9283: he's _that_."
9284: 
9285: "Well, I am sorry," said Mrs. Tiliot, "for I meant her to give my girls
9286: lessons when they came from school."
9287: 
9288: Mr. Wace and Mr. Pendrell meanwhile were standing up and looking round
9289: at the audience, nodding to their fellow-townspeople with the affability
9290: due from men in their position.
9291: 
9292: "It's time he came now," said Mr. Wace, looking at his watch and
9293: comparing it with the schoolroom clock. "This debating is a new-fangled
9294: sort of thing; but the rector would never have given in to it if there
9295: hadn't been good reasons. Nolan said he wouldn't come. He says this
9296: debating is an atheistical sort of thing; the Atheists are very fond of
9297: it. Theirs is a bad book to take a leaf out of. However, we shall hear
9298: nothing but what's good from Mr. Sherlock. He preaches a capital
9299: sermon--for such a young man."
9300: 
9301: "Well, it was our duty to support him--not to leave him alone among the
9302: Dissenters," said Mr. Pendrell. "You see everybody hasn't felt that.
9303: Labron might have shown himself, if not Lukyn. I could have alleged
9304: business myself if I had thought proper."
9305: 
9306: "Here he comes, I think," said Mr. Wace, turning round on hearing a
9307: movement near the small door on a level with the platform. "By George!
9308: it's Mr. Debarry. Come now, this is handsome."
9309: 
9310: Mr. Wace and Mr. Pendrell clapped their hands, and the example was
9311: followed even by most of the Dissenters. Philip was aware that he was
9312: doing a popular thing, of a kind that Treby was not used to from the
9313: elder Debarrys; but his appearance had not been long premeditated. He
9314: was driving through the town toward an engagement at some distance, but
9315: on calling at Labron's office he had found that the affair which
9316: demanded his presence had been deferred, and so had driven round to the
9317: Free School. Christian came in behind him.
9318: 
9319: Mr. Lyon was now roused from his abstraction, and, stepping from his
9320: slight elevation, begged Mr. Debarry to act as moderator or president on
9321: the occasion.
9322: 
9323: "With all my heart," said Philip. "But Mr. Sherlock has not arrived,
9324: apparently?"
9325: 
9326: "He tarries somewhat unduly," said Mr. Lyon. "Nevertheless there may be
9327: a reason of which we know not. Shall I collect the thoughts of the
9328: assembly by a brief introductory address in the interval?"
9329: 
9330: "No, no, no," said Mr. Wace, who saw a limit to his powers of endurance.
9331: "Mr. Sherlock is sure to be here in a minute or two."
9332: 
9333: "Christian," said Philip Debarry, who felt a slight misgiving, "just be
9334: so good--but stay, I'll go myself. Excuse me, gentlemen: I'll drive
9335: round to Mr. Sherlock's lodgings. He may be under a little mistake as to
9336: the time. Studious men are sometimes rather absent-minded. You needn't
9337: come with me, Christian."
9338: 
9339: As Mr. Debarry went out, Rufus Lyon stepped on to the tribune again in
9340: rather an uneasy state of mind. A few ideas had occurred to him,
9341: eminently fitted to engage the audience profitably, and so to wrest some
9342: edification out of an unforeseen delay. But his native delicacy made him
9343: feel that in this assembly the Church people might fairly decline any
9344: "deliverance" on his part which exceeded the programme, and Mr. Wace's
9345: negative had been energetic. But the little man suffered from imprisoned
9346: ideas, and was as restless as a racer held in. He could not sit down
9347: again, but walked backward and forward, stroking his chin, emitting his
9348: low guttural interjections under the pressure of clauses and sentences
9349: which he longed to utter aloud, as he would have done in his own study.
9350: There was a low buzz in the room which helped to deepen the minister's
9351: sense that the thoughts within him were as divine messengers unheeded or
9352: rejected by a trivial generation. Many of the audience were standing;
9353: all, except the old Churchwomen on the back seats, and a few devout
9354: Dissenters who kept their eyes shut and gave their bodies a gentle
9355: oscillating motion, were interested in chat.
9356: 
9357: "Your father is uneasy," said Felix to Esther.
9358: 
9359: "Yes; and now, I think, he is feeling for his spectacles. I hope he has
9360: not left them at home: he will not be able to see anything two yards
9361: before him without them;--and it makes him so unconscious of what people
9362: expect or want."
9363: 
9364: "I'll go and ask him whether he has them," said Felix, striding over the
9365: form in front of him, and approaching Mr. Lyon, whose face showed a
9366: gleam of pleasure at this relief from his abstracted isolation.
9367: 
9368: "Miss Lyon is afraid that you are at a loss for your spectacles, sir,"
9369: said Felix.
9370: 
9371: "My dear young friend," said Mr. Lyon, laying his hand on Felix Holt's
9372: fore-arm, which was about on a level with the minister's shoulder, "it
9373: is a very glorious truth, albeit made somewhat painful to me by the
9374: circumstances of the present moment, that as a counterpoise to the
9375: brevity of our mortal life (wherein, as I apprehend, our powers are
9376: being trained not only for the transmission of an improved heritage, as
9377: I have heard you insist, but also for our own entrance into a higher
9378: initiation in the Divine scheme)--it is, I say, a very glorious truth,
9379: that even in what are called the waste minutes of our time, like those
9380: of expectation, the soul may soar and range, as in some of our dreams
9381: which are brief as a broken rainbow in duration, yet seem to comprise a
9382: long history of terror or joy. And again, each moment may be a beginning
9383: of a new spiritual energy; and our pulse would doubtless be a coarse and
9384: clumsy notation of the passage from that which was not to that which is,
9385: even in the finer processes of the material world--and how much
9386: more----"
9387: 
9388: Esther was watching her father and Felix, and though she was not within
9389: hearing of what was being said, she guessed the actual state of the
9390: case--that the enquiry about the spectacles had been unheeded, and that
9391: her father was losing himself and embarrassing Felix in the intricacies
9392: of a dissertation. There was not the stillness around her that would
9393: have made a movement on her part seem conspicuous, and she was impelled
9394: by her anxiety to step on the tribune and walk up to her father, who
9395: paused a little startled.
9396: 
9397: "Pray see whether you have forgotten your spectacles, father. If so, I
9398: will go home at once and look for them."
9399: 
9400: Mr. Lyon was automatically obedient to Esther, and he began immediately
9401: to feel in his pockets.
9402: 
9403: "How is it that Miss Jermyn is so friendly with the Dissenting parson?"
9404: said Christian to Quorlen, the Tory printer, who was an intimate of his.
9405: "Those grand Jermyns are not Dissenters surely?"
9406: 
9407: "_What_ Miss Jermyn?"
9408: 
9409: "Why--don't you see?--that fine girl who is talking to him."
9410: 
9411: "Miss Jermyn! Why, that's the little parson's daughter."
9412: 
9413: "His daughter!" Christian gave a low brief whistle, which seemed a
9414: natural expression of surprise that "the rusty old ranter" should have a
9415: daughter of such distinguished appearance.
9416: 
9417: Meanwhile the search for the spectacles had proved vain. "'Tis a
9418: grievous fault in me, my dear," said the little man, humbly; "I become
9419: thereby sadly burdensome to you."
9420: 
9421: "I will go at once," said Esther, refusing to let Felix go instead of
9422: her. But she had scarcely stepped off the tribune when Mr. Debarry
9423: re-entered, and there was a commotion which made her wait. After a
9424: low-toned conversation with Mr. Pendrell and Mr. Wace, Philip Debarry
9425: stepped on to the tribune with his hat in his hand and said, with an air
9426: of much concern and annoyance--
9427: 
9428: "I am sorry to have to tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that--doubtless
9429: owing to some accidental cause which I trust will soon be explained as
9430: nothing serious--Mr. Sherlock is absent from his residence and is not to
9431: be found. He went out early, his landlady informs me, to refresh himself
9432: by a walk on this agreeable morning, as is his habit, she tells me, when
9433: he has been kept up late by study; and he has not returned. Do not let
9434: us be too anxious. I shall cause enquiry to be made in the direction of
9435: his walk. It is easy to imagine many accidents, not of a grave
9436: character, by which he might nevertheless be absolutely detained against
9437: his will. Under these circumstances, Mr. Lyon," continued Philip,
9438: turning to the minister, "I presume that the debate must be adjourned."
9439: 
9440: "The debate, doubtless," began Mr. Lyon; but his farther speech was
9441: drowned by a general rising of the Church people from their seats, many
9442: of them feeling that, even if the cause were lamentable, the adjournment
9443: was not altogether disagreeable.
9444: 
9445: "Good gracious me!" said Mrs. Tiliot, as she took her husband's arm, "I
9446: hope the poor young man hasn't fallen into the river or broken his leg."
9447: 
9448: But some of the more acrid Dissenters, whose temper was not controlled
9449: by the habits of retail business, had begun to hiss, implying that in
9450: their interpretation the curate's absence had not depended on any injury
9451: to life or limb.
9452: 
9453: "He's turned tail, sure enough," said Mr. Muscat to the neighbor behind
9454: him, lifting his eyebrows and shoulders, and laughing in a way that
9455: showed that, deacon as he was, he looked at the affair in an entirely
9456: secular light.
9457: 
9458: But Mrs. Muscat thought it would be nothing but right to have all the
9459: waters dragged, agreeing in this with the majority of the Church ladies.
9460: 
9461: "I regret sincerely, Mr. Lyon," said Philip Debarry, addressing the
9462: minister with politeness, "that I must say good-morning to you, with the
9463: sense that I have not been able at present to contribute to your
9464: satisfaction as I had wished."
9465: 
9466: "Speak not of it in the way of apology, sir," said Mr. Lyon, in a tone
9467: of depression. "I doubt not that you yourself have acted in good faith.
9468: Nor will I open any door of egress to constructions such as anger often
9469: deems ingenious, but which the disclosure of the simple truth may expose
9470: as erroneous and uncharitable fabrications. I wish you good-morning,
9471: sir."
9472: 
9473: When the room was cleared of the Church people, Mr. Lyon wished to
9474: soothe his own spirit and that of his flock by a few reflections
9475: introductory to a parting prayer. But there was a general resistance to
9476: this effort. The men mustered round the minister and declared their
9477: opinion that the whole thing was disgraceful to the Church. Some said
9478: that the curate's absence had been contrived from the first. Others more
9479: than hinted that it had been a folly in Mr. Lyon to set on foot any
9480: procedure in common with Tories and clergymen, who, if they ever aped
9481: civility to Dissenters, would never do anything but laugh at them in
9482: their sleeves. Brother Kemp urged in his heavy bass that Mr. Lyon should
9483: lose no time in sending an account of the affair to the _Patriot_; and
9484: brother Hawkins, in his high tenor, observed that it was an occasion on
9485: which some stinging things might be said with all the extra effect of an
9486: _apropos_.
9487: 
9488: The position of receiving a many-voiced lecture from the members of his
9489: church was familiar to Mr. Lyon; but now he felt weary, frustrated, and
9490: doubtful of his own temper. Felix, who stood by and saw that this man of
9491: sensitive fibre was suffering from talkers whose noisy superficiality
9492: cost them nothing, got exasperated. "It seems to me, sirs," he burst in,
9493: with his predominant voice, "that Mr. Lyon has hitherto had the hard
9494: part of the business, while you of his congregation have had the easy
9495: one. Punish the Church clergy, if you like--they can take care of
9496: themselves. But don't punish your own minister. It's no business of
9497: mine, perhaps, except so far as fair-play is everybody's business; but
9498: it seems to me the time to ask Mr. Lyon to take a little rest, instead
9499: of setting on him like so many wasps."
9500: 
9501: By this speech Felix raised a displeasure which fell on the minister as
9502: well as on himself; but he gained his immediate end. The talkers dropped
9503: off after a slight show of persistence, and Mr. Lyon quitted the field
9504: of no combat with a small group of his less imperious friends, to whom
9505: he confided his intention of committing his argument fully to paper,
9506: and forwarding it to a discriminating editor.
9507: 
9508: "But regarding personalities," he added, "I have not the same clear
9509: showing. For, say that this young man was pusillanimous--I were but
9510: ill-provided with arguments if I took my stand even for a moment on so
9511: poor an irrelevancy as that because one curate is ill furnished
9512: therefore Episcopacy is false. If I held up any one to just obloquy, it
9513: would be the well-designated Incumbent of this parish, who, calling
9514: himself one of the Church militant, sends a young and weak-kneed
9515: substitute to take his place in the fight."
9516: 
9517: Mr. Philip Debarry did not neglect to make industrious enquiry
9518: concerning the accidents which had detained the Reverend Theodore
9519: Sherlock on his morning walk. That well-intentioned young divine was
9520: seen no more in Treby Magna. But the river was not dragged, for by the
9521: evening coach the rector received an explanatory letter. The Reverend
9522: Theodore's agitation had increased so much during his walk, that the
9523: passing coach had been a means of deliverance not to be resisted; and,
9524: literally at the eleventh hour, he had hailed and mounted the cheerful
9525: Tally-ho! and carried away his portion of the debate in his pocket.
9526: 
9527: But the rector had subsequently the satisfaction of receiving Mr.
9528: Sherlock's painstaking production in print, with a dedication to the
9529: Reverend Augustus Debarry, a motto from St. Chrysostom, and other
9530: additions, the fruit of ripening leisure. He was "sorry for poor
9531: Sherlock, who wanted confidence"; but he was convinced that for his own
9532: part he had taken the course which under the circumstances was the least
9533: compromising to the Church. Sir Maximus, however, observed to his son
9534: and brother that he had been right and they had been wrong as to the
9535: danger of vague, enormous expressions of gratitude to a Dissenting
9536: preacher, and on any differences of opinion seldom failed to remind them
9537: of that precedent.
9538: 
9539: 
9540: 
9541: 
9542: CHAPTER XXV.
9543: 
9544:     Your fellow-man?--Divide the epithet:
9545:     Say rather, you're the fellow, he the man.
9546: 
9547: 
9548: When Christian quitted the Free School with the discovery that the young
9549: lady whose appearance had first startled him with an indefinable
9550: impression in the market-place was the daughter of the old Dissenting
9551: preacher who had shown so much agitated curiosity about his name, he
9552: felt very much like an uninitiated chess-player, who sees that the
9553: pieces are in a peculiar position on the board, and might open the way
9554: for him to give checkmate, if he only knew how. Ever since his interview
9555: with Jermyn, his mind had been occupied with the charade it offered to
9556: his ingenuity. What was the real meaning of the lawyer's interest in
9557: him, and in his relations with Maurice Christian Bycliffe? Here was a
9558: secret; and secrets were often a source of profit, of that agreeable
9559: kind which involved little labor. Jermyn had hinted at profit which
9560: might possibly come through him; but Christian said inwardly, with
9561: well-satisfied self-esteem, that he was not so pitiable a nincompoop as
9562: to trust Jermyn. On the contrary, the only problem before him was to
9563: find out by what combination of independent knowledge he could outwit
9564: Jermyn, elude any purchase the attorney had on him through his past
9565: history, and get a handsome bonus, by which a somewhat shattered man of
9566: pleasure might live well without a master. Christian, having early
9567: exhausted the more impulsive delights of life, had become a sober
9568: calculator; and he had made up his mind that, for a man who had long ago
9569: run through his own money, servitude in a great family was the best kind
9570: of retirement after that of a pensioner; but if a better chance offered,
9571: a person of talent must not let it slip through his fingers. He held
9572: various ends of threads, but there was danger of pulling at them too
9573: impatiently. He had not forgotten the surprise which had made him drop
9574: the punch-ladle, when Mr. Crowder, talking in the steward's room, had
9575: said that a scamp named Henry Scaddon had been concerned in a lawsuit
9576: about the Transome estate. Again, Jermyn was the family lawyer of the
9577: Transomes; he knew of the exchange of names between Scaddon and
9578: Bycliffe; he clearly wanted to know as much as he could about Bycliffe's
9579: history. The conclusion was not remote that Bycliffe had had some claim
9580: on the Transome property, and that a difficulty had arisen from his
9581: being confounded with Henry Scaddon. But hitherto the other incident
9582: which had been apparently connected with the interchange of names--Mr.
9583: Lyon's demand that he should write down the name Maurice Christian,
9584: accompanied with the question whether that were his whole name--had had
9585: no visible link with the inferences arrived at through Crowder and
9586: Jermyn.
9587: 
9588: The discovery made this morning at the Free School that Esther was the
9589: daughter of the Dissenting preacher at last suggested a possible link.
9590: Until then, Christian had not known why Esther's face had impressed him
9591: so peculiarly; but the minister's chief association for him was with
9592: Bycliffe, and that association served as a flash to show him that
9593: Esther's features and expression, and still more her bearing, now she
9594: stood and walked, revived Bycliffe's image. Daughter? There were various
9595: ways of being a daughter. Suppose this were a case of adoption; suppose
9596: Bycliffe were known to be dead, or thought to be dead. "Begad, if the
9597: old parson had fancied the original father was come to life again, it
9598: was enough to frighten him a little. Slow and steady," Christian said to
9599: himself; "I'll get some talk with the old man again. He's safe enough:
9600: one can handle him without cutting one's self. I'll tell him I knew
9601: Bycliffe, and was his fellow-prisoner. I'll worm out the truth about
9602: this daughter. Could pretty Annette have married again, and married this
9603: little scare-crow? There's no knowing what a woman will not do."
9604: 
9605: Christian could see no distinct result for himself from his industry;
9606: but if there were to be any such result, it must be reached by following
9607: out every clue; and to the non-legal mind there are dim possibilities in
9608: law and heirship which prevent any issue from seeming too miraculous.
9609: 
9610: The consequence of these meditations was, that Christian hung about
9611: Treby more than usual in his leisure time, and that on the first
9612: opportunity he accosted Mr. Lyon in the street with suitable civility,
9613: stating that since the occasion which had brought them together some
9614: weeks before he had often wished to renew their conversation, and, with
9615: Mr. Lyon's permission, would now ask to do so. After being assured, as
9616: he had been by Jermyn, that this courier, who had happened by some
9617: accident to possess the memorable locket and pocket-book, was certainly
9618: not Annette's husband, and was ignorant whether Maurice Christian
9619: Bycliffe were living or dead, the minister's mind had become easy again;
9620: his habitual lack of interest in personal details rendering him
9621: gradually oblivious of Jermyn's precautionary statement that he was
9622: pursuing enquiries, and that if anything of interest turned up, Mr. Lyon
9623: should be made acquainted with it. Hence, when Christian addressed him,
9624: the minister, taken by surprise and shaken by the recollections of
9625: former anxieties, said, helplessly--
9626: 
9627: "If it is business, sir, you would perhaps do better to address yourself
9628: to Mr. Jermyn."
9629: 
9630: He could not have said anything that was a more valuable hint to
9631: Christian. He inferred that the minister had made a confidant of Jermyn,
9632: and it was needful to be wary.
9633: 
9634: "On the contrary, sir," he answered, "it may be of the utmost importance
9635: to you that what passes between us should not be known to Mr. Jermyn."
9636: 
9637: Mr. Lyon was perplexed, and felt at once that he was no more in clear
9638: daylight concerning Jermyn than concerning Christian. He dared not
9639: neglect the possible duty of hearing what this man had to say, and he
9640: invited him to proceed to Malthouse Yard, where they could converse in
9641: private.
9642: 
9643: Once in Mr. Lyon's study, Christian opened the dialogue by saying that
9644: since he was in this room before it had occurred to him that the anxiety
9645: he had observed in Mr. Lyon might be owing to some acquaintance with
9646: Maurice Christian Bycliffe--a fellow-prisoner in France, whom he,
9647: Christian, had assisted in getting freed from his imprisonment, and who,
9648: in fact, had been the owner of the trifles which Mr. Lyon had recently
9649: had in his possession and had restored. Christian hastened to say that
9650: he knew nothing of Bycliffe's history since they had parted in France,
9651: but that he knew of his marriage with Annette Ledru, and had been
9652: acquainted with Annette herself. He would be very glad to know what
9653: became of Bycliffe, if he could, for he liked him uncommonly.
9654: 
9655: Here Christian paused; but Mr. Lyon only sat changing color and
9656: trembling. This man's bearing and tone of mind were made repulsive to
9657: him by being brought in contact with keenly-felt memories, and he could
9658: not readily summon the courage to give answers or ask questions.
9659: 
9660: "May I ask if you knew my friend Bycliffe?" said Christian, trying a
9661: more direct method.
9662: 
9663: "No, sir; I never saw him."
9664: 
9665: "Ah! well--you have seen a very striking likeness of him. It's
9666: wonderful--unaccountable; but when I saw Miss Lyon at the Free School
9667: the other day, I could have sworn she was Bycliffe's daughter."
9668: 
9669: "Sir!" said Mr. Lyon, in his deepest tone, half rising, and holding by
9670: the arms of his chair, "these subjects touch me with too sharp a point
9671: for you to be justified in thrusting them on me out of mere levity. Is
9672: there any good you seek or any injury you fear in relation to them?"
9673: 
9674: "Precisely, sir. We shall come to an understanding. Suppose I believed
9675: that the young lady who goes by the name of Miss Lyon was the daughter
9676: of Bycliffe?"
9677: 
9678: Mr. Lyon moved his lips silently.
9679: 
9680: "And suppose I had reason to suspect that there would be some great
9681: advantage for her if the law knew who was her father?"
9682: 
9683: "Sir!" said Mr. Lyon, shaken out of all reticence. "I would not conceal
9684: it. She believes herself to be my daughter. But I will bear all things
9685: rather than deprive her of a right. Nevertheless I appeal to the pity of
9686: any fellow-man, not to thrust himself between her and me, but to let me
9687: disclose the truth to her myself."
9688: 
9689: "All in good time," said Christian. "We must do nothing rash. Then Miss
9690: Lyon is Annette's child?"
9691: 
9692: The minister shivered as if the edge of a knife had been drawn across
9693: his hand. But the tone of this question, by the fact that it intensified
9694: his antipathy to Christian, enabled him to collect himself for what must
9695: be simply the endurance of a painful operation. After a moment or two he
9696: said more coolly, "It is true, sir. Her mother became my wife. Proceed
9697: with any statement which may concern my duty."
9698: 
9699: "I have no more to say than this: if there's a prize that the law might
9700: hand over to Bycliffe's daughter, I am much mistaken if there isn't a
9701: lawyer who'll take precious good care to keep the law hoodwinked. And
9702: that lawyer is Mat Jermyn. Why, my good sir, if you've been taking
9703: Jermyn into your confidence, you've been setting the fox to keep off the
9704: weasel. It strikes me that when you were made a little anxious about
9705: those articles of poor Bycliffe's, you put Jermyn on making enquiries of
9706: me. Eh? I think I am right?"
9707: 
9708: "I do not deny it."
9709: 
9710: "Ah!--it was very well you did, for by that means I've found that he's
9711: got hold of some secrets about Bycliffe which he means to stifle. Now,
9712: sir, if you desire any justice for your daughter--step-daughter, I
9713: should say--don't so much as wink to yourself before Jermyn; and if
9714: you've got any papers or things of that sort that may come in evidence,
9715: as these confounded rascals the lawyers call it, clutch them tight, for
9716: if they get into Jermyn's hands they may soon fly up the chimney. Have I
9717: said enough?"
9718: 
9719: "I had not purposed any further communication with Mr. Jermyn, sir;
9720: indeed, I have nothing further to communicate. Except that one fact
9721: concerning my daughter's birth, which I have erred in concealing from
9722: her, I neither seek disclosures nor do I tremble before them."
9723: 
9724: "Then I have your word that you will be silent about this conversation
9725: between us? It is for your daughter's interest, mind."
9726: 
9727: "Sir, I shall be silent," said Mr. Lyon, with cold gravity. "Unless,"
9728: he added, with an acumen as to possibilities rather disturbing to
9729: Christian's confident contempt for the old man--"unless I were called
9730: upon by some tribunal to declare the whole truth in this relation; in
9731: which case I should submit myself to that authority of investigation
9732: which is a requisite of social order."
9733: 
9734: Christian departed, feeling satisfied that he had got the utmost to be
9735: obtained at present out of the Dissenting preacher, whom he had not
9736: dared to question more closely. He must look out for chance lights, and
9737: perhaps, too, he might catch a stray hint by stirring the sediment of
9738: Mr. Crowder's memory. But he must not venture on enquiries that might be
9739: noticed.
9740: 
9741: When Mr. Lyon was alone he paced up and down among his books, and
9742: thought aloud, in order to relieve himself after the constraint of this
9743: interview. "I will not wait for the urgency of necessity," he said more
9744: than once. "I will tell the child without compulsion. And then I shall
9745: fear nothing. And an unwonted spirit of tenderness has filled her of
9746: late. She will forgive me."
9747: 
9748: 
9749: 
9750: 
9751: CHAPTER XXVI.
9752: 
9753:     Consideration like an angel came
9754:     And whipped the offending Adam out of her;
9755:     Leaving her body as a paradise
9756:     To envelope and contain celestial spirits.
9757: 
9758:                                        --SHAKESPEARE: _Henry V_.
9759: 
9760: 
9761: The next morning, after much prayer for the needful strength and wisdom,
9762: Mr. Lyon came down stairs with the resolution that another day should
9763: not pass without the fulfillment of the task he had laid on himself: but
9764: what hour he should choose for this solemn disclosure to Esther must
9765: depend on their mutual occupations. Perhaps he must defer it till they
9766: sat up alone together, after Lyddy was gone to bed. But at breakfast
9767: Esther said--
9768: 
9769: "To-day is a holiday, father. My pupils are all going to Duffield to see
9770: the wild beasts. What have you got to do to-day? Come, you are eating no
9771: breakfast. Oh, Lyddy, Lyddy, the eggs are hard again. I wish you would
9772: not read Alleyne's 'Alarm' before breakfast; it makes you cry and forget
9773: the eggs."
9774: 
9775: "They _are_ hard, and that's the truth; but there's hearts as are
9776: harder, Miss Esther," said Lyddy.
9777: 
9778: "I think not," said Esther. "This is leathery enough for the heart of
9779: the most obdurate Jew. Pray give it little Zachary for a football."
9780: 
9781: "Dear, dear, don't you be so light, miss. We may all be dead before
9782: night."
9783: 
9784: "You speak out of season, my good Lyddy," said Mr. Lyon, wearily;
9785: "depart into the kitchen."
9786: 
9787: "What have you got to do to-day, father?" persisted Esther. "I have a
9788: holiday."
9789: 
9790: Mr. Lyon felt as if this were a fresh summons not to delay. "I have
9791: something of great moment to do, my dear; and since you are not
9792: otherwise demanded, I will ask you to come and sit with me up-stairs."
9793: 
9794: Esther wondered what there could be on her father's mind more pressing
9795: than his morning studies.
9796: 
9797: Soon she knew. Motionless, but mentally stirred as she had never been
9798: before, Esther listened to her mother's story, and to the outpouring of
9799: her step-father's long-pent-up experience. The rays of the morning sun
9800: which fell athwart the books, the sense of the beginning day had
9801: deepened the solemnity more than night would have done. All knowledge
9802: which alters our lives penetrates us more when it comes in the early
9803: morning: the day that has to be travelled with something new and perhaps
9804: forever sad in its light, is an image of the life that spreads beyond.
9805: But at night the time of rest is near.
9806: 
9807: Mr. Lyon regarded his narrative as a confession--as a revelation to this
9808: beloved child of his own miserable weakness and error. But to her it
9809: seemed a revelation of another sort: her mind seemed suddenly enlarged
9810: by a vision of passion and struggle, of delight and renunciation, in the
9811: lot of beings who had hitherto been a dull enigma to her. And in the act
9812: of unfolding to her that he was not her real father, but had only
9813: striven to cherish her as a father, had only longed to be loved as a
9814: father, the odd, way-worn, unworldly man became the object of a new
9815: sympathy in which Esther exulted. Perhaps this knowledge would have been
9816: less powerful within her, but for the mental preparation that had come
9817: during the last two months from her acquaintance with Felix Holt, which
9818: had taught her to doubt the infallibility of her own standard, and
9819: raised a presentiment of moral depths that were hidden from her.
9820: 
9821: Esther had taken her place opposite to her father, and had not moved
9822: even her clasped hands while he was speaking. But after the long
9823: outpouring in which he seemed to lose the sense of everything but the
9824: memories he was giving utterance to, he paused a little while, and then
9825: said timidly--
9826: 
9827: "This is a late retrieval of a long error, Esther. I make not excuses
9828: for myself, for we ought to strive that our affections be rooted in the
9829: truth. Nevertheless you----"
9830: 
9831: Esther had risen, and had glided on to the wooden stool on a level with
9832: her father's chair, where he was accustomed to lay books. She wanted to
9833: speak, but the flood-gates could not be opened for words alone. She
9834: threw her arms round the old man's neck and sobbed out with a passionate
9835: cry, "Father, father! forgive me if I have not loved you enough. I
9836: will--I will!"
9837: 
9838: The old man's little delicate frame was shaken by a surprise and joy
9839: that was almost painful in their intensity. He had been going to ask
9840: forgiveness of her who asked it for herself. In that moment of supreme
9841: complex emotion one ray of the minister's joy was the thought, "Surely
9842: the work of grace is begun in her--surely here is a heart that the Lord
9843: hath touched."
9844: 
9845: They sat so, enclasped in silence, while Esther relieved her full heart.
9846: When she raised her head, she sat quite still for a minute or two
9847: looking fixedly before her, and keeping one little hand in the
9848: minister's. Presently she looked at him and said--
9849: 
9850: "Then you lived like a workingman, father; you were very, very poor. Yet
9851: my mother had been used to luxury, She was well born--she was a lady?"
9852: 
9853: "It is true, my dear; it was a poor life that I could give her."
9854: 
9855: Mr. Lyon answered in utter dimness as to the course Esther's mind was
9856: taking. He had anticipated before his disclosure, from his long-standing
9857: discernment of tendencies in her which were often the cause of silent
9858: grief to him, that the discovery likely to have the keenest interest for
9859: her would be that her parents had a higher rank than that of the poor
9860: Dissenting preacher; but she had shown that other and better
9861: sensibilities were predominant. He rebuked himself now for a hasty and
9862: shallow judgment concerning the child's inner life, and waited for new
9863: clearness.
9864: 
9865: "But that must be the best life, father," said Esther, suddenly rising,
9866: with a flush across her paleness, and standing with her head thrown a
9867: little backward, as if some illumination had given her a new decision.
9868: "That must be the best life."
9869: 
9870: "What life, my dear child?"
9871: 
9872: "Why, that where one bears and does everything because of some great and
9873: strong feeling--so that this and that in one's circumstances don't
9874: signify."
9875: 
9876: "Yea, verily; but the feeling that should be thus supreme is devotedness
9877: to the Divine Will."
9878: 
9879: Esther did not speak; her father's words did not fit on to the
9880: impressions wrought in her by what he had told her. She sat down again,
9881: and said, more quietly--
9882: 
9883: "Mamma did not speak much of my--first father?"
9884: 
9885: "Not much, dear. She said he was beautiful to the eye, and good and
9886: generous; and that his family was of those who had been long privileged
9887: among their fellows. But now I will deliver to you the letters, which,
9888: together with the ring and locket, are the only visible memorials she
9889: retained of him."
9890: 
9891: Mr. Lyon reached and delivered to Esther the box containing the relics.
9892: "Take them, and examine them in privacy, my dear. And that I may no more
9893: err by concealment, I will tell you some late occurrences that bear on
9894: these memorials, though to my present apprehension doubtfully and
9895: confusedly."
9896: 
9897: He then narrated to Esther all that had passed between himself and
9898: Christian. The possibility--to which Mr. Lyon's alarms had pointed--that
9899: her real father might still be living, was a new shock. She could not
9900: speak about it to her present father, but it was registered in silence
9901: as a painful addition to the uncertainties which she suddenly saw
9902: hanging over her life.
9903: 
9904: "I have little confidence in this man's allegations," Mr. Lyon ended. "I
9905: confess his presence and speech are to me as the jarring of metal. He
9906: bears the stamp of one who has never conceived aught of more sanctity
9907: than the lust of the eye and the pride of life. He hints at some
9908: possible inheritance for you, and denounces mysteriously the devices of
9909: Mr. Jermyn. All this may or may not have a true foundation. But it is
9910: not my part to move in this matter save on a clear showing."
9911: 
9912: "Certainly not, father," said Esther, eagerly. A little while ago, these
9913: problematic prospects might have set her dreaming pleasantly; but now,
9914: for some reasons that she could not have put distinctly into words, they
9915: affected her with dread.
9916: 
9917: 
9918: 
9919: 
9920: CHAPTER XXVII.
9921: 
9922:     To hear with eyes is part of love's rare wit.
9923: 
9924:                                         --SHAKESPEARE: _Sonnets_.
9925: 
9926:                         Custom calls me to't;
9927:     What custom wills, in all things should we do't.
9928:     The dust on antique time would lie unswept,
9929:     And mountainous error be too highly heaped
9930:     For truth to over-peer.--_Coriolanus._
9931: 
9932: 
9933: In the afternoon Mr. Lyon went out to see the sick amongst his flock,
9934: and Esther, who had been passing the morning in dwelling on the memories
9935: and the few remaining relics of her parents, was left alone in the
9936: parlor amidst the lingering odors of the early dinner, not easily got
9937: rid of in that small house. Rich people, who know nothing of these
9938: vulgar details, can hardly imagine their significance in the history of
9939: multitudes of human lives in which the sensibilities are never adjusted
9940: to the external conditions. Esther always felt so much discomfort from
9941: those odors that she usually seized any possibility of escaping from
9942: them, and to-day they oppressed her the more because she was weary with
9943: long-continued agitation. Why did she not put on her bonnet as usual and
9944: get out into the open air? It was one of those pleasant November
9945: afternoons--pleasant in the wide country--when the sunshine is on the
9946: clinging brown leaves of the young oaks, and the last yellow leaves of
9947: the elms flutter down in the fresh but not eager breeze. But Esther sat
9948: still on the sofa--pale and with reddened eyelids, her curls all pushed
9949: back carelessly, and her elbow resting on the ridgy black horsehair,
9950: which usually almost set her teeth on edge if she pressed it even
9951: through her sleeve--while her eyes rested blankly on the dull street.
9952: Lyddy had said, "Miss, you look sadly; if you can't take a walk, go and
9953: lie down." She had never seen the curls in such disorder, and she
9954: reflected that there had been a death from typhus recently. But the
9955: obstinate Miss only shook her head.
9956: 
9957: Esther was waiting for the sake of--not a probability, but--a mere
9958: possibility, which made the brothy odors endurable. Apparently, in less
9959: than half an hour, the possibility came to pass, for she changed her
9960: attitude, almost started from her seat, sat down again, and listened
9961: eagerly. If Lyddy should send him away, could she herself rush out and
9962: call him back? Why not? Such things were permissible where it was
9963: understood, from the necessity of the case, that there was only
9964: friendship. But Lyddy opened the door and said, "Here's Mr. Holt, Miss,
9965: wants to know if you'll give him leave to come in. I told him you was
9966: sadly."
9967: 
9968: "Oh, yes, Lyddy, beg him to come in."
9969: 
9970: "I should not have persevered," said Felix, as they shook hands, "only I
9971: know Lyddy's dismal way. But you do look ill," he went on, as he seated
9972: himself at the other end of the sofa. "Or rather--for that's a false way
9973: of putting it--you look as if you had been very much distressed. Do you
9974: mind about my taking notice of it?"
9975: 
9976: He spoke very kindly, and looked at her more persistently than he had
9977: ever done before, when her hair was perfect.
9978: 
9979: "You are quite right. I am not at all ill. But I have been very much
9980: agitated this morning. My father has been telling me things I never
9981: heard before about my mother, and giving me things that belonged to her.
9982: She died when I was a very little creature."
9983: 
9984: "Then it is no new pain or trouble for you and Mr. Lyon? I could not
9985: help being anxious to know that."
9986: 
9987: Esther passed her hand over her brow before she answered. "I hardly know
9988: whether it is pain, or something better than pleasure. It has made me
9989: see things I was blind to before--depths in my father's nature."
9990: 
9991: As she said this, she looked at Felix, and their eyes met very gravely.
9992: 
9993: "It is such a beautiful day," he said, "it would do you good to go into
9994: the air. Let me take you along the river toward Little Treby, will you?"
9995: 
9996: "I will put my bonnet on," said Esther, unhesitatingly, though they had
9997: never walked out together before.
9998: 
9999: It is true that to get into the fields they had to pass through the
10000: street; and when Esther saw some acquaintances, she reflected that her
10001: walking alone with Felix might be a subject of remark--all the more
10002: because of his cap, patched boots, no cravat, and thick stick. Esther
10003: was a little amazed herself at what she had come to. So our lives glide
10004: on: the river ends we don't know where, and the sea begins, and there is
10005: no more jumping ashore.
10006: 
10007: When they were in the streets Esther hardly spoke. Felix talked with his
10008: usual readiness, as easily as if he were not doing it solely to divert
10009: her thoughts, first about Job Tudge's delicate chest, and the
10010: probability that the little white-faced monkey would not live long; and
10011: then about a miserable beginning of a night-school, which was all he
10012: could get together at Sproxton, and the dismalness of that hamlet, which
10013: was a sort of lip to the coalpit on one side and the "public" on the
10014: other--and yet a paradise compared with the wynds of Glasgow, where
10015: there was little more than a chink of daylight to show the hatred in
10016: women's faces.
10017: 
10018: But soon they got into the fields, where there was a right of way toward
10019: Little Treby, now following the course of the river, now crossing toward
10020: a lane, and now turning into a cart-track through a plantation.
10021: 
10022: "Here we are!" said Felix, when they had crossed the wooden bridge, and
10023: were treading on the slanting shadows made by the elm-trunks. "I think
10024: this is delicious. I never feel less unhappy than in these late autumn
10025: afternoons when they are sunny."
10026: 
10027: "Less unhappy! There now!" said Esther, smiling at him with some of her
10028: habitual sauciness, "I have caught you in self-contradiction. I have
10029: heard you quite furious against puling, melancholy people. If I had said
10030: what you have just said, you would have given me a long lecture, and
10031: told me to go home and interest myself in the reason of the
10032: rule-of-three."
10033: 
10034: "Very likely," said Felix, beating the weeds, according to the foible of
10035: our common humanity when it has a stick in its hand. "But I don't think
10036: myself a fine fellow because I'm melancholy. I don't measure my force by
10037: the negations in me, and think my soul must be a mighty one because it
10038: is more given to idle suffering than to beneficent activity. That's what
10039: your favorite gentlemen do, of the Byronic-bilious style."
10040: 
10041: "I don't admit that those are my favorite gentlemen."
10042: 
10043: "I've heard you defend them--gentlemen like your Rénés, who have no
10044: particular talent for the finite, but a general sense that the infinite
10045: is the right thing for them. They might as well boast of nausea as a
10046: proof of a strong inside."
10047: 
10048: "Stop, stop! You run on in that way to get out of my reach. I convicted
10049: you of confessing that you are melancholy."
10050: 
10051: "Yes," said Felix, thrusting his left hand into his pocket, with a
10052: shrug; "as I could confess to a great many other things I'm not proud
10053: of. The fact is, there are not many easy lots to be drawn in the world
10054: at present; and such as they are I am not envious of them. I don't say
10055: life is not worth having to a man who has some sparks of sense and
10056: feeling and bravery in him. And the finest fellow of all would be the
10057: one who could be glad to have lived because the world was chiefly
10058: miserable, and his life had come to help some one who needed it. He
10059: would be the man who had the most powers and the fewest selfish wants.
10060: But I'm not up to the level of what I see to be best. I'm often a hungry
10061: discontented fellow."
10062: 
10063: "Why have you made your life so hard then?" said Esther, rather
10064: frightened as she asked the question. "It seems to me you have tried to
10065: find just the most difficult task."
10066: 
10067: "Not at all," said Felix, with curt decision. "My course was a very
10068: simple one. It was pointed out to me by conditions that I saw as clearly
10069: as I see the bars of this stile. It's a difficult stile too," added
10070: Felix, striding over. "Shall I help you, or will you be left to
10071: yourself?"
10072: 
10073: "I can do without help, thank you."
10074: 
10075: "It was simple enough," continued Felix, as they walked on. "If I meant
10076: to put a stop to the sale of those drugs, I must keep my mother, and of
10077: course at her age she would not leave the place she had been used to.
10078: And I had made up my mind against what they call genteel business."
10079: 
10080: "But suppose every one did as you do? Please to forgive me for saying
10081: so; but I cannot see why you could not have lived as honorably with some
10082: employment that presupposes education and refinement."
10083: 
10084: "Because you can't see my history or my nature," said Felix, bluntly. "I
10085: have to determine for myself, and not for other men. I don't blame them,
10086: or think I am better than they; their circumstances are different. I
10087: would never choose to withdraw myself from the labor and common burden
10088: of the world; but I do choose to withdraw myself from the push and the
10089: scramble for money and position. Any man is at liberty to call me a
10090: fool, and say that mankind are benefited by the push and the scramble in
10091: the long-run. But I care for the people who live now and will not be
10092: living when the long-run comes. As it is, I prefer going shares with the
10093: unlucky."
10094: 
10095: Esther did not speak, and there was silence between them for a minute or
10096: two, till they passed through a gate into a plantation where there was
10097: no large timber, but only thin-stemmed trees and underwood, so that the
10098: sunlight fell on the mossy spaces which lay open here and there.
10099: 
10100: "See how beautiful those stooping birch-stems are with the light on
10101: them!" said Felix. "Here is an old felled trunk they have not thought
10102: worth carrying away. Shall we sit down a little while?"
10103: 
10104: "Yes; the mossy ground with the dry leaves sprinkled over it is
10105: delightful to one's feet." Esther sat down and took off her bonnet, that
10106: the light breeze might fall on her head. Felix, too, threw down his cap
10107: and stick, lying on the ground with his back against the felled trunk.
10108: 
10109: "I wish I felt more as you do," she said, looking at the point of her
10110: foot, which was playing with a tuft of moss. "I can't help caring very
10111: much what happens to me. And you seem to care so little about yourself."
10112: 
10113: "You are thoroughly mistaken," said Felix. "It is just because I'm a
10114: very ambitious fellow, with very hungry passions, wanting a great deal
10115: to satisfy me, that I have chosen to give up what people call worldly
10116: good. At least that has been one determining reason. It all depends on
10117: what a man gets into his consciousness--what life thrusts into his mind,
10118: so that it becomes present to him as remorse is present to the guilty,
10119: or a mechanical problem to an inventive genius. There are two things
10120: I've got present in that way: one of them is the picture of what I
10121: should hate to be. I'm determined never to go about making my face
10122: simpering or solemn, and telling professional lies for profit; or to get
10123: tangled in affairs where I must wink at dishonesty and pocket the
10124: proceeds, and justify that knavery as part of a system that I can't
10125: alter. If I once went into that sort of struggle for success I should
10126: want to win--I should defend the wrong that I had once identified myself
10127: with. I should become everything that I see now beforehand to be
10128: detestable. And what's more, I should do this, as men are doing it every
10129: day, for a ridiculously small prize--perhaps for none at all--perhaps
10130: for the sake of two parlors, a rank eligible for the churchwardenship, a
10131: discontented wife, and several unhopeful children."
10132: 
10133: Esther felt a terrible pressure on her heart--the certainty of her
10134: remoteness from Felix--the sense that she was utterly trivial to him.
10135: 
10136: "The other thing that's got into my mind like a splinter," said Felix,
10137: after a pause, "is the life of the miserable--the spawning life of vice
10138: and hunger. I'll never be one of the sleek dogs. The old Catholics are
10139: right, with their higher rule and their lower. Some are called to
10140: subject themselves to a harder discipline, and renounce things
10141: voluntarily which are lawful for others. It is the old word--'necessity'
10142: is laid upon me.
10143: 
10144: "It seems to me you are stricter than my father is."
10145: 
10146: "No; I quarrel with no delight that is not base or cruel, but one must
10147: sometimes accommodate one's self to a small share. That is the lot of
10148: the majority. I would wish the minority joy, only they don't want my
10149: wishes."
10150: 
10151: Again there was silence. Esther's cheeks were hot in spite of the breeze
10152: that sent her hair floating backward. She felt an inward strain, a
10153: demand on her to see things in a light that was not easy or soothing.
10154: When Felix had asked her to walk he seemed so kind, so alive to what
10155: might be her feelings, that she had thought herself nearer to him than
10156: she had ever been before; but since they had come out he had appeared to
10157: forget all that. And yet she was conscious that this impatience of hers
10158: was very petty. Battling in this way with her own little impulses, and
10159: looking at the birch-stems opposite till her gaze was too wide for her
10160: to see anything distinctly, she was unaware how long they had remained
10161: without speaking. She did not know that Felix had changed his attitude a
10162: little, and was resting his elbow on the tree-trunk, while he supported
10163: his head, which was turned toward her. Suddenly he said, in a lower tone
10164: than was habitual to him:
10165: 
10166: "You are very beautiful."
10167: 
10168: She started and looked round at him, to see whether his face would give
10169: some help to the interpretation of this novel speech. He was looking up
10170: at her quite calmly, very much as a reverential Protestant might look at
10171: a picture of the Virgin, with a devoutness suggested by the type rather
10172: than by the image. Esther's vanity was not in the least gratified: she
10173: felt that, somehow or other, Felix was going to reproach her.
10174: 
10175: "I wonder," he went on, still looking at her, "whether the subtle
10176: measuring of forces will ever come to measuring the force there would be
10177: in one beautiful woman whose mind was as noble as her face was
10178: beautiful--who made a man's passion for her rush in one current with all
10179: the great aims of his life."
10180: 
10181: Esther's eyes got hot and smarting. It was no use trying to be
10182: dignified. She had turned away her head, and now said, rather bitterly,
10183: "It is difficult for a woman ever to try to be anything good when she is
10184: not believed in--when it is always supposed that she must be
10185: contemptible."
10186: 
10187: "No, dear Esther"--it was the first time Felix had been prompted to call
10188: her by her Christian name, and as he did so he laid his large hand on
10189: her two little hands, which were clasped on her knees. "You don't
10190: believe that I think you contemptible. When I first saw you----"
10191: 
10192: "I know, I know," said Esther, interrupting him impetuously, but still
10193: looking away. "You mean you did think me contemptible then. But it was
10194: very narrow of you to judge me in that way, when my life had been so
10195: different from yours. I have great faults. I know I am selfish, and
10196: think too much of my own small tastes and too little of what affects
10197: others. But I am not stupid. I am not unfeeling. I can see what is
10198: better."
10199: 
10200: "But I have not done you injustice since I knew more of you," said
10201: Felix, gently.
10202: 
10203: "Yes, you have," said Esther, turning and smiling at him through her
10204: tears. "You talk to me like an angry pedagogue. Were _you_ always wise?
10205: Remember the time when you were foolish or naughty."
10206: 
10207: "That is not far off," said Felix, curtly, taking away his hand, and
10208: clasping it with the other at the back of his head. The talk, which
10209: seemed to be introducing a mutual understanding, such as had not existed
10210: before, seemed to have undergone some check.
10211: 
10212: "Shall we get up and walk back now?" said Esther, after a few moments.
10213: 
10214: "No," said Felix, entreatingly. "Don't move yet. I dare say we shall
10215: never walk together or sit here again."
10216: 
10217: "Why not?"
10218: 
10219: "Because I am a man who am warned by visions. Those old stories of
10220: visions and dreams guiding men have their truth; we are saved by making
10221: the future present to ourselves."
10222: 
10223: "I wish I could get visions, then," said Esther, smiling at him, with an
10224: effort of playfulness, in resistance to something vaguely mournful
10225: within her.
10226: 
10227: "That is what I want," said Felix, looking at her very earnestly. "Don't
10228: turn your head. Do look at me, and then I shall know if I may go on
10229: speaking. I do believe in you; but I want you to have such a vision of
10230: the future that you may never lose your best self. Some charm or other
10231: may be flung about you--some of your attar-of-rose fascinations--and
10232: nothing but a good strong terrible vision will save you. And if it did
10233: save you, you might be that woman I was thinking of a little while ago
10234: when I looked at your face: the woman whose beauty makes a great task
10235: easier to men instead of turning them away from it. I am not likely to
10236: see such fine issues; but they may come where a woman's spirit is finely
10237: touched. I should like to be sure they would come to you."
10238: 
10239: "Why are you not likely to know what becomes of me?" said Esther,
10240: turning away her eyes in spite of his command. "Why should you not
10241: always be my father's friend and mine?"
10242: 
10243: "Oh, I shall go away as soon as I can to some large town," said Felix,
10244: in his more usual tone--"some ugly, wicked, miserable place. I want to
10245: be a demagogue of a new sort; an honest one, if possible, who will tell
10246: the people they are blind and foolish, and neither flatter them nor
10247: fatten on them. I have my heritage--an order I belong to. I have the
10248: blood of a line of handicraftsmen in my veins, and I want to stand up
10249: for the lot of the handicraftsman as a good lot, in which a man may be
10250: better trained to all the best functions of his nature than if he
10251: belonged to the grimacing set who have visiting-cards, and are proud to
10252: be thought richer than their neighbors."
10253: 
10254: "Would nothing ever make it seem right to you to change your mind?" said
10255: Esther (she had rapidly woven some possibilities out of the new
10256: uncertainties in her own lot, though she would not for the world have
10257: had Felix know of her weaving). "Suppose, by some means or other, a
10258: fortune might come to you honorably--by marriage, or in any other
10259: unexpected way--would you see no change in your course?"
10260: 
10261: "No," said Felix, peremptorily; "I will never be rich. I don't count
10262: that as any peculiar virtue. Some men do well to accept riches, but that
10263: is not my inward vocation: I have no fellow-feeling with the rich as a
10264: class; the habits of their lives are odious to me. Thousands of men have
10265: wedded poverty because they expect to go to heaven for it; I don't
10266: expect to go to heaven for it, but I wed it because it enables me to do
10267: what I most want to do on earth. Whatever the hopes for the world may
10268: be--whether great or small--I am a man of this generation; I will try to
10269: make life less bitter for a few within my reach. It is held reasonable
10270: enough to toil for the fortunes of a family, though it may turn to
10271: imbecility in the third generation. I choose a family with more chances
10272: in it."
10273: 
10274: Esther looked before her dreamily till she said, "That seems a hard lot;
10275: yet it is a great one." She rose to walk back.
10276: 
10277: "Then you don't think I'm a fool," said Felix, loudly, starting to his
10278: feet, and then stooping to gather up his cap and stick.
10279: 
10280: "Of course you suspected me of that stupidity."
10281: 
10282: "Well--women, unless they are Saint Theresas or Elizabeth Frys,
10283: generally think this sort of thing madness, unless when they read of it
10284: in the Bible."
10285: 
10286: "A woman can hardly ever choose in that way; she is dependent on what
10287: happens to her. She must take meaner things, because only meaner things
10288: are within her reach."
10289: 
10290: "Why, can you imagine yourself choosing hardship as the better lot?"
10291: said Felix, looking at her with a sudden question in his eyes.
10292: 
10293: "Yes, I can," she said, flushing over neck and brow.
10294: 
10295: Their words were charged with a meaning dependent entirely on the secret
10296: consciousness of each. Nothing had been said which was necessarily
10297: personal. They walked a few yards along the road by which they had come,
10298: without further speech, till Felix said gently, "Take my arm." She took
10299: it, and they walked home so, entirely without conversation. Felix was
10300: struggling as a firm man struggles with a temptation, seeing beyond it
10301: and disbelieving its lying promise. Esther was struggling as a woman
10302: struggles with the yearning for some expression of love, and with
10303: vexation under that subjection to a yearning which is not likely to be
10304: satisfied. Each was conscious of a silence which each was unable to
10305: break, till they entered Malthouse Lane, and were within a few yards of
10306: the minister's door.
10307: 
10308: "It is getting dusk," Felix then said; "will Mr. Lyon be anxious about
10309: you?"
10310: 
10311: "No, I think not. Lyddy would tell him that I went out with you, and
10312: that you carried a large stick," said Esther, with a light laugh.
10313: 
10314: Felix went in with Esther to take tea, but the conversation was entirely
10315: between him and Mr. Lyon about the tricks of canvassing, the foolish
10316: personality of the placards, and the probabilities of Transome's return,
10317: as to which Felix declared himself to have become indifferent. This
10318: scepticism made the minister uneasy: he had great belief in the old
10319: political watchwords, had preached that universal suffrage and no ballot
10320: were agreeable to the will of God, and liked to believe that a visible
10321: "instrument" was forthcoming in the Radical candidate who had pronounced
10322: emphatically against Whig finality. Felix, being in a perverse mood,
10323: contended that universal suffrage would be equally agreeable to the
10324: devil; that he would change his politics a little, have a larger
10325: traffic, and see himself more fully represented in Parliament.
10326: 
10327: "Nay, my friend," said the minister, "you are again sporting with
10328: paradox; for you will not deny that you glory in the name of Radical, or
10329: Root-and-branch man, as they said in the great times when Nonconformity
10330: was in its giant youth."
10331: 
10332: "A Radical--yes; but I want to go to some roots a good deal lower down
10333: than the franchise."
10334: 
10335: "Truly there is a work within which cannot be dispensed with; but it is
10336: our preliminary work to free men from the stifled life of political
10337: nullity, and bring them into what Milton calls 'the liberal air,'
10338: wherein alone can be wrought the final triumphs of the Spirit."
10339: 
10340: "With all my heart. But while Caliban is Caliban, though you multiply
10341: him by a million, he'll worship every Trinculo that carries a bottle. I
10342: forget, though--you don't read Shakespeare, Mr. Lyon."
10343: 
10344: "I am bound to confess that I have so far looked into a volume of
10345: Esther's as to conceive your meaning; but the fantasies therein were so
10346: little to be reconciled with a steady contemplation of that divine
10347: economy which is hidden from sense and revealed to faith, that I forbore
10348: the reading, as likely to perturb my ministrations."
10349: 
10350: Esther sat by in unusual silence. The conviction that Felix willed her
10351: exclusion from his life was making it plain that something more than
10352: friendship between them was not so thoroughly out of the question as she
10353: had always inwardly asserted. In her pain that his choice lay aloof from
10354: her, she was compelled frankly to admit to herself the longing that it
10355: had been otherwise, and that he had entreated her to share his difficult
10356: life. He was like no one else to her: he had seemed to bring at once a
10357: law, and the love that gave strength to obey the law. Yet the next
10358: moment, stung by his independence of her, she denied that she loved him;
10359: she had only longed for a moral support under the negations of her life.
10360: If she were not to have that support, all effort seemed useless.
10361: 
10362: Esther had been so long used to hear the formulas of her father's belief
10363: without feeling or understanding them, that they had lost all power to
10364: touch her. The first religious experience of her life--the first
10365: self-questioning, the first voluntary subjection, the first longing to
10366: acquire the strength of greater motives and obey the more strenuous
10367: rule--had come to her through Felix Holt. No wonder that she felt as if
10368: the loss of him were inevitable backsliding.
10369: 
10370: But was it certain that she should lose him? She did not believe that he
10371: was really indifferent to her.
10372: 
10373: 
10374: 
10375: 
10376: CHAPTER XXVIII.
10377: 
10378:     _Titus._  But what says Jupiter, I ask thee?
10379: 
10380:     _Clown._  Alas, sir, I know not Jupiter:
10381:               I never drank with him in all my life.
10382: 
10383:                                                 --_Titus Andronicus_
10384: 
10385: 
10386: The multiplication of uncomplimentary placards noticed by Mr. Lyon and
10387: Felix Holt was one of several signs that the days of nomination and
10388: election were approaching. The presence of the Revising Barrister in
10389: Treby was not only an opportunity for all persons not otherwise busy to
10390: show their zeal for the purification of the voting-lists, but also to
10391: reconcile private ease and public duty by standing about the streets and
10392: lounging at doors.
10393: 
10394: It was no light business for Trebians to form an opinion; the mere fact
10395: of a public functionary with an unfamiliar title was enough to give
10396: them pause, as a premise that was not to be quickly started from. To Mr.
10397: Pink, the saddler, for example, until some distinct injury or benefit
10398: had accrued to him, the existence of the Revising Barrister was like the
10399: existence of the young giraffe which Wombwell had lately brought into
10400: those parts--it was to be contemplated, and not criticised. Mr. Pink
10401: professed a deep-dyed Toryism; but he regarded all fault-finding as
10402: Radical and somewhat impious, as disturbing to trade, and likely to
10403: offend the gentry, or the servants through whom their harness was
10404: ordered: there was a Nemesis in things which made objection unsafe, and
10405: even the Reform Bill was a sort of electric eel which a thriving
10406: tradesman had better leave alone. It was only the "Papists" who lived
10407: far enough off to be spoken of uncivilly.
10408: 
10409: But Mr. Pink was fond of news, which he collected and retailed with
10410: perfect impartiality, noting facts and rejecting comments. Hence he was
10411: well pleased to have his shop so constant a place of resort for
10412: loungers, that to many Trebians there was a strong association between
10413: the pleasures of gossip and the smell of leather. He had the
10414: satisfaction of chalking and cutting, and of keeping his journeymen
10415: close at work, at the very time that he learned from his visitors who
10416: were those whose votes had been called in question before His Honor, how
10417: Lawyer Jermyn had been too much for Lawyer Labron about Todd's cottages,
10418: and how, in the opinion of some townsmen, this looking into the value of
10419: people's property, and swearing it down below a certain sum, was a nasty
10420: inquisitorial kind of thing; while others observed that being nice to a
10421: few pounds was all nonsense--they should put the figure high enough, and
10422: then never mind if a voter's qualification was thereabouts. But, said
10423: Mr. Sims, the auctioneer, everything was done for the sake of the
10424: lawyers. Mr. Pink suggested impartially that lawyers must live; but Mr.
10425: Sims, having a ready auctioneering wit, did not see that so many of them
10426: need live, or that babies were born lawyers. Mr. Pink felt that this
10427: speculation was complicated by the ordering of side-saddles for lawyers'
10428: daughters, and, returning to the firm ground of fact, stated that it was
10429: getting dusk.
10430: 
10431: The dusk seemed deepened the next moment by a tall figure obstructing
10432: the doorway, at sight of whom Mr. Pink rubbed his hands and smiled and
10433: bowed more than once, with evident solicitude to show honor where honor
10434: was due, while he said:
10435: 
10436: "Mr. Christian, sir, how do you do, sir?"
10437: 
10438: Christian answered with the condescending familiarity of a superior.
10439: "Very badly, I can tell you, with these confounded braces that you were
10440: to make such a fine job of. See, old fellow, they've burst out again."
10441: 
10442: "Very sorry, sir. Can you leave them with me?"
10443: 
10444: "Oh, yes, I'll leave them. What's the news, eh?" said Christian, half
10445: seating himself on a high stool, and beating his boot with a hand-whip.
10446: 
10447: "Well, sir, we look to you to tell us that," said Mr. Pink, with a
10448: knowing smile. "You're at headquarters--eh, sir? That was what I said to
10449: Mr. Scales the other day. He came up for some straps, Mr. Scales did,
10450: and he asked that question in pretty near the same terms that you've
10451: done, sir, and I answered him, as I may say, ditto. Not meaning any
10452: disrespect to you, sir, but a way of speaking."
10453: 
10454: "Come, that's gammon, Pink," said Christian. "You know everything. You
10455: can tell me if you will, who is the fellow employed to paste up
10456: Transome's handbills?"
10457: 
10458: "What do _you_ say, Mr. Sims?" said Pink, looking at the auctioneer.
10459: 
10460: "Why, you know and I know well enough. It's Tommy Trounsem--an old,
10461: crippling, half-mad fellow. Most people know Tommy. I've employed him
10462: myself for charity."
10463: 
10464: "Where shall I find him?" said Christian.
10465: 
10466: "At the Cross-Keys, in Pollard's End, most likely," said Mr. Sims. "I
10467: don't know where he puts himself when he isn't at the public."
10468: 
10469: "He was a stoutish fellow fifteen year ago, when he carried pots," said
10470: Mr. Pink.
10471: 
10472: "Ay, and has snared many a hare in his time," said Mr. Sims. "But he was
10473: always a little cracked. Lord bless you! he used to swear he had a right
10474: to the Transome estate."
10475: 
10476: "Why, what put that notion into his head?" said Christian, who had
10477: learned more than he expected.
10478: 
10479: "The lawing, sir--nothing but the lawing about the estate. There was a
10480: deal of it twenty year ago," said Mr. Pink. "Tommy happened to turn up
10481: hereabout at that time; a big, lungeous fellow, who would speak
10482: disrespectfully of hanybody."
10483: 
10484: "Oh, he meant no harm," said Mr. Sims. "He was fond of a drop to drink,
10485: and not quite right in the upper story, and he could hear no difference
10486: between Trounsem and Transome. It's an odd way of speaking they have in
10487: that part where he was born--a little north'ard. You'll hear it in his
10488: tongue now, if you talk to him."
10489: 
10490: "At the Cross-Keys I shall find him, eh?" said Christian, getting off
10491: his stool. "Good-day, Pink--good-day."
10492: 
10493: Christian went straight from the saddler's to Quorlen's, the Tory
10494: printer's, with whom he had contrived a political spree. Quorlen was a
10495: new man in Treby, who had so reduced the trade of Dow, the old
10496: hereditary printer, that Dow had lapsed to Whiggery and Radicalism and
10497: opinions in general, so far as they were contented to express themselves
10498: in a small stock of types. Quorlen had brought his Duffield wit with
10499: him, and insisted that religion and joking were the handmaids of
10500: politics; on which principle he and Christian undertook the joking, and
10501: left the religion to the rector. The joke at present in question was a
10502: practical one. Christian, turning into the shop, merely said, "I've
10503: found him out--give me the placards"; and, tucking a thickish flat
10504: bundle, wrapped in a black glazed cotton bag, under his arm, walked out
10505: into the dusk again.
10506: 
10507: "Suppose now," he said to himself, as he strode along--"suppose there
10508: should be some secret to be got out of this old scamp, or some notion
10509: that's as good as a secret to those who know how to use it? That would
10510: be virtue rewarded. But I'm afraid the old tosspot is not likely to be
10511: good for much. There's truth in wine, and there may be some in gin and
10512: muddy beer; but whether it's truth worth my knowing, is another
10513: question. I've got plenty of truth, but never any that was worth a
10514: sixpence to me."
10515: 
10516: The Cross-Keys was a very old-fashioned "public"; its bar was a big
10517: rambling kitchen, with an undulating brick floor; the small-paned
10518: windows threw an interesting obscurity over the far-off dresser,
10519: garnished with pewter and tin, and with large dishes that seemed to
