10520: speak of better times; the two settles were half pushed under the
10521: wide-mouthed chimney; and the grate with its brick hobs, massive iron
10522: crane, and various pothooks, suggested a generous plenty possibly
10523: existent in all moods and tenses except the indicative present. One way
10524: of getting an idea of our fellow-countrymen's miseries is to go and look
10525: at their pleasures. The Cross-Keys had a fungous-featured landlord and a
10526: yellow sickly landlady, with a large white kerchief bound round her cap,
10527: as if her head had recently required surgery; it had doctored ale, an
10528: odor of bad tobacco, and remarkably strong cheese. It was not what
10529: Astræa, when come back, might be expected to approve as the scene of
10530: ecstatic enjoyment for the beings whose special prerogative it is to
10531: lift their sublime faces toward heaven. Still, there was ample space on
10532: the hearth--accommodation for narrative bagmen or boxmen--room for a man
10533: to stretch his legs; his brain was not pressed upon by a white wall
10534: within a yard of him, and the light did not stare in mercilessly on bare
10535: ugliness, turning the fire to ashes. Compared with some beerhouses of
10536: this more advanced period, the Cross-Keys of that day presented a high
10537: standard of pleasure.
10538: 
10539: But though this venerable "public" had not failed to share in the recent
10540: political excitement of drinking, the pleasures it offered were not at
10541: this hour of the evening sought by a numerous company. There were only
10542: three or four pipes being smoked by the firelight, but it was enough for
10543: Christian when he found that one of these was being smoked by the
10544: bill-sticker, whose large flat basket, stuffed with placards, leaned
10545: near him against the settle. So splendid an apparition as Christian was
10546: not a little startling at the Cross-Keys, and was gazed at in expectant
10547: silence; but he was a stranger in Pollard's End, and was taken for the
10548: highest style of traveller when he declared that he was deucedly
10549: thirsty, ordered sixpenny worth of gin and a large jug of water, and,
10550: putting a few drops of the spirit into his own glass, invited Tommy
10551: Trounsem, who sat next him, to help himself. Tommy was not slower than a
10552: shaking hand obliged him to be in accepting this invitation. He was a
10553: tall, broad-shouldered old fellow, who had once been good-looking; but
10554: his cheeks and chest were both hollow now, and his limbs were shrunken.
10555: 
10556: "You've got some bills there, master, eh?" said Christian, pointing to
10557: the basket. "Is there an auction coming on?"
10558: 
10559: "Auction? no," said Tommy, with a gruff hoarseness, which was the
10560: remnant of a jovial bass, and with an accent which differed from the
10561: Trebian fitfully, as an early habit is wont to reassert itself. "I've
10562: nought to do wi' auctions; I'm a pol'tical charicter. It's me am getting
10563: Trounsem into Parl'ment."
10564: 
10565: "Trounsem, said he," the landlord observed, taking out his pipe with a
10566: low laugh. "It's Transome, sir. Maybe you don't belong to this part.
10567: It's the candidate 'ull do most for the workingmen, and's proved it too,
10568: in the way o' being open-handed and wishing 'em to enjoy themselves. If
10569: I'd twenty votes, I'd give one for Transome, and I don't care who hears
10570: me."
10571: 
10572: The landlord peered out from his fungous cluster of features with a
10573: beery confidence that the high figure of twenty had somehow raised the
10574: hypothetic value of his vote.
10575: 
10576: "Spilkins, now," said Tommy, waving his hand to the landlord, "you let
10577: one gentelman speak to another, will you? This genelman wants to know
10578: about my bills. Does he, or doesn't he?"
10579: 
10580: "What then? I spoke according," said the landlord, mildly holding his
10581: own.
10582: 
10583: "You're all very well, Spilkins," returned Tommy, "but y'aren't me. I
10584: know what the bills are. It's public business. I'm none o' your common
10585: bill-stickers, master; I've left off sticking up ten guineas reward for
10586: a sheep-stealer, or low stuff like that. These are Trounsem's bills; and
10587: I'm the rightful family, and so I give him a lift. A Trounsem I am, and
10588: a Trounsem I'll be buried; and if Old Nick tries to lay hold on me for
10589: poaching, I'll say, 'You be hanged for a lawyer, Old Nick; every hare
10590: and pheasant on the Trounsem's land is mine'; and what rises the family,
10591: rises old Tommy; and we're going to get into Parl'ment--that's the long
10592: and the short on't, master. And I'm the head o' the family, and I stick
10593: the bills. There's Johnsons, and Thomsons, and Jacksons, and Billsons;
10594: but I'm a Trounsem, I am. What do you say to that, master?"
10595: 
10596: This appeal, accompanied by a blow on the table, while the landlord
10597: winked at the company, was addressed to Christian, who answered, with
10598: severe gravity--
10599: 
10600: "I say there isn't any work more honorable than bill-sticking."
10601: 
10602: "No, no," said Tommy, wagging his head from side to side. "I thought
10603: you'd come in to that. I thought you'd know better than say contrairy.
10604: But I'll shake hands wi' you; I don't want to knock any man's head off.
10605: I'm a good chap--a sound crock--an old family kep' out o' my rights. I
10606: shall go to heaven, for all Old Nick."
10607: 
10608: As these celestial prospects might imply that a little extra gin was
10609: beginning to tell on the bill-sticker, Christian wanted to lose no time
10610: in arresting his attention. He laid his hand on Tommy's and spoke
10611: emphatically.
10612: 
10613: "But I'll tell you what you bill-stickers are not up to. You should be
10614: on the look-out when Debarry's side have stuck up fresh bills, and go
10615: and paste yours over them. I know where there's a lot of Debarry's bills
10616: now. Come along with me and I'll show you. We'll paste them over, and
10617: then we'll come back and treat the company."
10618: 
10619: "Hooray!" said Tommy. "Let's be off then."
10620: 
10621: He was one of the thoroughly inured, originally hale drunkards, and did
10622: not easily lose his head or legs or the ordinary amount of method in his
10623: talk. Strangers often supposed that Tommy was tipsy when he had only
10624: taken what he called "one blessed pint," chiefly from that glorious
10625: contentment with himself and his adverse fortunes which is not usually
10626: characteristic of the sober Briton. He knocked the ashes out of his
10627: pipe, seized his paste-vessel and his basket, and prepared to start with
10628: a satisfactory promise that he could know what he was about.
10629: 
10630: The landlord and some others had confidently concluded that they
10631: understood all about Christian now. He was a Transome's man, come to see
10632: after the bill-sticking in Transome's interest. The landlord, telling
10633: his yellow wife snappishly to open the door for the gentleman, hoped
10634: soon to see him again.
10635: 
10636: "This is a Transome's house, sir," he observed, "in respect of
10637: entertaining customers of that color. I do my duty as a publican, which,
10638: if I know it, is to turn back no genelman's money. I say, give every
10639: genelman a chance, and the more the merrier, in Parl'ment and out of it.
10640: And if anybody says they want but two Parl'ment men, I say it 'ud be
10641: better for trade if there was six of 'em, and voters according."
10642: 
10643: "Ay, ay," said Christian; "you're a sensible man, landlord. You don't
10644: mean to vote for Debarry, then, eh?"
10645: 
10646: "Not nohow," said the landlord, thinking that where negatives were good
10647: the more you had of them the better.
10648: 
10649: As soon as the door had closed behind Christian and his new companion
10650: Tommy said--
10651: 
10652: "Now, master, if you're to be my lantern, don't you be a Jacky Lantern,
10653: which I take to mean one as leads you the wrong way. For I'll tell you
10654: what--if you've had the luck to fall in wi' Tommy Trounsem, don't you
10655: let him drop."
10656: 
10657: "No, no--to be sure not," said Christian. "Come along here. We'll go to
10658: the Back Brewery wall first."
10659: 
10660: "No, no; don't you let me drop. Give me a shilling any day you like, and
10661: I'll tell you more nor you'll hear from Spilkins in a week. There isna
10662: many men like me. I carried pots for fifteen year off and on--what do
10663: you think o' that now, for a man as might ha' lived up there at Trounsem
10664: Park, and snared his own game? Which I'd ha' done," said Tommy, wagging
10665: his head at Christian in the dimness undisturbed by gas. "None o' your
10666: shooting for me--it's two to one you'll miss. Snaring's more
10667: fishing-like. You bait your hook, and if it isna the fishes' good-will
10668: to come, that's nothing again' the sporting genelman. And that's what I
10669: say by snaring."
10670: 
10671: "But if you'd a right to the Transome estate, how was it you were kept
10672: out of it, old boy? It was some foul shame or other, eh?"
10673: 
10674: "It's the law--that's what it is. You're a good sort of chap; I don't
10675: mind telling you. There's folks born to property, and there's folks
10676: catch hold on it; and the law's made for them to catch hold. I'm pretty
10677: deep; I see a good deal further than Spilkins. There was Ned Patch, the
10678: peddler, used to say to me, 'You canna read, Tommy,' says he. 'No; thank
10679: you,' says I; 'I'm not going to crack my headpiece to make myself as big
10680: a fool as you.' I was fond o' Ned. Many's the pot we've had together."
10681: 
10682: "I see well enough you're deep, Tommy. How came you to know you were
10683: born to property?"
10684: 
10685: "It was the regester--the parish regester," said Tommy, with his knowing
10686: wag of the head, "that shows as you was born. I allays felt it inside me
10687: as I was somebody, and I could see other chaps thought it on me too; and
10688: so one day at Littleshaw, where I kep' ferrets and a little bit of a
10689: public, there come a fine man looking after me, and walking me up and
10690: down wi' questions. And I made out from the clerk as he'd been at the
10691: regester; and I gave the clerk a pot or two, and he got it off our
10692: parson as the name o' Trounsem was a great name hereabout. And I waits a
10693: bit for my fine man to come again. Thinks I, if there's property wants a
10694: right owner, I shall be called for; for I didn't know the law then. And
10695: I waited and waited, till I see'd no fun i' waiting. So I parted with my
10696: public and my ferrets--for she was dead a' ready, my wife was, and I
10697: hadn't no cumbrance. And off I started a pretty long walk to this
10698: country-side, for I could walk for a wager in them days."
10699: 
10700: "Ah! well, here we are at the Back Brewery wall. Put down your paste and
10701: your basket now, old boy, and I'll help you. You paste, and I'll give
10702: you the bills, and then you can go on talking."
10703: 
10704: Tommy obeyed automatically, for he was now carried away by the rare
10705: opportunity of talking to a new listener, and was only eager to go on
10706: with his story. As soon as his back was turned, and he was stooping over
10707: his paste-pot, Christian, with quick adroitness, exchanged the placards
10708: in his own bag for those in Tommy's basket. Christian's placards had not
10709: been printed at Treby, but were a new lot which had been sent from
10710: Duffield that very day--"highly spiced," Quorlen had said, "coming from
10711: a pen that was up to that sort of thing." Christian had read the first
10712: of the sheaf, and supposed they were all alike. He proceeded to hand one
10713: to Tommy and said--
10714: 
10715: "Here, old boy, paste this over the other. And so, when you got into
10716: this country-side, what did you do?"
10717: 
10718: "Why, I put up at a good public and ordered the best, for I'd a bit o'
10719: money in my pocket; and I axed about, and they said to me, if it's
10720: Trounsem business you're after, you go to Lawyer Jermyn. And I went; and
10721: says I, going along, he's maybe the fine man as walked me up and down.
10722: But no such thing. I'll tell you what Lawyer Jermyn was. He stands you
10723: there, and holds you away from him wi' a pole three yard long. He stares
10724: at you, and says nothing, till you feel like a Tomfool; and then he
10725: threats you to set the justice on you; and then he's sorry for you, and
10726: hands you money, and preaches you a sarmint, and tells you you're a poor
10727: man, and he'll give you a bit of advice--and you'd better not be
10728: meddling wi' things belonging to the law, else you be catched up in a
10729: big wheel and fly to bits. And I went of a cold sweat, and I wished I
10730: might never come i' sight o' Lawyer Jermyn again. But he says, if you
10731: keep i' this neighborhood, behave yourself well, and I'll pertect you. I
10732: were deep enough, but it's no use being deep, 'cause you can never know
10733: the law. And there's times when the deepest fellow's most frightened."
10734: 
10735: "Yes, yes. There! Now for another placard. And so that was all?"
10736: 
10737: "All?" said Tommy, turning round and holding the paste-brush in suspense.
10738: "Don't you be running too quick. Thinks I, 'I'll meddle no more. I've
10739: got a bit o' money--I'll buy a basket, and be a pot-man. It's a pleasant
10740: life. I shall live at publics and see the world, and pick 'quaintance,
10741: and get a chance penny.' But when I'd turned into the Red Lion, and got
10742: myself warm again wi' a drop o' hot, something jumps into my head.
10743: Thinks I, Tommy, you've done finely for yourself: you're a rat as has
10744: broke up your house to take a journey, and show yourself to a ferret.
10745: And then it jumps into my head: I'd once two ferrets as turned on one
10746: another, and the little un killed the big un. Says I to the landlady,
10747: 'Missus, could you tell me of a lawyer,' says I, 'not very big or fine,
10748: but a second-size--a big-potato, like?' 'That I can,' says she; 'there's
10749: one now in the bar parlor.' 'Be so kind as bring us together,' says I.
10750: And she cries out--I think I hear her now--'Mr. Johnson!' And what do
10751: you think?"
10752: 
10753: At this crisis in Tommy's story the gray clouds, which had been
10754: gradually thinning, opened sufficiently to let down the sudden
10755: moonlight, and show his poor battered old figure and face in the
10756: attitude and with the expression of a narrator sure of the coming effect
10757: on his auditor; his body and neck stretched a little on one side, and
10758: his paste-brush held out with an alarming intention of tapping
10759: Christian's coat-sleeve at the right moment. Christian started to a safe
10760: distance, and said--
10761: 
10762: "It's wonderful. I can't tell what to think."
10763: 
10764: "Then never do you deny Old Nick," said Tommy, with solemnity. "I've
10765: believed in him more ever since. Who was Johnson? Why, Johnson was the
10766: fine man as had walked me up and down with questions. And I out with it
10767: to him then and there. And he speaks me civil, and says, 'Come away wi'
10768: me, my good fellow.' And he told me a deal o' law. And he says, 'Whether
10769: you're a Tommy Trounsem or no, it's no good to you, but only to them as
10770: have got hold o' the property. If you was a Tommy Trounsem twenty times
10771: over, it 'ud be no good, for the law's bought you out; and your life's
10772: no good, only to them as have catched hold o' the property. The more you
10773: live, the more they'll stick in. Not as they want you now,' says
10774: he--'you're no good to anybody, and you might howl like a dog foriver,
10775: and the law 'ud take no notice on you.' Says Johnson, 'I'm doing a kind
10776: thing by you to tell you. For that's the law.' And if you want to know
10777: the law, master, you ask Johnson. I heard 'em say after, as he was an
10778: understrapper at Jermyn's. I've never forgot it from that day to this.
10779: But I saw clear enough, as if the law hadn't been again' me, the
10780: Trounsem estate 'ud ha' been mine. But folks are fools hereabouts, and
10781: I've left off talking. The more you tell 'em the truth, the more they'll
10782: niver believe you. And I went and bought my basket and the pots,
10783: and----"
10784: 
10785: "Come then, fire away," said Christian. "Here's another placard."
10786: 
10787: "I'm getting a bit dry, master."
10788: 
10789: "Well, then, make haste, and you'll have something to drink all the
10790: sooner."
10791: 
10792: Tommy turned to his work again, and Christian, continuing his help,
10793: said, "And how long has Mr. Jermyn been employing you?"
10794: 
10795: "Oh, no particular time--off and on; but a week or two ago he sees me
10796: upo' the road, and speaks to me uncommon civil, and tells me to go up to
10797: his office and he'll give me employ. And I was noways unwilling to stick
10798: the bills to get the family into Parl'ment. For there's no man can help
10799: the law. And the family's the family, whether you carry pots or no.
10800: Master, I'm uncommon dry; my head's a-turning round; it's talking so
10801: long on end."
10802: 
10803: The unwonted excitement of poor Tommy's memory was producing a reaction.
10804: 
10805: "Well, Tommy," said Christian, who had just made a discovery among the
10806: placards which altered the bent of his thoughts, "you may go back to the
10807: Cross-Keys now, if you like; here's a half-crown for you to spend
10808: handsomely. I can't go back there myself just yet; but you may give my
10809: respects to Spilkins, and mind you paste the rest of the bills early
10810: to-morrow morning."
10811: 
10812: "Ay, ay. But don't you believe too much i' Spilkins," said Tommy,
10813: pocketing the half-crown, and showing his gratitude by giving this
10814: advice--"he's no harm much--but weak. He thinks he's at the bottom o'
10815: things because he scores you up. But I bear him no ill-will. Tommy
10816: Trounsem's a good chap; and any day you like to give me half-a-crown,
10817: I'll tell you the same story over again. Not now; I'm dry. Come, help me
10818: up wi' these things; you're a younger chap than me. Well, I'll tell
10819: Spilkins you'll come again another day."
10820: 
10821: The moonlight, which had lit up poor Tommy's oratorical attitude, had
10822: served to light up for Christian the print of the placards. He had
10823: expected the copies to be various, and had turned them half over at
10824: different depths of the sheaf before drawing out those he offered to the
10825: bill-sticker. Suddenly the clearer light had shown him on one of them a
10826: name which was just then especially interesting to him, and all the more
10827: when occurring in a placard intended to dissuade the electors of North
10828: Loamshire from voting for the heir of the Transomes. He hastily turned
10829: over the bills that preceded and succeeded, that he might draw out and
10830: carry away all of this pattern; for it might turn out to be wiser for
10831: him not to contribute to the publicity of handbills which contained
10832: allusions to Bycliffe _versus_ Transome. There were about a dozen of
10833: them; he pressed them together and thrust them into his pocket,
10834: returning all the rest to Tommy's basket. To take away this dozen might
10835: not be to prevent similar bills from being posted up elsewhere, but he
10836: had reason to believe that these were all of the same kind which had
10837: been sent to Treby from Duffield.
10838: 
10839: Christian's interest in his practical joke had died out like a morning
10840: rushlight. Apart from this discovery in the placards, old Tommy's story
10841: had some indications in it that were worth pondering over. Where was
10842: that well-informed Johnson now? Was he still an understrapper of
10843: Jermyn's?
10844: 
10845: With this matter in his thoughts, Christian only turned in hastily at
10846: Quorlen's, threw down the black bag which contained the captured Radical
10847: handbills, said he had done the job, and hurried back to the Manor that
10848: he might study his problem.
10849: 
10850: 
10851: 
10852: 
10853: CHAPTER XXIX.
10854: 
10855:     I doe believe that, as the gall has severall receptacles in several
10856:     creatures, soe there's scarce any creature but hath that emunctorye
10857:     somewhere.--SIR THOMAS BROWNE.
10858: 
10859: 
10860: Fancy what a game at chess would be if all the chessmen had passions and
10861: intellects, more or less small and cunning: if you were not only
10862: uncertain about your adversary's men, but a little uncertain about your
10863: own; if your knight could shuffle himself on to a new square by the sly;
10864: if your bishop, in disgust at your castling, could wheedle your pawns
10865: out of their places; and if your pawns, hating you because they are
10866: pawns, could make away from their appointed posts that you might get
10867: checkmate on a sudden. You might be the longest-headed of deductive
10868: reasoners, and yet you might be beaten by your own pawns. You would be
10869: especially likely to be beat, if you depended arrogantly on your
10870: mathematical imagination, and regarded your passionate pieces with
10871: contempt.
10872: 
10873: Yet this imaginary chess is easy compared with the game a man has to
10874: play against his fellow-men with other fellow-men for his instruments.
10875: He thinks himself sagacious, perhaps, because he trusts no bond except
10876: that of self-interest: but the only self-interest he can safely rely on
10877: is what seems to be such to the mind he would use or govern. Can he ever
10878: be sure of knowing this?
10879: 
10880: Matthew Jermyn was under no misgivings as to the fealty of Johnson. He
10881: had "been the making of Johnson"; and this seems to many men as a reason
10882: for expecting devotion, in spite of the fact that they themselves,
10883: though very fond of their own persons and lives, are not at all devoted
10884: to the Maker they believe in. Johnson was a most serviceable
10885: subordinate. Being a man who aimed at respectability, a family man, who
10886: had a good church-pew, subscribed for engravings of banquet pictures
10887: where there were portraits of political celebrities, and wished his
10888: children to be more unquestionably genteel than their father, he
10889: presented all the more numerous handles of worldly motive by which a
10890: judicious superior might get a hold on him. But this useful regard to
10891: respectability had its inconvenience in relation to such a superior: it
10892: was a mark of some vanity and some pride, which, if they were not
10893: touched just in the right handling-place, were liable to become raw and
10894: sensitive. Jermyn was aware of Johnson's weaknesses, and thought he had
10895: flattered them sufficiently. But on the point of knowing when we are
10896: disagreeable, our human nature is fallible. Our lavender-water, our
10897: smiles, our compliments, and other polite falsities, are constantly
10898: offensive, when in the very nature of them they can only be meant to
10899: attract admiration and regard. Jermyn had often been unconsciously
10900: disagreeable to Johnson, over and above the constant offence of being an
10901: ostentatious patron. He would never let Johnson dine with his wife and
10902: daughters; he would not himself dine at Johnson's house when he was in
10903: town. He often did what was equivalent to poohpoohing his conversation
10904: by not even appearing to listen, and by suddenly cutting it short with a
10905: query on a new subject. Jermyn was able and politic enough to have
10906: commanded a great deal of success in his life, but he could not help
10907: being handsome, arrogant, fond of being heard, indisposed to any kind of
10908: comradeship, amorous and bland toward women, cold and self-contained
10909: toward men. You will hear very strong denials that an attorney's being
10910: handsome could enter into the dislike he excited; but conversation
10911: consists a good deal in the denial of what is true. From the British
10912: point of view masculine beauty is regarded very much as it is in the
10913: drapery business:--as good solely for the fancy department--for young
10914: noblemen, artists, poets, and the clergy. Some one who, like Mr. Lingon,
10915: was disposed to revile Jermyn (perhaps it was Sir Maximus), had called
10916: him "a cursed, sleek, handsome, long-winded, overbearing sycophant";
10917: epithets which expressed, rather confusedly, the mingled character of
10918: the dislike he excited. And serviceable John Johnson, himself sleek, and
10919: mindful about his broadcloth and his cambric fronts, had what he
10920: considered "spirit" enough within him to feel that dislike of Jermyn
10921: gradually gathering force through years of obligation and subjection,
10922: till it had become an actuating motive disposed to use an opportunity;
10923: if it did not watch for one.
10924: 
10925: It was not this motive, however, but rather the ordinary course of
10926: business, which accounted for Johnson's playing a double part as an
10927: electioneering agent. What men do in elections is not to be classed
10928: either among sins or marks of grace; it would be profane to include
10929: business in religion, and conscience refers to failure, not to success.
10930: Still, the sense of being galled by Jermyn's harness was an additional
10931: reason for cultivating all relations that were independent of him; and
10932: pique at Harold Transome's behavior to him in Jermyn's office perhaps
10933: gave all the more zest to Johnson's use of his pen and ink when he wrote
10934: a handbill in the service of Garstin, and Garstin's incomparable agent,
10935: Putty, full of innuendoes against Harold Transome, as a descendant of
10936: the Durfey-Transomes. It is a natural subject of self-congratulation to
10937: a man, when special knowledge, gained long ago without any forecast,
10938: turns out to afford a special inspiration in the present; and Johnson
10939: felt a new pleasure in the consciousness that he of all people in the
10940: world next to Jermyn had the most intimate knowledge of the Transome
10941: affairs. Still better--some of these affairs were secrets of Jermyn's.
10942: If in an uncomplimentary spirit he might have been called Jermyn's "man
10943: of straw," it was a satisfaction to know that the unreality of the man
10944: John Johnson was confined to his appearance in annuity deeds, and that
10945: elsewhere he was solid, locomotive, and capable of remembering anything
10946: for his own pleasure and benefit. To act with doubleness towards a man
10947: whose conduct was double, was so near an approach to virtue that it
10948: deserved to be called by no meaner name than diplomacy.
10949: 
10950: By such causes it came to pass that Christian held in his hands a bill
10951: in which Jermyn was playfully alluded to as Mr. German Cozen, who won
10952: games by clever shuffling and odd tricks without any honor, and backed
10953: Durfey's crib against Bycliffe--in which it was adroitly implied that
10954: the so-called head of the Transomes was only the tail of the
10955: Durfeys--and that some said the Durfeys would have died out and left
10956: their nest empty if it had not been for their German Cozen.
10957: 
10958: Johnson had not dared to use any recollections except such as might
10959: credibly exist in other minds besides his own. In the truth of the case,
10960: no one but himself had the prompting to recall these out-worn scandals;
10961: but it was likely enough that such foul-winged things should be revived
10962: by election heats for Johnson to escape all suspicion.
10963: 
10964: Christian could gather only dim and uncertain inferences from this flat
10965: irony and heavy joking; but one chief thing was clear to him. He had
10966: been right in his conjecture that Jermyn's interest about Bycliffe had
10967: its source in some claim of Bycliffe's on the Transome property. And
10968: then, there was that story of the old bill-sticker's, which, closely
10969: considered, indicated that the right of the present Transomes depended,
10970: or, at least, had depended on the continuance of some other lives.
10971: Christian in his time had gathered enough legal notions to be aware that
10972: possession by one man sometimes depended on the life of another; that a
10973: man might sell his own interest in property, and the interest of his
10974: descendants, while a claim on that property would still remain to some
10975: one else than the purchaser, supposing the descendants became extinct,
10976: and the interests they had sold were at an end. But under what
10977: conditions the claim might be valid or void in any particular case, was
10978: all darkness to him. Suppose Bycliffe had any such claim on the Transome
10979: estates: how was Christian to know whether at the present moment it was
10980: worth anything more than a bit of rotten parchment? Old Tommy Trounsem
10981: had said that Johnson knew all about it. But even if Johnson were still
10982: above-ground--and all Johnsons are mortal--he might still be an
10983: understrapper of Jermyn's, in which case his knowledge would be on the
10984: wrong side of the hedge for the purposes of Henry Scaddon. His immediate
10985: care must be to find out all he could about Johnson. He blamed himself
10986: for not having questioned Tommy further while he had him at command; but
10987: on this head the bill-sticker could hardly know more than the less
10988: dilapidated denizens of Treby.
10989: 
10990: Now it had happened that during the weeks in which Christian had been at
10991: work trying to solve the enigma of Jermyn's interest about Bycliffe,
10992: Johnson's mind also had been somewhat occupied with suspicion and
10993: conjecture as to new information on the subject of the old Bycliffe
10994: claims which Jermyn intended to conceal from him. The letter which,
10995: after his interview with Christian, Jermyn had written with a sense of
10996: perfect safety to his faithful ally Johnson, was, as we know, written to
10997: a Johnson who had found his self-love incompatible with that
10998: faithfulness of which it was supposed to be the foundation. Anything
10999: that the patron felt it inconvenient for his obliged friend and servant
11000: to know, became by that very fact an object of peculiar curiosity. The
11001: obliged friend and servant secretly doted on his patron's inconvenience,
11002: provided that he himself did not share it; and conjecture naturally
11003: became active.
11004: 
11005: Johnson's legal imagination, being very differently furnished from
11006: Christian's, was at no loss to conceive conditions under which there
11007: might arise a new claim on the Transome estates. He had before him the
11008: whole history of the settlement of those estates made a hundred years
11009: ago by John Justus Transome, entailing them, whilst in his possession,
11010: on his son Thomas and his heirs-male, with remainder to the Bycliffes in
11011: fee. He knew that Thomas, son of John Justus, proving a prodigal, had,
11012: without the knowledge of his father, the tenant in possession, sold his
11013: own and his descendants' rights to a lawyer-cousin named Durfey; that,
11014: therefore, the title of the Durfey-Transomes, in spite of that old
11015: Durfey's tricks to show the contrary, depended solely on the purchase of
11016: the "base fee" thus created by Thomas Transome; and that the Bycliffes
11017: were the "remainder men" who might fairly oust the Durfey-Transomes if
11018: ever the issue of the prodigal Thomas went clean out of existence, and
11019: ceased to represent a right which he had bargained away from them.
11020: 
11021: Johnson, as Jermyn's subordinate, had been closely cognizant of the
11022: details concerning the suit instituted by successive Bycliffes, of whom
11023: Maurice Christian Bycliffe was the last, on the plea that the extinction
11024: of Thomas Transome's line had actually come to pass--a weary suit, which
11025: had eaten into the fortunes of two families, and had only made the
11026: cankerworms fat. The suit had closed with the death of Maurice Christian
11027: Bycliffe in prison; but before his death, Jermyn's exertions to get
11028: evidence that there was still issue of Thomas Transome's line surviving,
11029: as a security of the Durfey title, had issued in the discovery of a
11030: Thomas Transome at Littleshaw, in Stonyshire, who was the representative
11031: of the pawned inheritance. The death of Maurice had made this discovery
11032: useless--had made it seem the wiser part to say nothing about it; and
11033: the fact had remained a secret known only to Jermyn and Johnson. No
11034: other Bycliffe was known or believed to exist, and the Durfey-Transomes
11035: might be considered safe, unless--yes, there was an "unless" which
11036: Johnson could conceive: an heir or heiress of the Bycliffes--if such a
11037: personage turned out to be in existence--might sometime raise a new and
11038: valid claim when once informed that wretched old Tommy Trounsem the
11039: bill-sticker, tottering drunkenly on the edge of the grave, was the last
11040: issue remaining above-ground from that dissolute Thomas who played his
11041: Esau part a century before. While the poor old bill-sticker breathed,
11042: the Durfey-Transomes could legally keep their possession in spite of a
11043: possible Bycliffe proved real; but not when the parish had buried the
11044: bill-sticker.
11045: 
11046: Still, it is one thing to conceive conditions, and another to see any
11047: chance of proving their existence. Johnson at present had no glimpse of
11048: such a chance; and even if he ever gained the glimpse, he was not sure
11049: that he should ever make any use of it. His enquiries of Medwin, in
11050: obedience to Jermyn's letter, had extracted only a negative as to any
11051: information possessed by the lawyers of Bycliffe concerning a marriage,
11052: or expectation of offspring on his part. But Johnson felt not the less
11053: stung by curiosity to know what Jermyn had found out: that he had found
11054: something in relation to a possible Bycliffe, Johnson felt pretty sure.
11055: And he thought with satisfaction that Jermyn could not hinder him from
11056: knowing what he already knew about Thomas Transome's issue. Many things
11057: might occur to alter his policy and give a new value to facts. Was it
11058: certain that Jermyn would always be fortunate?
11059: 
11060: When greed and unscrupulousness exhibit themselves on a grand historical
11061: scale, and there is a question of peace or war or amicable partition, it
11062: often occurs that gentlemen of high diplomatic talents have their minds
11063: bent on the same object from different points of view. Each, perhaps, is
11064: thinking of a certain duchy or province, with a view to arranging the
11065: ownership in such a way as shall best serve the purposes of the
11066: gentleman with high diplomatic talents in whom each is more especially
11067: interested. But these select minds in high office can never miss their
11068: aims from ignorance of each other's existence or whereabouts. Their high
11069: titles may be learned even by common people from every pocket almanac.
11070: 
11071: But with meaner diplomats, who might be mutually useful, such ignorance
11072: is often obstructive. Mr. John Johnson and Mr. Christian, otherwise Mr.
11073: Scaddon, might have had a concentration of purpose and an ingenuity of
11074: device fitting them to make a figure in the parcelling of Europe, and
11075: yet they might never have met, simply because Johnson knew nothing of
11076: Christian, and because Christian did not know where to find Johnson.
11077: 
11078: 
11079: 
11080: 
11081: CHAPTER XXX.
11082: 
11083:     His nature is too noble for the world:
11084:     He would not flatter Neptune for his trident,
11085:     Or Jove for his power to thunder. His heart's his mouth;
11086:     What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent;
11087:     And, being angry, doth forget that ever
11088:     He heard the name of death.--_Coriolanus._
11089: 
11090: 
11091: Christian and Johnson did meet, however, by means that were quite
11092: incalculable. The incident which brought them into communication was due
11093: to Felix Holt, who of all men in the world had the least affinity either
11094: for the industrious or the idle parasite.
11095: 
11096: Mr. Lyon had urged Felix to go to Duffield on the fifteenth of December
11097: to witness the nomination of the candidates for North Loamshire. The
11098: minister wished to hear what took place; and the pleasure of gratifying
11099: him helped to outweigh some opposing reasons.
11100: 
11101: "I shall get into a rage at something or other," Felix had said. "I've
11102: told you one of my weak points. Where I have any particular business, I
11103: must incur the risks my nature brings. But I've no particular business
11104: at Duffield. However, I'll make a holiday and go. By dint of seeing
11105: folly, I shall get lessons in patience."
11106: 
11107: The weak point to which Felix referred was his liability to be carried
11108: completely out of his own mastery by indignant anger. His strong health,
11109: his renunciation of selfish claims, his habitual preoccupation with
11110: large thoughts and with purposes independent of everyday casualties,
11111: secured him a fine and even temper, free from moodiness or irritability.
11112: He was full of long-suffering toward his unwise mother, who "pressed him
11113: daily with her words and urged him, so that his soul was vexed;" he had
11114: chosen to fill his days in a way that required the utmost exertion of
11115: patience, that required those little rill-like outflowings of goodness
11116: which in minds of great energy must be fed from deep sources of thought
11117: and passionate devotedness. In this way his energies served to make him
11118: gentle; and now, in this twenty-sixth year of his life, they had ceased
11119: to make him angry, except in the presence of something that roused his
11120: deep indignation. When once exasperated, the passionateness of his
11121: nature threw off the yoke of a long-trained consciousness in which
11122: thought and emotion had been more and more completely mingled, and
11123: concentrated itself in a rage as ungovernable as that of boyhood. He was
11124: thoroughly aware of the liability, and knew that in such circumstances
11125: he could not answer for himself. Sensitive people with feeble frames
11126: have often the same sort of fury within them; but they are themselves
11127: shattered, and shatter nothing. Felix had a terrible arm: he knew that
11128: he was dangerous; and he avoided the conditions that might cause him
11129: exasperation as he would have avoided intoxicating drinks if he had been
11130: in danger of intemperance.
11131: 
11132: The nomination-day was a great epoch of successful trickery, or, to
11133: speak in a more parliamentary manner, of war-stratagem, on the part of
11134: skilful agents. And Mr. Johnson had his share of inward chuckling and
11135: self-approval, as one who might justly expect increasing renown, and be
11136: some day in as general request as the great Putty himself. To have the
11137: pleasure and the praise of electioneering ingenuity, and also to get
11138: paid for it, without too much anxiety whether the ingenuity will achieve
11139: its ultimate end, perhaps gives to some select persons a sort of
11140: satisfaction in their superiority to their more agitated fellow-men that
11141: is worthy to be classed with those generous enjoyments of having the
11142: truth chiefly to yourself, and of seeing others in danger of drowning
11143: while you are high and dry, which seem to have been regarded as unmixed
11144: privileges by Lucretius and Lord Bacon.
11145: 
11146: One of Mr. Johnson's great successes was this. Spratt, the hated manager
11147: of the Sproxton Colliery, in careless confidence that the colliers and
11148: other laborers under him would follow his orders, had provided carts to
11149: carry some loads of voteless enthusiasm to Duffield on behalf of
11150: Garstin; enthusiasm which, being already paid for by the recognized
11151: benefit of Garstin's existence as a capitalist with a share in the
11152: Sproxton mines, was not to cost much in the form of treating. A
11153: capitalist was held worthy of pious honor as the cause why workingmen
11154: existed. But Mr. Spratt did not sufficiently consider that a cause which
11155: was to be proved by argument or testimony is not an object of passionate
11156: devotion to colliers: a visible cause of beer acts on them much more
11157: strongly. And even if there had been any love of the far-off Garstin,
11158: hatred of the too immediate Spratt would have been the stronger motive.
11159: Hence Johnson's calculations, made long ago with Chubb, the remarkable
11160: publican, had been well founded, and there had been diligent care to
11161: supply treating at Duffield in the name of Transome. After the election
11162: was over it was not improbable that there would be much friendly joking
11163: between Putty and Johnson as to the success of this trick against
11164: Putty's employer, and Johnson would be conscious of rising in the
11165: opinion of his celebrated senior.
11166: 
11167: For the show of hands and the cheering, the hustling and the pelting,
11168: the roaring and the hissing, the hard hits with small missiles and the
11169: soft hits with small jokes, were strong enough on the side of Transome
11170: to balance the similar "demonstrations" for Garstin, even with the
11171: Debarry interest in his favor. And the inconvenient presence of Spratt
11172: was easily got rid of by a dexterously-managed accident, which sent him
11173: bruised and limping from the scene of action. Mr. Chubb had never before
11174: felt so thoroughly that the occasion was up to a level with his talents,
11175: while the clear daylight in which his virtue would appear when at the
11176: election he voted, as his duty to himself bound him, for Garstin only,
11177: gave him thorough repose of conscience.
11178: 
11179: Felix Holt was the only person looking on at the senseless exhibitions
11180: of this nomination-day, who knew from the beginning the history of the
11181: trick with the Sproxton men. He had been aware all along that the
11182: treating at Chubb's had been continued, and that so far Harold
11183: Transome's promise had produced no good fruits; and what he was
11184: observing to-day, as he watched the uproarious crowd, convinced him that
11185: the whole scheme would be carried out just as if he had never spoken
11186: about it. He could be fair enough to Transome to allow that he might
11187: have wished, and yet have been unable, with his notions of success, to
11188: keep his promise; and his bitterness toward the candidate only took the
11189: form of contemptuous pity; for Felix was not sparing in his contempt for
11190: men who put their inward honor in pawn by seeking the prizes of the
11191: world. His scorn fell too readily on the fortunate. But when he saw
11192: Johnson passing to and fro, and speaking to Jermyn on the hustings, he
11193: felt himself getting angry, and jumped off the wheel of the stationary
11194: cart on which he was mounted, that he might no longer be in sight of
11195: this man, whose vitiating cant had made his blood hot and his fingers
11196: tingle on the first day of encountering him at Sproxton. It was a little
11197: too exasperating to look at this pink-faced rotund specimen of
11198: prosperity, to witness the power for evil that lay in his vulgar cant,
11199: backed by another man's money, and to know that such stupid iniquity
11200: flourished the flags of Reform, and Liberalism, and justice to the
11201: needy. While the roaring and the scuffling were still going on, Felix,
11202: with his thick stick in his hand, made his way through the crowd, and
11203: walked on through the Duffield streets, till he came out on a grassy
11204: suburb, where the houses surrounded a small common. Here he walked
11205: about in the breezy air, and ate his bread and apples, telling himself
11206: that this angry haste of his about evils that could only be remedied
11207: slowly, could be nothing else than obstructive, and might some day--he
11208: saw it so clearly that the thought seemed like a presentiment--be
11209: obstructive of his own work.
11210: 
11211: "Not to waste energy, to apply force where it would tell, to do small
11212: work close at hand, not waiting for speculative chances of heroism, but
11213: preparing for them"--these were the rules he had been constantly urging
11214: on himself. But what could be a greater waste than to beat a scoundrel
11215: who had law and opodeldoc at command? After this meditation, Felix felt
11216: cool and wise enough to return into the town, not, however, intending to
11217: deny himself the satisfaction of a few pungent words wherever there was
11218: place for them. Blows are sarcasms turned stupid: wit is a form of force
11219: that leaves the limbs at rest.
11220: 
11221: Anything that could be called a crowd was no longer to be seen. The show
11222: of hands having been pronounced to be in favor of Debarry and Transome,
11223: and a poll having been demanded for Garstin, the business of the day
11224: might be considered at an end. But in the street where the hustings were
11225: erected, and where the great hotels stood, there were many groups, as
11226: well as strollers and steady walkers to and fro. Men in superior
11227: greatcoats and well-brushed hats were awaiting with more or less
11228: impatience an important dinner, either at the Crown, which was Debarry's
11229: house, or at the Three Cranes, which was Garstin's, or at the Fox and
11230: Hounds, which was Transome's. Knots of sober retailers, who had already
11231: dined, were to be seen at some shop-doors; men in very shabby coats and
11232: miscellaneous head-coverings, inhabitants of Duffield and not county
11233: voters, were lounging about in dull silence, or listening, some to a
11234: grimy man in a flannel shirt, hatless and with turbid red hair, who was
11235: insisting on political points with much more ease than had seemed to
11236: belong to the gentlemen speakers on the hustings, and others to a Scotch
11237: vendor of articles useful to sell, whose unfamiliar accent seemed to
11238: have a guarantee of truth in it wanting as an association with everyday
11239: English. Some rough-looking pipe-smokers, or distinguished
11240: cigar-smokers, chose to walk up and down in isolation and silence. But
11241: the majority of those who had shown a burning interest in the nomination
11242: had disappeared, and cockades no longer studded a close-pressed crowd,
11243: like, and also very unlike, meadow-flowers among the grass. The street
11244: pavement was strangely painted with fragments of perishable missiles
11245: ground flat under heavy feet: but the workers were resting from their
11246: toil, and the buzz and tread and the fitfully discernible voices seemed
11247: like stillness to Felix after the roar with which the wide space had
11248: been filled when he left it.
11249: 
11250: The group round the speaker in the flannel shirt stood at the corner of
11251: a side-street, and the speaker himself was elevated by the head and
11252: shoulders above his hearers, not because he was tall, but because he
11253: stood on a projecting stone. At the opposite corner of the turning was
11254: the great inn of the Fox and Hounds, and this was the ultra-Liberal
11255: quarter of the High street. Felix was at once attracted by this group;
11256: he liked the look of the speaker, whose bare arms were powerfully
11257: muscular, though he had the pallid complexion of a man who lives chiefly
11258: amidst the heat of furnaces. He was leaning against the dark stone
11259: building behind him with folded arms, the grimy paleness of his shirt
11260: and skin standing out in high relief against the dark stone building
11261: behind him. He lifted up one forefinger, and marked his emphasis with it
11262: as he spoke. His voice was high and not strong, but Felix recognized the
11263: fluency and the method of an habitual preacher or lecturer.
11264: 
11265: "It's the fallacy of all monopolists," he was saying. "We know what
11266: monopolists are: men who want to keep a trade all to themselves, under
11267: the pretence that they'll furnish the public with a better article. We
11268: know what that comes to: in some countries a poor man can't afford to
11269: buy a spoonful of salt, and yet there's salt enough in the world to
11270: pickle every living thing in it. That's the sort of benefit monopolists
11271: do to mankind. And these are the men who tell us we're to let politics
11272: alone; they'll govern us better without our knowing anything about it.
11273: We must mind our business; we are ignorant; we've no time to study great
11274: questions. But I tell them this: the greatest question in the world is,
11275: how to give every man a man's share in what goes on in life----"
11276: 
11277: "Hear, hear!" said Felix in his sonorous voice, which seemed to give a
11278: new impressiveness to what the speaker had said. Every one looked at
11279: him: the well-washed face and its educated expression along with a dress
11280: more careless than that of most well-to-do workmen on a holiday, made
11281: his appearance strangely arresting.
11282: 
11283: "Not a pig's share," the speaker went on, "not a horse's, not the share
11284: of a machine fed with oil only to make it work and nothing else. It
11285: isn't a man's share just to mind your pin-making, or your glass-blowing,
11286: and higgle about your own wages, and bring up your family to be ignorant
11287: sons of ignorant fathers, and no better prospect; that's a slave's
11288: share; we want a freeman's share, and that is to think and speak and act
11289: about what concerns us all, and see whether these fine gentlemen who
11290: undertake to govern us are doing the best they can for us. They've got
11291: the knowledge, say they. Very well, we've got the wants. There's many a
11292: one would be idle if hunger didn't pinch him; but the stomach sets us to
11293: work. There's a fable told where the nobles are the belly and the people
11294: the members. But I make another sort of fable. I say, we are the belly
11295: that feels the pinches, and we'll set these aristocrats, these great
11296: people who call themselves our brains, to work at some way of satisfying
11297: us a bit better. The aristocrats are pretty sure to try and govern for
11298: their own benefit; but how are we to be sure they'll try and govern for
11299: ours? They must be looked after, I think, like other workmen. We must
11300: have what we call inspectors, to see whether the work's well done for
11301: us. We want to send our inspectors to Parliament. Well, they say--you've
11302: got the Reform Bill; what more can you want? Send your inspectors. But I
11303: say, the Reform Bill is a trick--it's nothing but swearing-in special
11304: constables to keep the aristocrats safe in their monopoly; it's bribing
11305: some of the people with votes to make them hold their tongues about
11306: giving votes to the rest. I say, if a man doesn't beg or steal, but
11307: works for his bread, the poorer and the more miserable he is, the more
11308: he'd need have a vote to send an inspector to Parliament--else the man
11309: who is worst off is likely to be forgotten; and I say, he's the man who
11310: ought to be first remembered. Else what does their religion mean? Why do
11311: they build churches and endow them that their sons may get paid well for
11312: preaching a Saviour, and making themselves as little like Him as can be?
11313: If I want to believe in Jesus Christ, I must shut my eyes for fear I
11314: should see a parson. And what's a bishop? A bishop's a person dressed
11315: up, who sits in the House of Lords to help and throw out Reform Bills.
11316: And because it's hard to get anything in the shape of a man to dress
11317: himself up like that, and do such work, they have to give him a palace
11318: for it, and plenty of thousands a-year. And then they cry out--'The
11319: Church is in danger,'--'the poor man's Church.' And why is it the poor
11320: man's Church? Because he can have a seat for nothing. I think it _is_
11321: for nothing; for it would be hard to tell what he gets by it. If the
11322: poor man had a vote in the matter, I think he'd choose a different sort
11323: of Church to what that is. But do you think the aristocrats will ever
11324: alter it, if the belly doesn't pinch them? Not they. It's part of their
11325: monopoly. They'll supply us with our religion like everything else, and
11326: get a profit on it. They'll give us plenty of heaven. We may have land
11327: _there_. That's the sort of religion they like--a religion that gives us
11328: workingmen heaven, and nothing else. But we'll offer to change with
11329: them. We'll give them back some of their heaven, and take it out in
11330: something for us and our children in this world. They don't seem to care
11331: so much about heaven themselves till they feel the gout very bad; but
11332: you won't get them to give up anything else, if you don't pinch 'em for
11333: it. And to pinch them enough, we must get the suffrage, we must get
11334: votes, that we may send the men to Parliament who will do our work for
11335: us; and we must have Parliament dissolved every year, that we may change
11336: our man if he doesn't do what we want him to do; and we must have the
11337: country divided so that the little kings of the counties can't do as
11338: they like, but must be shaken up in one bag with us. I say, if we
11339: workingmen are ever to get a man's share, we must have universal
11340: suffrage, and annual Parliaments, and the vote by ballot, and electoral
11341: districts."
11342: 
11343: "No!--something else before all that," said Felix, again startling the
11344: audience into looking at him. But the speaker glanced coldly at him and
11345: went on.
11346: 
11347: "That's what Sir Francis Burdett went in for fifteen years ago; and it's
11348: the right thing for us, if it was Tomfool who went in for it. You must
11349: lay hold of such handles as you can. I don't believe much in Liberal
11350: aristocrats; but if there's any fine carved gold-headed stick of an
11351: aristocrat will make a broomstick of himself, I'll lose no time but I'll
11352: sweep with him. And that's what I think about Transome. And if any of
11353: you have acquaintance among county voters, give 'em a hint that you wish
11354: 'em to vote for Transome."
11355: 
11356: At the last word, the speaker stepped down from his slight eminence, and
11357: walked away rapidly, like a man whose leisure was exhausted, and who
11358: must go about his business. But he had left an appetite in his audience
11359: for further oratory, and one of them seemed to express a general
11360: sentiment as he hurried immediately to Felix, and said, "Come, sir, what
11361: do you say?"
11362: 
11363: Felix did at once what he would very likely have done without being
11364: asked--he stepped on the stone, and took off his cap by an instinctive
11365: prompting that always led him to speak uncovered. The effect of his
11366: figure in relief against the stone background was unlike that of the
11367: previous speaker. He was considerably taller, his head and neck were
11368: more massive, and the expression of his mouth and eyes was something
11369: very different from the mere acuteness and rather hard-lipped antagonism
11370: of the trades-union man. Felix Holt's face had the look of habitual
11371: meditative abstraction from objects of mere personal vanity or desire,
11372: which is the peculiar stamp of culture, and makes a very roughly-cut
11373: face worthy to be called "the human face divine." Even lions and dogs
11374: know a distinction between men's glances; and doubtless those Duffield
11375: men, in the expectation with which they looked up at Felix, were
11376: unconsciously influenced by the grandeur of his full yet firm mouth, and
11377: the calm clearness of his gray eyes, which were somehow unlike what they
11378: were accustomed to see along with an old brown velveteen coat, and an
11379: absence of chin-propping. When he began to speak, the contrast of voice
11380: was still stronger than that of appearance. The man in the flannel shirt
11381: had not been heard--had probably not cared to be heard--beyond the
11382: immediate group of listeners. But Felix at once drew the attention of
11383: persons comparatively at a distance.
11384: 
11385: "In my opinion," he said, almost the moment after he was addressed,
11386: "that was a true word spoken by your friend when he said the great
11387: question was how to give every man a man's share in life. But I think he
11388: expects voting to do more toward it than I do. I want the workingmen to
11389: have power. I'm a workingman myself, and I don't want to be anything
11390: else. But there are two sorts of power. There's a power to do
11391: mischief--to undo what has been done with great expense and labor, to
11392: waste and destroy, to be cruel to the weak, to lie and quarrel, and to
11393: talk poisonous nonsense. That's the sort of power that ignorant numbers
11394: have. It never made a joint stool or planted a potato. Do you think it's
11395: likely to do much toward governing a great country, and making wise
11396: laws, and giving shelter, food, and clothes to millions of men? Ignorant
11397: power comes in the end to the same thing as wicked power; it makes
11398: misery. It's another sort of power that I want us workingmen to have,
11399: and I can see plainly enough that our all having votes will do little
11400: toward it at present. I hope we, or the children that come after us,
11401: will get plenty of political power some time. I tell everybody plainly,
11402: I hope there will be great changes, and that some time, whether we live
11403: to see it or not, men will have come to be ashamed of things they're
11404: proud of now. But I should like to convince you that votes would never
11405: give you political power worth having while things are as they are now,
11406: and that if you go the right way to work you may get power sooner
11407: without votes. Perhaps all you who hear me are sober men, who try to
11408: learn as much of the nature of things as you can, and to be as little
11409: like fools as possible. A fool or idiot is one who expects things to
11410: happen that never can happen; he pours milk into a can without a bottom,
11411: and expects the milk to stay there. The more of such vain expectations a
11412: man has, the more he is a fool or idiot. And if any working man expects
11413: a vote to do for him what it never can do, he's foolish to that amount,
11414: if no more. I think that's clear enough, eh?"
11415: 
11416: "Hear, hear," said several voices, but they were not those of the
11417: original group; they belonged to some strollers who had been attracted
11418: by Felix Holt's vibrating voice, and were Tories from the Crown. Among
11419: them was Christian, who was smoking a cigar with a pleasure he always
11420: felt in being among people who did not know him, and doubtless took him
11421: to be something higher than he really was. Hearers from the Fox and
11422: Hounds also were slowly adding themselves to the nucleus. Felix,
11423: accessible to the pleasure of being listened to, went on with more and
11424: more animation: "The way to get rid of folly is to get rid of vain
11425: expectations, and of thoughts that don't agree with the nature of
11426: things. The men who have had true thoughts about water, and what it will
11427: do when it is turned into steam and under all sorts of circumstances,
11428: have made themselves a great power in the world: they are turning the
11429: wheels of engines that will help to change most things. But no engines
11430: would have done, if there had been false notions about the way water
11431: would act. Now, all the schemes about voting, and districts, and annual
11432: Parliaments, and the rest, are engines, and the water or steam--the
11433: force that is to work them--must come out of human nature--out of men's
11434: passions, feelings, desires. Whether the engines will do good work or
11435: bad depends on these feelings; and if we have false expectations about
11436: men's characters, we are very much like the idiot who thinks he'll carry
11437: milk in a can without a bottom. In my opinion, the notions about what
11438: mere voting will do are very much of that sort."
11439: 
11440: "That's very fine," said a man in dirty fustian, with a scornful laugh.
11441: "But how are we to get the power without votes?"
11442: 
11443: "I'll tell you what's the greatest power under heaven," said Felix, "and
11444: that is public opinion--the ruling belief in society about what is right
11445: and what is wrong, what is honorable and what is shameful. That's the
11446: steam that is to work the engines. How can political freedom make us
11447: better, any more than a religion we don't believe in, if people laugh
11448: and wink when they see men abuse and defile it? And while public opinion
11449: is what it is--while men have no better beliefs about public duty--while
11450: corruption is not felt to be a damning disgrace--while men are not
11451: ashamed in Parliament and out of it to make public questions which
11452: concern the welfare of millions a mere screen for their own petty
11453: private ends,--I say, no fresh scheme of voting will much mend our
11454: condition. For, take us workingmen of all sorts. Suppose out of every
11455: hundred who had a vote there were thirty who had some soberness, some
11456: sense to choose with, some good feeling to make them wish the right
11457: thing for all. And suppose there were seventy out of the hundred who
11458: were, half of them, not sober, who had no sense to choose one thing in
11459: politics more than another, and who had so little good feeling in them
11460: that they wasted on their own drinking the money that should have helped
11461: to feed and clothe their wives and children; and another half of them
11462: who, if they didn't drink, were too ignorant or stupid to see any good
11463: for themselves better than pocketing a five-shilling piece when it was
11464: offered them. Where would be the political power of the thirty sober
11465: men? The power would lie with the seventy drunken and stupid votes; and
11466: I'll tell you what sort of men would get the power--what sort of men
11467: would end by returning whom they pleased to Parliament."
11468: 
11469: Felix had seen every face around him, and had particularly noticed a
11470: recent addition to his audience; but now he looked about him, without
11471: appearing to fix his glance on any one. In spite of his cooling
11472: meditations an hour ago, his pulse was getting quickened by indignation,
11473: and the desire to crush what he hated was likely to vent itself in
11474: articulation. His tone became more biting.
11475: 
11476: "They would be men who would undertake to do the business for a
11477: candidate, and return him: men who have no real opinions, but who pilfer
11478: the words of every opinion, and turn them into a cant which will serve
11479: their purpose at the moment; men who look out for dirty work to make
11480: their fortunes by, because dirty work wants little talent and no
11481: conscience; men who know all the ins and outs of bribery, because there
11482: is not a cranny in their own souls where a bribe can't enter. Such men
11483: as these will be the masters wherever there's a majority of voters who
11484: care more for money, for drink, more for some mean little end which is
11485: their own and nobody else's, than for anything that has ever been called
11486: Right in the world. For suppose there's a poor voter named Jack, who has
11487: seven children, and twelve or fifteen shillings a-week wages, perhaps
11488: less. Jack can't read--I don't say whose fault that is--he never had the
11489: chance to learn; he knows so little that he perhaps thinks God made the
11490: poor-laws, and if anybody said the pattern of the work-house was laid
11491: down in the Testament, he wouldn't be able to contradict them. What is
11492: poor Jack likely to do when he sees a smart stranger coming to him, who
11493: happens to be just one of these men that I say will be the masters till
11494: public opinion gets too hot for them? He's a middle-sized man, we'll
11495: say; stout, with coat upon coat of fine broadcloth, open enough to show
11496: a fine gold chain: none of your dark, scowling men, but one with an
11497: innocent pink-and-white skin and very smooth light hair--a most
11498: respectable man, who calls himself a good, sound, well-known English
11499: name--as Green, or Baker, or Wilson, or let us say, Johnson----"
11500: 
11501: Felix was interrupted by an explosion of laughter from a majority of the
11502: bystanders. Some eyes had been turned on Johnson, who stood on the right
11503: hand of Felix, at the very beginning of the description, and these were
11504: gradually followed by others, till at last every hearer's attention was
11505: fixed on him, and the first burst of laughter from the two or three who
11506: knew the attorney's name, let every one sufficiently into the secret to
11507: make the amusement common. Johnson, who had kept his ground till his
11508: name was mentioned, now turned away, looking unusually white after being
11509: unusually red, and feeling by an attorney's instinct for his
11510: pocket-book, as if he felt it was a case for taking down the names of
11511: witnesses.
11512: 
11513: All the well-dressed hearers turned away too, thinking they had had the
11514: cream of the speech in the joke against Johnson, which, as a thing worth
11515: telling, helped to recall them to the scene of dinner.
11516: 
11517: "Who is this Johnson?" said Christian to a young man who had been
11518: standing near him, and had been one of the first to laugh. Christian's
11519: curiosity had naturally been awakened by what might prove a golden
11520: opportunity.
11521: 
11522: "Oh--a London attorney. He acts for Transome. That tremendous fellow at
11523: the corner there is some red-hot Radical demagogue, and Johnson has
11524: offended him, I suppose; else he wouldn't have turned in that way on a
11525: man of their own party."
11526: 
11527: "I had heard there was a Johnson who was an understrapper of Jermyn's,"
11528: said Christian.
11529: 
11530: "Well, so this man may have been for what I know. But he's a London man
11531: now--a very busy fellow--on his own legs in Bedford Row. Ha, ha! it's
11532: capital, though, when these Liberals get a slap in the face from the
11533: workingmen they're so very fond of."
11534: 
11535: Another turn along the street enabled Christian to come to a resolution.
11536: Having seen Jermyn drive away an hour before, he was in no fear: he
11537: walked at once to the Fox and Hounds and asked to speak to Mr. Johnson.
11538: A brief interview, in which Christian ascertained that he had before him
11539: the Johnson mentioned by the bill-sticker, issued in the appointment of
11540: a longer one at a later hour; and before they left Duffield they had
11541: come not exactly to a mutual understanding, but to an exchange of
11542: information mutually welcome.
11543: 
11544: Christian had been very cautious in the commencement, only intimating
11545: that he knew something important which some chance hints had induced him
11546: to think might be interesting to Mr. Johnson, but that this entirely
11547: depended on how far he had a common interest with Mr. Jermyn. Johnson
11548: replied that he had much business in which that gentleman was not
11549: concerned, but that to a certain extent they had a common interest.
11550: Probably then, Christian observed, the affairs of the Transome estate
11551: were part of the business in which Mr. Jermyn and Mr. Johnson might be
11552: understood to represent each other, in which case he need not detain Mr.
11553: Johnson? At this hint Johnson could not conceal that he was becoming
11554: eager. He had no idea what Christian's information was, but there were
11555: many grounds on which Johnson desired to know as much as he could about
11556: the Transome affairs independently of Jermyn. By little and little an
11557: understanding was arrived at. Christian told of his interview with Tommy
11558: Trounsem, and stated that if Johnson could show him whether the
11559: knowledge could have any legal value, he could bring evidence that a
11560: legitimate child of Bycliffe's existed: he felt certain of his fact, and
11561: of his proof. Johnson explained, that in this case the death of the old
11562: bill-sticker would give the child the first valid claim to the Bycliffe
11563: heirship; that for his own part he should be glad to further a true
11564: claim, but that caution would have to be observed. How did Christian
11565: know that Jermyn, was informed on this subject? Christian, more and more
11566: convinced that Johnson would be glad to counteract Jermyn at length
11567: became explicit about Esther, but still withheld his own real name, and
11568: the nature of his relations with Bycliffe. He said he would bring the
11569: rest of his information when Mr. Johnson took the case up seriously, and
11570: place it in the hands of Bycliffe's old lawyers--of course he would do
11571: that? Johnson replied that he would certainly do that; but that there
11572: were legal niceties which Mr. Christian was probably not acquainted
11573: with; that Esther's claim had not yet accrued, and that hurry was
11574: useless.
11575: 
11576: The two men parted, each in distrust of the other, but each well pleased
11577: to have learned something. Johnson was not at all sure how he should
11578: act, but thought it likely that events would soon guide him. Christian
11579: was beginning to meditate a way of securing his own ends without
11580: depending in the least on Johnson's procedure. It was enough for him
11581: that he was now assured of Esther's legal claim on the Transome estates.
11582: 
11583: 
11584: 
11585: 
11586: CHAPTER XXXI.
11587: 
11588:     "In the copia of the factious language the word Tory was
11589:     entertained, and being a vocal clever-sounding word, readily
11590:     pronounced, it kept its hold, and took possession of the foul
11591:     mouths of the faction.----The Loyalists began to cheer up and to
11592:     take heart of grace, and in the working of this crisis, according
11593:     to the common law of scolding, they considered which way to make
11594:     payment for so much of Tory as they had been treated with to clear
11595:     scores.----Immediately the train took, and ran like wildfire and
11596:     became general. And so the account of Tory was balanced, and soon
11597:     began to run up a sharp score on the other side."--NORTH'S
11598:     _Examen_, p. 321.
11599: 
11600: 
11601: At last the great epoch of the election for North Loamshire had arrived.
11602: The roads approaching Treby were early traversed by a larger number of
11603: vehicles, horsemen, and also foot-passengers than were ever seen at the
11604: annual fair. Treby was the polling-place for many voters whose faces
11605: were quite strange in the town; and if there were some strangers who did
11606: not come to poll, though they had business not unconnected with the
11607: election, they were not liable to be regarded with suspicion or especial
11608: curiosity. It was understood that no division of a county had ever been
11609: more thoroughly canvassed, and that there would be a hard run between
11610: Garstin and Transome. Mr. Johnson's headquarters were at Duffield; but
11611: it was a maxim which he repeated after the great Putty, that a capable
11612: agent makes himself omnipresent; and quite apart from the express
11613: between him and Jermyn, Mr. John Johnson's presence in the universe had
11614: potent effects on this December day at Treby Magna.
11615: 
11616: A slight drizzling rain which was observed by some Tories who looked out
11617: of their bedroom windows before six o'clock, made them hope that, after
11618: all, the day might pass off better than alarmists had expected. The rain
11619: was felt to be somehow on the side of quiet and Conservatism; but soon
11620: the breaking of the clouds and the mild gleams of a December sun brought
11621: back previous apprehensions. As there were already precedents for riot
11622: at a Reformed election, and as the Trebian district had had its
11623: confidence in the natural course of things somewhat shaken by a landed
11624: proprietor with an old name offering himself as a Radical candidate, the
11625: election had been looked forward to by many with a vague sense that it
11626: would be an occasion something like a fighting match, when bad
11627: characters would probably assemble, and there might be struggles and
11628: alarms for respectable men, which would make it expedient for them to
11629: take a little neat brandy as a precaution beforehand and a restorative
11630: afterward. The tenants on the Transome estate were comparatively
11631: fearless: poor Mr. Goffe, of Rabbit's End, considered that "one thing
11632: was as mauling as the other," and that an election was no worse than the
11633: sheep-rot; while Mr. Dibbs, taking the more cheerful view of a
11634: prosperous man, reflected that if the Radicals were dangerous, it was
11635: safer to be on their side. It was the voters for Debarry and Garstin who
11636: considered that they alone had the right to regard themselves as targets
11637: for evil-minded men; and Mr. Crowder, if he could have got his ideas
11638: countenanced, would have recommended a muster of farm-servants with
11639: defensive pitchforks on the side of Church and king. But the bolder men
11640: were rather gratified by the prospect of being groaned at, so that they
11641: might face about and groan in return.
11642: 
11643: Mr. Crow, the high constable of Treby, inwardly rehearsed a brief
11644: address to a riotous crowd in case it should be wanted, having been
11645: warned by the rector that it was a primary duty on these occasions to
11646: keep a watch against provocation as well as violence. The rector, with a
11647: brother magistrate who was on the spot, had thought it desirable to
11648: swear in some special constables, but the presence of loyal men not
11649: absolutely required for the polling was not looked at in the light of a
11650: provocation. The Benefit Clubs from various quarters made a show, some
11651: with the orange-colored ribbons and streamers of the true Tory
11652: candidate, some with the mazarine of the Whig. The orange-colored bands
11653: played "Auld Lang Syne," and a louder mazarine band came across them
11654: with "Oh, whistle and I will come to thee, my lad"--probably as the tune
11655: the most symbolical of Liberalism which their repertory would furnish.
11656: There was not a single club bearing the Radical blue: the Sproxton Club
11657: members wore the mazarine, and Mr. Chubb wore so much of it that he
11658: looked (at a sufficient distance) like a very large gentianella. It was
11659: generally understood that "these brave fellows," representing the fine
11660: institution of Benefit Clubs, holding aloft the motto, "Let brotherly
11661: love continue," were a civil force calculated to encourage voters of
11662: sound opinions and keep up their spirits. But a considerable number of
11663: unadorned heavy navvies, colliers, and stone-pit men, who used their
11664: freedom as British subjects to be present in Treby on this great
11665: occasion, looked like a possible uncivil force whose politics were
11666: dubious until it was clearly seen for whom they cheered and for whom
11667: they groaned.
11668: 
11669: Thus the way up to the polling-booths was variously lined, and those who
11670: walked it, to whatever side they belonged, had the advantage of hearing
11671: from the opposite side what were the most marked defects or excesses in
11672: their personal appearance; for the Trebians of that day held, without
11673: being aware that they had Cicero's authority for it, that the bodily
11674: blemishes of an opponent were a legitimate ground for ridicule; but if
11675: the voter frustrated wit by being handsome, he was groaned at and
11676: satirized according to a formula, in which the adjective was Tory, Whig,
11677: or Radical, as the case might be, and the substantive a blank to be
11678: filled up after the taste of the speaker.
11679: 
11680: Some of the more timid had chosen to go through this ordeal as early as
11681: possible in the morning. One of the earliest was Mr. Timothy Rose, the
11682: gentleman-farmer from Leek Malton. He had left home with some
11683: foreboding, having swathed his more vital parts in layers of flannel,
11684: and put on two greatcoats as a soft kind of armor. But reflecting with
11685: some trepidation that there were no resources for protecting his head,
11686: he once more wavered in his intention to vote; he once more observed to
11687: Mrs. Rose that these were hard times when a man of independent property
11688: was expected to vote "willy-nilly;" but finally coerced by the sense
11689: that he should be looked ill on "in these times" if he did not stand by
11690: the gentlemen round about, he set out in his gig, taking with him a
11691: powerful wagoner, whom he ordered to keep him in sight as he went to
11692: the polling-booth. It was hardly more than nine o'clock when Mr. Rose,
11693: having thus come up to the level of his times, cheered himself with a
11694: little cherry-brandy at the Marquis, drove away in a much more
11695: courageous spirit, and got down at Mr. Nolan's, just outside the town.
11696: The retired Londoner, he considered, was a man of experience, who would
11697: estimate properly the judicious course he had taken, and could make it
11698: known to others. Mr. Nolan was superintending the removal of some shrubs
11699: in his garden.
11700: 
11701: "Well, Mr. Nolan," said Rose, twinkling a self-complacent look over the
11702: red prominence of his cheeks, "have you been to give your vote yet?"
11703: 
11704: "No; all in good time. I shall go presently."
11705: 
11706: "Well, I wouldn't lose an hour, I wouldn't. I said to myself, if I've
11707: got to do gentlemen a favor, I'll do it at once. You see, I've got no
11708: landlord, Nolan--I'm in that position o' life that I can be
11709: independent."
11710: 
11711: "Just so, my dear sir," said the wiry-faced Nolan, pinching his
