11712: under-lip between his thumb and finger, and giving one of those
11713: wonderful universal shrugs, by which he seemed to be recalling all his
11714: garments from a tendency to disperse themselves. "Come in and see Mrs.
11715: Nolan?"
11716: 
11717: "No, no, thankye. Mrs. Rose expects me back. But, as I was saying, I'm a
11718: independent man, and I consider it's not my part to show favor to one
11719: more than another, but to make things as even as I can. If I'd been a
11720: tenant to anybody, well, in course I must have voted for my
11721: landlord--that stands to sense. But I wish everybody well; and if one's
11722: returned to Parliament more than another, nobody can say it's my doing;
11723: for when you can vote for two, you can make things even. So I gave one
11724: to Debarry and one to Transome; and I wish Garstin no ill, but I can't
11725: help the odd number, and he hangs on to Debarry, they say."
11726: 
11727: "God bless me, sir," said Mr. Nolan, coughing down a laugh, "don't you
11728: perceive that you might as well have stayed at home and not voted at
11729: all, unless you would rather send a Radical to Parliament than a sober
11730: Whig?"
11731: 
11732: "Well, I'm sorry you should have anything to say against what I've done,
11733: Nolan," said Mr. Rose, rather crestfallen, though sustained by inward
11734: warmth. "I thought you'd agree with me, as you're a sensible man. But
11735: the most a independent man can do is to try and please all; and if he
11736: hasn't the luck--here's wishing I may do it another time," added Mr.
11737: Rose, apparently confounding a toast with a salutation, for he put out
11738: his hand for a passing shake, and then stepped into his gig again.
11739: 
11740: At the time that Mr. Timothy Rose left the town, the crowd in King
11741: Street and in the market-place, where the polling-booths stood, was
11742: fluctuating. Voters as yet were scanty, and brave fellows who had come
11743: from any distance this morning, or who had sat up late drinking the
11744: night before, required some reinforcement of their strength and spirits.
11745: Every public house in Treby, not excepting the venerable and sombre
11746: Cross-Keys, was lively with changing and numerous company. Not, of
11747: course, that there was any treating: treating necessarily had stopped,
11748: from moral scruples, when once "the writs were out;" but there was
11749: drinking, which did equally well under any name.
11750: 
11751: Poor Tommy Trounsem, breakfasting here on Falstaff's proportion of
11752: bread, and something which, for gentility's sake, I will call sack, was
11753: more than usually victorious over the ills of life, and felt himself one
11754: of the heroes of the day. He had an immense light-blue cockade in his
11755: hat, and an amount of silver in a dirty little canvas bag which
11756: astonished himself. For some reason, at first inscrutable to him, he had
11757: been paid for his bill-sticking with great liberality at Mr. Jermyn's
11758: office, in spite of his having been the victim of a trick by which he
11759: had once lost his own bills and pasted up Debarry's; but he soon saw
11760: that this was simply a recognition of his merit as "an old family kept
11761: out of its rights," and also of his peculiar share in an occasion when
11762: the family was to get into Parliament. Under these circumstances, it was
11763: due from him that he should show himself prominently where business was
11764: going forward, and give additional value by his presence to every vote
11765: for Transome. With this view he got a half-pint bottle filled with his
11766: peculiar kind of "sack," and hastened back to the market-place, feeling
11767: good-natured and patronizing toward all political parties, and only so
11768: far partial as his family bound him to be.
11769: 
11770: But a disposition to concentrate at that extremity of King Street which
11771: issued in the market-place, was not universal among the increasing
11772: crowd. Some of them seemed attracted toward another nucleus at the other
11773: extremity of King Street, near the Seven Stars. This was Garstin's chief
11774: house, where his committee sat, and it was also a point which must
11775: necessarily be passed by many voters entering the town on the eastern
11776: side. It seemed natural that the mazarine colors should be visible
11777: here, and that Pack, the tall "shepherd" of the Sproxton men, should be
11778: seen moving to and fro where there would be a frequent opportunity of
11779: cheering the voters for a gentleman who had the chief share in the
11780: Sproxton mines. But the side lanes and entries out of King Street were
11781: numerous enough to relieve any pressure if there was need to make way.
11782: The lanes had a distinguished reputation. Two of them had odors of
11783: brewing; one had a side entrance to Mr. Tiliot's wine and spirit vaults;
11784: up another Mr. Muscat's cheeses were frequently being unloaded; and even
11785: some of the entries had those cheerful suggestions of plentiful
11786: provision which were among the characteristics of Treby.
11787: 
11788: Between ten and eleven the voters came in more rapid succession, and the
11789: whole scene became spirited. Cheers, sarcasms, and oaths, which seemed
11790: to have a flavor of wit for many hearers, were beginning to be
11791: reinforced by more practical demonstrations, dubiously jocose. There was
11792: a disposition in the crowd to close and hem in the way for voters,
11793: either going or coming, until they had paid some kind of toll. It was
11794: difficult to see who set the example in the transition from words to
11795: deeds. Some thought it was due to Jacob Cuff, a Tory charity-man, who
11796: was a well-known ornament of the pothouse, and gave his mind much
11797: leisure for amusing devices; but questions of origination in stirring
11798: periods are notoriously hard to settle. It is by no means necessary in
11799: human things that there should be only one beginner. This, however, is
11800: certain--that Mr. Chubb, who wished it to be noticed that he voted for
11801: Garstin solely, was one of the first to get rather more notice than he
11802: wished, and that he had his hat knocked off and crushed in the interest
11803: of Debarry by Tories opposed to coalition. On the other hand, some said
11804: it was at the same time that Mr. Pink, the saddler, being stopped on his
11805: way and made to declare that he was going to vote for Debarry, got
11806: himself well chalked as to his coat, and pushed up an entry, where he
11807: remained the prisoner of terror combined with the want of any back
11808: outlet, and never gave his vote that day.
11809: 
11810: The second Tory joke was performed with much gusto. The majority of the
11811: Transome tenants came in a body from the Ram Inn, with Mr. Banks, the
11812: bailiff, leading them. Poor Goffe was the last of them, and his worn
11813: melancholy look and forward-leaning gait gave the jocose Cuff the notion
11814: that the farmer was not what he called "compus." Mr. Goffe was cut off
11815: from his companions and hemmed in: asked, by voices with hot breath
11816: close to his ear, how many horses he had, how many cows, how many fat
11817: pigs; then jostled from one to another, who made trumpets with their
11818: hands, and deafened him by telling him to vote for Debarry. In this way
11819: the melancholy Goffe was hustled on till he was at the polling-booth,
11820: filled with confused alarms, the immediate alarm being that of having to
11821: go back in still worse fashion than he had come. Arriving in this way
11822: after the other tenants had left, he astonished all hearers who knew him
11823: for a tenant of the Transomes by saying "Debarry," and was jostled back
11824: trembling amid shouts of laughter.
11825: 
11826: By stages of this kind the fun grew faster, and was in danger of getting
11827: rather serious. The Tories began to feel that their jokes were returned
11828: by others of a heavier sort, and that the main strength of the crowd was
11829: not on the side of sound opinion, but might come to be on the side of
11830: sound cudgelling and kicking. The navvies and pitmen in dishabille
11831: seemed to be multiplying, and to be clearly not belonging to the party
11832: of Order. The shops were freely resorted to for various forms of playful
11833: missiles and weapons; and news came to the magistrates, watching from
11834: the large window of the Marquis, that a gentleman coming in on horseback
11835: at the other end of the street to vote for Garstin had had his horse
11836: turned round and frightened into a headlong gallop out of it again.
11837: 
11838: Mr. Crow and his subordinates, and all the special constables, felt that
11839: it was necessary to make some energetic effort, or else every voter
11840: would be intimidated and the poll must be adjourned. The rector
11841: determined to get on horseback and go amidst the crowd with the
11842: constables; and he sent a message to Mr. Lingon, who was at the Ram,
11843: calling on him to do the same. "Sporting Jack" was sure the good fellows
11844: meant no harm, but he was courageous enough to face any bodily dangers,
11845: and rode out in his brown leggings and colored bandana, speaking
11846: persuasively.
11847: 
11848: It was nearly twelve o'clock when this sally was made: the constables
11849: and magistrates tried the most pacific measures, and they seemed to
11850: succeed. There was a rapid thinning of the crowd: the most boisterous
11851: disappeared, or seemed to do so by becoming quiet; missiles ceased to
11852: fly, and a sufficient way was cleared for voters along King Street. The
11853: magistrates returned to their quarters, and the constables took
11854: convenient posts of observation. Mr. Wace, who was one of Debarry's
11855: committee, had suggested to the rector that it might be wise to send
11856: for the military from Duffield, with orders that they should station
11857: themselves at Hathercote, three miles off: there was so much property in
11858: the town that it would be better to make it secure against risks. But
11859: the rector felt that this was not the part of a moderate and wise
11860: magistrate, unless the signs of riot recurred. He was a brave man, and
11861: fond of thinking that his own authority sufficed for the maintenance of
11862: the general good in Treby.
11863: 
11864: 
11865: 
11866: 
11867: CHAPTER XXXII.
11868: 
11869:     Go from me. Yet I feel that I shall stand
11870:     Henceforward in thy shadow. Nevermore
11871:     Alone upon the threshold of my door
11872:     Of individual life, I shall command
11873:     The uses of my soul, nor lift my hand
11874:     Serenely in the sunshine as before
11875:     Without the sense of that which I forbore--
11876:     Thy touch upon the palm. The widest land
11877:     Doom takes to part us, leaves thy heart in mine
11878:     With pulses that beat double. What I do
11879:     And what I dream include thee, as the wine
11880:     Must taste of its own grapes. And when I sue
11881:     God for myself, He hears that name of thine,
11882:     And sees within my eyes the tears of two.
11883: 
11884:                                             --MRS. BROWNING.
11885: 
11886: 
11887: Felix Holt, seated at his work without his pupils, who had asked for a
11888: holiday with a notion that the wooden booths promised some sort of show,
11889: noticed about eleven o'clock that the noises which reached him from the
11890: main street were getting more and more tumultuous. He had long seen bad
11891: auguries for this election, but, like all people who dread the prophetic
11892: wisdom that ends in desiring the fulfillment of its own evil
11893: forebodings, he had checked himself with remembering that, though many
11894: conditions were possible which might bring on violence, there were just
11895: as many which might avert it. There would, perhaps, be no other mischief
11896: than what he was already certain of. With these thoughts he sat down
11897: quietly to his work, meaning not to vex his soul by going to look on at
11898: things he would fain have made different if he could. But he was of a
11899: fiber that vibrated too strongly to the life around him to shut himself
11900: away in quiet, even from suffering and irremediable wrong. As the noises
11901: grew louder, and wrought more and more strongly on his imagination, he
11902: was obliged to lay down his delicate wheel-work. His mother came from
11903: her turnip-paring, in the kitchen, where little Job was her companion,
11904: to observe that they must be killing everybody in the High Street, and
11905: that the election, which had never been before at Treby, must have come
11906: for a judgment; that there were mercies where you didn't look for them,
11907: and that she thanked God in His wisdom for making her live up a back
11908: street.
11909: 
11910: Felix snatched his cap and rushed out. But when he got to the turning
11911: into the market-place the magistrates were already on horseback there,
11912: the constables were moving about, and Felix observed that there was no
11913: strong spirit of resistance to them. He stayed long enough to see the
11914: partial dispersion of the crowd and the restoration of tolerable quiet,
11915: and then went back to Mrs. Holt to tell her that there was nothing to
11916: fear now; he was going out again, and she must not be in any anxiety at
11917: his absence. She might set by his dinner for him.
11918: 
11919: Felix had been thinking of Esther and her probable alarm at the noises
11920: that must have reached her more distinctly than they had reached him,
11921: for Malthouse Yard was removed but a little way from the main street.
11922: Mr. Lyon was away from home, having been called to preach charity
11923: sermons and attend meetings in a distant town; and Esther, with the
11924: plaintive Lyddy for her sole companion, was not cheerfully
11925: circumstanced. Felix had not been to see her yet since her father's
11926: departure, but to-day he gave way to new reasons.
11927: 
11928: "Miss Esther was in the garret," Lyddy said, trying to see what was
11929: going on. But before she was fetched she came running down the stairs,
11930: drawn by the knock at the door, which had shaken the small dwelling.
11931: 
11932: "I am so thankful to see you," she said, eagerly. "Pray come in."
11933: 
11934: When she had shut the parlor door behind them, Felix said, "I suspected
11935: that you might have been made anxious by the noises. I came to tell you
11936: that things are quiet now. Though, indeed, you can hear that they are."
11937: 
11938: "I _was_ frightened," said Esther. "The shouting and roaring of rude men
11939: is so hideous. It is a relief to me that my father is not at home--that
11940: he is out of the reach of any danger he might have fallen into if he had
11941: been here. But I gave you credit for being in the midst of the danger,"
11942: she added, smiling, with a determination not to show much feeling. "Sit
11943: down and tell me what has happened."
11944: 
11945: They sat down at the extremities of the old black sofa, and Felix said--
11946: 
11947: "To tell you the truth, I had shut myself up, and tried to be as
11948: indifferent to the election as if I'd been one of the fishes in the
11949: Lapp, till the noises got too strong for me. But I only saw the tail end
11950: of the disturbance. The poor noisy simpletons seemed to give way before
11951: the magistrates and the constables. I hope nobody has been much hurt.
11952: The fear is that they may turn out again by-and-by; their giving way so
11953: soon may not be altogether a good sign. There's a great number of heavy
11954: fellows in the town. If they go and drink more, the last end may be
11955: worse than the first. However----"
11956: 
11957: Felix broke off, as if this talk was futile, clasped his hands behind
11958: his head, and, leaning backward, looked at Esther, who was looking at
11959: him.
11960: 
11961: "May I stay here a little while?" he said, after a moment, which seemed
11962: long.
11963: 
11964: "Pray do," said Esther, coloring. To relieve herself she took some work
11965: and bowed her head over her stitching. It was in reality a little heaven
11966: to her that Felix was there, but she saw beyond it--saw that by-and-by
11967: he would be gone, and that they should be farther on their way, not
11968: toward meeting, but parting. His will was impregnable. He was a rock,
11969: and she was no more to him than the white clinging mist-cloud.
11970: 
11971: "I wish I could be sure that you see things just as I do," he said
11972: abruptly, after a minute's silence.
11973: 
11974: "I am sure you see them much more wisely than I do!" said Esther, almost
11975: bitterly, without looking up.
11976: 
11977: "There are some people one must wish to judge truly. Not to wish it
11978: would be mere hardness. I know you think I am a man without feeling--at
11979: least, without strong affections. You think I love nothing but my own
11980: resolutions."
11981: 
11982: "Suppose I reply in the same sort of strain?" said Esther, with a little
11983: toss of the head.
11984: 
11985: "How?"
11986: 
11987: "Why, that you think me a shallow woman, incapable of believing what is
11988: best in you, setting down everything that is too high for me as a
11989: deficiency."
11990: 
11991: "Don't parry what I say. Answer me." There was an expression of painful
11992: beseeching in the tone with which Felix said this. Esther let her work
11993: fall on her lap and looked at him, but she was unable to speak.
11994: 
11995: "I want you to tell me--once--that you know it would be easier to me to
11996: give myself up to loving and being loved, as other men do, when they
11997: can, than to----"
11998: 
11999: This breaking-off in speech was something quite new in Felix. For the
12000: first time he had lost his self-possession, and turned his eyes away. He
12001: was at variance with himself. He had begun what he felt he ought not to
12002: finish.
12003: 
12004: Esther, like a woman as she was--a woman waiting for love, never able
12005: to ask for it--had her joy in these signs of her power; but they made
12006: her generous, not chary, as they might have done if she had had a
12007: pettier disposition. She said, with deep yet timid earnestness--
12008: 
12009: "What you have chosen to do has only convinced me that your love would
12010: be the better worth having."
12011: 
12012: All the finest part of Esther's nature trembled in those words. To be
12013: right in great memorable moments is perhaps the thing we need most
12014: desire for ourselves.
12015: 
12016: Felix as quick as lightning turned his look upon her again, and, leaning
12017: forward, took her sweet hand and held it to his lips some moments before
12018: he let it fall again and raised his head.
12019: 
12020: "We shall always be the better for thinking of each other," he said,
12021: leaning his elbow on the back of the sofa, and supporting his head as he
12022: looked at her with calm sadness. "This thing can never come to me twice
12023: over. It is my knighthood. That was always a business of great cost."
12024: 
12025: He smiled at her, but she sat biting her inner lip and pressing her
12026: hands together. She desired to be worthy of what she reverenced in
12027: Felix, but the inevitable renunciation was too difficult. She saw
12028: herself wandering through the future weak and forsaken. The charming
12029: sauciness was all gone from her face, but the memory of it made this
12030: childlike dependent sorrow all the more touching.
12031: 
12032: "Tell me what you would----" Felix burst out, leaning nearer to her; but
12033: the next instant he started up, went to the table, took his cap in his
12034: hand and came in front of her.
12035: 
12036: "Good-bye," he said, very gently, not daring to put out his hand. But
12037: Esther put up hers instead of speaking. He just pressed it and then went
12038: away.
12039: 
12040: She heard the doors close behind him, and felt free to be miserable. She
12041: cried bitterly. If she might have married Felix Holt, she could have
12042: been a good woman. She felt no trust that she could ever be good without
12043: him.
12044: 
12045: Felix reproached himself. He would have done better not to speak in that
12046: way. But the prompting to which he had chiefly listened had been the
12047: desire to prove to Esther that he set a high value on her feelings. He
12048: could not help seeing that he was very important to her; and he was too
12049: simple and sincere a man to ape a sort of humility which would not have
12050: made him any the better if he had possessed it. Such pretences turn our
12051: lives into sorry dramas. And Felix wished Esther to know that her love
12052: was dear to him as the beloved dead are dear. He felt that they must
12053: not marry--that they would ruin each other's lives. But he had longed
12054: for her to know fully that his will to be always apart from her was
12055: renunciation, not an easy preference. In this he was thoroughly
12056: generous; and yet, now some subtle, mysterious conjuncture of
12057: impressions and circumstances had made him speak, he questioned the
12058: wisdom of what he had done. Express confessions give definiteness to
12059: memories that might more easily melt away without; and Felix felt for
12060: Esther's pain as the strong soldier, who can march on hungering without
12061: fear that he shall faint, feels for the young brother--the
12062: maiden-cheeked conscript whose load is too heavy for him.
12063: 
12064: 
12065: 
12066: 
12067: CHAPTER XXXIII.
12068: 
12069:     Mischief, thou art afoot.--_Julius Cæsar._
12070: 
12071: 
12072: Felix could not go home again immediately after quitting Esther. He got
12073: out of the town, skirted it a little while, looking across the December
12074: stillness of the fields, and then re-entered it by the main road into
12075: the market-place, thinking that, after all, it would be better for him
12076: to look at the busy doings of men than to listen in solitude to the
12077: voices within him; and he wished to know how things were going on.
12078: 
12079: It was now nearly half-past one, and Felix perceived that the street was
12080: filling with more than the previous crowd. By the time he got in front
12081: of the booths, he was himself so surrounded by men who were being thrust
12082: hither and thither that retreat would have been impossible; and he went
12083: where he was obliged to go, although his height and strength were above
12084: the average even in a crowd where there were so many heavy-armed workmen
12085: used to the pickaxe. Almost all shabby-coated Trebians must have been
12086: there, but the entries and back streets of the town did not supply the
12087: mass of the crowd; and besides the rural incomers, both of the more
12088: decent and the rougher sort, Felix, as he was pushed along, thought he
12089: discerned here and there men of that keener aspect which is only common
12090: in manufacturing towns.
12091: 
12092: But at present there was no evidence of any distinctly mischievous
12093: design. There was only evidence that the majority of the crowd were
12094: excited with drink, and that their action could hardly be calculated on
12095: more than those of the oxen and pigs congregated amidst hootings and
12096: pushings. The confused deafening shouts, the incidental fighting, the
12097: knocking over, pulling and scuffling, seemed to increase every moment.
12098: Such of the constables as were mixed with the crowd were quite helpless;
12099: and if an official staff was seen above the heads, it moved about
12100: fitfully, showing as little sign of a guiding hand as the summit of a
12101: buoy on the waves. Doubtless many hurts and bruises had been received,
12102: but no one could know the amount of injuries that were widely scattered.
12103: 
12104: It was clear that no more voting could be done, and the poll had been
12105: adjourned. The probabilities of serious mischief had grown strong enough
12106: to prevail over the rector's objection to getting military aid within
12107: reach; and when Felix re-entered the town, a galloping messenger had
12108: already been dispatched to Duffield. The rector wished to ride out
12109: again, and read the Riot Act from a point where he could be better heard
12110: than from the window of the Marquis; but Mr. Crow, the high
12111: constable, who had returned from closer observation, insisted that the
12112: risk would be too great. New special constables had been sworn in, but
12113: Mr. Crow said prophetically that if once mischief began, the mob was
12114: past caring for constables.
12115: 
12116: But the rector's voice was ringing and penetrating, and when he appeared
12117: on the narrow balcony and read the formula, commanding all men to go to
12118: their homes or about their lawful business, there was a strong transient
12119: effect. Every one within hearing listened, and for a few moments after
12120: the final words, "God save the King!" the comparative silence continued.
12121: Then the people began to move, the buzz rose again, and grew, and grew,
12122: till it turned to shouts and roaring as before. The movement was that of
12123: a flood hemmed in; it carried nobody away. Whether the crowd would obey
12124: the order to disperse themselves within an hour, was a doubt that
12125: approached nearer to a negative certainty.
12126: 
12127: Presently Mr. Crow, who called himself a tactician, took a
12128: well-intentioned step, which went far to fulfill his own prophecy. He
12129: had arrived with the magistrates by a back way at the Seven Stars, and
12130: here again the Riot Act was read from a window, with much the same
12131: result as before. The rector had returned by the same way to the
12132: Marquis, as the headquarters most suited for administration, but Mr.
12133: Crow remained at the other extremity of King Street, where some
12134: awe-striking presence was certainly needed. Seeing that the time was
12135: passing, and all effect from the voice of law had disappeared, he showed
12136: himself at an upper window, and addressed the crowd, telling them that
12137: the soldiers had been sent for, and that if they did not disperse they
12138: would have cavalry upon them instead of constables.
12139: 
12140: Mr. Crow, like some other high constables more celebrated in history,
12141: "enjoyed a bad reputation"; that is to say, he enjoyed many things which
12142: caused his reputation to be bad, and he was anything but popular in
12143: Treby. It is probable that a pleasant message would have lost something
12144: from his lips, and what he actually said was so unpleasant that, instead
12145: of persuading the crowd, it appeared to enrage them. Some one, snatching
12146: a raw potato from a sack in the green-grocer's shop behind him, threw it
12147: at the constable, and hit him on the mouth. Straightway raw potatoes and
12148: turnips were flying by twenties at the windows of the Seven Stars, and
12149: the panes were smashed. Felix, who was half-way up the street, heard the
12150: voices turning to a savage roar, and saw a rush toward the hardware
12151: shop, which furnished more effective weapons and missiles than turnips
12152: and potatoes. Then a cry ran along that the Tories had sent for the
12153: soldiers, and if those among the mob who called themselves Tories as
12154: willingly as anything else were disposed to take whatever called itself
12155: the Tory side, they only helped the main result of reckless disorder.
12156: 
12157: But there were proofs that the predominant will of the crowd was against
12158: "Debarry's men," and in favor of Transome. Several shops were invaded,
12159: and they were all of them "Tory shops." The tradesmen who could do so
12160: now locked their doors and barricaded their windows within. There was a
12161: panic among the householders of this hitherto peaceful town, and a
12162: general anxiety for the military to arrive. The rector was in painful
12163: anxiety on this head; he had sent out two messengers as secretly as he
12164: could toward Hathercote, to order the soldiers to ride straight to the
12165: town; but he feared that these messengers had been somehow intercepted.
12166: 
12167: It was three o'clock; more than an hour had elapsed since the reading of
12168: the Riot Act. The rector of Treby Magna wrote an indignant message and
12169: sent it to the Ram, to Mr. Lingon, the rector of Little Treby, saying
12170: that there was evidently a Radical animus in the mob, and that Mr.
12171: Transome's party should hold themselves peculiarly responsible. Where
12172: was Mr. Jermyn?
12173: 
12174: Mr. Lingon replied that he was going himself out toward Duffield to see
12175: after the soldiers. As for Jermyn, he was not that attorney's sponsor;
12176: he believed that Jermyn was gone away somewhere on business--to fetch
12177: voters.
12178: 
12179: A serious effort was now being made by all the civil force at command.
12180: The December day would soon be passing into evening, and all disorder
12181: would be aggravated by obscurity. The horrors of fire were as likely to
12182: happen as any minor evil. The constables, as many of them as could do
12183: so, armed themselves with carbines and sabres; all the respectable
12184: inhabitants who had any courage, prepared themselves to struggle for
12185: order; and many felt with Mr. Wace and Mr. Tiliot that the nearest duty
12186: was to defend the breweries and the spirit and wine vaults, where the
12187: property was of a sort at once most likely to be threatened and most
12188: dangerous in its effects. The rector, with fine determination, got on
12189: horseback again, as the best mode of leading the constables, who could
12190: only act efficiently in a close body. By his direction the column of
12191: armed men avoided the main street, and made their way along a back road,
12192: that they might occupy the two chief lanes leading into the wine-vaults
12193: of the brewery, and bear down on the crowd from these openings, which it
12194: was especially desirable to guard.
12195: 
12196: Meanwhile Felix Holt had been hotly occupied in King Street. After the
12197: first window-smashing at the Seven Stars, there was a sufficient reason
12198: for damaging that inn to the utmost. The destructive spirit tends toward
12199: completeness; and any object once maimed or otherwise injured, is as
12200: readily doomed by unreasoning men as by unreasoning boys. Also the Seven
12201: Stars sheltered Spratt; and to some Sproxton men in front of that inn it
12202: was exasperating that Spratt should be safe and sound on a day when
12203: blows were going, and justice might be rendered. And again, there was
12204: the general desirableness of being inside a public house.
12205: 
12206: Felix had at last been willingly urged on to this spot. Hitherto swayed
12207: by the crowd, he had been able to do nothing but defend himself and keep
12208: on his legs; but he foresaw that the people would burst into the inn; he
12209: heard cries of "Spratt!" "Fetch him out!" "We'll pitch him out!" "Pummel
12210: him!" It was not unlikely that lives might be sacrificed; and it was
12211: intolerable to Felix to be witnessing the blind outrages of this mad
12212: crowd, and yet be doing nothing to counteract them. Even some vain
12213: effort would satisfy him better than mere gazing. Within the walls of
12214: the inn he might save some one. He went in with a miscellaneous set, who
12215: dispersed themselves with different objects--some to the tap-room, and
12216: to search for the cellar: some up-stairs to search in all the rooms for
12217: Spratt, or any one else, perhaps, as a temporary scapegoat for Spratt.
12218: Guided by the screams of women, Felix at last got to a high up-stairs
12219: passage, where the landlady and some of her servants were running away
12220: in helpless terror from two or three half-tipsy men, who had been
12221: emptying a spirit decanter in the bar. Assuming the tone of a mob-leader
12222: he cried out, "Here, boys, here's better fun this way--come with me!"
12223: and drew the men back with him along the passage. They reached the lower
12224: staircase in time to see the unhappy Spratt being dragged, coatless and
12225: screaming, down the steps. No one at present was striking or kicking
12226: him; it seemed as if he were being reserved for punishment on some wider
12227: area, where the satisfaction might be more generally shared. Felix
12228: followed close, determined, if he could, to rescue both assailers and
12229: assaulted from the worst consequences. His mind was busy with possible
12230: devices.
12231: 
12232: Down the stairs, out along the stones through the gateway, Spratt was
12233: dragged as a mere heap of linen and cloth rags. When he was got outside
12234: the gateway, there was an immense hooting and roaring, though many there
12235: had no grudge against him, and only guessed that others had the grudge.
12236: But this was the narrower part of the street; it widened as it went
12237: onward, and Spratt was dragged on, his enemies crying, "We'll make a
12238: ring--we'll see how frightened he looks!"
12239: 
12240: "Kick him, and have done with him," Felix heard another say. "Let's go
12241: to Tiliot's vaults--there's more gin there!"
12242: 
12243: Here were two hideous threats. In dragging Spratt onward the people were
12244: getting very near to the lane leading up to Tiliot's. Felix kept as
12245: close as he could to the threatened victim. He had thrown away his own
12246: stick, and carried a bludgeon which had escaped from the hands of an
12247: invader at the Seven Stars; his head was bare; he looked, to
12248: undiscerning eyes, like a leading spirit of the mob. In this condition
12249: he was observed by several persons looking anxiously from their upper
12250: windows, and finally observed to push himself, by violent efforts, close
12251: behind the dragged man.
12252: 
12253: Meanwhile, the foremost among the constables, who, coming by the back
12254: way, had now reached the opening of Tiliot's lane, discerned that the
12255: crowd had a victim amongst them. One spirited fellow, named Tucker, who
12256: was a regular constable, feeling that no time was to be lost in
12257: meditation, called on his neighbor to follow him, and with a sabre that
12258: happened to be his weapon, got away for himself where he was not
12259: expected, by dint of quick resolution. At this moment Spratt had been
12260: let go--had been dropped, in fact, almost lifeless with terror, on the
12261: street stones, and the men round him had retreated for a little space,
12262: as if to amuse themselves with looking at him. Felix had taken his
12263: opportunity; and seeing the first step toward a plan he was bent on, he
12264: sprang forward close to the cowering Spratt. As he did this, Tucker had
12265: cut his way to the spot, and imagining Felix to be the destined
12266: executioner of Spratt--for any discrimination of Tucker's lay in his
12267: muscles rather than his eyes--he rushed up to Felix, meaning to collar
12268: him and throw him down. But Felix had rapid senses and quick thoughts;
12269: he discerned the situation; he chose between two evils. Quick as
12270: lightning he frustrated the constable, fell upon him, and tried to
12271: master his weapon. In the struggle, which was watched without
12272: interference, the constable fell undermost, and Felix got his weapon. He
12273: started up with the bare sabre in his hand. The crowd round him cried
12274: "Hurray!" with a sense that he was on their side against the constable.
12275: Tucker did not rise immediately; but Felix did not imagine that he was
12276: much hurt.
12277: 
12278: "Don't touch him!" said Felix. "Let him go. Here, bring Spratt, and
12279: follow me."
12280: 
12281: Felix was perfectly conscious that he was in the midst of a tangled
12282: business. But he had chiefly before his imagination the horrors that
12283: might come if the mass of wild chaotic desires and impulses around him
12284: were not diverted from any further attacks on places where they would
12285: get in the midst of intoxicating and inflammable materials. It was not a
12286: moment in which a spirit like his could calculate the effect of
12287: misunderstanding as to himself: nature never makes men who are at once
12288: energetically sympathetic and minutely calculating. He believed he had
12289: the power and was resolved to try, to carry the dangerous mass out of
12290: mischief till the military came to awe them--which he supposed, from Mr.
12291: Crow's announcement a long time ago, must be a near event.
12292: 
12293: He was followed the more willingly, because Tiliot's lane was seen by
12294: the hindmost to be now defended by constables, some of whom had
12295: firearms; and where there is no strong counter-movement, any proposition
12296: to do something that is unspecified stimulates stupid curiosity. To many
12297: of the Sproxton men who were within sight of him, Felix was known
12298: personally, and vaguely believed to be a man who meant many queer
12299: things, not at all of an everyday kind. Pressing along like a leader,
12300: with the sabre in his hand, and inviting them to bring on Spratt, there
12301: seemed a better reason for following him than for doing anything else. A
12302: man with a definite will and an energetic personality acts as a sort of
12303: flag to draw and bind together the foolish units of a mob. It was on
12304: this sort of influence over men whose mental state was a mere medley of
12305: appetites and confused impressions, that Felix had dared to count. He
12306: hurried them along with words of invitation, telling them to hold up
12307: Spratt and not drag him; and those behind followed him, with a growing
12308: belief that he had some design worth knowing, while those in front were
12309: urged along partly by the same notion, partly by the sense that there
12310: was a motive in those behind them, not knowing what the motive was. It
12311: was that mixture of pushing forward and being pushed forward, which is a
12312: brief history of most human things.
12313: 
12314: What Felix really intended to do, was to get the crowd by the nearest
12315: way out of the town, and induce them to skirt it on the north side with
12316: him, keeping up in them the idea that he was leading them to execute
12317: some stratagem, by which they would surprise something worth attacking,
12318: and circumvent the constables who were defending the lanes. In the
12319: meantime he trusted that the soldiers would have arrived, and with this
12320: sort of mob which was animated by no real political passion or fury
12321: against social distinctions, it was in the highest degree unlikely that
12322: there would be any resistance to a military force. The presence of fifty
12323: soldiers would probably be enough to scatter the rioting hundreds. How
12324: numerous the mob was, no one ever knew: many inhabitants afterward were
12325: ready to swear that there must have been at least two thousand rioters.
12326: Felix knew he was incurring great risks; but "his blood was up"; we
12327: hardly allow enough in common life for the results of that enkindled
12328: passionate enthusiasm which, under other conditions, makes world-famous
12329: deeds.
12330: 
12331: He was making for a point where the street branched off on one side
12332: toward a speedy opening between hedgerows, on the other toward the
12333: shabby wideness of Pollard's End. At this forking of the street there
12334: was a large space, in the centre of which there was a small stone
12335: platform, mounting by three steps, with an old green finger-post upon
12336: it. Felix went straight to this platform and stepped upon it, crying
12337: "Halt!" in a loud voice to the men behind and before him, and calling to
12338: those who held Spratt to bring him there. All came to a stand with faces
12339: toward the finger-post, and perhaps for the first time the extremities
12340: of the crowd got a definite idea that a man with a sabre in his hand was
12341: taking the command.
12342: 
12343: "Now!" said Felix, when Spratt had been brought to the stone platform,
12344: faint and trembling, "has anybody got cord? if not, handkerchiefs
12345: knotted fast; give them to me."
12346: 
12347: He drew out his own handkerchief, and two or three others were mustered
12348: and handed to him. He ordered them to be knotted together, while curious
12349: eyes were fixed on him. Was he going to have Spratt hanged? Felix kept
12350: fast hold of his weapon, and ordered others to act.
12351: 
12352: "Now, put it round his waist, wind his arms in, draw them a little
12353: backward--so! and tie it fast on the other side of the post."
12354: 
12355: When that was done, Felix said, imperatively:
12356: 
12357: "Leave him there--we shall come back to him; let us make haste; march
12358: along, lads! Up Park Street and down Hobb's Lane."
12359: 
12360: It was the best chance he could think of for saving Spratt's life. And
12361: he succeeded. The pleasure of seeing the helpless man tied up sufficed
12362: for the moment, if there were any who had ferocity enough to count much
12363: on coming back to him. Nobody's imagination represented the certainty
12364: that some one out of the houses at hand would soon come and untie him
12365: when he was left alone.
12366: 
12367: And the rioters pushed up Park Street, a noisy stream, with Felix still
12368: in the midst of them, though he was laboring hard to get his way to the
12369: front. He wished to determine the course of the crowd along a by-road
12370: called Hobb's Lane, which would have taken them to the other--the
12371: Duffield end of the town. He urged several of the men round him, one of
12372: whom was no less a person than the big Dredge, our old Sproxton
12373: acquaintance, to get forward, and be sure that all the fellows would go
12374: down the lane, else they would spoil sport. Hitherto Felix had been
12375: successful, and he had gone along with an unbroken impulse. But soon
12376: something occurred which brought with a terrible shock the sense that
12377: his plan might turn out to be as mad as all bold projects are seen to be
12378: when they have failed.
12379: 
12380: Mingled with the more headlong and half-drunken crowd there were some
12381: sharp-visaged men who loved the irrationality of riots for something
12382: else than its own sake, and who at present were not so much the richer
12383: as they desired to be, for the pains they had taken in coming to the
12384: Treby election, induced by certain prognostics gathered at Duffield on
12385: the nomination-day that there might be the conditions favorable to that
12386: confusion which was always a harvest-time. It was known to some of these
12387: sharp men that Park Street led out toward the grand house of Treby
12388: Manor, which was as good--nay, better, for their purpose than the bank.
12389: While Felix was entertaining his ardent purpose, these other sons of
12390: Adam were entertaining another ardent purpose of their peculiar sort,
12391: and the moment had come when they were to have their triumph.
12392: 
12393: From the front ranks backward toward Felix there ran a new summons--a
12394: new invitation.
12395: 
12396: "Let us go to Treby Manor!"
12397: 
12398: From that moment Felix was powerless; a new definite suggestion overrode
12399: his vaguer influence. There was a determined rush past Hobb's Lane, and
12400: not down it. Felix was carried along too. He did not know whether to
12401: wish the contrary. Once on the road, out of town, with openings into
12402: fields and with the wide park at hand, it would have been easy to
12403: liberate himself from the crowd. At first it seemed to him the better
12404: part to do this, and to get back to the town as fast as he could, in the
12405: hope of finding the military and getting a detachment to come and save
12406: the Manor. But he reflected that the course of the mob had been
12407: sufficiently seen, and that there were plenty of people in Park Street
12408: to carry the information faster than he could. It seemed more necessary
12409: that he should secure the presence of some help for the family at the
12410: Manor by going there himself. The Debarrys were not of the class of
12411: people he was wont to be anxious about; but Felix Holt's conscience was
12412: alive to the accusation that any danger they might be in now was brought
12413: on by a deed of his. In these moments of bitter vexation and
12414: disappointment, it did occur to him that very unpleasant consequences
12415: might be hanging over him of a kind quite different from inward
12416: dissatisfaction; but it was useless now to think of averting such
12417: consequences. As he was pressed along with the multitude into Treby
12418: Park, his very movement seemed to him only an image of the day's
12419: fatalities, in which the multitudinous small wickednesses of small
12420: selfish ends, really undirected toward any larger result, had issued in
12421: widely-shared mischief that might yet be hideous.
12422: 
12423: [Illustration: FELIX WOUNDED IN THE RIOT.]
12424: 
12425: The light was declining: already the candles shone through many windows
12426: of the Manor. Already the foremost part of the crowd had burst into the
12427: offices, and adroit men were busy in the right places to find plate,
12428: after setting others to force the butler into unlocking the cellars; and
12429: Felix had only just been able to force his way on to the front terrace,
12430: with the hope of getting to the rooms where he would find the ladies of
12431: the household and comfort them with the assurance that rescue must
12432: soon come, when the sound of horses' feet convinced him that the rescue
12433: was nearer than he had expected. Just as he heard the horses, he had
12434: approached the large window of a room where a brilliant light suspended
12435: from the ceiling showed him a group of women clinging together in
12436: terror. Others of the crowd were pushing their way up the terrace-steps
12437: and gravel-slopes at various points. Hearing the horses, he kept his
12438: post in front of the window, and, motioning with his sabre, cried out to
12439: the oncomers, "Keep back! I hear the soldiers coming." Some scrambled
12440: back, some paused automatically.
12441: 
12442: The louder and louder sound of the hoofs changed its pace and
12443: distribution. "Halt! Fire!" Bang! bang! bang!--came deafening the ears
12444: of the men on the terrace.
12445: 
12446: Before they had time or nerve to move, there was a rushing sound closer
12447: to them--again "Fire!" a bullet whizzed, and passed through Felix Holt's
12448: shoulder--the shoulder of the arm that held the naked weapon which shone
12449: in the light from the window.
12450: 
12451: Felix fell. The rioters ran confusedly, like terrified sheep. Some of
12452: the soldiers, turning, drove them along with the flat of their swords.
12453: The greater difficulty was to clear the invaded offices.
12454: 
12455: The rector, who with another magistrate and several other gentlemen on
12456: horseback had accompanied the soldiers, now jumped on to the terrace,
12457: and hurried to the ladies of the family.
12458: 
12459: Presently there was a group round Felix, who had fainted, and, reviving,
12460: had fainted again. He had had little food during the day, and had been
12461: overwrought. Two of the group were civilians, but only one of them knew
12462: Felix, the other being a magistrate not resident in Treby. The one who
12463: knew Felix was Mr. John Johnson, whose zeal for the public peace had
12464: brought him from Duffield when he heard that the soldiers were summoned.
12465: 
12466: "I know this man very well," said Mr. Johnson. "He is a dangerous
12467: character--quite revolutionary."
12468: 
12469: It was a weary night; and the next day, Felix, whose wound was declared
12470: trivial, was lodged in Loamford Jail. There were three charges against
12471: him: that he had assaulted a constable, that he had committed
12472: manslaughter (Tucker was dead from spinal concussion), and that he had
12473: led a riotous onslaught on a dwelling-house.
12474: 
12475: Four other men were committed: one of them for possessing himself of a
12476: gold cup with the Debarry arms on it; the three others, one of whom was
12477: the collier Dredge, for riot and assault.
12478: 
12479: That morning Treby town was no longer in terror; but it was in much
12480: sadness. Other men, more innocent than the hated Spratt, were groaning
12481: under severe bodily injuries. And poor Tucker's corpse was not the only
12482: one that had been lifted from the pavement. It is true that none grieved
12483: much for the other dead man, unless it be grief to say, "Poor old
12484: fellow!" He had been trampled upon, doubtless, where he fell drunkenly,
12485: near the entrance of the Seven Stars. This second corpse was old Tommy
12486: Trounsem, the bill-sticker--otherwise Thomas Transome, the last of a
12487: very old family-line.
12488: 
12489: 
12490: 
12491: 
12492: CHAPTER XXXIV.
12493: 
12494:     The fields are hoary with December's frost,
12495:     I too am hoary with the chills of age.
12496:     But through the fields and through the untrodden woods
12497:     Is rest and stillness--only in my heart
12498:     The pall of winter shrouds a throbbing life.
12499: 
12500: 
12501: A week after that Treby riot, Harold Transome was at Transome Court. He
12502: had returned from a hasty visit to town to keep his Christmas at this
12503: delightful country home, not in the best Christmas spirits. He had lost
12504: the election; but if that had been his only annoyance, he had good humor
12505: and good sense enough to have borne it as well as most men, and to have
12506: paid the eight or nine thousand, which had been the price of
12507: ascertaining that he was not to sit in the next Parliament, without
12508: useless grumbling. But the disappointments of life can never, any more
12509: than its pleasures, be estimated singly; and the healthiest and most
12510: agreeable of men is exposed to that coincidence of various vexations,
12511: each heightening the effect of the other, which may produce in him
12512: something corresponding to the spontaneous and externally unaccountable
12513: moodiness of the morbid and disagreeable.
12514: 
12515: Harold might not have grieved much at a small riot in Treby, even if it
12516: had caused some expenses to fall on the county; but the turn which the
12517: riot had actually taken was a bitter morsel for rumination, on more
12518: grounds than one. However the disturbances had arisen and been
12519: aggravated--and probably no one knew the whole truth on these
12520: points--the conspicuous, gravest incidents had all tended to throw the
12521: blame on the Radical party, that is to say, on Transome and on
12522: Transome's agents; and so far the candidateship and its results had done
12523: Harold dishonor in the county: precisely the opposite effect to that
12524: which was a dear object of his ambition. More than this, Harold's
12525: conscience was active enough to be very unpleasantly affected by what
12526: had befallen Felix Holt. His memory, always good, was particularly vivid
12527: in its retention of Felix Holt's complaint to him about the treating of
12528: the Sproxton men, and of the subsequent irritating scene in Jermyn's
12529: office, when the personage with the inauspicious name of Johnson had
12530: expounded to him the impossibility of revising an electioneering scheme
12531: once begun, and of turning your vehicle back when it had already begun
12532: to roll downhill. Remembering Felix Holt's words of indignant warning
12533: about hiring men with drink in them to make a noise, Harold could not
12534: resist the urgent impression that the offences for which Felix was
12535: committed were fatalities, not brought about by any willing co-operation
12536: of his with the noisy rioters, but arising probably from some rather
12537: ill-judged efforts to counteract their violence. And this urgent
12538: impression, which insisted on growing into a conviction, became in one
12539: of its phases an uneasy sense that he held evidence which would at once
12540: tend to exonerate Felix and to place himself and his agents in anything
12541: but a desirable light. It was likely that some one else could give
12542: equivalent evidence in favor of Felix--the little talkative Dissenting
12543: preacher, for example: but, anyhow, the affair with the Sproxton men
12544: would be ripped open and made the worst of by the opposite parties. The
12545: man who has failed in the use of some indirectness, is helped very
12546: little by the fact that his rivals are men to whom that indirectness is
12547: a something human, very far from being alien. There remains this grand
12548: distinction, that he has failed, and that the jet of light is thrown
12549: entirely on his misdoings.
12550: 
12551: In this matter Harold felt himself a victim. Could he hinder the tricks
12552: of his agents? In this particular case he had tried to hinder them, and
12553: had tried in vain. He had not loved the two agents in question, to begin
12554: with; and now at this later stage of events he was more innocent than
12555: ever of bearing them anything but the most sincere ill-will. He was more
12556: utterly exasperated with them than he would probably have been if his
12557: one great passion had been for public virtue. Jermyn, with his John
12558: Johnson, had added this ugly, dirty business of the Treby election to
12559: all the long-accumulating list of offences, which Harold was resolved to
12560: visit on him to the utmost. He had seen some handbills carrying the
12561: insinuation that there was a discreditable indebtedness to Jermyn on
12562: the part of the Transomes. If any such notions existed apart from
12563: electioneering slander, there was all the more reason for letting the
12564: world see Jermyn severely punished for abusing his power over the family
12565: affairs, and tampering with the family property. And the world certainly
12566: should see this with as little delay as possible. The cool, confident,
12567: assuming fellow should be bled to the last drop in compensation, and all
12568: connection with him be finally got rid of. Now that the election was
12569: done with, Harold meant to devote himself to private affairs, till
12570: everything lay in complete order under his supervision.
12571: 
12572: This morning he was seated as usual in his private room, which had now
12573: been handsomely fitted up for him. It was but the third morning after
12574: the first Christmas he had spent in his English home for fifteen years,
12575: and the home looked like an eminently desirable one. The white frost was
12576: now lying on the broad lawn, on the many-formed leaves of the evergreens
12577: and on the giant trees at a distance. Logs of dry oak blazed on the
12578: hearth; the carpet was like warm moss under his feet; he had breakfasted
12579: just according to his taste, and he had the interesting occupations of a
12580: large proprietor to fill the morning. All through the house now steps
12581: were noiseless on carpets or on fine matting; there was warmth in hall
12582: and corridors; there were servants enough to do everything, and to do it
12583: at the right time. Skilful Dominic was always at hand to meet his
12584: master's demands, and his bland presence diffused itself like a smile
12585: over the household, infecting the gloomy English mind with the belief
12586: that life was easy, and making his real predominance seem as soft and
12587: light as a down quilt. Old Mr. Transome had gathered new courage and
12588: strength since little Harry and Dominic had come, and since Harold had
12589: insisted on his taking drives. Mrs. Transome herself was seen on a fresh
12590: background with a gown of rich new stuff. And if, in spite of this, she
12591: did not seem happy, Harold either did not observe it, or kindly ignored
12592: it as the necessary frailty of elderly women whose lives have had too
12593: much of dullness and privation. Our minds get tricks and attitudes as
12594: our bodies do, thought Harold, and age stiffens them into
12595: unalterableness. "Poor mother! I confess I should not like to be an
12596: elderly woman myself. One requires a good deal of the purring cat for
12597: that, or else of the loving grandame. I wish she would take more to
12598: little Harry. I suppose she has her suspicions about the lad's mother,
12599: and is as rigid in those matters as in her Toryism. However, I do what
12600: I can; it would be difficult to say what there is wanting to her in the
12601: way of indulgence and luxury to make up for the old niggardly life."
12602: 
12603: And certainly Transome Court was now such a home as many women would
12604: covet. Yet even Harold's own satisfaction in the midst of its elegant
12605: comfort needed at present to be sustained by the expectation of
12606: gratified resentment. He was obviously less bright and enjoying than
12607: usual, and his mother, who watched him closely without daring to ask
12608: questions, had gathered hints and drawn inferences enough to make her
12609: feel sure that there was some storm gathering between him and Jermyn.
12610: She did not dare to ask questions, and yet she had not resisted the
12611: temptation to say something bitter about Harold's failure to get
12612: returned as a Radical, helping, with feminine self-defeat, to exclude
12613: herself more completely from any consultation by him. In this way poor
12614: women, whose power lies solely in their influence, make themselves like
12615: music out of tune, and only move men to run away.
12616: 
12617: This morning Harold had ordered his letters to be brought to him at the
12618: breakfast-table, which was not his usual practice. His mother could see
12619: that there were London business letters about which he was eager, and
12620: she had found out that the letter brought by a clerk the day before was
12621: to make an appointment with Harold for Jermyn to come to Transome Court
12622: at eleven this morning. She observed Harold swallow his coffee and push
12623: away his plate with an early abstraction from the business of breakfast
12624: which was not at all after his usual manner. She herself ate nothing:
12625: her sips of tea seemed to excite her; her cheeks flushed, and her hands
12626: were cold. She was still young and ardent in her terrors; the passions
12627: of the past were living in her dread.
12628: 
12629: When Harold left the table she went into the long drawing-room, where
12630: she might relieve her restlessness by walking up and down, and catch the
12631: sound of Jermyn's entrance into Harold's room, which was close by. Here
12632: she moved to and fro amongst the rose-colored satin of chairs and
12633: curtains--the great story of this world reduced for her to the little
12634: tale of her own existence--dull obscurity everywhere, except where the
12635: keen light fell on the narrow track of her own lot, wide only for a
12636: woman's anguish. At last she heard the expected ring and footstep, and
12637: the opening and closing door. Unable to walk about any longer, she sank
12638: into a large cushioned chair, helpless and prayerless. She was not
12639: thinking of God's anger or mercy, but of her son's. She was thinking of
12640: what might be brought, not by death, but by life.
12641: 
12642: 
12643: 
12644: 
12645: CHAPTER XXXV.
12646: 
12647:     _M._  Check to your queen!
12648: 
12649:     _N._                      Nay, your own king is bare,
12650:           And moving so, you give yourself checkmate.
12651: 
12652: 
12653: When Jermyn entered the room, Harold, who was seated at his library
12654: table examining papers, with his back toward the light and his face
12655: toward the door, moved his head coldly. Jermyn said an ungracious
12656: "Good-morning,"--as little as possible like a salutation to one who
12657: might regard himself as a patron. On the attorney's handsome face there
12658: was a black cloud of defiant determination slightly startling to Harold,
12659: who had expected to feel that the overpowering weight of temper in the
12660: interview was on his own side. Nobody was ever prepared beforehand for
12661: this expression of Jermyn's face, which seemed as strongly contrasted
12662: with the cold impenetrableness which he preserved under the ordinary
12663: annoyance of business as with the bland radiance of his lighter moments.
12664: 
12665: Harold himself did not look amiable just then, but his anger was of the
12666: sort that seeks a vent without waiting to give a fatal blow; it was that
12667: of a nature more subtly mixed than Jermyn's--less animally forcible,
12668: less unwavering in selfishness, and with more of high-bred pride. He
12669: looked at Jermyn with increased disgust and secret wonder.
12670: 
12671: "Sit down," he said curtly.
12672: 
12673: Jermyn seated himself in silence, opened his greatcoat, and took some
12674: papers from a side pocket.
12675: 
12676: "I have written to Makepeace," said Harold, "to tell him to take the
12677: entire management of the election expenses. So you will transmit your
12678: accounts to him."
12679: 
12680: "Very well. I am come this morning on other business."
12681: 
12682: "If it's about the riot and the prisoners, I have only to say that I
12683: shall enter into no plans. If I am called on, I shall say what I know
12684: about that young fellow Felix Holt. People may prove what they can about
12685: Johnson's damnable tricks, or yours either."
12686: 
12687: "I am not come to speak about the riot. I agree with you in thinking
12688: that quite a subordinate subject." (When Jermyn had the black cloud over
12689: his face, he never hesitated or drawled, and made no Latin quotations.)
12690: 
12691: "Be so good, then, as to open your business at once," said Harold, in a
12692: tone of imperious indifference.
12693: 
12694: "That is precisely what I wish to do. I have here information from a
12695: London correspondent that you are about to file a bill against me in
12696: Chancery." Jermyn, as he spoke, laid his hand on the papers before him,
12697: and looked straight at Harold.
12698: 
12699: "In that case, the question for you is, how far your conduct as the
12700: family solicitor will bear investigation. But it is a question which you
12701: will consider quite apart from me."
12702: 
12703: "Doubtless. But prior to that there is a question which we must consider
12704: together."
12705: 
12706: The tone in which Jermyn said this gave an unpleasant shock to Harold's
12707: sense of mastery. Was it possible that he should have the weapon
12708: wrenched out of his hand?
12709: 
12710: "I shall know what to think of that," he replied, as haughtily as ever,
12711: "when you have stated what the question is."
12712: 
12713: "Simply, whether you will choose to retain the family estates, or lay
12714: yourself open to be forthwith legally deprived of them."
12715: 
12716: "I presume you refer to some underhand scheme of your own, on a par with
12717: the annuities you have drained us by in the name of Johnson," said
12718: Harold, feeling a new movement of anger. "If so, you had better state
12719: your scheme to my lawyers, Dymock and Halliwell."
12720: 
12721: "No. I think you will approve of my stating in your own ear first of
12722: all, that it depends on my will whether you remain an important landed
12723: proprietor in North Loamshire, or whether you retire from the country
12724: with the remainder of the fortune you have acquired in trade."
12725: 
12726: Jermyn paused, as if to leave time for this morsel to be tasted.
12727: 
12728: "What do you mean?" said Harold, sharply.
12729: 
12730: "Not any scheme of mine; but a state of the facts resulting from the
12731: settlement of the estate made in 1729: state of the facts which renders
12732: your father's title and your own title to the family estates utterly
12733: worthless as soon as the claimant is made aware of his right."
12734: 
12735: "And you intend to inform him?"
12736: 
12737: "That depends. I am the only person who has the requisite knowledge. It
12738: rests with you to decide whether I shall use that knowledge against you;
12739: or whether I shall use it in your favor by putting an end to the
12740: evidence that would serve to oust you in spite of your 'robust title of
12741: occupancy.'"
12742: 
12743: Jermyn paused again. He had been speaking slowly, but without the least
12744: hesitation, and with a bitter definiteness of enunciation. There was a
12745: moment or two before Harold answered, and then he said abruptly--
12746: 
12747: "I don't believe you."
12748: 
12749: "I thought you were more shrewd," said Jermyn, with a touch of scorn. "I
12750: thought you understood that I had had too much experience to waste my
12751: time in telling fables to persuade a man who has put himself into the
12752: attitude of my deadly enemy."
12753: 
12754: "Well, then, say at once what your proofs are," said Harold, shaking in
12755: spite of himself, and getting nervous.
12756: 
12757: "I have no inclination to be lengthy. It is not more than a few weeks
12758: since I ascertained that there is in existence an heir of the Bycliffes,
12759: the old adversaries of your family. More curiously, it is only a few
12760: days ago--in fact, only since the day of the riot--that the Bycliffe
12761: claim has become valid, and that the right of remainder accrues to the
12762: heir in question."
12763: 
12764: "And how, pray?" said Harold, rising from his chair, and making a turn
12765: in the room, with his hands thrust in his pockets. Jermyn rose too, and
12766: stood near the hearth, facing Harold, as he moved to and fro.
12767: 
12768: "By the death of an old fellow who got drunk and was trampled to death
12769: in the riot. He was the last of that Thomas Transome's line, by the
12770: purchase of whose interest your family got its title to the estate. Your
12771: title died with him. It was supposed that the line had become extinct
12772: before--and on that supposition the old Bycliffes founded their claim.
12773: But I hunted up this man just about the time the last suit was closed.
12774: His death would have been of no consequence to you if there had not been
12775: a Bycliffe in existence; but I happen to know that there is, and that
12776: the fact can be legally proved."
12777: 
12778: For a minute or two Harold did not speak, but continued to pace the
12779: room, while Jermyn kept his position, holding his hands behind him. At
12780: last Harold said, from the other end of the room, speaking in a scornful
12781: tone--
12782: 
12783: "That sounds alarming. But it is not to be proved simply by your
12784: statement."
12785: 
12786: "Clearly. I have here a document, with a copy which will back my
12787: statement. It is the opinion given on the case more than twenty years
12788: ago, and it bears the signature of the Attorney-General and the first
12789: conveyancer of the day."
12790: 
12791: Jermyn took up the papers he had laid on the table, opening them slowly
12792: and coolly as he went on speaking, and as Harold advanced toward him.
12793: 
12794: "You may suppose that we spared no pains to ascertain the state of the
12795: title in the last suit against Maurice Christian Bycliffe, which
12796: threatened to be a hard run. This document is the result of a
12797: consultation; it gives an opinion which must be taken as a final
12798: authority. You may cast your eyes over that, if you please; I will wait
12799: your time. Or you may read the summing-up here," Jermyn ended, holding
12800: out one of the papers to Harold, and pointing to a final passage.
12801: 
12802: Harold took the paper with a slight gesture of impatience. He did not
12803: choose to obey Jermyn's indication, and confine himself to the
12804: summing-up. He ran through the document. But in truth he was too much
12805: excited really to follow the details, and was rather acting than
12806: reading, till at once he threw himself into his chair and consented to
12807: bend his attention on the passage to which Jermyn had pointed. The
12808: attorney watched him as he read and twice re-read:--
12809: 
12810:     To sum up----we are of opinion that the title of the present
12811:     possessors of the Transome estate can be strictly proved to rest
12812:     solely upon a base fee created under the original settlement of
12813:     1729, and to be good so long only as issue exists of the tenant in
12814:     tail by whom that base fee was created. We feel satisfied by the
12815:     evidence that such issue exists in the person of Thomas Transome,
12816:     otherwise Trounsem, of Littleshaw. But upon his decease without
12817:     issue we are of opinion that the right in remainder of the Bycliffe
12818:     family will arise, which right would not be barred by any statute
12819:     of limitation.
12820: 
12821: When Harold's eyes were on the signatures to this document for the third
12822: time, Jermyn said--
12823: 
12824: "As it turned out, the case being closed by the death of the claimant,
12825: we had no occasion for producing Thomas Transome, who was the old fellow
12826: I told you of. The enquiries about him set him agog, and after they were
12827: dropped he came into this neighborhood, thinking there was something
12828: fine in store for him. Here, if you like to take it, is a memorandum
12829: about him. I repeat that he died in the riot. The proof is ready. And I
12830: repeat, that, to my knowledge, and mine only, there is a Bycliffe in
12831: existence; and that I know how the proof can be made out."
12832: 
12833: Harold rose from his chair again, and again paced the room. He was not
12834: prepared with any defiance.
12835: 
12836: "And where is he--this Bycliffe?" he said at last, stopping in his walk,
12837: and facing round toward Jermyn.
12838: 
12839: "I decline to say more till you promise to suspend proceedings against
12840: me."
12841: 
12842: Harold turned again, and looked out of the window, without speaking, for
12843: a moment or two. It was impossible that there should not be a conflict
12844: within him, and at present it was a very confused one. At last he said--
12845: 
12846: "This person is in ignorance of his claim?"
12847: 
12848: "Yes."
12849: 
12850: "Has been brought up in an inferior station?"
12851: 
12852: "Yes," said Jermyn, keen enough to guess part of what was going on in
12853: Harold's mind. "There is no harm in leaving him in ignorance. The
12854: question is a purely legal one. And, as I said before, the complete
12855: knowledge of the case, as one of evidence, lies exclusively with me. I
12856: can nullify the evidence, or I can make it tell with certainty against
12857: you. The choice lies with you."
12858: 
12859: "I must have time to think of this," said Harold, conscious of a
12860: terrible pressure.
12861: 
12862: "I can give you no time unless you promise me to suspend proceedings."
12863: 
12864: "And then, when I ask you, you will lay the details before me?"
12865: 
12866: "Not without a thorough understanding beforehand. If I engage not to use
12867: my knowledge against you, you must engage in writing that on being
12868: satisfied by the details, you will cancel all hostile proceedings
12869: against me, and will not institute fresh ones on the strength of any
12870: occurrences now past."
12871: 
12872: "Well, I must have time," said Harold, more than ever inclined to thrash
12873: the attorney, but feeling bound hand and foot with knots that he was not
12874: sure he could ever unfasten.
12875: 
12876: "That is to say," said Jermyn, with his black-browed persistence, "you
12877: will write to suspend proceedings."
12878: 
12879: Again Harold paused. He was more than ever exasperated, but he was
12880: threatened, mortified, and confounded by the necessity for an immediate
12881: decision between alternatives almost equally hateful to him. It was with
12882: difficulty that he could prevail on himself to speak any conclusive
12883: words. He walked as far as he could from Jermyn--to the other end of the
12884: room--then walked back to his chair and threw himself into it. At last
12885: he said, without looking at Jermyn, "I agree--I must have time."
12886: 
12887: "Very well. It is a bargain."
12888: 
12889: "No further than this," said Harold, hastily, flashing a look at
12890: Jermyn--"no further than this, that I require time, and therefore I give
12891: it to you."
12892: 
12893: "Of course. You require time to consider whether the pleasure of trying
12894: to ruin me--me to whom you are really indebted--is worth the loss of the
12895: Transome estates. I shall wish you good-morning."
12896: 
12897: Harold did not speak to him or look at him again, and Jermyn walked out
12898: of the room. As he appeared outside the door and closed it behind him,
12899: Mrs. Transome showed her white face at another door which opened on a
12900: level with Harold's in such a way that it was just possible for Jermyn
12901: not to see her. He availed himself of that possibility, and walked
12902: straight across the hall, where there was no servant in attendance to
12903: let him out, as if he believed that no one was looking at him who could
12904: expect recognition. He did not want to speak to Mrs. Transome at
12905: present; he had nothing to ask from her, and one disagreeable interview
12906: had been enough for him this morning.
12907: 
12908: She was convinced that he had avoided her, and she was too proud to
12909: arrest him. She was as insignificant now in his eyes as in her son's.
12910: "Men have no memories in their hearts," she said to herself, bitterly.
12911: And then turning into her sitting-room she heard the voices of Mr.
12912: Transome and little Harry at play together. She would have given a great
12913: deal at this moment if her feeble husband had not always lived in dread
12914: of her temper and her tyranny, so that he might have been fond of her
12915: now. She felt herself loveless; if she was important to any one, it was
12916: only to her old waiting-woman Denner.
12917: 
12918: 
12919: 
12920: 
12921: CHAPTER XXXVI.
12922: 
12923:     Are these things then necessities?
12924:     Then let us meet them like necessities.
12925: 
12926:                                         --SHAKESPEARE: _Henry IV_.
12927: 
12928:     See now the virtue living in a word!
12929:     Hobson will think of swearing it was noon
12930:     When he saw Dobson at the May-day fair,
12931:     To prove poor Dobson did not rob the mail.
12932:     'Tis neighborly to save a neighbor's neck:
12933:     What harm in lying when you mean no harm?
12934:     But say 'tis perjury, then Hobson quakes--
12935:     He'll none of perjury.
12936:                           Thus words embalm
12937:     The conscience of mankind: and Roman laws
12938:     Bring still a conscience to poor Hobson's aid.
12939: 
12940: 
12941: Few men would have felt otherwise than Harold Transome felt, if, having
12942: a reversion tantamount to possession of a fine estate, carrying an
12943: association with an old name and considerable social importance, they
12944: were suddenly informed that there was a person who had a legal right to
12945: deprive them of these advantages; that person's right having never been
12946: contemplated by any one as more than a chance, and being quite unknown
12947: to himself. In ordinary cases a shorter possession than Harold's family
12948: had enjoyed was allowed by the law to constitute an indefeasible right;
12949: and if in rare and peculiar instances the law left the possessor of a
12950: long inheritance exposed to deprivation as the consequence of old
12951: obscure transactions, the moral reasons for giving legal validity to the
12952: title of long occupancy were not the less strong. Nobody would have said
12953: that Harold was bound to hunt out this alleged remainder-man and urge
12954: his rights upon him; on the contrary, all the world would have laughed
12955: at such conduct, and he would have been thought an interesting patient
12956: for a mad-doctor. The unconscious remainder-man was probably much better
12957: off, left in his original station: Harold would not have been called
12958: upon to consider his existence, if it had not been presented to him in
12959: the shape of a threat from one who had power to execute the threat.
12960: 
12961: In fact, what he would have done had the circumstances been different,
12962: was much clearer than what he should choose to do or feel himself
12963: compelled to do in the actual crisis. He would not have been disgraced
12964: if, on a valid claim being urged, he had got his lawyers to fight it out
12965: for him on the chance of eluding the claim by some adroit technical
12966: management. Nobody off the stage could be sentimental about these
12967: things, or pretend to shed tears of joy because an estate was handed
12968: over from a gentleman to a mendicant sailor with a wooden leg. And this
12969: chance remainder-man was perhaps some such specimen of inheritance as
12970: the drunken fellow killed in the riot. All the world would think the
12971: actual Transomes in the right to contest any adverse claim to the
12972: utmost. But then--it was not certain that they would win in the contest;
12973: and not winning, they would incur other losses besides that of the
12974: estate. There had been a little too much of such loss already.
12975: 
12976: But why, if it were not wrong to contest the claim, should he feel the
12977: most uncomfortable scruples about robbing the claim of its sting by
12978: getting rid of its evidence? It was a mortal disappointment--it was a
12979: sacrifice of indemnification--to abstain from punishing Jermyn. But even
12980: if he brought his mind to contemplate that as the wiser course, he still
12981: shrank from what looked like complicity with Jermyn; he still shrank
12982: from the secret nullification of a just legal claim. If he had only
12983: known the details, if he had known who this alleged heir was, he might
12984: have seen his way to some course that would not have grated on his sense
12985: of honor and dignity. But Jermyn had been too acute to let Harold know
12986: this: he had even carefully kept to the masculine pronoun. And he
12987: believed that there was no one besides himself who would or could make
12988: Harold any wiser. He went home persuaded that between this interview and
12989: the next which they would have together, Harold would be left to an
12990: inward debate, founded entirely on the information he himself had given.
12991: And he had not much doubt that the result would be what he desired.
12992: Harold was no fool: there were many good things he liked better in life
12993: than an irrational vindictiveness.
12994: 
12995: And it did happen that, after writing to London in fulfillment of his
