12996: pledge, Harold spent many hours over that inward debate, which was not
12997: very different from what Jermyn imagined. He took it everywhere with him
12998: on foot and on horseback, and it was his companion through a great deal
12999: of the night. His nature was not of a kind given to internal conflict,
13000: and he had never before been long undecided and puzzled. This
13001: unaccustomed state of mind was so painfully irksome to him--he rebelled
13002: so impatiently against the oppression of circumstances in which his
13003: quick temperament and habitual decision could not help him--that it
13004: added tenfold to his hatred of Jermyn, who was the cause of it. And
13005: thus, as the temptation to avoid all risk of losing the estate grew and
13006: grew till scruples looked minute by the side of it, the difficulty of
13007: bringing himself to make a compact with Jermyn seemed more and more
13008: insurmountable.
13009: 
13010: But we have seen that the attorney was much too confident in his
13011: calculations. And while Harold was being gulled by his subjection to
13012: Jermyn's knowledge, independent information was on its way to him. The
13013: messenger was Christian, who, after as complete a survey of
13014: probabilities as he was capable of, had come to the conclusion that the
13015: most profitable investment he could make of his peculiar experience and
13016: testimony in relation to Bycliffe and Bycliffe's daughter, was to place
13017: them at the disposal of Harold Transome. He was afraid of Jermyn; he
13018: utterly distrusted Johnson; but he thought he was secure in relying on
13019: Harold Transome's care for his own interest; and he preferred above all
13020: issues the prospect of forthwith leaving the country with a sum that at
13021: least for a good while would put him at his ease.
13022: 
13023: When, only three mornings after the interview with Jermyn, Dominic
13024: opened the door of Harold's sitting-room, and said that "Meester
13025: Chreestian," Mr. Philip Debarry's courier and an acquaintance of his own
13026: at Naples, requested to be admitted on business of importance, Harold's
13027: immediate thought was that the business referred to the so-called
13028: political affairs which were just now his chief association with the
13029: name of Debarry, though it seemed an oddness requiring explanation, that
13030: a servant should be personally an intermediary. He assented, expecting
13031: something rather disagreeable than otherwise.
13032: 
13033: Christian wore this morning those perfect manners of a subordinate who
13034: is not servile, which he always adopted toward his unquestionable
13035: superiors. Mr. Debarry, who preferred having some one about him with as
13036: little resemblance as possible to a regular servant, had a singular
13037: liking for the adroit, quiet-mannered Christian, and would have been
13038: amazed to see the insolent assumption he was capable of in the presence
13039: of people like Mr. Lyon, who were of no account in society. Christian
13040: had that sort of cleverness which is said to "know the world"--that is
13041: to say, he knew the price-current of most things.
13042: 
13043: Aware that he was looked at as a messenger while he remained standing
13044: near the door with his hat in his hand, he said, with respectful ease--
13045: 
13046: "You will probably be surprised, sir, at my coming to speak to you on my
13047: own account; and, in fact, I could not have thought of doing so if my
13048: business did not happen to be something of more importance to you than
13049: to any one else."
13050: 
13051: "You don't come from Mr. Debarry, then?" said Harold, with some
13052: surprise.
13053: 
13054: "No, sir. My business is a secret; and, if you please, must remain so."
13055: 
13056: "Is it a pledge you are demanding from me?" said Harold, rather
13057: suspiciously, having no ground for confidence in a man of Christian's
13058: position.
13059: 
13060: "Yes, sir; I am obliged to ask no less than that you will pledge
13061: yourself not to take Mr. Jermyn into confidence concerning what passes
13062: between us."
13063: 
13064: "With all my heart," said Harold, something like a gleam passing over
13065: his face. His circulation had become more rapid. "But what have you had
13066: to do with Jermyn?"
13067: 
13068: "He has not mentioned me to you then--has he, sir?"
13069: 
13070: "No; certainly not--never."
13071: 
13072: Christian thought, "Aha, Mr. Jermyn! you are keeping the secret well,
13073: are you?" He said, aloud--
13074: 
13075: "Then Mr. Jermyn has never mentioned to you, sir, what I believe he is
13076: aware of--that there is danger of a new suit being raised against you on
13077: the part of a Bycliffe, to get the estate?"
13078: 
13079: "Ah!" said Harold, starting up, and placing himself with his back
13080: against the mantelpiece. He was electrified by surprise at the quarter
13081: from which this information was coming. Any fresh alarm was counteracted
13082: by the flashing thought that he might be enabled to act independently of
13083: Jermyn; and in the rush of feelings he could utter no more than an
13084: interjection. Christian concluded that Harold had no previous hint.
13085: 
13086: "It is this fact, that I came to tell you of."
13087: 
13088: "From some other motive than kindness to me, I presume," said Harold,
13089: with a slight approach to a smile.
13090: 
13091: "Certainly," said Christian, as quietly as if he had been stating
13092: yesterday's weather. "I should not have the folly to use any affectation
13093: with you, Mr. Transome. I lost considerable property early in life, and
13094: am now in the receipt of a salary simply. In the affair I have just
13095: mentioned to you I can give evidence which will turn the scale against
13096: you. I have no wish to do so, if you will make it worth my while to
13097: leave the country."
13098: 
13099: Harold listened as if he had been a legendary hero, selected for
13100: peculiar solicitation by the Evil One. Here was temptation in a more
13101: alluring form than before, because it was sweetened by the prospect of
13102: eluding Jermyn. But the desire to gain time served all the purposes of
13103: caution and resistance, and his indifference to the speaker in this case
13104: helped him to preserve perfect self-command.
13105: 
13106: "You are aware," he said, coolly, "that silence is not a commodity worth
13107: purchasing unless it is loaded. There are many persons, I dare say, who
13108: would like me to pay their travelling expenses for them. But they might
13109: hardly be able to show me that it was worth my while."
13110: 
13111: "You wish me to state what I know?"
13112: 
13113: "Well, that is a necessary preliminary to any further conversation."
13114: 
13115: "I think you will see, Mr. Transome, that, as a matter of justice, the
13116: knowledge I can give is worth something, quite apart from my future
13117: appearance or non-appearance as a witness. I must take care of my own
13118: interest, and if anything should hinder you from choosing to satisfy me
13119: for taking an essential witness out of the way, I must at least be paid
13120: for bringing you the information."
13121: 
13122: "Can you tell me who and where this Bycliffe is?"
13123: 
13124: "I can."
13125: 
13126: "-----And give me a notion of the whole affair?"
13127: 
13128: "Yes; I have talked to a lawyer--not Jermyn--who is at the bottom of the
13129: law in the affair."
13130: 
13131: "You must not count on any wish of mine to suppress evidence or remove a
13132: witness. But name your price for the information."
13133: 
13134: "In that case I must be paid the higher for my information. Say, two
13135: thousand pounds."
13136: 
13137: "Two thousand devils!" burst out Harold, throwing himself into his chair
13138: again, and turning his shoulder toward Christian. New thoughts crowded
13139: upon him. "This fellow may want to decamp for some reason or other," he
13140: said to himself. "More people besides Jermyn know about his evidence, it
13141: seems. The whole thing may look black for me if it comes out. I shall be
13142: believed to have bribed him to run away, whether or not." Thus the
13143: outside conscience came in aid of the inner.
13144: 
13145: "I will not give you one sixpence for your information," he said,
13146: resolutely, "until time has made it clear that you do not intend to
13147: decamp, but will be forthcoming when you are called for. On those terms
13148: I have no objection to give you a note, specifying that after the
13149: fulfilment of that condition--that is, after the occurrence of a suit,
13150: or the understanding that no suit is to occur--I will pay you a certain
13151: sum in consideration of the information you now give me!"
13152: 
13153: Christian felt himself caught in a vise. In the first instance he had
13154: counted confidently on Harold's ready seizure of his offer to disappear,
13155: and after some words had seemed to cast a doubt on this presupposition
13156: he had inwardly determined to go away, whether Harold wished it or not,
13157: if he could get a sufficient sum. He did not reply immediately, and
13158: Harold waited in silence, inwardly anxious to know what Christian could
13159: tell, but with a vision at present so far cleared that he was determined
13160: not to risk incurring the imputation of having anything to do with
13161: scoundrelism. We are very much indebted to such a linking of events as
13162: makes a doubtful action look wrong.
13163: 
13164: Christian was reflecting that if he stayed and faced some possible
13165: inconveniences of being known publicly as Henry Scaddon for the sake of
13166: what he might get from Esther, it would at least be wise to be certain
13167: of some money from Harold Transome, since he turned out to be of so
13168: peculiar a disposition as to insist on a punctilious honesty to his own
13169: disadvantage. Did he think of making a bargain with the other side? If
13170: so, he might be content to wait for the knowledge till it came in some
13171: other way. Christian was beginning to be afraid lest he should get
13172: nothing by this clever move of coming to Transome Court. At last he
13173: said--
13174: 
13175: "I think, sir, two thousand would not be an unreasonable sum, on those
13176: conditions."
13177: 
13178: "I will not give two thousand."
13179: 
13180: "Allow me to say, sir, you must consider that there is no one whose
13181: interest it is to tell you as much as I shall, even if they could; since
13182: Mr. Jermyn, who knows it, has not thought fit to tell you. There may be
13183: use you don't think of in getting the information at once."
13184: 
13185: "Well?"
13186: 
13187: "I think a gentleman should act liberally under such circumstances."
13188: 
13189: "So I will."
13190: 
13191: "I could not take less than a thousand pounds. It really would not be
13192: worth my while. If Mr. Jermyn knew I gave you the information, he would
13193: endeavor to injure me."
13194: 
13195: "I will give you a thousand," said Harold, immediately, for Christian
13196: had unconsciously touched a sure spring. "At least, I'll give you a note
13197: to the effect I spoke of."
13198: 
13199: He wrote as he had promised, and gave the paper to Christian.
13200: 
13201: "Now, don't be circuitous," said Harold. "You seem to have a
13202: business-like gift of speech. Who and where is this Bycliffe?"
13203: 
13204: "You will be surprised to hear, sir, that she is supposed to be the
13205: daughter of the old preacher, Lyon, in Malthouse Yard."
13206: 
13207: "Good God! How can that be?" said Harold. At once, the first occasion on
13208: which he had seen Esther rose in his memory--the little dark parlor--the
13209: graceful girl in blue, with the surprisingly distinguished manners and
13210: appearance.
13211: 
13212: "In this way. Old Lyon, by some strange means or other, married
13213: Bycliffe's widow when this girl was a baby. And the preacher didn't want
13214: the girl to know that he was not her real father: he told me that
13215: himself. But she is the image of Bycliffe, whom I knew well--an
13216: uncommonly fine woman--steps like a queen."
13217: 
13218: "I have seen her," said Harold, more than ever glad to have purchased
13219: this knowledge. "But now, go on."
13220: 
13221: Christian proceeded to tell all he knew, including his conversation with
13222: Jermyn, except so far as it had an unpleasant relation to himself.
13223: 
13224: "Then," said Harold, as the details seemed to have come to a close, "you
13225: believe that Miss Lyon and her supposed father are at present unaware of
13226: the claims that might be urged for her on the strength of her birth?"
13227: 
13228: "I believe so. But I need not tell you that where the lawyers are on
13229: the scent you can never be sure of anything long together. I must remind
13230: you, sir, that you have promised to protect me from Mr. Jermyn by
13231: keeping my confidence."
13232: 
13233: "Never fear. Depend upon it, I shall betray nothing to Mr. Jermyn."
13234: 
13235: Christian was dismissed with a "good-morning"; and while he cultivated
13236: some friendly reminiscences with Dominic, Harold sat chewing the cud of
13237: his new knowledge, and finding it not altogether so bitter as he had
13238: expected.
13239: 
13240: From the first, after his interview with Jermyn, the recoil of Harold's
13241: mind from the idea of strangling a legal right threw him on the
13242: alternative of attempting a compromise. Some middle course might be
13243: possible, which would be a less evil than a costly lawsuit, or than the
13244: total renunciation of the estates. And now he had learned that the new
13245: claimant was a woman--a young woman, brought up under circumstances that
13246: would make the fourth of the Transome property seem to her an immense
13247: fortune. Both the sex and the social condition were of the sort that
13248: lies open to many softening influences. And having seen Esther, it was
13249: inevitable that, amongst the various issues, agreeable and disagreeable,
13250: depicted by Harold's imagination, there should present itself a
13251: possibility that would unite the two claims--his own, which he felt to
13252: be the rational, and Esther's, which apparently was the legal claim.
13253: 
13254: Harold, as he had constantly said to his mother, was "not a marrying
13255: man"; he did not contemplate bringing a wife to Transome Court for many
13256: years to come, if at all. Having little Harry as an heir, he preferred
13257: freedom. Western women were not to his taste; they showed a transition
13258: from the feebly animal to the thinking being, which was simply
13259: troublesome. Harold preferred a slow-witted large-eyed woman, silent and
13260: affectionate, with a load of black hair weighing much more heavily than
13261: her brains. He had seen no such woman in England, except one which he
13262: had brought with him from the East.
13263: 
13264: Therefore Harold did not care to be married until or unless some
13265: surprising chance presented itself; and now that such a chance had
13266: occurred to suggest marriage to him, he would not admit to himself that
13267: he contemplated marrying Esther as a plan; he was only obliged to see
13268: that such an issue was not inconceivable. He was not going to take any
13269: step expressly directed toward that end: what he had made up his mind
13270: to, as the course most satisfactory to his nature under present
13271: urgencies, was to behave to Esther with a frank gentle manliness, which
13272: must win her good will, and incline her to save his family interest as
13273: much as possible. He was helped to this determination by the pleasure of
13274: frustrating Jermyn's contrivance to shield himself from punishment, and
13275: his most distinct and cheering prospect was that within a very short
13276: space of time he should not only have effected a satisfactory compromise
13277: with Esther, but should have made Jermyn aware by a very disagreeable
13278: form of announcement, that Harold Transome was no longer afraid of him.
13279: Jermyn should bite the dust.
13280: 
13281: At the end of these meditations he felt satisfied with himself and
13282: light-hearted. He had rejected two dishonest propositions, and he was
13283: going to do something that seemed eminently graceful. But he needed his
13284: mother's assistance, and it was necessary that he should both confide in
13285: her and persuade her.
13286: 
13287: Within two hours after Christian left him, Harold begged his mother to
13288: come into his private room, and there he told her the strange and
13289: startling story, omitting, however, any particulars which would involve
13290: the identification of Christian as his informant. Harold felt that his
13291: engagement demanded his reticence; and he told his mother that he was
13292: bound to conceal the source of that knowledge which he had got
13293: independently of Jermyn.
13294: 
13295: Mrs. Transome said little in the course of the story: she made no
13296: exclamations, but she listened with close attention, and asked a few
13297: questions so much to the point as to surprise Harold. When he showed her
13298: the copy of the legal opinion which Jermyn had left with him, she said
13299: she knew it very well; she had a copy herself. The particulars of that
13300: last lawsuit were too well engraven on her mind: it happened at a time
13301: when there was no one to supersede her, and she was the virtual head of
13302: the family affairs. She was prepared to understand how the estate might
13303: be in danger; but nothing had prepared her for the strange details--for
13304: the way in which the new claimant had been reared and brought within the
13305: range of converging motives that had led to this revelation, least of
13306: all for the part Jermyn had come to play in the revelation. Mrs.
13307: Transome saw these things through the medium of certain dominant
13308: emotions that made them seem like a long-ripening retribution. Harold
13309: perceived that she was painfully agitated, that she trembled, and that
13310: her white lips would not readily lend themselves to speech. And this
13311: was hardly more than he expected. He had not liked the revelation
13312: himself when it had first come to him.
13313: 
13314: But he did not guess what it was in his narrative which had most pierced
13315: his mother. It was something that made the threat about the estate only
13316: a secondary alarm. Now, for the first time, she heard of the intended
13317: proceedings against Jermyn. Harold had not chosen to speak of them
13318: before; but having at last called his mother into consultation, there
13319: was nothing in his mind to hinder him from speaking without reserve of
13320: his determination to visit on the attorney his shameful
13321: maladministration of the family affairs.
13322: 
13323: Harold went through the whole narrative--of what he called Jermyn's
13324: scheme to catch him in a vise, and his power of triumphantly frustrating
13325: that scheme--in his usual rapid way, speaking with a final decisiveness
13326: of tone; and his mother felt that if she urged any counter-consideration
13327: at all, she could only do so when he had no more to say.
13328: 
13329: "Now, what I want you to do, mother, if you can see this matter as I see
13330: it," Harold said in conclusion, "is to go with me to call on this girl
13331: in Malthouse Yard. I will open the affair to her; it appears she is not
13332: likely to have been informed yet; and you will invite her to visit you
13333: here at once, that all scandal, all hatching of law-mischief, may be
13334: avoided, and the thing may be brought to an amicable conclusion."
13335: 
13336: "It seems almost incredible--extraordinary--a girl in her position,"
13337: said Mrs. Transome, with difficulty. It would have seemed the bitterest,
13338: humiliating penance if another sort of suffering had left any room in
13339: her heart.
13340: 
13341: "I assure you she is a lady; I saw her when I was canvassing, and was
13342: amazed at the time. You will be quite struck with her. It is no
13343: indignity for you to invite her."
13344: 
13345: "Oh," said Mrs. Transome, with low-toned bitterness, "I must put up with
13346: all things as they are determined for me. When shall we go?"
13347: 
13348: "Well," said Harold, looking at his watch, "it is hardly two yet. We
13349: could really go to-day, when you have lunched. It is better to lose no
13350: time. I'll order the carriage."
13351: 
13352: "Stay," said Mrs. Transome, with a desperate effort. "There is plenty of
13353: time. I shall not lunch. I have a word to say."
13354: 
13355: Harold withdrew his hand from the bell, and leaned against the
13356: mantelpiece to listen.
13357: 
13358: "You see I comply with your wish at once, Harold?"
13359: 
13360: "Yes, mother, I'm much obliged to you for making no difficulties."
13361: 
13362: "You ought to listen to me in return."
13363: 
13364: "Pray go on," said Harold, expecting to be annoyed.
13365: 
13366: "What is the good of having these Chancery proceedings against Jermyn?"
13367: 
13368: "Good? This good: that fellow has burdened the estate with annuities and
13369: mortgages to the extent of three thousand a year; and the bulk of them,
13370: I am certain, he holds himself under the name of another man. And the
13371: advances this yearly interest represents, have not been much more than
13372: twenty thousand. Of course, he has hoodwinked you, and my father never
13373: gave attention to these things. He has been up to all sorts of devil's
13374: work with the deeds; he didn't count on my coming back from Smyrna to
13375: fill poor Durfey's place. He shall feel the difference. And the good
13376: will be, that I shall save almost all the annuities for the rest of my
13377: father's life, which may be ten years or more, and I shall get back some
13378: of the money, and I shall punish a scoundrel. That is the good."
13379: 
13380: "He will be ruined."
13381: 
13382: "That's what I intend," said Harold, sharply.
13383: 
13384: "He exerted himself a great deal for us in the old suits: everyone said
13385: he had wonderful zeal and ability," said Mrs. Transome, getting courage
13386: and warmth, as she went on. Her temper was rising.
13387: 
13388: "What he did, he did for his own sake, you may depend on that," said
13389: Harold, with a scornful laugh.
13390: 
13391: "There were very painful things in that last suit. You seem anxious
13392: about this young woman, to avoid all further scandal and contests in the
13393: family. Why don't you wish to do it in this case? Jermyn might be
13394: willing to arrange things amicably--to make restitution as far as he
13395: can--if he has done anything wrong."
13396: 
13397: "I will arrange nothing amicably with him," said Harold, decisively. "If
13398: he has ever done anything scandalous as our agent, let him bear the
13399: infamy. And the right way to throw the infamy on him is to show the
13400: world that he has robbed us, and that I mean to punish him. Why do you
13401: wish to shield such a fellow, mother? It has been chiefly through him
13402: that you have had to lead such a thrifty, miserable life--you who used
13403: to make as brilliant a figure as a woman need wish."
13404: 
13405: Mrs. Transome's rising temper was turned into a horrible sensation, as
13406: painful as a sudden concussion from something hard and immovable when we
13407: have struck out with our fist, intending to hit something warm, soft,
13408: and breathing like ourselves. Poor Mrs. Transome's strokes were sent
13409: jarring back on her by a hard unalterable past. She did not speak in
13410: answer to Harold, but rose from the chair as if she gave up the debate.
13411: 
13412: "Women are frightened at everything I know," said Harold, kindly,
13413: feeling that he had been a little harsh after his mother's compliance.
13414: "And you have been used for so many years to think Jermyn a law of
13415: nature. Come, mother," he went on, looking at her gently, and resting
13416: his hands on her shoulders, "look cheerful. We shall get through all
13417: these difficulties. And this girl--I dare say she will be quite an
13418: interesting visitor for you. You have not had any young girl about you
13419: for a long while. Who knows? she may fall deeply in love with me, and I
13420: may be obliged to marry her."
13421: 
13422: He spoke laughingly, only thinking how he could make his mother smile.
13423: But she looked at him seriously and said, "Do you mean that, Harold?"
13424: 
13425: "Am I not capable of making a conquest? Not too fat yet--a handsome,
13426: well-rounded youth of thirty-four?"
13427: 
13428: She was forced to look straight at the beaming face, with its rich dark
13429: color, just bent a little over her. Why could she not be happy in this
13430: son whose future she had once dreamed of, and who had been as fortunate
13431: as she had ever hoped? The tears came, not plenteously, but making her
13432: dark eyes as large and bright as youth had once made them without tears.
13433: 
13434: "There, there!" said Harold, coaxingly. "Don't be afraid. You shall not
13435: have a daughter-in-law unless she is a pearl. Now we will get ready to
13436: go."
13437: 
13438: In half an hour from that time Mrs. Transome came down, looking majestic
13439: in sables and velvet, ready to call on "the girl in Malthouse Yard." She
13440: had composed herself to go through this task. She saw there was nothing
13441: better to be done. After the resolutions Harold had taken, some sort of
13442: compromise with this oddly-placed heiress was the result most to be
13443: hoped for; if the compromise turned out to be a marriage--well, she had
13444: no reason to care much: she was already powerless. It remained to be
13445: seen what this girl was.
13446: 
13447: The carriage was to be driven round the back way, to avoid too much
13448: observation. But the late election affairs might account for Mr. Lyon's
13449: receiving a visit from the unsuccessful Radical candidate.
13450: 
13451: 
13452: 
13453: 
13454: CHAPTER XXXVII.
13455: 
13456:     I also could speak as ye do; if your soul were in my soul's stead,
13457:     I could heap up words against you, and shake mine head at
13458:     you.--_Book of Job._
13459: 
13460: 
13461: In the interval since Esther parted with Felix Holt on the day of the
13462: riot, she had gone through so much emotion, and had already had so
13463: strong a shock of surprise, that she was prepared to receive any new
13464: incident of an unwonted kind with comparative equanimity.
13465: 
13466: When Mr. Lyon had got home again from his preaching excursion, Felix was
13467: already on his way to Loamford Jail. The little minister was terribly
13468: shaken by the news. He saw no clear explanation of Felix Holt's conduct;
13469: for the statements Esther had heard were so conflicting that she had not
13470: been able to gather distinctly what had come out in the examination by
13471: the magistrates. But Mr. Lyon felt confident that Felix was innocent of
13472: any wish to abet a riot or the infliction of injuries; what he chiefly
13473: feared was that in the fatal encounter with Tucker he had been moved by
13474: a rash temper, not sufficiently guarded against by a prayerful and
13475: humble spirit.
13476: 
13477: "My poor young friend is being taught with mysterious severity the evil
13478: of a too confident self-reliance," he said to Esther, as they sat
13479: opposite to each other, listening and speaking sadly.
13480: 
13481: "You will go and see him, father?"
13482: 
13483: "Verily will I. But I must straightway go and see that poor afflicted
13484: woman, whose soul is doubtless whirled about in this trouble like a
13485: shapeless and unstable thing driven by divided winds." Mr. Lyon rose and
13486: took his hat hastily, ready to walk out, with his greatcoat flying open
13487: and exposing his small person to the keen air.
13488: 
13489: "Stay, father, pray, till you have had some food," said Esther, putting
13490: her hand on his arm. "You look quite weary and shattered."
13491: 
13492: "Child, I cannot stay. I can neither eat bread nor drink water till I
13493: have learned more about this young man's deeds, what can be proved and
13494: what cannot be proved against him. I fear he has none to stand by him in
13495: this town, for even by the friends of our church I have been ofttimes
13496: rebuked because he seemed dear to me. But, Esther, my beloved child----"
13497: 
13498: Here Mr. Lyon grasped her arm, and seemed in the need of speech to
13499: forget his previous haste. "I bear in mind this: the Lord knoweth them
13500: that are His; but we--we are left to judge by uncertain signs, that so
13501: we may learn to exercise hope and faith toward one another; and in this
13502: uncertainty I cling with awful hope to those whom the world loves not
13503: because their conscience, albeit mistakenly, is at war with the habits
13504: of the world. Our great faith, my Esther, is the faith of martyrs: I
13505: will not lightly turn away from any man who endures harshness because he
13506: will not lie; nay, though I would not wantonly grasp at ease of mind
13507: through an arbitrary choice of doctrine, I cannot but believe that the
13508: merits of the Divine Sacrifice are wider than our utmost charity. I once
13509: believed otherwise--but not now, not now."
13510: 
13511: The minister paused, and seemed to be abstractedly gazing at some
13512: memory: he was always liable to be snatched away by thoughts from the
13513: pursuit of a purpose which had seemed pressing. Esther seized the
13514: opportunity and prevailed on him to fortify himself with some of Lyddy's
13515: porridge before he went out on his tiring task of seeking definite
13516: trustworthy knowledge from the lips of various witnesses, beginning with
13517: that feminine darkener of counsel, poor Mrs. Holt.
13518: 
13519: She, regarding all her trouble about Felix in the light of a fulfilment
13520: of her own prophecies, treated the sad history with a preference for
13521: edification above accuracy, and for mystery above relevance, worthy of a
13522: commentator on the Apocalypse. She insisted chiefly, not on the
13523: important facts that Felix had sat at his work till after eleven, like a
13524: deaf man, had rushed out in surprise and alarm, had come back to report
13525: with satisfaction that things were quiet, and had asked her to set by
13526: his dinner for him--facts which would tell as evidence that Felix was
13527: disconnected with any project of disturbances, and was averse to them.
13528: These things came out incidentally in her long plaint to the minister;
13529: but what Mrs. Holt felt it essential to state was, that long before
13530: Michaelmas was turned, sitting in her chair, she had said to Felix that
13531: there would be a judgment on him for being so certain sure about the
13532: Pills and the Elixir.
13533: 
13534: "And now, Mr. Lyon," said the poor woman, who had dressed herself in a
13535: gown previously cast off, a front all out of curl, and a cap with no
13536: starch in it, while she held little coughing Job on her knee,--"and now
13537: you see--my words have come true sooner than I thought they would. Felix
13538: may contradict me if he will; but there he is in prison, and here am I,
13539: with nothing in the world to bless myself with but half-a-crown a-week
13540: as I've saved by my own scraping, and this house I've got to pay rent
13541: for. It's not me has done wrong, Mr. Lyon; there's nobody can say it of
13542: me--not the orphan child on my knee is more innicent o' riot and murder
13543: and anything else as is bad. But when you've got a son so masterful and
13544: stopping medicines as Providence has sent, and his betters have been
13545: taking up and down the country since before he was a baby, it's o' no
13546: use being good here below. But he _was_ a baby, Mr. Lyon, and I gave him
13547: the breast,"--here poor Mrs. Holt's motherly love over-came her
13548: expository eagerness, and she fell more and more to crying as she
13549: spoke--"And to think there's folks saying now as he'll be transported,
13550: and his hair shaved off, and the treadmill, and everything. Oh, dear!"
13551: 
13552: As Mrs. Holt broke off into sobbing, little Job also, who had got a
13553: confused yet profound sense of sorrow, and of Felix being hurt and gone
13554: away, set up a little wail of wondering misery.
13555: 
13556: "Nay, Mistress Holt," said the minister, soothingly, "enlarge not your
13557: grief by more than warrantable grounds. I have good hope that my young
13558: friend, your son, will be delivered from any severe consequences beyond
13559: the death of the man Tucker, which I fear will ever be a sore burden on
13560: his memory. I feel confident that a jury of his country-men will
13561: discern between misfortune, or it may be misjudgment, and an evil will,
13562: and that he will be acquitted of any grave offence."
13563: 
13564: "He never stole anything in his life, Mr. Lyon," said Mrs. Holt,
13565: reviving. "Nobody can throw it in my face as my son ran away with money
13566: like the young man at the bank--though he looked most respectable, and
13567: far different on a Sunday to what Felix ever did. And I know it's very
13568: hard fighting with constables; but they say Tucker's wife'll be a deal
13569: better off than she was before, for the great folks'll pension her, and
13570: she'll be put on all the charities, and her children at the Free School,
13571: and everything. Your trouble's easy borne when everybody gives it a lift
13572: for you; and if judge and jury wants to do right by Felix, they'll think
13573: of his poor mother, with the bread took out of her mouth, all but
13574: half-a-crown a-week and furniture--which, to be sure, is most excellent,
13575: and of my own buying--and got to keep this orphin child as Felix himself
13576: brought on me. And I might send him back to his old grandfather on
13577: parish pay, but I'm not that woman, Mr. Lyon; I've a tender heart. And
13578: here's his little feet and toes, like marbil; do but look"--here Mrs.
13579: Holt drew off Job's sock and shoe, and showed a well-washed little
13580: foot--"and you'll perhaps say I might take a lodger; but it's easy
13581: talking; it isn't everybody at a loose-end wants a parlor and a bedroom;
13582: and if anything bad happens to Felix, I may as well go and sit in the
13583: parish pound, and nobody to buy me out; for it's beyond everything how
13584: the church members find fault with my son. But I think they might leave
13585: his mother to find fault; for queer and masterful he might be, and
13586: flying in the face of the very Scripture about the physic, but he was
13587: most clever beyond anything--that I _will_ say--and was his own father's
13588: lawful child, and me his mother, that was Mary Wall thirty years before
13589: ever I married his father." Here Mrs. Holt's feelings again became too
13590: much for her, but she struggled on to say, sobbingly, "And if they're to
13591: transport him, I should like to go to the prison and take the orphin
13592: child; for he was most fond of having him on his lap, and said he'd
13593: never marry; and there was One above overheard him, for he's been took
13594: at his word."
13595: 
13596: Mr. Lyon listened with low groans, and then tried to comfort her by
13597: saying that he would himself go to Loamford as soon as possible, and
13598: would give his soul no rest till he had done all he could do for Felix.
13599: 
13600: On one point Mrs. Holt's plaint tallied with his own forebodings, and he
13601: found them verified: the state of feeling in Treby among the Liberal
13602: Dissenting flock was unfavorable to Felix. None who had observed his
13603: conduct from the windows saw anything tending to excuse him, and his own
13604: account of his motives, given on his examination, was spoken of with
13605: head-shaking; if it had not been for his habit of always thinking
13606: himself wiser than other people, he would never have entertained such a
13607: wild scheme. He had set himself up for something extraordinary, and had
13608: spoken ill of respectable trades-people. He had put a stop to the making
13609: of saleable drugs, contrary to the nature of buying and selling, and to
13610: a due reliance on what Providence might effect in the human inside
13611: through the instrumentality of remedies unsuitable to the stomach,
13612: looked at in a merely secular light; and the result was what might have
13613: been expected. He had brought his mother to poverty, and himself into
13614: trouble. And what for? He had done no good to "the cause"; if he had
13615: fought about Church-rates, or had been worsted in some struggle in which
13616: he was distinctly the champion of Dissent and Liberalism, his case would
13617: have been one for gold, silver, and copper subscriptions, in order to
13618: procure the best defence; sermons might have been preached on him, and
13619: his name might have floated on flags from Newcastle to Dorchester. But
13620: there seemed to be no edification in what had befallen Felix. The riot
13621: at Treby, "turn it which way you would," as Mr. Muscat observed, was no
13622: great credit to Liberalism; and what Mr. Lyon had to testify as to Felix
13623: Holt's conduct in the matter of the Sproxton men, only made it clear
13624: that the defence of Felix was the accusation of his party. The whole
13625: affair, Mr. Nuttwood said, was dark and inscrutable, and seemed not to
13626: be one in which the interference of God's servants would tend to give
13627: the glory where the glory was due. That a candidate for whom the richer
13628: church members had all voted should have his name associated with the
13629: encouragement of drunkenness, riot, and plunder, was an occasion for the
13630: enemy to blaspheme; and it was not clear how the enemy's mouth would be
13631: stopped by exertions in favor of a rash young man, whose interference
13632: had made things worse instead of better. Mr. Lyon was warned lest his
13633: human partialities should blind him to the interests of truth: it was
13634: God's cause that was endangered in this matter.
13635: 
13636: The little minister's soul was bruised; he himself was keenly alive to
13637: the complication of public and private regards in this affair, and
13638: suffered a good deal at the thought of Tory triumph in the demonstration
13639: that, excepting the attack on the Seven Stars, which called itself a
13640: Whig house, all damage to property had been borne by Tories. He cared
13641: intensely for his opinions, and would have liked events to speak for
13642: them in a sort of picture-writing that everybody could understand. The
13643: enthusiasms of the world are not to be stimulated by a commentary in
13644: small and subtle characters which alone can tell the whole truth; and
13645: the picture writing in Felix Holt's troubles was of an entirely puzzling
13646: kind: if he were a martyr, neither side wanted to claim him. Yet the
13647: minister, as we have seen, found in his Christian faith a reason for
13648: clinging the more to one who had not a large party to back him. That
13649: little man's heart was heroic; he was not one of those Liberals who make
13650: their anxiety for "the cause" of Liberalism a plea for cowardly
13651: desertion.
13652: 
13653: Besides himself, he believed there was no one who could bear testimony
13654: to the remonstrances of Felix concerning the treating of the Sproxton
13655: men, except Jermyn, Johnson, and Harold Transome. Though he had the
13656: vaguest idea of what could be done in the case, he fixed his mind on the
13657: probability that Mr. Transome would be moved to the utmost exertion, if
13658: only as an atonement; but he dared not take any step until he had
13659: consulted Felix, who he foresaw was likely to have a very strong
13660: determination as to the help he would accept or not accept.
13661: 
13662: This last expectation was fulfilled. Mr. Lyon returned to Esther, after
13663: his day's journey to Loamford and back, with less of trouble and
13664: perplexity in his mind: he had at least got a definite course marked
13665: out, to which he must resign himself. Felix had declared that he would
13666: receive no aid from Harold Transome, except the aid he might give as an
13667: honest witness. There was nothing to be done for him but what was
13668: perfectly simple and direct. Even if the pleading of counsel had been
13669: permitted (and at that time it was not) on behalf of a prisoner on trial
13670: for felony, Felix would have declined it: he would in any case have
13671: spoken in his own defence. He had a perfectly simple account to give,
13672: and needed not to avail himself of any legal adroitness. He consented to
13673: accept the services of a respectable solicitor in Loamford, who offered
13674: to conduct his case without any fees. The work was plain and easy, Felix
13675: said. The only witnesses who had to be hunted up at all were some who
13676: could testify that he had tried to take the crowd down Hobb's Lane, and
13677: that they had gone to the Manor in spite of him.
13678: 
13679: "Then he is not so much cast down as you feared, father?" said Esther.
13680: 
13681: "No, child; albeit he is pale and much shaken for one so stalwart. He
13682: hath no grief, he says, save for the poor man Tucker, and for his
13683: mother; otherwise his heart is without a burden. We discoursed greatly
13684: on the sad effect of all this for his mother, and on the perplexed
13685: condition of human things, whereby even right action seems to bring evil
13686: consequences, if we have respect only to our own brief lives, and not to
13687: that larger rule whereby we are stewards of the eternal dealings, and
13688: not contrivers of our own success."
13689: 
13690: "Did he say nothing about me, father?" said Esther, trembling a little,
13691: but unable to repress her egoism.
13692: 
13693: "Yes; he asked if you were well, and sent his affectionate regards. Nay,
13694: he bade me say something which appears to refer to your discourse
13695: together when I was not present. 'Tell her,' he said, 'whatever they
13696: sentence me to, she knows they can't rob me of my vocation. With poverty
13697: for my bride, and preaching and pedagoguy for my business, I am sure of
13698: a handsome establishment.' He laughed--doubtless bearing in mind some
13699: playfulness of thine."
13700: 
13701: Mr. Lyon seemed to be looking at Esther as he smiled, but she was not
13702: near enough for him to discern the expression of her face. Just then it
13703: seemed made for melancholy rather than for playfulness. Hers was not a
13704: childish beauty; and when the sparkle of mischief, wit and vanity was
13705: out of her eyes, and the large look of abstracted sorrow was there, you
13706: would have been surprised by a certain grandeur which the smiles had
13707: hidden. That changing face was the perfect symbol of her mixed
13708: susceptible nature, in which battle was inevitable, and the side of
13709: victory uncertain.
13710: 
13711: She began to look on all that had passed between herself and Felix as
13712: something not buried, but embalmed and kept as a relic in a private
13713: sanctuary. The very entireness of her preoccupation about him, the
13714: perpetual repetition in her memory of all that had passed between them,
13715: tended to produce this effect. She lived with him in the past; in the
13716: future she seemed shut out from him. He was an influence above her life,
13717: rather than a part of it; some time or other, perhaps, he would be to
13718: her as if he belonged to the solemn admonishing skies, checking her
13719: self-satisfied pettiness with the suggestion of a wider life.
13720: 
13721: But not yet--not while her trouble was so fresh. For it was still _her_
13722: trouble, and not Felix Holt's. Perhaps it was a subtraction from his
13723: power over her, that she could never think of him with pity, because he
13724: always seemed to her too great and strong to be pitied; he wanted
13725: nothing. He evaded calamity by choosing privation. The best part of a
13726: woman's love is worship; but it is hard to her to be sent away with her
13727: precious spikenard rejected, and her long tresses too, that were let
13728: fall ready to soothe the wearied feet.
13729: 
13730: While Esther was carrying these things in her heart, the January days
13731: were beginning to pass by with their wonted wintry monotony, except that
13732: there was rather more of good cheer than usual remaining from the feast
13733: of Twelfth Night among the triumphant Tories, and rather more scandal
13734: than usual excited among the mortified Dissenters by the wilfulness of
13735: their minister. He had actually mentioned Felix Holt by name in his
13736: evening sermon, and offered up a petition for him in the evening prayer,
13737: also by name--not as "a young Ishmaelite, whom he would fain see brought
13738: back from the lawless life of the desert, and seated in the same fold
13739: even with the sons of Judah and of Benjamin," a suitable periphrasis
13740: which Brother Kemp threw off without any effort, and with all the
13741: felicity of a suggestive critic. Poor Mrs. Holt, indeed, even in the
13742: midst of her grief, experienced a proud satisfaction; that though she
13743: was not a church member she was now an object of congregational remark
13744: and ministerial allusion. Feeling herself a spotless character standing
13745: out in relief on a dark background of affliction, and a practical
13746: contradiction to that extreme doctrine of human depravity which she had
13747: never "given in to," she was naturally gratified and soothed by a notice
13748: which must be a recognition. But more influential hearers were of
13749: opinion, that in a man who had so many long sentences at command as Mr.
13750: Lyon, so many parentheses and modifying clauses, this naked use of a
13751: non-scriptural Treby name in an address to the Almighty was all the more
13752: offensive. In a low unlettered local preacher of the Wesleyan persuasion
13753: such things might pass; but a certain style in prayer was demanded from
13754: Independents, the most educated body in the ranks of orthodox Dissent.
13755: To Mr. Lyon such notions seemed painfully perverse, and the next morning
13756: he was declaring to Esther his resolution stoutly to withstand them, and
13757: to count nothing common or unclean on which a blessing could be asked,
13758: when the tenor of his thoughts was completely changed by a great shock
13759: of surprise which made both himself and Esther sit looking at each other
13760: in speechless amazement.
13761: 
13762: The cause was a letter brought by a special messenger from Duffield; a
13763: heavy letter addressed to Esther in a business-like manner, quite
13764: unexampled in her correspondence. And the contents of the letter were
13765: more startling than its exterior. It began:
13766: 
13767:     MADAM,--Herewith we send you a brief abstract of evidence which has
13768:     come within our knowledge, that the right of remainder whereby the
13769:     lineal issue of Edward Bycliffe can claim possession of the estates
13770:     of which the entail was settled by John Justus Transome in 1729,
13771:     now first accrues to you as the sole and lawful issue of Maurice
13772:     Christian Bycliffe. We are confident of success in the prosecution
13773:     of this claim, which will result to you in the possession of
13774:     estates to the value, at the lowest, of from five to six thousand
13775:     per annum----
13776: 
13777: It was at this point that Esther, who was reading aloud, let her hand
13778: fall with the letter on her lap, and with a palpitating heart looked at
13779: her father, who looked again in silence that lasted for two or three
13780: minutes. A certain terror was upon them both, though the thoughts that
13781: laid that weight on the tongue of each were different.
13782: 
13783: It was Mr. Lyon who spoke first.
13784: 
13785: "This, then, is what the man named Christian referred to. I distrusted
13786: him, yet it seems he spoke truly."
13787: 
13788: "But," said Esther, whose imagination ran necessarily to those
13789: conditions of wealth which she could best appreciate, "Do they mean that
13790: the Transomes would be turned out of Transome Court, and that I should
13791: go and live there? It seems quite an impossible thing."
13792: 
13793: "Nay, child, I know not. I am ignorant in these things, and the thought
13794: of worldly grandeur for you hath more of terror than of gladness for me.
13795: Nevertheless we must duly weigh all things, not considering aught that
13796: befalls us as a bare event, but rather as an occasion for faithful
13797: stewardship. Let us go to my study and consider this writing further."
13798: 
13799: How this announcement, which to Esther seemed as unprepared as if it had
13800: fallen from the skies, came to be made to her by solicitors other than
13801: Batt & Cowley, the old lawyers of the Bycliffes, was by a sequence as
13802: natural, that is to say, as legally natural, as any in the world. The
13803: secret worker of the apparent wonder was Mr. Johnson, who, on the very
13804: day when he wrote to give his patron, Mr. Jermyn, the serious warning
13805: that a bill was likely to be filed in Chancery against him, had carried
13806: forward with added zeal the business already commenced, of arranging
13807: with another firm his share in the profits likely to result from the
13808: prosecution of Esther Bycliffe's claim.
13809: 
13810: Jermyn's star was certainly going down, and Johnson did not feel an
13811: unmitigated grief. Beyond some troublesome declarations as to his actual
13812: share in transactions in which his name had been used, Johnson saw
13813: nothing formidable in prospect for himself. He was not going to be
13814: ruined, though Jermyn probably was: he was not a high-flyer, but a mere
13815: climbing-bird, who could hold on and get his livelihood just as well if
13816: his wings were clipped a little. And, in the meantime, here was
13817: something to be gained in this Bycliffe business, which, it was not
13818: unpleasant to think, was a nut that Jermyn had intended to keep for his
13819: own particular cracking, and which would be rather a severe astonishment
13820: to Mr. Harold Transome, whose manners towards respectable agents were
13821: such as leave a smart in a man of spirit.
13822: 
13823: Under the stimulus of small many-mixed motives like these, a great deal
13824: of business has been done in the world by well-clad and, in 1833,
13825: clean-shaven men, whose names are on charity lists, and who do not know
13826: that they are base. Mr. Johnson's character was not much more
13827: exceptional than his double chin.
13828: 
13829: No system, religious or political, I believe, has laid it down as a
13830: principle that all men are alike virtuous, or even that all the people
13831: rated for £80 houses are an honor to their species.
13832: 
13833: 
13834: 
13835: 
13836: CHAPTER XXXVIII.
13837: 
13838:     The down we rest on in our aëry dreams
13839:     Has not been plucked from birds that live and smart;
13840:     'Tis but warm snow, that melts not.
13841: 
13842: 
13843: The story and the prospect revealed to Esther by the lawyer's letter,
13844: which she and her father studied together, had made an impression on her
13845: very different from what she had been used to figure to herself in her
13846: many day-dreams as to the effect of a sudden elevation in rank and
13847: fortune. In her day-dreams she had not traced out the means by which
13848: such a change could be brought about; in fact, the change had seemed
13849: impossible to her, except in her little private Utopia, which, like
13850: other Utopias, was filled with delightful results, independent of
13851: processes. But her mind had fixed itself habitually on the signs and
13852: luxuries of ladyhood, for which she had the keenest perception. She had
13853: seen the very mat in her carriage, had scented the dried rose-leaves in
13854: her corridors, had felt the soft carpet under her pretty feet, and seen
13855: herself, as she rose from her sofa cushions, in the crystal panel that
13856: reflected a long drawing-room, where the conservatory flowers and the
13857: pictures of fair women left her still with the supremacy of charm. She
13858: had trodden the marble-firm gravel of her garden-walks and the soft deep
13859: turf of her lawn; she had had her servants about her filled with adoring
13860: respect, because of her kindness as well as her grace and beauty; but
13861: she had had several accomplished cavaliers all at once sueing for her
13862: hand--one of whom, uniting very high birth with long dark eyelashes and
13863: the most distinguished talents, she secretly preferred, though his pride
13864: and hers hindered an avowal, and supplied the inestimable interest of
13865: retardation. The glimpses she had had in her brief life as a family
13866: governess, supplied her ready faculty with details enough of delightful
13867: still life to furnish her day-dreams; and no one who has not, like
13868: Esther, a strong natural prompting and susceptibility toward such
13869: things, and has at the same time suffered from the presence of opposite
13870: conditions, can understand how powerfully those minor accidents of rank
13871: which please the fastidious sense can preoccupy the imagination.
13872: 
13873: It seemed that almost everything in her day-dreams--cavaliers
13874: apart--must be found at Transome Court. But now that fancy was becoming
13875: real, and the impossible appeared possible, Esther found the balance of
13876: her attention reversed: now that her ladyhood was not simply in Utopia,
13877: she found herself arrested and painfully grasped by the means through
13878: which the ladyhood was to be obtained. To her inexperience this strange
13879: story of an alienated inheritance, of such a last representative of
13880: pure-blooded lineage as old Thomas Transome the bill-sticker, above all
13881: of the dispossession hanging over those who actually held, and had
13882: expected always to hold, the wealth and position which were suddenly
13883: announced to be rightly hers--all these things made a picture, not for
13884: her own tastes and fancies to float in with Elysian indulgence, but in
13885: which she was compelled to gaze on the degrading hard experience of
13886: other human beings, and on a humiliating loss which was the obverse of
13887: her own proud gain. Even in her times of most untroubled egoism, Esther
13888: shrank from anything ungenerous; and the fact that she had a very lively
13889: image of Harold Transome and his gypsy-eyed boy in her mind, gave
13890: additional distinctness to the thought that if she entered they must
13891: depart. Of the elder Transomes she had a dimmer vision, and they were
13892: necessarily in the background to her sympathy.
13893: 
13894: She and her father sat with their hands locked, as they might have done
13895: if they had been listening to a solemn oracle in the days of old
13896: revealing unknown kinship and rightful heirdom. It was not that Esther
13897: had any thought of renouncing her fortune; she was incapable, in these
13898: moments, of condensing her vague ideas and feelings into any distinct
13899: plan of action, nor indeed did it seem that she was called upon to act
13900: with any promptitude. It was only that she was conscious of being
13901: strangely awed by something that was called good fortune; and the awe
13902: shut out any scheme of rejection as much as any triumphant joy in
13903: acceptance. Her father, she learned, had died disappointed and in
13904: wrongful imprisonment, and an undefined sense of Nemesis seemed half to
13905: sanctify her inheritance, and counteract its apparent arbitrariness.
13906: 
13907: Felix Holt was present in her mind throughout; what he would say was an
13908: imaginary commentary that she was constantly framing, and the words that
13909: she most frequently gave him--for she dramatized under the inspiration
13910: of a sadness slightly bitter--were of this kind: "That is clearly your
13911: destiny--to be aristocratic, to be rich. I always saw that our lots lay
13912: widely apart. You are not fit for poverty, or any work of difficulty.
13913: But remember what I once said to you about a vision of consequences;
13914: take care where your fortune leads you."
13915: 
13916: Her father had not spoken since they had ended their study and
13917: discussion of the story and the evidence as it was presented to them.
13918: Into this he had entered with his usual penetrating activity; but he was
13919: so accustomed to the impersonal study of narrative, that even in these
13920: exceptional moments the habit of half a century asserted itself, and he
13921: seemed sometimes not to distinguish the case of Esther's inheritance
13922: from a story in ancient history, until some detail recalled him to the
13923: profound feeling that a great, great change might be coming over the
13924: life of this child who was so close to him. At last he relapsed into
13925: total silence, and for some time Esther was not moved to interrupt it.
13926: He had sunk back in his chair with his hand locked in hers, and was
13927: pursuing a sort of prayerful meditation: he lifted up no formal
13928: petition, but it was as if his soul travelled again over the facts he
13929: had been considering in the company of a guide ready to inspire and
13930: correct him. He was striving to purify his feeling in this matter from
13931: selfish or worldly dross--a striving which is that prayer without
13932: ceasing, sure to wrest an answer by its sublime importunity.
13933: 
13934: There is no knowing how long they might have sat in this way, if it had
13935: not been for the inevitable Lyddy reminding them dismally of dinner.
13936: 
13937: "Yes, Lyddy, we come," said Esther: and then, before moving--
13938: 
13939: "Is there any advice you have in your mind for me, father?" The sense of
13940: awe was growing in Esther. Her intensest life was no longer in her
13941: dreams, where she made things to her own mind: she was moving in a world
13942: charged with forces.
13943: 
13944: "Not yet, my dear--save this; that you will seek special illumination in
13945: this juncture, and, above all, be watchful that your soul be not lifted
13946: up within you by what, rightly considered, is rather an increase of
13947: charge, and a call upon you to walk along a path which is indeed easy to
13948: the flesh, but dangerous to the spirit."
13949: 
13950: "You would always live with me, father?" Esther said, under a strong
13951: impulse--partly affection, partly the need to grasp at some moral help.
13952: But she had no sooner uttered the words than they raised a vision,
13953: showing, as by a flash of lightning, the incongruity of that past which
13954: had created the sanctities and affections of her life with that future
13955: which was coming to her----The little rusty old minister, with the one
13956: luxury of his Sunday evening pipe, smoked up the kitchen chimney, coming
13957: to live in the midst of grandeur----but no! her father, with the
13958: grandeur of his past sorrow and his long struggling labors, forsaking
13959: his vocation, and vulgarly accepting an existence unsuited to
13960: him.----Esther's face flushed with the excitement of this vision and its
13961: reversed interpretation, which five months ago she would have been
13962: incapable of seeing. Her question to her father seemed like a mockery;
13963: she was ashamed. He answered slowly--
13964: 
13965: "Touch not that chord yet, my child. I must learn to think of thy lot
13966: according to the demands of Providence. We will rest a while from the
13967: subject; and I will seek calmness in my ordinary duties."
13968: 
13969: The next morning nothing more was said. Mr. Lyon was absorbed in his
13970: sermon-making, for it was near the end of the week, and Esther was
13971: obliged to attend to her pupils. Mrs. Holt came by invitation with
13972: little Job to share their dinner of roast-meat; and, after much of what
13973: the minister called unprofitable discourse, she was quitting the house
13974: when she hastened back with an astonished face, to tell Mr. Lyon and
13975: Esther, who were already in wonder at crashing, thundering sounds on the
13976: pavement, that there was a carriage stopping and stamping at the entry
13977: into Malthouse Yard, with "all sorts of fine liveries," and a lady and
13978: gentleman inside. Mr. Lyon and Esther looked at each other, both having
13979: the same name in their minds.
13980: 
13981: "If it's Mr. Transome or somebody else as is great, Mr. Lyon," urged
13982: Mrs. Holt, "you'll remember my son, and say he's got a mother with a
13983: character they may enquire into as much as they like. And never mind
13984: what Felix says, for he's so masterful he'd stay in prison and be
13985: transported whether or no, only to have his own way. For it's not to be
13986: thought but what the great people could get him off if they would; and
13987: it's very hard with a King in the country and all the texts in Proverbs
13988: about the King's countenance, and Solomon and the live baby----"
13989: 
13990: Mr. Lyon lifted up his hand deprecatingly, and Mrs. Holt retreated from
13991: the parlor-door to a corner of the kitchen, the outer doorway being
13992: occupied by Dominic, who was enquiring if Mr. and Miss Lyon were at
13993: home, and could receive Mrs. Transome and Mr. Harold Transome. While
13994: Dominic went back to the carriage Mrs. Holt escaped with her tiny
13995: companion to Zachary's, the new pew-opener, observing to Lyddy that she
13996: knew herself, and was not that woman to stay where she might not be
13997: wanted; whereupon Lyddy, differing fundamentally, admonished her parting
13998: ear that it was well if she knew herself to be dust and ashes--silently
13999: extending the application of this remark to Mrs. Transome, as she saw
14000: the tall lady sweep in arrayed in her rich black and fur, with that fine
14001: gentleman behind her whose thick top-knot of wavy hair, sparkling ring,
14002: dark complexion, and general air of worldly exaltation unconnected with
14003: chapel, were painfully suggestive to Lyddy of Herod, Pontius Pilate, or
14004: the much-quoted Gallio.
14005: 
14006: Harold Transome, greeting Esther gracefully, presented his mother, whose
14007: eagle-like glance, fixed on her from the first moment of entering,
14008: seemed to Esther to pierce her through. Mrs. Transome hardly noticed Mr.
14009: Lyon, not from studied haughtiness, but from sheer mental inability to
14010: consider him--as a person ignorant of natural history is unable to
14011: consider a fresh-water polyp otherwise than as a sort of animated weed,
14012: certainly not fit for table. But Harold saw that his mother was
14013: agreeably struck by Esther, who indeed showed to much advantage. She was
14014: not at all taken by surprise, and maintained a dignified quietude; but
14015: her previous knowledge and reflection about the possible dispossession
14016: of these Transomes gave her a softened feeling toward them which tinged
14017: her manners very agreeably.
14018: 
14019: Harold was carefully polite to the minister, throwing out a word to make
14020: him understand that he had an important part in the important business
14021: which had brought this unannounced visit; and the four made a group
14022: seated not far off each other near the window, Mrs. Transome and Esther
14023: being on the sofa.
14024: 
14025: "You must be astonished at a visit from me, Miss Lyon," Mrs. Transome
14026: began; "I seldom come to Treby Magna. Now I see you, the visit is an
14027: unexpected pleasure; but the cause of my coming is business of a serious
14028: nature, which my son will communicate to you."
14029: 
14030: "I ought to begin by saying that what I have to announce to you is the
14031: reverse of disagreeable, Miss Lyon," said Harold, with lively ease. "I
14032: don't suppose the world would consider it very good news for me; but a
14033: rejected candidate, Mr. Lyon," Harold went on, turning graciously to the
14034: minister, "begins to be inured to loss and misfortune."
14035: 
14036: "Truly, sir," said Mr. Lyon, with a rather sad solemnity, "your allusion
14037: hath a grievous bearing for me, but I will not retard your present
14038: purpose by further remark."
14039: 
14040: "You will never guess what I have to disclose," said Harold, again
14041: looking at Esther, "unless, indeed, you have already had some previous
14042: intimation of it."
14043: 
14044: "Does it refer to law and inheritance?" said Esther, with a smile. She
14045: was already brightened by Harold's manner. The news seemed to be losing
14046: its chillness, and to be something really belonging to warm,
14047: comfortable, interesting life.
14048: 
14049: "Then you have already heard of it?" said Harold, inwardly vexed, but
14050: sufficiently prepared not to seem so.
14051: 
14052: "Only yesterday," said Esther, quite simply, "I received a letter from
14053: some lawyers with a statement of many surprising things, showing that I
14054: was an heiress"--here she turned very prettily to address Mrs.
14055: Transome--"which, as you may imagine, is one of the last things I could
14056: have supposed myself to be."
14057: 
14058: "My dear," said Mrs. Transome with elderly grace, just laying her hand
14059: for an instant on Esther's, "it is a lot that would become you
14060: admirably."
14061: 
14062: Esther blushed, and said playfully:
14063: 
14064: "Oh, I know what to buy with fifty pounds a-year, but I know the price
14065: of nothing beyond that."
14066: 
14067: Her father sat looking at her through his spectacles, stroking his chin.
14068: It was amazing to herself that she was taking so lightly now what had
14069: caused her such deep emotion yesterday.
14070: 
14071: "I daresay, then," said Harold, "you are more fully possessed of
14072: particulars than I am. So that my mother and I need only tell you what
14073: no one else can tell you--that is, what are her and my feelings and
14074: wishes under these new and unexpected circumstances."
14075: 
14076: "I am most anxious," said Esther, with a grave beautiful look of respect
14077: to Mrs. Transome--"most anxious on that point. Indeed, being of course
14078: in uncertainty about it, I have not yet known whether I could rejoice."
14079: Mrs. Transome's glance had softened. She liked Esther to look at her.
14080: 
14081: "Our chief anxiety," she said, knowing what Harold wished her to say,
14082: "is, that there may be no contest, no useless expenditure of money. Of
14083: course we will surrender what can be rightfully claimed."
14084: 
14085: "My mother expresses our feeling precisely, Miss Lyon," said Harold.
14086: "And I'm sure, Mr. Lyon, you will understand our desire."
14087: 
14088: "Assuredly, sir. My daughter would in any case have had my advice to
14089: seek a conclusion which would involve no strife. We endeavor, sir, in
14090: our body, to hold to the apostolic rule that one Christian brother
14091: should not go to law with another; and I, for my part, would extend this
14092: rule to all my fellow-men, apprehending that the practice of our courts
14093: is little consistent with the simplicity that is in Christ."
14094: 
14095: "If it is to depend on my will," said Esther, "there is nothing that
14096: would be more repugnant to me than any struggle on such a subject. But
14097: can't the lawyers go on doing what they will in spite of me? It seems
14098: that this is what they mean."
14099: 
14100: "Not exactly," said Harold, smiling. "Of course they live by such
14101: struggles as you dislike. But we can thwart them by determining not to
14102: quarrel. It is desirable that we should consider the affair together,
14103: and put it into the hands of honorable solicitors. I assure you we
14104: Transomes will not contend for what is not our own."
14105: 
14106: "And this is what I have come to beg of you," said Mrs. Transome. "It is
14107: that you will come to Transome Court--and let us take full time to
14108: arrange matters. Do oblige me: you shall not be teased more than you
14109: like by an old woman: you shall do just as you please, and become
14110: acquainted with your future home, since it is to be yours. I can tell
14111: you a world of things that you will want to know; and the business can
14112: proceed properly."
14113: 
14114: "Do consent," said Harold, with winning brevity.
14115: 
14116: Esther was flushed and her eyes were bright. It was impossible for her
14117: not to feel that the proposal was a more tempting step toward her change
14118: of condition than she could have thought of beforehand. She had
14119: forgotten that she was in any trouble. But she looked toward her father,
14120: who was again stroking his chin, as was his habit when he was doubting
14121: or deliberating.
14122: 
14123: "I hope you do not disapprove of Miss Lyon's granting us this favor?"
14124: said Harold to the minister.
14125: 
14126: "I have nothing to oppose to it, sir, if my daughter's own mind is clear
14127: as to her course."
14128: 
14129: "You will come--now--with us," said Mrs. Transome, persuasively. "You
14130: will go back with us now in the carriage."
14131: 
14132: Harold was highly gratified with the perfection of his mother's manner
14133: on this occasion, which he had looked forward to as difficult. Since he
14134: had come home again he had never seen her so much at her ease, or with
14135: so much benignancy in her face. The secret lay in the charm of Esther's
14136: sweet young deference, a sort of charm that had not before entered into
14137: Mrs. Transome's elderly life. Esther's pretty behavior, it must be
14138: confessed, was not fed entirely from lofty moral sources: over and above
14139: her really generous feeling, she enjoyed Mrs. Transome's accent, the
14140: high-bred quietness of her speech, the delicate odor of her drapery. She
14141: had always thought that life must be particularly easy if one could pass
14142: it among refined people; and so it seemed at this moment. She wished,
14143: unmixedly, to go to Transome Court.
14144: 
14145: "Since my father has no objection," she said, "and you urge me so
14146: kindly. But I must beg for time to pack up a few clothes."
14147: 
14148: "By all means," said Mrs. Transome. "We are not at all pressed."
14149: 
14150: When Esther had left the room, Harold said, "Apart from our immediate
14151: reason for coming, Mr. Lyon, I could have wished to see you about these
14152: unhappy consequences of the election contest. But you will understand
14153: that I have been much preoccupied with private affairs."
14154: 
14155: "You have well said that the consequences are unhappy, sir. And but for
14156: a reliance on something more than human calculation, I know not which I
14157: should most bewail--the scandal which wrong-dealing has brought on right
14158: principles or the snares which it laid for the feet of a young man who
14159: is dear to me. 'One soweth, and another reapeth,' is a verity that
14160: applies to evil as well as good."
14161: 
14162: "You are referring to Felix Holt. I have not neglected steps to secure
14163: the best legal help for the prisoners: but I am given to understand that
14164: Holt refuses any aid from me. I hope he will not go rashly to work in
14165: speaking in his own defence without any legal instruction. It is an
14166: opprobrium of our law that no counsel is allowed to plead for the
14167: prisoner in cases of felony. A ready tongue may do a man as much harm as
14168: good in a court of justice. He piques himself on making a display, and
14169: displays a little too much."
14170: 
14171: "Sir, you know him not," said the little minister, in his deeper tone.
14172: "He would not accept, even if it were accorded, a defense wherein the
14173: truth was screened or avoided,--not from a vainglorious spirit of
14174: self-exhibition, for he hath a singular directness and simplicity of
14175: speech; but from an averseness to a profession wherein a man may without
14176: shame seek to justify the wicked for reward, and take away the
14177: righteousness of the righteous from him."
14178: 
14179: "It's a pity a fine young fellow should do himself harm by fanatical
14180: notions of that sort. I could at least have procured the advantage of
14181: first-rate consultation. He didn't look to me like a dreamy personage."
14182: 
14183: "Nor is he dreamy; rather, his excess lies in being too practical."
14184: 
14185: "Well, I hope you will not encourage him in such irrationality; the
14186: question is not one of misrepresentation, but of adjusting fact, so as
14187: to raise it to the power of evidence. Don't you see that?"
14188: 
14189: "I do, I do. But I distrust not Felix Holt's discernment in regard to
14190: his own case. He builds not on doubtful things and hath no illusory
14191: hopes; on the contrary, he is of a too-scornful incredulity where I
14192: would fain see a more childlike faith. But he will hold no belief
14193: without action corresponding thereto; and the occasion of his return to
14194: this, his native place, at a time which has proved fatal, was no other
14195: than his resolve to hinder the sale of some drugs, which had chiefly
14196: supported his mother, but which his better knowledge showed him to be
14197: pernicious to the human frame. He undertook to support her by his own
14198: labor; but, sir, I pray you to mark--and old as I am, I will not deny
14199: that this young man instructs me herein--I pray you to mark the
14200: poisonous confusion of good and evil which is the wide-spreading effect
14201: of vicious practices. Through the use of undue electioneering
14202: means--concerning which, however, I do not accuse you farther than of
14203: having acted the part of him who washes his hands when he delivers up to
14204: others the exercise of an iniquitous power--Felix Holt is, I will not
14205: scruple to say, the innocent victim of a riot; and that deed of strict
14206: honesty, whereby he took on himself the charge of his aged mother, seems
14207: now to have deprived her of sufficient bread, and is even an occasion of
14208: reproach to him from the weaker brethren."
14209: 
14210: "I shall be proud to supply her as amply as you think desirable," said
14211: Harold, not enjoying this lecture.
14212: 
14213: "I will pray you to speak of this question with my daughter, who, it
14214: appears, may herself have large means at command, and would desire to
14215: minister to Mrs. Holt's needs with all friendship and delicacy. For the
14216: present I can take care that she lacks nothing essential."
14217: 
14218: As Mr. Lyon was speaking, Esther re-entered, equipped for her drive. She
14219: laid her hand on her father's arm and said, "You will let my pupils know
14220: at once, will you, father?"
14221: 
14222: "Doubtless, my dear," said the old man, trembling a little under the
14223: feeling that this departure of Esther's was a crisis. Nothing again
14224: would be as it had been in their mutual life. But he feared that he was
14225: being mastered by a too tender self-regard, and struggled to keep
14226: himself calm.
14227: 
14228: Mrs. Transome and Harold had both risen.
14229: 
14230: "If you are quite ready, Miss Lyon," said Harold, divining that the
14231: father and daughter would like to have an unobserved moment, "I will
14232: take my mother to the carriage and come back for you."
14233: 
14234: When they were alone, Esther put her hands on her father's shoulders and
14235: kissed him.
14236: 
14237: "This will not be a grief to you, I hope, father? You think it is better
14238: that I should go?"
14239: 
14240: "Nay, child, I am weak. But I would fain be capable of a joy quite apart
14241: from the accidents of my aged earthly existence, which, indeed, is a
14242: petty and almost dried-up fountain--whereas to the receptive soul the
14243: river of life pauses not, nor is diminished."
14244: 
14245: "Perhaps you will see Felix Holt again and tell him all?"
14246: 
14247: "Shall I say aught to him for you?"
14248: 
14249: "Oh, no; only that Job Tudge has a little flannel shirt and a box of
14250: lozenges," said Esther, smiling. "Ah, I hear Mr. Transome coming back. I
14251: must say good-bye to Lyddy, else she will cry over my hard heart."
14252: 
14253: In spite of all the grave thoughts that had been, Esther felt it a very
14254: pleasant as well as new experience to be led to the carriage by Harold
14255: Transome, to be seated on soft cushions, and bowled along, looked at
14256: admiringly and deferentially by a person opposite, whom it was agreeable
14257: to look at in return, and talked to with suavity and liveliness. Toward
14258: what prospect was that easy carriage really leading her? She could not
14259: be always asking herself Mentor-like questions. Her young, bright nature
14260: was rather weary of the sadness that had grown heavier in these last
14261: weeks, like a chill white mist hopelessly veiling the day. Her fortune
14262: was beginning to appear worthy of being called good fortune. She had
14263: come to a new stage in her journey; a new day had arisen on new scenes,
14264: and her young untired spirit was full of curiosity.
14265: 
14266: 
14267: 
14268: 
14269: CHAPTER XXXIX.
14270: 
14271:     No man believes that many-textured knowledge and skill--as a just
14272:     idea of the solar system, or the power of painting flesh, or of
14273:     reading written harmonies--can come late and of a sudden; yet many
14274:     will not stick at believing that happiness can come at any day and
14275:     hour solely by a new disposition of events; though there is naught
14276:     less capable of a magical production than a mortal's happiness,
14277:     which is mainly a complex of habitual relations and dispositions
14278:     not to be wrought by news from foreign parts, or any whirling of
14279:     fortune's wheel for one on whose brow Time has written legibly.
14280: 
14281: 
14282: Some days after Esther's arrival at Transome Court, Denner, coming to
14283: dress Mrs. Transome before dinner--a labor of love for which she had
14284: ample leisure now--found her mistress seated with more than ever of a
14285: marble aspect of self-absorbed suffering, which to the waiting-woman's
14286: keen observation had been gradually intensifying itself during the past
14287: week. She had tapped at the door without having been summoned, and she
14288: had ventured to enter though she had heard no voice saying, "Come in."
14289: 
14290: Mrs. Transome had on a dark warm dressing-gown, hanging in thick folds
14291: about her, and she was seated before a mirror which filled a panel from
14292: the floor to the ceiling. The room was bright with the light of the fire
