14293: and of wax candles. For some reason, contrary to her usual practice,
14294: Mrs. Transome had herself unfastened her abundant gray hair, which
14295: rolled backward in a pale sunless stream over her dark dress. She was
14296: seated before the mirror apparently looking at herself, her brow knit in
14297: one deep furrow, and her jewelled hands laid one above the other on her
14298: knee. Probably she had ceased to see the reflection in the mirror, for
14299: her eyes had the fixed wide-open look that belongs not to examination,
14300: but to reverie. Motionless in that way, her clear-cut features keeping
14301: distinct record of past beauty, she looked like an image faded, dried,
14302: and bleached by uncounted suns, rather than a breathing woman who had
14303: numbered the years as they passed, and had a consciousness within her
14304: which was the slow deposit of those ceaseless rolling years.
14305: 
14306: Denner, with all her ingrained and systematic reserve, could not help
14307: showing signs that she was startled, when, peering from between her
14308: half-closed eyelids, she saw the motionless image in the mirror opposite
14309: to her as she entered. Her gentle opening of the door had not roused her
14310: mistress, to whom the sensations produced by Denner's presence were as
14311: little disturbing as those of a favorite cat. But the slight cry, and
14312: the start reflected in the glass, were unusual enough to break the
14313: reverie, Mrs. Transome moved, leaned back in her chair, and said--
14314: 
14315: "So you're come at last, Denner?"
14316: 
14317: "Yes, madam; it is not late. I'm sorry you should have undone your hair
14318: yourself."
14319: 
14320: "I undid it to see what an old hag I am. These fine clothes you put on
14321: me, Denner, are only a smart shroud."
14322: 
14323: "Pray don't talk so, madam. If there's anybody doesn't think it pleasant
14324: to look at you, so much the worse for them. For my part, I've seen no
14325: young ones fit to hold up your train. Look at your likeness down below;
14326: and though you're older now, what signifies? I wouldn't be Letty in the
14327: scullery because she's got red cheeks. She mayn't know she's a poor
14328: creature, but I know it, and that's enough for me; I know what sort of a
14329: dowdy draggletail she'll be in ten years' time. I would change with
14330: nobody, madam. And if troubles were put up to market, I'd sooner buy old
14331: than new. It's something to have seen the worst."
14332: 
14333: "A woman never has seen the worst till she is old, Denner," said Mrs.
14334: Transome, bitterly.
14335: 
14336: The keen little waiting-woman was not clear as to the cause of her
14337: mistress's added bitterness; but she rarely brought herself to ask
14338: questions, when Mrs. Transome did not authorize them by beginning to
14339: give her information. Banks the bailiff and the head-servant had nodded
14340: and winked a good deal over the certainty that Mr. Harold was "none so
14341: fond" of Jermyn, but this was a subject on which Mrs. Transome had never
14342: made up her mind to speak, and Denner knew nothing definite. Again, she
14343: felt quite sure that there was some important secret connected with
14344: Esther's presence in the house; she suspected that the close Dominic
14345: knew the secret, and was more trusted than she was, in spite of her
14346: forty years' service; but any resentment on this ground would have been
14347: an entertained reproach against her mistress, inconsistent with Denner's
14348: creed and character. She inclined to the belief that Esther was the
14349: immediate cause of the new discontent.
14350: 
14351: "If there's anything worse coming to you, I should like to know what it
14352: is, madam," she said, after a moment's silence, speaking always in the
14353: same low quick way, and keeping up her quiet labors. "When I awake at
14354: cock-crow, I'd sooner have one real grief on my mind than twenty false.
14355: It's better to know one's robbed than to think one's going to be
14356: murdered."
14357: 
14358: "I believe you are the creature in the world that loves me best, Denner;
14359: yet you will never understand what I suffer. It's of no use telling you.
14360: There's no folly in you, and no heartache. You are made of iron. You
14361: have never had any trouble."
14362: 
14363: "I've had some of your trouble, madam."
14364: 
14365: "Yes, you good thing. But as a sick-nurse, that never caught the fever.
14366: You never even had a child."
14367: 
14368: "I can feel for things I never went through. I used to be sorry for the
14369: poor French Queen when I was young; I'd have lain cold for her to lie
14370: warm. I know people have feelings according to their birth and station.
14371: And you always took things to heart, madam, beyond anybody else. But I
14372: hope there's nothing new, to make you talk of the worst."
14373: 
14374: "Yes, Denner, there is--there is," said Mrs. Transome, speaking in a low
14375: tone of misery, while she bent for her head-dress to be pinned on.
14376: 
14377: "Is it this young lady?"
14378: 
14379: "Why, what do you think about her, Denner?" said Mrs. Transome, in a
14380: tone of more spirit, rather curious to hear what the old woman would
14381: say.
14382: 
14383: "I don't deny she's graceful, and she has a pretty smile and very good
14384: manners: it's quite unaccountable by what Banks says about her father. I
14385: know nothing of those Treby townsfolk myself, but for my part I'm
14386: puzzled. I'm fond of Mr. Harold. I always shall be, madam. I was at his
14387: bringing into the world, and nothing but his doing wrong by you would
14388: turn me against him. But the servants all say he's in love with Miss
14389: Lyon."
14390: 
14391: "I wish it were true, Denner," said Mrs. Transome, energetically. "I
14392: wish he were in love with her, so that she could master him, and make
14393: him do what she pleased."
14394: 
14395: "Then it is not true--what they say?"
14396: 
14397: "Not true that she will ever master him. No woman ever will. He will
14398: make her fond of him, and afraid of him. That's one of the things you
14399: have never gone through, Denner. A woman's love is always freezing into
14400: fear. She wants everything, she is secure of nothing. This girl has a
14401: fine spirit--plenty of fire and pride and wit. Men like such captives,
14402: as they like horses that champ the bit and paw the ground: they feel
14403: more triumph in their mastery. What is the use of a woman's will?--if
14404: she tries, she doesn't get it, and she ceases to be loved. God was cruel
14405: when He made women."
14406: 
14407: Denner was used to such outbursts as this. Her mistress's rhetoric and
14408: temper belonged to her superior rank, her grand person, and her piercing
14409: black eyes. Mrs. Transome had a sense of impiety in her words which made
14410: them all the more tempting to her impotent anger. The waiting-woman had
14411: none of that awe which could be turned into defiance: the Sacred Grove
14412: was a common thicket to her.
14413: 
14414: "It mayn't be good luck to be a woman," she said. "But one begins with
14415: it from a baby: one gets used to it. And I shouldn't like to be a
14416: man--to cough so loud, and stand straddling about on a wet day, and be
14417: so wasteful with meat and drink. They're a coarse lot, I think. Then I
14418: needn't make a trouble of this young lady, madam," she added, after a
14419: moment's pause.
14420: 
14421: "No, Denner, I like her. If that were all--I should like Harold to marry
14422: her. It would be the best thing. If the truth were known--and it will be
14423: known soon--the estate is hers by law--such law as it is. It's a strange
14424: story: she's a Bycliffe really."
14425: 
14426: Denner did not look amazed, but went on fastening her mistress's dress,
14427: as she said--
14428: 
14429: "Well, madam, I was sure there was something wonderful at the bottom of
14430: it. And turning the old lawsuits and everything else over in my mind, I
14431: thought the law might have something to do with it. Then she is a born
14432: lady?"
14433: 
14434: "Yes; she has good blood in her veins."
14435: 
14436: "We talked that over in the housekeeper's room--what a hand and an
14437: instep she has, and how her head is set on her shoulders--almost like
14438: your own, madam. But her lightish complexion spoils her, to my thinking.
14439: And Dominic said Mr. Harold never admired that sort of woman before.
14440: There's nothing that smooth fellow couldn't tell you if he would: he
14441: knows the answer to riddles before they're made. However, he knows how
14442: to hold his tongue; I'll say that for him. And so do I, madam."
14443: 
14444: "Yes, yes; you will not talk of it till other people are talking of it."
14445: 
14446: "And so, if Mr. Harold married her, it would save all fuss and
14447: mischief?"
14448: 
14449: "Yes--about the estate."
14450: 
14451: "And he seems inclined; and she'll not refuse him, I'll answer for it.
14452: And you like her, madam. There's everything to set your mind at rest."
14453: 
14454: Denner was putting the finishing-touch to Mrs. Transome's dress by
14455: throwing an Indian scarf over her shoulders, and so completing the
14456: contrast between the majestic lady in costume and the dishevelled
14457: Hecuba-like woman whom she had found half an hour before.
14458: 
14459: "I am not at rest!" Mrs. Transome said, with slow distinctness, moving
14460: from the mirror to the window, where the blind was not drawn down, and
14461: she could see the chill white landscape and the far-off unheeding stars.
14462: 
14463: Denner, more distressed by her mistress's suffering than she could have
14464: been by anything else, took up with the instinct of affection a gold
14465: vinaigrette which Mrs. Transome often liked to carry with her, and going
14466: up to her put it into her hand gently. Mrs. Transome grasped the little
14467: woman's hand hard, and held it so.
14468: 
14469: "Denner," she said, in a low tone, "if I could choose at this moment, I
14470: would choose that Harold should never have been born."
14471: 
14472: "Nay, my dear," (Denner had only once before in her life said "my dear"
14473: to her mistress), "it was a happiness to you then."
14474: 
14475: "I don't believe I felt the happiness then as I feel the misery now. It
14476: is foolish to say people can't feel much when they are getting old. Not
14477: pleasure, perhaps--little comes. But they can feel they are
14478: forsaken--why, every fibre in me seems to be a memory that makes a pang.
14479: They can feel that all the love in their lives is turned to hatred or
14480: contempt."
14481: 
14482: "Not mine, madam, not mine. Let what would be I should want to live for
14483: your sake, for fear you should have nobody to do for you as I would."
14484: 
14485: "Ah, then you are a happy woman, Denner; you have loved somebody for
14486: forty years who is old and weak now, and can't do without you."
14487: 
14488: The sound of the dinner-gong resounded below, and Mrs. Transome let the
14489: faithful hand fall again.
14490: 
14491: 
14492: 
14493: 
14494: CHAPTER XL.
14495: 
14496:     "She's beautiful; and therefore to be wooed:
14497:     She is a woman; therefore to be won."
14498: 
14499:                                                --_Henry VI._
14500: 
14501: 
14502: If Denner had had a suspicion that Esther's presence at Transome Court
14503: was not agreeable to her mistress, it was impossible to entertain such a
14504: suspicion with regard to the other members of the family. Between her
14505: and little Harry there was an extraordinary fascination. This creature,
14506: with the soft, broad, brown cheeks, low forehead, great black eyes,
14507: tiny, well-defined nose, fierce, biting tricks toward every person and
14508: thing he disliked, and insistence on entirely occupying those he liked,
14509: was a human specimen such as Esther had never seen before, and she
14510: seemed to be equally original in Harry's experience. At first sight her
14511: light complexion and her blue gown, probably also her sunny smile and
14512: her hands stretched out toward him, seemed to make a show for him as of
14513: a new sort of bird: he threw himself backward against his "Gappa," as he
14514: called old Mr. Transome, and stared at this new comer with the gravity
14515: of a wild animal. But she had no sooner sat down on the sofa in the
14516: library than he climbed up to her, and began to treat her as an
14517: attractive object in natural history, snatched up her curls with his
14518: brown fist, and, discovering that there was a little ear under them,
14519: pinched it and blew into it, pulled at her coronet of plaits, and seemed
14520: to discover with satisfaction that it did not grow at the summit of her
14521: head, but could be dragged down and altogether undone. Then finding that
14522: she laughed, tossed him back, kissed, and pretended to bite him--in
14523: fact, was an animal that understood fun--he rushed off and made Dominic
14524: bring a small menagerie of white mice, squirrels, and birds, with Moro,
14525: the black spaniel, to make her acquaintance. Whomsoever Harry liked, it
14526: followed that Mr. Transome must like: "Gappa," along with Nimrod the
14527: retriever, was part of the menagerie, and perhaps endured more than all
14528: the other live creatures in the way of being tumbled about. Seeing that
14529: Esther bore having her hair pulled down quite merrily, and that she was
14530: willing to be harnessed and beaten, the old man began to confide to her,
14531: in his feeble, smiling, and rather jerking fashion, Harry's remarkable
14532: feats: how he had one day, when Gappy was asleep, unpinned a whole
14533: drawerful of beetles, to see if they would fly away; then, disgusted
14534: with their stupidity, was about to throw them all on the ground and
14535: stamp on them, when Dominic came in and rescued these valuable
14536: specimens; also, how he had subtly watched Mrs. Transome at the cabinet
14537: where she kept her medicines, and, when she had left it for a little
14538: while without locking it, had gone to the drawers and scattered half the
14539: contents on the floor. But what old Mr. Transome thought the most
14540: wonderful proof of an almost preternatural cleverness was, that Harry
14541: would hardly ever talk, but preferred making inarticulate noises, or
14542: combining syllables after a method of his own.
14543: 
14544: "He can talk well enough if he likes," said Gappa, evidently thinking
14545: that Harry, like the monkeys, had deep reasons for his reticence.
14546: 
14547: "You mind him," he added, nodding at Esther, and shaking with low-toned
14548: laughter. "You'll hear: he knows the right names of things well enough,
14549: but he likes to make his own. He'll give you one all to yourself before
14550: long."
14551: 
14552: And when Harry seemed to have made up his mind distinctly that Esther's
14553: name was "Boo," Mr. Transome nodded at her with triumphant satisfaction,
14554: and then told her in a low whisper, looking round cautiously beforehand,
14555: that Harry would never call Mrs. Transome "Gamma," but always "Bite."
14556: 
14557: "It's wonderful!" said he, laughing slyly.
14558: 
14559: The old man seemed so happy now in the new world created for him by
14560: Dominic and Harry, that he would perhaps have made a holocaust of his
14561: flies and beetles if it had been necessary in order to keep this living,
14562: lively kindness about him. He no longer confined himself to the library,
14563: but shuffled along from room to room, staying and looking on at what was
14564: going forward whenever he did not find Mrs. Transome alone.
14565: 
14566: To Esther the sight of this feeble-minded, timid, paralytic man, who had
14567: long abdicated all mastery over the things that were his, was something
14568: piteous. Certainly this had never been part of the furniture she had
14569: imagined for the delightful aristocratic dwelling in her Utopia; and the
14570: sad irony of such a lot impressed her the more because in her father she
14571: was accustomed to age accompanied with mental acumen and activity. Her
14572: thoughts went back in conjecture over the past life of Mr. and Mrs.
14573: Transome, a couple so strangely different from each other. She found it
14574: impossible to arrange their existence in the seclusion of this fine park
14575: and in this lofty large-roomed house, where it seemed quite ridiculous
14576: to be anything so small as a human being, without finding it rather
14577: dull. Mr. Transome had always had his beetles, but Mrs. Transome----? it
14578: was not easy to conceive that the husband and wife had ever been very
14579: fond of each other.
14580: 
14581: Esther felt at her ease with Mrs. Transome: she was gratified by the
14582: consciousness--for on this point Esther was very quick--that Mrs.
14583: Transome admired her, and looked at her with satisfied eyes. But when
14584: they were together in the early days of her stay, the conversation
14585: turned chiefly on what happened in Mrs. Transome's youth--what she wore
14586: when she was presented at Court--who were the most distinguished and
14587: beautiful women at that time--the terrible excitement of the French
14588: Revolution--the emigrants she had known, and the history of various
14589: titled members of the Lingon family. And Esther, from native delicacy,
14590: did not lead to more recent topics of a personal kind. She was copiously
14591: instructed that the Lingon family was better than that even of the elder
14592: Transomes, and was privileged with an explanation of the various
14593: quarterings, which proved that the Lingon blood had been continually
14594: enriched. Poor Mrs. Transome, with her secret bitterness and dread,
14595: still found a flavor in this sort of pride; none the less because
14596: certain deeds of her own life had been in fatal inconsistency with it.
14597: Besides, genealogies entered into her stock of ideas, and her talk on
14598: such subjects was as necessary as the notes of the linnet or the
14599: blackbird. She had no ultimate analysis of things that went beyond blood
14600: and family--the Herons of Fenshore or the Badgers of Hillbury. She had
14601: never seen behind the canvas with which her life was hung. In the dim
14602: background there was the burning mount and the tables of the law; in the
14603: foreground there was Lady Debarry privately gossipping about her, and
14604: Lady Wyvern finally deciding not to send her invitations to dinner.
14605: Unlike that Semiramis who made laws to suit her practical license, she
14606: lived, poor soul, in the midst of desecrated sanctities, and of honors
14607: that looked tarnished in the light of monotonous and weary suns.
14608: Glimpses of the Lingon heraldry in their freshness were interesting to
14609: Esther; but it occurred to her that when she had known about them a good
14610: while they would cease to be succulent themes of converse or meditation,
14611: and Mrs. Transome, having known them all along, might have felt a vacuum
14612: in spite of them.
14613: 
14614: Nevertheless it was entertaining at present to be seated on soft
14615: cushions with her netting before her, while Mrs. Transome went on with
14616: her embroidery, and told in that easy phrase, and with that refined
14617: high-bred tone and accent which she possessed in perfection, family
14618: stories that to Esther were like so many novelettes; what diamonds were
14619: in the Earl's family, own cousins to Mrs. Transome; how poor Lady Sara's
14620: husband went off into jealous madness only a month after their marriage,
14621: and dragged that sweet blue-eyed thing by the hair; and how the
14622: brilliant Fanny, having married a country parson, became so niggardly
14623: that she had gone about almost begging for fresh eggs from the farmers'
14624: wives, though she had done very well with her six sons, as there was a
14625: bishop and no end of interest in the family, and two of them got
14626: appointments in India.
14627: 
14628: At present Mrs. Transome did not touch at all on her own time of
14629: privation, or her troubles with her eldest son, or on anything that lay
14630: very close to her heart. She conversed with Esther, and acted the part
14631: of hostess, as she performed her toilet and went on with her embroidery:
14632: these things were to be done whether one were happy or miserable. Even
14633: the patriarch Job, if he had been a gentleman of the modern West, would
14634: have avoided picturesque disorder and poetical laments; and the friends
14635: who called on him, though not less disposed than Bildad the Shuhite to
14636: hint that their unfortunate friend was in the wrong, would have sat on
14637: chairs and held their hats in their hands. The harder problems of our
14638: life have changed less than our manners; we wrestle with the old
14639: sorrows, but more decorously. Esther's inexperience prevented her from
14640: divining much about this fine gray-haired woman, whom she could not help
14641: perceiving to stand apart from the family group, as if there were some
14642: cause of isolation for her both within and without. To her young heart
14643: there was a peculiar interest in Mrs. Transome. An elderly woman, whose
14644: beauty, position, and graceful kindness toward herself, made deference
14645: to her spontaneous, was a new figure in Esther's experience. Her quick
14646: light movement was always ready to anticipate what Mrs. Transome wanted;
14647: her bright apprehension and silvery speech were always ready to cap Mrs.
14648: Transome's narratives or instructions even about doses and liniments,
14649: with some lively commentary. She must have behaved charmingly; for one
14650: day when she had tripped across the room to put the screen just in the
14651: right place, Mrs. Transome said, taking her hand, "My dear, you make me
14652: wish I had a daughter!"
14653: 
14654: That was pleasant; and so it was to be decked by Mrs. Transome's own
14655: hands in a set of turquoise ornaments, which became her wonderfully,
14656: worn with a white Cashmere dress, which was also insisted on. Esther
14657: never reflected that there was a double intention in these pretty ways
14658: toward her; with young generosity, she was rather preoccupied by the
14659: desire to prove that she herself entertained no low triumph in the fact
14660: that she had rights prejudicial to this family whose life she was
14661: learning. And besides, through all Mrs. Transome's perfect manners,
14662: there pierced some undefinable indications of a hidden anxiety much
14663: deeper than anything she could feel about this affair of the estate--to
14664: which she often alluded slightly as a reason for informing Esther of
14665: something. It was impossible to mistake her for a happy woman; and young
14666: speculation is always stirred by discontent for which there is no
14667: obvious cause. When we are older, we take the uneasy eyes and the bitter
14668: lips more as a matter of course.
14669: 
14670: But Harold Transome was more communicative about recent years than his
14671: mother was. He thought it well that Esther should know how the fortune
14672: of his family had been drained by law expenses, owing to suits
14673: mistakenly urged by her family; he spoke of his mother's lonely life
14674: and pinched circumstances, of her lack of comfort in her elder son, and
14675: of the habit she had consequently acquired of looking at the gloomy side
14676: of things. He hinted that she had been accustomed to dictate, and that,
14677: as he had left her when he was a boy, she had perhaps indulged the dream
14678: that he would come back a boy. She was still sore on the point of his
14679: politics. These things could not be helped, but so far as he could, he
14680: wished to make the rest of her life as cheerful as possible.
14681: 
14682: Esther listened eagerly, and took these things to heart. The claim to an
14683: inheritance, the sudden discovery of a right to a fortune held by
14684: others, was acquiring a very distinct and unexpected meaning for her.
14685: Every day she was getting more clearly into her imagination what it
14686: would be to abandon her own past, and what she would enter into in
14687: exchange for it; what it would be to disturb a long possession, and how
14688: difficult it was to fix a point at which the disturbance might begin, so
14689: as to be contemplated without pain.
14690: 
14691: Harold Transome's thoughts turned on the same subject, but accompanied
14692: by a different state of feeling and with more definite resolutions. He
14693: saw a mode of reconciling all difficulties, which looked pleasanter to
14694: him the longer he looked at Esther. When she had been hardly a week in
14695: the house, he had made up his mind to marry her; and it had never
14696: entered into that mind that the decision did not rest entirely with his
14697: inclination. It was not that he thought slightly of Esther's demands; he
14698: saw that she would require considerable attractions to please her, and
14699: that there were difficulties to be overcome. She was clearly a girl who
14700: must be wooed; but Harold did not despair of presenting the requisite
14701: attractions, and the difficulties gave more interest to the wooing than
14702: he could have believed. When he had said that he would not marry an
14703: Englishwoman, he had always made a mental reservation in favor of
14704: peculiar circumstances; and now the peculiar circumstances were come. To
14705: be deeply in love was a catastrophe not likely to happen to him; but he
14706: was readily amorous. No woman could make him miserable, but he was
14707: sensitive to the presence of women, and was kind to them; not with
14708: grimaces, like a man of mere gallantry, but beamingly, easily, like a
14709: man of genuine good-nature. And each day he was near Esther, the
14710: solution of all difficulties by marriage became a more pleasing
14711: prospect; though he had to confess to himself that the difficulties did
14712: not diminish on a nearer view, in spite of the flattering sense that
14713: she brightened at his approach.
14714: 
14715: Harold was not one to fail in a purpose for want of assiduity. After an
14716: hour or two devoted to business in the morning, he went to look for
14717: Esther, and if he did not find her at play with Harry and old Mr.
14718: Transome, or chatting with his mother, he went into the drawing-room,
14719: where she was usually either seated with a book on her knee and "making
14720: a bed for her cheek" with one little hand, while she looked out of the
14721: window, or else standing in front of one of the full-length family
14722: portraits with an air of rumination. Esther found it impossible to read
14723: in these days; her life was a book which she seemed herself to be
14724: constructing--trying to make character clear before her, and looking
14725: into the ways of destiny.
14726: 
14727: The active Harold had almost always something definite to propose by way
14728: of filling the time; if it were fine, she must walk out with him and see
14729: the grounds; and when the snow melted and it was no longer slippery, she
14730: must get on horseback and learn to ride. If they staid indoors, she must
14731: learn to play at billiards, or she must go over the house and see the
14732: pictures he had had hung anew, or the costumes he had brought from the
14733: East; or come into his study and look at the map of the estate, and hear
14734: what--if it had remained in his family--he had intended to do in every
14735: corner of it in order to make the most of its capabilities.
14736: 
14737: About a certain time in the morning Esther had learned to expect him.
14738: Let every wooer make himself strongly expected; he may succeed by dint
14739: of being absent, but hardly in the first instance. One morning Harold
14740: found her in the drawing-room, leaning against a console-table, and
14741: looking at the full-length portrait of a certain Lady Betty Transome,
14742: who had lived a century and a half before, and had the usual charm of
14743: ladies in Sir Peter Lely's style.
14744: 
14745: "Don't move, pray," he said on entering; "you look as if you were
14746: standing for your own portrait."
14747: 
14748: "I take that as an insinuation," said Esther, laughing, and moving
14749: toward her seat on an ottoman near the fire, "for I notice almost all
14750: the portraits are in a conscious, affected attitude. That fair Lady
14751: Betty looks as if she had been drilled into that posture, and had not
14752: will enough of her own ever to move again unless she had a little push
14753: given to her."
14754: 
14755: "She brightens up that panel well with her long satin skirt," said
14756: Harold, as he followed Esther, "but alive I dare say she would have been
14757: less cheerful company."
14758: 
14759: "One would certainly think that she had just been unpacked from silver
14760: paper. Ah, how chivalrous you are!" said Esther, as Harold, kneeling on
14761: one knee, held her silken netting-stirrup for her to put her foot
14762: through. She had often fancied pleasant scenes in which such homage was
14763: rendered to her, and the homage was not disagreeable now it was really
14764: come; but, strangely enough, a little darting sensation at that moment
14765: was accompanied by the vivid remembrance of some one who had never paid
14766: the least attention to her foot. There had been a slight blush, such as
14767: often came and went rapidly, and she was silent a moment. Harold
14768: naturally believed that it was he himself who was filling the field of
14769: vision. He would have liked to place himself on the ottoman near Esther,
14770: and behave very much more like a lover; but he took a chair opposite to
14771: her at a circumspect distance. He dared not do otherwise. Along with
14772: Esther's playful charm she conveyed an impression of personal pride and
14773: high spirit which warned Harold's acuteness that in the delicacy of
14774: their present position he might easily make a false move and offend her.
14775: A woman was likely to be credulous about adoration, and to find no
14776: difficulty in referring it to her intrinsic attractions; but Esther was
14777: too dangerously quick and critical not to discern the least awkwardness
14778: that looked like offering her marriage as a convenient compromise for
14779: himself. Beforehand, he might have said that such characteristics as
14780: hers were not loveable in a woman; but, as it was, he found that the
14781: hope of pleasing her had a piquancy quite new to him.
14782: 
14783: "I wonder," said Esther, breaking the silence in her usual light silvery
14784: tones--"I wonder whether the women who looked in that way ever felt any
14785: troubles. I see there are two old ones up-stairs in the billiard-room
14786: who have only got fat; the expression of their faces is just of the same
14787: sort."
14788: 
14789: "A woman ought never to have any trouble. There should always be a man
14790: to guard her from it. (Harold Transome was masculine and fallible; he
14791: had incautiously sat down this morning to pay his addresses by talk
14792: about nothing in particular; and, clever experienced man as he was, he
14793: fell into nonsense.)
14794: 
14795: "But suppose the man himself got into trouble--you would wish her to
14796: mind about that. Or suppose," added Esther, suddenly looking up merrily
14797: at Harold, "the man himself was troublesome?"
14798: 
14799: "Oh, you must not strain probabilities in that way. The generality of
14800: men are perfect. Take me, for example."
14801: 
14802: "You are a perfect judge of sauces," said Esther, who had her triumphs
14803: in letting Harold know that she was capable of taking notes.
14804: 
14805: "That is perfection number one. Pray go on."
14806: 
14807: "Oh, the catalogue is too long--I should be tired before I got to your
14808: magnificent ruby ring and your gloves always of the right color."
14809: 
14810: "If you would let me tell you your perfections, I should not be tired."
14811: 
14812: "That is not complimentary; it means that the list is short."
14813: 
14814: "No; it means that the list is pleasant to dwell upon."
14815: 
14816: "Pray don't begin," said Esther, with her pretty toss of the head; "it
14817: would be dangerous to our good understanding. The person I liked best in
14818: the world was one who did nothing but scold me and tell me of my
14819: faults."
14820: 
14821: When Esther began to speak, she meant to do no more than make a remote
14822: unintelligible allusion, feeling, it must be owned, a naughty will to
14823: flirt and be saucy, and thwart Harold's attempts to be felicitous in
14824: compliment. But she had no sooner uttered the words than they seemed to
14825: her like a confession. A deep flush spread itself over her face and
14826: neck, and the sense that she was blushing went on deepening her color.
14827: Harold felt himself unpleasantly illuminated as to a possibility that
14828: had never yet occurred to him. His surprise made an uncomfortable pause,
14829: in which Esther had time to feel much vexation.
14830: 
14831: "You speak in the past tense," said Harold, at last; "yet I am rather
14832: envious of that person. I shall never be able to win your regard in the
14833: same way. Is it anyone at Treby? Because in that case I can enquire
14834: about your faults."
14835: 
14836: "Oh, you know I have always lived among grave people," said Esther, more
14837: able to recover herself now she was spoken to. "Before I came home to be
14838: with my father I was nothing but a school-girl first, and then a teacher
14839: in different stages of growth. People in those circumstances are not
14840: usually flattered. But there are varieties in fault-finding. At our
14841: Paris school the master I liked best was an old man who stormed at me
14842: terribly when I read Racine, but yet showed that he was proud of me."
14843: 
14844: Esther was getting quite cool again. But Harold was not entirely
14845: satisfied; if there was any obstacle in his way, he wished to know
14846: exactly what it was.
14847: 
14848: "That must have been a wretched life for you at Treby," he said--"a
14849: person of your accomplishments."
14850: 
14851: "I used to be dreadfully discontented," said Esther, much occupied with
14852: mistakes she had made in her netting. "But I was becoming less so. I
14853: have had time to get rather wise, you know; I am two-and-twenty."
14854: 
14855: "Yes," said Harold, rising and walking a few paces backward and forward,
14856: "you are past your majority; you are empress of your own fortunes--and
14857: more besides."
14858: 
14859: "Dear me," said Esther, letting her work fall, and leaning back against
14860: the cushions; "I don't think I know very well what to do with my
14861: empire."
14862: 
14863: "Well," said Harold, pausing in front of her, leaning one arm on the
14864: mantelpiece, and speaking very gravely, "I hope that in any case, since
14865: you appear to have no near relative who understands affairs, you will
14866: confide in me, and trust me with all your intentions as if I had no
14867: other personal concern in the matter than a regard for you. I hope you
14868: believe me capable of acting as the guardian of your interest, even
14869: where it turns out to be inevitably opposed to my own."
14870: 
14871: "I am sure you have given me reason to believe it," said Esther, with
14872: seriousness, putting out her hand to Harold. She had not been left in
14873: ignorance that he had had opportunities twice offered of stifling her
14874: claims.
14875: 
14876: Harold raised the hand to his lips, but dared not retain it more than an
14877: instant. Still the sweet reliance in Esther's manner made an
14878: irresistible temptation to him. After standing still a moment or two,
14879: while she bent over her work, he glided to the ottoman and seated
14880: himself close by her, looking at her busy hands.
14881: 
14882: "I see you have made mistakes in your work," he said, bending still
14883: nearer, for he saw that she was conscious, yet not angry.
14884: 
14885: "Nonsense! you know nothing about it," said Esther, laughing, and
14886: crushing up the soft silk under her palms. "Those blunders have a design
14887: in them."
14888: 
14889: She looked round, and saw a handsome face very near her. Harold was
14890: looking, as he felt, thoroughly enamored of this bright woman, who was
14891: not at all to his preconceived taste. Perhaps a touch of hypothetic
14892: jealousy now helped to heighten the effect. But he mastered all
14893: indiscretion, and only looked at her as he said--
14894: 
14895: "I am wondering whether you have any deep wishes and secrets that I
14896: can't guess."
14897: 
14898: "Pray don't speak of my wishes," said Esther, quite overmastered by this
14899: new and apparently involuntary manifestation in Harold; "I could not
14900: possibly tell you one at this moment--I think I shall never find them
14901: out again. Oh, yes," she said, abruptly, struggling to relieve herself
14902: from the oppression of unintelligible feelings--"I do know one wish
14903: distinctly. I want to go and see my father. He writes me word that all
14904: is well with him, but still I want to see him."
14905: 
14906: "You shall be driven there when you like."
14907: 
14908: "May I go now--I mean as soon as it is convenient?" said Esther, rising.
14909: 
14910: "I will give the order immediately, if you wish it," said Harold,
14911: understanding that the audience was broken up.
14912: 
14913: 
14914: 
14915: 
14916: CHAPTER XLI.
14917: 
14918:     He rates me as the merchant does the wares
14919:     He will not purchase--"quality not high
14920:     'Twill lose its color opened to the sun,
14921:     Has no aroma, and, in fine, is naught--
14922:     I barter not for such commodities--
14923:     There is no ratio betwixt sands and gems."
14924:     'Tis wicked judgment! for the soul can grow,
14925:     As embryos, that live and move but blindly,
14926:     Burst from the dark, emerge, regenerate,
14927:     And lead a life of vision and of choice.
14928: 
14929: 
14930: Esther did not take the carriage into Malthouse Lane, but left it to
14931: wait for her outside the town; and when she entered the house she put
14932: her finger on her lip to Lyddy and ran lightly up-stairs. She wished to
14933: surprise her father by this visit, and she succeeded. The little
14934: minister was just then almost surrounded by a wall of books, with merely
14935: his head peeping above them, being much embarrassed to find a substitute
14936: for tables and desks on which to arrange the volumes he kept open for
14937: reference. He was absorbed in mastering all those painstaking
14938: interpretations of the Book of Daniel, which are by this time well gone
14939: to the limbo of mistaken criticism; and Esther, as she opened the door
14940: softly, heard him rehearsing aloud a passage in which he declared, with
14941: some parenthetic provisoes, that he conceived not how a perverse
14942: ingenuity could blunt the edge of prophetic explicitness, or how an open
14943: mind could fail to see in the chronology of "the little horn" the
14944: resplendent lamp of an inspired symbol searching out the germinal growth
14945: of an anti-Christian power.
14946: 
14947: "You will not like me to interrupt you, father?" said Esther, slyly.
14948: 
14949: "Ah, my beloved child!" he exclaimed, upsetting a pile of books, and
14950: thus unintentionally making a convenient breach in his wall, through
14951: which Esther could get up to him and kiss him. "Thy appearing is as a
14952: joy despaired of. I had thought of thee as the blinded think of the
14953: daylight--which indeed is a thing to rejoice in, like all other good,
14954: though we see it not nigh."
14955: 
14956: "Are you sure you have been as well and comfortable as you said you were
14957: in your letters?" said Esther, seating herself close in front of her
14958: father and laying her hand on his shoulder.
14959: 
14960: "I wrote truly, my dear, according to my knowledge at the time. But to
14961: an old memory like mine the present days are but as a little water
14962: poured on the deep. It seems now that all has been as usual, except my
14963: studies, which have gone somewhat curiously into prophetic history. But
14964: I fear you will rebuke me for my negligent apparel," said the little
14965: man, feeling in front of Esther's brightness like a bat overtaken by the
14966: morning.
14967: 
14968: "That is Lyddy's fault, who sits crying over her want of Christian
14969: assurance instead of brushing your clothes and putting out your clean
14970: cravat. She is always saying her righteousness is filthy rags, and
14971: really I don't think that is a very strong expression for it. I'm sure
14972: it is dusty clothes and furniture."
14973: 
14974: "Nay, my dear, your playfulness glances too severely on our faithful
14975: Lyddy. Doubtless I am myself deficient, in that I do not aid her infirm
14976: memory by admonition. But now tell me aught that you have left untold
14977: about yourself. Your heart has gone out somewhat toward this family--the
14978: old man and the child, whom I had not reckoned of?"
14979: 
14980: "Yes, father. It is more and more difficult to me to see how I can make
14981: up my mind to disturb these people at all."
14982: 
14983: "Something should doubtless be devised to lighten the loss and the
14984: change to the aged father and mother. I would have you in any case seek
14985: to temper a vicissitude, which is nevertheless a providential
14986: arrangement not to be wholly set aside."
14987: 
14988: "Do you think, father--do you feel assured that a case of inheritance
14989: like this of mine is a sort of providential arrangement that makes a
14990: command?"
14991: 
14992: "I have so held it," said Mr. Lyon, solemnly; "in all my meditations I
14993: have so held it. For you have to consider, my dear, that you have been
14994: led by a peculiar path, and into experience which is not ordinarily the
14995: lot of those who are seated in high places, and what I have hinted to
14996: you already in my letters on this head, I shall wish on a future
14997: opportunity to enter into more at large."
14998: 
14999: Esther was uneasily silent. On this great question of her lot she saw
15000: doubts and difficulties, in which it seemed as if her father could not
15001: help her. There was no illumination for her in this theory of
15002: providential arrangement. She said suddenly (what she had not thought of
15003: at all suddenly)--
15004: 
15005: "Have you been again to see Felix Holt, father? You have not mentioned
15006: him in your letters."
15007: 
15008: "I have been since I last wrote, my dear, and I took his mother with me,
15009: who, I fear, made the time heavy to him with her plaints. But afterward
15010: I carried her away to the house of a brother minister at Loamford, and
15011: returned to Felix, and then we had much discourse."
15012: 
15013: "Did you tell him of everything that has happened--I mean about
15014: me--about the Transomes?"
15015: 
15016: "Assuredly I told him, and he listened as one astonished. For he had
15017: much to hear, knowing naught of your birth, and that you had any other
15018: father than Rufus Lyon. 'Tis a narrative I trust I shall not be called
15019: on to give to others; but I was not without satisfaction in unfolding
15020: the truth to this young man, who hath wrought himself into my affection
15021: strangely--I would fain hope for ends that will be a visible good in his
15022: less way-worn life, when mine shall be no longer."
15023: 
15024: "And you told him how the Transomes had come, and that I was staying at
15025: Transome Court?"
15026: 
15027: "Yes, I told these things with some particularity, as is my wont
15028: concerning what hath imprinted itself on my mind."
15029: 
15030: "What did Felix say?"
15031: 
15032: "Truly, my dear, nothing desirable to recite," said Mr. Lyon, rubbing
15033: his hand over his brow.
15034: 
15035: "Dear father, he did say something, and you always remember what people
15036: say. Pray tell me; I want to know."
15037: 
15038: "It was a hasty remark, and rather escaped him than was consciously
15039: framed. He said, 'Then she will marry Transome; that is what Transome
15040: means.'"
15041: 
15042: "That was all?" said Esther, turning rather pale, and biting her lip
15043: with the determination that the tears should not start.
15044: 
15045: "Yes, we did not go further into that branch of the subject. I apprehend
15046: there is no warrant for his seeming prognostic, and I should not be
15047: without disquiet if I thought otherwise. For I confess that in your
15048: accession to this great position and property, I contemplate with
15049: hopeful satisfaction your remaining attached to that body of
15050: congregational Dissent, which, as I hold, hath retained most of pure and
15051: primitive discipline. Your education and peculiar history would thus be
15052: seen to have coincided with a long train of events in making this family
15053: property a means of honoring and illustrating a purer form of
15054: Christianity than that which hath unhappily obtained the pre-eminence in
15055: this land. I speak, my child, as you know, always in the hope that you
15056: will fully join our communion; and this dear wish of my heart--nay, this
15057: urgent prayer--would seem to be frustrated by your marriage with a man,
15058: of whom there is at least no visible indication that he would unite
15059: himself to our body."
15060: 
15061: If Esther had been less agitated, she would hardly have helped smiling
15062: at the picture her father's words suggested of Harold Transome "joining
15063: the church" in Malthouse Yard. But she was too seriously preoccupied
15064: with what Felix had said, which hurt her in a two-edged fashion that was
15065: highly significant. First, she was very angry with him for daring to say
15066: positively whom she would marry; and secondly, she was angry at the
15067: implication that there was from the first a cool deliberate design in
15068: Harold Transome to marry her. Esther said to herself that she was quite
15069: capable of discerning Harold Transome's disposition, and judging of his
15070: conduct. She felt sure he was generous and open. It did not lower him in
15071: her opinion that since circumstances had brought them together he
15072: evidently admired her--was in love with her--in short, desired to marry
15073: her; and she thought that she discerned the delicacy which hindered him
15074: from being more explicit. There is no point on which young women are
15075: more easily piqued than this of their sufficiency to judge the men who
15076: make love to them. And Esther's generous nature delighted to believe in
15077: generosity. All these thoughts were making a tumult in her mind while
15078: her father was suggesting the radiance her lot might cast on the cause
15079: of congregational Dissent. She heard what he said, and remembered it
15080: afterward, but she made no reply at present, and chose rather to start
15081: up in search of a brush--an action which would seem to her father quite
15082: a usual sequence with her. It served the purpose of diverting him from a
15083: lengthy subject.
15084: 
15085: "Have you yet spoken with Mr. Transome concerning Mrs. Holt, my dear?"
15086: he said, as Esther was moving about the room. "I hinted to him that you
15087: would best decide how assistance should be tendered to her."
15088: 
15089: "No, father, we have not approached the subject. Mr. Transome may have
15090: forgotten it, and, for several reasons, I would rather not talk of
15091: this--of money matters to him at present. There is money due to me from
15092: the Lukyns and the Pendrells."
15093: 
15094: "They have paid it," said Mr. Lyon, opening his desk. "I have it here
15095: ready to deliver to you."
15096: 
15097: "Keep it, father, and pay Mrs. Holt's rent with it, and do anything else
15098: that is wanted for her. We must consider everything temporary now," said
15099: Esther, enveloping her father in a towel, and beginning to brush his
15100: auburn fringe of hair, while he shut his eyes in preparation for this
15101: pleasant passivity. "Everything is uncertain--what may become of
15102: Felix--what may become of us all. Oh, dear!" she went on, changing
15103: suddenly to laughing merriment, "I am beginning to talk like Lyddy, I
15104: think."
15105: 
15106: "Truly," said Mr. Lyon, smiling, "the uncertainty of things is a text
15107: rather too wide and obvious for fruitful application; and to discourse
15108: of it is, as one may say, to bottle up the air, and make a present of it
15109: to those who are already standing out of doors."
15110: 
15111: "Do you think," said Esther, in the course of their chat, "that the
15112: Treby people know at all about the reasons of my being at Transome
15113: Court?"
15114: 
15115: "I have had no sign thereof: and indeed there is no one, as it appears,
15116: who could make the story public. The man Christian is away in London
15117: with Mr. Debarry, Parliament now beginning; and Mr. Jermyn would
15118: doubtless respect the confidence of the Transomes. I have not seen him
15119: lately. I know nothing of his movements. And so far as my own speech is
15120: concerned, and my strict command to Lyddy, I have withheld the means of
15121: information even as to your having returned to Transome Court in the
15122: carriage, not wishing to give any occasion to solicitous questioning
15123: till time hath somewhat inured me. But it hath got abroad that you are
15124: there, and is the subject of conjectures, whereof, I imagine, the chief
15125: is, that you are gone as companion to Mistress Transome; for some of our
15126: friends have already hinted a rebuke to me that I should permit your
15127: taking a position so little likely to further your spiritual welfare."
15128: 
15129: "Now, father, I think I shall be obliged to run away from you, not to
15130: keep the carriage too long," said Esther, as she finished her reforms on
15131: the minister's toilet. "You look beautiful now, and I must give Lyddy a
15132: little lecture before I go."
15133: 
15134: "Yes, my dear; I would not detain you, seeing that my duties demand me.
15135: But take with you this Treatise, which I have purposely selected. It
15136: concerns all the main questions between ourselves and the
15137: Establishment--government, discipline, state-support. It is seasonable
15138: that you should give a nearer attention to these polemics, lest you be
15139: drawn aside by the fallacious association of a State Church with
15140: elevated rank."
15141: 
15142: Esther chose to take the volume submissively, rather than to adopt the
15143: ungraceful sincerity of saying that she was unable at present to give
15144: her mind to the original functions of a bishop or the comparative merit
15145: of Endowments and Voluntaryism. But she did not run her eyes over the
15146: pages during her solitary drive to get a foretaste of the argument, for
15147: she was entirely occupied with Felix Holt's prophecy that she would
15148: marry Harold Transome.
15149: 
15150: 
15151: 
15152: 
15153: CHAPTER XLII.
15154: 
15155:     Thou sayst it, and not I; for thou hast done
15156:     The ugly deed that made these ugly words.
15157: 
15158:                                      --SOPHOCLES: _Electra_.
15159: 
15160:                        Yea, it becomes a man
15161:     To cherish memory, where he had delight.
15162:     For kindness is the natural birth of kindness.
15163:     Whose soul records not the great debt of joy,
15164:     Is stamped for ever an ignoble man.
15165: 
15166:                                         --SOPHOCLES: _Ajax_.
15167: 
15168: 
15169: It so happened that, on the morning of the day when Esther went to see
15170: her father, Jermyn had not yet heard of her presence at Transome Court.
15171: One fact conducing to keep him in this ignorance was, that some days
15172: after his critical interview with Harold--days during which he had been
15173: wondering how long it would be before Harold made up his mind to
15174: sacrifice the luxury of satisfied anger for the solid advantage of
15175: securing fortune and position--he was peremptorily called away by
15176: business to the south of England, and was obliged to inform Harold by
15177: letter of his absence. He took care also to notify his return; but
15178: Harold made no sign in reply. The days passed without bringing him any
15179: gossip concerning Esther's visit, for such gossip was almost confined to
15180: Mr. Lyon's congregation, her Church pupils, Miss Louisa Jermyn among
15181: them, having been satisfied by her father's written statement that she
15182: was gone on a visit of uncertain duration. But on this day of Esther's
15183: call in Malthouse Yard, the Miss Jermyns in their walk saw her getting
15184: into the Transomes' carriage, which they had previously observed to be
15185: waiting, and which they now saw bowled along on the road toward Little
15186: Treby. It followed that only a few hours later the news reached the
15187: astonished ears of Matthew Jermyn.
15188: 
15189: Entirely ignorant of those converging indications and small links of
15190: incident which had raised Christian's conjectures, and had gradually
15191: contributed to put him in possession of the facts; ignorant too of some
15192: busy motives in the mind of his obliged servant Johnson; Jermyn was not
15193: likely to see at once how the momentous information that Esther was the
15194: surviving Bycliffe could possibly have reached Harold. His daughters
15195: naturally leaped, as others had done, to the conclusion that the
15196: Transomes, seeking a governess for little Harry, had had their choice
15197: directed to Esther, and observed that they must have attracted her by a
15198: high salary to induce her to take charge of such a small pupil; though
15199: of course it was important that his English and French should be
15200: carefully attended to from the first. Jermyn, hearing this suggestion,
15201: was not without a momentary hope that it might be true, and that Harold
15202: was still safely unconscious of having under the same roof with him the
15203: legal claimant of the family estate.
15204: 
15205: But a mind in the grasp of a terrible anxiety is not credulous of easy
15206: solutions. The one stay that bears up our hopes is sure to appear frail,
15207: and if looked at long will seem to totter. Too much depended on that
15208: unconsciousness of Harold's; and although Jermyn did not see the course
15209: of things that could have disclosed and combined the various items of
15210: knowledge which he had imagined to be his own secret, and therefore his
15211: safeguard, he saw quite clearly what was likely to be the result of the
15212: disclosure. Not only would Harold Transome be no longer afraid of him,
15213: but also, by marrying Esther (and Jermyn at once felt sure of this
15214: issue), would be triumphantly freed from any unpleasant consequences,
15215: and could pursue much at his ease the gratification of ruining Matthew
15216: Jermyn. The prevision of an enemy's triumphant ease is in any case
15217: sufficiently irritating to hatred, and there were reasons why it was
15218: peculiarly exasperating here: but Jermyn had not the leisure now for
15219: mere fruitless emotion; he had to think of a possible device which might
15220: save him from imminent ruin--not an indefinite adversity, but a ruin in
15221: detail, which his thoughts painted out with the sharpest, ugliest
15222: intensity. A man of sixty, with an unsuspicious wife and daughters
15223: capable of shrieking and fainting at a sudden revelation, and of looking
15224: at him reproachfully in their daily misery under a shabby lot to which
15225: he had reduced them--with a mind and with habits dried hard by the
15226: years--with no glimpse of an endurable standing-ground except where he
15227: could domineer and be prosperous according to the ambitions of pushing
15228: middle-class gentility,--such a man is likely to find the prospect of
15229: worldly ruin ghastly enough to drive him to the most uninviting means of
15230: escape. He will probably prefer any private scorn that will save him
15231: from public infamy, or that will leave him with money in his pocket, to
15232: the humiliation and hardship of new servitude in old age, a shabby hat
15233: and a melancholy hearth, where the firing must be used charily and the
15234: women look sad. But though a man may be willing to escape through a
15235: sewer, a sewer with an outlet into the dry air is not always at hand.
15236: Running away, especially when spoken of as absconding, seems at a
15237: distance to offer a good modern substitute for the right of sanctuary;
15238: but seen closely, it is often found inconvenient and scarcely possible.
15239: 
15240: Jermyn, on thoroughly considering his position, saw that he had no very
15241: agreeable resources at command. But he soon made up his mind what he
15242: would do next. He wrote to Mrs. Transome requesting her to appoint an
15243: hour in which he could see her privately: he knew she would understand
15244: that it was to be an hour when Harold was not at home. As he sealed the
15245: letter, he indulged a faint hope that in this interview he might be
15246: assured of Esther's birth being unknown at Transome Court; but in the
15247: worst case, perhaps some help might be found in Mrs. Transome. To such
15248: uses may tender relations come when they have ceased to be tender! The
15249: Hazaels of our world who are pushed on quickly against their
15250: preconceived confidence in themselves to do doglike actions by the
15251: sudden suggestion of a wicked ambition, are much fewer than those who
15252: are led on through the years by the gradual demands of a selfishness
15253: which has spread its fibres far and wide through the intricate vanities
15254: and sordid cares of an everyday existence.
15255: 
15256: In consequence of that letter to Mrs. Transome, Jermyn was, two days
15257: afterward, ushered into the smaller drawing-room at Transome Court. It
15258: was a charming little room in its refurbished condition: it had two
15259: pretty inlaid cabinets, great china vases with contents that sent forth
15260: odors of paradise, groups of flowers in oval frames on the walls, and
15261: Mrs. Transome's own portrait in the evening costume of 1800, with a
15262: garden in the background. That brilliant young woman looked smilingly
15263: down on Mr. Jermyn as he passed in front of the fire; and at present
15264: hers was the only gaze in the room. He could not help meeting the gaze
15265: as he waited, holding his hat behind him--could not help seeing many
15266: memories lit up by it; but the strong bent of his mind was to go on
15267: arguing each memory into a claim, and to see in the regard others had
15268: for him a merit of his own. There had been plenty of roads open to him
15269: when he was a young man; perhaps if he had not allowed himself to be
15270: determined (chiefly, of course, by the feelings of others, for of what
15271: effect would his own feelings have been without them?) into the road he
15272: actually took, he might have done better for himself. At any rate, he
15273: was likely at last to get the worst of it, and it was he who had most
15274: reason to complain. The fortunate Jason, as we know from Euripides,
15275: piously thanked the goddess, and saw clearly that he was not at all
15276: obliged to Medea; Jermyn was, perhaps, not aware of the precedent, but
15277: thought out his own freedom from obligation and the indebtedness of
15278: others toward him with a native faculty not inferior to Jason's.
15279: 
15280: Before three minutes had passed, however, as if by some sorcery, the
15281: brilliant smiling young woman above the mantelpiece seemed to be
15282: appearing at the doorway withered and frosted by many winters, and with
15283: lips and eyes from which the smile had departed. Jermyn advanced, and
15284: they shook hands, but neither of them said anything by way of greeting.
15285: Mrs. Transome seated herself, and pointed to a chair opposite and near
15286: her.
15287: 
15288: "Harold has gone to Loamford," she said, in a subdued tone. "You had
15289: something particular to say to me?"
15290: 
15291: "Yes," said Jermyn, with his soft and deferential air. "The last time I
15292: was here I could not take the opportunity of speaking to you. But I am
15293: anxious to know whether you are aware of what has passed between me and
15294: Harold?"
15295: 
15296: "Yes, he has told me everything."
15297: 
15298: "About his proceedings against me? and the reason he stopped them?"
15299: 
15300: "Yes: have you had notice that he has begun them again?"
15301: 
15302: "No," said Jermyn, with a very unpleasant sensation.
15303: 
15304: "Of course he will now," said Mrs. Transome. "There is no reason in his
15305: mind why he should not."
15306: 
15307: "Has he resolved to risk the estate then?"
15308: 
15309: "He feels in no danger on that score. And if there were, the danger
15310: doesn't depend on you. The most likely thing is, that he will marry this
15311: girl."
15312: 
15313: "He knows everything then?" said Jermyn, the expression of his face
15314: getting clouded.
15315: 
15316: "Everything. It's of no use for you to think of mastering him: you can't
15317: do it. I used to wish Harold to be fortunate, and he is fortunate," said
15318: Mrs. Transome, with intense bitterness. "It's not my star that he
15319: inherits."
15320: 
15321: "Do you know how he came by the information about this girl?"
15322: 
15323: "No; but she knew it all before we spoke to her. It's no secret."
15324: 
15325: Jermyn was confounded by this hopeless frustration to which he had no
15326: key. Though he thought of Christian, the thought shed no light; but the
15327: more fatal point was clear: he held no secret that could help him.
15328: 
15329: "You are aware that these chancery proceedings may ruin me?"
15330: 
15331: "He told me they would. But if you are imagining I can do anything, pray
15332: dismiss the notion. I have told him as plainly as I dare that I wish him
15333: to drop all public quarrel with you, and that you could make an
15334: arrangement without scandal. I can do no more. He will not listen to me;
15335: he doesn't mind about my feelings. He cares more for Mr. Transome than
15336: he does for me. He will not listen to me any more than if I were an old
15337: ballad-singer."
15338: 
15339: "It's very hard on me, I know," said Jermyn, in the tone with which a
15340: man flings out a reproach.
15341: 
15342: "I besought you three months ago to bear anything rather than quarrel
15343: with him."
15344: 
15345: "I have not quarrelled with him. It is he who has been always seeking a
15346: quarrel with me. I have borne a great deal--more than any one else
15347: would. He set his teeth against me from the first."
15348: 
15349: "He saw things that annoyed him; and men are not like women," said Mrs.
15350: Transome. There was bitter innuendo in that truism.
15351: 
15352: "It's very hard on me--I know that," said Jermyn, with an
15353: intensification of his previous tone, rising and walking a step or two,
15354: then turning and laying his hand on the back of the chair. "Of course
15355: the law in this case can't in the least represent the justice of the
15356: matter. I made a good many sacrifices in times past. I gave up a great
15357: deal of fine business for the sake of attending to the family affairs,
15358: and in that lawsuit they would have gone to rack and ruin if it hadn't
15359: been for me."
15360: 
15361: He moved away again, laid down his hat, which he had been previously
15362: holding, and thrust his hands into his pockets as he returned. Mrs.
15363: Transome sat motionless as marble, and almost as pale. Her hands lay
15364: crossed on her knees. This man, young, slim, and graceful, with a
15365: selfishness which then took the form of homage to her, had at one time
15366: kneeled to her and kissed those hands fervently, and she had thought
15367: there was a poetry in such passion beyond any to be found in everyday
15368: domesticity.
15369: 
15370: "I stretched my conscience a good deal in that affair of Bycliffe, as
15371: you know perfectly well. I told you everything at the time. I told you I
15372: was very uneasy about those witnesses, and about getting him thrown into
15373: prison. I know it's the blackest thing anybody could charge me with, if
15374: they knew my life from beginning to end; and I should never have done
15375: it, if I had not been under an infatuation such as makes a man do
15376: anything. What did it signify to me about the loss of the lawsuit? I was
15377: a young bachelor--I had the world before me."
15378: 
15379: "Yes," said Mrs. Transome, in a low tone. "It was a pity you didn't make
15380: another choice."
15381: 
15382: "What would have become of you?" said Jermyn, carried along a climax,
15383: like other self-justifiers. "I had to think of you. You would not have
15384: liked me to make another choice then."
15385: 
15386: "Clearly," said Mrs. Transome, with concentrated bitterness, but still
15387: quietly; "the greater mistake was mine."
15388: 
15389: Egoism is usually stupid in a dialogue; but Jermyn's did not make him so
15390: stupid that he did not feel the edge of Mrs. Transome's words. They
15391: increased his irritation.
15392: 
15393: "I hardly see that," he replied, with a slight laugh of scorn. "You had
15394: an estate and a position to save, to go no farther. I remember very well
15395: what you said to me--'A clever lawyer can do anything if he has the
15396: will; if it's impossible, he will make it possible. And the property is
15397: sure to be Harold's some day.' He was a baby then."
15398: 
15399: "I remember most things a little too well; you had better say at once
15400: what is your object in recalling them."
15401: 
15402: "An object that is nothing more than justice. With the relation I stood
15403: in, it was not likely I should think myself bound by all the forms that
15404: are made to bind strangers. I had often immense trouble to raise the
15405: money necessary to pay off debts and carry on the affairs; and, as I
15406: said before, I had given up other lines of advancement which would have
15407: been open to me if I had not stayed in this neighborhood at a critical
15408: time when I was fresh to the world. Anybody who knew the whole
15409: circumstances would say that my being hunted and run down on the score
15410: of my past transactions with regard to the family affairs, is an
15411: abominably unjust and unnatural thing."
15412: 
15413: Jermyn paused a moment, and then added, "At my time of life----and with
15414: a family about me----and after what has passed----I should have thought
15415: there was nothing you would care more to prevent."
15416: 
15417: "I do care. It makes me miserable. That is the extent of my power--to
15418: feel miserable."
15419: 
15420: "No, it is not the extent of your power. You could save me if you would.
15421: It is not to be supposed that Harold would go on against me--if he knew
15422: the whole truth."
15423: 
15424: Jermyn had sat down before he uttered the last words. He had lowered his
15425: voice slightly. He had the air of one who thought that he had prepared
15426: the way for an understanding. That a man with so much sharpness, with so
15427: much suavity at command--a man who piqued himself on his persuasiveness
15428: toward women--should behave just as Jermyn did on this occasion, would
15429: be surprising but for the constant experience that temper and selfish
15430: insensibility will defeat excellent gifts--will make a sensible person
15431: shout when shouting is out of place, and will make a polished man rude
15432: when his polish might be of eminent use to him.
15433: 
15434: As Jermyn, sitting down and leaning forward with an elbow on his knee,
15435: uttered his last words--"if he knew the whole truth"--a slight shock
15436: seemed to pass through Mrs. Transome's hitherto motionless body,
15437: followed by a sudden light in her eyes, as in an animal's about to
15438: spring.
15439: 
15440: "And you expect me to tell him?" she said, not loudly, but yet with a
15441: clear metallic ring in her voice.
15442: 
15443: "Would it not be right for him to know?" said Jermyn, in a more bland
15444: and persuasive tone than he had yet used.
15445: 
15446: Perhaps some of the most terrible irony of the human lot is this of a
15447: deep truth coming to be uttered by lips that have no right to it.
15448: 
15449: "I will never tell him!" said Mrs. Transome, starting up, her whole
15450: frame thrilled with a passion that seemed almost to make her young
15451: again. Her hands hung beside her clenched tightly, her eyes and lips
15452: lost the helpless repressed bitterness of discontent, and seemed
15453: suddenly fed with energy. "You reckon up your sacrifices for me: you
15454: have kept a good account of them, and it is needful: they are some of
15455: them what no one else could guess or find out. But you made your
15456: sacrifices when they seemed pleasant to you; when you told me they were
15457: your happiness; when you told me that it was I who stooped, and I who
15458: bestowed favors."
15459: 
15460: Jermyn rose too, and laid his hand on the back of the chair. He had
15461: grown visibly paler, but seemed about to speak.
15462: 
15463: "Don't speak!" Mrs. Transome said peremptorily. "Don't open your lips
15464: again. You have said enough; I will speak now. I have made sacrifices
15465: too, but it was when I knew that they were not my happiness. It was
15466: after I saw that I had stooped--after I saw that your tenderness had
15467: turned into calculation--after I saw that you cared for yourself only,
15468: and not for me. I heard your explanations--of your duty in life--of our
15469: mutual reputation--of a virtuous young lady attached to you. I bore it;
15470: I let everything go; I shut my eyes: I might almost have let myself
15471: starve, rather than have scenes of quarrel with the man I had loved, in
15472: which I must accuse him of turning my love into a good bargain." There
15473: was a slight tremor in Mrs. Transome's voice in the last words, and for
15474: a moment she paused: but when she spoke again it seemed as if the tremor
15475: had frozen into a cutting icicle. "I suppose if a lover picked one's
15476: pocket, there's no woman would like to own it. I don't say I was not
15477: afraid of you: I was afraid of you, and I know now I was right."
15478: 
15479: "Mrs. Transome," said Jermyn, white to the lips, "it is needless to say
15480: more. I withdraw any words that have offended you."
15481: 
15482: "You can't withdraw them. Can a man apologize for being a dastard?--And
15483: I have caused you to strain your conscience, have I?--it is I who have
15484: sullied your purity? I should think the demons have more honor--they are
15485: not so impudent to one another. I would not lose the misery of being a
15486: woman, now I see what can be the baseness of a man. One must be a
15487: man--first to tell a woman that her love has made her your debtor, and
15488: then ask her to pay you by breaking the last poor threads between her
15489: and her son."
15490: 
15491: "I do not ask it," said Jermyn, with a certain asperity. He was
15492: beginning to find this intolerable. The mere brute strength of a
15493: masculine creature rebelled. He felt almost inclined to throttle the
15494: voice out of this woman.
15495: 
15496: "You do ask it: it is what you would like. I have had a terror on me
15497: lest evil should happen to you. From the first, after Harold came home,
15498: I had a terrible dread. It seemed as if murder might come between you--I
15499: didn't know what. I felt the horror of his not knowing the truth. I
15500: might have been dragged at last, by my own feeling--by my own memory--to
15501: tell him all, and make him as well as myself miserable, to save you."
15502: 
15503: Again there was a slight tremor, as if at the remembrance of womanly
15504: tenderness and pity. But immediately she launched forth again.
15505: 
15506: "But now you have asked me, I will never tell him! Be ruined--no--do
15507: something more dastardly to save yourself. If I sinned, my judgment went
15508: beforehand--that I should sin for a man like you."
15509: 
15510: Swiftly upon those last words Mrs. Transome passed out of the room. The
15511: softly padded door closed behind her making no noise, and Jermyn found
15512: himself alone.
15513: 
15514: For a brief space he stood still. Human beings in moments of passionate
15515: reproach and denunciation, especially when their anger is on their own
15516: account, are never so wholly in the right that the person who has to
15517: wince cannot possibly protest against some unreasonableness or
15518: unfairness in their outburst. And if Jermyn had been capable of feeling
15519: that he had thoroughly merited this infliction, he would not have
15520: uttered the words that drew it down on him. Men do not become penitent
15521: and learn to abhor themselves by having their backs cut open with the
15522: lash; rather, they learn to abhor the lash. What Jermyn felt about Mrs.
15523: Transome when she disappeared was, that she was a furious woman--who
15524: would not do what he wanted her to do. And he was supported as to his
15525: justifiableness by the inward repetition of what he had already said to
15526: her; it was right that Harold should know the truth. He did not take
15527: into account (how should he?) the exasperation and loathing excited by
15528: his daring to urge the plea of right. A man who had stolen the pyx, and
15529: got frightened when justice was at his heels, might feel the sort of
15530: penitence which would induce him to run back in the dark and lay the pyx
15531: where the sexton might find it; but if in doing so he whispered to the
15532: Blessed Virgin that he was moved by considering the sacredness of all
15533: property, and the peculiar sacredness of the pyx, it is not to be
15534: believed that she would like him the better for it. Indeed, one often
15535: seems to see why the saints should prefer candles to words, especially
15536: from penitents whose skin is in danger. Some salt of generosity would
15537: have made Jermyn conscious that he had lost the citizenship which
15538: authorized him to plead the right; still more, that his self-vindication
15539: to Mrs. Transome would be like the exhibition of a brand-mark, and only
15540: show that he was shame-proof. There is heroism even in the circles of
15541: hell for fellow-sinners who cling to each other in the fiery whirlwind
15542: and never recriminate. But these things, which are easy to discern when
15543: they are painted for us on the large canvas of poetic story, become
15544: confused and obscure even for well-read gentlemen when their affection
15545: for themselves is alarmed by pressing details of actual experience. If
15546: their comparison of instances is active at such times, it is chiefly in
15547: showing them that their own case has subtle distinctions from all other
15548: cases, which should free them from unmitigated condemnation.
15549: 
15550: And it was in this way with Matthew Jermyn. So many things were more
15551: distinctly visible to him, and touched him more acutely, than the effect
15552: of his acts or words on Mrs. Transome's feelings! In fact--he asked,
15553: with a touch of something that makes us all akin--was it not
15554: preposterous, this excess of feeling on points which he himself did not
15555: find powerfully moving? She had treated him most unreasonably. It would
15556: have been right for her to do what he had--not asked, but only hinted at
15557: in a mild and interrogatory manner. But the clearest and most unpleasant
15558: result of the interview was, that this right thing which he desired so
15559: much would certainly not be done for him by Mrs. Transome.
15560: 
15561: As he was moving his arm from the chair-back, and turning to take his
15562: hat, there was a boisterous noise in the entrance-hall; the door of the
15563: drawing-room, which had closed without latching, was pushed open, and
15564: old Mr. Transome appeared with a face of feeble delight, playing horse
15565: to little Harry, who roared and flogged behind him, while Moro yapped in
15566: a puppy voice at their heels. But when Mr. Transome saw Jermyn in the
15567: room he stood still in the doorway, as if he did not know whether
15568: entrance was permissible. The majority of his thoughts were but ravelled
15569: threads of the past. The attorney came forward to shake hands with due
15570: politeness, but the old man said, with a bewildered look, and in a
15571: hesitating way--
15572: 
15573: "Mr. Jermyn?--why--why--where is Mrs. Transome?"
15574: 
15575: Jermyn smiled his way out past the unexpected group; and little Harry,
15576: thinking he had an eligible opportunity, turned round to give a parting
15577: stroke on the stranger's coat-tails.
15578: 
15579: 
15580: 
15581: 
15582: CHAPTER XLIII.
15583: 
15584:     Whichever way my days decline,
15585:       I felt and feel, though left alone,
15586:       His being working in mine own,
15587:     The footsteps of his life in mine.
15588: 
15589:            *       *       *       *       *
15590: 
15591:     Dear friend, far off, my lost desire
15592:       So far, so near, in woe and weal;
15593:       Oh, loved the most when most I feel
15594:     There is a lower and a higher!
15595: 
15596:                                   --TENNYSON: _In Memoriam_.
15597: 
15598: 
15599: After that morning on which Esther found herself reddened and confused
15600: by the sense of having made a distant allusion to Felix Holt, she felt
15601: it impossible that she should even, as she had sometimes intended, speak
15602: of him explicitly to Harold, in order to discuss probabilities as to the
15603: issue of his trial. She was certain she could not do it without
15604: betraying emotion, and there were very complex reasons in Esther's mind
15605: why she could not bear that Harold should detect her sensibility on this
15606: subject. It was not only all the fibres of maidenly pride and reserve,
15607: of a bashfulness undefinably peculiar toward this man, who, while much
15608: older than herself, and bearing the stamp of an experience quite hidden
15609: from her imagination, was taking strongly the aspect of a lover--it was
15610: not only this exquisite kind of shame which was at work within her:
15611: there was another sort of susceptibility in Esther, which her present
15612: circumstances tended to encourage, though she had come to regard it as
15613: not at all lofty, but rather as something which condemned her to
