15614: littleness in comparison with a mind she had learned to venerate. She
15615: knew quite well that, to Harold Transome, Felix Holt was one of the
15616: common people who could come into question in no other than a public
15617: light. She had a native capability for discerning that the sense of
15618: ranks and degrees has its repulsions corresponding to the repulsions
15619: dependent on difference of race and color; and she remembered her own
15620: impressions too well not to foresee that it would come on Harold
15621: Transome as a shock, if he suspected there had been any love-passages
15622: between her and this young man, who to him was of course no more than
15623: any other intelligent member of the working class. "To him," said Esther
15624: to herself, with a reaction of her newer, better pride, "who has not had
15625: the sort of intercourse in which Felix Holt's cultured nature would have
15626: asserted its superiority." And in her fluctuations on this matter, she
15627: found herself mentally protesting that, whatever Harold might think,
15628: there was a light in which he was vulgar compared with Felix. Felix had
15629: ideas and motives which she did not believe Harold could understand.
15630: More than all, there was this test: she herself had no sense of
15631: inferiority and just subjection when she was with Harold Transome; there
15632: were even points in him for which she felt a touch, not of anger, but of
15633: playful scorn; whereas with Felix she had always a sense of dependence
15634: and possible illumination. In those large, grave, candid gray eyes of
15635: his, love seemed something that belonged to the high enthusiasm of life,
15636: such as now might be forever shut out from her.
15637: 
15638: All the same, her vanity winced at the idea that Harold should discern
15639: what, from his point of view, would seem like a degradation of her taste
15640: and refinement. She could not help being gratified by all the
15641: manifestations from those around her that she was thought thoroughly
15642: fitted for a high position--could not help enjoying, with more or less
15643: keenness, a rehearsal of that demeanor amongst luxuries and dignities
15644: which had often been a part of her day-dreams, and the rehearsal
15645: included the reception of more and more emphatic attentions from Harold,
15646: and of an effusiveness in his manners, which, in proportion as it would
15647: have been offensive if it had appeared earlier, became flattering as the
15648: effect of a growing acquaintance and daily contact. It comes in so many
15649: forms in this life of ours--the knowledge that there is something
15650: sweetest and noblest of which we despair, and the sense of something
15651: present that solicits us with an immediate and easy indulgence. And
15652: there is a pernicious falsity in the pretence that a woman's love lies
15653: above the range of such temptations.
15654: 
15655: Day after day Esther had an arm offered her, had very beaming looks upon
15656: her, had opportunities for a great deal of light, airy talk, in which
15657: she knew herself to be charming, and had the attractive interest of
15658: noticing Harold's practical cleverness--the masculine ease with which he
15659: governed everybody and administered everything about him, without the
15660: least harshness, and with a facile good-nature which yet was not weak.
15661: In the background, too, there was the ever-present consideration, that
15662: if Harold Transome wished to marry her, and she accepted him, the
15663: problem of her lot would be more easily solved than in any other way. It
15664: was difficult, by any theory of Providence, or consideration of results,
15665: to see a course which she could call duty: if something would come and
15666: urge itself strongly as pleasure, and save her from the effort to find a
15667: clue of principle amid the labyrinthine confusions of right and
15668: possession, the promise could not but seem alluring. And yet, this life
15669: at Transome Court was _not_ the life of her day-dreams: there was
15670: dullness already in its ease, and in the absence of high demand; and
15671: there was a vague consciousness that the love of this not unfascinating
15672: man who hovered about her gave an air of moral mediocrity to all her
15673: prospects. She would not have been able perhaps to define this
15674: impression; but somehow or other by this elevation of fortune it seemed
15675: that the higher ambition which had begun to spring in her was forever
15676: nullified. All life seemed cheapened; as it might seem to a young
15677: student who, having believed that to gain a certain degree he must write
15678: a thesis in which he would bring his powers to bear with memorable
15679: effect, suddenly ascertained that no thesis was expected, but the sum
15680: (in English money) of twenty-seven pounds ten shillings and sixpence.
15681: 
15682: After all, she was a woman, and could not make her own lot. As she had
15683: once said to Felix, "A woman must choose meaner things, because only
15684: meaner things are offered to her." Her lot is made for her by the love
15685: she accepts. And Esther began to think that her lot was being made for
15686: her by the love that was surrounding her with the influence of a garden
15687: on a summer morning.
15688: 
15689: Harold, on his side, was conscious that the interest of his wooing was
15690: not standing still. He was beginning to think it a conquest, in which it
15691: would be disappointing to fail, even if this fair nymph had no claim to
15692: the estate. He would have liked--and yet he would not have liked--that
15693: just a slight shadow of doubt as to his success should be removed. There
15694: was something about Esther that he did not altogether understand. She
15695: was clearly a woman that could be governed: she was too charming for him
15696: to fear that she would ever be obstinate or interfering. Yet there was a
15697: lightning that shot out of her now and then, which seemed the sign of a
15698: dangerous judgment; as if she inwardly saw something more admirable than
15699: Harold Transome. Now, to be perfectly charming, a woman should not see
15700: this.
15701: 
15702: One fine February day, when already the golden and purple crocuses were
15703: out on the terrace--one of those flattering days which sometimes precede
15704: the north-east winds of March, and make believe that the coming spring
15705: will be enjoyable--a very striking group, of whom Esther and Harold made
15706: a part, came out at midday to walk upon the gravel at Transome Court.
15707: They did not, as usual, go toward the pleasure grounds on the eastern
15708: side, because Mr. Lingon, who was one of them, was going home, and his
15709: road lay through the stone gateway into the park.
15710: 
15711: Uncle Lingon, who disliked painful confidences, and preferred knowing
15712: "no mischief of anybody," had not objected to be let into the important
15713: secret about Esther, and was sure at once that the whole affair, instead
15714: of being a misfortune, was a piece of excellent luck. For himself, he
15715: did not profess to be a judge of women, but she seemed to have all the
15716: "points," and to carry herself as well as Arabella did, which was saying
15717: a good deal. Honest Jack Lingon's first impressions quickly became
15718: traditions, which no subsequent evidence could disturb. He was fond of
15719: his sister, and seemed never to be conscious of any change for the worse
15720: in her since their early time. He considered that man a beast who said
15721: anything unpleasant about the persons to whom he was attached. It was
15722: not that he winked; his wide-open eyes saw nothing but what his easy
15723: disposition inclined him to see. Harold was a good fellow, a clever
15724: chap; and Esther's peculiar fitness for him, under all the
15725: circumstances, was extraordinary; it reminded him of something in the
15726: classics, though he couldn't think exactly what--in fact, a memory was a
15727: nasty uneasy thing. Esther was always glad when the old rector came.
15728: With an odd contrariety to her former niceties she liked his rough
15729: attire and careless frank speech; they were something not point device
15730: that seemed to connect the life of Transome Court with that rougher,
15731: commoner world where her home had been.
15732: 
15733: She and Harold were walking a little in advance of the rest of the
15734: party, who were retarded by various causes. Old Mr. Transome, wrapped in
15735: a cloth cloak trimmed with sable, and with a soft warm cap also trimmed
15736: with fur on his head, had a shuffling uncertain walk. Little Harry was
15737: dragging a toy vehicle, on the seat of which he had insisted on tying
15738: Moro with a piece of scarlet drapery round him, making him look like a
15739: barbaric prince in a chariot. Moro, having little imagination, objected
15740: to this, and barked with feeble snappishness as the tyrannous lad ran
15741: forward, then whirled the chariot round, and ran back to "Gappa," then
15742: came to a dead stop, which overset the chariot, that he might watch
15743: Uncle Lingon's water-spaniel run for the hurled stick and bring it in
15744: his mouth. Nimrod kept close to his old master's legs, glancing with
15745: much indifference at this youthful ardor about sticks--he had "gone
15746: through all that"; and Dominic walked by, looking on blandly, and
15747: taking care both of young and old. Mrs. Transome was not there.
15748: 
15749: [Illustration: ESTHER LYON AND HAROLD TRANSOME.]
15750: 
15751: Looking back and seeing that they were a good deal in advance of the
15752: rest, Esther and Harold paused.
15753: 
15754: "What do you think about thinning the trees over there?" said Harold,
15755: pointing with his stick. "I have a bit of a notion that if they were
15756: divided into clumps so as to show the oaks beyond it would be a great
15757: improvement. It would give an idea of extent that is lost now. And there
15758: might be some very pretty clumps got out of those mixed trees. What do
15759: you think?"
15760: 
15761: "I should think it would be an improvement. One likes a 'beyond'
15762: everywhere. But I never heard you express yourself so dubiously," said
15763: Esther, looking at him rather archly: "you generally see things so
15764: clearly, and are so convinced, that I shall begin to feel quite
15765: tottering if I find you in uncertainty. Pray don't begin to be doubtful;
15766: it is infectious."
15767: 
15768: "You think me a great deal too sure--too confident?" said Harold.
15769: 
15770: "Not at all. It is an immense advantage to know your own will, when you
15771: always mean to have it."
15772: 
15773: "But suppose I couldn't get it, in spite of meaning?" said Harold, with
15774: a beaming inquiry in his eyes.
15775: 
15776: "Oh, then," said Esther, turning her head aside, carelessly, as if she
15777: were considering the distant birch-stems, "you would bear it quite
15778: easily, as you did your not getting into Parliament. You would know you
15779: could get it another time--or get something else as good."
15780: 
15781: "The fact is," said Harold, moving on a little, as if he did not want to
15782: be quite overtaken by the others, "you consider me a fat, fatuous,
15783: self-satisfied fellow."
15784: 
15785: "Oh, there are degrees," said Esther, with a silvery laugh; "you have
15786: just as much of those qualities as is becoming. There are different
15787: styles. You are perfect in your own."
15788: 
15789: "But you prefer another style, I suspect. A more submissive, tearful,
15790: devout worshipper, who would offer his incense with more trembling."
15791: 
15792: "You are quite mistaken," said Esther, still lightly. "I find I am very
15793: wayward. When anything is offered to me, it seems that I prize it less,
15794: and don't want to have it."
15795: 
15796: Here was a very baulking answer, but in spite of it Harold could not
15797: help believing that Esther was very far from objecting to the sort of
15798: incense he had been offering just then.
15799: 
15800: "I have often read that that is in human nature," she went on, "yet it
15801: takes me by surprise in myself. I suppose," she added, smiling, "I
15802: didn't think of myself as human nature."
15803: 
15804: "I don't confess to the same waywardness," said Harold. "I am very fond
15805: of things that I can get. And I never longed much for anything out of my
15806: reach. Whatever I feel sure of getting I like all the better. I think
15807: half those priggish maxims about human nature in the lump are no more to
15808: be relied on than universal remedies. There are different sorts of human
15809: nature. Some are given to discontent and longing, others to securing and
15810: enjoying. And let me tell you, the discontented longing style is
15811: unpleasant to live with."
15812: 
15813: Harold nodded with a meaning smile at Esther.
15814: 
15815: "Oh, I assure you I have abjured all admiration for it," she said,
15816: smiling up at him in return.
15817: 
15818: She was remembering the schooling Felix had given her about her Byronic
15819: heroes, and was inwardly adding a third sort of human nature to those
15820: varieties which Harold had mentioned. He naturally supposed that he
15821: might take the abjuration to be entirely in his own favor. And his face
15822: did look very pleasant; she could not help liking him, although he was
15823: certainly too particular about sauces, gravies, and wines, and had a way
15824: of virtually measuring the value of everything by the contribution it
15825: made to his own pleasure. His very good-nature was unsympathetic; it
15826: never came from any thorough understanding or deep respect for what was
15827: in the mind of the person he obliged or indulged; it was like his
15828: kindness to his mother--an arrangement of his for the happiness of
15829: others, which, if they were sensible, ought to succeed. And an
15830: inevitable comparison which haunted her, showed her the same quality in
15831: his political views: the utmost enjoyment of his own advantages was the
15832: solvent that blended pride in his family and position, with the adhesion
15833: to changes that were to obliterate tradition and melt down enchased gold
15834: heirlooms into plating for the egg-spoons of "the people." It is
15835: terrible--the keen bright eye of a woman when it has once been turned
15836: with admiration on what is severely true; but then, the severely true
15837: rarely comes within its range of vision. Esther had had an unusual
15838: illumination; Harold did not know how, but he discerned enough of the
15839: effect to make him more cautious than he had ever been in his life
15840: before. That caution would have prevented him just then from following
15841: up the question as to the style of person Esther would think pleasant to
15842: live with, even if Uncle Lingon had not joined them, as he did, to talk
15843: about soughing tiles, saying presently that he should turn across the
15844: grass and get on to the Home Farm, to have a look at the improvements
15845: that Harold was making with such racing speed.
15846: 
15847: "But you know, lad," said the rector, as they paused at the expected
15848: parting, "you can't do everything in a hurry. The wheat must have time
15849: to grow, even when you've reformed all us old Tories off the face of the
15850: ground. Dash it! now the election's over, I'm an old Tory again. You
15851: see, Harold, a Radical won't do for the county. At another election, you
15852: must be on the look-out for a borough where they want a bit of blood. I
15853: should have liked you uncommonly to stand for the county; and a Radical
15854: of good family squares well enough with a new-fashioned Tory like young
15855: Debarry; but you see, these riots--it's been a nasty business. I shall
15856: have my hair combed at the sessions for a year to come. But, heyday!
15857: What dame is this, with a small boy?--not one of my parishioners?"
15858: 
15859: Harold and Esther turned, and saw an elderly woman advancing with a tiny
15860: red-haired boy, scantily attired as to his jacket, which merged into a
15861: small sparrow-tail a little higher than his waist, but muffled as to his
15862: throat with a blue woollen comforter. Esther recognized the pair too
15863: well, and felt very uncomfortable. We are so pitiably in subjection to
15864: all sorts of vanity--even the very vanities we are practically
15865: renouncing! And in spite of the almost solemn memories connected with
15866: Mrs. Holt, Esther's first shudder was raised by the idea of what things
15867: this woman would say, and by the mortification of having Felix in any
15868: way represented by his mother.
15869: 
15870: As Mrs. Holt advanced into closer observation, it became more evident
15871: that she was attired with a view not to charm the eye, but rather to
15872: afflict it with all that expression of woe which belongs to very rusty
15873: bombazine and the limpest state of false hair. Still, she was not a
15874: woman to lose the sense of her own value, or become abject in her
15875: manners under any circumstances of depression; and she had a peculiar
15876: sense on the present occasion that she was justly relying on the force
15877: of her own character and judgment, in independence of anything that Mr.
15878: Lyon or the masterful Felix would have said, if she had thought them
15879: worthy to know of her undertaking. She courtesied once, as if to the
15880: entire group, now including even the dogs, who showed various degrees of
15881: curiosity, especially as to what kind of game the smaller animal Job
15882: might prove to be after due investigation; and then she proceeded at
15883: once toward Esther, who, in spite of her annoyance, took her arm from
15884: Harold's, said, "How do you do, Mrs. Holt?" very kindly, and stooped to
15885: pat little Job.
15886: 
15887: "Yes--you know him, Miss Lyon," said Mrs. Holt, in that tone which
15888: implies that the conversation is intended for the edification of the
15889: company generally; "you know the orphin child, as Felix brought home for
15890: me that am his mother to take care of. And it's what I've done--nobody
15891: more so--though it's trouble is my reward."
15892: 
15893: Esther had raised herself again, to stand in helpless endurance of
15894: whatever might be coming. But by this time young Harry, struck even more
15895: than the dogs by the appearance of Job Tudge, had come round dragging
15896: his chariot, and placed himself close to the pale child, whom he
15897: exceeded in height and breadth, as well as in depth of coloring. He
15898: looked into Job's eyes, peeped round at the tail of his jacket and
15899: pulled it a little, and then, taking off the tiny cloth-cap, observed
15900: with much interest the tight red curls which had been hidden underneath
15901: it. Job looked at his inspector with the round blue eyes of
15902: astonishment, until Harry, purely by way of experiment, took a bon-bon
15903: from a fantastic wallet which hung over his shoulder, and applied the
15904: test to Job's lips. The result was satisfactory to both. Every one had
15905: been watching this small comedy, and when Job crunched the bon-bon while
15906: Harry looked down at him inquiringly and patted his back, there was
15907: general laughter except on the part of Mrs. Holt, who was shaking her
15908: head slowly, and slapping the back of her left hand with the painful
15909: patience of a tragedian whose part is in abeyance to an ill-timed
15910: introduction of the humorous.
15911: 
15912: "I hope Job's cough has been better lately," said Esther, in mere
15913: uncertainty as to what it would be desirable to say or do.
15914: 
15915: "I dare say you hope so, Miss Lyon," said Mrs. Holt, looking at the
15916: distant landscape. "I've no reason to disbelieve but what you wish well
15917: to the child, and to Felix, and to me. I'm sure nobody has any occasion
15918: to wish me otherways. My character will bear enquiry, and what you, as
15919: are young, don't know, others can tell you. That was what I said to
15920: myself when I made up my mind to come here and see you, and ask you to
15921: get me the freedom to speak to Mr. Transome. I said, whatever Miss Lyon
15922: may be now, in the way of being lifted up among great people, she's our
15923: minister's daughter, and was not above coming to my house and walking
15924: with my son Felix--though I'll not deny he made that figure on the
15925: Lord's Day, that'll perhaps go against him with the judge, if anybody
15926: thinks well to tell him."
15927: 
15928: Here Mrs. Holt paused a moment, as with a mind arrested by the painful
15929: image it had called up.
15930: 
15931: Esther's face was glowing, when Harold glanced at her; and seeing this,
15932: he was considerate enough to address Mrs. Holt instead of her.
15933: 
15934: "You are then the mother of the unfortunate young man who is in prison?"
15935: 
15936: "Indeed I am, sir," said Mrs. Holt, feeling that she was now in deep
15937: water. "It's not likely I should claim him if he wasn't my own; though
15938: it's not by my will, nor my advice, sir, that he ever walked; for I gave
15939: him none but good. But if everybody's son was guided by their mothers,
15940: the world 'ud be different; my son is not worse than many another
15941: woman's son, and that in Treby, whatever they may say as haven't got
15942: their sons in prison. And as to his giving up the doctoring, and then
15943: stopping his father's medicines, I know it's bad--that I know--but it's
15944: me has had to suffer, and it's me a king and Parliament 'ud consider, if
15945: they meant to do the right thing, and had anybody to make it known to
15946: 'em. And as for the rioting and killing the constable--my son said most
15947: plain to me he never meant it, and there was his bit of potato-pie for
15948: dinner getting dry by the fire, the whole blessed time as I sat and
15949: never knew what was coming on me. And it's my opinion as if great people
15950: make elections to get themselves into Parliament, and there's riot and
15951: murder to do it, they ought to see as the widow and the widow's son
15952: doesn't suffer for it. I well know my duty: and I read my Bible; and I
15953: know in Jude where it's been stained with the dried tulip-leaves this
15954: many a year, as you're told not to rail at your betters if they was the
15955: devil himself; nor will I; but this I do say, if it's three Mr.
15956: Transomes instead of one as is listening to me, as there's them ought to
15957: go to the king and get him to let off my son Felix."
15958: 
15959: This speech, in its chief points, had been deliberately prepared. Mrs.
15960: Holt had set her face like a flint, to make the gentry know their duty
15961: as she knew hers: her defiant defensive tone was due to the
15962: consciousness, not only that she was braving a powerful audience, but
15963: that she was daring to stand on the strong basis of her own judgment in
15964: opposition to her son's. Her proposals had been waived off by Mr Lyon
15965: and Felix; but she had long had the feminine conviction that if she
15966: could "get to speak" in the right quarter, things might be different.
15967: The daring bit of impromptu about the three Mr. Transomes was
15968: immediately suggested by a movement of old Mr. Transome to the
15969: foreground in a line with Mr. Lingon and Harold; his furred and unusual
15970: costume appearing to indicate a mysterious dignity which she must hasten
15971: to include in her appeal.
15972: 
15973: And there were reasons that none could have foreseen, which made Mrs.
15974: Holt's remonstrance immediately effective. While old Mr. Transome
15975: stared, very much like a waxen image in which the expression is a
15976: failure, and the rector, accustomed to female parishioners and
15977: complainants, looked on with a smile in his eyes, Harold said at once,
15978: with cordial kindness--
15979: 
15980: "I think you are quite right, Mrs. Holt. And for my part, I am
15981: determined to do my best for your son, both in the witness-box and
15982: elsewhere. Take comfort; if it is necessary, the king shall be appealed
15983: to. And rely upon it, I shall bear you in mind as Felix Holt's mother."
15984: 
15985: Rapid thoughts had convinced Harold that in this way he was best
15986: commending himself to Esther.
15987: 
15988: "Well, sir," said Mrs. Holt, who was not going to pour forth
15989: disproportionate thanks, "I am glad to hear you speak so becoming; and
15990: if you had been the king himself, I should have made free to tell you my
15991: opinion. For the Bible says the king's favor is toward a wise servant;
15992: and it's reasonable to think he'd make all the more account of them as
15993: have never been in service, or took wage, which I never did, and never
15994: thought of my son doing; and his father left money, meaning otherways,
15995: so as he might have been a doctor on horseback at this very minute,
15996: instead of being in prison."
15997: 
15998: "What! was he regularly apprenticed to a doctor?" said Mr. Lingon, who
15999: had not understood this before.
16000: 
16001: "Sir, he was, and most clever, like his father before him, only he
16002: turned contrary. But as for harming anybody, Felix never meant to harm
16003: anybody but himself and his mother, which he certainly did in respect of
16004: his clothes, and taking to be a low workingman, and stopping my living
16005: respectable, more particular by the pills, which had a sale, as you may
16006: be sure they suited people's insides. And what folks can never have
16007: boxes enough of to swallow, I should think you have a right to sell. And
16008: there's many and many a text for it, as I've opened on without ever
16009: thinking; for if it's true, 'Ask, and you shall have,' I should think
16010: it's truer when you're willing to pay for what you have."
16011: 
16012: This was a little too much for Mr. Lingon's gravity; he exploded, and
16013: Harold could not help following him. Mrs. Holt fixed her eyes on the
16014: distance, and slapped the back of her left hand again; it might be that
16015: this kind of mirth was the peculiar effect produced by forcible truth on
16016: high and worldly people who were neither in the Independent nor the
16017: General Baptist connection.
16018: 
16019: "I'm sure you must be tired with your long walk, and little Job too,"
16020: said Esther, by way of breaking this awkward scene. "Aren't you, Job?"
16021: she added, stooping to caress the child, who was timidly shrinking from
16022: Harry's invitation to him to pull the little chariot--Harry's view being
16023: that Job would make a good horse for him to beat, and would run faster
16024: than Gappa.
16025: 
16026: "It's well you can feel for the orphin child, Miss Lyon," said Mrs.
16027: Holt, choosing an indirect answer rather than to humble herself by
16028: confessing fatigue before gentlemen who seemed to be taking her too
16029: lightly. "I didn't believe but what you'd behave pretty, as you always
16030: did to me, though everybody said you held yourself high. But I'm sure
16031: you never did to Felix, for you let him sit by you at the Free School
16032: before all the town, and him with never a bit of stock round his neck.
16033: And it shows you saw _that_ in him worth taking notice of;--and it is
16034: but right, if you know my words are true, as you should speak for him to
16035: the gentlemen."
16036: 
16037: "I assure you, Mrs. Holt," said Harold, coming to the rescue--"I assure
16038: you that enough has been said to make me use my best efforts for your
16039: son. And now, pray, go on to the house with the little boy and take some
16040: rest. Dominic, show Mrs. Holt the way, and ask Mrs. Hickes to make her
16041: comfortable, and see that somebody takes her back to Treby in the
16042: buggy."
16043: 
16044: "I will go back with Mrs. Holt," said Esther, making an effort against
16045: herself.
16046: 
16047: "No, pray," said Harold, with that kind of entreaty which is really a
16048: decision. "Let Mrs. Holt have time to rest. We shall have returned, and
16049: you can see her before she goes. We will say good-by for the present,
16050: Mrs. Holt."
16051: 
16052: The poor woman was not sorry to have the prospect of rest and food,
16053: especially for "the orphin child," of whom she was tenderly careful.
16054: Like many women who appear to others to have a masculine decisiveness of
16055: tone, and to themselves to have a masculine force of mind, and who come
16056: into severe collision with sons arrived at the masterful stage, she had
16057: the maternal cord vibrating strongly within her toward all tiny
16058: children. And when she saw Dominic pick up Job and hoist him on his arm
16059: for a little while, by way of making acquaintance, she regarded him with
16060: an approval which she had not thought it possible to extend to a
16061: foreigner. Since Dominic was going, Harry and old Mr. Transome chose to
16062: follow. Uncle Lingon shook hands and turned off across the grass, and
16063: thus Esther was left alone with Harold.
16064: 
16065: But there was a new consciousness between them. Harold's quick
16066: perception was least likely to be slow in seizing indications of
16067: anything that might affect his position with regard to Esther. Some time
16068: before, his jealousy had been awakened to the possibility that before
16069: she had known him she had been deeply interested in some one else.
16070: Jealousy of all sorts--whether for our fortune or our love--is ready at
16071: combinations, and likely even to outstrip the fact. And Esther's renewed
16072: confusion, united with her silence about Felix, which now first seemed
16073: noteworthy, and with Mrs. Holt's graphic details as to her walking with
16074: him and letting him sit by her before all the town were grounds not
16075: merely for a suspicion, but for a conclusion in Harold's mind. The
16076: effect of this which he at once regarded as a discovery, was rather
16077: different from what Esther had anticipated. It seemed to him that Felix
16078: was the least formidable person that he could have found as an object of
16079: interest antecedent to himself. A young workman who had got himself
16080: thrown into prison, whatever recommendations he might have had for a
16081: girl at a romantic age in the dreariness of Dissenting society at Treby,
16082: could hardly be considered by Harold in the light of a rival. Esther was
16083: too clever and tasteful a woman to make a ballad heroine of herself, by
16084: bestowing her beauty and her lands on this lowly lover. Besides, Harold
16085: cherished the belief that, at the present time, Esther was more wisely
16086: disposed to bestow these things on another lover in every way eligible.
16087: But in two directions this discovery had a determining effect on him;
16088: his curiosity was stirred to know exactly what the relation with Felix
16089: had been, and he was solicitous that his behavior with regard to this
16090: young man should be such as to enhance his own merit in Esther's eyes.
16091: At the same time he was not inclined to any euphemisms that would seem
16092: to bring Felix into the lists with himself.
16093: 
16094: Naturally when they were left alone, it was Harold who spoke first. "I
16095: should think there's a good deal of worth in this young fellow--this
16096: Holt, notwithstanding the mistakes he has made. A little queer and
16097: conceited, perhaps; but that is usually the case with men of his class
16098: when they are at all superior to their fellows."
16099: 
16100: "Felix Holt is a highly cultivated man; he is not at all conceited,"
16101: said Esther. The different kinds of pride within her were coalescing
16102: now. She was aware that there had been a betrayal.
16103: 
16104: "Ah?" said Harold, not quite liking the tone of this answer. "This
16105: eccentricity is a sort of fanaticism, then?--this giving up being a
16106: doctor on horseback, as the old woman calls it, and taking to--let me
16107: see--watchmaking, isn't it?"
16108: 
16109: "If it is eccentricity to be very much better than other men, he is
16110: certainly eccentric; and fanatical too, if it is fanatical to renounce
16111: all small selfish motives for the sake of a great and unselfish one. I
16112: never knew what nobleness of character really was before I knew Felix
16113: Holt."
16114: 
16115: It seemed to Esther as if in the excitement of this moment, her own
16116: words were bringing her a clearer revelation.
16117: 
16118: "God bless me!" said Harold, in a tone of surprised yet thorough belief,
16119: and looking in Esther's face. "I wish you had talked to me about this
16120: before."
16121: 
16122: Esther at that moment looked perfectly beautiful, with an expression
16123: which Harold had never hitherto seen. All the confusion which had
16124: depended on personal feeling had given way before the sense that she had
16125: to speak the truth about the man whom she felt to be admirable.
16126: 
16127: "I think I didn't see the meaning of anything fine--I didn't even see
16128: the value of my father's character, until I had been taught a little by
16129: hearing what Felix Holt said, and seeing that his life was like his
16130: words."
16131: 
16132: Harold looked and listened, and felt his slight jealousy allayed rather
16133: than heightened. "This is not like love," he said to himself, with some
16134: satisfaction. With all due regard to Harold Transome, he was one of
16135: those men who are liable to make the greater mistakes about a particular
16136: woman's feelings, because they pique themselves on a power of
16137: interpretation derived from much experience. Experience is enlightening,
16138: but with a difference. Experiments on live animals may go on for a long
16139: period, and yet the fauna on which they are made may be limited. There
16140: may be a passion in the mind of a woman which precipitates her, not
16141: along the path of easy beguilement, but into a great leap away from it.
16142: Harold's experience had not taught him this; and Esther's enthusiasm
16143: about Felix Holt did not seem to him to be dangerous.
16144: 
16145: "He's quite an apostolic sort of fellow, then," was the self-quieting
16146: answer he gave to her last words. "He didn't look like that; but I had
16147: only a short interview with him, and I was given to understand that he
16148: refused to see me in prison. I believe he's not very well inclined
16149: toward me. But you saw a great deal of him, I suppose, and your
16150: testimony to any one is enough for me," said Harold, lowering his voice
16151: rather tenderly. "Now I know what your opinion is, I shall spare no
16152: effort on behalf of such a young man. In fact, I had come to the same
16153: resolution before, but your wish would make difficult things easy."
16154: 
16155: After that energetic speech of Esther's, as often happens, the tears had
16156: just suffused her eyes. It was nothing more than might have been
16157: expected in a tender-hearted woman, considering Felix Holt's
16158: circumstances, and the tears only made more lovely the look with which
16159: she met Harold's when he spoke so kindly. She felt pleased with him; she
16160: was open to the fallacious delight of being assured that she had power
16161: over him to make him do what she liked, and quite forgot the many
16162: impressions which had convinced her that Harold had a padded yoke ready
16163: for the neck of every man, woman, and child that depended on him.
16164: 
16165: After a short silence, they were getting near the stone gateway, and
16166: Harold said, with an air of intimate consultation--
16167: 
16168: "What could we do for this young man, supposing he were let off? I shall
16169: send a letter with fifty pounds to the old woman to-morrow. I ought to
16170: have done it before, but it really slipped my memory, amongst the many
16171: things that have occupied me lately. But this young man--what do you
16172: think would be the best thing we could do for him, if he gets at large
16173: again. He should be put in a position where his qualities could be more
16174: telling."
16175: 
16176: Esther was recovering her liveliness a little, and was disposed to
16177: encourage it for the sake of veiling other feelings, about which she
16178: felt renewed reticence, now that the overpowering influence of her
16179: enthusiasm was past. She was rather wickedly amused and scornful at
16180: Harold's misconceptions and ill-placed intentions of patronage.
16181: 
16182: "You are hopelessly in the dark," she said, with a light laugh and toss
16183: of her head. "What would you offer Felix Holt? a place in the Excise?
16184: You might as well think of offering it to John the Baptist. Felix has
16185: chosen his lot. He means always to be a poor man."
16186: 
16187: "Means? Yes," said Harold, slightly piqued, "but what a man means
16188: usually depends on what happens. I mean to be a commoner; but a peerage
16189: might present itself under acceptable circumstances."
16190: 
16191: "Oh, there is no sum in proportion to be done there," said Esther, again
16192: gaily. "As you are to a peerage so is not Felix Holt to any offer of
16193: advantage that you could imagine for him."
16194: 
16195: "You must think him fit for any position--the first in the county."
16196: 
16197: "No, I don't," said Esther, shaking her head mischievously. "I think him
16198: too high for it."
16199: 
16200: "I see you can be ardent in your admiration."
16201: 
16202: "Yes, it is my champagne; you know I don't like the other kind."
16203: 
16204: "That would be satisfactory if one were sure of getting your
16205: admiration," said Harold, leading her up to the terrace, and amongst the
16206: crocuses, from whence they had a fine view of the park and river. They
16207: stood still near the east parapet, and saw the dash of light on the
16208: water, and the pencilled shadows of the trees on the grassy lawn.
16209: 
16210: "Would it do as well to admire you, instead of being worthy to be
16211: admired?" said Harold, turning his eyes from that landscape to Esther's
16212: face.
16213: 
16214: "It would be a thing to be put up with," said Esther, smiling at him
16215: rather roguishly. "But you are not in that state of self-despair."
16216: 
16217: "Well, I am conscious of not having those severe virtues that you have
16218: been praising."
16219: 
16220: "That is true. You are quite in another _genre_."
16221: 
16222: "A woman would not find me a tragic hero."
16223: 
16224: "Oh, no! She must dress for general comedy--such as your mother once
16225: described to me--where the most thrilling event is the drawing of a
16226: handsome check."
16227: 
16228: "You are a naughty fairy," said Harold, daring to press Esther's hand a
16229: little more closely to him, and drawing her down the eastern steps into
16230: the pleasure-ground, as if he were unwilling to give up the
16231: conversation. "Confess that you are disgusted with my want of romance."
16232: 
16233: "I shall not confess to being disgusted. I shall ask you to confess that
16234: you are not a romantic figure."
16235: 
16236: "I am a little too stout."
16237: 
16238: "For romance--yes. At least you must find security for not getting
16239: stouter."
16240: 
16241: "And I don't look languishing enough?"
16242: 
16243: "Oh, yes--rather too much so--at a fine cigar."
16244: 
16245: "And I am not in danger of committing suicide?"
16246: 
16247: "No; you are a widower."
16248: 
16249: Harold did not reply immediately to this last thrust of Esther's. She
16250: had uttered it with innocent thoughtlessness from the playful
16251: suggestions of the moment; but it was a fact that Harold's previous
16252: married life had entered strongly in her impressions about him. The
16253: presence of Harry made it inevitable. Harold took this allusion of
16254: Esther's as an indication that his quality of widower was a point that
16255: made against him; and after a brief silence he said, in an altered, more
16256: serious tone--
16257: 
16258: "You don't suppose, I hope, that any other woman has ever held the place
16259: that you could hold in my life?"
16260: 
16261: Esther began to tremble a little, as she always did when the love-talk
16262: between them seemed getting serious. She only gave the rather stumbling
16263: answer, "How so?"
16264: 
16265: "Harry's mother had been a slave--was bought, in fact."
16266: 
16267: It was impossible for Harold to preconceive the effect this had on
16268: Esther. His natural disqualification for judging of a girl's feelings
16269: was heightened by the blinding effect of an exclusive object--which was
16270: to assure her that her own place was peculiar and supreme. Hitherto
16271: Esther's acquaintance with oriental love was derived chiefly from
16272: Byronic poems, and this had not sufficed to adjust her mind to a new
16273: story, where the Giaour concerned was giving her his arm. She was unable
16274: to speak; and Harold went on--
16275: 
16276: "Though I am close on thirty-five, I never met with a woman at all like
16277: you before. There are new eras in one's life that are equivalent to
16278: youth--are something better than youth. I was never an aspirant till I
16279: knew you."
16280: 
16281: Esther was still silent.
16282: 
16283: "Not that I dare to call myself that. I am not so confident a personage
16284: as you imagine. I am necessarily in a painful position for a man who has
16285: any feeling."
16286: 
16287: Here at last Harold had stirred the right fibre. Esther's generosity
16288: seized at once the whole meaning implied in that last sentence. She had
16289: a fine sensibility to the line at which flirtation must cease; and she
16290: was now pale and shaken with feelings she had not yet defined for
16291: herself.
16292: 
16293: "Do not let us speak of difficult things any more now," she said, with
16294: gentle seriousness. "I am come into a new world of late, and have to
16295: learn life all over again. Let us go in. I must see poor Mrs. Holt
16296: again, and my little friend Job."
16297: 
16298: She paused at the glass door that opened on the terrace, and entered
16299: there, while Harold went round to the stables.
16300: 
16301: When Esther had been up-stairs and descended again into the large
16302: entrance-hall, she found its stony capaciousness made lively by human
16303: figures extremely unlike the statues. Since Harry insisted on playing
16304: with Job again, Mrs. Holt and her orphan, after dining, had just been
16305: brought to this delightful scene for a game at hide-and-seek, and for
16306: exhibiting the climbing powers of the two pet squirrels. Mrs. Holt sat
16307: on a stool, in singular relief against the pedestal of the Apollo, while
16308: Dominic and Denner (otherwise Mrs. Hickes) bore her company; Harry, in
16309: his bright red and purple, flitted about like a great tropic bird after
16310: the sparrow-tailed Job, who hid himself with much intelligence behind
16311: the scagliola pillars and the pedestals; while one of the squirrels
16312: perched itself on the head of the tallest statue, and the other was
16313: already peeping down from among the heavy stuccoed angels on the
16314: ceiling, near the summit of a pillar.
16315: 
16316: Mrs. Holt held on her lap a basket filled with good things for Job, and
16317: seemed much soothed by pleasant company and excellent treatment. As
16318: Esther, descending softly and unobserved, leaned over the stone
16319: banisters and looked at the scene for a minute or two, she saw that Mrs.
16320: Holt's attention, having been directed to the squirrel which had
16321: scampered on to the head of the Silenus carrying the infant Bacchus, had
16322: been drawn downward to the tiny babe looked at with so much affection by
16323: the rather ugly and hairy gentleman, of whom she nevertheless spoke with
16324: reserve as of one who possibly belonged to the Transome family.
16325: 
16326: "It's most pretty to see its little limbs, and the gentleman holding it.
16327: I should think he was amiable by his look; but it was odd he should have
16328: his likeness took without any clothes. Was he Transome by name?" (Mrs.
16329: Holt suspected that there might be a mild madness in the family.)
16330: 
16331: Denner, peering and smiling quietly, was about to reply, when she was
16332: prevented by the appearance of old Mr. Transome, who since his walk had
16333: been having "forty winks" on the sofa in the library, and now came out
16334: to look for Harry. He had doffed his fur cap and cloak, but in lying
16335: down to sleep he had thrown over his shoulders a soft Oriental scarf
16336: which Harold had given him, and this still hung over his scanty white
16337: hair and down to his knees, held fast by his wooden-looking arms and
16338: laxly-clasped hands, which fell in front of him.
16339: 
16340: This singular appearance of an undoubted Transome fitted exactly into
16341: Mrs. Holt's thought at the moment. It lay in the probabilities of things
16342: that gentry's intellects should be peculiar: since they had not to get
16343: their own living, the good Lord might have economized in their case that
16344: common-sense which others were so much more in need of; and in the
16345: shuffling figure before her she saw a descendant of the gentleman who
16346: had chosen to be represented without his clothes--all the more eccentric
16347: where there were the means of buying the best. But these oddities "said
16348: nothing" in great folks, who were powerful in high quarters all the
16349: same. And Mrs. Holt rose and courtesied with a proud respect, precisely
16350: as she would have done if Mr. Transome had looked as wise as Lord
16351: Burleigh.
16352: 
16353: "I hope I'm in no way taking a liberty, sir," she began, while the old
16354: gentleman looked at her with bland feebleness; "I'm not that woman to
16355: sit anywhere out of my own home without inviting and pressing to. But I
16356: was brought here to wait, because the little gentleman wanted to play
16357: with the orphin child."
16358: 
16359: "Very glad, my good woman--sit down--sit down," said Mr. Transome,
16360: nodding and smiling between his clauses. "Nice little boy. Your
16361: grandchild?"
16362: 
16363: "Indeed, sir, no," said Mrs. Holt, continuing to stand. Quite apart from
16364: any awe of Mr. Transome--sitting down, she felt, would be a too great
16365: familiarity with her own pathetic importance on this extra and
16366: unlooked-for occasion. "It's not me has any grandchild, nor ever shall
16367: have, though most fit. But with my only son saying he'll never be
16368: married, and in prison besides, and some saying he'll be transported,
16369: you may see yourself--though a gentleman--as there isn't much chance of
16370: my having grandchildren of my own. And this is old Master Tudge's
16371: grandchild, as my own Felix took to for pity because he was sickly and
16372: clemm'd, and I was noways against it, being of a tender heart. For I'm a
16373: widow myself, and my son Felix, though big, is fatherless, and I know my
16374: duty in consequence. And it's to be wished, sir, as others should know
16375: it as are more in power and live in great houses, and can ride in a
16376: carriage where they will. And if you're the gentleman as is the head of
16377: everything--and it's not to be thought you'd give up to your son as a
16378: poor widow's been forced to do--it behooves you to take the part of them
16379: as are deserving; for the Bible says gray hairs should speak."
16380: 
16381: "Yes, yes--poor woman--what shall I say?" said old Mr. Transome, feeling
16382: himself scolded, and, as usual, desirous of mollifying displeasure.
16383: 
16384: "Sir, I can tell you what to say fast enough; for it's what I should say
16385: myself if I could get to speak to the king. For I've asked them that
16386: know, and they say it's the truth, both out of the Bible, and in, as the
16387: king can pardon anything and anybody. And judging by his countenance on
16388: the new signs, and the talk there was a while ago about his being the
16389: people's friend, as the minister once said it from the very pulpit--if
16390: there's any meaning in words, he'll do the right thing by me and my son,
16391: if he's asked proper."
16392: 
16393: "Yes--a very good man--he'll do anything right," said Mr. Transome,
16394: whose own ideas about the king just then were somewhat misty, consisting
16395: chiefly in broken reminiscences of George III. "I'll ask him anything
16396: you like," he added, with a pressing desire to satisfy Mrs. Holt, who
16397: alarmed him slightly.
16398: 
16399: "Then, sir, if you'll go in your carriage and say, this young man, Felix
16400: Holt by name, as his father was known the country round, and his mother
16401: most respectable--he never meant harm to anybody, and so far from bloody
16402: murder and fighting, would part with his victual to them that needed it
16403: more--and if you'd get other gentlemen to say the same, and if they're
16404: not satisfied to enquire--I'll not believe but what the king 'ud let my
16405: son out of prison. Or if it's true he must stand his trial, the king 'ud
16406: take care no mischief happened to him. I've got my senses, and I'll
16407: never believe as in a country where there's a God above and a king
16408: below, the right thing can't be done if great people was willing to do
16409: it."
16410: 
16411: Mrs. Holt, like all orators, had waxed louder and more energetic,
16412: ceasing to propel her arguments, and being propelled by them. Poor old
16413: Mr. Transome, getting more and more frightened at this severe-spoken
16414: woman, who had the horrible possibility to his mind of being a novelty
16415: that was to become permanent, seemed to be fascinated by fear, and stood
16416: helplessly forgetful that if he liked he might turn round and walk away.
16417: 
16418: Little Harry, alive to anything that had relation to "Gappa," had paused
16419: in his game, and discerning what he thought a hostile aspect in this
16420: naughty black old woman, rushed toward her and proceeded first to beat
16421: her with his mimic jockey's whip, and then, suspecting that her
16422: bombazine was not sensitive, to set his teeth in her arm. While Dominic
16423: rebuked him and pulled him off, Nimrod began to bark anxiously, and the
16424: scene was become alarming even to the squirrels, which scrambled as far
16425: off as possible.
16426: 
16427: Esther, who had been waiting for an opportunity of intervention, now
16428: came up to Mrs. Holt to speak some soothing words; and old Mr. Transome,
16429: seeing a sufficient screen between himself and his formidable suppliant,
16430: at last gathered courage to turn round and shuffle away with unusual
16431: swiftness into the library.
16432: 
16433: "Dear Mrs. Holt," said Esther, "do rest comforted. I assure you, you
16434: have done the utmost that can be done by your words. Your visit has not
16435: been thrown away. See how the children have enjoyed it! I saw little Job
16436: actually laughing. I think I never saw him do more than smile before."
16437: Then turning round to Dominic, she said, "Will the buggy come round to
16438: this door?"
16439: 
16440: This hint was sufficient. Dominic went to see if the vehicle was ready,
16441: and Denner, remarking that Mrs. Holt would like to mount it in the inner
16442: court, invited her to go back into the housekeeper's room. But there was
16443: a fresh resistance raised in Harry by the threatened departure of Job,
16444: who had seemed an invaluable addition to the menagerie of tamed
16445: creatures; and it was barely in time that Esther had the relief of
16446: seeing the entrance hall cleared so as to prevent any further encounter
16447: of Mrs. Holt with Harold, who was now coming up the flight of steps at
16448: the entrance.
16449: 
16450: 
16451: 
16452: 
16453: CHAPTER XLIV.
16454: 
16455:            I'm sick at heart. The eye of day,
16456:     The insistent summer noon, seems pitiless,
16457:     Shining in all the barren crevices
16458:     Of weary life, leaving no shade, no dark,
16459:     Where I may dream that hidden waters lie.
16460: 
16461: 
16462: Shortly after Mrs. Holt's striking presentation of herself at Transome
16463: Court, Esther went on a second visit to her father. The Loamford Assizes
16464: were approaching; it was expected that in about ten days Felix Holt's
16465: trial would come on, and some hints in her father's letters had given
16466: Esther the impression that he was taking a melancholy view of the
16467: result. Harold Transome had once or twice mentioned the subject with a
16468: facile hopefulness as to "the young fellow's coming off easily," which,
16469: in her anxious mind, was not a counterpoise to disquieting suggestions,
16470: and she had not chosen to introduce another conversation about Felix
16471: Holt, by questioning Harold concerning the probabilities he relied on.
16472: Since those moments on the terrace, Harold had daily become more of the
16473: solicitous and indirectly beseeching lover; and Esther, from the very
16474: fact that she was weighed on by thoughts that were painfully bewildering
16475: to her--by thoughts which, in their newness to her young mind, seemed to
16476: shake her belief that life could be anything else than a compromise with
16477: things repugnant to the moral taste--had become more passive to his
16478: attentions at the very time that she had begun to feel more profoundly
16479: that in accepting Harold Transome she left the high mountain air, the
16480: passionate serenity of perfect love forever behind her, and must adjust
16481: her wishes to a life of middling delights, overhung with the languorous
16482: haziness of motiveless ease, where poetry was only literature, and the
16483: fine ideas had to be taken down from the shelves of the library when her
16484: husband's back was turned. But it seemed as if all outward conditions
16485: concurred, along with her generous sympathy for the Transomes, and with
16486: those native tendencies against which she had once begun to struggle, to
16487: make this middling lot the best she could attain to. She was in this
16488: half-sad, half-satisfied resignation to something like what is called
16489: worldly wisdom, when she went to see her father, and learn what she
16490: could from him about Felix.
16491: 
16492: The little minister was much depressed, unable to resign himself to the
16493: dread which had begun to haunt him, that Felix might have to endure the
16494: odious penalty of transportation for the manslaughter, which was the
16495: offence that no evidence in his favor could disprove.
16496: 
16497: "I had been encouraged by the assurances of men instructed in this
16498: regard," said Mr. Lyon, while Esther sat on the stool near him, and
16499: listened anxiously, "that though he were pronounced guilty in regard to
16500: this deed whereunto he hath calamitously fallen, yet that a judge mildly
16501: disposed, and with a due sense of that invisible activity of the soul
16502: whereby the deeds which are the same in outward appearance and effect,
16503: yet differ as the knife-stroke of the surgeon, even though it kill,
16504: differs from the knife-stroke of a wanton mutilater, might use his
16505: discretion in tempering the punishment, so that it would not be very
16506: evil to bear. But now it is said that the judge who cometh is a severe
16507: man, and one nourishing a prejudice against the bolder spirits who
16508: stand not in the old paths."
16509: 
16510: "I am going to be present at the trial, father," said Esther, who was
16511: preparing the way to express a wish, which she was timid about even with
16512: her father. "I mentioned to Mrs. Transome that I should like to do so,
16513: and she said that she used in old days always to attend the assizes, and
16514: that she would take me. You will be there, father?"
16515: 
16516: "Assuredly I shall be there, having been summoned to bear witness to
16517: Felix's character, and to his having uttered remonstrances and warnings
16518: long beforehand whereby he proved himself an enemy to riot. In our ears,
16519: who know him, it sounds strangely that aught else should be credible;
16520: but he hath few to speak for him, though I trust that Mr. Harold
16521: Transome's testimony will go far, if, as you say, he is disposed to set
16522: aside minor regards, and not to speak the truth grudgingly and
16523: reluctantly. For the very truth hath a color from the disposition of the
16524: utterer."
16525: 
16526: "He is kind; he is capable of being generous," said Esther.
16527: 
16528: "It is well. For I verily believe that evil-minded men have been at work
16529: against Felix. The _Duffield Watchman_ hath written continually in
16530: allusion to him as one of those mischievous men who seek to elevate
16531: themselves through the dishonor of their party; and as one of those who
16532: go not heart and soul with the needs of the people, but seek only to get
16533: a hearing for themselves by raising their voices in crotchety discord.
16534: It is these things that cause me heaviness of spirit: the dark secret of
16535: this young man's lot is a cross I carry daily."
16536: 
16537: "Father," said Esther, timidly, while the eyes of both were filling with
16538: tears, "I should like to see him again before his trial. Might I? Will
16539: you ask him? Will you take me?"
16540: 
16541: The minister raised his suffused eyes to hers, and did not speak for a
16542: moment or two. A new thought had visited him. But his delicate
16543: tenderness shrank even from an inward enquiry that was too curious--that
16544: seemed like an effort to peep at sacred secrets.
16545: 
16546: "I see naught against it, my dear child, if you arrived early enough,
16547: and would take the elderly lady into your confidence, so that you might
16548: descend from the carriage at some suitable place--the house of the
16549: Independent minister, for example--where I could meet and accompany you.
16550: I would forewarn Felix, who would doubtless delight to see your face
16551: again; seeing that he may go away, and be, as it were, buried from you,
16552: even though it may be only in prison, and not----"
16553: 
16554: This was too much for Esther. She threw her arms round her father's neck
16555: and sobbed like a child. It was an unspeakable relief to her after all
16556: the pent-up, stifling experience, all the inward incommunicable debate
16557: of the last few weeks. The old man was deeply moved, too, and held his
16558: arm close round the dear child, praying silently.
16559: 
16560: No word was spoken for some minutes, till Esther raised herself, dried
16561: her eyes, and, with an action that seemed playful, though there was no
16562: smile on her face, pressed her handkerchief against her father's cheeks.
16563: Then, when she had put her hand in his, he said, solemnly--
16564: 
16565: "'Tis a great and mysterious gift, this clinging of the heart, my
16566: Esther, whereby it hath often seemed to me that even in the very moment
16567: of suffering our souls have the keenest foretaste of heaven. I speak not
16568: lightly, but as one who hath endured. And 'tis a strange truth that only
16569: in the agony of parting we look into the depths of love."
16570: 
16571: So the interview ended, without any question from Mr. Lyon concerning
16572: what Esther contemplated as the ultimate arrangement between herself and
16573: the Transomes.
16574: 
16575: After this conversation, which showed him that what happened to Felix
16576: touched Esther more closely than he had supposed, the minister felt no
16577: impulse to raise the images of a future so unlike anything that Felix
16578: would share. And Esther would have been unable to answer any such
16579: questions. The successive weeks, instead of bringing her nearer to
16580: clearness and decision, had only brought that state of disenchantment
16581: belonging to the actual presence of things which have long dwelt in the
16582: imagination with all the factitious charms of arbitrary arrangement. Her
16583: imaginary mansion had not been inhabited just as Transome Court was; her
16584: imaginary fortune had not been attended with circumstances which she was
16585: unable to sweep away. She, herself, in her Utopia, had never been what
16586: she was now--a woman whose heart was divided and oppressed. The first
16587: spontaneous offering of her woman's devotion, the first great
16588: inspiration of her life, was a sort of vanished ecstasy which had left
16589: its wounds. It seemed to her a cruel misfortune of her young life that
16590: her best feeling, her most precious dependence, had been called forth
16591: just where the conditions were hardest, and that all the easy
16592: invitations of circumstance were toward something which that previous
16593: consecration of her longing had made a moral descent for her. It was
16594: characteristic of her that she scarcely at all entertained the
16595: alternative of such a compromise as would have given her the larger
16596: portion of the fortune to which she had a legal claim, and yet have
16597: satisfied her sympathy by leaving the Transomes in possession of their
16598: old home. Her domestication with this family had brought them into the
16599: foreground of her imagination; the gradual wooing of Harold had acted on
16600: her with a constant immediate influence that predominated over all
16601: indefinite prospects; and a solitary elevation to wealth, which out of
16602: Utopia she had no notion how she should manage, looked as chill and
16603: dreary as the offer of dignities in an unknown country.
16604: 
16605: In the ages since Adam's marriage, it has been good for some men to be
16606: alone, and for some women also. But Esther was not one of these women:
16607: she was intensely of the feminine type, verging neither toward the saint
16608: nor the angel. She was "a fair divided excellence, whose fullness of
16609: perfection" must be in marriage. And, like all youthful creatures, she
16610: felt as if the present conditions of choice were final. It belonged to
16611: the freshness of her heart that, having had her emotions strongly
16612: stirred by real objects, she never speculated on possible relations yet
16613: to come. It seemed to her that she stood at the first and last parting
16614: of the ways. And, in one sense she was under no illusion. It is only in
16615: that freshness of our time that the choice is possible which gives unity
16616: to life, and makes the memory a temple where all relics and all votive
16617: offerings, all worship and all grateful joy, are an unbroken history
16618: sanctified by one religion.
16619: 
16620: 
16621: 
16622: 
16623: CHAPTER XLV.
16624: 
16625:     We may not make this world a paradise
16626:     By walking it together with clasped hands
16627:     And eyes that meeting feed a double strength.
16628:     We must be only joined by pains divine,
16629:     Of spirits blent in mutual memories.
16630: 
16631: 
16632: It was a consequence of that interview with her father, that when Esther
16633: stepped early on a gray March morning into the carriage with Mrs.
16634: Transome, to go to the Loamford Assizes, she was full of an expectation
16635: that held her lips in trembling silence, and gave her eyes that
16636: sightless beauty which tells that the vision is all within.
16637: 
16638: Mrs. Transome did not disturb her with unnecessary speech. Of late,
16639: Esther's anxious observation had been drawn to a change in Mrs.
16640: Transome, shown in many small ways which only women notice. It was not
16641: only that when they sat together the talk seemed more of an effort to
16642: her: that might have come from the gradual draining away of matter for
16643: discourse pertaining to most sorts of companionship, in which repetition
16644: is not felt to be as desirable as novelty. But while Mrs. Transome was
16645: dressed just as usual, took her seat as usual, trifled with her drugs
16646: and had her embroidery before her as usual, and still made her morning
16647: greetings with that finished easy politeness and consideration of tone
16648: which to rougher people seems like affectation, Esther noticed a strange
16649: fitfulness in her movements. Sometimes the stitches of her embroidery
16650: went on with silent unbroken swiftness for a quarter of an hour, as if
16651: she had to work out her deliverance from bondage by finishing a
16652: scroll-patterned border; then her hands dropped suddenly and her gaze
16653: fell blankly on the table before her, and she would sit in that way
16654: motionless as a seated statue, apparently unconscious of Esther's
16655: presence, till some thought darting within her seemed to have the effect
16656: of an external shock and rouse her with a start, when she looked around
16657: hastily like a person ashamed of having slept. Esther, touched with
16658: wondering pity at signs of unhappiness that were new in her experience,
16659: took the most delicate care to appear inobservant, and only tried to
16660: increase the gentle attention that might help to soothe or gratify this
16661: uneasy woman. But, one morning, Mrs. Transome had said, breaking a
16662: rather long silence--
16663: 
16664: "My dear, I shall make this house dull for you. You sit with me like an
16665: embodied patience. I am unendurable; I am getting into a melancholy
16666: dotage. A fidgety old woman like me is as unpleasant to see as a rook
16667: with its wing broken. Don't mind me, my dear. Run away from me without
16668: ceremony. Every one else does, you see. I am part of the old furniture
16669: with new drapery."
16670: 
16671: "Dear Mrs. Transome," said Esther, gliding to the low ottoman close by
16672: the basket of embroidery, "do you dislike my sitting with you?"
16673: 
16674: "Only for your own sake, my fairy," said Mrs. Transome, smiling faintly,
16675: and putting her hand under Esther's chin. "Doesn't it make you shudder
16676: to look at me?"
16677: 
16678: "Why will you say such naughty things?" said Esther, affectionately. "If
16679: you had had a daughter, she would have desired to be with you most when
16680: you most wanted cheering. And surely every young woman has something of
16681: a daughter's feeling toward an older one who has been kind to her."
16682: 
16683: "I should like you to be really my daughter," said Mrs. Transome,
16684: rousing herself to look a little brighter. "That is something still for
16685: an old woman to hope for."
16686: 
16687: Esther blushed: she had not foreseen this application of words that came
16688: from pitying tenderness. To divert the train of thought as quickly as
16689: possible, she at once asked what she had previously had in her mind to
16690: ask. Before her blush had disappeared she said:
16691: 
16692: "Oh, you are so good; I shall ask you to indulge me very much. It is to
16693: let us set out very early to Loamford on Wednesday, and put me down at a
16694: particular house, that I may keep an appointment with my father. It is a
16695: private matter, that I wish no one to know about, if possible. And he
16696: will bring me back to you wherever you appoint."
16697: 
16698: In that way Esther won her end without needing to betray it; and as
16699: Harold was already away at Loamford, she was the more secure.
16700: 
16701: The Independent minister's house at which she was set down, and where
16702: she was received by her father, was in a quiet street not far from the
16703: jail. Esther had thrown a dark cloak over the handsomer coverings which
16704: Denner had assured her were absolutely required of ladies who sat
16705: anywhere near the judge at a great trial; and as the bonnet of that day
16706: did not throw the face into high relief, but rather into perspective, a
16707: veil drawn down gave her a sufficiently inconspicuous appearance.
16708: 
16709: "I have arranged all things, my dear," said Mr. Lyon, "and Felix expects
16710: us. We will lose no time."
16711: 
16712: They walked away at once, Esther not asking a question. She had no
16713: consciousness of the road along which they passed; she could never
16714: remember anything but a dim sense of entering within high walls and
16715: going along passages, till they were ushered into a larger space than
16716: she had expected, and her father said:
16717: 
16718: "It is here that we are permitted to see Felix, my Esther. He will
16719: presently appear."
16720: 
16721: Esther automatically took off her gloves and bonnet, as if she had
16722: entered the house after a walk. She had lost the complete consciousness
16723: of everything except that she was going to see Felix. She trembled. It
16724: seemed to her as if he too would look altered after her new life--as if
16725: even the past would change for her and be no longer a steadfast
16726: remembrance, but something she had been mistaken about, as she had been
16727: about the new life. Perhaps she was growing out of that childhood to
16728: which common things have rareness, and all objects look larger. Perhaps
16729: from henceforth the whole world was to be meaner for her. The dread
16730: concentrated in those few moments seemed worse than anything she had
16731: known before. It was what the dread of the pilgrim might be who has it
16732: whispered to him that the holy places are a delusion, or that he will
16733: see them with a soul unstirred and unbelieving. Every minute that passes
16734: may be charged with some such crisis in the little inner world of man or
16735: woman.
16736: 
16737: But soon the door opened slightly; someone looked in; then it opened
16738: wide, and Felix Holt entered.
16739: 
16740: "Miss Lyon--Esther!" and her hand was in his grasp.
16741: 
16742: He was just the same--no, something inexpressibly better, because of the
16743: distance and separation, and the half-weary novelties, which made him
16744: like the return of the morning.
16745: 
16746: "Take no heed of me, children," said Mr. Lyon. "I have some notes to
16747: make, and my time is precious. We may remain here only a quarter of an
16748: hour." And the old man sat down at a window with his back to them,
16749: writing with his head bent close to the paper.
16750: 
16751: "You are very pale; you look ill, compared with your old self," said
16752: Esther. She had taken her hand away, but they stood still near each
16753: other, she looking up at him.
16754: 
16755: "The fact is, I'm not fond of prison," said Felix, smiling; "but I
16756: suppose the best I can hope for is to have a good deal more of it."
16757: 
16758: "It is thought that in the worst case a pardon may be obtained," said
16759: Esther, avoiding Harold Transome's name.
16760: 
16761: "I don't rely on that," said Felix, shaking his head. "My wisest course
16762: is to make up my mind to the very ugliest penalty they can condemn me
16763: to. If I can face that, anything less will seem easy. But you know," he
16764: went on, smiling at her brightly, "I never went in for fine company and
16765: cushions. I can't be very heavily disappointed in that way."
16766: 
16767: "Do you see things just as you used to do?" said Esther, turning pale as
16768: she said it--"I mean--about poverty, and the people you will live among.
16769: Has all the misunderstanding and sadness left you just as obstinate?"
16770: She tried to smile, but could not succeed.
16771: 
16772: "What--about the sort of life I should lead if I were free again?" said
16773: Felix.
16774: 
16775: "Yes. I can't help being discouraged for you by all these things that
16776: have happened. See how you may fail!" Esther spoke timidly. She saw a
16777: peculiar smile, which she knew well, gathering in his eyes. "Ah, I dare
16778: say I am silly," she said, deprecatingly.
16779: 
16780: "No, you are dreadfully inspired," said Felix. "When the wicked Tempter
16781: is tired of snarling that word failure in a man's cell, he sends a voice
16782: like a thrush to say it for him. See now what a messenger of darkness
16783: you are!" He smiled, and took her two hands between his, pressed
16784: together as children hold them up in prayer. Both of them felt too
16785: solemnly to be bashful. They looked straight into each other's eyes, as
16786: angels do when they tell some truth. And they stood in that way while he
16787: went on speaking.
16788: 
16789: "But I'm proof against that word failure. I've seen behind it. The only
16790: failure a man ought to fear is failure in cleaving to the purpose he
16791: sees to be best. As to just the amount of result he may see from his
16792: particular work--that's a tremendous uncertainty: the universe has not
16793: been arranged for the gratification of his feelings. As long as a man
16794: sees and believes in some great good, he'll prefer working toward that
16795: in the way he's best fit for, come what may. I put effects at their
16796: minimum, but I'd rather have the maximum of effect, if it's of the sort
16797: I care for, than the maximum of effect I don't care for--a lot of fine
16798: things that are not to my taste--and if they were, the conditions of
16799: holding them while the world is what it is, are such as would jar on me
16800: like grating metal."
16801: 
16802: "Yes," said Esther, in a low tone, "I think I understand that now,
16803: better than I used to do." The words of Felix at last seemed strangely
16804: to fit her own experience. But she said no more, though he seemed to
16805: wait for it a moment or two, looking at her. But then he went on--
16806: 
16807: "I don't mean to be illustrious, you know, and make a new era, else it
16808: would be kind of you to get a raven and teach it to croak 'failure' in
16809: my ears. Where great things can't happen, I care for very small things,
16810: such as will never be known beyond a few garrets and workshops. And
16811: then, as to one thing I believe in, I don't think I can altogether fail.
16812: If there's anything our people want convincing of, it is, that there's
16813: some dignity and happiness for a man other than changing his station.
16814: That's one of the beliefs I choose to consecrate my life to. If anybody
16815: could demonstrate to me that I was a flat for it, I shouldn't think it
16816: would follow that I must borrow money to set up genteelly and order new
16817: clothes. That's not a rigorous consequence to my understanding."
16818: 
16819: They smiled at each other, with the old sense of amusement they had so
16820: often had together.
16821: 
16822: "You are just the same," said Esther.
16823: 
16824: "And you?" said Felix. "My affairs have been settled long ago. But
16825: yours--a great change has come in them--magic at work."
16826: 
16827: "Yes," said Esther, rather falteringly.
16828: 
16829: "Well," said Felix, looking at her gravely again, "it's a case of
16830: fitness that seems to give a chance sanction to that musty law. The
16831: first time I saw you your birth was an immense puzzle to me. However,
16832: the appropriate conditions are come at last."
16833: 
16834: These words seemed cruel to Esther. But Felix could not know all the
16835: reasons for their seeming so. She could not speak; she was turning cold
16836: and feeling her heart beat painfully.
16837: 
16838: "All your tastes are gratified now," he went on innocently. "But you'll
16839: remember the old pedagogue and his lectures?"
16840: 
16841: One thought in the mind of Felix was, that Esther was sure to marry
16842: Harold Transome. Men readily believe these things of the women who love
16843: them. But he could not allude to the marriage more directly. He was
16844: afraid of this destiny for her, without having any very distinct
16845: knowledge by which to justify his fear to the mind of another. It did
16846: not satisfy him that Esther should marry Harold Transome.
16847: 
16848: "My children," said Mr. Lyon at this moment, not looking round, but only
16849: looking close at his watch, "we have just two minutes more." Then he
16850: went on writing.
16851: 
16852: Esther did not speak, but Felix could not help observing now that her
16853: hands had turned to a deathly coldness, and that she was trembling. He
16854: believed, he knew, that whatever prospects she had, this feeling was for
16855: his sake. An overpowering impulse from mingled love, gratitude, and
16856: anxiety, urged him to say--
16857: 
16858: "I had a horrible struggle, Esther. But you see I was right. There was a
16859: fitting lot in reserve for you. But remember you have cost a great
16860: price--don't throw what is precious away. I shall want the news that you
16861: have a happiness worthy of you."
16862: 
16863: Esther felt too miserable for tears to come. She looked helplessly at
16864: Felix for a moment, then took her hands from his, and, turning away
16865: mutely, walked dreamily toward her father, and said, "Father, I am
16866: ready--there is no more to say."
16867: 
16868: She turned back again, toward the chair where her bonnet lay, with a
16869: face quite corpse-like above her dark garments.
16870: 
16871: "Esther!"
16872: 
16873: She heard Felix say the word, with an entreating cry, and went toward
16874: him with the swift movement of a frightened child toward its protector.
16875: He clasped her, and they kissed each other.
16876: 
16877: She never could recall anything else that happened, till she was in the
16878: carriage again with Mrs. Transome.
16879: 
16880: 
16881: 
16882: 
16883: CHAPTER XLVI.
16884: 
16885:     Why, there are maidens of heroic touch,
16886:     And yet they seem like things of gossamer
16887:     You'd pinch the life out of, as out of moths.
16888:     Oh, it is not loud tones and mouthingness,
16889:     'Tis not the arms akimbo and large strides,
16890:     That make a woman's force. The tiniest birds,
16891:     With softest downy breasts, have passions in them,
16892:     And are brave with love.
16893: 
16894: 
16895: Esther was so placed in the Court, under Mrs. Transome's wing, as to see
16896: and hear everything without effort: Harold had received them at the
16897: hotel, and had observed that Esther looked ill, and was unusually
16898: abstracted in her manner; but this seemed to be sufficiently accounted
16899: for by her sympathetic anxiety about the result of a trial in which the
16900: prisoner at the bar was a friend, and in which both her father and
16901: himself were important witnesses. Mrs. Transome had no reluctance to
16902: keep a small secret from her son, and no betrayal was made of that
16903: previous "engagement" of Esther's with her father. Harold was
16904: particularly delicate and unobtrusive in his attentions to-day: he had
16905: the consciousness that he was going to behave in a way that would
16906: gratify Esther and win her admiration, and we are all of us made more
16907: graceful by the inward presence of what we believe to be a generous
16908: purpose; our actions move to a hidden music--"a melody that's sweetly
16909: played in tune."
16910:
