16911: If Esther had been less absorbed by supreme feelings, she would have
16912: been aware that she was an object of special notice. In the bare
16913: squareness of a public hall, where there was not one jutting angle to
16914: hang a guess or a thought upon, not an image or a bit of color to stir
16915: the fancy, and where the only objects of speculation, of admiration, or
16916: of any interest whatever were human beings, that occupied positions
16917: indicating some importance, the notice bestowed on Esther would not have
16918: been surprising, even if it had been merely a tribute to her youthful
16919: charm, which was well championed by Mrs. Transome's elderly majesty. But
16920: it was due also to whisperings that she was an hereditary claimant of
16921: the Transome estates, whom Harold Transome was about to marry. Harold
16922: himself had of late not cared to conceal either the fact or the
16923: probability: they both tended rather to his honor than his dishonor. And
16924: to-day, when there was a good proportion of Trebians present, the
16925: whisperings spread rapidly.
16926: 
16927: The Court was still more crowded than on the previous day, when our poor
16928: acquaintance Dredge and his two collier companions were sentenced to a
16929: year's imprisonment with hard labor, and the more enlightened prisoner,
16930: who stole the Debarry's plate, to transportation for life. Poor Dredge
16931: had cried, had wished he'd "never heared of 'lection," and in spite of
16932: sermons from the jail chaplain, fell back on the explanation that this
16933: was a world in which Spratt and Old Nick were sure to get the best of
16934: it; so that in Dredge's case, at least, most observers must have had the
16935: melancholy conviction that there had been no enhancement of public
16936: spirit and faith in progress from that wave of political agitation which
16937: had reached the Sproxton Pits.
16938: 
16939: But curiosity was necessarily at a higher pitch to-day, when the
16940: character of the prisoner and the circumstances of his offence were of a
16941: highly unusual kind. Soon as Felix appeared at the bar, a murmur rose
16942: and spread into a loud buzz, which continued until there had been
16943: repeated authoritative calls for silence in the Court. Rather
16944: singularly, it was now for the first time that Esther had a feeling of
16945: pride in him on the ground simply of his appearance. At this moment,
16946: when he was the centre of a multitudinous gaze, which seemed to act on
16947: her own vision like a broad unmitigated daylight, she felt that there
16948: was something pre-eminent in him, notwithstanding the vicinity of
16949: numerous gentlemen. No apple-woman would have admired him; not only to
16950: feminine minds like Mrs. Tiliot's, but to many minds in coat and
16951: waistcoat, there was something dangerous and perhaps unprincipled in his
16952: bare throat and great Gothic head; and his somewhat massive person would
16953: doubtless have come out very oddly from the hands of a fashionable
16954: tailor of that time. But as Esther saw his large gray eyes looking round
16955: calmly and undefiantly, first at the audience generally, and then with a
16956: more observant expression at the lawyers and other persons immediately
16957: around him, she felt that he bore the outward stamp of a distinguished
16958: nature. Forgive her if she needed this satisfaction; all of us, whether
16959: men or women, are liable to this weakness of liking to have our
16960: preference justified before others as well as ourselves. Esther said
16961: inwardly, with a certain triumph, that Felix Holt looked as worthy to
16962: be chosen in the midst of this large assembly, as he had ever looked in
16963: their _tête-à-tête_ under the sombre light of the little parlor in
16964: Malthouse Yard.
16965: 
16966: Esther had felt some relief in hearing from her father that Felix had
16967: insisted on doing without his mother's presence; and since to Mrs.
16968: Holt's imagination, notwithstanding her general desire to have her
16969: character enquired into, there was no greatly consolatory difference
16970: between being a witness and a criminal, and an appearance of any kind
16971: "before the judge" could hardly be made to suggest anything definite
16972: that would overcome the dim sense of unalleviated disgrace, she had been
16973: less inclined than usual to complain of her son's decision. Esther had
16974: shuddered beforehand at the inevitable farce there would be in Mrs.
16975: Holt's testimony. But surely Felix would lose something for want of a
16976: witness who could testify to his behavior in the morning before he
16977: became involved in the tumult?
16978: 
16979: "He is really a fine young fellow," said Harold, coming to speak to
16980: Esther after a colloquy with the prisoner's solicitor. "I hope he will
16981: not make a blunder in defending himself."
16982: 
16983: "He is not likely to make a blunder," said Esther. She had recovered her
16984: color a little, and was brighter than she had been all the morning
16985: before.
16986: 
16987: Felix had seemed to include her in his general glance, but had avoided
16988: looking at her particularly. She understood how delicate feeling for her
16989: would prevent this, and that she might safely look at him, and toward
16990: her father, whom she could see in the same direction. Turning to Harold,
16991: to make an observation, she saw that he was looking toward the same
16992: point, but with an expression on his face that surprised her.
16993: 
16994: "Dear me," she said, prompted to speak without any reflection; "--how
16995: angry you look! I never saw you look so angry before. It is not my
16996: father you are looking at?"
16997: 
16998: "Oh, no! I am angry at something I'm looking away from," said Harold,
16999: making an effort to drive back the troublesome demon who would stare out
17000: at window. "It's that Jermyn," he added, glancing at his mother as well
17001: as Esther. "He will thrust himself under my eyes everywhere since I
17002: refused him an interview and returned his letter. I'm determined never
17003: to speak to him directly again, if I can help it."
17004: 
17005: Mrs. Transome heard with a changeless face. She had for some time been
17006: watching, and had taken on her marble look of immobility. She said an
17007: inward bitter "Of course!" to everything that was unpleasant.
17008: 
17009: After this Esther soon became impatient of all speech; her attention was
17010: rivetted on the proceedings of the Court, and on the mode in which Felix
17011: bore himself. In the case for the prosecution there was nothing more
17012: than a reproduction, with irrelevancies added by witnesses, of the facts
17013: already known to us. Spratt had retained consciousness enough, in the
17014: midst of his terror, to swear that, when he was tied to the finger-post,
17015: Felix was presiding over the actions of the mob. The landlady of the
17016: Seven Stars, who was indebted to Felix for rescue from pursuit by some
17017: drunken rioters, gave evidence that went to prove his assumption of
17018: leadership prior to the assault on Spratt,--remembering only that he had
17019: called away her pursuers to "better sport." Various respectable
17020: witnesses swore to Felix's "encouragement" of the rioters who were
17021: dragging Spratt in King Street; to his fatal assault on Tucker; and to
17022: his attitude in front of the drawing-room window at the Manor.
17023: 
17024: Three other witnesses gave evidence of expressions used by the prisoner,
17025: tending to show the character of the acts with which he was charged. Two
17026: were Treby tradesmen, the third was a clerk from Duffield. The clerk had
17027: heard Felix speak at Duffield; the Treby men had frequently heard him
17028: declare himself on public matters; and they all quoted expressions which
17029: tended to show that he had a virulent feeling against the respectable
17030: shopkeeping class, and that nothing was likely to be more congenial to
17031: him than the gutting of retailer's shops. No one else knew--the
17032: witnesses themselves did not know fully--how far their strong perception
17033: and memory on these points was due to a fourth mind, namely, that of Mr.
17034: John Johnson, the attorney, who was nearly related to one of the Treby
17035: witnesses, and a familiar acquaintance of the Duffield clerk. Man cannot
17036: be defined as an evidence-giving animal; and in the difficulty of
17037: getting up evidence on any subject, there is room for much unrecognized
17038: action of diligent persons who have the extra stimulus of some private
17039: motive. Mr. Johnson was present in Court to-day, but in a modest,
17040: retired situation. He had come down to give information to Mr. Jermyn,
17041: and to gather information in other quarters, which was well illuminated
17042: by the appearance of Esther in company with the Transomes.
17043: 
17044: When the case for the prosecution closed, all strangers thought that it
17045: looked very black for the prisoner. In two instances only Felix had
17046: chosen to put a cross-examining question. The first was to ask Spratt if
17047: he did not believe that his having been tied to the post had saved him
17048: from a probably mortal injury? The second was to ask the tradesman who
17049: swore to his having heard Felix tell the rioters to leave Tucker alone
17050: and come along with him, whether he had not, shortly before, heard cries
17051: among the mob summoning to an attack on the wine-vaults and brewery.
17052: 
17053: Esther had hitherto listened closely but calmly. She knew that there
17054: would be this strong adverse testimony; and all her hopes and fears were
17055: bent on what was to come beyond it. It was when the prisoner was asked
17056: what he had to adduce in reply that she felt herself in the grasp of
17057: that tremor which does not disable the mind, but rather gives keener
17058: consciousness of a mind having a penalty of body attached to it.
17059: 
17060: There was a silence as of night when Felix Holt began to speak. His
17061: voice was firm and clear: he spoke with simple gravity, and evidently
17062: without any enjoyment of the occasion. Esther had never seen his face
17063: look so weary.
17064: 
17065: "My Lord, I am not going to occupy the time of the Court with
17066: unnecessary words. I believe the witnesses for the prosecution have
17067: spoken the truth as far as a superficial observation would enable them
17068: to do it; and I see nothing that can weigh with the jury in my favor,
17069: unless they believe my statement of my own motives, and the testimony
17070: that certain witnesses will give to my character and purposes as being
17071: inconsistent with my willingly abetting disorder. I will tell the Court
17072: in as few words as I can, how I got entangled in the mob, how I came to
17073: attack the constable, and how I was led to take a course which seems
17074: rather mad to myself, now I look back upon it."
17075: 
17076: Felix then gave a concise narrative of his motives and conduct on the
17077: day of the riot, from the moment when he was startled into quitting his
17078: work by the earlier uproar of the morning. He omitted, of course, his
17079: visit to Malthouse Yard, and merely said that he went out to walk again
17080: after returning to quiet his mother's mind. He got warmed by the story
17081: of his experience, which moved him more strongly than ever, now he
17082: recalled it in vibrating words before a large audience of his
17083: fellow-men. The sublime delight of truthful speech to one who has the
17084: great gift of uttering it, will make itself felt even through the pangs
17085: of sorrow.
17086: 
17087: "That is all I have to say for myself, my Lord. I pleaded 'Not guilty'
17088: to the charge of manslaughter, because I know that word may carry a
17089: meaning which would not fairly apply to my act. When I threw Tucker
17090: down, I did not see the possibility that he would die from a sort of
17091: attack which ordinarily occurs in fighting without any fatal effect. As
17092: to my assaulting a constable, it was a quick choice between two evils: I
17093: should else have been disabled. And he attacked me under a mistake about
17094: my intentions. I'm not prepared to say I never would assault a constable
17095: where I had more chance of deliberation. I certainly should assault him
17096: if I saw him doing anything that made my blood boil: I reverence the
17097: law, but not where it is a pretext for wrong, which it should be the
17098: very object of law to hinder. I consider that I should be making an
17099: unworthy defence, if I let the Court infer from what I say myself, or
17100: from what is said by my witnesses, that because I am a man who hates
17101: drunken, motiveless disorder, or any wanton harm, therefore I am a man
17102: who would never fight against authority: I hold it blasphemy to say that
17103: a man ought not to fight against authority: there is no great religion
17104: and no great freedom that has not done it, in the beginning. It would be
17105: impertinent for me to speak of this now, if I did not need to say in my
17106: own defence, that I should hold myself the worst sort of traitor if I
17107: put my hand to either fighting or disorder--which must mean to injure
17108: somebody--if I were not urged to it by what I hold to be sacred
17109: feelings, making a sacred duty either to my own manhood or to my
17110: fellow-man. And certainly," Felix ended, with a strong ring of scorn in
17111: his voice, "I never held it a sacred duty to try and get a Radical
17112: candidate returned for North Loamshire, by willingly heading a drunken
17113: howling mob, whose public action must consist in breaking windows,
17114: destroying hard-got produce, and endangering the lives of men and women.
17115: I have no more to say, my Lord."
17116: 
17117: "I foresaw he would make a blunder," said Harold, in a low voice to
17118: Esther. Then, seeing her shrink a little, he feared she might suspect
17119: him of being merely stung by the allusion to himself. "I don't mean what
17120: he said about the Radical candidate," he added, hastily, in correction.
17121: "I don't mean the last sentence. I mean that whole peroration of his,
17122: which he ought to have left unsaid. It has done him harm with the
17123: jury--they won't understand it, or rather will misunderstand it. And
17124: I'll answer for it, it has soured the judge. It remains to be seen what
17125: we witnesses can say for him, to nullify the effect of what he has said
17126: for himself. I hope the attorney has done his best in collecting the
17127: evidence: I understand the expense of the witnesses is undertaken by
17128: some Liberals at Glasgow and in Lancashire, friends of Holt's. But I
17129: suppose your father has told you."
17130: 
17131: The first witness called to the defence was Mr. Lyon. The gist of his
17132: statements was, that from the beginning of September last till the day
17133: of the election he was in very frequent intercourse with the prisoner;
17134: that he had become intimately acquainted with his character and views of
17135: life, and his conduct with respect to the election, and that these were
17136: totally inconsistent with any other supposition than his being involved
17137: in the riot, and his fatal encounter with the constable, were due to the
17138: calamitous failure of a bold but good purpose. He stated further that he
17139: had been present when an interview had occurred in his own house between
17140: the prisoner and Mr. Harold Transome, who was then canvassing for the
17141: representation of North Loamshire. That the object of the prisoner in
17142: seeking this interview had been to inform Mr. Transome of treating given
17143: in his name to the workmen in the pits and on the canal at Sproxton, and
17144: to remonstrate against its continuance; the prisoner fearing that
17145: disturbance and mischief might result from what he believed to be the
17146: end toward which this treating was directed--namely, the presence of
17147: these men on the occasions of the nomination and polling. Several times
17148: after this interview, Mr. Lyon said, he had heard Felix Holt recur to
17149: the subject therein discussed with expressions of grief and anxiety. He
17150: himself was in the habit of visiting Sproxton in his ministerial
17151: capacity: he knew fully what the prisoner had done there in order to
17152: found a night school, and was certain that the prisoner's interest in
17153: the workingmen of that district turned entirely on the possibility of
17154: converting them somewhat to habits of soberness and to a due care for
17155: the instruction of their children. Finally, he stated that the prisoner,
17156: in compliance with his request, had been present at Duffield on the day
17157: of the nomination, and had on his return expressed himself with strong
17158: indignation concerning the employment of the Sproxton men on that
17159: occasion, and what he called the wickedness of hiring blind violence.
17160: 
17161: The quaint appearance and manner of the little Dissenting minister could
17162: not fail to stimulate the peculiar wit of the bar. He was subjected to
17163: a troublesome cross-examination, which he bore with wide-eyed
17164: short-sighted quietude and absorption in the duty of truthful response.
17165: On being asked rather sneeringly, if the prisoner was not one of his
17166: flock? he answered, in that deeper tone which made one of the most
17167: effective transitions of his varying voice--
17168: 
17169: "Nay--would to God he were! I should then feel that the great virtues
17170: and the pure life I have beheld in him were a witness to the efficacy of
17171: the faith I believe in and the discipline of the Church whereunto I
17172: belong."
17173: 
17174: Perhaps it required a larger power of comparison than was possessed by
17175: any of that audience to appreciate the moral elevation of an Independent
17176: minister who could utter those words. Nevertheless there was a murmur
17177: which was clearly one of sympathy.
17178: 
17179: The next witness, and the one on whom the interest of the spectators was
17180: chiefly concentrated, was Harold Transome. There was a decided
17181: predominance of Tory feeling in the Court, and the human disposition to
17182: enjoy the infliction of a little punishment on an opposite party, was in
17183: this instance, of a Tory complexion. Harold was keenly alive to this,
17184: and to everything else that might prove disagreeable to him in his
17185: having to appear in the witness-box. But he was not likely to lose his
17186: self-possession, or to fail in adjusting himself gracefully, under
17187: conditions which most men would find it difficult to carry without
17188: awkwardness. He had generosity and candor enough to bear Felix Holt's
17189: proud rejection of his advances without any petty resentment; he had all
17190: the susceptibilities of a gentleman; and these moral qualities gave the
17191: right direction to his acumen, in judging of the behavior that would
17192: best secure his dignity. Everything requiring self-command was easier to
17193: him because of Esther's presence; for her admiration was just then the
17194: object which this well-tanned man of the world had it most at heart to
17195: secure.
17196: 
17197: When he entered the witness-box he was much admired by the ladies
17198: amongst the audience, many of whom sighed a little at the thought of his
17199: wrong course in politics. He certainly looked like a handsome portrait
17200: by Sir Thomas Lawrence, in which that remarkable artist had happily
17201: omitted the usual excess of honeyed blandness mixed with alert
17202: intelligence, which is hardly compatible with the state of man out of
17203: paradise. He stood not far off Felix; and the two Radicals certainly
17204: made a striking contrast. Felix might have come from the hands of a
17205: sculptor in the later Roman period, when the plastic impulse was stirred
17206: by the grandeur of barbaric forms--when rolled collars were not yet
17207: conceived, and satin stocks were not.
17208: 
17209: Harold Transome declared he had had only one interview with the
17210: prisoner: it was the interview referred to by the previous witness, in
17211: whose presence and in whose house it was begun. The interview, however,
17212: was continued beyond the observation of Mr. Lyon. The prisoner and
17213: himself quitted the Dissenting minister's house in Malthouse Yard
17214: together, and proceeded to the office of Mr. Jermyn, who was then
17215: conducting electioneering business on his behalf. His object was to
17216: comply with Holt's remonstrance by enquiring into the alleged
17217: proceedings at Sproxton, and, if possible, to put a stop to them. Holt's
17218: language, both in the Malthouse Yard and in the attorney's office, was
17219: strong: he was evidently indignant, and his indignation turned on the
17220: danger of employing ignorant men excited by drink on an occasion of
17221: popular concourse. He believed that Holt's sole motive was the
17222: prevention of disorder, and what he considered the demoralization of the
17223: workmen by treating. The event had certainly justified his
17224: remonstrances. He had not had any subsequent opportunities of observing
17225: the prisoner; but if any reliance was to be placed on a rational
17226: conclusion, it must, he thought, be plain that the anxiety thus
17227: manifested by Holt was a guarantee of the statement he had made as to
17228: his motives on the day of the riot. His entire impression from Holt's
17229: manner in that single interview was that he was a moral and political
17230: enthusiast, who, if he sought to coerce others, would seek to coerce
17231: them into a difficult, and perhaps impracticable, scrupulosity.
17232: 
17233: Harold spoke with as noticeable directness and emphasis, as if what he
17234: said could have no reaction on himself. He had of course not entered
17235: unnecessarily into what occurred in Jermyn's office. But now he was
17236: subjected to a cross-examination on this subject, which gave rise to
17237: some subdued shrugs, smiles, and winks, among county gentlemen.
17238: 
17239: The questions were directed so as to bring out, if possible, some
17240: indication that Felix Holt was moved to his remonstrance by personal
17241: resentment against the political agents concerned in setting on foot the
17242: treating at Sproxton, but such questioning is a sort of target-shooting
17243: that sometimes hits about widely. The cross-examining counsel had close
17244: connections among the Tories of Loamshire, and enjoyed his business
17245: to-day. Under the fire of various questions about Jermyn and the agent
17246: employed by him at Sproxton, Harold got warm, and in one of his replies
17247: said, with rapid sharpness--
17248: 
17249: "Mr. Jermyn was my agent then, not now: I have no longer any but hostile
17250: relations with him."
17251: 
17252: The sense that he had shown a slight heat would have vexed Harold more
17253: if he had not got some satisfaction out of the thought that Jermyn heard
17254: those words. He recovered his good temper quickly, and when,
17255: subsequently, the question came--
17256: 
17257: "You acquiesced in the treating of the Sproxton men, as necessary to the
17258: efficient working of the reformed constituency?" Harold replied, with
17259: quiet fluency--"Yes; on my return to England, before I put up for North
17260: Loamshire, I got the best advice from practised agents, both Whig and
17261: Tory. They all agreed as to electioneering measures."
17262: 
17263: The next witness was Michael Brincey, otherwise Mike Brindle, who gave
17264: evidence of the sayings and doings of the prisoner among the Sproxton
17265: men. Mike declared that Felix went "uncommon again' drink, and
17266: pitch-and-toss, and quarrelling, and sich," and was "all for schooling
17267: and bringing up the little chaps"; but on being cross-examined, he
17268: admitted that he "couldn't give much account"; that Felix did talk
17269: again' idle folks, whether poor or rich, and that most like he meant the
17270: rich, who had "a rights to be idle," which was what he, Mike, liked
17271: himself sometimes, though for the most part he was "a hard-working
17272: butty." On being checked for this superfluous allegation of his own
17273: theory and practice, Mike became timidly conscious that answering was a
17274: great mystery beyond the reach of a butty's soul, and began to err from
17275: defect instead of excess. However, he reasserted that what Felix most
17276: wanted was, "to get 'em to set up a school for the little chaps."
17277: 
17278: With the two succeeding witnesses, who swore to the fact that Felix had
17279: tried to lead the mob along Hobb's Lane instead of toward the Manor, and
17280: to the violently threatening character of Tucker's attack on him, the
17281: case for the defence was understood to close.
17282: 
17283: Meanwhile Esther had been looking on and listening with growing misery,
17284: in the sense that all had not been said which might have been said on
17285: behalf of Felix. If it was the jury who were to be acted on, she argued
17286: to herself, there might have been an impression made on their feelings
17287: which would determine their verdict. Was it not constantly said and seen
17288: that juries pronounced Guilty or Not Guilty from sympathy for or against
17289: the accused? She was too inexperienced to check her own argument by
17290: thoroughly representing to herself the course of things: how the counsel
17291: for the prosecution would reply, and how the judge would sum up, with
17292: the object of cooling down sympathy into deliberation. What she had
17293: painfully pressing on her inward vision was that the trial was coming to
17294: an end, and that the voice of right and truth had not been strong
17295: enough.
17296: 
17297: When a woman feels purely and nobly, that ardor of hers which breaks
17298: through formulas too rigorously urged on men by daily practical needs,
17299: makes one of her most precious influences: she is the added impulse that
17300: shatters the stiffening crust of cautious experience. Her inspired
17301: ignorance gives a sublimity to actions so incongruously simple, that
17302: otherwise they would make men smile. Some of that ardor which has
17303: flashed out and illuminated all poetry and history was burning to-day in
17304: the bosom of sweet Esther Lyon. In this, at least, her woman's lot was
17305: perfect: that the man she loved was her hero; that her woman's passion
17306: and her reverence for rarest goodness rushed together in an undivided
17307: current. And to-day they were making one danger, one terror, one
17308: irresistible impulse for her heart. Her feelings were growing into a
17309: necessity for action, rather than a resolve to act. She could not
17310: support the thought that the trial would come to an end, that sentence
17311: would be passed on Felix, and that all the while something had been
17312: omitted which might have been said for him. There had been no witness to
17313: tell what had been his behavior and state of mind just before the riot.
17314: She must do it. It was possible. There was time. But not too much time.
17315: All other agitation became merged in eagerness not to let the moment
17316: escape. The last witness was being called. Harold Transome had not been
17317: able to get back to her on leaving the witness-box, but Mr. Lingon was
17318: close by her. With firm quickness she said to him--
17319: 
17320: "Pray tell the attorney that I have evidence to give for the
17321: prisoner--lose no time."
17322: 
17323: "Do you know what you are going to say, my dear?" said Mr. Lingon,
17324: looking at her in astonishment.
17325: 
17326: "Yes--I entreat you, for God's sake," said Esther, in that low tone of
17327: urgent beseeching which is equivalent to a cry; and with a look of
17328: appeal more penetrating still, "I would rather die than not do it."
17329: 
17330: The old rector, always leaning to the good-natured view of things, felt
17331: chiefly that there seemed to be an additional chance for the poor fellow
17332: who had got himself into trouble. He disputed no farther, but went to
17333: the attorney.
17334: 
17335: Before Harold was aware of Esther's intention she was on her way to the
17336: witness-box. When she appeared there, it was as if a vibration, quick as
17337: light, had gone through the Court and had shaken Felix himself, who had
17338: hitherto seemed impassive. A sort of a gleam seemed to shoot across his
17339: face, and any one close to him would have seen that his hand, which lay
17340: on the edge of the dock, trembled.
17341: 
17342: At the first moment Harold was startled and alarmed; the next, he felt
17343: delight in Esther's beautiful aspect, and in the admiration of the
17344: Court. There was no blush on her face: she stood, divested of all
17345: personal considerations whether of vanity or shyness. Her clear voice
17346: sounded as it might have done if she had been making a confession of
17347: faith. She began and went on without query or interruption. Every face
17348: looked grave and respectful.
17349: 
17350: "I am Esther Lyon, the daughter of Mr. Lyon, the Independent minister at
17351: Treby, who has been one of the witnesses for the prisoner. I know Felix
17352: Holt well. On the day of the election at Treby, when I had been much
17353: alarmed by the noises that reached me from the main street, Felix Holt
17354: came to call upon me. He knew that my father was away, and he thought
17355: that I should be alarmed by the sounds of disturbance. It was about the
17356: middle of the day, and he came to tell me that the disturbance was
17357: quieted, and that the streets were nearly emptied. But he said he feared
17358: that the men would collect again after drinking, and that something
17359: worse might happen later in the day. And he was in much sadness at this
17360: thought. He stayed a little while, and then he left me. He was very
17361: melancholy. His mind was full of great resolutions that came from his
17362: kind feeling toward others. It was the last thing he would have done to
17363: join in riot or to hurt any man, if he could have helped it. His nature
17364: is very noble; he is tender-hearted; he could never have had any
17365: intention that was not brave and good."
17366: 
17367: There was something so naive and beautiful in this action of Esther's,
17368: that it conquered every low or petty suggestion even in the commonest
17369: minds. The three men in that assembly who knew her best--even her father
17370: and Felix Holt--felt a thrill of surprise mingling with their
17371: admiration. This bright, delicate, beautiful-shaped thing that seemed
17372: most like a toy or ornament--some hand had touched the chords, and there
17373: came forth music that brought tears. Half a year before, Esther's dread
17374: of being ridiculous spread over the surface of her life; but the depth
17375: below was sleeping.
17376: 
17377: Harold Transome was ready to give her his hand and lead her back to her
17378: place. When she was there, Felix, for the first time, could not help
17379: looking toward her, and their eyes met in one solemn glance.
17380: 
17381: Afterward Esther found herself unable to listen so as to form any
17382: judgment on what she heard. The acting out of that strong impulse had
17383: exhausted every energy. There was a brief pause, filled with a murmur, a
17384: buzz, and much coughing. The audience generally felt as if dull weather
17385: was setting in again. And under those auspices the counsel for the
17386: prosecution got up to make his reply. Esther's deed had its effect
17387: beyond the momentary one, but the effect was not visible in the rigid
17388: necessities of legal procedure. The counsel's duty of restoring all
17389: unfavorable facts to due prominence in the minds of the jurors, had its
17390: effect altogether reinforced by the summing-up of the judge. Even the
17391: bare discernment of facts, much more their arrangement with a view to
17392: inferences, must carry a bias: human impartiality, whether judicial or
17393: not, can hardly escape being more or less loaded. It was not that the
17394: judge had severe intentions; it was only that he saw with severity. The
17395: conduct of Felix was not such as inclined him to indulgent
17396: consideration, and, in his directions to the jury, that mental attitude
17397: necessarily told on the light in which he placed the homicide. Even to
17398: many in the Court who were not constrained by judicial duty, it seemed
17399: that though this high regard felt for the prisoner by his friends, and
17400: especially by a generous-hearted woman, was very pretty, such conduct as
17401: his was not the less dangerous and foolish, and assaulting and killing a
17402: constable was not the less an offence to be regarded without leniency.
17403: 
17404: Esther seemed now so tremulous, and looked so ill, that Harold begged
17405: her to leave the Court with his mother and Mr. Lingon. He would come and
17406: tell her the issue. But she said, quietly, that she would rather stay;
17407: she was only a little overcome by the exertion of speaking. She was
17408: inwardly resolved to see Felix to the last moment before he left the
17409: Court.
17410: 
17411: Though she could not follow the address of the counsel or the judge, she
17412: had a keen ear for what was brief and decisive. She heard the verdict,
17413: "Guilty of manslaughter." And every word uttered by the judge in
17414: pronouncing sentence fell upon her like an unforgetable sound that would
17415: come back in dreaming and in waking. She had her eyes on Felix, and at
17416: the words, "Imprisonment for four years," she saw his lip tremble. But
17417: otherwise he stood firm and calm.
17418: 
17419: Esther gave a start from her seat. Her heart swelled with a horrible
17420: sensation of pain; but, alarmed lest she should lose her self-command,
17421: she grasped Mrs. Transome's hand, getting some strength from that human
17422: contact.
17423: 
17424: Esther saw that Felix had turned. She could no longer see his face.
17425: "Yes," she said, drawing down her veil, "let us go."
17426: 
17427: 
17428: 
17429: 
17430: CHAPTER XLVII.
17431: 
17432:     The devil tempts us not--'tis we tempt him,
17433:     Beckoning his skill with opportunity.
17434: 
17435: 
17436: The more permanent effect of Esther's action in the trial was visible in
17437: a meeting which took place the next day in the principal room of the
17438: White Hart of Loamford. To the magistrates and other county gentlemen
17439: who were drawn together about noon, some of the necessary impulse might
17440: have been lacking but for that stirring of heart in certain
17441: just-spirited men and good fathers among them, which had been raised to
17442: a high pitch of emotion by Esther's maidenly fervor. Among these one of
17443: the foremost was Sir Maximus Debarry, who had come to the assizes with a
17444: mind, as usual, slightly rebellious under an influence which he never
17445: ultimately resisted--the influence of his son. Philip Debarry himself
17446: was detained in London, but in his correspondence with his father he had
17447: urged him, as well as his uncle Augustus, to keep eyes and interest
17448: awake on the subject of Felix Holt, whom, from all the knowledge of the
17449: case he had been able to obtain, he was inclined to believe peculiarly
17450: unfortunate rather than guilty. Philip had said he was the more anxious
17451: that his family should intervene benevolently in this affair, if it were
17452: possible, because he understood that Mr. Lyon took the young man's case
17453: particularly to heart, and he should always regard himself as obliged to
17454: the old preacher. At this superfineness of consideration Sir Maximus had
17455: vented a few "pshaws!" and, in relation to the whole affair, had
17456: grumbled that Phil was always setting him to do he didn't know
17457: what--always seeming to turn nothing into something by dint of words
17458: which hadn't so much substance as a mote behind them. Nevertheless he
17459: was coerced; and in reality he was willing to do anything fair or
17460: good-natured which had a handle that his understanding could lay hold
17461: of. His brother, the rector, desired to be rigorously just; but he had
17462: come to Loamford with a severe opinion concerning Felix, thinking that
17463: some sharp punishment might be a wholesome check on the career of a
17464: young man disposed to rely too much on his own crude devices.
17465: 
17466: Before the trial commenced, Sir Maximus had naturally been one of those
17467: who had observed Esther with curiosity, owing to the report of her
17468: inheritance, and her probable marriage to his once welcome but now
17469: exasperating neighbor, Harold Transome; and he had made the emphatic
17470: comment--"A fine girl! something thoroughbred in the look of her. Too
17471: good for a Radical; that's all I have to say." But during the trial Sir
17472: Maximus was wrought into a state of sympathetic ardor that needed no
17473: fanning. As soon as he could take his brother by the buttonhole, he
17474: said--
17475: 
17476: "I tell you what, Gus! we must exert ourselves to get a pardon for this
17477: young fellow. Confound it! what's the use of mewing him up for four
17478: years? Example? Nonsense. Will there be a man knocked down the less for
17479: it? That girl made me cry. Depend upon it, whether she's going to marry
17480: Transome or not, she's been fond of Holt--in her poverty, you know.
17481: She's a modest, brave, beautiful woman. I'd ride a steeple-chase, old as
17482: I am, to gratify her feelings. Hang it! the fellow's a good fellow if
17483: she thinks so. And he threw out a fine sneer, I thought, at the Radical
17484: candidate. Depend upon it, he's a good fellow at bottom."
17485: 
17486: The rector had not exactly the same kind of ardor, nor was he open too
17487: precisely that process of proof which appeared to have convinced Sir
17488: Maximus; but he had been so far influenced as to be inclined to unite in
17489: an effort on the side of mercy, observing also that he "knew Phil would
17490: be on that side." And by the co-operation of similar movements in the
17491: minds of other men whose names were of weight, a meeting had been
17492: determined on to consult about getting up a memorial to the Home
17493: Secretary on behalf of Felix Holt. His case had never had the sort of
17494: significance that could rouse political partisanship; and such interest
17495: as was now felt in him was still more unmixed with that inducement. The
17496: gentlemen who gathered in the room at the White Hart were--not as the
17497: large imagination of the _North_ _Loamshire Herald_ suggested, "of all
17498: shades of political opinion," but--of as many shades as were to be found
17499: among the gentlemen of that county.
17500: 
17501: Harold Transome had been energetically active in bringing about this
17502: meeting. Over and above the stings of conscience and a determination to
17503: act up to the level of all recognized honorableness, he had the powerful
17504: motive of desiring to do what would satisfy Esther. His gradually
17505: heightened perception that she had a strong feeling toward Felix Holt
17506: had not made him uneasy. Harold had a conviction that might have seemed
17507: like fatuity if it had not been that he saw the effect he produced on
17508: Esther by the light of his opinions about women in general. The
17509: conviction was, that Felix Holt could not be his rival in any formidable
17510: sense. Esther's admiration for this eccentric young man was, he thought,
17511: a moral enthusiasm, a romantic fervor, which was one among those many
17512: attractions quite novel in his own experience; her distress about the
17513: trouble of one who had been a familiar object in her former home, was no
17514: more than naturally followed from a tender woman's compassion. The place
17515: young Holt had held in her regard had necessarily changed its relations
17516: now that her lot was so widely changed. It is undeniable, that what most
17517: conduced to the quieting nature of Harold's conclusions was the
17518: influence on his imagination of the more or less detailed reasons that
17519: Felix Holt was a watchmaker, that his home and dress were of a certain
17520: quality, that his person and manners--that, in short (for Harold, like
17521: the rest of us, had many impressions which saved him the trouble of
17522: distinct ideas), Felix Holt was not the sort of a man a woman would be
17523: in love with when she was wooed by Harold Transome.
17524: 
17525: Thus, he was sufficiently at rest on this point not to be exercising any
17526: painful self-conquest in acting as the zealous advocate of Felix Holt's
17527: cause with all persons worth influencing; but it was by no direct
17528: intercourse between him and Sir Maximus that they found themselves in
17529: co-operation, for the old baronet would not recognize Harold by more
17530: than the faintest bow, and Harold was not a man to expose himself to a
17531: rebuff. Whatever he in his inmost soul regarded as nothing more than a
17532: narrow prejudice, he could defy, not with airs of importance, but with
17533: easy indifference. He could bear most things good-humoredly where he
17534: felt that he had the superiority. The object of the meeting was
17535: discussed, and the memorial agreed upon without any clashing. Mr.
17536: Lingon was gone home, but it was expected that his concurrence and
17537: signature would be given, as well as those of other gentlemen who were
17538: absent. The business gradually reached that stage at which the
17539: concentration of interest ceases--when the attention of all but a few
17540: who are more practically concerned drops off and disperses itself in
17541: private chat, and there is no longer any particular reason why everybody
17542: stays except that everybody is there. The room was rather a long one,
17543: and invited to a little movement; one gentleman drew another aside to
17544: speak in an undertone about Scotch bullocks; another had something to
17545: say about the North Loamshire hunt to a friend who was the reverse of
17546: good-looking, but who, nevertheless, while listening, showed his
17547: strength of mind by giving a severe attention also to his full-length
17548: reflection in the handsome tall mirror that filled the space between two
17549: windows. And in this way the groups were continually shifting.
17550: 
17551: But in the meantime there were moving toward this room at the White Hart
17552: the footsteps of a person whose presence had not been invited, and who,
17553: very far from being drawn thither by the belief that he would be
17554: welcome, knew well that his entrance would, to one person at least, be
17555: bitterly disagreeable. They were the footsteps of Mr. Jermyn, whose
17556: appearance that morning was not less comely and less carefully tended
17557: than usual, but who was suffering the torment of a compressed rage,
17558: which, if not impotent to inflict pain on another, was impotent to avert
17559: evil from himself. After his interview with Mrs. Transome there had been
17560: for some reasons a delay of positive procedures against him by Harold,
17561: of which delay Jermyn had twice availed himself; first, to seek an
17562: interview with Harold, and then to send him a letter. The interview had
17563: been refused; and the letter had been returned, with the statement that
17564: no communication could take place except through Harold's lawyers. And
17565: yesterday Johnson had brought Jermyn the information that he would
17566: quickly hear of the proceedings in Chancery being resumed: the watch
17567: Johnson kept in town had given him secure knowledge on this head. A
17568: doomed animal, with every issue earthed up except that where its enemy
17569: stands, must, if it has teeth and fierceness, try its one chance without
17570: delay. And a man may reach a point in his life in which his impulses are
17571: not distinguished from those of a hunted brute by any capability of
17572: scruples. Our selfishness is so robust and many-clutching, that, well
17573: encouraged, it easily devours all sustenance away from our poor little
17574: scruples.
17575: 
17576: Since Harold would not give Jermyn access to him, that vigorous attorney
17577: was resolved to take it. He knew all about the meeting at the White
17578: Hart, and he was going thither with the determination of accosting
17579: Harold. He thought he knew what he should say, and the tone in which he
17580: should say it. It would be a vague intimation, carrying the effect of a
17581: threat, which should compel Harold to give him a private interview. To
17582: any counter-consideration that presented itself in his mind--to anything
17583: that an imagined voice might say--the imagined answer arose, "That's all
17584: very fine, but I'm not going to be ruined if I can help it--least of
17585: all, ruined in that way." Shall we call it degeneration or gradual
17586: development--this effect of thirty additional winters on the
17587: soft-glancing, versifying young Jermyn?
17588: 
17589: When Jermyn entered the room at the White Hart he did not immediately
17590: see Harold. The door was at the extremity of the room, and the view was
17591: obstructed by groups of gentlemen with figures broadened by overcoats.
17592: His entrance excited no particular observation: several persons had come
17593: in late. Only one or two, who knew Jermyn well, were not too much
17594: preoccupied to have a glancing remembrance of what had been chatted
17595: about freely the day before--Harold's irritated reply about his agent,
17596: from the witness box. Receiving and giving a slight nod here and there,
17597: Jermyn pushed his way, looking round keenly, until he saw Harold
17598: standing near the other end of the room. The solicitor who had acted for
17599: Felix was just then speaking to him, but having put a paper into his
17600: hand turned away; and Harold, standing isolated, though at no great
17601: distance from others, bent his eyes on the paper. He looked brilliant
17602: that morning; his blood was flowing prosperously. He had come in after a
17603: ride, and was additionally brightened by rapid talk and the excitement
17604: of seeking to impress himself favorably, or at least powerfully, on the
17605: minds of neighbors nearer or more remote. He had just that amount of
17606: flush which indicates that life is more enjoyable than usual; and as he
17607: stood with his left hand caressing his whisker, and his right holding
17608: the paper and his riding-whip, his dark eyes running rapidly along the
17609: written lines, and his lips reposing in a curve of good-humor which had
17610: more happiness in it than a smile, all beholders might have seen that
17611: his mind was at ease.
17612: 
17613: Jermyn walked quickly and quietly close up to him. The two men were of
17614: the same height, and before Harold looked round Jermyn's voice was
17615: saying, close to his ear, not in a whisper, but in a hard, incisive,
17616: disrespectful and yet not loud tone--
17617: 
17618: "Mr. Transome, I must speak to you in private."
17619: 
17620: The sound jarred through Harold with a sensation all the more
17621: insufferable because of the revulsion from the satisfied, almost elated,
17622: state in which it had seized him. He started and looked round into
17623: Jermyn's eyes. For an instant, which seemed long, there was no sound
17624: between them, but only angry hatred gathering in the two faces. Harold
17625: felt himself going to crush this insolence: Jermyn felt that he had
17626: words within him that were fangs to clutch this obstinate strength, and
17627: wring forth the blood and compel submission. And Jermyn's impulse was
17628: the more urgent. He said, in a tone that was rather lower, but yet
17629: harder and more biting--
17630: 
17631: "You will repent else--for your mother's sake."
17632: 
17633: At that sound, quick as a leaping flame, Harold had struck Jermyn across
17634: the face with his whip. The brim of the hat had been a defense. Jermyn,
17635: a powerful man, had instantly thrust out his hand and clutched Harold
17636: hard by the clothes just below the throat, pushing him slightly so as to
17637: make him stagger.
17638: 
17639: By this time everybody's attention had been called to this end of the
17640: room, but both Jermyn and Harold were beyond being arrested by any
17641: consciousness of spectators.
17642: 
17643: "Let me go, you scoundrel!" said Harold, fiercely, "or I'll be the death
17644: of you."
17645: 
17646: "Do," said Jermyn, in a grating voice; "_I am your father_."
17647: 
17648: In the thrust by which Harold had been made to stagger backward a
17649: little, the two men had got very near the long mirror. They were both
17650: white; both had anger and hatred in their faces; the hands of both were
17651: upraised. As Harold heard the last terrible words he started at a
17652: leaping throb that went through him, and in the start turned his eyes
17653: away from Jermyn's face. He turned them on the same face in the glass
17654: with his own beside it, and saw the hated fatherhood reasserted.
17655: 
17656: The strong man reeled with a sick faintness. But in the same moment
17657: Jermyn released his hold, and Harold felt himself supported by the arm.
17658: It was Sir Maximus Debarry who had taken hold of him.
17659: 
17660: "Leave the room, sir!" the baronet said to Jermyn, in a voice of
17661: imperious scorn. "This is a meeting of gentlemen."
17662: 
17663: "Come, Harold," he said, in the old friendly voice, "come away with
17664: me."

17669: CHAPTER XLVIII.
17670: 
17671:     'Tis law as steadfast as the throne of Zeus--
17672:     Our days are heritors of days gone by.
17673: 
17674:                                   ÆSCHYLUS: _Agamemnon_.
17675: 
17676: 
17677: A little after five o'clock that day, Harold arrived at Transome Court.
17678: As he was winding along the broad road of the park, some parting gleams
17679: of the March sun pierced the trees here and there, and threw on the
17680: grass a long shadow of himself and the groom riding, and illuminated a
17681: window or two of the home he was approaching. But the bitterness in his
17682: mind made these sunny gleams almost as odious as an artificial smile. He
17683: wished he had never come back to this pale English sunshine.
17684: 
17685: In the course of his eighteen miles' drive he had made up his mind what
17686: he would do. He understood now, as he had never understood before, the
17687: neglected solitariness of his mother's life, the allusions and
17688: innuendoes which had come out during the election. But with a proud
17689: insurrection against the hardship of an ignominy which was not of his
17690: own making, he inwardly said, that if the circumstances of his birth
17691: were such as to warrant any man in regarding his character of gentleman
17692: with ready suspicion, that character should be the more strongly
17693: asserted in his conduct. No one should be able to allege with any show
17694: of proof that he had inherited meanness.
17695: 
17696: As he stepped from the carriage and entered the hall, there were the
17697: voice and the trotting feet of little Harry as usual, and the rush to
17698: clasp his father's leg and make his joyful puppy-like noises. Harold
17699: just touched the boy's head, and then said to Dominic in a weary voice--
17700: 
17701: "Take the child away. Ask where my mother is."
17702: 
17703: Mrs. Transome, Dominic said, was up-stairs. He had seen her go up after
17704: coming in from her walk with Miss Lyon, and she had not come down again.
17705: 
17706: Harold throwing off his hat and greatcoat, went straight to his mother's
17707: dressing-room. There was still a hope in his mind. He might be suffering
17708: simply from a lie. There is much misery created in the world by mere
17709: mistake or slander, and he might have been stunned by a lie suggested by
17710: such slander. He rapped at his mother's door.
17711: 
17712: Her voice said immediately, "Come in."
17713: 
17714: Mrs. Transome was resting in her easy-chair, as she often did between an
17715: afternoon walk and dinner. She had taken off her walking-dress and
17716: wrapped herself in a soft dressing-gown. She was neither more nor less
17717: empty of joy than usual. But when she saw Harold, a dreadful certainty
17718: took possession of her. It was as if a long expected letter, with a
17719: black seal, had come at last.
17720: 
17721: Harold's face told her what to fear the more decisively, because she had
17722: never before seen it express a man's deep agitation. Since the time of
17723: its pouting childhood and careless youth she had seen only the confident
17724: strength and good-humored imperiousness of maturity. The last five hours
17725: had made a change as great as illness makes. Harold looked as if he had
17726: been wrestling, and had had some terrible blow. His eyes had that sunken
17727: look which, because it is unusual, seems to intensify expression.
17728: 
17729: He looked at his mother as he entered, and her eyes followed him as he
17730: moved, till he came and stood in front of her, she looking up at him,
17731: with white lips.
17732: 
17733: "Mother," he said, speaking with a distinct slowness, in strange
17734: contrast with his habitual manner, "tell me the truth, that I may know
17735: how to act."
17736: 
17737: He paused a moment, and then said, "Who is my father?"
17738: 
17739: She was mute: her lips only trembled. Harold stood silent for a few
17740: moments, as if waiting. Then he spoke again.
17741: 
17742: "_He_ has said--said it before others--that _he_ is my father."
17743: 
17744: He looked still at his mother. She seemed as if age were striking her
17745: with a sudden wand--as if her trembling face were getting haggard before
17746: him. She was mute. But her eyes had not fallen; they looked up in
17747: helpless misery at her son.
17748: 
17749: Her son turned away his eyes from her, and left her. In that moment
17750: Harold felt hard: he could show no pity. All the pride of his nature
17751: rebelled against his sonship.

17756: CHAPTER XLIX.
17757: 
17758:     Nay, falter not--'tis an assured good
17759:     To seek the noblest--'tis your only good
17760:     Now you have seen it; for that higher vision
17761:     Poisons all meaner choice forevermore.

17763: 
17764: That day Esther dined with old Mr. Transome only. Harold sent word that
17765: he was engaged and had already dined, and Mrs. Transome that she was
17766: feeling ill. Esther was much disappointed that any tidings Harold might
17767: have brought relating to Felix were deferred in this way; and, her
17768: anxiety making her fearful, she was haunted by the thought that if there
17769: had been anything cheering to tell, he would have found time to tell it
17770: without delay. Old Mr. Transome went as usual to his sofa in the library
17771: to sleep after dinner, and Esther had to seat herself in the small
17772: drawing-room, in a well-lit solitude that was unusually dispiriting to
17773: her. Pretty as this room was, she did not like it. Mrs. Transome's
17774: full-length portrait, being the only picture there, urged itself too
17775: strongly on her attention: the youthful brilliancy it represented
17776: saddened Esther by its inevitable association with what she daily saw
17777: had come instead of it--a joyless, embittered age. The sense that Mrs.
17778: Transome was unhappy, affected Esther more and more deeply as the
17779: growing familiarity which relaxed the efforts of the hostess revealed
17780: more and more the threadbare tissue of this majestic lady's life. Even
17781: the flowers and the pure sunshine and the sweet waters of Paradise would
17782: have been spoiled for a young heart, if the bowered walks had been
17783: haunted by an Eve gone gray with bitter memories of an Adam who had
17784: complained. "The woman----she gave me of the tree, and I did eat." And
17785: many of us know how, even in our childhood, some blank discontented face
17786: on the background of our home has marred our summer mornings. Why was
17787: it, when the birds were singing, when the fields were a garden, and when
17788: we were clasping another little hand just larger than our own, there was
17789: somebody who found it hard to smile? Esther had got far beyond that
17790: childhood to a time and circumstances when this daily presence of
17791: elderly dissatisfaction amidst such outward things as she had always
17792: thought must greatly help to satisfy, awaked, not merely vague
17793: questioning emotion, but strong determining thought. And now, in these
17794: hours since her return from Loamford, her mind was in that state of
17795: highly-wrought activity, that large discourse, in which we seem to stand
17796: aloof from our own life--weighing impartially our own temptations and
17797: the weak desires that most habitually solicit us. "I think I am getting
17798: that power Felix wished me to have: I shall soon see strong visions,"
17799: she said to herself, with a melancholy smile flitting across her face,
17800: as she put out her wax lights that she might get rid of the oppressive
17801: urgency of walls and upholstery and that portrait smiling with deluded
17802: brightness, unwitting of the future.
17803: 
17804: Just then Dominic came to say that Mr. Harold sent his compliments, and
17805: begged that she would grant him an interview in his study. He disliked
17806: the small drawing-room: if she would oblige him by going to the study at
17807: once, he would join her very soon. Esther went, in some wonder and
17808: anxiety. What she most feared or hoped in these moments related to Felix
17809: Holt, and it did not occur to her that Harold could have anything
17810: special to say to her that evening on other subjects.
17811: 
17812: Certainly the study was pleasanter than the small drawing-room. A quiet
17813: light shone on nothing but greenness and dark wood, and Dominic had
17814: placed a delightful chair for her opposite to his master's, which was
17815: still empty. All the little objects of luxury around indicated Harold's
17816: habitual occupancy; and as Esther sat opposite all these things along
17817: with the empty chair which suggested the coming presence, the
17818: expectation of his beseeching homage brought with it an impatience and
17819: repugnance which she had never felt before. While these feelings were
17820: strongly upon her, the door opened and Harold appeared.
17821: 
17822: He had recovered his self-possession since his interview with his
17823: mother: he had dressed and was perfectly calm. He had been occupied with
17824: resolute thoughts, determining to do what he knew that perfect honor
17825: demanded, let it cost him what it would. It is true he had a tacit hope
17826: behind, that it might not cost him what he prized most highly: it is
17827: true he had a glimpse even of reward; but it was not less true that he
17828: would have acted as he did without that hope or glimpse. It was the most
17829: serious moment in Harold Transome's life; for the first time the iron
17830: had entered into his soul, and he felt the hard pressure of our common
17831: lot, the yoke of that mighty resistless destiny laid upon us by the acts
17832: of other men as well as our own.
17833: 
17834: When Esther looked at him she relented, and felt ashamed of her
17835: gratuitous impatience. She saw that his mind was in some way burdened.
17836: But then immediately sprang the dread that he had to say something
17837: hopeless about Felix.
17838: 
17839: They shook hands in silence, Esther looking at him with anxious
17840: surprise. He released her hand, but it did not occur to her to sit down,
17841: and they both continued standing on the hearth.
17842: 
17843: "Don't let me alarm you," said Harold, seeing that her face gathered
17844: solemnity from his. "I suppose I carry the marks of a past agitation. It
17845: relates entirely to troubles of my own--of my own family. No one beyond
17846: is involved in them."
17847: 
17848: Esther wondered still more, and felt still more relenting.
17849: 
17850: "But," said Harold, after a slight pause, and in a voice that was
17851: weighted with new feeling, "it involves a difference in my position with
17852: regard to you; and it is on this point that I wished to speak to you at
17853: once. When a man sees what ought to be done, he had better do it
17854: forthwith. He can't answer for himself to-morrow."
17855: 
17856: While Esther continued to look at him, with eyes widened by anxious
17857: expectation, Harold turned a little, leaned on the mantelpiece, and
17858: ceased to look at her as he spoke.
17859: 
17860: "My feelings drag me another way. I need not tell you that your regard
17861: has become very important to me--that if our mutual position had been
17862: different--that, in short, you must have seen--if it had not seemed to
17863: be a matter of worldly interest, I should have told you plainly already
17864: that I loved you, and that my happiness could be complete only if you
17865: would consent to marry me."
17866: 
17867: Esther felt her heart beginning to beat painfully. Harold's voice and
17868: words moved her so much that her own task seemed more difficult than she
17869: had before imagined. It seemed as if the silence, unbroken by anything
17870: but the clicking of the fire, had been long, before Harold turned round
17871: toward her again and said--
17872: 
17873: "But to-day I have heard something that affects my own position. I
17874: cannot tell you what it is. There is no need. It is not any culpability
17875: of my own. But I have not just the same unsullied name and fame in the
17876: eyes of the world around us, as I believed that I had when I allowed
17877: myself to entertain that wish about you. You are very young, entering on
17878: a fresh life with bright prospects--you are worthy of everything that is
17879: best. I may be too vain in thinking it was at all necessary; but I take
17880: this precaution against myself. I shut myself out from the chance of
17881: trying, after to-day, to induce you to accept anything which others may
17882: regard as specked and stained by any obloquy, however slight."
17883: 
17884: Esther was keenly touched. With a paradoxical longing, such as often
17885: happens to us, she wished at that moment that she could have loved this
17886: man with her whole heart. The tears came into her eyes; she did not
17887: speak, but, with an angel's tenderness in her face, she laid her hand on
17888: his sleeve. Harold commanded himself strongly and said--
17889: 
17890: "What is to be done now is, that we should proceed at once to the
17891: necessary legal measures for putting you in possession of your own, and
17892: arranging mutual claims. After that I shall probably leave England."
17893: 
17894: Esther was oppressed by an overpowering difficulty. Her sympathy with
17895: Harold at this moment was so strong, that it spread itself like a mist
17896: over all previous thought and resolve. It was impossible now to wound
17897: him afresh. With her hand still resting on his arm, she said, timidly--
17898: 
17899: "Should you be urged--obliged to go--in any case?"
17900: 
17901: "Not in every case, perhaps," Harold said, with an evident movement of
17902: the blood toward his face; "at least not for long, not for always."
17903: 
17904: Esther was conscious of the gleam in his eyes. With terror at herself,
17905: she said, in difficult haste, "I can't speak. I can't say anything
17906: to-night. A great decision has to be made: I must wait--till to-morrow."
17907: 
17908: She was moving her hand from his arm, when Harold took it reverentially
17909: and raised it to his lips. She turned toward her chair, and as he
17910: released her hand she sank down on the seat with a sense that she needed
17911: that support. She did not want to go away from Harold yet. All the while
17912: there was something she needed to know, and yet she could not bring
17913: herself to ask it. She must resign herself to depend entirely on his
17914: recollection of anything beyond his own immediate trial. She sat
17915: helpless under contending sympathies while Harold stood at some distance
17916: from her, feeling more harassed by weariness and uncertainty, now that
17917: he had fulfilled his resolve, and was no longer under the excitement of
17918: actually fulfilling it.
17919: 
17920: Esther's last words had forbidden his revival of the subject that was
17921: necessarily supreme with him. But still she sat there, and his mind,
17922: busy as to the probabilities of her feeling, glanced over all she had
17923: done and said in the later days of their intercourse. It was this
17924: retrospect that led him to say at last--
17925: 
17926: "You will be glad to hear that we shall get a very powerfully signed
17927: memorial to the Home Secretary about young Holt. I think your speaking
17928: for him helped a great deal. You made all the men wish what you wished."
17929: 
17930: This was what Esther had been yearning to hear and dared not ask, as
17931: well from respect for Harold's absorption in his own sorrow, as from the
17932: shrinking that belongs to our dearest need. The intense relief of
17933: hearing what she longed to hear, affected her whole frame: her color,
17934: her expression, changed as if she had been suddenly freed from some
17935: torturing constraint. But we interpret signs of emotion as we interpret
17936: other signs--often quite erroneously, unless we have the right key to
17937: what they signify. Harold did not gather that this was what Esther had
17938: waited for, or that the change in her indicated more than he had
17939: expected her to feel at this allusion to an unusual act which she had
17940: done under a strong impulse.
17941: 
17942: Besides the introduction of a new subject after very momentous words
17943: have passed, and are still dwelling on the mind, is necessarily a sort
17944: of concussion, shaking us into a new adjustment of ourselves.
17945: 
17946: It seemed natural that soon afterward Esther put out her hand and said,
17947: "Good-night."
17948: 
17949: Harold went to his bedroom on the same level with his study, thinking of
17950: the morning with an uncertainty that dipped on the side of hope. This
17951: sweet woman, for whom he felt a passion newer than any he had expected
17952: to feel, might possibly make some hard things more bearable--if she
17953: loved him. If not--well, he had acted so that he could defy anyone to
17954: say he was not a gentleman.
17955: 
17956: Esther went up-stairs to her bedroom, thinking that she should not sleep
17957: that night. She set her light on a high stand, and did not touch her
17958: dress. What she desired to see with undisturbed clearness were things
17959: not present: the rest she needed was the rest of a final choice. It was
17960: difficult. On each side there was renunciation.
17961: 
17962: She drew up her blinds, liking to see the gray sky, where there were
17963: some veiled glimmerings of moonlight, and the lines of the forever
17964: running river, and the bending movement of the black trees. She wanted
17965: the largeness of the world to help her thought. This young creature, who
17966: trod lightly backward and forward, and leaned against the window-frame,
17967: and shook back her brown curls as she looked at something not visible,
17968: had lived hardly more than six months since she saw Felix Holt for the
17969: first time. But life is measured by the rapidity of change, the
17970: succession of influences that modify the being; and Esther had undergone
17971: something little short of an inward revolution. The revolutionary
17972: struggle, however, was not quite at an end.
17973: 
17974: There was something which she now felt profoundly to be the best thing
17975: that life could give her. But--if it was to be had at all--it was not to
17976: be had without paying a heavy price for it, such as we must pay for all
17977: that is greatly good. A supreme love, a motive that gives a sublime
17978: rhythm to a woman's life, and exalts habit into partnership with the
17979: soul's highest needs, is not to be had where and how she wills: to know
17980: that high initiation, she must often tread where it is hard to tread,
17981: and feel the chill air, and watch through darkness. It is not true that
17982: love makes all things easy: it makes us choose what is difficult.
17983: Esther's previous life had brought her into close acquaintance with many
17984: negations, and with many positive ills too, not of the acutely painful,
17985: but of the distasteful sort. What if she chose the hardship, and had to
17986: bear it alone, with no strength to lean upon--no other better self to
17987: make a place for trust and joy? Her past experience saved her from
17988: illusions. She knew the dim life of the back street, the contact with
17989: sordid vulgarity, the lack of refinement for the senses, the summons to
17990: a daily task; and the gain that was to make that life of privation
17991: something on which she dreaded to turn her back, as if it were
17992: heaven--the presence and the love of Felix Holt--was only a quivering
17993: hope, not a certainty. It was not in her woman's nature that the hope
17994: should not spring within her and make a strong impulse. She knew that he
17995: loved her: had he not said how a woman might help a man if she were
17996: worthy? and if she proved herself worthy? But still there was the dread
17997: that after all she might find herself on the stony road alone, and faint
17998: and be weary. Even with the fulfillment of her hope, she knew that she
17999: pledged herself to meet high demands.
18000: 
18001: And on the other side there was a lot where everything seemed easy--but
18002: for the fatal absence of those feelings which, now she had once known
18003: them, it seemed nothing less than a fall and degradation to do without.
18004: With a terrible prescience which a multitude of impressions during her
18005: stay at Transome Court had contributed to form, she saw herself in a
18006: silken bondage that arrested all motive, and was nothing better than a
18007: well-cushioned despair. To be restless amidst ease, to be languid among
18008: all appliances for pleasure, was a possibility that seemed to haunt the
18009: rooms of this house, and wander with her under the oaks and elms of the
18010: park. And Harold Transome's love, no longer a hovering fancy with which
18011: she played, but become a serious fact, seemed to threaten her with a
18012: stifling oppression. The homage of a man may be delightful until he asks
18013: straight for love, by which a woman renders homage. Since she and Felix
18014: had kissed each other in the prison, she felt as if she had vowed
18015: herself away, as if memory lay on her lips like a seal of possession.
18016: Yet what had happened that very evening had strengthened her liking for
18017: Harold, and her care for all that regarded him: it had increased her
18018: repugnance to turning him out of anything he had expected to be his, or
18019: to snatching anything from him on the ground of an arbitrary claim. It
18020: had even made her dread, as a coming pain, the task of saying anything
18021: to him that was not a promise of the utmost comfort under this
18022: newly-disclosed trouble of his.
18023: 
18024: It was already near midnight, but with these thoughts succeeding and
18025: returning in her mind like scenes through which she was living, Esther
18026: had a more intense wakefulness than any she had known by day. All had
18027: been stillness hitherto, except the fitful wind outside. But her ears
18028: now caught a sound within--slight, but sudden. She moved near her door,
18029: and heard the sweep of something on the matting outside. It came closer,
18030: and paused. Then it began again, and seemed to sweep away from her. Then
18031: it approached, and paused as it had done before. Esther listened,
18032: wondering. The same thing happened again and again, till she could bear
18033: it no longer. She opened the door, and in the dim light of the corridor,
18034: where the glass above seemed to make a glimmering sky, she saw Mrs.
18035: Transome's tall figure pacing slowly, with her cheek upon her hand.
18036:

18040: CHAPTER L.
18041: 
18042:     The great question in life is the suffering we cause: and the
18043:     utmost ingenuity of metaphysics cannot justify the man who has
18044:     pierced the heart that loved him.
18045: 
18046:                                                 --BENJAMIN CONSTANT.
18047: 
18048: 
18049: When Denner had gone up to her mistress's room to dress her for dinner,
18050: she had found her seated just as Harold had found her, only with eyelids
18051: drooping and trembling over slowly-rolling tears--nay, with a face in
18052: which every sensitive feature, every muscle, seemed to be quivering with
18053: a silent endurance of some agony.
18054: 
18055: Denner went and stood by the chair a minute without speaking, only
18056: laying her hand gently on Mrs. Transome's. At last she said
18057: beseechingly, "Pray, speak, madam. What has happened?"
18058: 
18059: "The worst, Denner--the worst."
18060: 
18061: "You are ill. Let me undress you, and put you to bed."
18062: 
18063: "No, I am not ill. I am not going to die! I shall live--I shall live!"
18064: 
18065: "What may I do?"
18066: 
18067: "Go and say I shall not dine. Then you may come back, if you will."
18068: 
18069: The patient waiting-woman came back and sat by her mistress in
18070: motionless silence, Mrs. Transome would not let her dress be touched,
18071: and waved away all proffers with a slight movement of her hand. Denner
18072: dared not even light a candle without being told. At last, when the
