18074: 
18075: "Go down, Denner, and find out where Harold is, and come back and tell
18076: me."
18077: 
18078: "Shall I ask him to come to you, madam?"
18079: 
18080: "No; don't dare to do it, if you love me. Come back."
18081: 
18082: Denner brought word that Mr. Harold was in his study, and that Miss Lyon
18083: was with him. He had not dined, but had sent later to ask Miss Lyon to
18084: go into his study.
18085: 
18086: "Light the candles and leave me."
18087: 
18088: "Mayn't I come again?"
18089: 
18090: "No. It may be that my son will come to me."
18091: 
18092: "Mayn't I sleep on the little bed in your bedroom?"
18093: 
18094: "No, good Denner; I am not ill. You can't help me."
18095: 
18096: "That's the hardest word of all, madam."
18097: 
18098: "The time will come--but not now. Kiss me. Now go."
18099: 
18100: The small quiet old woman obeyed, as she had always done. She shrank
18101: from seeming to claim an equal's share in her mistress's sorrow.
18102: 
18103: For two hours Mrs. Transome's mind hung on what was hardly a
18104: hope--hardly more than the listening for a bare possibility. She began
18105: to create the sounds that her anguish craved to hear--began to imagine a
18106: footfall, and a hand upon the door. Then, checked by continual
18107: disappointment, she tried to rouse a truer consciousness by rising from
18108: her seat and walking to her window, where she saw streaks of light
18109: moving and disappearing on the grass, and heard the sound of bolts and
18110: closing doors. She hurried away and threw herself into her seat again,
18111: and buried her head in the deafening down of the cushions. There was no
18112: sound of comfort to her.
18113: 
18114: Then her heart cried out within her against the cruelty of this son.
18115: When he turned from her in the first moment, he had not had time to feel
18116: anything but the blow that had fallen on himself. But afterward--was it
18117: possible that he should not be touched with a son's pity--was it
18118: possible that he should not have been visited by some thought of the
18119: long years through which she had suffered? The memory of those years
18120: came back to her now with a protest against the cruelty that had all
18121: fallen on _her_. She started up with a new restlessness from this spirit
18122: of resistance. She was not penitent. She had borne too hard a
18123: punishment. Always the edge of calamity had fallen on _her_. Who had
18124: felt for her? She was desolate. God had no pity, else her son would not
18125: have been so hard. What dreary future was there after this dreary past?
18126: She, too, looked out into the dim night; but the black boundary of trees
18127: and the long line of the river seemed only part of the loneliness and
18128: monotony of her life.
18129: 
18130: Suddenly she saw a light on the stone balustrades of the balcony that
18131: projected in front of Esther's window, and the flash of a moving candle
18132: falling on a shrub below. Esther was still awake and up. What had Harold
18133: told her--what had passed between them? Harold was fond of this young
18134: creature, who had been always sweet and reverential to her. There was
18135: mercy in her young heart; she might be a daughter who had no impulse to
18136: punish and to strike her whom fate had stricken. On the dim loneliness
18137: before her she seemed to see Esther's gentle look; it was possible still
18138: that the misery of this night might be broken by some comfort. The proud
18139: woman yearned for the caressing pity that must dwell in that young
18140: bosom. She opened her door gently, but when she had reached Esther's she
18141: hesitated. She had never yet in her life asked for compassion--had never
18142: thrown herself in faith on an unproffered love. And she might have gone
18143: on pacing the corridor like an uneasy spirit without a goal, if Esther's
18144: thought, leaping toward her, had not saved her from the need to ask
18145: admission.
18146: 
18147: Mrs. Transome was walking toward the door when it opened. As Esther saw
18148: that image of restless misery, it blent itself by a rapid flash with all
18149: that Harold had said in the evening. She divined that the son's new
18150: trouble must be one with the mother's long sadness. But there was no
18151: waiting. In an instant Mrs. Transome felt Esther's arm round her neck,
18152: and a voice saying softly--
18153: 
18154: "Oh, why didn't you call me before?"
18155: 
18156: They turned hand and hand into the room, and sat down on a sofa at the
18157: foot of the bed. The disordered gray hair--the haggard face--the
18158: reddened eyelids under which the tears seemed to be coming again with
18159: pain, pierced Esther to the heart. A passionate desire to soothe this
18160: suffering woman came over her. She clung round her again, and kissed her
18161: poor quivering lips and eyelids, and laid her young cheek against the
18162: pale and haggard one. Words could not be quick or strong enough to utter
18163: her yearning. As Mrs. Transome felt that soft clinging, she said--
18164: 
18165: "God has some pity on me."
18166: 
18167: "Rest on my bed," said Esther. "You are so tired. I will cover you up
18168: warmly, and then you will sleep."
18169: 
18170: "No--tell me, dear--tell me what Harold said."
18171: 
18172: "That he has had some new trouble."
18173: 
18174: "He said nothing hard about me?"
18175: 
18176: "No--nothing. He did not mention you."
18177: 
18178: "I have been an unhappy woman, dear."
18179: 
18180: "I feared it," said Esther, pressing her gently.
18181: 
18182: "Men are selfish. They are selfish and cruel. What they care for is
18183: their own pleasure and their own pride."
18184: 
18185: "Not all," said Esther, on whom these words fell with a painful jar.
18186: 
18187: "All I have ever loved," said Mrs. Transome. She paused a moment or two,
18188: and then said, "For more than twenty years I have not had an hour's
18189: happiness. Harold knows it, and yet he is hard to me."
18190: 
18191: "He will not be. To-morrow he will not be. I am sure he will be good,"
18192: said Esther, pleadingly. "Remember--he said to me his trouble was
18193: new--he has not had time."
18194: 
18195: "It is too hard to bear, dear," Mrs. Transome said, a new sob rising as
18196: she clung fast to Esther in return. "I am old, and expect so little
18197: now--a very little thing would seem great. Why should I be punished any
18198: more?"
18199: 
18200: Esther found it difficult to speak. The dimly-suggested tragedy of this
18201: woman's life, the dreary waste of years empty of sweet trust and
18202: affection, afflicted her even to horror. It seemed to have come as a
18203: last vision to urge her toward the life where the draughts of joy sprang
18204: from the unchanging fountains of reverence and devout love.
18205: 
18206: But all the more she longed to still the pain of this heart that beat
18207: against hers.
18208: 
18209: "Do let me go to your own room with you, and let me undress you, and let
18210: me tend upon you," she said, with a woman's gentle instinct. "It will be
18211: a very great thing to me. I shall seem to have a mother again. Do let
18212: me."
18213: 
18214: Mrs. Transome yielded at last, and let Esther soothe her with a
18215: daughter's tendance. She was undressed and went to bed; and at last
18216: dozed fitfully, with frequent starts. But Esther watched by her till the
18217: chills of morning came, and then she only wrapped more warmth around
18218: her, and slept fast in the chair till Denner's movement in the room
18219: roused her. She started out of a dream in which she was telling Felix
18220: what had happened to her that night.
18221: 
18222: Mrs. Transome was now in the sounder morning sleep which sometimes
18223: comes after a long night of misery. Esther beckoned Denner into the
18224: dressing-room, and said:
18225: 
18226: "It is late, Mrs. Hickes. Do you think Mr. Harold is out of his room?"
18227: 
18228: "Yes, a long while; he was out earlier than usual."
18229: 
18230: "Will you ask him to come up here? Say I begged you."
18231: 
18232: When Harold entered Esther was leaning against the back of the empty
18233: chair where yesterday he had seen his mother sitting. He was in a state
18234: of wonder and suspense, and when Esther approached him and gave him her
18235: hand, he said, in a startled way--
18236: 
18237: "Good God! how ill you look! Have you been sitting up with my mother?"
18238: 
18239: "Yes. She is asleep now," said Esther. They had merely pressed hands by
18240: way of greeting, and now stood apart looking at each other solemnly.
18241: 
18242: "Has she told you anything?" said Harold.
18243: 
18244: "No, only that she is wretched. Oh, I think I would bear a great deal of
18245: unhappiness to save her from having any more."
18246: 
18247: A painful thrill passed through Harold, and showed itself in his face
18248: with that pale rapid flash which can never be painted. Esther pressed
18249: her hands together, and said, timidly, though it was from an urgent
18250: prompting--
18251: 
18252: "There is nothing in all this place--nothing since ever I came here--I
18253: could care for so much as that you should sit down by her now, and that
18254: she should see you when she wakes."
18255: 
18256: Then with delicate instinct, she added, just laying her hand on his
18257: sleeve, "I know you would have come. I know you meant it. But she is
18258: asleep now. Go gently before she wakes."
18259: 
18260: Harold just laid his right hand for an instant on the back of Esther's
18261: as it rested on his sleeve, and then stepped softly to his mother's
18262: bedside.
18263: 
18264:        *       *       *       *       *
18265: 
18266: An hour afterward, when Harold had laid his mother's pillow afresh, and
18267: sat down again by her, she said--
18268: 
18269: "If that dear thing will marry you, Harold, it will make up to you for a
18270: great deal."
18271: 
18272: But before the day closed Harold knew that this was not to be. That
18273: young presence, which had flitted like a white new-winged dove over all
18274: the saddening relics and new finery of Transome Court, could not find
18275: its home there. Harold heard from Esther's lips that she loved some one
18276: else, and that she resigned all claim to the Transome estates. She
18277: wished to go back to her father.
18278: 
18279: 
18280: 
18281: 
18282: CHAPTER LI.
18283: 
18284:     The maiden said, I wis the londe
18285:       Is very fair to see,
18286:     But my true-love that is in bonde
18287:       Is fairer still to me.
18288: 
18289: 
18290: One April day, when the sun shone on the lingering raindrops, Lyddy was
18291: gone out, and Esther chose to sit in the kitchen, in the wicker-chair
18292: against the white table, between the fire and the window. The kettle was
18293: singing, and the clock was ticking steadily toward four o'clock.
18294: 
18295: She was not reading, but stitching; and as her fingers moved nimbly,
18296: something played about her parted lips like a ray. Suddenly she laid
18297: down her work, pressed her hands together on her knees, and bent forward
18298: a little. The next moment there came a loud rap at the door. She started
18299: up and opened it, but kept herself hidden behind it.
18300: 
18301: "Mr. Lyon at home?" said Felix, in his firm tones.
18302: 
18303: "No, sir," said Esther from behind her screen; "but Miss Lyon is, if
18304: you'll please to walk in."
18305: 
18306: "Esther!" exclaimed Felix, amazed.
18307: 
18308: They held each other by both hands, and looked into each other's faces
18309: with delight.
18310: 
18311: "You are out of prison?"
18312: 
18313: "Yes, till I do something bad again. But you?--how is it all?"
18314: 
18315: "Oh, it is," said Esther, smiling brightly as she moved toward the
18316: wicker chair, and seated herself again, "that everything is as usual: my
18317: father is gone to see the sick; Lyddy is gone in deep despondency to buy
18318: the grocery; and I am sitting here, with some vanity in me, needing to
18319: be scolded."
18320: 
18321: Felix had seated himself on a chair that happened to be near her, at the
18322: corner of the table. He looked at her still with questioning eyes--he
18323: grave, she mischievously smiling.
18324: 
18325: "Are you come back to live here then?"
18326: 
18327: "Yes."
18328: 
18329: "You are not going to be married to Harold Transome, or to be rich?"
18330: 
18331: "No." Something made Esther take up her work again, and begin to stitch.
18332: The smiles were dying into a tremor.
18333: 
18334: "Why?" said Felix, in rather a low tone, leaning his elbow on the table,
18335: and resting his head on his hand while he looked at her.
18336: 
18337: "I did not wish to marry him, or to be rich."
18338: 
18339: "You have given it all up?" said Felix, leaning forward a little, and
18340: speaking in a still lower tone. Esther did not speak. They heard the
18341: kettle singing and the clock loudly ticking. There was no knowing how it
18342: was: Esther's work fell, their eyes met; and the next instant their arms
18343: were round each other's necks, and once more they kissed each other.
18344: 
18345: When their hands fell again, their eyes were bright with tears. Felix
18346: laid his hand on her shoulder.
18347: 
18348: "Could you share the life of a poor man, then, Esther?"
18349: 
18350: "If I thought well enough of him," she said, the smile coming again,
18351: with the pretty saucy movement of her head.
18352: 
18353: "Have you considered well what it would be?--that it would be a very
18354: bare and simple life?"
18355: 
18356: "Yes--without atta of rose."
18357: 
18358: Felix suddenly removed his hand from her shoulder, rose from his chair,
18359: and walked a step or two; then he turned round and said, with deep
18360: gravity--
18361: 
18362: "And the people I shall live among, Esther? They have not just the same
18363: follies and vices as the rich, but they have their own forms of folly
18364: and vice; and they have not what are called the refinements of the rich
18365: to make their faults more bearable. I don't say more bearable to me--I'm
18366: not fond of those refinements; but you are."
18367: 
18368: Felix paused an instant, and then added--
18369: 
18370: "It is very serious, Esther."
18371: 
18372: "I know it is serious," said Esther, looking up at him. "Since I have
18373: been at Transome Court I have seen many things very seriously. If I had
18374: not, I should not have left what I did leave. I made a deliberate
18375: choice."
18376: 
18377: Felix stood a moment or two, dwelling on her with a face where the
18378: gravity gathered tenderness.
18379: 
18380: "And these curls?" he said, with a sort of relenting, seating himself
18381: again, and putting his hand on them.
18382: 
18383: "They cost nothing--they are natural."
18384: 
18385: "You are such a delicate creature."
18386: 
18387: "I am very healthy. Poor women, I think, are healthier than the rich.
18388: Besides," Esther went on, with a mischievous meaning, "I think of having
18389: some wealth."
18390: 
18391: "How?" said Felix, with an anxious start. "What do you mean?"
18392: 
18393: "I think even of two pounds a week: one needn't live up to the splendor
18394: of all that, you know; we might live as simply as you liked: there would
18395: be money to spare, and you could do wonders, and be obliged to work too,
18396: only not if sickness came. And then I think of a little income for your
18397: mother, enough for her to live as she has been used to live; and a
18398: little income for my father, to save him from being dependent when he is
18399: no longer able to preach."
18400: 
18401: Esther said all this in a playful tone, but she ended, with a grave look
18402: of appealing submission----
18403: 
18404: "I mean--if you approve. I wish to do what you think it will be right to
18405: do."
18406: 
18407: Felix put his hand on her shoulder again and reflected a little while,
18408: looking on the hearth: then he said, lifting up his eyes, with a smile
18409: at her----
18410: 
18411: "Why, I shall be able to set up a great library, and lend the books to
18412: be dog's-eared and marked with bread-crumbs."
18413: 
18414: Esther said, laughing, "You think you are to be everything. You don't
18415: know how clever I am. I mean to go on teaching a great many things."
18416: 
18417: "Teaching me?"
18418: 
18419: "Oh, yes," she said, with a little toss; "I shall improve your French
18420: accent."
18421: 
18422: "You won't want me to wear a stock," said Felix, with a defiant shake of
18423: the head.
18424: 
18425: "No; and you will not attribute stupid thoughts to me before I've
18426: uttered them."
18427: 
18428: They laughed merrily, each holding the other's arms, like girl and boy.
18429: There was the ineffable sense of youth in common.
18430: 
18431: Then Felix leaned forward, that their lips might meet again, and after
18432: that his eyes roved tenderly over her face and curls.
18433: 
18434: "I'm a rough, severe fellow, Esther. Shall you never repent?--never be
18435: inwardly reproaching me that I was not a man who could have shared your
18436: wealth? Are you quite sure?"
18437: 
18438: "Quite sure!" said Esther, shaking her head; "for then I should have
18439: honored you less. I am weak--my husband must be greater and nobler than
18440: I am."
18441: 
18442: "Oh, I tell you what, though!" said Felix, starting up, thrusting his
18443: hands into his pockets, and creasing his brow playfully, "if you take me
18444: in that way I shall be forced to be a much better fellow than I ever
18445: thought of being."
18446: 
18447: "I call that retribution," said Esther, with a laugh as sweet as the
18448: morning thrush.
18449: 
18450: 
18451: 
18452: 
18453: EPILOGUE.
18454: 
18455:     Our finest hope is finest memory;
18456:     And those who love in age think youth is happy,
18457:     Because it has a life to fill with love.
18458: 
18459: 
18460: The very next May, Felix and Esther were married. Every one in those
18461: days was married at the parish church; but Mr. Lyon was not satisfied
18462: without an additional private solemnity, "wherein there was no bondage
18463: to questionable forms, so that he might have a more enlarged utterance
18464: of joy and supplication."
18465: 
18466: It was a very simple wedding; but no wedding, even the gayest, ever
18467: raised so much interest and debate in Treby Magna. Even very great
18468: people, like Sir Maximus and his family, went to the church to look at
18469: this bride, who had renounced wealth, and chosen to be the wife of a man
18470: who said he would always be poor.
18471: 
18472: Some few shook their heads; could not quite believe it; and thought
18473: there was "more behind." But the majority of honest Trebians were
18474: affected somewhat in the same way as happy-looking Mr. Wace was, who
18475: observed to his wife, as they walked from under the churchyard
18476: chestnuts, "It's wonderful how things go through you--you don't know
18477: how. I feel somehow as if I believed more in everything that's good."
18478: 
18479: Mrs. Holt, that day, said she felt herself to be receiving "some
18480: reward," implying that justice certainly had much more in reserve.
18481: Little Job Tudge had an entirely new suit, of which he fingered every
18482: separate brass button in a way that threatened an arithmetical mania;
18483: and Mrs. Holt had out her best tea-trays and put down her carpet again,
18484: with the satisfaction of thinking that there would no more be boys
18485: coming in all weathers with dirty shoes.
18486: 
18487: For Felix and Esther did not take up their abode in Treby Magna; and
18488: after a while Mr. Lyon left the town too, and joined them where they
18489: dwelt. On his resignation the church in Malthouse Yard chose a successor
18490: to him whose doctrine was rather higher.
18491: 
18492: There were other departures from Treby. Mr. Jermyn's establishment was
18493: broken up, and he was understood to have gone to reside at a great
18494: distance: some said "abroad," that large home of ruined reputations. Mr.
18495: Johnson continued blond and sufficiently prosperous till he got gray
18496: and rather more prosperous. Some persons who did not think highly of
18497: him, held that his prosperity was a fact to be kept in the background,
18498: as being dangerous to the morals of the young; judging that it was not
18499: altogether creditable to the Divine Providence that anything but virtue
18500: should be rewarded by a front and back drawing-room in Bedford Row.
18501: 
18502: As for Mr. Christian, he had no more profitable secrets at his disposal.
18503: But he got his thousand pounds from Harold Transome.
18504: 
18505: The Transome family were absent some time from Transome Court. The place
18506: was kept up and shown to visitors, but not by Denner, who was away with
18507: her mistress. After a while the family came back, and Mrs. Transome died
18508: there. Sir Maximus was at her funeral, and throughout that neighborhood
18509: there was silence about the past.
18510: 
18511: Uncle Lingon continued to watch over the shooting on the Manor and the
18512: covers until that event occurred which he had predicted as a part of
18513: Church reform sure to come. Little Treby had a new rector, but others
18514: were sorry besides the old pointers.
18515: 
18516: As to all that wide parish of Treby Magna, it has since prospered as the
18517: rest of England has prospered. Doubtless there is more enlightenment
18518: now. Whether the farmers are all public-spirited, the shopkeepers nobly
18519: independent, the Sproxton men entirely sober and judicious, the
18520: Dissenters quite without narrowness or asperity in religion and
18521: politics, and the publicans all fit, like Gaius, to be the friends of an
18522: apostle--these things I have not heard; not having correspondence in
18523: those parts. Whether any presumption may be drawn from the fact that
18524: North Loamshire does not yet return a Radical candidate, I leave to the
18525: all-wise--I mean the newspapers.
18526: 
18527: As to the town in which Felix Holt now resides, I will keep that a
18528: secret, lest he should be troubled by any visitor having the
18529: insufferable motive of curiosity.
18530: 
18531: I will only say that Esther has never repented. Felix, however, grumbles
18532: a little that she has made his life too easy, and that, if it were not
18533: for much walking, he should be a sleek dog.
18534: 
18535: There is a young Felix, who has a great deal more science than his
18536: father, but not much more money.
18537: 
18538: 
18539: THE END.
